title: Frequency Response Model for Power Systems Including HVDC-Connected Offshore Wind Power With Communication-Free Frequency Control
authors: Jinpeng Guo, Wenhao Li, Xueping Pan, Jinhai Zheng, Ningyu Zhang, Yuqiao Jia, Xiaorong Sun, Yuyi Kuang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: This paper develops a system frequency response (SFR) model and proposes a control parameter design strategy, accounting for the communication-free frequency support of offshore wind farm (OWF) connected through high voltage direct current (HVDC) transmission system. By incorporating the power dynamics of OWF and HVDC during frequency disturbance, the traditional SFR model is extended to quantitatively evaluate the contribution of HVDC-connected OWF to onshore grid frequency dynamics. Furthermore, the control parameters to provide frequency support are optimally designed based on the extended SFR model by considering constraints on wind turbine power variation and DC voltage fluctuation. Compared to the works relying on detailed simulations, the salient novelty of the paper lies in the fast and accurate system performance analysis and control parameter design, ensuring efficiency and practicality for real-world applications. Comprehensive case studies in the PSCAD/EMTDC and the MATLAB/SIMULINK platforms demonstrate that the system frequency response characteristics can be evaluated accurately and improved significantly while satisfying the operational constraints.

title: End-to-End Resource Allocation and V2X-Assisted Motion Planning: A Learning-Based Optimization Framework
authors: Wenbo Hu, Hongfeng Wang, Hao Zhang, Junwei Wang
abstract: This study proposes a roadside unit (RSU)-enabled autonomous driving framework addressing occlusion challenges through global state awareness and dynamic resource co-optimization. The methodology resolves two interconnected problems: (1) navigation reliability degradation caused by occluded road users, and (2) communication resource allocation inefficiency in high-mobility vehicle-to-everything (V2X) networks. A three-tier technical architecture is developed: (a) RSU-assisted environmental state estimation that fuses infrastructure-side perception with vehicular status to mitigate occlusion-induced uncertainty, (b) joint communication-planning optimization via a differentiable end-to-end framework, unifying motion control and resource allocation decisions, and (c) distributed motion planning with latency-aware safety verification, ensuring real-time feasibility through edge-assisted pipeline optimization. Experimental results demonstrate superior performance in occlusion-rich scenarios compared to existing V2X-dependent approaches, achieving balanced improvement in task completion rates and communication overhead reduction. The framework maintains operational robustness under varying traffic densities while ensuring real-time computational feasibility through edge-assisted pipeline optimization.

title: Impact of Solder Joint Design Profile on the Reliability of QFN Packages
authors: Unique Rahangdale, Rishikesh Tendulkar, Sai Abhideep Pundla, Dereje Agonafer
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Quad Flat No-lead package (QFN) is one of the cutting-edge technologies emerged in the market, exhibiting high performance and efficiency with unparalleled cost effectiveness. QFN, a leadless package, is an ideal choice for applications where size, weight thermal and electrical characteristics are critical, particularly in mobile and handheld devices. Applications like automotive, defense and high current circuits require the package to be mounted on thick printed circuit boards (PCB). The motivation of this work is to understand the effect of design variations of solder joints affecting reliability and optimize the solder package to improve reliability for application on different PCBs. Initially, the material properties of the PCBs were determined using Thermal Mechanical Analyzer (TMA), Dynamic Mechanical Analyzer (DMA). The PCBs were then cross sectioned to find the layer composition and Copper content in the boards. Different designs of solder joints were made using ANSYS Space Claim. The quarter models of boards with the different solder designs were then subjected to Accelerated Thermal Cycling Tests, to study stresses generated on the solder joints and variation in Plastic work. A comparative study was performed on obtained results for different solder designs and on different PCB boards to propose the optimum solder design to reduce solder damage and increased life in QFN assemblies.

title: Exploring Social Dynamics through Multi-User Virtual and Augmented Reality Serious Games for Stroke Rehabilitation
authors: Sérgio Oliveira, Bernardo Marques, Paula Amorim, Inês Figueiredo, Bianca Guerreiro, David Palricas, Samuel Silva, Paulo Dias, Beatriz Sousa Santos
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Social interaction is a fundamental aspect of human dynamics, influencing communication, emotional well-being, and everyday activities. Yet, many conventional stroke rehabilitation methods tend to overlook this crucial element, focusing primarily on repetitive, individual exercises. These may lead to disengagement, reduced motivation, and slower recovery, highlighting the need for more socially enriched rehabilitation approaches. This work proposes a collection of multi-user eXtended Reality (XR) serious games designed to assist stroke rehabilitation. Developed with guidance from healthcare professionals using a Human-Centered Design (HCD) methodology, the games promote physical and cognitive recovery while emphasizing social interaction among stroke survivors. By dynamically transitioning between immersive to augmented environments (i.e., Virtual to Augmented Reality (VR/AR) and vice-versa), the games used offer a stimulating experience. Initial findings confirmed the functionality and user acceptance of the games, with participants responding positively to the engaging nature and social aspects, offering valuable feedback to guide future enhancements.

title: GenLinguaScape: Enabling User-Defined VR Scenarios for Communicative Language Practice
authors: Ruoyu Wen, Qiaomin Li, Wei Pu, Rui Mu, Alaeddin Nassani, Simon Hoermann, Mark Billinghurst, Thammathip Piumsomboon
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We present GenLinguaScape, an adaptive system for communicative language teaching that uses generative AI to create immersive, customisable practice scenarios. In a formative study with six participants, three English learners and three language-teaching specialists, we explored user experience, perceived learning value and avenues for system improvement.

title: A Multi-Component AI-NLP Driven Platform for Intelligent Student Placement Prediction and Personalized Career Development
authors: Gali Ramesh Kumar, Adina Karunasri
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Insufficient interview preparation, a lack of specialized advice and a mismatch between the requirements of the job and the candidate frequently delay the student placement process. This work suggests an Intelligent Selection and Career Planning Platform that combines artificial intelligence (AI) and natural language processing (NLP) to address these problems. The system includes several modules: K Nearest Neighbors (KNN 89% accuracy) and Logistic Regression (95% accuracy) for Resume Screening; BERT for Candidate Matching for context alignment; Random Forest for Placement Prediction which achieves 99.87% accuracy and TFIDF and Cosine Similarity for Interview Preparation. Additionally, NLP driven quizzes offer dynamic skill evaluation and a YouTube API-based course suggests content using BERT sentiment analysis (96.7% accuracy). All modules show excellent precision in the results ensuring reliable performance for applications in real time. All things taken into account, the platform helps marketers and students connect by providing data-driven insights, customized suggestions and improved employability results.

title: A Lightweight Neural Network Approach for MOSFET Remaining Useful Life Prediction
authors: Wanli Qin, Guansong Xiong
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: To meet the health management requirements of aerospace missions and considering the operating characteristics of Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor Field-Effect Transistors (MOSFETs) under computational resource constraints, this paper proposes a remaining useful life (RUL) prediction method based on the integration of a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) and a Variational Autoencoder (VAE). The GRU is employed to model the temporal evolution of device operating features and predict degradation trends, while the VAE performs latent-space modeling and reconstruction-error quantification of degradation states, thereby enabling both quantitative RUL estimation and uncertainty characterization. In degradation trend prediction, the GRU is compared with the Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks. The results show that the GRU significantly outperforms EKF in accuracy and achieves performance comparable to LSTM, while requiring only about three-quarters of the parameters and slightly higher inference speed, highlighting its lightweight nature. By combining historical operating data with GRU predictions, the VAE effectively captures latent features of the degradation process and quantifies the degree of degradation through reconstruction error, thus enabling robust RUL estimation with uncertainty analysis. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed lightweight neural network achieves a root-mean-square error below 0.003 for degradation prediction and an average error of less than 10% for RUL estimation. The model consistently tracks the overall degradation trend and maintains high accuracy with minimal computational overhead, indicating strong potential for deployment in resource-constrained end devices.

title: Analyzing the Characteristics of Strain-Induced SiNW Super-lattice pin Based Single-Pole-Single Throw Series-shunt and Shunt Switch at THz frequency
authors: Moumita Chakraborty, Rupanwita Das Mahapatra, Abhijit Kundu, Saunak Bhattacharya, Arijit Dutta, Moumita Mukherjee
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: This study presents the potentiality of strain-induced SiNW super-lattice p+-i-n+ based Single-Pole-Single throw series-shunt and shunt SPST switching operation at THz-frequency region. In order to develop the SiNW, strained and unstrained Si layers are alternately incorporated into the device's active region. The strained Si layers are formed by the amalgamation of a 2% Ge mole fraction into the unstrained or intrinsic Si layer. The induced strain significantly enhances the effective-mobility of the electron which plays a vital role in the device's performance. The switching features of the designed THz switch have been investigated by employing the self-reliable Quantum Corrected Charge-Carrier Transport model along with PSpice software. The proposed Quantum Corrected Charge- Carrier Transport model has been verified through the experimental findings under almost identical operation circumstances.

title: Enabling Resilient and Secure 5G Architectures: An Evaluation of Deep Learning and Metaheuristic Optimization Solutions
authors: Reshma. P, R. Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The quick rollout of 5 G networks creates a complicated environment with changing traffic, security needs and real-time service requirements for a range of applications, such as telemedicine and industrial automation. Ensuring resilience, security, availability and dependability becomes crucial as these networks support more and more vital infrastructure. This survey provides an in-depth analysis of Deep Learning (DL) techniques used to address key 5G issues such traffic classification, network slicing, mobility management, resource allocation, and physical layer security. Also, the optimisation algorithms, such as met heuristic like Genetic Algorithm (GA), Particle Swarm Optimisation (PSO) and Ant Colony Optimisation (ACO) to optimise DL models for improved network performance. Enabling technologies including secure identities, AI-assisted autonomous defence mechanisms and confidential computing that facilitate reliable 5G networks are given particular attention. The presented articles also examine the unresolved issues in verifiable trust, traceable decision-making, and the contribution of AI to end-toend system integrity. For researchers and industry professionals working to create reliable, safe and intelligent 5 G infrastructures for upcoming digital ecosystems, this article seeks to be an invaluable resource.

title: Design and Practice of Digital Learning Path Optimization Algorithm Based on Reinforcement Learning
authors: Jiajun Chen, Jie Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Digital learning platforms often employ static path designs, lacking dynamic adaptation to individual learners' needs, which reduces efficiency and resource utilization. This study addresses the challenge of delivering personalized learning experiences through real-time path optimization. We propose a reinforcement learning-based framework incorporating a multidimensional state space (cognitive, behavioral, and knowledge dimensions) and a reward mechanism guided by a course knowledge graph. The Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) algorithm is enhanced with a hierarchical attention mechanism and a course-guided exploration strategy to improve path relevance and convergence. Experiments demonstrate that our method achieves a personalization score of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 8 5}$</tex>, outperforming A3C (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 7 2}$</tex>) and DQN (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 7 0}$</tex>). It converges faster (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 0. 0 9}$</tex> steps on average) and improves mastery of high-difficulty knowledge modules by 77.0 %, compared to 61.9 % (A3C) and 58.2 % (DQN). The algorithm enables dynamic, personalized learning path optimization with high efficiency and adaptability. Future work will explore cross-domain applicability and federated learning extensions.

title: Grid-Connected PV Array and Battery Storage-Based EV Charging Station Using FOPID Control Strategy
authors: Venkata Pavan Kumar Arapirala, C Kamal Basha, R Vineela, P Kavyasree, Y Pavani, V Pranay Teja Reddy
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: This paper presents a grid-connected electric vehicle (EV) charging station that integrates a photovoltaic (PV) array and a battery energy storage system (BESS). It employs a Fractional-Order Proportional-Integral-Derivative (FOPID) control strategy to optimize power flow and improve system efficiency. The proposed system reduces grid dependency, maximizes renewable energy use, and stabilizes power quality. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the FOPID controller in enhancing system stability, voltage regulation, and overall performance when compared to conventional PID controllers. This research contributes to the development of sustainable and efficient EV charging infrastructure.

title: Hybrid Fault Diagnosis Methodology for SEIG Stand Alone Systems
authors: Victoria Herrera, Jesus Andrade Romero
abstract: The self-excited induction generator (SEIG) is widely used in power generation due to its low cost and high reliability. However, electrical and load disturbances can lead to fault conditions, resulting in power losses and reduced lifetime. This paper analyzes the behavior of SEIGs under electrical fault conditions and proposes a hybrid fault diagnosis methodology, considering both model-based and signal-based approaches. The proposed methodology uses an electrical fault condition SEIG model to define a feature vector based on wavelet transform and power quality indicators. After developing numerical simulations of the fault condition model, fault classes are defined based on the selected feature vector. To validate the proposed diagnosis methodology, an experimental setup with a low-power electric machine configured for the studied fault electric conditions was employed.

title: System for Recording and Validation of Eye-Based Biometry Models in the Wild
authors: Norbert Barczyk, Kamil Koniuch, Artur Stefańczyk, Michał Maj, Mateusz Olszewski, Lucjan Janowski
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: This research demo presents a system integrating eye movement-based biometric models with the Unity environment. Using the "Eye Know You Too" model, we authorize players in a VR multiplayer lobby, enabling seamless user authentication. Our solution is adaptable to various Unity-based games and compatible with diverse eye movement models. In this demo, participants use their eye movement data for embeddings during free VR exploration and verify classification accuracy for themselves and their partners. Systems like ours are essential for enabling secure, non-intrusive biometry in VR environments and can serve as a safeguard against spoofing attacks.

title: Enhancing Power-Dense and Reliability-Oriented Heat Sink Structures through Additive Manufacturing for Power Electronics in Aviation Applications
authors: Jannes Kai Briese, Hendrik Schefer, Lukas Radomsky, Robert Keilmann, Regine Mallwitz
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: The electrification of aircraft represents a viable approach to achieving decarbonization in the aviation sector. In substituting combustion-driven propulsion systems, an increased required power-to-weight ratio and high fault-tolerance expectations challenge this transition. The environmental conditions in 6000 m, the high required power density, and the high required reliability challenge the heat sink design. Most failure mechanisms in the field of power electronics are temperature-dependent. Nevertheless, the heat sink weight and the available hydraulic power limit design factors. Thus, effective cooling strengthens the reliability of power electronics and increases aircraft safety. With the help of additive manufacturing (AM) and genetic algorithms (GA), a compromise can be found between heat transfer, pressure drop, weight, and temperature spreading. How does such an additively manufactured heat sink perform compared to well-established baseplate (BP) designs based on Pin Fins or jet impingement? Can a genetic algorithm optimize an entire BP close to the application? This investigation uses a genetic optimization approach of a triply periodic minimal surface structure. A multi-criteria optimization finds the optimal BP design based on the mentioned objectives. A proof of concept is presented by discussing the feasibility of BP design for a two-level and three-level module.

title: Multimodal Brain-Computer Interfaces Using Cross-Modal Transformer Fusion Framework
authors: Supriya Lenka, Sateesh Kumar Pradhan, Zabiha Khan, Priyabrata Sahu, Suvendu Kumar Jena
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Recently, the Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCIs) are emerging as an important tool for neurorehabilitation, cognitive monitoring and human-machine interaction where the multimodal integration of neural signals improves system robustness. Among these available modalities, the Electroencephalography (EEG) provides high temporal resolution while functional Near-Infrared Spectroscopy (fNIRS) captures complementary hemodynamic responses. However, the existing methods often depends on decision-level fusion which fails to fully exploit the deep cross-modal relationships between EEG and fNIRS. Hence, this research proposes Crossattention Transformer-based Fusion Framework (CTFF) for more effective multimodal representation. Initially, the input data is collected from EEG-fNIRS dataset which contains synchronized multimodal brain data. Then, the collected data is preprocessed with Independent Component Analysis (ICA) and Band-Pass Filter (BPF) to remove non-neural artifacts and isolate task-related signals respectively. Further, the modalityspecific encoders are trained with contrastive pretraining to learn robust latent embeddings and align modalities in a shared space. After that, an intermediate fusion stage employs a crossattention transformer to capture temporal dependencies and nonlinear interactions across modalities. Finally, the pooled fused features are classified through a Deep Neural Network (DNN) with auxiliary losses for generalization and uncertainty estimation. The proposed CTFF achieved better results in terms of accuracy (99.89 %) than existing Schizophrenia Diagnosis Framework (Schizo-Net) model.

title: Performance Evaluation of Elasticsearch for Big Data Search in Digital Cultural Heritage Collections
authors: Khin Chan Myae Ko Ko, Zaw Htet Paing, Kaung Khant Kyaw, Aye Chan Mon
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: The digitization of cultural heritage produces massive, heterogeneous datasets that require scalable big data solutions for storage, integration, and search. This paper focuses on optimizing Elasticsearch for archival search tasks, using MongoDB as a reference point for comparison. Data from The Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Harvard Art Museums were integrated through a modular Extract, Transform, Load process, ensuring schema consistency and clean indexing. The tests compared MongoDB regex queries with optimized Elasticsearch configurations, including replacing wildcard queries with match phrase prefix and introducing sharding for distributed execution. Results show that this optimization reduced query latency by up to 82% and improved relevance through linguistic analysis and prefix matching. The findings confirm that proper query design and distributed indexing significantly enhance search speed and scalability for cultural heritage collections, and they can also guide performance tuning in other big-data retrieval domains.

title: Research on Optimal Control Strategy of ANPC Carrier Overlapping Based on Modulating Wave Offset
authors: Yiming Wang, Po Xu, Haohui Yuan, Daming Huang, Kun Xia, Jingxia Wang
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: When designing an inverter based on active neutral point clamped (ANPC), the floating capacitor in the topology is a complex area to control. Using the traditional carrier cascade modulation strategy to control the floating capacitor will lead to a sudden change in the floating capacitor voltage at the carrier junction. Although the carrier overlap modulation strategy can solve the problem of levitated capacitor voltage jumping, its control strategy will increase harmonics in the output voltage and current. Given the above issues, this paper optimizes the carrier overlapping method to inhibit the jumping of the floating capacitor voltage at the carrier junction without increasing the harmonics of the output voltage and current significantly. In this paper, the theoretical feasibility of the scheme is verified by simulation, after which an experimental platform is built. The simulation and experiment results prove that the capacitor voltage fluctuation of this scheme is reduced by 38% compared with the carrier cascade, which indicates that this scheme has a particular engineering value.

title: Design and Implementation of a Wireless Data Acquisition System with LoRa Communication for Monitoring Photovoltaic Power Plants
authors: Geyse Mirelle Rezende Brito, Arthur Ichiro Moreira Manabe, Flávio de Castro Alves Filho, Carlos Victor Pinheiro Targino, Marcel Veloso Campos, Leandro Tiago Manera, Tárcio André dos Santos Barros
abstract: Monitoring solarimetric stations enables the tracking of key variables essential to the performance of photovoltaic (PV) plants, facilitating the early detection of faults and anomalies. When properly implemented, such monitoring enhances maintenance efficiency and can significantly reduce associated costs. The development of a wireless data acquisition system using LoRa communication presents notable advantages over conventional monitoring solutions currently used in PV plants. These benefits include easier sensor replacement, real-time data monitoring, integrated battery backup, solar-powered operation, ease of transport and deployment, and a compact, cost-effective design compared to traditional systems.

title: Dynamic Gimmick Learning for Navigation Agents in Social VR Through User-Agent Dialogue
authors: Atsuya Matsumoto, Hikari Yanagawa, Yuichi Hiroi, Yuji Hatada, Takuji Narumi, Takefumi Hiraki
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: User-generated interactive mechanisms ("gimmicks") in metaverse platforms offer unique experiences, but their complexity hinders player exploration. Existing navigation agents, reliant on static metadata, cannot comprehend these dynamic gimmicks. We propose the "Conversational Knowledge Acquisition Loop," a method for agents to dynamically learn gimmicks through player conversation. A preliminary study showed that our agent successfully acquired knowledge via conversation and applied it to solve analogous gimmicks.

title: Evaluating Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models for PET Denoising: A Critical Analysis in a Limited Data Regime
authors: Bram Popelier, Ide Van den Borre, Simon DeKeyser, Vic De Ridder, Aleksandra Pižurica
publish: 2025 13th European Workshop on Visual Information Processing (EUVIP)
abstract: Positron Emission Tomography (PET) is a key imaging technique in clinical practice offering unique functional insights. However, its broader applicability is limited by radiation exposure and lengthy scan times, and reducing either degrades image quality by increasing noise. Over recent years, U-Net-based convolutional neural networks have become dominant approaches for PET denoising. These methods show good performance in denoising, but they offer limited uncertainty handling due to their deterministic nature and are prone to oversmoothing. This paper critically evaluates the applicability of denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs) for low-dose PET image denoising, particularly when training data is limited. We adapted a conditional DDPM architecture to the PET context and compared its performance to a U-Net baseline on clinical PET data. The conditional DDPM was both deployed as a standalone method and in a hybrid-ensemble format where it was placed in series with the baseline U-Net. The conditional DDPM, while promising in theory, introduced unrealistic features in some outputs and was computationally intensive. The hybrid model, intended to combine both strengths, underperformed due to high sample variability in DDPM outputs. Contrary to recent studies suggesting DDPM superiority, our experiments demonstrate that DDPMs underperform relative to U-Net, showing inferior PSNR and SSIM and introducing notable artifacts. Our findings highlight the importance of training dataset size and quality for DDPM effectiveness and provide practical guidelines regarding the trustworthiness of diffusion models for clinical PET denoising.

title: Foot Length Measuring System Using OpenCV and ResNet50
authors: Archa Satheish, Sania Jimmy, Sanjana, Shinto Thomas, Renjith Thomas
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Footwear purchases made online tend to have high return rates because of improper selection of size, mainly resulting from variable measurements of foot length. For this, we propose a web-based smartphone-based foot length measurement system involving OpenCV for preprocessing and a five-Rupee coin as a reference object. A U-Net model is applied for segmentation of the foot, followed by a ResNet50-based regression model for the estimation of foot length along with dynamic pixel-tometric scaling. The system then maps the length into US, UK, and EU shoe sizes, providing real-time recommendations on the client side. Experimental verification on varying image conditions resulted in a mean absolute error (MAE) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 2 m m}$</tex> with respect to manual measurements, proving near-manual accuracy and high reliability. The suggested system is scalable, economical, and applicable for e-commerce websites.

title: Self-Adaptive Artificial Intelligence System for Context-Aware Problem Solving and Data-Driven Decision Optimization
authors: Nagendra Rao Madugula, Nader Mohammad Aljawarneh, Kaustubh G. Kulkarni, Namita Kalita, Sajiv. G, Ponni Valavan M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The present need for real-time optimization and choices makes standard AI systems hard to adjust when facing ambiguous situations. The path optimization and problemsolving software tool ACO shows widespread use however it encounters premature convergence issues as well as flexibility restrictions. Fuzzy logic handles uncertainties effectively yet it does not have strong learning abilities or optimization methods. The presented research creates a new self-adaptive AI system by uniting ACO with fuzzy logic for enhancing decision-making abilities which adapt to changing environmental conditions. Through the proposed hybrid model the pheromone updating bounds operate using fuzzy-controlled mechanisms alongside probabilistic selection methods that automatically modify evaporation parameters and selection weights through the detection of live environmental conditions. The approach improves both exploration-exploitation equilibrium and problem-solving speed together with solution efficiency. The system undergoes evaluation through benchmarking that matches traditional ACO and alternative optimization algorithms while showing maximal accuracy levels and excellent adaptability features and computational efficiency outcomes. Real-life applications of the fuzzy logic-based ACO system are demonstrated in logistics as well as healthcare and IoT-based decision systems and these applications show its feasibility at different scales. Experimental tests validate that fuzzy logicbased advancements in ACO promote outstanding results in highly complex situations combined with dynamic problem spaces. The research demonstrates how combinatorial AI methods can autonomously learn while optimizing real-time operations which creates the foundation for future AI-driven choice systems across multiple industrial sectors.

title: Online Optimization of Robust Polarized Beamforming for Smart Skin Antenna Array
authors: Zhibin Chen, Zhikun Chen, Yuxi Zhu, Jingchao You
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: The smart skin antenna integrates with the carrier height, and polarization provides refined recognition capabilities, both of which combine to achieve maximum aperture and improved degrees of freedom. However, the beam performance of skin antenna depends on strain measurement data, and real-time monitoring will introduce errors, causing steering vector mismatches that degrade beam performance and polarization accuracy. To address this challenge, an online optimization method is proposed to achieve robust polarized beamforming in smart skin antenna array. The strain measurement data is used to develop a reconfigurable antenna model online via the modal method. Building on this foundation, the improved feature subspace (IFS) method estimates the actual steering vector in real-time. The estimated steering vector is then integrated with second-order cone programming (SOCP) algorithm to achieve online optimal robust polarized beamforming for smart skin array. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method not only enables real-time reconstruction of the optimal robust polarized beamforming but also significantly improves the overall performance of the smart skin array. The optimizations in beamwidth, pattern gain, and polarization matching exceed those of previous studies, highlighting the engineering potential of smart skin arrays in robust polarized beamforming.

title: A Visualization-Based Approach to Bodily Sensation Awareness using AR and LLM-generated Meditation Guidance
authors: Soi Choi, Jean Ho Chu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: This work presents an augmented reality (AR) meditation system that visualizes internal bodily sensations through circular objects mapped to key body joints. Using MediaPipe, the system tracks pose and hand gestures to enable users to adjust chakra-like visual elements via pinch gestures, reflecting changes in bodily attention. A local large language model (LLM, Ollama) generates meditation prompts, which are then converted to speech via TTS. These components create a layered experience in which the body informs visual interaction and language guidance supports sustained inward focus, offering an embodied meditation environment that bridges somatic awareness with reflection.

title: Augmented Reality for Operating Room Equipment Placement with Real-time Feedback
authors: Hyunggu Jung, Seungjun Chong, Duhyung Kwak, Minh Do Ngoc Luong, Hyeonmin Choi, Minju Kim, Yunseo Moon, Chaeyoung Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Operating room (OR) equipment misplacement errors compromise patient safety and surgical outcomes. Ensuring precise and efficient positioning of OR equipment is therefore crucial to minimizing infection risks and reducing operative time. To address this challenge, we developed an augmented reality (AR) application that integrates a fine-tuned YOLOv11 object detection model with Gemini for standardizing surgical titles. Our system utilizes AR to visualize optimal operating table position and provides AI-driven placement feedback within the OR environment in a time-critical scenario. This novel approach reduces cognitive burden on OR nurses and enhances patient safety through AR-based automated feedback.

title: Innovation as a Bridge: Enhancing Undergraduate Nursing Education through International Collaborations
authors: Kara Sealock, Ji-Young Yeo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Technology and innovation can connect nursing students with the knowledge and experiences needed to provide care to diverse global populations. As pedagogy shifts to embrace digital tools, extended reality and simulation-based narratives offer safe, immersive environments for developing clinical skills and cultural awareness. These tools expose students to a range of experiences, including addressing cultural awareness in end-of-life care, in ways that traditional classrooms cannot. Meaningful international and transdisciplinary collaboration is crucial to creating authentic and engaging learning experiences. By leveraging these technologies, nursing education can foster culturally sensitive practitioners with the global perspective needed in today’s healthcare landscape. In this paper, we share how international and transdisciplinary researchers came together in conversation to explore the interconnectedness and commonality of nursing education and co-develop immersive experiences to enhance learning.

title: Research on UAV Path Planning Strategy Based on Fused Improved PSO Algorithm
authors: Hanchen Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: UAV path planning, a core issue in autonomous navigation, requires balancing safe obstacle avoidance, optimal energy efficiency, and trajectory smoothness in complex dynamic environments. While the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm exhibits potential in this field due to its global search capabilities, single improvement strategies struggle to adapt to diverse scenarios. This paper proposes a hybrid PSO algorithm integrating linear inertia weight, self-cognition weight, and mutated particles. Simulations were conducted in urban building environments with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5, 1 0}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5}$</tex> high-rise buildings to compare its performance with traditional PSO, linear weight PSO, mutated particle PSO, and SA. Key metrics such as path energy consumption and trajectory smoothness were analyzed. Results demonstrate that the hybrid algorithm achieves optimal comprehensive performance in complex environments, providing a new solution for UAV path planning in urban logistics, emergency rescue, and similar scenarios.

title: Deviation Generation Mechanism and Control Strategy for VES in EV Clusters Participating in Grid Scheduling
authors: Yi Lin, Peng Zheng, Jingwei Xue, Taifeng Kang, Tian Lan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Electric vehicle (EV) cluster virtual energy storage (VES) participates in grid dispatch through aggregators. However, due to the stochastic characteristics of EV mobility, the VES of each cluster struggles to fully respond to the aggregators’ reference power setpoints. To address the deviation between the VES response power of each cluster and the aggregators’ reference power commands, this paper proposes a dual-layer dispatch command deviation mitigation strategy for photovoltaic-storage charging stations. Based on the number and parameters of in-service EVs, a quantifiable model of VES deviation mitigation capacity is established to evaluate the local EV cluster’s VES deviation management capacity. Subsequently, a local deviation mitigation strategy is proposed. To tackle residual deviations after local regulation, cross-cluster coordinated deviation mitigation and dynamic adjustment strategies are proposed, enabling full utilization of multi-cluster VES resources. Simulation results show that the proposed method effectively reduces dispatch command execution deviations, enhances the aggregators’ economic benefits, and ensures the safe and stable operation of the distribution network.

title: Physiological and Subjective Responses to VR and 2D Occupational Safety Training Videos
authors: Ratna Permata Sari, Qi Wang, Hong-In Cheng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: VR (Virtual Reality) is gaining popularity in occupational safety training due to its immersive effect and potential to improve learning efficiency. This study analyses the physiological and subjective responses of participants when exposed to immersive safety training content using a VR headset and a desktop computer monitor. Sixteen students voluntarily participated in the experiment. Participants viewed three videos on occupational safety which were created for the purpose of safety training. Their HR (Heart Rate) and HRV (Heart Rate Variability) were measured before, during, and after the training. SDNN (Standard Deviation of NN Intervals) and RMSSD (Root Mean Square of Successive Differences) were observed as the primary HRV data. Questionnaires were used to collect subjective responses. During and after training, there were no statistically significant differences between the two groups regarding HR and RMSSD. The VR training video significantly increased the trainees’ SDNN values compared to the video presented on a computer monitor. Immersive training experiences resulted in higher levels of stress and emotional involvement. As compared to traditional training, VR training was easier to comprehend, more effective, and more satisfying for trainees. This study shows the possibility of VR-based occupational safety training.

title: D-PerceptCT: Deep Perceptual Enhancement for Low-Dose CT Images
authors: Taifour Yousra Nabila, Azeddine Beghdadi, Marie Luong, Zuheng Ming, Habib Zaidi, Faouzi Alaya Cheikh
publish: 2025 13th European Workshop on Visual Information Processing (EUVIP)
abstract: Low Dose Computed Tomography (LDCT) is widely used as an imaging solution to aid diagnosis and other clinical tasks. However, this comes at the price of a deterioration in image quality due to the low dose of radiation used to reduce the risk of secondary cancer development. While some efficient methods have been proposed to enhance LDCT quality, many overestimate noise and perform excessive smoothing, leading to a loss of critical details. In this paper, we introduce D-PerceptCT, a novel architecture inspired by key principles of the Human Visual System (HVS) to enhance LDCT images. The objective is to guide the model to enhance or preserve perceptually relevant features, thereby providing radiologists with CT images where critical anatomical structures and fine pathological details are perceptually visible. D-PerceptCT consists of two main blocks: 1) a Visual Dual-path Extractor (ViDex), which integrates semantic priors from a pretrained DINOv2 model with local spatial features, allowing the network to incorporate semantic-awareness during enhancement; (2) a Global-Local State-Space block that captures long-range information and multiscale features to preserve the important structures and fine details for diagnosis. In addition, we propose a novel deep perceptual loss, designated as the Deep Perceptual Relevancy Loss Function (DPRLF), which is inspired by human contrast sensitivity, to further emphasize perceptually important features. Extensive experiments on the Mayo2016 dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of D-PerceptCT method for LDCT enhancement, showing better preservation of structural and textural information within LDCT images compared to SOTA methods.

title: Learning to Judge Motion: Likelihood-Based Evaluation with Normalizing Flows
authors: Mahamat Issa Choueb, Praveen Kumar Sekharamantry, Giulia Martinelli, Alessandro Floris, Nicola Conci
publish: 2025 13th European Workshop on Visual Information Processing (EUVIP)
abstract: Human motion generation aims to synthesize realistic and diverse body movements from inputs such as text, poses, or environmental cues. Effective evaluation of generated motion requires metrics that capture realism, accuracy, and diversity. Existing approaches tend to overemphasize similarity to ground truth, assume Gaussian distributions, ignore temporal structure, or rely heavily on subjective assessments. To overcome these limitations, we introduce a novel evaluation method based on Conditional Glow Normalizing Flows, which model the full data distribution without assuming gaussianity and without requiring paired reference samples. Trained on two contrasting datasets, AMASS, which contains high-fidelity motion capture performed by real actors, and Mixamo, a synthetic dataset with retargeted animations, our model provides exact likelihood estimates that quantify the degree to which a motion sequence aligns with real or synthetic distributions. This enables not just binary classification, but a nuanced evaluation of physical and kinematic plausibility. We conduct extensive experiments across several state-of-the-art generative models, demonstrating that our likelihood-based metric offers an interpreTable tool for motion validation.

title: Browser-Embedded, Legal-Aware Cybersecurity Co-Pilot for Myanmar with RAG, Multilingual Defense and Privacy
authors: Htet Myet Zaw, Hpone Khant Naing, Aung Kaung Myat, Htet Paing Linn, Thurein Lin, Thiri Thitsar Khaing
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: We present Konbaung AI, a multilingual, privacy-preserving browser extension that integrates real-time cyber defense with contextual legal awareness for Myanmar’s digital citizens. The system combines an Ollama-compatible large language model with Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) over Myanmar Cyber Law and global privacy and security frameworks, while incorporating natural language– based phishing detection, URL heuristics, cryptographic file hashing with malware verification, and breach exposure analysis. A privacy-by-default design ensures local inference, minimal external dependencies, and the absence of remote user data storage. We formalize a threat model for browser-resident AI and propose a modular architecture that couples lightweight client processing with secure backend services. Experimental evaluation across detection accuracy, response latency, and user interaction indicates phishing and spam classification, close alignment with established malware verdicts, effective legal and privacy policy summarization in Burmese, and sustained engagement through adaptive gamification. Remaining challenges include dialectal speech processing and limited domain-specific datasets, offline-capable mechanisms, and broader cross-platform deployment.

title: Digital Reusable Smart-Catheter Platform for Intermittent Point-of-care Urinary Monitoring : Flexible Catheter System with Potentiometric pH, Pressure, and Temperature Sensors
authors: Erika Solano, Zhi Dou, WT Alshaibani, Mohammed Alhendi, Abdullah Obeidat, Riadh Al-Haidari, Mark J. Schadt, Mark Poliks, Daniel Wollin, Souvik Paul, Kara Allanach
abstract: CathBuddy, Inc.'s Aurie System is an intermittent urinary catheter with a cleaning and disinfection unit that enables its safe reusability. This feature supports a digital platform in a "smart catheter", aimed at point-of-care monitoring of biomarkers of catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs). Our digital system integrates commercial pressure (P) and temperature (T) sensors alongside an in-house fabricated, wire-type, potentiometric pH sensor into the 14 Fr Aurie reusable catheter. Consistent monitoring of T and pH in the bladder may aid in early CAUTI diagnosis, while bladder P measurements can help establish urinary baselines and personalize catheterization. Here, successful integration of commercial solid-state P and T sensors was demonstrated, with simultaneous data acquisition during catheterization of a custom bladder model with controlled P and artificial urine flow. The custom-fabricated pH sensors exhibited high sensitivity, with near-Nernstian behavior and robust performance after multiple cleaning and disinfecting cycles, thus confirming their compatibility with the reusable catheterization system, and showcasing their promising implementation towards earlier CAUTI detection, with more accessible and efficient intermittent catheterizations.

title: A Common-Ground Five-Level Dynamic Boost Transformerless Inverter
authors: Felipe B. Grigoletto, Sound Cedieu, Sze Sing Lee, Yam P. Siwakoti
abstract: Transformerless inverters based on the common-ground (CG) concept have been attracting significant attention, particularly for grid-connected photovoltaic systems. The suppression of leakage currents by these topologies improves safety and reduces electromagnetic interference. Most topologies reported in the literature exhibit discontinuous input current and limited voltage gain. This paper proposes a CG five-level (5 L) transformerless inverter with a dynamic boost voltage gain resulting in continuous input current. In addition, the paper presents the operating principles and modulation strategy of the proposed inverter. Furthermore, a comparison with an existing five-level inverter, highlighting the benefits of the new topology is presented. Finally, simulation results are shown to validate the operation of the inverter.

title: An Enhanced PSO-Based MPPT Method for Photovoltaic Systems Under Partial Shading
authors: Igor De Matos da Rosa, Thiago Fonseca Rech, Alison Roberto Panisson, Lenon Schmitz
abstract: This paper introduces an advanced maximum power point tracking (MPPT) approach based on particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm. The method incorporates a swarm size reduction (SSR) technique with a dynamic monitoring reset (DMR) mechanism. The SSR improves the convergence time of the tracking, while the DMR enhances the ability of the PSO to adapt and maintain tracking accuracy in rapidly changing shading environments, providing robust tracking of the global maximum power point (GMPP). Hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly improves the efficiency of the photovoltaic (PV) system, reducing energy losses and optimizing performance under variable and complex shading patterns.

title: Towards Efficient and Robust Waste Classification via Adaptive Group-Wise Dynamics
authors: Yifan Zhang, Jiechao Yang, Jinxin Yang, Congsheng Jia, Keyu Li, Fangkai Cai, Ning Fu
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: Real-world waste classification systems face significant challenges in achieving high detection accuracy, computational efficiency, and robustness under complex conditions-such as occlusion, small object instances and irregular shapes. To address these limitations, this paper presents AGDYOLO, a novel object detection framework empowered by Adaptive Group-wise Dynamics (AGD), designed to balance efficiency and robustness through adaptive feature learning. The framework integrates four key components: (1) a GhostNet-based lightweight backbone to minimize model size and computational cost; (2) an Adaptive Down-Sampling (ADS) module to preserve fine-grained spatial details for detecting small waste items; (3) multi-scale Receptive Field Block (RFB) modules in the neck to enhance contextual discrimination among visually similar categories; and (4) ODConv-enabled dynamic heads that adaptively capture shape variations in irregularly shaped objects. A large-scale waste dataset is constructed, comprising 4,800 highresolution images across 60 fine-grained classes, with detailed annotations for occlusion level, object size, and deformation degree. Extensive ablation studies and cross-dataset validation on TrashNet and TACO demonstrate the effectiveness and generalizability of the AGD framework. Experimental results show that AGD-YOLO achieves 83.2% mAP@50 with only 7.1 M parameters and runs at 165 FPS on an RTX 4060 Ti 16 G, outperforming YOLOv8 by +6.9% in mAP and reducing misclassification rates by up to 46% in heavily occluded scenarios. The proposed AGD mechanism establishes a new paradigm for deployable vision systems in smart recycling applications.

title: Impact of Gate-Source/Drain Underlap on Device Performance of Germanium Nanosheet FETs
authors: Anwesha Halder, Subir Kumar Maity, Rudra Sankar Dhar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: This study compares the analog, radio frequency, and DC performance of a Germanium Underlap nanosheet transistor with a gate length of 16nm to a variety of Germanium nanosheet transistors with underlap lengths of 10 nm, 15nm, and 5nm, respectively. The enhanced electron mobility of the Germanium device with a 5nm underlap length results in notable gains in drive current, even though it shows a bigger subthreshold swing because of increased short-channel effects. In particular, the 5nm underlap length Germanium nanosheet transistor exhibits higher ON current and an enhanced transition frequency in comparison to the 10nm and 15nm undelap length Germanium nanosheet FETs. Better RF performance, such as increased gain-frequency and transconductance-frequency products, is also a result of these current improvements

title: Thermo-Hydraulic Performance of Targeted Flow in Aluminum and Copper Heat Sinks for Immersion Cooling Applications
authors: Prasanna Jayaramu, Emami Meysam, Vishal Talari, Md Raisul Islam, Kaustubh Adsul, Rohit Suthar, Lochan Sai Reddy Chinthaparthy, Dereje Agonafer, Pratik Bansode, Ahson Hussain, Puxuan Li, Tao Geng
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: The increasing computational, storage, and networking demands of modern data centers have led to escalating power densities, posing significant thermal management challenges. Air-cooled high-performance servers necessitate low air supply temperatures and elevated airflow rates, rendering air cooling progressively inefficient beyond specific thermal design power (TDP) thresholds. Single-phase liquid immersion cooling (Sp-LIC) presents a viable alternative by leveraging the high thermal capacity and superior heat dissipation capabilities of dielectric fluids, which establish direct contact with all powered components. Additionally, Sp-LIC enhances system reliability by shielding IT hardware from environmental contaminants while reducing both capital expenditure (CapEx) and operational costs through the elimination of fans and air handling units. Unlike direct-to-chip liquid cooling, Sp-LIC obviates the need for intricate coolant distribution manifolds, as the dielectric fluid directly interfaces with all server components, making it particularly advantageous for hyperscale, edge, and modular data center deployments. This study investigates the thermal performance of single-phase immersion cooling under forced convection, wherein coolant flow is directed toward the heat sink. Performance is assessed across varying flow rates and power dissipation levels using three commercially available heat sink configurations: an aluminum heat sink, a copper heat sink, and an aluminum heat sink featuring a copper vapor chamber base. The coolant flow rate is varied between 1 and 8 LPM, while power dissipation ranges from 250 W to 900 W, with the fluid inlet temperature maintained at $40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. A Thermal Test Vehicle (TTV) replicating a server environment, inclusive of a motherboard and Dual Inline Memory Modules (DIMMs), is employed. Experimental measurements, including case temperature and pressure drop, are analyzed to evaluate system performance, with thermal resistance calculated for each heat sink configuration.

title: Empowering the Emerging: Governance Mechanisms for Urban Innovation Ecosystems
authors: Anna Eberhardt, Patrick Ruess, Sandrine Faißt, Jens Neuhüttler
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: Urban innovation ecosystems foster technological progress, economic growth, and global competitiveness, involving networks of businesses, academic institutions, public authorities, and community organizations. Effective governance in these ecosystems is key to coordinating activities, enabling knowledge exchange, and ensuring long-term sustainability. While much research has focused on ecosystem types and characteristics, the relationship between governance structures and their practical implementation remains underexplored. This study addresses this gap by analyzing governance mechanisms through a mixed-method approach, including literature review and expert interviews. The findings offer actionable insights to improve governance practices and to promote resilient and adaptable ecosystems.

title: Frequency-Response Error and Its Equivalence for Designing Cascade-Form Phase-Equalizers
authors: Tian-Bo Deng
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: Phase equalizers are critical to the equalization of phase distortions occurring in a phase-distorted system. This paper considers the error functions to be minimized in designing a phase equalizer. This equalizer consists of cascaded allpass sections, which is called cascade-form allpass (CFAP) phase equalizer. We first derive the error of its frequency-response (FR), and then relate the FR-error with the phase-deviation of the CFAP phase equalizer. This paper proves that the absolute FR-error of the CFAP phase equalizer equals the absolute sine of half phase-deviation. This relation signifies that minimizing either the absolute FR-error or the absolute sine of half phase-deviation produces the same result. To demonstrate this equivalence, we simulate an example of designing the CFAP phase equalizer by utilizing both FR-error and sine of half phase-deviation. Simulation results confirm the mathematically proved error equivalence.

title: Differential Physiological Responses to Proxemic and Facial Threats in Virtual Avatar Interactions
authors: Birgit Nierula, Mustafa Tevfik Lafci, Anna Melnik, Mert Akgül, Farelle Toumaleu Siewe, Sebastian Bosse
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Proxemics, the study of spatial behavior, is fundamental to social interaction and increasingly relevant for virtual reality (VR) applications. While previous research has established that users respond to personal space violations in VR similarly as in real-world settings, phase-specific physiological responses and the modulating effects of facial expressions remain understudied. We investigated physiological and subjective responses to personal space violations by virtual avatars, to understand how threatening facial expressions and interaction phases (approach vs. standing) influence these responses. Sixteen participants experienced a 2×2 factorial design manipulating Personal Space (intrusion vs. respect) and Facial Expression (neutral vs. angry) while we recorded skin conductance response (SCR), heart rate variability (HRV), and discomfort ratings. Personal space boundaries were individually calibrated using a stop-distance procedure. Results show that SCR responses are significantly higher during the standing phase compared to the approach phase when personal space was violated, indicating that prolonged proximity within personal space boundaries is more physiologically arousing than the approach itself. Angry facial expressions significantly reduced HRV, reflecting decreased parasympathetic activity, and increased discomfort ratings, but did not amplify SCR responses. These findings demonstrate that different physiological modalities capture distinct aspects of proxemic responses: SCR primarily reflects spatial boundary violations, while HRV responds to facial threat cues. Our results provide insights for developing comprehensive multi-modal assessments of social behavior in virtual environments and inform the design of more realistic avatar interactions.

title: Power Sharing Strategy in Hybrid Microgrids with Charging Stations: Analysis of Voltage Fluctuation and Flicker Mitigation
authors: Márcio V. R. Campos, Lucas Jonys R. Silva, Deniver R. Schutz, Bruno M. Zilli, Thales Augusto Fagundes, Rodolpho V. A. Neves, Ricardo Quadros Machado
abstract: Charging stations integrated with renewable energy sources can introduce voltage fluctuations and flicker into the grid. Accordingly, this work proposes a comprehensive analysis of this issue through a case study of a DC coupled to AC side hybrid microgrid, employing a sub-second timescale modeling approach. This work assess the grid voltage quality under intense charging daily demand, comparing a Power-Sharing Strategy (PSS) for DC-AC interlinking converter operating with and without an Energy Storage System (ESS). The results achieve a reduction in both grid voltage fluctuations and perceptible flickers, improving power quality of the AC distribution network.

title: Screen-Printed Thermoformed Additive In-Mold Electronics Thermal Cycling Reliability for Automotive Applications.
authors: Aditya Harsha, Pradeep Lall, Scott Miller
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: In-Mold Electronics (IME) offers transformative possibilities for the seamless integration of electronic circuits into diverse product forms and surfaces. Despite the advancements, there remains a significant gap in detailed research concerning the electrical characteristics of IME circuits, especially when subjected to thermal shock. This study seeks to address this research void by examining how thermal cycling affects the electrical performance of thermoformed substrates. The changes in electrical parameters of the circuit have been examined after first printing on the polycarbonate substrate using a screen printer and thermoforming over a mold designed for the door handle of a car when subjected to thermal cycling. The electrical performance of an RC oscillator circuit additively fabricated on a polycarbonate substrate with surface mount components has been examined and compared with a rigid FR4 board. Electrically conductive adhesive has been used to attach the components. The evolution of the circuit performance has been measured through thermal cycling, which is expected in automotive grade-3 applications.

title: Partitioning and Substation Siting Method for Super Large Scale Offshore Wind Clusters
authors: Mengyao Zhang, Ling Xu, Le Zhao, Xuanze Zuo, Yue Yang, Jingwen Ling, Guanglong Zhu, Xiaoyan Bian
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: The scale of super large scale offshore wind clusters (SLSOWCs) has reached 10 GW level, and the traditional planning methods for small wind farm can no longer meet the demand for grid connection, and make it difficult to obtain the global optimal solution. This paper presents a planning method applicable to SLSOWCs, including partitioning, offshore booster station and aggregation station siting. First, the elbow method and an improved K-means method are used for partitioning of SLSOWCs. Second, the improved center of gravity method is applied to locate offshore booster station and aggregation station, considering difference of wind turbines(WTs) capacities in one partition and line loss. Finally, the case analysis proves the effectiveness of the proposed planning method.

title: Voltage Supporting and Fast Power Balance Control in a VSC-HVDC System
authors: Sichao Wang, Hanbin Zhang, Xiao Zhou, Yuexi Yang, Yu Bai, Guiliang Gao
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: The effectiveness and reliability of voltage source converter based high voltage direct current (VSC-HVDC) technology has already been verified in practical engineering application. Based on this scenario, this paper additionally considers the coordinate control and power flow interaction among the local weak ac grid, VSC-HVDC rectifier station and the renewable resources [represented by the commonly used grid-following (GFL) inverter]. By applying the frequency-following voltage-forming control method in the VSC-HVDC system and adding an outer active power balance control loop, the rectifier station can not only achieve the voltage supporting that to avoid the weak-grid instability of GFL inverter, but also realize the active power flow balance to determine how much power that comes from the renewable resources could flow into the HVDC system. A full-order state-space model is established to access the small-signal stability and the port admittance bode plot is also obtained accordingly to verify the voltage supporting performance. Two operating case studies are conducted to demonstrate the grid-strength improvement as well as the active power balance performance by this control method.

title: Design and Optimization of a Signal Acquisition System for Arc Fault Detection and Interruption
authors: Natanael Roberto Dos Santos, Cláudio Henrique Gomes Dos Santos, Leandro Tiago Manêra, Tárcio André Dos Santos Barros
abstract: This paper presents the optimization of a hardware system designed for signal acquisition in arc-fault detection and interruption applications. The proposed approach focuses on analyzing the AC component of the input current, which proved to be the most effective strategy for identifying arc events. The system was designed to acquire direct current signals with an alternating component ranging from 100 mA to 8 A and deliver them to the conditioning stage with minimal distortion, ensuring waveform integrity and power characteristics preservation, even at reduced measurement scales. The hardware design was guided by a mathematical model, which served as the basis for circuit development. The solution was later validated through PSpice simulations and experimental tests using a dedicated setup. The results indicated that the system achieved a highly satisfactory output resolution, with an error lower than 10 %.

title: Cobot: An Embodied AI Agent for Immersive Analytics
authors: Nicolas Barbotin, Jack Fraser, Jeremy McDade, Andrew Cunningham
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Recent Immersive Analytics research envisioned AI collaborators that assist with data exploration and analysis. With the advent of Large Language Models (LLMs), such collaborators are now feasible. Yet, fundamental design questions remain: How can we leverage LLMs to support expressive, emergent interactions while managing hallucinations or errors? How can we make such agents feel spatially embedded in the user’s environment? To explore these questions, we present Cobot, an embodied AI agent integrated into an Immersive Analytics platform. This paper describes the design and implementation of Cobot, highlighting challenges and opportunities in building embodied, interactive AI collaborators for immersive environments.

title: A Graduate-Level Photovoltaic Systems Course Module with Practical Modeling and Code Repository
authors: João Lucas de Souza Silva, João Frederico Souza De Paula, Gustavo Fraidenraich, Tárcio André dos Santos Barros
abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) energy systems have gained increasing relevance in both academia and industry. However, educational approaches often lack integration between theoretical foundations, practical skills, and industry perspectives. This paper presents a case study of a graduate-level course module on PV Systems in University of Campinas (Brazil) designed to address these gaps. The course includes theoretical modules on PV fundamentals, followed by practical Python-based modeling of the PV energy generation chain. Further topics cover basic power electronics, inverter operation, and maximum power point tracking (MPPT) algorithms. A technical visit to a laboratory focused on inverter and PV module testing provided applied experience. All course materials, including simulation codes and project proposals, were shared through a collaborative GitHub repository, promoting reproducibility and active student participation. The course received positive feedback, and its structure presents a replicable model for other graduate programs seeking to improve PV education. The approach also encourages stronger connections between academic institutions and the solar energy sector.

title: An Embrace-Type VR System for Older Adults
authors: Tatsuya Yamamoto, Daisuke Iwai, Kosuke Sato
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: For older users, conventional head-mounted displays present challenges such as physical discomfort, limited ease of operation, and potential safety concerns, particularly. To address these issues, we propose a multisensory VR system that adopts a embrace-type, lap-mounted form factor, eliminating the need for headbands and enabling intuitive interaction through visual feedback of the user’s hands and joystick. The device integrates visual, auditory, and vibrotactile components to enhance the immersive experience while maintaining physical comfort. A prototype system was developed and evaluated through preliminary trials with young adults. The results suggest improved comfort due to the embrace-type design, enhanced operability through hand–controller visualization, and increased presence with synchronized vibration feedback.

title: Hybrid Transformer Architecture for an Effective Teaching and Resource Sharing Platform for Higher Vocational English Teaching
authors: Yalian Shu, Jiajia Lu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In recent days, Higher Vocational English Teaching and Training methods encapsulates the very specialized practical leaning systems which can capable of understanding crystal clear semantic relationships, practical understanding and most importantly domain specific technology. But the existing methods fails to capture the effective practical knowledge which fails the learners to understand the specific domains. To solve the above problem, this research study proposes a Hybrid Transformer Architectures for enhancing the understanding ability of the Higher Vocational English Teaching resources that can be integrated with online education systems with the resource sharing capabilities. The proposed framework consist of four components: 1) Data collection system 2) Pre-processing 3) Transformer Networks 4) Recommendation process. The comprehensive experimentation has been carried out by collecting the real time English vocational courses from the different online learning platform and text books. Furthermore, students' feedbacks are collected to aid for the further enhancing in the online learning systems. The evaluation metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall are calculated and compared with the other learning models. Evaluation results demonstrates the performance of the model has achieved the accuracy of 0.9755, precision of 0.9663, recall of 0.960 in effectively predicting the student's proficiency levels with personalized recommendation of improvement

title: Sports Digital Video Conversion and Detection Analysis Based on Improved Multi-Objective Optimization
authors: Si Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: With the widespread application of sports videos in competitive analysis, tactical review, and smart sports scenarios, achieving efficient video conversion and accurate motion detection while maintaining image quality has become a critical issue. To this end, this paper proposes an improved multi-objective optimization algorithm that integrates dynamic image complexity assessment, an adaptive mutation strategy, and an elite solution retention mechanism. The algorithm dynamically adjusts optimization weights during video keyframe selection, inter-frame compression rate control, and motion region precision identification. Empirical results on subsets of UCF Sports and Kinetics demonstrate that the proposed IMOPSO (Improved Multi-Objective Particle Swarm Optimization) algorithm (Group G3) achieves an optimal balance between compression efficiency and image quality. Its compression ratio reaches 3.15, significantly higher than the 2.78 of NSGA-II (Non-Dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II) (Group G2) and the compression ratios of the other two ablation groups (2.97 for G4 and 2.89 for G5).

title: Power Quality Disturbance Identification Based on Markov Transfer Field and Improved RepVGG
authors: Bo Shao, Jiandong Duan, Zejian Shu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Aiming at the problem that the traditional power quality disturbances (PQDs) classifier manually selects the feature process is complex and the degree of refinement is insufficient, this paper proposes a composite power quality disturbance recognition method based on Markov transfer field and improved Re-parameterized VGG (RepVGG). Firstly, the one-dimensional time-domain disturbance signal is converted into a two-dimensional visual image by using the Markov transfer field. After that, RepVGG extracts the disturbance features covered in the image from the sample set by itself. At the same time, in order to improve its feature extraction ability, the atrous spatial pyramid pooling module is introduced. The simulation results show that the proposed strategy can effectively overcome the shortcomings of traditional methods such as strong subjectivity and poor anti-noise performance in the case of no noise and signal-to-noise ratio of 30dB and 20dB, and has a high recognition rate for composite PQD.

title: Analysis of the Provision of Ancillary Services in Electric Power Distribution Systems to Improve Quality Indicators
authors: Daniel Fonseca do Nascimento, Augusto C. Rueda-Medina
abstract: This work analyzes the provision of ancillary services (AS) through distributed generation (DG) in electric power distribution systems. Building upon market-based dispatch methodologies, the study extends traditional approaches by incorporating regulatory compliance with voltage quality standards from Module 8 of the Brazilian Procedures for Electricity Distribution. A 24-hour simulation of the IEEE 37-bus test feeder is performed using the optimization software AMPL, optimizing active and reactive dispatch from photovoltaic DG units. The methodology assesses the technical benefits, including voltage profile improvements and loss reductions, while economically evaluating the potential to avoid penalties for non-compliance with Permitted Deviation Range and Critical Deviation Range voltage limits. The model integrates a competitive market remuneration structure and estimates net benefit from ancillary service deployment. Results aim to demonstrate the viability of DG-based AS provision to enhance quality indicators, reduce operational costs for distribution utilities by 41% and avoid penalty expenses by 93,5%.

title: A Markov-Chain Based PUF Using Chain-Block-Obfuscation Mechanism Resisting Machine Learning Attacks with High Uniformity Robustness
authors: Junhong Gan, Hanqing Luo, Yuanfeng Xie, Liping Liang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: Physical Unclonable Functions (PUFs) are lightweight hardware security primitives suitable for resource-constrained Internet of Things(IoT) devices. The Arbiter PUF (APUF), as a classic strong PUF structure, is well-suited for lightweight device authentication. Unfortunately, due to certain structural characteristics, the classic APUF can be successfully modeled by various machine learning (ML) models with only a small number of CRP (Challenge-Response Pair) samples. To address this security issue, In this paper, we build upon the classic APUF structure by introducing a Chain Block Obfuscation(CBO) mechanism and a Markov obfuscation mechanism at the input and output stages, respectively. This approach demonstrates strong resistance against four machine learning models—logistic regression (LR), support vector machine (SVM), covariance matrix adaptation evolutionary strategies (CMA-ES), and artificial neural networks (ANN)—while optimizing hardware resource usage by at least 53.4% compared to previous attack-resistant structures. Even with up to 2M CRPs for training, the prediction accuracy remains around 50%. Additionally, XOR, a widely adopted output obfuscation mechanism by many researchers, has limitations in output uniformity when the number of intra-chip parallel APUFs is small. Studies have shown that the uniqueness between intra-chip APUFs may not reach the ideal value of 50%. In such cases, especially when there are only two parallel APUFs in the circuit, the uniformity of the XOR output is affected by insufficient uniqueness. To address this issue, this paper proposes a MUX-based Markov output obfuscation mechanism. Experimental data on the Xilinx Artix-7 field-programmable gate array (FPGA) platform demonstrate that this mechanism exhibits strong robustness in uniformity compared to the traditional XOR output obfuscation, particularly when the number of intra-chip parallel APUFs is small.

title: A Gradient Meta-Learning Joint Optimization for Beamforming and Antenna Position in Pinching-Antenna Systems
authors: Kang Zhou, Weixi Zhou, Donghong Cai, Xianfu Lei, Yanqing Xu, Zhiguo Ding, Pingzhi Fan
abstract: In this paper, we consider a novel optimization design for multi-waveguide pinching-antenna systems, aiming to maximize the weighted sum rate (WSR) by jointly optimizing beamforming coefficients and antenna position. To handle the formulated non-convex problem, a gradient-based meta-learning joint optimization (GML-JO) algorithm is proposed. Specifically, the original problem is initially decomposed into two sub-problems of beamforming optimization and antenna position optimization through equivalent substitution. Then, the convex approximation methods are used to deal with the nonconvex constraints of sub-problems, and two sub-neural networks are constructed to calculate the sub-problems separately. Different from alternating optimization (AO), where two sub-problems are solved alternately and the solutions are influenced by the initial values, two sub-neural networks of proposed GML-JO with fixed channel coefficients are considered as local sub-tasks and the computation results are used to calculate the loss function of joint optimization. Finally, the parameters of sub-networks are updated using the average loss function over different sub-tasks and the solution that is robust to the initial value is obtained. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed GML-JO algorithm achieves 5.6 bits/s/Hz WSR within 100 iterations, yielding a 32.7% performance enhancement over conventional AO with substantially reduced computational complexity. Moreover, the proposed GML-JO algorithm is robust to different choices of initialization and yields better performance compared with the existing optimization methods.

title: High Reliability and Low Thermal Resistance Spacer Based on via-DPC for Double-Side Cooling Module
authors: Chi Zhang, Cai Chen, BaiHan Liu, Yiyang Yan, Jianwei Lv, Jiaxin Liu, Yong Kang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Components, Packaging and Manufacturing Technology
abstract: The double-sided cooling (DSC) power modules are sandwich packaging with more soldering interfaces, which suffer higher thermal-induced stress than traditional wire-bonding packaging. Considering reliability and thermal conductivity, state-of-the-art spacers were implemented as a buffer to lower the stress.
