This article introduced a spacer made of direct-plated copper (DPC) with vias to reduce the thermomechanical stresses in the DSC power module. The DPC-via-spacer (DVS) consists of AlN ceramic with close CTE to SiC devices and copper layers with stress-strain relieved edge design. Single-switch DSC modules with copper spacer, molybdenum spacer, and DVS were designed and fabricated. Simulation results showed that, at a power loss of 90W, the thermally induced strain at the most vulnerable solder layer of the module with the DVS was reduced by 80% compared to that of the module with the copper spacer. Compared with the Mo spacer, the junction temperature is reduced by 4% under a similar stress-strain behavior. Considering skin effect under 500MHz frequency, the electrical resistance of the DVS is 92.6% and 50.5% of that of the copper spacer and the Mo spacer, respectively. Power cycling test results showed that the lifetime of the modules with DVS is 50% and 20% longer than that of the modules with copper spacer and Mo spacer, respectively. The results prove that DVS can reduce the thermomechanical stress-strain on the solder layer and enhance the reliability of the power module.

title: A Multi-Sensor Fusion Localization Method to Enhance Autonomous Navigation in Off-Road Environments
authors: Bo Zhang, Bowen Xiao, Jinshi Qiu, Sicheng Tan, Yu Hu
abstract: This paper develops a real-time localization framework based on multi-sensor fusion for the autonomous navigation of mobile robots in challenging off-road environments. The proposed framework employs a hybrid coupling strategy at its front-end, which integrates Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) data with Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) and LiDAR. As a consequence, GNSS Inertial Odometry (GIO) and Lidar Inertial Odometry (LIO) are created and these are crucial for achieving precise localization in real-time. The RGB-Height-Intensity descriptor is used to improve the precision of loop closure detection while maintaining search efficiency. This is achieved by integrating surface reflectance data from the LiDAR intensity channel and RGB data from camera images. Finally, in the back-end procedure of this framework, the accuracy of posture estimation is enhanced by the optimization of odometry and loop closure factors. Additionally, a framework of real-time localization and autonomous navigation is developed and implemented on a wheeled robot to verify the proposed real-time localization framework. The experimental results indicate the framework exhibited higher performance in off-road environments, where conventional localization techniques generally degrade.

title: Periodic Sparsity Enhanced Channel Estimation Method via Improved BSBL for Ultrasonic Through-Metal Communication
authors: Shengqiang Shen, Hongmiao Wang, Yifan Zheng, Kai Shi, Zongyan Li, Shiyin Li
abstract: Ultrasonic through-metal communication is critical for many applications in industrial IoT (IIoT) environments but suffers from frequency-selective fading, requiring orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM). Accurate channel estimation with minimal pilot overhead is essential for optimizing OFDM performance. Existing methods for estimating ultrasonic through-metal communication channel ignore the sparsity of the ultrasonic through-metal channel impulse response (CIR), leading to high pilot overhead, while sparse estimation algorithms fail to exploit the CIR’s structural features. Therefore, a periodic sparsity enhanced channel estimation method via improved block sparse Bayesian learning (BSBL) for ultrasonic through-metal communication is proposed, which further improves the estimation accuracy and reduces the pilot overhead by integrating three key features of CIR—the periodic occurrence of echo blocks, their exponential attenuation, and their intrinsic waveform—into the Bayesian prior. Experiments show that the proposed algorithm significantly outperforms standard BSBL in estimation accuracy while substantially reducing pilot overhead compared to conventional non-sparse techniques. This method not only enhances estimation precision but also improves spectral efficiency and link reliability in resource-constrained and harsh IIoT environments.

title: Real-Time Multi-Physics Modeling of Automotive Fuel Cells: A Method Based on Multilevel Cyclic Iteration and Orthogonal List-Conjugate Gradient
authors: Zhuang Tian, Zhongliang Li, Rachid Outbib, Daming Zhou
abstract: As hydrogen fuel cell vehicles are deployed on a large scale, the development of high-fidelity and computationally efficient modeling techniques has become essential for the widespread commercialization of proton exchange membrane fuel cells. To balance computational accuracy and real-time solving performance, this paper proposes a high-dimensional multi-physics modeling approach coupling partial differential equations (PDEs)- multilevel cyclic iterative modeling framework (MCIMF) and Orthogonal List-Conjugate Gradient (OL-CG) modeling approach. Firstly, high-dimensional PDEs are utilized to describe the high-dimensional multi-physics coupling phenomena in fuel cells, thus ensuring model accuracy. Secondly, multilevel cyclic iterative modeling framework is developed to ensure the conservation of electric and fluid domain physical characteristics during the transformation of PDEs. Lastly, the OL-CG method efficiently and flexibly stores effective information in matrix using a linked storage structure and searches for numerical solutions along the gradient descent, thus the model real-time solving performance is enhanced. Validation on hardware platforms and commercial CFD shows strong fidelity: the gas-pressure distribution matches ANSYS Fluent with MAPEs of 0.009% at 155 kPa and 0.012% at 135 kPa. Moreover, at a grid size of 36480, the proposed OL-CG delivers 86.17% and 53.23% faster computation than the FS and FS-CG methods, respectively, demonstrating a favorable balance between accuracy and high-speed solving.

title: Digital Illustration Color Visualization Enhancement Algorithm Based on Deep Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Qia Guo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In digital illustration creation, color imbalance often diminishes the overall aesthetic appeal of the work. Traditional color correction methods rely on manual feature recognition, which struggles to accurately grasp complex color relationships and results in low processing efficiency. This paper addresses this issue by utilizing a deep convolutional neural network (DCNN) to automatically identify color features and the color relationships between elements. It also combines a pretrained VGG16 model with an adaptation layer to enhance color feature learning. It then deeply analyzes feature maps to define the color characteristics of elements and constructs a color affinity model to assess the similarity between elements, ultimately generating a new target color scheme. The system utilizes an event-driven architecture to dynamically extract and refresh color information in real time. Experimental data demonstrates an average visual performance improvement of 28.15% and a 45.6% increase in contrast.

title: Design and Financial Risk Control Application of Credit Scoring Card Model Based on XGBoost and CatBoost
authors: Yunpeng Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: With the rapid development of Internet technology, Internet finance has gradually become an important financial model, providing more convenient and low-cost financial services for users and SMEs. This article is based on the historical credit data of Lending Club and designs a fusion model combining XGBoost and CatBoost to address the pre loan customer classification problem. And improved the CatBoost model by introducing the Stacking method, constructing a structure based on XGBoost and CatBoost models. To improve the interpretability of the model and prevent overfitting, this paper adopts logistic regression as the binary model. In order to reduce the impact of data imbalance on the model, a weighted cross entropy loss function was also designed, and the XG CatBoost fusion model was ultimately optimized. In the model construction and experimental section, this article conducted empirical analysis on CatBoost, logistic regression, random forest, GBDT, XGBoost, and XG CatBoost models through five fold cross validation, using accuracy, AUC value, and KS value as evaluation criteria. The experimental results show that compared with a single model, CatBoost has higher accuracy in pre loan forecasting, and the XG CatBoost fusion model outperforms other models in terms of various indicators.

title: A Novel Liquid Cooled Heat Sink with Adjacent Micro Synthetic Jets for Thermal Management in Microelectronic Devices
authors: Delara Soltani, Tim Persoons, Sajad Alimohammadi
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: This paper investigates the use of flow vectoring phenomena in adjacent synthetic jets for cooling hot spots in a microchannel. By applying an appropriate phase difference, fluid flow is induced within the microchannel using adjacent synthetic jets. The performance of this configuration is evaluated under conditions representative of cooling electronic packages using pure water and water- Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> nanofluids with varying concentrations and particle diameters while maintaining constant jet operating conditions. The addition of nanoparticles alters the fluid properties, resulting in two competing effects: weakened jet performance due to increased viscosity and enhanced heat transfer through improved thermal conductivity. Both effects are analysed, and the best performance is observed with water-based nanofluids, showing a 4.5% enhancement in heat transfer compared to pure water under the same operating conditions. This indicates that although the same input power is applied to both water and nanofluids, the latter exhibits a lower $R e_{j}$ due to changes in fluid properties but demonstrates better performance in cooling the hot spot. When the $R e_{j}$ is kept constant, a 21% enhancement in heat transfer is achieved for water- $A l_{2} O_{3}$ at $\varphi= 5 \%$ and $\boldsymbol{d}_{\boldsymbol{p}}=30 \mathrm{~nm}$ compared to pure water.

title: Performance Evaluation of a Coupled Power Generation and Ice-Making System for Liquefied Natural Gas Cold Energy Recovery
authors: Zuqiang Li, Xinyu Lang, Liang Cai
publish: 2025 International Power and Sustainable Energy Technologies Conference (PSETC)
abstract: Efficiently recovering the cold energy of liquefied natural gas (LNG) holds significant carbon reduction and economic value. Therefore, a power generation and ice-making coupled system for LNG cold energy recovery was proposed, and the system's power generation and ice-making performance were analyzed. The simulation results show that as the export pressure increases, the system's power generation decreases. The ice-making performance shows little difference between medium and high delivery pressure scenarios, but is significantly lower than that under low delivery pressure. Under low delivery pressure conditions, the system can achieve a power output of 10,378 kW and an ice production rate of 100.3 kg/s. Furthermore, the system achieves daily profits of $114,051, $69,967, and $67,732 under low, medium, and high delivery scenarios, respectively, all of which are higher than those of a system without the coupled ice-making process.

title: Lights-out Factories – Hands-on Control: Haptic Teleoperation of a Robotic Arm through Virtual Reality
authors: Sebastian Mölder, Christian Eichhorn, Theodoros Papadopoulos, David A. Plecher
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: This paper investigates the effects of visual and haptic feedback on perceived presence and embodiment in a Lights-out Factory (LoF) environment. LoF describes fully automated production settings without human operators, but to enable occasional human intervention, advanced solutions such as robotic arms controlled with Virtual Reality (VR) are proposed. The first user study examined haptic feedback influences on usability and efficiency in robotic teleoperation. Results show that haptic gloves (SenseGlove Nova 1) significantly influence user preferences and Task Completion Time (TCT) of a LoF User Interface (UI). While most of the 32 participants preferred the haptic glove, their 59% slower performance suggests conventional controllers may be more efficient in automated LoF tasks. The haptic glove achieved a System Usability Scale (SUS) score of 77.5, while the controller scored significantly higher at 83.1, indicating both methods were highly usable, with the controller maintaining an advantage. The second study (six participants) investigated how different visual interaction techniques affect performance and efficiency using only the controller. Supplementary visualization (e.g., ray control or transparent overlay of future position) shows improved accuracy during operation, suggesting enhanced visualization positively impacts performance. The research contributes to remote LoF operation by (1) providing empirical evidence for the trade-off between haptic feedback and operational efficiency, (2) demonstrating that enhanced visualization techniques can improve accuracy by up to 9.8%, and (3) proposing a hybrid approach combining controller-based operation with selective haptic feedback for critical tasks in a LoF environment.

title: Census Data Forecasting using Hybrid ARIMA-LSTM with LR Model
authors: Ei Ei Moe, Si Si Mar Win, Kyi Lai Lai Khine
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: In census data analysis, poverty is a critical focus due to it highlights disparities in economic growth across different living standards. Accurate and timely forecasting of poverty is a critical for local government aiming to anticipate and mitigate economic-related challenges. However, the chaotic nature of the economic growth is a large obstacle in the way of using it. Despite the chaotic structures and uncertainty, there are some predictive methods that have been developed for forwarding predictions. Researchers have developed statistical methods in order to minimize the error in guessing methods used to evaluate time series. Specifically, this paper aims to identify the suitable model among ARIMA, LSTM and Hybrid ARIMA-LSTM based on the period from 2013 to 2024 using U.S Census Bureau dataset and also evaluates the need for reliable poverty forecasting by comparing the performance of these models by using Root Mean Square Error (RMSE). Logistic Regression (LR) was applied first to identify the most influential factors determining poverty, since the dataset contains many variables that could impact poverty outcomes. Based on the evaluation results, the Hybrid model offers superior performance compared to the other tested models. It consistently maintains high predictive accuracy and achieves the lowest RMSE values even with a reduced set of features, thus optimizing both data utilization and computational efficiency. This highlights the Hybrid model’s flexibility and practicality advantage over both LSTM and ARIMA.

title: Improved Genetic Algorithm-Based Optimization of Port Berth Allocation and Quay Crane Task Volume Scheduling
authors: Pengyu Wang, Haonan Xie, Wai Leong Pang, Swee King Phang, Hui Hwang Goh
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: Rational allocation of electrified port resources like berths, quay cranes, and shore power systems boosts operational efficiency. This study integrates shore power allocation into a berth-quay crane scheduling framework, developing a nonlinear integer programming model considering vessel arrival times, handling volumes, ship length restrictions, and resource constraints to minimize operation time, waiting time, and delays while maximizing crane utilization. An improved genetic algorithm is proposed, enhancing scheduling efficiency through intelligent initial solutions, restart mechanisms, adaptive mutation, and elite retention strategies. Experiments show the algorithm improves initial solution quality by 12.6% and reduces the objective function value to 779.54, 13.19% lower than the traditional genetic algorithm's 897.98, supporting intelligent, electrified container terminal operations.

title: Corrective measures for Failures in Airborne Radar
authors: Shangguang Liu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Manufacturing System (ICAMTMS)
abstract: When troubleshooting radar faults, it is necessary to reproduce the fault in advance. Then troubleshoot according to the logic of radar fault reporting. In many cases, the service environment of radar needs to be created, and even high acceleration stress can be used to stimulate faults. So, the analysis methods for environmental tests, such as Highly Accelerated Life Testing (HALT) and Highly Accelerated Stress Screening (HASS) were analysed and potential quantification pathways were proposed. After eliminating radar failures, designers must fundamentally eliminate potential risks by providing corrective measures. design improvements and Environmental Stress Screening (ESS) are introduced. The Burn-in method was proposed to test the ability of radar to work continuously for a long time, and the comprehensive stress screening method was used to eliminate radar defects and test environmental adaptability. We hope that the methods presented in this paper will provide valuable references for relevant engineering technicians, ultimately achieving reliability growth for radar equipment.

title: Impact of $d$-axis Inductance Variations on the Maximum Torque per Ampere Control Performance in Synchronous Reluctance Machine
authors: Francisco Joaquim de Souza Neto, Daniel Braga Melo, Marcelo Vinícius de Paula
abstract: Sustainable transportation, particularly electric vehicles (EVs), has emerged as a key focus in modern society. Aiming to reduce dependency on fossil fuels. This study explores the potential of the Synchronous Reluctance Machine (SynRM) as a promising alternative in the evolution of EV propulsion systems. A significant advantage of SynRM lies in its rotor geometry, which can be optimized to enhance torque production and efficiency. Furthermore, this paper presents a comparison of two Maximum Torque Per Ampere (MTPA) control strategies applied in this machine. The methods are evaluated through parametric variations of the direct-axis inductance <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{L}_{\boldsymbol{d}}$</tex> to understand the effects of temperature variation on SynRM performance with different MTPA techniques. Models and control strategies were implemented in MATLAB/Simulink ®. Simulation results show that a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 5 \%}$</tex> reduction in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{d}$</tex> increases the torque-to-current ratio from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.228 \text{Nm} /$</tex> A to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.257 \text{Nm} / \mathrm{A}$</tex>, causing a performance increase of 12.7 %, for the classic MTPA, while a 15 % increase in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{d}$</tex> reduces <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T_{e} / I_{s}$</tex> it to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.208 \text{Nm} / \mathrm{A}$</tex>, meaning an 8.8 % performance decrease. Future work will focus on extending control techniques and enhancing robustness for real-world EV applications.

title: Extrinsic Calibration of RGB-D Cameras using Composite Planar Pattern
authors: Peter O. Fasogbon
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: RGB-D cameras are vital for real-time 3D teleconferencing, often deployed in multi-camera setups to enhance viewpoint coverage. However, calibrating such rigs is difficult due to limited shared features and challenges in accurate depth feature extraction. We propose a novel calibration algorithm for multiple RGB-D sensors with two key contributions: (1) a composite object of multiple planar patterns that ensures each camera captures at least one plane, removing the need for shared features; and (2) a non-linear optimization process that refines depth feature extraction while minimizing global reprojection error. This reduces both the number of required calibration images and errors from unreliable depth data.

title: Evaluating Magic Leap 2 Controller Tracking for Sensor Tool Guidance in AR-Based Industrial Inspections
authors: Christian Masuhr, Julian Koch, Thorsten Schüppstuhl
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Rigorous evaluation of commercial Augmented Reality (AR) hardware is crucial, yet public benchmarks for tool tracking on modern Head-Mounted Displays (HMDs) are limited. This paper addresses this gap by systematically assessing the Magic Leap 2 (ML2) controller’s tracking performance. Using a robotic arm for repeatable motion (EN ISO 9283) and an optical tracking system as ground truth, our protocol evaluates static and dynamic performance under various conditions, including realistic paths from a hydrogen leak inspection use case. The results provide a quantitative baseline of the ML2 controller’s accuracy and repeatability and present a robust, transferable evaluation methodology. The findings provide a basis to assess the controller’s suitability for the inspection use case and similar industrial sensor-based AR guidance tasks.

title: Bitrate Allocation Improvement for Hybrid Animation-Based Face Video Compression
authors: Pierre-Loup Cabarat, Xiaoran Jiang, Lu Zhang
publish: 2025 13th European Workshop on Visual Information Processing (EUVIP)
abstract: The growing usage of video conferencing and online streaming applications is raising research interest in real-time compression solutions for visual face content. Meanwhile, the performance brought by deep generative network-based compression methods is beginning to get attention from standardization organizations such as Moving Picture Expert Group (MPEG). This paper focuses on generative methods in use for efficient compression of face videos. We analyze the bitrate contribution corresponding to different coded entities in the purpose of optimizing coding efficiency for a recently proposed Generative Face Video Coding (GFVC) scheme. Based on this study, we propose a simple but efficient enhancement of the existing hybrid face video compression, leading to an average of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10-20{\%}$</tex> Bjøntegaard Delta-rate (BD-Rate) gain over the reference Hybrid Deep Animation Codec (HDAC) method, without further training of the initial model.

title: Multi-UAV Cooperative Target Consensus Detection and Trajectory Optimization in Urban Environments
authors: Kunzhong Miao, Chang Wang, Yifeng Niu, Huangzhi Yu, Tianqing Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: As the demand for autonomous reconnaissance in urban environments grows, target loss occurs when multiple unmanned aerial vehicles (multi-UAVs) encounter regions that are difficult to access since obstacles. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a multi-UAV cooperative target consensus detection strategy. A model related to the UAV's visual region and sensor coverage area is established, considering the line-of-sight (LoS) obstruction caused by obstacles in urban environments. Bayesian theory is applied to update the global probability map, by employing dynamic occupancy grids to represent the probability of target presence and integrating sensor data from UAVs. To enhance detection speed, a consensus-based information fusion algorithm with state predictor is incorporated. Furthermore, an objective function for trajectory optimization is constructed by integrating cumulative probability and detection cost. Different typical target scenarios are designed, and UAV positions are dynamically adjusted using an improved sparrow search algorithm (ISSA) within a model predictive control framework. Then, an obstacle configuration mechanism is proposed: when at least one UAV avoids obstacles, a strict constraint mechanism is applied; otherwise, a fuzzy constraint mechanism is utilized. Finally, simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

title: AIP-LEAP: Adaptive and Multimedia-Enhanced Teaching for University Ideological and Political Education
authors: Xiaochen Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The quality and efficiency of ideological and political education in universities is increasingly depended on personalized, engaging, and data-driven education. This paper introduces a secure, university-hosted educational platform, that is an Adaptive Ideological and Political Learning with Engagement, Assessment, and Personalization (AIP-LEAP). Thid framework is designed to enhance the learning outcomes in university ideological and political education spaces. Further, AIP-LEAP is built on a Model-View-Controller (MVC) architecture and incorporates an Structured Query Language (SQL) database for efficient management of student information, course materials, and interaction data. While personalized learning pathways are offered through a knowledge graph-based recommendations system. Moreover, the learning modules included in proposed AIP-LEAP uses multimedia content and gamification of tasks to increase engagement, and evaluates student performance in light of cognitive, behavioural, and affective dimensions holistically. Furthermore, refining the educational process through the inclusion of teacher and student feedback with statistical analysis is implemented in a continuous loop to develop and renew the content, recommendations, and assessments. Thus, experimental results shows that proposed AIP-LEAP enhances student motivation, student engagement, and the learning outcomes of students. Therefore, the proposed AIP-LEAP is a systematic, secure, expandable educational and information platform that adapts to modern educational contexts.

title: A Multi-Branch Semantic Fusion Network with Knowledge Distillation and Pruning for Lightweight Medical Image Segmentation
authors: Jiabei Meng
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: Medical image segmentation is crucial for clinical diagnosis and treatment planning. Existing models often suffer from high computational cost and limited feature representation. We propose a Multi-branch Semantic Fusion Network (MSFNet) that integrates low- and high-level features within a multibranch framework to improve segmentation accuracy. To enable lightweight deployment, the highest-level semantic branch guides lower-level branches via knowledge distillation and is pruned afterward, while the remaining branches continue feature fusion. Experiments on the Synapse multi-organ CT dataset show that MSF-Net achieves a Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) of 83.2%, outperforming several state-of-the-art methods. The results demonstrate that MSF-Net effectively balances accuracy and efficiency, showing strong potential for clinical applications.

title: 3D Path Planning for Urban Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Based on Hybrid Bat-Firefly Algorithm
authors: Qixin Geng, Linzhu Guo
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: This paper addresses the current issues of poor flight stability, long flight distance, and insufficient safety of drones in complex urban environments by proposing a hybrid batfirefly algorithm (HB-FA). The main innovation of this algorithm lies in the use of a fractional calculus strategy to improve the position information update method of the bat algorithm, enabling the algorithm to comprehensively utilise historical information during the search process and adaptively adjust the weight of historical information to balance the algorithm's exploration and exploitation capabilities. Additionally, by integrating the Lévy flight mechanism, the bat algorithm is enabled to perform longdistance jumps during the search process, reducing redundant computations and overcoming the drawbacks of traditional bat algorithms, such as slow search speeds and a tendency to get stuck in local optima. Furthermore, an enhanced stepping mechanism is introduced into the firefly algorithm, dynamically allocating search permissions based on the relative brightness of fireflies. Through conditional judgments, the algorithm determines whether fireflies should adopt attraction-based movement or random exploration, further improving the smoothness of flight paths and enabling the algorithm to flexibly adapt to the complex obstacles in urban environments. Simulation results show that, compared with the single bat algorithm and firefly algorithm, the average planning path of the hybrid algorithm proposed in this paper is reduced by 19.8%, 17% and 30.6%, respectively. The average running time is shortened by 62.1%, 51.6% and 75.8%, respectively.

title: Single Phase Immersion Cooling: Going above and beyond 400W
authors: Shiraz Gulraiz, Bachar Geha, John Bean
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: In recent years, single-phase immersion cooling (SPIC) has emerged as a formidable method to cool high-density electronics. In this work, SPIC thermal efficiency is investigated using a 2 RU- 4 nodes 400 W dual CPU server in a 24 RU Green Revolution Cooling (GRC) rack. The test matrix consists of a baseline case and two flow augmentation methods developed inhouse by GRC. The results show that a thermal resistance (die-toliquid) of $0.142 \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{W}$ can be achieved without any modification to the test setup and can be further reduced to $0.090 \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{W}$ using GRC’s flow augmentation methods. The present work reports die-to-liquid thermal resistance obtained from server manufacturer thermal utility instead of the more widely used case-to-liquid thermal resistance which is a significantly lower value. The flow augmentation methods presented here can be readily implemented in the data centers without the need for major modifications to the current setup. To further enhance thermal performance, Intel Corporation’s directed flow heat sinks are deployed in GRC’s immersed direct liquid cooling (iDLC) architecture. The results show that these heat sinks can reduce thermal resistance (case-toliquid) to below $0.020 \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{W}$. It should be noted here that the scope of this work is limited to flow enhancement through heat sinks. Higher TDPs can be achieved by optimizing heat sinks and TIM, using high-performance fluid, immersion-focused server design, and lower coolant temperatures.

title: Developing a Palliative Care Simulation for the Hindu Cultural Context Using Interactive Virtual Agents: A Work-in-Progress
authors: Arjun Chatha, Hyeongil Nam, Kara Sealock, Kangsoo Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Cultural competence is critical in palliative care, yet traditional nursing education often lacks effective tools to teach the nuanced communication and empathy skills required for culturally diverse end-of-life scenarios. We present a work-in-progress virtual reality (VR) simulation featuring interactive AI-driven agents that embody culturally and spiritually sensitive behaviors rooted in Hindu traditions. Designed for undergraduate nursing education, the simulation allows learners to practice delivering care to a dying patient and family members through respectful, empathetic interactions. A planned user study will explore the simulation’s impact on learners’ cultural competence, empathy, and communication skills, offering insights into how embodied virtual agents can support experiential learning in sensitive healthcare contexts.

title: Where to Look? VR Gaze-Based Analysis in Adverse Weather Driving
authors: Junsik Bang, Uijong Ju
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Driving under visibility-impaired conditions significantly increases the occurrence of accidents. To understand why accidents are more frequent in adverse weather, it is essential to examine how drivers redistribute their visual attention during emergency situations under different weather conditions, and how this redistribution differs depending on whether an accident occurs. To address this issue, we developed VR driving simulations that incorporate varying weather conditions and accident types integrated with eye-tracking. We analyzed gaze allocation from 50 participants across a 10-second window preceding a critical event, segmented into 1-second bins. Comparing successful and failed trials under both clear and adverse weather conditions, we identified significant differences in the timing of attention re-allocation based on task success and weather. Drivers who failed to complete the scenario fixated more on the forward view during the early and middle phases, with differences between the Pass and Fail groups emerging earlier under adverse weather conditions. Our findings highlight early imbalances in gaze behavior as potential indicators of successful hazard avoidance, which could contribute to the design of gaze-based driver assistance systems aimed at preventing accidents.

title: Research on Robust Control Based on Improved State Observer
authors: Jiale Geng, Guang Tong
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Manufacturing System (ICAMTMS)
abstract: The development of control methods for two-joint robotic arms often employs rigid connections for model simplification. However, rigid connections cannot be implemented in practical applications, resulting in uncertain variations within the control system, which significantly complicates the practical implementation of control methods. Therefore, the development of control methods must consider flexible joints. This paper proposes a robust tracking control method that accounts for uncertain variations in system parameters caused by flexible joints. An ideal model is established based on dynamic equations. A highly robust controller is designed to ensure that the error between actual signals and the ideal signals generated by the model converges to zero, thereby achieving the desired control performance. Furthermore, system stability analysis is conducted, demonstrating that the proposed control method satisfies system stability requirements. MATLAB simulations verify that adjusting a single design parameter can enhance control performance.

title: Three-Phase Isolated AC-DC Bidirectional Converter with Single-Transformer Excited by the Common Mode Voltage and ZVS Capability
authors: Vitor Freire Bezerra, Douglas De Souza Sesion, Montiê Alves Vitorino
abstract: This paper proposes a new three-phase AC-DC converter capable of operating with bidirectional power flow, based on an operating principle analogous to that of Double Active Bridge (DAB) converters. Important aspects of the topology are discussed, including the operating principle, modulation strategy, power flow control, and DC link voltage regulation to the desired reference value, ensuring unity power factor. In addition to simulation results, experimental results obtained from a laboratory prototype with a nominal power of approximately 800 W are presented, which validate the performance of the proposed converter. The complete results are presented and discussed to validate the topology of the proposed converter.

title: Six-Pulse Rectifier with Partial Power Processing via Isolated DC-DC Converter for Electrolyzer Applications
authors: Jefferson M. Sousa, Luan C. S. Mazza, Robério O. Rodrigues, Edilson M. Sá, José W. M. De Araújo, Samanta G. Barbosa, Paulo P. Praça, Demercil S. Oliveira
abstract: This article proposes a power converter topology for electrolyzer operation. The topology employs a six-pulse rectifier and an isolated DC-DC converter for partial power processing. The converter topology is presented, followed by the analysis of the output voltage and power as a composition of the rectifier and DC-DC converter voltages, as well as an analysis of partial power processing. Experimental results are obtained from a reducedscale prototype supplying a 2.8 kW electrolyzer, demonstrating its functionality under different operating points. The converter effectively met the power quality requirements of the electrolyzer, achieving low current and voltage ripple while processing at most 54.9% of the total power through the DC-DC converter. On the grid side, the power quality parameters were not satisfactory but remain consistent with the expected behavior of a six-pulse rectifier with a capacitive filter. Therefore, the proposed topology stands as a promising solution for electrolyzer power supply.

title: A Two-Stage Methodology for Accurate PV Energy Yield Estimation Using Satellite Weather Data and PV Modeling Python Library
authors: João Frederico Souza de Paula, João Lucas de Souza Silva, Marcelo Vinícius de Paula, Gustavo Fraidenraich, Tárcio André dos Santos Barros
abstract: Accurate photovoltaic (PV) energy yield estimation is essential for feasibility assessment, operational planning, and risk analysis. However, conventional approaches often fail to distinguish the appropriate use of Typical Meteorological Year (TMY) and Specific Meteorological Year (SMY) datasets across different stages of PV project design and operation. To address this gap, this work proposes a two-stage PV modeling methodology that relies exclusively on freely available satellite data and open-source tools. In the first stage, a TMY derived from the SARAH-3 dataset supports feasibility studies, while in the second stage, a SMY corresponding to the initial year of operation enables performance validation. The methodology is benchmarked against the commercial software PVsyst and validated with measured data from a 336.96 kWp rooftop PV system in São Paulo, Brazil. Results show that all configurations satisfied the statistical thresholds established for feasibility and operational analyses, with SMY-based simulations reducing monthly RMSE and MAE by more than 3 percentage points and shifting MBE by over 1.7 percentage points compared to TMY. These findings demonstrate the complementary role of TMY and SMY datasets, where TMY supports long-term feasibility assessments, and SMY provides accurate operational validation within a fully accessible and cost-free PV modeling framework.

title: Extended Gate FET Biosensor for Rapid Monitoring of Living Drugs
authors: Isli Cela, Trang-Anh Nguyen-Le, Christin Neuber, Željko Janićijević, Liliana Rodrigues Loureiro, Anja Feldmann, Michael Bachmann, Larysa Baraban
abstract: The new era of living drugs has increased the demand for innovative ways to monitor their presence in vivo. We present a label-free sensor for sensitive detection of immunotherapeutic drugs in serum. We developed an extended gate sensor based on a single commercial field effect transistor (FET), reducing the cost of the overall device. The sensing component consists of an in-house fabricated chip of 32 gold electrodes on glass, which combined with the electronic multiplexing and readout modules, allows for simultaneous data acquisition. The sensor was utilized for detection of a bispecific molecule, called the Target Module (TM), a crucial component of the Universal CAR (UniCAR) system, a safer module of the adaptive CAR T-cell therapy. We utilized the sensor to screen TMs of different sizes through a versatile functionalized layer that resourcefully aims to minimize the Debye screening length effect. The detection of the TMs was achieved in buffer and serum at the femtomolar level, significantly below the limit of the standard colorimetric technique ELISA. Additionally, we utilized the same system to track the presence of the TMs in mouse serum over time. The recorded data showed an expected shorter half-life for the smaller TM (scFv TM 32 kDa) as compared to the bigger TM (IgG4 TM 112 kDa). These results were comparable with the radioactivity data circumventing the need for radioactive labelling. Overall, we demonstrate a promising application of low-cost, label-free, and accurate extended gate (EG)-FET biosensor for immunotherapeutic drug monitoring and dose adjustment.

title: Research on SSA-SVM Circuit Breaker Fault Diagnosis Method Based on the Fusion of VMD Closing and Opening Energy Entropy and Temporal Characteristics
authors: Shaoyu Chen, Yong Jiang, Zhenli Liang, Yang Feng, Yajun Wu, Yangfei Zhou, Mengke Huang, Wei Ran
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: In response to the problem of low accuracy in fault diagnosis of high-voltage circuit breakers with a single feature domain or single process signal, this paper proposes an SSA-SVM circuit breaker fault diagnosis method based on variational mode decomposition (VMD) fusion of closing and opening energy entropy and temporal characteristics. Firstly, the vibration signal is preprocessed using wavelet soft thresholding method; Secondly, in the time domain, collision specific points are determined based on the mechanism of circuit breaker closing and opening actions, and temporal characteristics are extracted as temporal characteristics quantities. In the time-frequency domain, VMD is used to decompose the closing and opening vibration signals, and the energy entropy of each intrinsic mode function (IMF) is obtained through Hilbert transform. The closing and opening energy entropy is fused with temporal characteristics as the feature vector for fault diagnosis; Finally, the sparrow search algorithm (SSA) is used to optimize the parameters of the support vector machine (SVM) and determine the optimal parameters for the fault diagnosis model. Taking LW30-126 circuit breaker with CT26 spring operating mechanism as the research object, 9 types of circuit breaker states were simulated, and different degrees of faults and coupling faults were set for the same fault type. The vibration signals during the closing and opening process were collected and feature vectors were extracted. The feature vectors were input into the SSA-SVM diagnostic model for fault classification. Experimental data showed that the fault recognition accuracy of our method reached 99.2%. Compared with single feature domain and single process signal features, our method has better performance in diagnosing circuit breaker fault types.

title: An IoT and Deep Learning Model for Prediction and Training Systems of Throwing Action
authors: Nan Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Recent Internet of Things (IoT) advances result to the most promising paradigm called Military Throwing Action Prediction and Training systems. These industries are considered the strong merger of the activity with the IoT objects. In Prediction and Training systems, specifically the Military throwing such as grenades requires strong trustworthy guesses and demands thoughtful focus on the reliable trustworthy improvisation. Yet, current systems are genuinely relays on the mainstream approaches that may produce unsteady performances. These methods may lead to the high misclassification ratio that even undermine the training findings. To overcome this problem, this paper proposes the novel IoT enabled Throwing Action Prediction and Training systems which ensembles powerful SKIP GRU, Attention and Extreme feedforward neural networks (EFNN). The thorough experiments were conducted with real-world datasets/testbed and compared against other state-of-the-art trust learning models using various metrics, including accuracy, precision, recall, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex>-score, etc. The findings indicate the applicability of the proposed model, and it has consistently outperformed the existing models: 0.99 accuracy, 0.98 precision, 0.97 recall, and 0.98 F1-score, which demonstrates its strong potential for developing intelligent Throwing Action Prediction and Training systems that can be customized for Training Military Throwing Action.

title: Systematic Errors in Non-Ideal ASTM D5470 Measurements
authors: Andrés E. Becerra, Daniel Ramírez
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: The ASTM D5470 test method for the determination of thermal resistance and thermal conductivity of thermal interface materials (TIMs) is gaining broader industrial adoption, both during R&D efforts and in quality control. This test method assumes perfectly unidirectional heat flow from a heat source to a heat sink through two reference bars sandwiching a specimen. Perfect alignment and planarity are further assumed. The impact of deviations from this ideal scenario are studied here with the goal of guiding users on instrument use, maintenance and troubleshooting.This work quantifies, through modeling, the systematic errors introduced by: (1) imperfect reference bar insulation; (2) imperfect reference bar alignment; (3) imperfections in the reference bars due to wear; and (4) specimen overflow.High systematic errors in thermal resistance measurements are predicted in cases with reference bar tilt misalignment, reference bar angled face wear or specimen overflow, while reference bar shift misalignment and edge wear have smaller impact. Only specimen overflow is found to impact the determination of bulk thermal conductivity from resistance vs. thickness measurements. Experimental results validate the significant impact of specimen overflow and tilt misalignment. Caution with automated measurements of Type I materials is warranted, as are periodic parallelism checks.

title: Instruction Frequency-Based ALU Simplification on RISC-V for TinyML
authors: Yosuke Asai, Wai Leong Pang, Hui Hwang Goh
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: TinyML has gained significant attention for enabling machine learning inference on edge devices with limited resources. In such contexts, minimizing power consumption and chip area is critical. This study focuses on optimizing the Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU) in RISC-V, leveraging its open-source and highly modular architecture. An analysis of the impact of instruction usage frequency guides the optimization. An extensive simulation was carried out. A sine wave prediction model was trained and implemented on an RISC-V system using a C program. Instruction usage was profiled using the Spike simulator. The design was synthesized and evaluated on an Xilinx Artix-7 FPGA using Vivado, resulting in a 27% reduction in Look-Up Table (LUT) usage and a 13% reduction in static power. These results highlight the potential of application-driven optimization through instruction profiling in enhancing RISC-V architectures for TinyML applications.

title: Anomaly Detection Frameworks and Trends in Vehicular Ad-Hoc Networks (VANETs)
authors: K. Nikhil Reddy, K. Hosmitha, K. Srividya, M.A. Jabbar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Intelligent Transportation Systems play a key role in many crucial operations. These operations are supported by Vehicular Ad Hoc Networks (VANETs), which facilitate communication between infrastructure and automobiles. But as they are dynamic and decentralized, they are vulnerable to a range of security risks and unusual activity. Particularly in situations with limited data availability and high mobility, traditional rule-based or single layer machine learning (ML) techniques have demonstrated limited efficacy in detecting such intricate, dynamic threats. The recent developments in anomaly detection for VANETs are examined in this review, with an emphasis on hybrid model approaches that combine rule-based, machine learning, and deep learning methodologies. This paper also investigates the use of GenVRAM and other synthetic datasets, hierarchical detection architectures, and the efficiency of merging models at various network layers. For improved VANET security, the paper contrasts current methods, identifies important issues like latency and data scarcity, and suggests future directions like federated anomaly detection and adaptive learning.

title: Towards Novel Gesture Recognition for Real-Time Code Generation in Extended Reality
authors: Clare E. Heinbaugh, Per Ola Kristensson
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Advances in code generation using large language models (LLMs) enable novel virtual reality (VR) interactions defined at runtime [4]. Further, gestures allow users to express intent in VR, often with a metaphoric correspondence to a real-life object or action [16], [14]. In this paper, we propose a system that allows users to define novel gestures with metaphoric significance to inform real-time code generation in extended reality. The system enables the articulation of novel gestures to trigger novel interactions on-the-fly. Such a system can potentially enable more flexible experiences for users as the system can provide appropriate gesture interaction tools for specific contexts of use. However, to fully realize this vision requires tackling three challenges: (1) online gesture recognition; (2) the tradeoff between scene context and creative ambiguity; and (3) limitations of LLMs.

title: Measurement of Thermal Impedance in Heterogeneous Media
authors: Lucas Oelkers, Rachel McAfee, Adam Wilson, Michael Fish, Patrick J. Shamberger
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: The measurement of thermal impedance can be used to understand the thermal performance of a thermal management system (TMS) under transient thermal loads and can isolate the role of melting in a phase change composite (PCC) systems. Accurate measurement of thermal impedance under transient thermal loads of a heterogeneous media is critical for evaluating the thermal performance of complex systems, such as those encountered in power electronic devices. The study presents a systematic framework to measure and interpret thermal impedance in heterogeneous PCCs with varying operating conditions, including duty factor, on-time, heat flux, air temperature, and thermal loads. Various reference scenarios are examined to isolate the role of melting, and a framework for directly comparing experimentally determined thermal performance characteristics in TMSs was determined. Key concepts such as developing convergence criteria in experimental testing, defining appropriate factors within the uncertainty of the measurement, and identifying sources of variability are discussed. The results highlight that including a phase change within a TMS can induce a $0.11^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \cdot \mathrm{W}^{-1}$ decrease in junction temperature at 10 s, with a decrease in junction temperature between 0.5 and 50 s. This work establishes a foundation for optimizing composite PCM-based TMS in nextgeneration power electronic systems.

title: Decision Support System Based on Association Rule Mining for Student Career Planning
authors: Miao Yu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Recently, effective career planning has become crucial for students to align themselves with their academic performance, interests, and future opportunities. However, existing systems mainly focus on either classroom engagement analysis or academic achievement independently, which leads to a lack of actionable and long-term career guidance. Hence, this study proposes a decision-support system based on Association Rule Mining (DSS-ARM) for student career planning. The proposed DSS-ARM integrates real-time classroom engagement, academic records, and student interest data to generate personalized and explainable career recommendations. Initially, input data were collected from classroom monitoring systems, academic databases, and student-provided surveys. Then, the data were preprocessed with data cleaning, integration, discretization, and encoding using median imputation, key-based join, equal-frequency binning, and one-hot encoding, respectively, to transform the raw data into a structured form for mining patterns. ARM then employs the Frequent Pattern Growth (FP-Growth) algorithm to identify meaningful patterns linking engagement and performance to potential career paths. Furthermore, rule validation and pruning use cross-validation and lift-based pruning to ensure interpretable rules. Finally, the rule-based DSS generates personalized recommendations and incorporates feedback for continuous system improvement. The proposed DSS-ARM established a higher accuracy (89.32%) than the existing Random Forest (RF) model.

title: Thermal Aware Floorplan Methodology Considering Heat Transfer Coefficient of Package to SOC Power Scenario
authors: Youngsang Cho, Heonwoo Kim, Haerim Kim, Hyunhee Kim, Seungwook Yoon, Ilryong Kim
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: In the design process of a semiconductor chip, comparing the thermal characteristics based on floorplan placement typically involves a process. It takes a certain amount of time to apply the thermal analysis results to the chip design. The previous paper, [1]"Thermal Aware Floorplan Optimization of SOC” 2023 ITherm, explains a method where designers can immediately check the temperature characteristics based on floorplan placement and apply them to the design in real-time, using a thermal resistance matrix for internal chip areas without needing to request a simulation [2, 8]. An issue was discovered where the error between the Computational Fluid Dynamics(CFD) simulation temperature data and the temperature data calculated using the Thermal Resistance Matrix(TRM) increased as the power in the scenario increased. As power increases, the airflow on the surface of the application accelerates, increasing convective heat transfer, which in turn reduces the junction-to-ambient thermal resistance compared to the initial state. This paper defines a range of power scenarios applicable in a mobile phone environment and analyzes the method of reducing errors by comparing the changes in thermal resistance in the chip’s floorplan areas.

title: Study on IES Optimal Operation Considering Demand Response and CHP Heat-Power Decoupling
authors: Buwei Ou, He Yang, Xin Huang, Zijian Pan, Bensheng Zheng, Junyu You
publish: 2025 International Power and Sustainable Energy Technologies Conference (PSETC)
abstract: To address the flexibility challenges from high renewable penetration, this paper proposes an Integrated Energy System (IES) operational model that co-optimizes supply-side (via CHP heat-power decoupling) and demand-side (via demand response) flexibility. Within a tiered carbon trading framework, the model targets the dual objectives of economic efficiency and low-carbon performance. Case studies demonstrate that while individual flexibility measures offer limited benefits, their synergistic co-optimization yields a transformative improvement, achieving a 14.4% reduction in total cost and 100% wind power accommodation. The research confirms that coordinating supply and demand-side flexibility is the critical pathway toward economic and low-carbon IES operation

title: Chronoamperometry with Room-Temperature Ionic Liquids: Sub-Second Inference Techniques
authors: Kordel K. France
abstract: Chronoamperometry (CA) is a fundamental electrochemical technique used for quantifying redox-active species. However, in room-temperature ionic liquids (RTILs), the high viscosity and slow mass transport often lead to extended measurement durations. This paper presents a novel mathematical regression approach that reduces CA measurement windows to under 1 second, significantly faster than previously reported methods, which typically require 1–4 seconds or longer. By applying an inference algorithm to the initial transient current response, this method accurately predicts steady-state electrochemical parameters without requiring additional hardware modifications. The approach is validated through comparison with standard chronoamperometric techniques and is demonstrated to maintain reasonable accuracy while dramatically reducing data acquisition time. The implications of this technique are explored in analytical chemistry, sensor technology, and battery science, where rapid electrochemical quantification is critical. Our technique is focused on enabling faster multiplexing of chronoamperometric measurements for rapid olfactory and electrochemical analysis.

title: Influence of tactile presence and body ownership on virtual stroking pleasantness
authors: Shoichi Hasegawa, Rikuto Sagehashi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: The rise of social Virtual Reality brings reports of pseudosensations like touch experienced without physical stimuli. How factors like body ownership influence the pleasantness of such virtual affective experiences remains unclear. This work investigates the influence of concurrent physical tactile stimulation and the sense of body ownership on the perceived pleasantness of having one’s avatar arm stroked in VR. Fourteen participants stroked their avatar’s arm under two conditions (Visual-Only, Visual-Tactile) and rated pleasantness. Results suggest participants with strong body ownership perceived pleasantness even in the Visual-Only condition. In contrast, those with weak ownership relied heavily on actual touch. These findings indicate that body ownership critically modulates affective touch perception in VR. When ownership is strong, visual input can partially substitute tactile input.

title: Enhancing Thermal Management through Deep Learning-Based Analysis of Bubble Dynamics in Flow Boiling
authors: Forouzan Naderi, Farshad Barghi Golezani, Chirag Kharangate
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Bubble dynamics are essential in thermal management systems, especially in flow boiling, where precise monitoring of void fraction (VOF) and bubble properties enhances thermal system efficiency. This study introduces a machine learning framework utilizing Mask R-CNN for accurate bubble segmentation in experimental flow boiling images under top-wall heating circumstances. High-speed imaging data from boiling tests were utilized to train and evaluate the model, resulting in a pixelwise F 1 -score of 0.68, precision of 0.71, and recall of 0.67. These measures confirm the model’s efficacy in segmenting bubbles of diverse sizes and shapes in various flow settings. The segmented data were further processed for the calculation of VOF, which enabled far-reaching studies of bubble distribution and development under various heat conditions. This research couples some of the latest segmentation algorithms with realworld data in order to develop a robust approach toward realtime identification of bubbles and estimation of their VOF for the enhancement of designing more efficient thermal management systems. Thus, the presented methodology can be adapted to very precise tasks, improving the understanding of the flow boiling process and enabling energy-efficient cooling devices.

title: Single-Phase Common-Ground Transformerless Photovoltaic Microinverter
authors: Alan Santana Felinto, Jean Torelli Cardoso, Cursino Brandão Jacobina, Jose Allan Pedrosa da Silva, Jhonatan Moreira Macedo
abstract: This article proposes a transformerless inverter where the grid, the converter and the solar photovoltaic (PV) module share a common-ground connection. It is composed of a boost dc-dc converter cascaded with a half-bridge inverter. The novelty of this converter relies in the connection of the grid with the half bridge and the filter employed in this interface. It is employed a series LC filter between the inverter and the grid in order to eliminate the de component of the grid current. In addition, the common ground connection allows an operation without leakage current due to the bypass of the PV parasite capacitance. Converter model and control strategy is provided as well simulation and experimental results. The proposed inverter is compared with conventional common-ground topologies in terms of semiconductor losses, total harmonic distortion of the grid current and number of components. Compared with the conventional solutions, the proposed converter presents a reduced number of semiconductor devices and reduced conduction losses.

title: LongAct: A Dataset for Motion Generation from Long-Term Multi-Action Text Descriptions
authors: Jeong Yeon Lee, Soung Sill Park, Young Ho Chai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Text-to-motion is a research field that generates human body motion sequences from detailed textual descriptions of actions. It is useful for quickly generating avatar motions that can be efficiently applied to a wide range of content. However, most existing methods struggle to generate long sequences involving multiple types of actions. To address this limitation, we propose LongAct, a new dataset constructed by connecting multiple human motion segments. We evaluate LongAct on the task of generating long human motion sequences. Both quantitative and qualitative results demonstrate that our dataset enables the generation of natural and coherent motion sequences in long sequence multi-action scenarios. https://github.com/YeonYeonni/LongAct

title: A Mixed Reality Framework for Acupoint Therapy Teaching: Localization, Practice and Evaluation
authors: Jiacheng Liu, Bohan Chen, Weichao Song, Fangfei Ye, Haibin Ling, Bingyao Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Acupoint therapy is an essential therapeutic method in Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM), and it requires precise acupoint localization and manipulation skills. Existing Mixed Reality (MR) systems often fall short in real-time acupoint detection and visualization, comprehensive simulated practice, and evaluation standards. To overcome these limitations, we introduce a framework for acupoint therapy teaching. It provides real-time full-body acupoint detection and visualization, guided simulated practice for complex acupuncture and moxibustion techniques, and a novel TCM theory-based standard for user performance evaluation. A user study confirms that our system improves users’ 3D acupoint localization and procedural proficiency compared to traditional textbook-based methods.

title: Inverter for Three-Phase and Single-Phase Operation With Active Ripple Control
authors: Thiago Fonseca Rech, Victor Ferreira Gruner, Roberto Francisco Coelho, Marcelo Lobo Heldwein
abstract: Grid-interfacing inverters are more attractive when configurable for both single- and three-phase operation. Few high-performance systems currently provide such reconfigurability. This work proposes a topology enabling single- and threephase grid-tied operation. In single-phase mode, one inverter leg functions as an Active Ripple Control Circuit (ARRC), mitigating the double-line-frequency ripple inherent to the DC-bus voltage due to the instantaneous power mismatch between input and output. In three-phase mode, the inverter achieves enhanced performance across diverse applications, including low commonmode transformerless systems. Interesting simulation results are presented and discussed to validate the proposed power and control structures.

title: Development of a Self-Powered Photovoltaic Module Characterizer Without Current Sensor
authors: Luis Antônio Gregório Lopes, Luis Gustavo Teixeira Campos, Paulo Henrique Souza Ferreira, Victor Pellanda Dardengo, Heverton Augusto Pereira
abstract: This work presents a prototype of a photovoltaic (PV) module characterizer based on the capacitive load method. The system is controlled by a Gate Driver circuit managed by an ESP32 microcontroller, which records voltage measurements during the capacitor charging process and calculates the corresponding current signal. Unlike conventional approaches that employ both current and voltage sensors, the proposed method uses only a voltage sensor. This not only reduces the overall cost and complexity of the equipment but also minimizes issues related to current sensor accuracy and noise, particularly at low sampling speeds. Additionally, the device is self-powered-requiring neither a battery nor an external power source-which makes it suitable for field applications. Experimental tests performed with a Jinko JJM330P module showed strong agreement between the results obtained from the characterizer and those measured using a reference oscilloscope.

title: SlowFast-Flow: A New no Reference Metric for Video Shakiness Quality Assessment
authors: Borhen-Eddine Dakkar, Azeddine Beghdadi, Aladine Chetouani, Stefania Colonnese
publish: 2025 13th European Workshop on Visual Information Processing (EUVIP)
abstract: The rise of devices equipped with cameras resulted in a remarkable surge in user-generated content (UGC) videos to be shared on various platforms and applications. UGC videos suffers from shakiness, due to unsTable cameras hold, and this has boosted the development of video stabilization algorithms. The development of evaluation metrics has received comparatively less attention, and the existing metrics do not address the challenges posed by shakiness distortions. To fill this gap, we propose a novel no-reference metric based on deep neural network to evaluate the perceptual quality of shakiness in UGC videos. We extract spatial and temporal features using SlowFast network reinforce them by integrating optical flow features obtained by the Inflated 3D ConvNet network. The attributes of the two networks were integrated and passed through regression layers to generate the final shakiness quality score, referred to as the SlowFast-Flow metric. Comprehensive experiments confirm that the SlowFast-Flow metric outperforms state-of-the-art. The codes of the SlowFast-Flow are available at https://github.com/dborhen/SlowFast_Flow_VQA.git

title: A Novel Approach to Test Case Reduction Based on Test Path and Data Composition
authors: Hongbo Wang, Sheng Chen, Yufei Du, Xiaolong Chang, Tianzhe Qi, Hongbin Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: With the wide application of formal modelling methods in the testing of autonomous systems such as unmanned ground vehicles(UGVs), the use of formal modelling of UGVs and other autonomous systems to generate test cases has become an important means of improving the reliability of UGVs and other autonomous systems, and this method of generating test cases ensures that the generated test cases comprehensively cover the different testing requirements of the system. However, the generated test cases may contain redundant paths and test data, leading to inefficient testing and increased computational costs. Therefore, test case approximation becomes a necessary optimisation tool. In this paper, we propose a test case approximation method based on the combination of test paths and data. Firstly, by simplifying the redundant test paths generated by the state machine diagrams in the formal modelling of autonomous systems such as UGV, it ensures that the number of state transfers that can be covered by the simplified set of test paths is consistent with that covered by the original test paths, and avoids repetitive testing. Secondly, by optimising the test parameter space generated by the module definition graphs and test paths in the formal modelling of autonomous systems such as UGV, redundant test data are removed, thus reducing unnecessary computation. The approximation method proposed in this paper not only ensures the coverage and diversity of the original test cases, but also improves the execution efficiency of the tests, providing a new optimisation idea for the testing of autonomous unmanned systems.

title: Crypto-Compression of Color Images Based on Paillier's Cryptosystem
authors: Norman Hutte, Pauline Puteaux, William Puech
publish: 2025 13th European Workshop on Visual Information Processing (EUVIP)
abstract: An increasing amount of multimedia data, including images, is being transmitted over networks and stored in the Cloud. This data requires both compression and security measures. In this paper, we present a new method based on Paillier's cryptosystem applied to images in order to perform homomorphic encryption, and compress them without loss of information. This allows us to reduce the size expansion between plain and encrypted messages, which by default is greater than 2 bits. Our method is based on an analysis of the random values of the parameter <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$r$</tex> of the cryptosystem, in order to find encrypted values whose least significant bits (LSB) are equal to 0. Then we exploit this by removing k LSB par block to compress the encrypted image. This method is fully reversible, as we just need to add the previously removed LSB during the decryption phase, thus recovering the original image without any loss to quality. Experimental results show that our method can be applied to color images with large pixel block sizes.

title: A Simulation Study of Impact of Defect Configuration at Die-Attach Solder Joint on LED Performance and Applicability of MIL-STD-883
authors: Erik Sorensen, Roy Luo
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: The impact of defect configuration at die-attached solder joint on UV LED performance is studied by using Computation Fluid Dynamic (CFD) modeling. In this work, four types of solder joint void configurations are simulated: Type-I, A single large void located under the center of the die; Type- II, A single large void located under the corner of the LED die; TypeIII, multiple small voids with the same total area as Type-I and II void, but evenly distributed under the LED die; Type-IV, a single void located in one quadrant of the die. Simulation results show that for a given void size, type-II void causes the most significant hot spot, leading to the highest LED junction temperature ($\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{j}}$). Type-III void, on the other hand, demonstrates the lowest $\mathbf{T}_{\mathbf{j}}$. A further study of void configuration on LED reliability is conducted with respect to the widely used MIL-STD-883 in the microcircuit industry. It is concluded that LEDs demonstrate a similar lifetime as expected from the LED die manufacturers, under the condition that die-attach void levels meet the MIL-STD-883 standard, regardless the void types. This result suggests that MIL-STD-883 can be safely utilized for LED die-attach process qualification.

title: Prediction and Optimization of Fire Protection Performance of Bridge Cables Based on Machine Learning
authors: Yuwen Ning
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Fire resistance of bridge cables is critical for structural safety, but conventional evaluation relies on costly and time-consuming experiments that fail to capture multi-parameter coupling effects. This study develops a machine learning-based predictive and optimization framework integrating ensemble learning and multi-objective optimization to evaluate cable fire performance under diverse fire scenarios. The proposed model achieved a test-set <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R 2}$</tex> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 9 6 3}$</tex> with a mean absolute error of 83 s in predicting the limiting oxygen temperature (LOT). Optimization with gradient fireproof coatings extended the fire resistance by 38.7 % at the critical failure temperature of 620° C, while reducing material usage and cost. The framework provides an efficient and reliable tool for dynamic assessment and design optimization of cable fire protection, offering practical guidance for intelligent fire safety engineering.

title: A Novelty Single-Phase to Three-Phase Converter for PV Panel Grid Connection
authors: Arthur P. Da Costa, Cursino B. Jacobina, Brenda Mayra Da S. Pereira, Arthur De Queiroz T. B. Mesquita, Douglas De S. Sesion, Reuben Palmer R. De Sousa
abstract: This paper presents a power conversion solution for the integration of single-phase cascaded H-bridge (CHB) photovoltaic (PV) systems into the three-phase grid. The proposed topology employs a four-leg converter, comprising a conventional three-leg shunt structure and an additional leg connected in series with one grid phase. This configuration enables both series and shunt compensation, ensuring stable grid integration with unity power factor, even under partial shading and nonlinear load conditions. In contrast to direct CHB-to-grid connections, the converter improves system reliability by mitigating phase imbalance, harmonic distortion, and voltage sags. The topology is also capable of isolating the PV system during grid disturbances and selectively delivering only active power to the grid while powering local nonlinear loads. These features make it a suitable interface for modern PV applications, where power quality and fault tolerance are critical.

title: Concept Design of a Confined, Direct Two-Phase Jet Impingement Cooler with Phase Separation of Low-Surface-Tension Fluids
authors: Gopinath Sahu, Ketan Yogi, Tiwei Wei, Justin A. Weibel
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Jet impingement, enhanced by evaporation and boiling from a porous wick structure, has potential for dissipating high heat fluxes. This study investigates the enhancement of twophase jet impingement cooling using capillary-driven boiling and proposes a concept design to address the challenges associated with two-phase operation, including pressure fluctuations, surface temperature oscillations, and premature critical heat flux. A novel manifold design is proposed, featuring a three-path manifold with distributed liquid inlets, liquid outlets, and vapor outlets. The integration of porous wick structures on the surface increases the availability of nucleation sites that promote boiling and evaporation throughout the evaporator. Embedded tunnels within the wick facilitate liquid bypass to the liquid outlets and act as an integrated liquid reservoir for capillary wicking to the porous regions. Whereas vapor generated during boiling in the wick exits through dedicated vapor outlets to achieve phase-separation. The tunnel spacing is optimized to ensure a sufficient capillary wicking length in the wick structure to avoid dry out at high heat flux operation, even for low-surface-tension dielectric coolants used in electronics cooling. A reduced-order model was developed to assess the thermo-hydraulic performance of the proposed system under various flow rates and heat flux conditions, using R1233zd as the working fluid. The manifold and wick dimensions were designed to maintain a target pressure drop of 40 kPa and heat flux of $500 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}$. This work demonstrates an energy-efficient, low-cost, and package-integrated two-phase jet impingement cooler optimized for minimal pressure drop and maximum thermal performance. By addressing challenges such as phase separation and manufacturing constraints, the proposed design offers a scalable and robust solution for managing extreme thermal loads in high-performance applications.

title: A Stretchable, Skin-Adhesive FBG-based Wearable Sensor for Human Health Monitoring: from Vital Signs to Biomechanical Activity
authors: I. Condò, S. M. Giannitelli, M. Trombetta, E. Schena, D. Lo Presti
abstract: Wearable technologies enhance the accuracy of health monitoring, but ensuring at the same time user comfort remains a significant challenge. Flexible strain sensors have emerged as promising candidates for this task, thanks to their ability to conform to the body and capture subtle biomechanical signals. Among these, sensors based on fiber Bragg gratings (FBGs) offer advantages such as high sensitivity, flexibility, compactness, multiplexing capabilities, and immunity to electromagnetic interference. However, most FBG-based flexible sensors require external adhesives or fixations to maintain contact with the skin, which can limit comfort, usability, and reliability of collected data. This study introduces an innovative bilayer wearable (BW) sensor that integrates a single FBG within a stretchable silicone structure combined with a self-adhesive silicone layer. The device can be directly attached to the skin without any additional support, ensuring stable and comfortable wear even during motion. This work details the fabrication process and metrological characterization of the BW sensor exhibiting repeatable behavior under strain and low hysteresis across a wide range of traction speeds. Preliminary tests on healthy volunteers confirmed the sensor’s capability to be applied in biomedical scenarios ranging from vital signs monitoring to biomechanics. In particular, BW was able to accurately detect respiratory and heart rates, as well as joint movement and muscle contraction.
