The combination of soft adhesion and optical sensing performance makes the proposed BW sensor a promising tool for real-time, reliable health monitoring.

title: OFDM-Based Positioning with Unknown Data Payloads: Bounds and Applications to LEO PNT
authors: Andrew M. Graff, Todd E. Humphreys
abstract: This paper presents bounds, estimators, and signal design strategies for exploiting both known pilot resources and unknown data payload resources in time-of-arrival (TOA)-based positioning systems with orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM) signals. It is the first to derive the Ziv-Zakai bound (ZZB) on TOA estimation for OFDM signals containing both known pilot and unknown data resources. In comparison to the Cram´er-Rao bounds (CRBs) derived in prior work, this ZZB captures the low-signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) thresholding effects in TOA estimation and accounts for an unknown carrier phase. The derived ZZB is evaluated against CRBs and empirical TOA error variances. It is then evaluated on signals with resource allocations optimized for pilot-only TOA estimation, quantifying the performance gain over the best-case pilot-only signal designs. Finally, the positioning accuracy of maximum-likelihood and decision-directed estimators is evaluated on simulated low-Earth-orbit non-terrestrial-network channels and compared against their respective ZZBs.

title: Toward Better De-Raining Generalization via Rainy Characteristics Memorization and Replay_supp1-3631072.pdf
authors: Xueyang Fu
abstract: Current image de-raining methods primarily learn from a limited dataset, leading to inadequate performance in varied real-world rainy conditions. To tackle this, we introduce a new framework that enables networks to progressively expand their de-raining knowledge base by tapping into a growing pool of datasets, significantly boosting their adaptability. Drawing inspiration from the human brain’s ability to continually absorb and generalize from ongoing experiences, our approach borrows the mechanism of the complementary learning system. Specifically, we first deploy generative adversarial networks (GANs) to capture and retain the unique features of new data, mirroring the hippocampus’s role in learning and memory. Then, the de-raining network is trained with both existing and GAN-synthesized data, mimicking the process of hippocampal replay and interleaved learning. Furthermore, we employ knowledge distillation with the replayed data to replicate the synergy between the neocortex’s activity patterns triggered by hippocampal replays and the preexisting neocortical knowledge. This comprehensive framework empowers the de-raining network to accumulate knowledge from various datasets, continually enhancing its performance on previously unseen rainy scenes. Our testing on three benchmark de-raining networks confirms the framework’s effectiveness. It not only facilitates continual knowledge accumulation across six datasets but also surpasses state-of-the-art methods in generalizing to new real-world scenarios. Our code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/wangkunyu241/CLGID</uri>

title: A Step-Up Inductorless 11-level Boosting Inverter with Lower Standing Voltage and Limited Input Spike Current
authors: Hossein Mansourizadeh, Majid Hosseinpour, Ali Seifi
abstract: Switched-capacitor multilevel inverters (SCMLIs) have recently attracted increasing attention for medium-power applications due to their inductor- and transformer-less operation, high efficiency, and compact power density. However, many existing SCMLI topologies suffer from limited scalability caused by the large number of semiconductor devices, high voltage stress, severe inrush current, and high cost. This study aims to design and implement a single-source 11-level step-up inverter that significantly reduces the component count by employing only nine switches, four diodes, and four capacitors, while limiting the total standing voltage (TSV) to 5.4V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</sub> and the inrush current to 4I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</sub>. In the proposed method, a level-shifted modulation algorithm requires only six control signals, and an optimized capacitor charging/discharging sequence effectively reduces the longest discharge period (LDP), keeping the voltage ripple of each capacitor below 3.5%. The research methodology includes detailed modeling, analysis of voltage and current stresses, capacitor sizing, and loss evaluation through MATLAB/Simulink simulations, followed by the experimental validation of a 300 W laboratory prototype. Both simulation and experimental results confirm that the proposed inverter achieves a voltage gain of 2.5, an output voltage THD of about 6.7%, and a peak efficiency of 98.39% at 300 W, with well-balanced stress distribution among semiconductor devices. A comparative study with recent SCMLI structures demonstrates that the proposed topology, while maintaining high efficiency, achieves the lowest TSV, the smallest number of components, and strong potential for extension to higher voltage and power levels.

title: Impact of High-Reflectivity Wall Coatings on Non-Line-of-Sight Visible Light Communication Channels
authors: Mauro Biagi
abstract: This work investigates the impact of high-reflectivity wall coatings on the performance of NLOS VLC channels. We extend conventional models by incorporating measured Bidirectional Reflectance Distribution Function (BRDF) data to better represent real-world surface behaviors. A comprehensive analysis is conducted through simulations that assess key channel parameters, including received signal strength, delay spread, and achievable data rates. The results demonstrate that specialized coatings significantly enhance NLOS performance, improving signal coverage while moderately affecting multipath dispersion. Unlike prior BRDF-based studies focusing on single-surface cases, this letter provides a systematic, material-aware comparison (ρ =0.60–0.99) that jointly maps SNR, delay spread, and ISI-aware capacity, yielding quantitative design guidelines for NLOS VLC in real rooms.

title: HHO-Based Energy-Efficient Routing Protocol with Neural Network Clustering for IoT Sensor Networks
authors: P. Nagarathna, Chennaiah Madduri, Raed Hameed, Ramesh. K, E. Shalini
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Over the last few years, routing protocols for Internet of Things (IoT) sensor networks have gained significant attention due to their essential role in increasing the network lifespan to ensure reliable data delivery in resource-constrained environments. However, the existing Neural Network Clustering Particle Swarm Optimization Routing (NNC-PSOR) faces suboptimal cluster head selection, lack of Quality of Service (QoS) awareness, and high randomness in routing, resulting in reduced efficiency in large-scale and dynamic IoT scenarios. This research proposed a Neural Network Clustering-Harris Hawks Optimization Multi Objective Routing (NNC-HHO-MOR) protocol. Initially, the environmental data and residual energy information is collected from the sensor nodes. Next, Neural Network based Clustering (NNC) is applied to form clusters of sensor nodes. Furthermore, Harris Hawks Optimization (HHO) is employed for the selection of the most suitable cluster heads through a multi objective fitness function. Moreover, HHO is applied for QoS-aware routing from cluster heads to the sink, thereby optimizing the path, reliability, latency, and energy consumption. Finally, adaptive parameter tuning is applied to dynamically adjust the HHO search parameters based on the current network conditions. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed NNC-HHO-MOR protocol improves the network lifetime with 97% accuracy and 98% energy consumption.

title: Experimental Characterization of a Low Thermal Resistance Microchannel Heatsink Utilizing Low GWP Refrigerant for High Power GPU Applications
authors: David J. Apigo, Sarwesh N. Parbat, Haotian Jia, Haoyun Qiu, Pouya Kabirzadeh, Manohar Bongarala, Syed Faisal, Rishav Roy, Nenad Miljkovic, Todd Salamon
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Increased demand from AI/ML applications has led to a drastic rise in the thermal design power (TDP) of the latest GPUs, with chipsets exceeding 1000 W of heat dissipation. Traditional air-cooling technologies cannot efficiently cool these components at expected workloads and liquid cooling solutions have become necessary, especially to improve energy efficiency in datacenters. However, as chips become more power hungry, the limit of these cooling solutions will also be realized. Two-phase cooling offers higher heat transfer coefficients by utilizing the latent heat of vaporization as the fluid undergoes a phase change from liquid to vapor and thus provides an attractive approach for cooling higher power chips. The experiments reported here utilize two-phase flow boiling in high-aspect-ratio (20:1) copper microchannel heatsinks with $76 \times 76 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}$ footprint to cool power levels expected from some of the recently announced GPUs ($\geq 1000 W$). A low global warming potential (GWP) refrigerant, R1233zd(E), is used as the working fluid, and the thermofluidic performance of the evaporators is investigated under different mass flow rates of 50, 60, 73, and $90 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{hr}$. Performance at each flow rate is characterized by measuring thermal resistance and pressure drops for heat loads ranging from 100 W to 1100 W while maintaining $1^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ inlet subcooling. The heatsinks demonstrate a total thermal resistance of $R_{\theta} \leq 0.0065 \mathrm{~K} / \mathrm{W}$ at $\geq 1000 \mathrm{~W}$ of total heat load. Such a low thermal resistance enables the capability of a high heat rejection and waste heat capture efficiencies as the working fluid can be supplied at ${71}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, while maintaining a chip backside temperature of $\leq \mathbf{9 0}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. In addition to the low thermal resistance, the heatsink demonstrates low pressure drop at high power ($\leq 3 \mathrm{kPa}$), making it an ideal candidate for pumpless cooling solutions.

title: Direct Visualization of Local Thermal Conductivity and Boundary Conductance of Diamond Particles
authors: Luke Gyubin Min, Heungdong Kwon, Christopher Perez, Mehdi Asheghi, Kenneth E. Goodson
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: The 3D chip integration and packaging of high-power logic and RF devices is constrained by strict junction temperature limits, especially with hot spots exceeding $1 \mathrm{kWcm}^{-2}$. There is an urgent need for cost-effective heat spreaders with thermal conductivities above that of copper. This work proposes the development of a Diamond/Cu Alloy heat spreader by in-situ electroplating copper through diamond particles in the range of 10 to $100 \mu \mathrm{~m}$. The thermal conductivity and boundary conductance of diamond microparticles were investigated using time-domain thermoreflectance (TDTR). Measurement sensitivity was examined by calculating sensitivity coefficients for various fitting methods, and the relationship between these coefficients and the resulting measurement standard deviations was experimentally verified. Measurements were performed on monocrystalline diamond particles of $\sim 70 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ and $\sim 20 \mu \mathrm{~m}$, examining thermal properties at the center and edge. While a significant decrease in thermal conductivity was observed as the measurement spot moved from the center to the edge-suggesting greater phonon scattering near boundaries-this suppression effect may also arise from the fact that the 2 D radial heat conduction model for the TDTR data fitting does not account for the finite geometry of the diamond particle. For $\sim 70 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ and $\sim 20 \mu \mathrm{m}$ particles, the thermal conductivity dropped by 38% and 53%, respectively. The boundary conductance ranged from $187.2 \pm 57.3$ to $191.0 \pm 50.4 \mathrm{MWm}^{-2} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}$, with one outlier ($\sim 20 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ at the edge). High uncertainties remain, partly due to low sensitivity at short time delays. Future work will include simulations to separate boundary scattering effects from boundary conditions and optimize transducer thickness.

title: Fatigue Detection Using Machine Learning Approach
authors: Jordan Chew Ding Jian, Sumendra Yogarayan, Thinesh Ganesan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: Facial expressions are one of the reliable indicators of a person’s physiological state. For drivers, behavioral cues such as lip yawning, eyelid closure, and head movement patterns provide signals of fatigue, which is a leading cause of road accidents worldwide. Fatigue-related crashes often result in severe injuries and fatalities, making early detection an urgent research priority. This study investigates the application of machine learning for real-time driver fatigue detection, where a system that could be practical for everyday use. The Driver Fatigue Dataset (DFD) was utilised, consisting of two categories: "Drowsy" and "Non-Drowsy." Each category contains 9,200 labeled images, totaling 18,400 images. These were used to train and test machine learning models, enabling the system to differentiate between fatigued and normal states. Data preprocessing and feature extraction were applied to improve recognition of facial cues, while classification models were optimized to achieve prediction accuracy. The experimental results demonstrated that the system achieved performance with precise differentiation between drowsy and non-drowsy states, showing potential for real-world deployment. By reliably identifying signs of fatigue, the proposed system can serve as an assistive safety tool, alerting drivers before their drowsiness leads to impaired driving. The findings contribute to the broader goal of reducing accident rates caused by fatigue and improving road safety standards, particularly in regions where driver exhaustion is a significant concern.

title: Blockchain Transaction Anonymity and Identity Authentication Security Based on Zero-Knowledge Proof Algorithm
authors: Shuo Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: This paper proposes a framework that integrates zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs) and verifiable credentials (VCs) to achieve the synergistic optimization of transaction privacy and trusted identity authentication. First, a pseudonymous transaction protocol based on zk-SNARKs (zero-knowledge succinct non-interactive arguments of knowledge) is designed. The R1CS constraint system is used to construct a circuit that hides the transaction amount and address, resulting in a proof that takes up only 1.5 KB. Second, the W3C standard VC is introduced to enable off-chain identity attribute authentication. Users generate a “credential validity proof” using ZKPs and upload the proof along with the transaction to the chain. Finally, smart contracts verify the dual proofs, using Merkle tree aggregation to reduce verification overhead. An innovative “attribute-bound anonymous transaction” model is proposed to dynamically decouple transaction and identity attribute verification. Deployment on the Ethereum testnet demonstrates that this scheme reduces transaction correlation to approximately 0.3 %. Groth16 achieves a throughput of 142 transactions per second (TPS) in 798 ms at a scale of 200,000 gates.

title: Advancing Lunar Communication Through Inter-Domain Space Networks and Dynamic Orchestration
authors: Selen Geçgel Çetin, Barş Dönmez, Güneş Karabulut Kurt
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: The resurgent era of lunar exploration is defined by a strategic shift from temporary visits to a sustained international and commercial presence, resulting in an unprecedented demand for a robust and continuously available communication infrastructure. The conventional direct-to-Earth communication architecture relies on limited and oversubscribed deep space networks, which are further challenged by the radiative environment and insufficient visibility in certain areas of the cislunar domain. We address these issues by proposing a foundational move toward inter-domain space network cooperation by introducing architectures based on near space networks. They can directly service lunar surface users or, via cislunar relays, by forming a resilient and multi-layered communication backbone. First, we establish a unified link analysis framework incorporating frequently disregarded environmental factors, such as the Moon's variable illumination, to provide a high-fidelity performance evaluation. Second, we assess architectures' reliability based on the outage risk, essential for quantifying the operational robustness of communication links. Finally, to manage the inherent dynamism of architectures, we propose an inter-domain space digital twin: a dynamic decision-making engine that performs real-time analysis to autonomously select the best communication path, ensuring high and stable reliability while simultaneously optimizing power consumption. Overall, our paper provides a holistic architectural and conceptual management framework, emphasizing the necessity of lunar communications to support a permanent human and economic foothold on the Moon.

title: Intelligent Indoor Temperature Control Strategy of Intelligent Buildings Based on Deep Learning Algorithm
authors: Rui Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Traditional adaptive temperature control methods face limitations in meeting dynamic indoor environmental demands. This paper proposes an intelligent temperature control system based on deep learning, utilizing historical temperature data and employing data preprocessing alongside a deep learning model to analyze indoor environments and user preferences. The intelligent thermostat consumes 100-150W, significantly lower than traditional thermostats (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\geqslant$</tex> 200W), improving control accuracy and energy efficiency. This study contributes an energy-efficient deep learning-based system, enhancing accuracy and adaptability in smart buildings.

title: Estimating Ground Reaction Force and Gait Cycle Percentage from Wearable Insole Data using Random Forests
authors: Josée Mallah, Yu Zhu, Zibo Zhang, Shaoping Bai, Luigi G. Occhipinti
abstract: Ground reaction force (GRF) and gait phase are two key variables to be monitored for motion analysis or assistive device control. This paper presents two machine learning models based on random forests to estimate the vertical component of the ground reaction force (vGRF) along with the gait cycle percentage (GC%) from insole data, achieving an NRMSE of 4.84% for vGRF and an RMSE of 6.62% for GC%.

title: High Step-Up Ćuk PFC Rectifier Integrated to Gain Cell Based on Coupled Inductor and Voltage Multiplier
authors: Christopher da Fonseca Gonçalves, José A. Anderson, Denizar C. Martins, Lenon Schmitz, Roberto Francisco Coelho
abstract: In this work, an AC-DC converter operating with power factor correction and high voltage gain is proposed and experimentally evaluated. To attain high static gain, the converter utilizes a gain cell formed by a coupled inductor along with voltage multiplier cells applied to the conventional Ćuk rectifier. The topology control is implemented using two control loops: one to maintain the output voltage regulated, and another to ensure the current drawn from the power grid is sinusoidal and in phase with the voltage, thus achieving power factor correction. The prototype built for laboratory testing was evaluated under different operating conditions, with variations in load and input voltage. Designed to operate at a nominal power of 250 W, the converter achieves an output voltage of 2500 V, efficiency of 90%, and current harmonic distortion of 4.45%.

title: Towards Embodied Conversational Agents for Reducing Oral Exam Anxiety in Extended Reality
authors: Jens Grubert, Yvonne Sedelmaier, Dieter Landes
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Oral examinations are a prevalent but psychologically demanding form of assessment in higher education. Many students experience intense anxiety, which can impair cognitive performance and hinder academic success. This position paper explores the potential of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) in extended reality (XR) environments to support students preparing for oral exams. We propose a system concept that integrates photorealistic ECAs with real-time capable large language models (LLMs) to enable psychologically safe, adaptive, and repeatable rehearsal of oral examination scenarios. We also discuss the potential benefits and challenges of such an envisioned system.

title: Small-Signal Analysis of a Bidirectional and Interleaved DC-DC Converter
authors: Italo Roger F. M. P. da Silva, Gabriel G. Veriato, João Victor F. Kuhnen, Camila S. Gehrke
abstract: The increasing penetration of renewable energy sources into modern power systems has intensified the demand for efficient and reliable power conversion technologies. Bidirectional interleaved converters have emerged as a promising solution due to their ability to enhance overall system performance in diverse applications. This paper develops medium- and small-signal models of a bidirectional interleaved converter to evaluate its dynamic behavior and validate its effectiveness through simulations. The results provide a solid basis for the design, optimization, and further specialized studies of this converter topology in renewable energy systems.

title: AquARium: Augmented Reality Integration for Enhanced Tourism Experiences in a Diorama Fish Tank
authors: Suwon Lee, Hyunwoo Cho, Sang-Min Choi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of AquARium, an innovative aquarium concept integrating physical dioramas of real islands with augmented reality (AR) technology. This project aims to enhance user experience by creating an immersive visual, auditory, and interactive environment. The diorama, housed in a glass aquarium filled with water, serves as the focal point, while AR technology overlays digital content to simulate natural sounds and provides narrations.

title: Prediction of Accidents by Surveillance and Continuous Monitoring of Road Conditions Using Deep Learning Techniques
authors: M. Giri, N. Malavika, R. Lakshmi Devi, E. Ranjith Kumar, K. Rohith, P. Rushikesh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: India like a developing countries road accident are common and are occurred frequently. Many people lost their life due to accidents, and that are occurred mainly due to driver fault, vehicle faults, and road faults like road damages and government fails to monitor road conditions. In this research we proposed a new technique to detect damages on roads using vehicles of Arial type (UAV) to capture road pictures frequently and to predict incidents we are using deep learning approach. In India maintenance of roads with good condition is a difficult and challenging task. However, collecting road pictures frequently by manual techniques are human interest and also not advisable. In our research we are planned to identify damages on road surfaces, we used versions 4, 5, 7 of YOLO for detecting objects, all these three methods are trained and also tested using dataset, results are evaluated, and our method shows efficient results.

title: Mushroom Shaped UWB Antenna with Circular Parasitic Patch for Wireless Communication
authors: Rajashree Priyadarshini, Sanjeev Kumar Mishra, Surya Prakash Singh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: This work introduces a compact ultra-wideband (UWB) antenna designed with an inverted half-circular monopole structure characterized by a mushroom-like profile. Designed on an FR4 substrate the antenna employs a semi-elliptical ground plane to achieve wideband (3.5 GHz - 10.6 GHz) impedance matching. The performance of the antenna is elevated by introducing a circular parasitic patch, opposite to the radiating structure. The effect of the change in the shape of the parasitic patch is also studied and it is found that the circular parasitic patch provides the widest frequency coverage and stable gain in contrast to the hexagonal and rectangular parasitic patches. With a maximum realized gain of 4 dBi, the proposed antenna provides a space-efficient and high-performance solution for ultra-wideband (UWB) communication systems.

title: Application of Multi-dimensional Security Strategies in Power System
authors: Subi Deng, Yuwen Wang, Jinning Guo
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: With the development of smart grids, the cybersecurity of power automation systems, as a critical component of power systems, faces increasingly severe challenges. This paper explores the application of multi-dimensional security strategies in power automation systems from the perspectives of confidentiality, integrity, availability and non-repudiation. It covers various aspects including Symmetric and Asymmetric Encryption; Certificates; Credential Establishment, Conversion, and Renewal; Certificate and Key Management; Public Key Infrastructure(PKI); IEC 62351 Security for DNP and IEC 61850; Transport Layer Security(TLS); Identity Establishment, Quality, and Mapping; Authentication for Role-Based Access Control(RBAC); Digital signatures, HMAC,SHA-256 and Cyclic Redundancy Check(CRC); Firewalls with Access Control Lists(ACL); Rate Limiting Access Control; Intrusion Detection Systems(IDS); Audit Logging; During Attack Coping and Post-Attack Recovery; Security Incident and Vulnerability Reporting; Backup and Recovery; Network and System Management(NSM). The aim is to provide comprehensive solutions and theoretical support for enhancing the cybersecurity level of power automation systems.

title: High-Frequency Interactions in Bipolar DC Microgrids with Long Connections
authors: Mateus Pinheiro Dias, Debora Pereira Damasceno, José Carlos Ugaz Peña, José Antenor Pomilio
abstract: Bipolar dc microgrids are a reliable solution for modern electrical systems due to their advantages in fault tolerance and efficiency. However, the interaction of power converters through long cable connections can trigger highfrequency phenomena that degrade power quality. This paper presents an analysis of high-frequency interactions in bipolar dc microgrids with long connections. A case study composed of a buck-boost voltage balancer and two buck converters connected to the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p-0$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0-n$</tex> buses is considered. The influence of electromagnetic interference filters (EMIFs) and line impedances is investigated. The study highlights how these factors contribute to the emergence of harmonic distortions that may lead to violations of power quality standards in dc buses. Simulation results are presented in order to evaluate the bipolar dc microgrid under high-frequency disturbances.

title: Effect of Pin-Shapes on Chip-Embedded Two-Phase Cooling
authors: Pritish R. Parida
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Increase in demand for high-performance computing for modern AI applications is driving the need for highpower heterogeneously integrated 2.5 D and 3D packages that cannot be thermally managed by conventional air-cooling approaches. Novel liquid cooling solutions such as inter-chip two phase cooling, which utilizes two-phase flow boiling of dielectric fluid through microscale cavities while being compatible with device function, 3D chip stack interconnects, fabrication and assembly, can provide effective thermal management. In this work, previously developed high fidelity Eulerian multiphase model was used to compare the chip-embedded two-phase cooling performance of five different types of micro-fin shapes, namely round, square, diamond, triangular and rectangular. Results showed that for the same mass flow rate, the square and rectangular fins resulted in the lowest device temperatures while triangular fins resulted in the highest device temperatures. Round pins have slightly higher thermal resistance compared to rectangular pins but at lower pressure drop.

title: Preserving Privacy in Marketing: a Comparative Study of Synthetic Data for Personalized Campaign Generation
authors: Shailendra Kumar Mishra, Aryan Rai, Aditya Ranjan, Ananmay Lohia, Mihir S Arya
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
abstract: This paper analyzes the effectiveness of synthetic data for creating personalized marketing campaigns, compared to real customer data, which raises growing privacy concerns. An integrated system was developed using a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)-based synthetic data generator and a Groqpowered campaign generation framework. Using a dataset of 400,000 customer records, corresponding synthetic datasets were created, and campaigns from both data types were evaluated. Evaluation combined automated Large Language Model (LLM) assessment and a survey of 200 participants. Results show synthetic data-based campaigns scored 4.1/5, slightly below the 4.2/5 for real data, with minimal loss in relevance and accuracy. Statistical analysis found no significant difference between the two (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p>0.1$</tex>). These findings suggest synthetic data offers a privacy-preserving alternative without sacrificing campaign quality.

title: Research on the Application of Multi Modal Sentiment Computing in Dynamic Visual Communication
authors: Chang Li, Jiayi Lin, Yaqi Wu, Xiao Shao, Zihui Xu, Wanqi Zhou, Zihui Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: With the boom of digital media (e.g., TikTok, YouTube), dynamic visual content (digital ads, short videos) conveys emotions via multi-modal cues. However, traditional single-modal sentiment analysis-relying solely on text, image, or audio-fails to capture complex emotional dynamics: text ignores visual/audio cues, images miss temporal changes, and audio lacks semantic context, leading to inaccurate recognition (Gandhi et al., 2023). Integrate text, image, and audio modalities: collect 5000 clips from YouTube (35 %), TikTok (40 %), Instagram Reels (25 %) (covering 6 genres) for annotated dataset construction; design the Cross-Modal Temporal Attention (CMTA) model with Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) alignment and adaptive attention fusion. The CMTA model achieves 89.2 % accuracy and 0.88 F1-score, outperforming single-modal methods (Text-BERT, Image-ResNet: 12.7%20.3% gain) and existing multi-modal methods (Graph Fusion: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.9 \%-7.1 \%$</tex> gain). It fills gaps in dynamic visual multi-modal sentiment analysis, providing theoretical support for crossmodal fusion research and practical guidance for optimizing digital ad multi-modal combinations and social media emotional recommendation.

title: Multi-Objective Optimization of Route Planning Based on Distributed Breadth Convolutional Neural Network and Markov Decision Processes
authors: Rundong Gao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The traditional route planning methods lack high computational efficiency and flexibility in complex traffic. To address these issues, a multi-objective optimization model to enhance computational efficiency and flexibility in route planning based on the Distributed Breadth Convolutional Neural Network and Markov Decision Processes (M-DBCNN) is presented. Specifically, distributed width convolutional neural networks extend the width of convolutional neural network (CNN) to enhance the feature extraction of convolutional layers without increasing the depth of the network, and improve the computational efficiency of the network model in a distributed way. Subsequently, Markov decision process models the route planning problem by defining state space, action space and state transition probability, deals with uncertainty in the environment, and optimizes the decision with the help of reward function to find the optimal path strategy to meet a specific goal. Simulation experiments show that the proposed algorithm is able to find the optimal route under different complexity levels. Compared with other algorithms, in more complex environments, the proposed algorithm can effectively balance the efficiency and flexibility of route planning and find better routes.

title: A Comprehensive Circuit Breaker Condition Monitoring Technique Based on D-S Theory
authors: Xi Lu, Mengli Chen, Hongming Shen, Congying Wu, Zhihong Xiao, Peili Yan, Bolin Zhang, Guodong Wu, Saisai Ni
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: The paper analyzes the primary factors and mechanisms that lead to the failure of high-voltage switchgear circuit breakers. A condition monitoring model based on D-S theory is proposed in this paper. This model addresses the inconsistency of monitoring information from different sensors. It aims to facilitate a comprehensive diagnosis and assessment of the operating state of high-voltage circuit breakers. In addition, it can enhance the level of intelligent monitoring of circuit breakers.

title: SonoCraftAR: Towards Supporting Personalized Authoring of Sound-Reactive AR Interfaces by Deaf and Hard of Hearing Users
authors: Jaewook Lee, Davin Win Kyi, Leejun Kim, Jenny Peng, Gagyeom Lim, Jeremy Zhengqi Huang, Dhruv Jain, Jon E. Froehlich
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Augmented reality (AR) has shown promise for supporting Deaf and hard-of-hearing (DHH) individuals by captioning speech and visualizing environmental sounds, yet existing systems do not allow users to create personalized sound visualizations. We present SonoCraftAR, a proof-of-concept prototype that empowers DHH users to author custom sound-reactive AR interfaces using typed natural language input. SonoCraftAR integrates real-time audio signal processing with a multi-agent LLM pipeline that procedurally generates animated 2D interfaces via a vector graphics library. The system extracts the dominant frequency of incoming audio and maps it to visual properties such as size and color, making the visualizations respond dynamically to sound. This early exploration demonstrates the feasibility of open-ended sound-reactive AR interface authoring and discusses future opportunities for personalized, AI-assisted tools to improve sound accessibility.

title: A Cartography of Queer Voices: An Interactive Projection of LGBTQ+ Community Challenges and Experiences
authors: Anish Kundu, Burcu Nimet Dumlu, Giulia Barbareschi, Kouta Minamizawa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: A Cartography of Queer Voices is a multi-screen interactive installation that transforms community generated challenges into a spatial and auditory experience. It draws from 316 notes collected during a 2023 workshop with 35 LGBTQ+ participants, who discussed challenges and co-developed solutions using VR. The system visualizes these narratives as 3D semantic networks grouped by theme. Participants navigate the installation using Leap Motion hand gestures, triggering visual and auditory feedback as they explore each node. A pilot test with five users on a laptop version confirmed usability and emotional resonance. This installation offers an embodied, evolving archive of community voices.

title: A Comprehensive Analysis of the Dynamic Phasor Model for the Active Ripple Reduction Circuit
authors: Thiago Fonseca Rech, Tailan Orlando, Amanda Lahera Guerra, André Luís Kirsten, Marcelo Lobo Heldwein, Roberto Francisco Coelho
abstract: This paper addresses the modeling and analysis of a single-phase grid-tied system featuring an Active Ripple Reduction Circuit (ARRC). The paper first reviews the conventional approach to mitigating power oscillation. In addition, it highlights the limitations of relying solely on linearized small-signal average models, especially under large-signal conditions with significant harmonic components. To overcome these shortcomings, the study adopts a Dynamic Phasor (DP) framework, enabling a more accurate representation of time-varying signals around the fundamental frequency. Nonlinear state-space equations are formulated to capture the frequency-dependent behavior, and the steady-state values are derived by equating the system to zero. Finally, numerical simulations demonstrate that the DP model accurately predicts system dynamics and captures low-frequency ripple effects, offering improved insight compared to traditional averaged models.

title: Critical Discourse Analysis of Smart City Narratives
authors: Sona Hakobyan, Gohar Avetisyan
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: Smart city projects represent a transformative approach to urban development making the most of modern technologies to improve life qualities, efficiency and sustainability in cities. These initiatives integrate data analytics, IoT devices, artificial intelligence, and digital connectivity to create more vibrant and efficient urban environments. However, for these technological solutions to be truly effective, they must be accessible and meticulously communicated. Although there has been a myriad of studies on the effectiveness, challenges and opportunities of smart cities, there is a lack of focus on the discourse that constructs and propagates these narratives. This paper employs Critical Discourse Analysis (CDA) to explore how language is used to construct, legitimize, and disseminate smart city ideologies. The findings reveal that language plays an indispensable role in framing smart cities as efficient and future-oriented, often relegating questions of equity, inclusivity, and democratic participation.

title: Perception-In-The-Loop Bed-To-Wheelchair Transfer: Lightweight Rgb-D Posture Recognition and Safety-Constrained Control in a Digital Twin
authors: Xuan Xi, Shiyuan Ren, Yongfei Feng, Chipu Zhang, Hongbo Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: Transitioning frail seniors between supine, sitting, and wheelchair configurations is labor-intensive and safetycritical. We present a perception-in-the-loop framework that couples a lightweight RGB-D posture recognizer with a safetyconstrained controller for a bed-to-wheelchair transformation robot. The entire pipeline is validated in a high-fidelity digital twin (Gazebo + ROS 2) with strict contact-force limits. Across three representative scenarios, our method attains posturerecognition accuracy of 96.8% and transfer success rate of 98.5% (mean over 10 runs), improving over RGB-only and skeletononly baselines while maintaining an end-to-end latency of 53 ms. Ablations confirm the benefits of depth cues and temporal smoothing, and sensitivity analysis indicates robust performance for confidence thresholds in the range 0.8-0.95.

title: Benefit Evaluation Study of New Adjustable Loads Participating in Flexible Grid Interaction
authors: Min Zhang, Yantao Chen, Wenwen Zhu, Xiazhe Tu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: With the continuous development of new power systems, the increasing importance of flexible regulation resources in the grid, especially the potential of regulation burden in improving grid operation and reliability, has been widely recognized. This paper proposes a set of scientific efficacy evaluation methods, focusing on the construction of an evaluation index system including technical, economic and environmental dimensions. The weights of the indicators are assigned through the hierarchical analysis method (AHP), and based on typical scenarios set up, such as high renewable energy penetration, peak-valley differential regulation and The results of the study show that the new adjustment burden is able to achieve the effective grid regulation capacity and stability in the technical dimension, and it has significant cost-saving benefits in the economic dimension, and at the same time in the research in this paper, the research for the application of the adjustable loads in the new type of electric power system provides a scientific basis for the application of adjustable load in the new power system, and lays a theoretical foundation for the realization of efficient and green operation of the power grid.

title: Artificial Intelligence in Smart Cities Enhancing Public Services Infrastructure and Real Time Citizen Engagement Tools
authors: K. Sathish
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: This paper submits a Federated Multi Agent AI Framework (FMAIF) toward urban governance issues that regulate and improve the delivery of optimum public services and citizen involvement in the governance process. The conventional methods of managing the infrastructure are not realistic to maintain real-time responsiveness and resource optimization implying that intelligent solutions are vital in the call of facilitating the sustainable development. The system combines machine learning, IoT sensors, and predictive analytics and incorporates them into a single smart city system. Natural language processing will be a way to analyze citizen feedback, computer vision can be used to manage traffic, and deep learning can be used to monitor infrastructure. Implementation proves: 94.7 % accuracy of traffic prediction, 92 % efficiency of waste management and 78 % reduced emergency response time and 97.8 % citizen satisfaction with average response time of 2.3 seconds. Improving energy optimization led to forecast accuracy of 91.3 % on the demand and the cost went down by 23 %. The FMAIF delivers 67 percent of the communication overhead savings and preserves 0.89 on the privacy preservation metric. The study helps provide anonymity with scalable privacy preservation solution to enhance service provisioning by predictive maintenance, automated resource distribution and enhanced transparency in government-citizen communications to underpin sustainable urban conversion.

title: Tap-Intel: A Threat Alerting and Profiling Intelligence Framework Based on Natural Language Processing
authors: S. H. Sanjeevini, Kvnsk Thasya Sri, Siddani Srivalli, Siriyala Sowjanya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Cyber attackers take advantage of newly revealed vulnerabilities within hours before more traditional defenses are even mounted. To discharge this urgency, automated cyberthreat intelligence systems are required. In this study, we advance the concept of TAP-INTEL. This online framework utilizes Open-Source Intelligence (OSINT) from Twitter, using Natural Language Processing (NLP) and supervised machine learning, to identify and profile novel cyber threats. TAPINTEL maps adversarial strategies within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, enabling automatic behavioral profiling. Experimental results reveal that the F1-score is 77 % on 14 tactics, with the Support Vector Machine obtaining the best performance (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 7 \% F 1}$</tex>). In a real-world attack during a financial institution deployment, TAP-INTEL can detect 17 days before disclosure and respond to attacks before a patched mitigation is available. These results suggest that TAP-INTEL could be a viable option for a scalable, proactive countermeasure mechanism that should be considered for predicting and neutralizing potential cyber threats.

title: Automated IC Footprint Recognition and Classification Using Deep Learning and Dimensional Similarity Metrics
authors: Tushar Shrivastava
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Accurate mapping of integrated-circuit (IC) footprints to PCB layouts is time-consuming and error-prone in highdensity manufacturing. We present an automated pipeline combining tolerance-aware dimensional similarity metrics with an ensemble of fine-tuned convolutional neural networks (ResNet-50, EfficientNet-B3) and a recommendation engine implemented in Python-SQLite3-Qt. The system normalizes datasheet parameters, applies candidate filtering, computes weighted similarity scores, and fuses visual classification probabilities into a single ranking score. On a curated dataset of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4, 5 0 0}$</tex> images spanning 12 package types, our optimized pipeline attains 95.0 % test accuracy with 0.15 s average inference latency. Ablation studies show the benefit of weighted dimensional prioritization and transfer learning. The approach is practical for inline designassist and pick-and-place recommendation, reducing manual footprint lookup and improving placement accuracy.

title: Multifunctional Inverter for DER Integration and PQ Improvement in Microgrids: Prototype Implementation and Testing
authors: Alexandre Hugo da Silveira, Aquiles Rossoni, Fausto Bastos Líbano, Roberto Chouhy Leborgne, António Manuel Santos Spencer Andrade
abstract: This work presents the development and evaluation of a multifunctional inverter (MI) for low-voltage microgrids, operating in both grid-connected and islanded modes. The MI enhances power quality by mitigating harmonics. Simulations and experimental tests in a laboratory-scale microgrid demonstrate a significant reduction in the total demand distortion of current (TDDi) and improvements in voltage waveform, proving the MI's effectiveness in improving power quality and in integrating renewable energy.

title: Frequency-adaptive PI+VPI Current Control under Weak Power Grid Conditions
authors: Zhou Lili, Han Wei, Chen Yufang, Li Dandan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Aiming at the problem that the grid-side current imbalance, distortion and frequency deviation lead to the decrease of the output frequency and phase estimation accuracy of the three-phase synchronous reference frame phase-locked loop(SRF-PLL) under the complex working conditions of the weak power grid, which affects the performance of the harmonic current reference and the vector proportional integral(VPI) current tracking control link, a frequency adaptive proportional integral(PI) + VPI current control strategy under the weak power grid is proposed. Based on the analysis of the influence mechanism of grid-side current imbalance, distortion and frequency deviation on the phase-locked loop(PLL), a three-phase SRF-PLL based on adaptive notch filter(ANF) is used to realize the accurate adaptive estimation and fast convergence of frequency and phase under the above complex conditions. The phase estimation information is used in real time for harmonic current extraction and Park transformation, and the frequency estimation information is used in real time for the VPI control module to overcome the problem of active power filter (APF) compensation performance degradation under frequency deviation conditions. The estimation performance of notch filter-based synchronous phase-locked loop (NF-PLL) and ANF-PLL under frequency deviation is compared and analyzed by simulation. The experimental results of APF compensation performance under weak power grid conditions show that the frequency adaptive PI + VPI control / ANF-PLL strategy has better frequency deviation adaptability than the frequency adaptive PI + VPI control / NF-PLL strategy.

title: Determination of p-Cymene Content in Ajwain Oil Samples Using a Quartz Crystal Microbalance (QCM) Based Sensor
authors: Mohasin Ali Miah, Sumit Kundu, Deepam Gangopadhyay, Runu Banerjee Roy
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: P-cymene, a natural monoterpene found in various spices and herbs, plays a significant role in human health as this volatile compound has antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antimicrobial effects. In this study, a quartz crystal microbalance (QCM) sensor has been developed from methacrylic acid (MAA) and acrylic acid (AA) based co-polymer to detect p-cymene present in different commercially available ajwain essential oils (AEOs). The developed sensor exhibited a linear response over a 30-300 ppm concentration range, with repeatability and reproducibility of 93.92% ± 0.01% and 94.94% ± 0.01%, respectively. The sensor was used to analyze p-cymene in ajwain essential oils (AEOs), demonstrating excellent recovery. The sensitivity of the fabricated sensor towards p-cymene was found to be 0.128 Hz/ppm, with a linear regression coefficient (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) of 0.99. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) was applied to differentiate four different ajwain essential oil (AEO) samples, with the PCA plot demonstrating clear and effective clustering separation among them.

title: Abnormality Detection in PET Imaging Using Foundation Models: A Comparative Study and Analysis
authors: Nathan Vandekerckhove, Ide Van den Borre, Simon De Keyser, Maarten Larmuseau, Aleksandra Pižurica
publish: 2025 13th European Workshop on Visual Information Processing (EUVIP)
abstract: The escalating clinical demand for positron emission tomography (PET) is accompanied by a heterogeneity in scanners, tracers and acquisition protocols, making PET data complex to interpret, especially when the lesions of interest are subtle or minute. Motivated by this challenge, we investigate abnormality detection on PET scans through the lens of large-scale foundation models and other pre-trained vision encoders, whose broad applicability has recently energised deep-learning research. We present the first systematic 2-D study that contrasts such pretrained backbones with traditional, task-specific architectures in both binary classification and semantic segmentation. For classification, embeddings were extracted from frozen encoders (DINOv2, RAD-DINO, ConvNeXt, etc.) and fed to a lightweight fully-connected head, while a traditional CNN provided the baseline. For segmentation, frozen pretrained encoders-both off-the-shelf and custom-built-are grafted onto the nud-Net pipeline, exploring information fusion at the bottleneck and across multiple feature levels. Experiments demonstrate that DINOv2-based embeddings achieve the most promising results in classification, surpassing the CNN baseline across all metrics while requiring only lightweight training once embeddings are harvested. For segmentation, plain nnU-Net remains superior, indicating that PET-specific fine-tuning of general-purpose encoders may be necessary. These findings chart the promise and current limits of foundation models for clinical PET analysis.

title: Integrating Resilience and Sustainability into Grid Planning: An Extended Approach for Distribution System Operators Under Extreme Weather Risks
authors: Madeleine Jendernalik, Christian Rehtanz
publish: 2025 International Power and Sustainable Energy Technologies Conference (PSETC)
abstract: Extreme weather events pose a growing threat to the operational safety and stability of electricity distribution grids. At the same time, the pressure on distribution grid operators to adapt their infrastructures to new technological, ecological and regulatory requirements in terms of sustainability is increasing. This paper presents an extended planning model that systematically integrates resilience and sustainability criteria. Resilience, in this context, is understood as the system’s ability to maintain or rapidly restore functionality under disruptive conditions, and is conceptually distinct from operational safety, which refers to normal, fault-free operating conditions. The analysis is carried out on two levels: the asset level and the grid structure level. Specific criteria for increasing resilience are identified, linked to sustainable planning approaches and made measurable using suitable key performance indicators (KPIs). The effectiveness of the approach is analyzed using the flood disaster in the Ahr Valley as an example. In addition, an economic evaluation of the measures is carried out using a cost-benefit analysis. The analysis suggests that resilience and sustainability, when integrated methodically, can be treated as complementary rather than competing objectives in the context of future-proof grid development.

title: Virtual Vector Direct Torque Control Applied to an Open-End Six-Phase Induction Machine Drive in Healthy and Postfault Operation Under Single-Phase Open-Circuit Fault
authors: Victor Felipe M. B. Melo, Gilielson F. Da Paz, Emerson De Lacerda Soares, Isaac Soares De Freitas, Edison R. C. Da Silva
abstract: This work consists in applying the Virtual Vector Direct Torque Control (VV-DTC) to regulate electromagnetic torque and stator flux in an open-end six-phase induction machine drive system operating under healthy and postfault operation under a single-phase open-circuit fault. Although the use of VVDTC in drive systems has been discussed in previous works, the study of its performance applied to the open-end topology lacks in literature. Simulation results show the applicability of the method under healthy operation, providing the elimination of the 5th harmonic current components, as well as under postfault operation, since it is able to provide low torque and flux ripples, and proper rotor speed regulation.

title: Automatic Post-Editing (APE) Algorithm for Machine Translation Based on Deep Learning
authors: Chunlan Jiang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Existing automatic post-editing (APE) technologies still face significant shortcomings in handling complex contextual relationships, integrating multi-source input information, and fine-tuning generated content. This paper introduces multiple post-editing modeling strategies within a deep learning framework and systematically constructs three representative models: a Bi-RNN+Attention architecture, a multi-input Transformer architecture, and a generative pre-trained language model (GPT-style). In the experimental design, this paper examines the impact of different architectures on translation error detection, contextual consistency capture, and low-resource transfer capabilities. Results show that when the model receives both SRC and MT as input, its TER (Translation Editing Rate) reaches a minimum of 21.3, with BLEU (Bilingual Evaluation Understudy) and ChrF++ (Character n-gram F-score Plus Plus) scores of 71.9 and 77.8, respectively, significantly outperforming any single-input configuration. This demonstrates that dual-source information fusion can effectively enhance semantic integrity, structural alignment, and linguistic naturalness.

title: ECD Single Phase Inverter — A New ZCS-ZVS Converter
authors: Emmanuel Cordeiro Dias, Carlos Antonio Pereira Viana, Leandro Celso Duarte
abstract: This work proposes a new electronic arrangement or converter topology with non-dissipative switching, called the Single-Phase ECD (Energy-Capacitor-Dual) Inverter, which imposes current on a capacitor through two energy sources. The main characteristics of the new inverter are the absence of an output filter, ZCS (Zero Current Switching) and ZVS (Zero Voltage Switching) non-dissipative switching, high electrical efficiency, and the ability to provide sinusoidal voltage with low total harmonic distortion to both linear and non-linear loads over a wide frequency range. The topology consists of four semiconductor switches, with non-dissipative commutations operate during part of the operating periods. ZCS occurs in the switches S2 and S3 connected to the output capacitor, while ZVS occurs in the switches S1 and S4 connected to the DC sources. During the positive half-cycle of the generated sinusoid, switches S3 and S4 operate in soft commutation. During the negative half-cycle generation, switches S1 and S2 assume this function, operating in non-dissipative mode. This new single-phase sinusoidal inverter has been patented in Brazil and the United States. Theoretical analysis, simulations, practical results and efficiency are presented in the face of frequency variation and load variation in the fixed frequency of 60 Hz.

title: Robust Watermarking Approach for Full HD Videos: Adaptive DE with $13 / 7-\mathrm{T}$ and $6 / 14$ ITI Wavelet Transforms
authors: Sujatha. G, Arun Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Digital video, a Key digital media type in the Internet of Things (IoT), is vulnerable to unauthorised copying of data. To protect the copyrights, the paper presents a robust watermarking technique suitable for Full HD videos using adaptive Difference Expansion (DE) with integer to integer (ITI) wavelet transforms, namely 13/7-T and 6/14 ITI transform. The embedding adapts based on local block variance to balance high capacity and imperceptibility. The lossless ITI-DWT allows perfect reconstruction of original frames after watermark extraction, preserving quality. Watermark bits are embedded in HH sub-band pixels via DE, ensuring reversibility with low distortion. Performance is evaluated using SSIM, MSE, PSNR, and VIF, alongside payload capacity analysis under varying thresholds. Results confirm the method's suitability for secure, reversible video watermarking in copyright protection and multimedia authentication.

title: CeylonXR: A Virtual Tour Platform Powered by Gaussian Splatting, Multiplayer Immersion, and AI Guidance
authors: Ravindu Wijayathunga, Lahiru Eranga, Pasindu Vishmitha, Mayura Manawadu, Udaya Wijenayake, Gayantha Kodagoda
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Virtual tour systems broaden remote access to real-world landmarks, yet integrating photorealistic rendering, seamless navigation, multiuser interaction, and AI guidance into a single cross-platform experience remains challenging. We present CeylonXR, a browser-first and VR-capable platform that renders scenes with Gaussian splatting, supports multiuser exploration with spatial voice chat and customizable avatars, and provides context-aware narration with real-time question answering. The system streams directly to modern web browsers and a standalone VR application. We field-tested CeylonXR at Sri Lankan heritage sites, including the Colombo National Museum and the Ella Nine Arch Bridge, and observed positive early usability feedback alongside stable real-time performance on commodity hardware. CeylonXR demonstrates a practical path to immersive, social virtual tours and suggests applications in tourism, education, and cultural heritage.

title: Design and Optimization of DC Railway Traction System Dynamics using Metaheuristic Techniques
authors: A.S.L.K. Gopalamma, S Ramana Kumar Joga, Srinu Naik Ramavathu, Kantamreddy Bala, Nidrabingi Girija, Doddi Chakradhar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: The increasing demand for energy-efficient and high-performance rail transportation systems has necessitated advanced modeling and optimization techniques for metro train dynamics. This project focuses on the design and simulation of metro train dynamics and tractive effort models using MATLAB/Simulation. A comprehensive vehicle dynamics model is developed to evaluate the impact of acceleration, braking forces, and energy losses due to resistance (rolling resistance, aerodynamic drag, and gradient resistance). The study also incorporates gear ratio optimization to enhance torque transmission efficiency, ensuring minimal power losses while maintaining optimal train performance. Additionally, the motor-inverter system efficiency is analyzed to assess power conversion losses and control strategies for improved energy utilization. By integrating these elements into a unified simulation-based framework, the project provides insights into energy-efficient metro train operation while optimizing tractive effort and power distribution. The results from these simulations contribute to the development of sustainable and efficient urban rail transport systems, offering a pathway toward enhanced energy savings and system performance. optimized the performance parameters of the DC traction system using particle swarm optimization (PSO) and charge system algorithm (CSS) and analyzed the performance based on the results.

title: Engineering Experiments Based on Enhanced Genetic Algorithm Based Feed Forward Networks
authors: Pengpeng Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Chemical engineering experiments is a systematic approach that ensures the best operating conditions for a particular process. It is applied to maximize desirable resultsproduct yield, purity, or efficiency-together with the minimization of undesirable factors such as energy use, waste generation, and operating expenses. This is accomplished by utilization of statistical design of experiments (DOE) and highlevel computational algorithms to enable engineers to probe into the intricate interactions between process variables with the lowest possible number of experimental tests. Finally, this strategy is critical because it turns experimentation from an ad hoc process into a discipline-based, data-intensive science and allows the construction of safer, more cost-effective, and environmentally benign chemical processes in research and industrial environments. The conventional methods, such as rule-based systems and traditional database-backed models, have sought to counter these issues but have been insufficient based on their rigidity and failure to dynamically adapt according to environment. To ensure the optimization of Chemcial experiments, this research paper proposes a novel ensemble of deep feed-forward networks with the hyperparameters tuned by genetic-pollinated technique to enhance a learning-based intelligent framework to recommend the appropriate Chemical tests. The experimental validation has been carried in wastewater treatment process in which the hybrid model yield 30 % increases in productivity with 50 % reducing in time of operation against the traditional methods.

title: Research on Migration Learning MPC Strategy for HDT Devices Under Sparse Data
authors: Jianfeng Chen, Jiamin Lei, Zhenye Chen, Yingxiang Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In order to improve the modeling accuracy and control stability of HDT devices under sparse data conditions, a model predictive control strategy incorporating a migration learning mechanism is constructed. Based on the state space modeling of HDT systems, effective migration of dynamic properties in the source and target domains is achieved through source domain knowledge characterization, feature alignment and structure preserving regular design. The maximum mean difference and the migration regularity term are introduced in the controller design to construct the joint optimization objective function, and the online MPC solution is completed by combining Kalman filtering and QP solver. The experiments are carried out on Simulink platform for comparative analysis, and the results show that the migration-enhanced MPC strategy outperforms the traditional method in terms of prediction accuracy, control smoothness, and system steady-state response, and especially exhibits stronger robustness and convergence performance under the scenario of insufficient samples.

title: Assembly Error Modeling Method Based on Jacobian-Torsor Embedded Neural Network
authors: Gang Zhao, Yuanzhi Zeng, Yazui Liu, Haodong Shen
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: In high-precision manufacturing domains such as military equipment and aerospace, assembly accuracy of complex products fundamentally determines their core performance and operational reliability. Traditional assembly error modeling approaches encounter significant limitations when characterizing the nonlinear behaviors of ‘geometry-mechanics’ coupling, particularly in addressing contact deformation and dynamic coupling effects. To overcome these challenges, this paper introduces an innovative Jacobian-Torsor embedded neural network approach. The proposed method incorporates the Jacobian-Torsor theory by imposing physical constraints within the neural network architecture, enabling precise modeling of nonlinear mechanisms through a joint optimization framework that combines the ‘Jacobian-Torsor loss function' with network prediction errors. The approach leverages the multi-layer nonlinear mapping capabilities of neural networks to capture implicit correlations while employing kinematic constraints from Jacobian-Torsor theory to regularize network training, thereby significantly enhancing small-sample generalization and physical interpretability. Experimental validation on a dual-axis turntable demonstrates substantial improvements, with prediction errors reduced by 46.51%, 37.44%, and 50.86% in the x, y, and z directions respectively, compared to conventional networks without Jacobian embedding. This cross-domain fusion framework, integrating physical mechanism constraints and datadriven fitting, establishes a novel pathway for addressing the nonlinear transfer challenges in high-precision assembly applications.

title: Optimizing Treatment Matching with Causal Learning
authors: Shreya G. Tendulkar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: This study presents a novel causal learning framework for optimizing treatment matching by estimating heterogeneous treatment effects (HTEs). The method integrates Bayesian decomposition, deep learning, and sequential models to personalize treatment intensity. They propose the Dual R-Learner and Direct Ranking Model (DRM), which optimizes a unified costbenefit objective under budget constraints. Empirical evaluations on over one million ride-sharing transactions across 21 cities demonstrate a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 - 1 0 \%}$</tex> improvement in AUCC over baseline models. Additionally, a stacked LSTM variant captures temporal dependencies, outperforming static baselines in both offline and online deployments. These results show strong potential for scalable, real-time treatment policy optimization.

title: Reachability Analysis-Based Quantitative Impact Assessment of Cyber Attacks on Inverter-Based Microgrids
authors: Wen Gao, Qunjie Zhou, Kaihao Zou, Kaishun Xiahou, Lingling Xu, Junhui He
publish: 2025 International Power and Sustainable Energy Technologies Conference (PSETC)
abstract: In the integration of cyber-physical systems, the vulnerability of information communication systems to cyber attacks threatens the safety and stability of inverter-based microgrids. To investigate the mechanisms of attacks on microgrids, this paper employs reachability analysis method to quantitatively assess the impact of uncertain attacks on microgrids. Firstly, a nonlinear mathematical model considering inverter dynamics is constructed. Then, to better describe and manage the uncertainties associated with attack amplitudes, zonotopes are employed for modeling. Based on reachability analysis, the reachable set is computed to effectively capture the nonlinear dynamics of microgrid and the uncertainties of attacks for quantitative assessment. Case studies validate the effectiveness of the method, and the results indicate that different types and amplitudes of cyber attacks significantly affect the operational states of microgrid, providing important guidance for vulnerability quantitation in dynamic scenarios.

title: Prediction of Diabetic Retinopathy using NASNet Deep Learning and Comparison Study
authors: Sanjeeb Kumar Sahoo, Rekha Sahu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: Diabetic retinopathy leads to vision loss and people suffering with this blindness worldwide. By identifying diabetic retinopathy early, the risk of blindness due to diabetics can be decreased. Ophthalmologists have long depended on the laborious, manual method of diabetic retinopathy screening, which is time consuming and tends to inaccurate results. Computerized diagnosis method is found as diagnostic tools for confirming the opinions of ophthalmologists, has taken less time with chances of giving accurate result. In this research, we have collected diabetic retinopathy dataset from Kaggle database and experimented NASNet deep learning model on DR dataset to classify diabetic retinopathy in contrast to non-diabetic retinopathy. We have found the performance of NASNet as 99% accuracy. Again, ResNet-50, MobileNet, AlexNet and DenseNet models are trained on the same dataset and comparatively found that NASNet has given better performance. However, more experiments are needed to find a suitable model for prediction of diabetic retinopathy.

title: I-MOR: Intention-Driven Motion Overriding for Realistic Authoring
authors: Joung Jun Kim, Won Jin Hong, Jin Kim, Young Ho Chai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Realistic avatar motion in VR environments is crucial for user immersion, emphasizing the need for techniques that transform basic movements into professional-level articulation. We propose a lightweight framework (I-MOR) that employs quaternion-based representations to bridge user input and high-quality motion generation efficiently. Rather than relying on templates or data-driven models, I-MOR captures instantaneous angular changes from expressive gestures and maps them to frame-wise transformations. SpongeBob Shuffle dance recordings are analyzed to extract quantitative velocity, acceleration, and directional profiles as physical benchmarks. During authoring, user input is continuously compared to these benchmarks, enabling intuitive modulation of rhythm, sharpness, and range without altering core structure. Experiments show that users can synthesize professional-quality motion timing and articulation through simple gestures, advancing low-barrier control, grounded motion generation, and intention-aware authoring in VR.

title: Spatial Distribution Modeling of Panthera tigris for Conservation Planning in India: A Google Earth Engine-Based Approach
authors: Akash Mondal, Ankur Saha, Arijeet Ghosh, Sudipta Dey, Sreya Ghosh, Avik Kumar Das
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: This study introduces a cloud-based framework for modelling species distribution (SDM) to assess habitat suitability for the endangered Bengal tiger (Panthera tigris) across India. Using Google Earth Engine (GEE) and random forest classification, the approach efficiently predicts key tiger habitats while ensuring scalability and computational efficiency. A two-phased ensemble approach, involving ten independent model runs with balanced presence and pseudo-absence data, demonstrated high predictive performance (AUC-ROC: 0.8969 ± 0.0695; PR-AUC: 0.8509 ± 0.0506). Key predictors—elevation, slope, distance to water bodies and human settlements, and seasonal precipitation—were consistently identified as ecologically meaningful variables. The model generated continuous and binary habitat suitability maps that accurately delineated critical tiger habitats in the Sundarbans, Central India, and the Western Ghats. The ensemble approach ensured spatial and statistical robustness, confirming the effectiveness of cloud-integrated machine learning for large-scale ecological modeling. This methodology offers valuable insights for tiger conservation planning and can be adapted for habitat assessment of other threatened species.

title: Improved Overload Operation in Nine-Phase Induction Motors with Electronic Pole Changing
authors: Pedro M. Bichara, Braz J. Cardoso Filho, Rodrigo R. Bastos
abstract: This paper investigates the performance of a ninephase induction motor under overload conditions, comparing two configurations: operation with four poles and nominal airgap flux, and operation with twelve poles and variable airgap flux. The pole count is modified electronically using Pole Phase Modulation (PPM), while flux variation is achieved by adjusting the voltage-to-frequency ratio. Although increasing the number of poles enhances torque production, it also reduces the machine's magnetizing inductance, leading to elevated stator currents and reduced power factor. This work explores how controlled flux reduction can mitigate these effects, enabling significant torque gains with lower overload currents and extended thermal operating limits. The study evaluates key performance metrics, such as torque, current demand, power factor, copper losses, and converter stress, in both scenarios. Additionally, it includes an analysis of the implications for converter sizing in overload operation. The findings offer insights into the trade-offs and practical advantages of pole-changing multiphase machines in applications requiring high transient torque, such as heavy electric vehicles, cranes, and industrial machinery.

title: Visual-Inertial Localization Method Based on Semantic and Geometric Fusion in Dynamic Scenes
authors: Bogen Xie
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In dynamic environments, moving objects negatively impact feature matching and pose estimation in visual-inertial systems, reducing localization accuracy.This paper proposes a fused framework combining semantic segmentation and geometric constraints to distinguish dynamic and static features. A dual-buffer tracking strategy mitigates feature loss due to segmentation delay, while semantic masks guide uniform feature extraction in static regions to sustain stable observational constraints. Evaluated on dynamic scenes, the method reduces Absolute Trajectory Error by 3.51%31.08 % compared to VINS-Mono while operating at 30 Hz in real time.The approach significantly enhances localization robustness in dynamic settings, effectively balancing accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: AI-Based Posture Analysis and Personalized Feedback System for Weight Training: Real-Time Imbalance Detection and LLM-Assisted Coaching
authors: Sejun Yoon, Jeongha Lee, Jae-In Hwang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Cost-efficient and accessible digital healthcare solutions without spatial or temporal constraints have been gaining significant attention. In particular, systems that analyze user posture and deliver real-time feedback are rapidly advancing in weight training. However, most existing systems rely on single-frame analysis or simple visual comparison, limiting their ability to capture continuous movements and user-specific characteristics.We propose a novel system that utilizes real-time 3D pose estimation algorithm in combination with a custom-developed joint angle-based imbalance detection algorithm to automatically identify postural asymmetries occurring during weight training and provide feedback based on a Large Language Model (LLM). Detected postural imbalances are visualized in real time as overlays on the video, and all related data are chronologically recorded. The accumulated data are then processed through the GPT-4o to generate comprehensive text-based reports from functional-anatomical and biomechanical perspectives. These reports include potential risk factors, root cause analysis, and corrective strategies such as stretching and accessory exercises. Users can subsequently engage in interactive, dialogue-based feedback sessions with our system to gain deeper insights.

title: Hierarchical thermal transport across multiple length scales in high-capacity lithium-ion batteries for stationary energy storage systems
authors: Oscar A. Alvarez, Carlos M. Da Silva, Cristina H. Amon
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: High-capacity (above 100 Ah) lithium-ion battery (LIB) cells are the core building units of grid-scale battery energy storage systems (BESS). For optimal thermal performance and lifespan, the temperature of hundreds of LIB cells in BESS must be maintained within a relatively narrow range ($25-40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$) while preserving spatial uniformity within and across the cells. BESS exhibit hierarchical thermal transport across multiple length scales spanning up to six orders of magnitude. This work proposes a cost-effective hierarchical methodology for modeling thermal transport across sub-cell, cell, module, and rack domains. This methodology leverages high-fidelity finite elements simulations to hierarchically characterize relevant BESS domains through effective thermophysical properties and heat generation rates obtained from a representative number of sub-domains, without explicitly modeling all individual components within each BESS domain. The practical application of this methodology is illustrated through a case study of a $220-\mathrm{kWh}$ BESS serving as an energy buffer for an electric vehicle fast charging station.
