This study quantifies how changes at the smallest levels in the hierarchy, such as electrode thickness at the sub-cell level, impact the system-level thermal performance and reliability.

title: Analysis of Meta-Heuristic Optimization for Sustainable Green Manufacturing
authors: Omkar Bhalekar, Apeksha Bamniya
publish: 2025 International Power and Sustainable Energy Technologies Conference (PSETC)
abstract: Green manufacturing is considered one of the most eminent approaches to sustainable industrial development through reducing the wear and tear of the environment without compromising economic sustainability. Facility layout optimization plays a crucial role in saving material handling cost and emission. Conventional approaches are very inefficient in compromising among several competing objectives. This paper suggests that Green Manufacturing processes can be optimized by the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) technique for minimum Total Material Handling Cost (TMHC) and emission. Experiments were performed on a typical computing platform with Python and a high number of iterations, and the findings indicated that the PSO model greatly outmatched Arithmetic Optimization Algorithm (ASSO). The PSO obtained the minimum emission of 177.8 and best TMHC of 2,141,814 at the 30th iteration. Comparative analysis confirmed the effectiveness of PSO in terms of comparative environmental and economic benefits. The presented concept can be applied to the sustainable and cost-effective production at the large scale. The results show the potential uses of PSO as an efficient solution to improve sustainability in manufacturing.

title: Investigation on thermal characteristics of solid state drive under single phase immersion cooling environment
authors: Byunghan Ko, Heechul Lee, Woochul Jeong, Hwanjoo Park, Duksoo Kim, Sunghoon Chun
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: As the era of big data and AI arrives, the amount and size of data that needs to be processed continue to increase, and the performance of data centers is improving day by day to meet this demand. However, since it requires too much energy to cool the heat generated by the performance improvement of the data center with a conventional air cooling method, research is actively underway to switch to immersion cooling. Among the essential components of a data center is a solid-state drive (SSD), which has a relatively low heat generation per device, but since dozens of devices are installed per rack, the total heat generation cannot be ignored. Therefore, it is important to accurately predict the thermal characteristics of SSDs when operating in an immersion cooling environment, and based on this, optimizing the design of the immersion cooling environment can satisfy the operating temperature of the SSD while lowering the power usage efficiency (PUE) of the data center. In this study, we established a computational fluid dynamic (CFD) simulation to predict the temperature characteristics of data center SSDs when applied to a single-phase immersion cooling (SPIC) environment, and verified the accuracy of the prediction model by constructing an experimental setup and verifying the temperature during operation. The CFD simulation was performed using FloTHERM, and based on the SSD model that shows an error level of less than $10 \%$ in the previously established air cooling environment, the fluid condition was changed to Shell S5X, a hydrocarbon-based fluid, to establish a simulation model for a SPIC condition. Next, a SPIC tank capable of mounting a 1U rack server was built for the experiment, and the temperature of major components inside the SSD was measured under various coolant flow rate conditions by installing a SAMSUNG enterprise-class SSD. Through the experiment results, it was confirmed that there was an error of up to $15 \%$ in the simulation results, which was expected to occur due to inaccurate measurement of the flow rate passing through the SSD. Finally, based on the simulation and experimental results, we predicted the thermal designed power (TDP) that could be operated without thermal throttling when the SAMSUNG enterprise-class SSD operates in a SPIC condition, and it was expected that up to 80W could be used when operating the fluid at $35^{\prime} \mathrm{C}$, confirming that the next-generation 70W or higher form factor can be sufficiently cooled by the appropriate control of coolant condition.

title: A Sensorless Vector Control Strategy for Induction Motors Based on Model Reference Adaptive System
authors: Qihang Sun, Mei Ye, Xiangyu Li, Jiabao Kou, Yuxing Dai, Kamal Al-Haddad
publish: 2025 International Power and Sustainable Energy Technologies Conference (PSETC)
abstract: In industrial applications, the rotor speed of induction motors is typically measured using physical sensors such as optical encoders. However, the use of speed sensors increases the overall system cost and undermines the inherent simplicity and robustness of induction motors, particularly in harsh environments. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a sensorless speed estimation method based on the Model Reference Adaptive System (MRAS) framework. The proposed approach constructs a speed estimation scheme by leveraging both the voltage and current models of rotor flux linkage, and derives an adaptive law grounded in Popov's hyperstability theory. A simulation model is implemented in MATLAB/Simulink to validate the strategy. The results show that the proposed method achieves accurate and stable rotor speed estimation under varying load and speed conditions, thereby demonstrating its effectiveness and potential for practical sensorless vector control of induction motors.

title: Comparative Analysis of Traditional Model Predictive Control and Sliding Mode Model Predictive Control
authors: Giovanna Gomes Andrade, Estevão Modolo de Souza, Nimrod Vazquez Nava, Lucas Frizera Encarnação
abstract: This paper proposes a quantitative and qualitative analysis of two predictive control strategies applied to power electronics: traditional finite control set model predictive control and finite control set model predictive control based on sliding mode theory. Transient response, total harmonic distortion, mean absolute error and sensibility to model mismatches were calculated from a Simulink/MATLAB simulation for an inverter with output inductive filter. Besides, the effect of calculation delay was tested for both control schemes, evaluating their behavior before and after delay compensation.

title: SVSCIR: Intelligent Scheduling Method for Virtual Station Area Collection Task Scheduling Based on Improved Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Huang Fuxing, Liu Xuan, Xiang Zhijun, Song Shanshan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Overseas countries generally lack the concept of station area, and the phenomenon of crossing multiple station areas is very common. It has the characteristics of complex power grid structure, various meter types, diverse collection and communication methods, which bring great challenges to the scheduling of collection tasks. In order to solve these problems, this paper proposes a virtual station collection task scheduling method combining whale optimization algorithm and deep reinforcement learning. The deep Q network is optimized by whale optimization algorithm, and the virtual station environment model is constructed. The current connection number, signal strength, task priority, importance and urgency of the collection task are integrated to construct a state space, which provides information support for the decision-making of the agent. In the agent, ε-greedy strategy is used to select actions to realize intelligent task scheduling. Through simulation experiments, the task completion rate of the proposed method is 95.02%, and the average task completion time is 2413.36ms. Compared with other methods, the proposed method has better collection task scheduling effect.

title: Projects for the Digital Transformation
authors: Carsten Wolff, Peter Arras, Rūta Čiutienė, Carolina Cruz, Jurga Duobienė, Ekaterina Hermann, Bassam Hussein, Maider Iturrondobeitia, Jan Ivens, Dennie Jansen, Iuliia Mende, Nargiza Mikhridinova, Bertha Joseph Ngereja, Christian Reimann, Thorsten Ruben, Daymy Tamayo Avila, Rahnuma Tarannum, Nerea Toledo, Wim Van Petegem, Elena Vitkauskaitė
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: The management of the digital transformation faces challenges resulting from the specific characteristics of the transformation process. These characteristics can be more or less distinctive and relevant for a particular aspect, e.g., the domain where the transformation takes place. The partitioning of the complex transformation process into manageable work packages can be done with projects which are a proven tool for structuring and managing transformation. In this respect, digital transformation projects (DTP) form a new and specific type of projects and need specific project management methodology, not only for Smart City projects, but also for other types of DTP. Within the Erasmus+ Knowledge Alliance "Projects for the Digital Transformation (ProDiT)" the characteristics of DTP and the respective processes, methods and tools have been investigated, new methods have been developed and evaluated. Furthermore, guidelines, teaching and training materials were developed, and case studies were compiled. This contribution provides an overview of the results and illustrates the findings by giving examples based on the case of a Smart City project which conducts the digital transformation in cities, covering a broad range of relevant aspects.

title: Accuracy Improvement of Eloran Propagation Delay Based on Spatiotemporal Neural Network
authors: Fumao Liu, Jun Lu
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: The long-wave navigation and timing system holds significant application value in the fields of high-precision positioning and time synchronization, and the accurate prediction of propagation delay is the key to improving system performance. Addressing the impact of meteorological factors on the propagation delay of the eLoran system, this paper proposes a prediction model that integrates the Spatiotemporal Neural Network (STNN) and Four-Dimensional Variational Assimilation (4D-Var). Through preprocessing, feature extraction, and spatiotemporal modeling of meteorological data and propagation delay data, high-precision prediction of propagation delay in complex environments is achieved. Experimental results show that the model performs excellently in terms of indicators such as Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and Coefficient of Determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>), providing an effective solution for delay modeling and environmental adaptability optimization of the eLoran system.

title: Vision-Guided Precise Landing Algorithm for UAV Combining Deep Learning and Kalman Filtering
authors: Houfeng Tang, Jun Lu
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: This study aims to design and validate a vision-guided precise landing algorithm for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) combining deep learning and Kalman filtering. Addressing the challenges of positioning accuracy and environmental adaptability in autonomous UAV landing, we propose a multi-sensor fusion approach. The proposed scheme first utilizes a downward-looking camera equipped with lightweight deep learning models to quickly identify and lock onto ground-based QR code or AprilTag landing markers, guiding the UAV for initial alignment. Subsequently, based on AprilTag-derived pose information, combined with Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) and altimeter data, an Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) algorithm is employed for high-precision fused state estimation of the UAV, converting visual coordinates into precise displacement control commands in the geodetic coordinate system. The algorithm was systematically validated on the Microsoft AirSim simulation platform. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm significantly improves the precision and robustness of UAV landing, with an average landing error maintained within the centimeter-level range. This verifies the effectiveness and practicality of the proposed algorithm in complex environments, offering a reliable technical pathway for future autonomous precise UAV landing.

title: HIL Validation of a FCS-MPC Current Controller with Switching Frequency Minimization for a Grid-Tied Single-Phase Inverter
authors: Leonardo Maier, Flávio A. S. Gonçalves, Rafael dos Santos
abstract: This work presents the implementation and realtime Hardware-in-the-Loop (HIL) validation of a Finite Control Set Model Predictive Control (FCS-MPC) current controller applied to a single-phase grid-tied full-bridge inverter. The controller ensures low current total harmonic distortion (THD), precise current tracking, and switching frequency minimization through a penalization weighting factor in the cost function, allowing a trade-off between accurate current tracking and reduced switching frequency. This control strategy was validated using a Real-Time Simulation on the OPAL-RT real-time platform and implemented on a TI F28379D DSP, proving to be feasible under realistic conditions.

title: Research on Minimally Invasive Surgical Robot Technology Based on VOS viewer and CiteSpace
authors: Jingyi Li, Xiaoyi Jin, Weibiao Kong, Ying Xi, Maolin Zhu, Kaiwei Zhong
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Manufacturing System (ICAMTMS)
abstract: To identify research hotspots in minimally invasive surgical robotics over the past 15 years, this study conducted a visual analysis of relevant papers and technical reviews from the Web of Science Core Collection database using VOSviewer and CiteSpace. The analysis examined publication trends by year, discipline, country, institution, author, journal, and keywords to pinpoint key research foci within the field. Research in minimally invasive surgical robotics globally demonstrates a consistent upward trend and exhibits a strong interdisciplinary character. China leads in publication output, followed by the United States. Author collaborations predominantly occur in small-scale clusters, indicating relatively limited overall connectivity within the research community. SURG ENDOSC emerged as the most frequently cited journal. Current research hotspots in minimally invasive surgical robotics focus on robotic precision, the learning curve, kinematics, vision systems, master-slave control, haptic feedback, among other areas.

title: Revisiting put-that-there, context aware window interactions via LLMs
authors: Riccardo Bovo, Daniele Giunchi, Pasquale Cascarano, Eric J. Gonzalez, Mar Gonzalez-Franco
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We revisit Bolt’s classic Put-That-There concept for modern head-mounted displays by pairing Large Language Models (LLMs) with XR sensor and tech stack. The agent fuses (i) a semantically segmented 3-D environment, (ii) live application metadata, and (iii) users’ verbal, pointing, and head-gaze cues to issue JSON window-placement actions. As a result, users can manage a panoramic workspace through: (1) explicit commands ("Place Google Maps on the coffee table"), (2) deictic speech plus gestures ("Put that there"), or (3) high-level goals ("I need to send a message"). Unlike traditional explicit interfaces, our system supports one-to-many action mappings and goal-centric reasoning, allowing the LLM to dynamically infer relevant applications and layout decisions, including interrelationships across tools. This enables seamless, intent-driven interaction without manual window juggling in immersive XR environments.

title: Optimized Charging Management for Electric Vehicles Using Neural Networks Considering Fast Charging and Vehicle-To-Grid Operations
authors: A. V. V. Sudhakar, Rajesh. G, Sandeep. C S, Aswani. K, Sivaganesan Sivanantham, Anvesh Perada
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The emergence of electric cars as a cleaner and more efficient substitute for ICE vehicles has raised hopes for a lessening of pollution and strain on the power system. There are a number of obstacles that need to be overcome before electric vehicles can be widely adopted. These include higher initial costs, longer charging times, shorter driving ranges caused by restricted battery capacity, and the added expense of increasing battery capacity to alleviate range anxiety. Market penetration is slowed down by these problems. A data-driven solution was created utilising powerful machine learning techniques to address these limitations and improve Electric Vehicles Charging Management. Prior to feature selection using SPCA, the dataset was subjected to preparation procedures like data cleaning and numerical feature normalisation. The training model used real-world charging data from Temixco and is a two-layer CNN-LSTM. By surpassing previous models, the suggested model achieved an outstanding accuracy rate of 98.56 % when tested on two popular benchmarks. These findings demonstrate the promise of the CNN-LSTM architecture for improved management of electric vehicle charging. Scalable electric vehicle integration is supported by this model, which optimizes charging procedures, allowing for smarter and more sustainable energy management and assisting in the overcoming of important adoption hurdles.

title: A Lightweight Multi-Feature Hybrid Mamba for Remote Sensing Image Scene Classification
authors: Huihui Dong, Jingcao Li, Zongfang Ma, Zhijie Li, Mengkun Liu, Xiaohui Wei, Licheng Jiao
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Remote sensing (RS) image scene classification has wide applications in the field of RS. Although existing methods have achieved remarkable performance, there are still limitations in feature extraction and lightweight design. Current multi-branch models, although performing well, have large parameter counts and high computational costs, making them difficult to deploy on resource-constrained edge devices such as unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). On the other hand, lightweight models like StarNet, having less parameter, but rely on element-wise multiplication to generate features and lack the capture of explicit long-range spatial feature, resulting in insufficient classification accuracy. To address these issues, this letter proposes a lightweight mamba-based hybrid network, namely LMHMamba, whose core is an innovative lightweight multi-feature hybrid mamba (LMHM) module. This module combines the advantage of StarNet in implicitly generating high-dimensional nonlinear features, introduces a lightweight state space module to enhance spatial feature learning capabilities, and then uses local and global attention modules to emphasize local and global features. This enables effective multi-dimensional feature fusion while maintaining low parameter. We validate the performance of LMHMamba model on three remote sensing scene classification datasets and compare it with mainstream lightweight models and the latest methods. Experimental results show that LMHMamba achieves advanced levels in both classification accuracy and computational efficiency, significantly outperforming existing lightweight models, providing an efficient solution for edge deployment. Code is available at https://github.com/yizhilanmaodhh/LMHMamba.

title: Multifunctional Filtering Power Divider With Flexible Frequency, Insertion Phase/Amplitude, and Output Ports Using Multiway Phase Control Network
authors: Yuhang Ning, Zhihua Wei, Pei-Ling Chi, Tao Yang
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: A design methodology for a multifunctional filtering power divider (PD) with tunable frequency, insertion phase, transmission amplitude, and number of output ports is proposed in this letter. The design features a reconfigurable third-order Chebyshev bandpass filter (BPF) integrated with multiple controllable external coupling channels at the outputs. Each output channel includes an external-coupling admittance <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$J$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-inverter and a shunt nonresonating node (NRN). By controlling the established multiway phase control network (PCN), which is composed of the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$J$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-inverters, NRNs, and a resonator for the BPF, the power dividing ratio (PDR) and insertion phase of each port can be independently adjusted while maintaining a constant amplitude response. With zero coupling effect enabled by <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$J$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-inverters, each output ports can be turned on/off. Comprehensive theoretical analysis is provided along with closed-form design equations to guide the design process. For the proof of concept, a circuit prototype of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1\times 4$</tex-math> </inline-formula> multifunctional filtering PD is fabricated and measured, validating the design methodology.

title: DFPL: Decentralized Federated Prototype Learning Across Heterogeneous Data Distributions
authors: Hongliang Zhang, Fenghua Xu, Zhongyuan Yu, Shanchen Pang, Chunqiang Hu, Jiguo Yu
abstract: Federated learning is a distributed machine learning paradigm through centralized model aggregation. However, standard federated learning relies on a centralized server, making it vulnerable to server failures. While existing solutions utilize blockchain technology to implement Decentralized Federated Learning (DFL), the statistical heterogeneity of data distributions among clients severely degrades the performance of DFL. Driven by this issue, this paper proposes a decentralized federated prototype learning framework, named DFPL, which significantly improves the performance of DFL under heterogeneous data distributions. Specifically, DFPL introduces prototype learning into DFL to mitigate the impact of statistical heterogeneity and reduces the amount of parameters exchanged between clients. Additionally, blockchain is embedded into our framework, enabling the training and mining processes to be executed locally on each client. From a theoretical perspective, we analyze the convergence of DFPL by modeling the required computational resources during both training and mining. The experiment results highlight the superiority of DFPL in both model performance and communication efficiency across four benchmark datasets with heterogeneous data distributions.

title: Base Station Beam Scheduling for mmWave Networks with Full-Frequency Reuse
authors: Tung T. Vu, Swaroop Gopalam, Iain B. Collings, Stephen V. Hanly, Hazer Inaltekin
abstract: This paper considers mmWave networks with full-frequency reuse, where each base station (BS) employs a hybrid beamforming (HBF) architecture. We propose a beam scheduling scheme that guarantees users’ target rates, using the smallest possible number of slots at each BS in each transmission block. We avoid intra-BS interference by enforcing constraints that ensure users in adjacent spatial areas are not scheduled simultaneously. We formulate the beam scheduling task as a stochastic mixed-integer nonconvex time allocation problem, allocating time to user-BS links, and provide a novel iterative algorithm that solves the problem. In each iteration there are three stages. Stage one optimizes the time-fraction allocation for user-BS links given an estimate of user rates in each transmission block. Stage two allocates these time-fractions to beams at each BS using a sand-filling policy. Stage three schedules the beams, and updates the estimate of user rates in each block. We apply the scheduler to a HBF transmitter with a zero-forcing (ZF) digital component, and compare its performance to a pure analog beamformer. Numerical results reveal that our proposed scheduling scheme significantly outperforms baseline schemes, and that intra-BS interference is so effectively avoided that the digital ZF is not needed in the HBF.

title: A Multi-dimensional Multi-choice Knapsack Framework for Efficient Resource Allocation in LEO Satellite Networks
authors: Yi Huang, Jin Li, Yonghan Wu, Weixuan Fan, Danshi Wang, Min Zhang
abstract: Large-scale Internet of Things (IoT) connections in dynamic low Earth orbit (LEO) satellite networks face significant challenges in uplink resource scheduling. This paper proposes a framework for optimizing spectral efficiency. The framework satisfies heterogeneous quality of service (QoS) requirements and dynamic buffer constraints under time-varying IoT traffic bursts. It integrates three critical aspects. First, it considers the spatial geometric relationship between satellites and ground user equipment (UE), which determines the connection duration. Second, it achieves service-specific QoS priorities through an adaptive weighting mechanism. Third, it addresses time-varying traffic patterns. Under time-varying resource constraints, the high-dimensional scheduling optimization problem is modeled as a multi-dimensional multi-choice knapsack problem (MMKP). A satellite selection scheme is proposed to efficiently solve the MMKP with mixed constraints. This scheme simplifies the three-dimensional knapsack problem (KP) into a two-dimensional one by taking connection duration into account. This reduction explicitly accounts for the space and time limitations of satellite-ground links. It also integrates service-specific priorities. Meanwhile, the scheme enables each satellite to handle its own computations and resource allocation independently. A binary split dynamic programming (BSDP) algorithm is developed to solve the two-dimensional KP. To compare performance, two large-scale integer optimization methods—the Lagrangian Relaxation Algorithm (LRA) and Branch and Bound (B&B)—were used to solve the KP. The results were compared with a perception-based greedy resource block (RB) allocation for the original resource allocation problem. Extensive simulations based on Starlink demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed solution. When serving over 4000 UEs, the MMKP solution achieves a 46% gain in QoS compared to the greedy benchmark. It also achieves a 60.7% throughput gain. Additionally, BSDP performs almost as well as B&B. BSDP has approximately two orders of magnitude lower computational cost than LRA.

title: Modeling Analysis and experimental verification of tri-axial differential pressure vector hydrophones based on piezoelectric MEMS arrayed sensors
authors: Wei Gao, Zhe Chen, Jiaming Ji, Chunen Zhao, Lixun Qian, Zhi Yang, Tao Xie, Yongyao Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: This paper proposes a tri-axial acoustic differential pressure vector hydrophone, which consists of three pairs of piezoelectric MEMS sensors. The presented sensors are designed and fabricated using the AlN-on-CSOI MEMS platform, realizing an improving acoustic pressure sensitivity of 178.5 dB±2 dB (re 1V/μPa)@1kHz. The pressure-gradient receiving model of pairs of symmetrically distributed MEMS sensors in acoustic field is analyzed, guiding the structure design of the tri-axial acoustic differential pressure vector hydrophone. Calibrations in a standing wave tube are conducted. The effectively operating working frequency band for the presented vector hydrophone is within 20–2000 Hz. The acoustic sensitivities of the hydrophone for the three axes are −182.1 dB@ 1000Hz, -182.5 dB@ 1000 Hz and -182.8 dB @1000 Hz (0 dB = 1 V/μPa), respectively, with a maximum error of less than ±1 dB. Moreover, apparent “eight-shape” directivities for the three axes coupled with the concave point depths of 43.2 dB, 42.1 dB and 39.3 dB, and the asymmetries of 1.8 dB, 2 dB and 1.9 dB are demonstrated. The results indicate that the tri-axial differential pressure MEMS vector hydrophone holds promising prospects for low-frequency underwater acoustic detection applications.

title: Reliability Assessment of the Exchanged Crossed Cube Based on $g$-Extra Connectivity
authors: Xiaowang Li, Shuming Zhou, Lili Tian, Xiaomin Hu
abstract: As the scale of multiprocessor systems increases, so do the requirements for system reliability and security. Modeling how processors and links are connected in a multiprocessor system through a network topology (or graph) is an effective means to study the reliability of the system. Connectivity, one of the important concepts in graph theory, can be used as an indicator of multiprocessor system’s reliability. However, as classical connectivity is not well suited for practical applications, the concept of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$g$</tex-math></inline-formula>-extra connectivity has been proposed to more accurately characterize system’s reliability. The exchanged crossed cube, an innovative network topology derived from the classical hypercube, achieves not only a smaller diameter (improving information transmission efficiency) but also fewer connecting edges (reducing hardware costs when scaling the network). In this article, we derive the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$g$</tex-math></inline-formula>-extra connectivity of the exchanged crossed cube and comparatively analyze its advantages in reliability evaluation through simulations.
