title: Joint Optimization of Model Retraining and Inference Services in DT-Assisted Edge Computing
authors: Xuan Ai, Weifa Liang, Caiyi Liu
abstract: With the advance of emerging digital twin (DT) technology, the combination of DT with edge intelligence brings great potential for high-fidelity, delay-sensitive inference services at the network edge. Due to the training data drift over time, the accuracy of an inference model degrades dramatically. To maintain and/or enhance its accuracy, the service model requires to be continuously retrained using newly generated update data. However, model retraining and inference services compete with each other for the limited computing resource in a mobile edge computing network (MEC), which may decrease user satisfaction with services due to unbearable service delays caused by insufficient resource supplies. Therefore, to ensure high fidelity of service models by choosing models for retraining while maximizing user satisfaction, it becomes a great challenge to allocate the limited computing resource in an MEC to both model retraining and inference services. In this paper, we investigate fidelity-aware, delay-sensitive services in a DT-assisted MEC network over a given time horizon. We study a novel user satisfaction maximization problem with the aim to maximize the long-term user satisfaction on services. We first formulate an integer linear programming (ILP) solution to its offline version. We then devise an online algorithm for the problem with a bounded expected cumulative regret, by leveraging an efficient prediction mechanism and a multi-armed bandit (MAB) based resource allocation strategy. Finally, we evaluate the performance of the proposed algorithm via simulations. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm is promising, outperforming the comparison benchmarks.

title: Coping with Extreme Weather Risks: Implications of Insurance Innovation and Government Subsidies in Agricultural Supply Chains
authors: Xin Wang, Jianghua Wu
abstract: Extreme weather events increasingly disrupt agricultural supply chains (ASCs). Insurance serves as a vital financial buffer, compensating smallholder farmers' input costs while also enhancing their ability to repay loans. Traditional insurance, due to lengthy verification and delayed payouts, limits the farmers' quick response to extreme weather. Recently, smart insurance has emerged as a promising solution, leveraging index-based verification and automated payouts to facilitate timely farmer recovery. This study explores the operation of an e-commerce-based ASC under extreme weather, considering dual protection of crop insurance (traditional or smart) and government subsidies (premium or input). We examine the insurer's decision to adopt smart insurance and its alignment with the socially optimal outcome. Our results show that when farmer recovery efficiency is low, smart insurance is preferred only if traditional verification incurs high costs. Conversely, with efficient farmer recovery, the insurer always adopts smart insurance, which empowers the ASC to sustain under severe weather conditions but may lead to a decline in social welfare due to the associated subsidy expenditure. Furthermore, we analyze the implications of insurance innovation for government subsidy policies. We find that smart insurance can resolve the policy dilemma faced by traditional insurance, where no policy can outperform the other in both farmer well-being and social welfare under severe weather conditions. In contrast, smart insurance enables the input subsidy to achieve a dual-benefit outcome. This finding highlights the potential of insurance innovation in improving government policy effectiveness.

title: Co-opetition in the Ride-Hailing Market: The Role of the Integrated Channel in Balancing Supply and Demand
authors: Chenwei Xu, Gang Li, Chuangyin Dang
abstract: In the ride-hailing market, platforms such as Didi Chuxing are increasingly collaborating with taxi services through the integrated channel, like Simultaneous Ride-Hailing Request (SR). SR allows riders to submit a single request that includes both platform-based and taxi services, with the platform allocating each request to one of the two services and charging the corresponding price. To investigate the implications of SR, we develop an analytical model of a ride-hailing platform that integrates a platform-based service with self-scheduling drivers and a taxi service with fixed supply. Riders differ in their service preferences and sensitivity to driver availability. We find that although integrating the taxi service into the platform intensifies competition for riders between the two services, SR can yield a win-win outcome by improving both platform profitability and taxi utilization. In particular, SR enables the platform to serve additional riders without lowering the price and helps the taxi service alleviate demand loss caused by offline search frictions, thereby mitigating price competition across services. Moreover, we identify the sensitivity of self-scheduling drivers to rider availability as a key performance determinant driving these results. When self-scheduling drivers are sufficiently sensitive, SR adoption is profitable by enhancing supply–demand coordination. Finally, we confirm the robustness of our results by relaxing two key assumptions: allowing the platform to charge the commission fee on the taxi service and permitting platform-based riders to also use SR. Overall, this study provides new insights into platform–taxi cooperation and contributes to the broader understanding of sustainable ride-hailing markets.

title: Imputation using training labels and classification via label imputation
authors: Thu Nguyen, Uyen Dang, Tuan L. Vo, Pål Halvorsen, Michael A. Riegler
abstract: Missing data is a common problem in practice, and various imputation methods have been developed to deal with missing data. However, even though in many cases, the labels are available in the training data, the common practice of imputation usually only relies on the input and ignores the label. We propose Classification Based on MissForest Imputation (CBMI), a classification strategy that initializes the predicted test label with missing values and stacks the label with the input for imputation, allowing the label and the input to be imputed simultaneously. In addition, we propose the Imputation Using Labels (IUL) algorithm, an imputation strategy that stacks the label into the input and illustrates how it can significantly improve the imputation quality. Experiments show that CBMI has competitive classification accuracy when the test set contains missing data, especially for imbalanced data and categorical data. Moreover, for both the regression and classification, IUL consistently shows significantly better results than imputation based on only the input data.

title: Robust prescribed performance fault-tolerant tracking control for p-normal form systems with actuator faults
authors: Guangda Liu, Liyao Hu
abstract: This paper addresses the robust prescribed performance fault-tolerant tracking (RPPFTT) control problem for a class of p-normal form strict-feedback systems with actuator faults. In contrast to existing tracking control strategies, this paper considers the realistic scenario where the reference signal to be tracked is inexactly known. This condition renders the tracking error unobtainable with precision, which consequently poses significant challenges to the tracking control problem. To overcome this challenge, a special finite-time performance function (FTPF) is first proposed. Subsequently, based on the FTPF and the fault-tolerant control (FTC), an RPPFTT controller is developed, ensuring that all states of the closed-loop system remain globally bounded. Furthermore, the tracking error satisfies the prescribed performance bounds and converges to a predefined neighborhood of the equilibrium within any given time, even under the dual challenges of an inexactly known reference signal and actuator faults. Finally, two simulation examples are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness and advantage of the proposed method.

title: KAQG: A Knowledge-Graph-Enhanced RAG for Difficulty-Controlled Question Generation
authors: Ching Han Chen, Ming Fang Shiu
abstract: This study introduces Knowledge Augmented Question Generation (KAQG), an educational assessment framework that integrates Item Response Theory (IRT), Bloom’s Taxonomy, and knowledge graphs into a multi-agent Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system. The proposed approach overcomes limitations of existing methods by enabling fine-grained control over item difficulty, psychometric calibration, and cognitive alignment. It employs multi-graph isolation to preserve domain-specific semantics and leverages a distributed agent architecture coordinated through Data Distribution Service (DDS) for scalable and fault-tolerant operations. Each agent specializes in tasks such as retrieval, generation, or evaluation, forming a modular and traceable pipeline. Distinctively, the framework encodes semantic hierarchies, PageRank-based concept weighting, and assessment-theory parameters directly into the generation process, ensuring that questions are both contextually grounded and cognitively calibrated. Deployed at Taiwan’s National Institute of Environmental Research, the system has demonstrated practical value by reducing manual workload, improving reliability and validity, and supporting both adaptive and standardized assessments. By integrating psychometric theory with AI-driven retrieval and generation, this work establishes a scalable and cognitively aligned solution for education and professional certification.

title: Comparison of Operating Costs and Energy Use in a Thermo-Caloric Heat Pump and an Air-Cooled Chiller System for Data Center Cooling
authors: Brandon Kibbel, Bryce Cox
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Traditional refrigerants used in vapor compression cooling are excellent heat transfer fluids because they change phase at relatively convenient temperatures and pressures. The latent energy associated with this phase change allows for large amounts of heat transfer. Shape memory alloy (SMA) thermocaloric heat pumps are a potential alternative to refrigerant based vapor compression cooling. These heat pumps take advantage of the unique feature of solid SMA materials. When compressed, these materials undergo a solid-to-solid phase change that releases heat. When the compression is released, the phase change is reversed, and the material absorbs heat. The latent heat associated with the phase change, which occurs at room temperature, can be used to provide heating or cooling. By cycling two or more solid heat pump cores, continuous cooling can be provided by an SMA heat pump. Heat pump systems using shape memory alloys like nitinol, can be used to provide cooling. This study examines two potential thermocaloric systems that could be used for data center cooling and compares their performance against a traditional aircooled water chiller. The first thermocaloric system uses a solid block of material with interior channels for cooling water flow. The second system design uses wires instead of a solid block, with cooling water flowing between the wires. A high-level cost comparison was performed to compare the annual energy cost and the purchase cost for each system. The block-based cooler had much higher purchase and energy costs than the alternatives. The wire-based cooler had high purchase costs, but energy costs that were lower than the other two systems. The traditional chiller had the lowest purchase cost, but higher energy use than the wire cooler system. The low energy use estimated for the wire cooler system indicates that there is potential benefit for continued study of this cooling technology, particularly if material costs could be reduced.

title: Demonstrating "FeltSight": Star-nosed Mole-inspired Mixed Reality Haptic Gloves
authors: Danlin Huang, Botao Amber Hu, Dong Zhang, Yifei Liu, Takatoshi Yoshida, Rem RunGu Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: FeltSight is a mixed reality haptic experience that reimagines human perception by drawing inspiration from the tactile navigation of the star-nosed mole. Moving beyond traditional, vision-dominated interaction paradigms, FeltSight enables users to engage in meditative wandering guided by extended-range haptics with subtle visual cues. The system comprises a wearable haptic glove paired with an extended reality interface. As users reach toward objects in their environment, the glove’s vibration actuators—driven by audio-responsive patterns—simulate material textures, producing a sensation akin to touch. Meanwhile, the mixed reality interface offers a deliberately "reduced reality", presenting nearby objects as dynamic point clouds that materialize only in response to exploratory hand gestures. By shifting perceptual focus from the visual to the tactile, FeltSight challenges ocularcentric sensory hierarchies and foregrounds an embodied, relational, and more-than-human mode of sensing.

title: Resource Scheduling Algorithm for Multi-Task Collaborative Planning of Airborne Sensors Based on Low Interception Probability
authors: Chenyang Wang, Yichao Cai, Li Hao, Wenxuan Shen
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: Aiming at the operational scenarios with complex battlefield environments, variable mission requirements, and limited early warning resources in distant seas and regions, this paper proposes an airborne radar low interception probability resource scheduling algorithm based on multi-task collaborative planning. Firstly, combined with the early warning mission requirement framework, the analytical expressions of the networked radar joint interception probability, multi-task echo signal-to-noise ratio, and global task allocation utility function with radar-task node scheduling parameters as variables are derived respectively, which are used as indicators to measure the survival capability of one's own battlefield, target detection performance, and multi-task collaborative execution efficiency. On this basis, with the goal of maximizing the global collaborative scheduling utility function of networked radars, and subject to constraints such as meeting the given maximum allocable time resources of radars, echo signal-to-noise ratio, system detection performance, and minimum interception probability of networked radars, an airborne radar resource scheduling model based on multi-task collaborative planning is established. Finally, a discrete particle swarm optimization algorithm improved based on compression factors is proposed to solve the above nonlinear discrete optimization problem, adaptively generate the global task allocation matrix of radars, and optimize the allocation results of radar-task node scheduling parameters. Simulation results show that compared with other algorithms, the proposed algorithm can effectively improve the efficiency of multi-task collaborative execution and realize efficient resource scheduling of airborne radars.

title: Enhancing Polyp Segmentation Via Encoder Attention and Dynamic Kernel Update
authors: Fatemeh Salahi Chashmi, Roya Sotoudeh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Polyp segmentation is a critical step in colorectal cancer detection, but it remains challenging due to the varied shapes, sizes, and low-contrast boundaries of polyps in medical imaging. In this work, we introduce a novel framework designed to improve segmentation accuracy and efficiency by incorporating a Dynamic Kernel (DK) mechanism and a global Encoder Attention (EA) module. The DK mechanism, initialized by a global context vector from the EA module, iteratively refines segmentation predictions across decoding stages, allowing the model to focus on and accurately delineate complex polyp boundaries. The EA module enhances the network's ability to capture critical lesion features by aggregating multi-scale features from all encoder layers. Additionally, we implement Unified Channel Adaptation (UCA) in the decoder, which standardizes feature dimensions across stages, ensuring consistent and computationally efficient information fusion. We clarify that our approach builds upon the lesion-aware kernel framework [1] by introducing a more flexible, attention-driven kernel initialization and a unified decoder design. Extensive experiments on the Kvasir-SEG and CVC-ClinicDB benchmark datasets demonstrate that our model outperforms several state-of-the-art segmentation models, achieving superior Dice and Intersection over Union (IoU) scores. The UCA simplifies the decoder architecture, resulting in reduced computational cost without compromising accuracy. Our proposed method thus provides a robust, adaptable solution for polyp segmentation, with potential applications in clinical and automated diagnostic systems.

title: Experimental Investigation of Flow Pattern in a Loop Thermosyphon with Horizontal Evaporator
authors: Prem Kumar, Aalekh Srivastava, Susmita Dash, Amrit Ambirajan, Pradip Dutta
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: A loop thermosyphon is a passive two-phase heat transfer device consisting of an evaporator, riser, condenser, and downcomer, and contains a working fluid. It utilizes the latent heat of vaporization and condensation of the working fluid to transfer heat from the heat source to the heat sink. It is a gravityassisted device (evaporator below condenser), as gravity helps liquid return from the condenser to the evaporator. For modeling of a loop thermosyphon, the general assumptions used are (a) two-phase flow exists in the riser and (b) the downcomer is partially or completely filled. However, it is not well understood in which conditions these assumptions are valid, as they depend on the filling ratio, working fluid, and operating heat loads. The present study experimentally explores flow patterns in the riser and downcomer to verify these assumptions. A stainless-steel loop thermosyphon with horizontal evaporator and condenser is utilized. A portion of the riser and downcomer are made of glass tubes to enable visualization of the flow pattern. The effect of working fluid (methanol and isobutane), filling ratio ($20 \%-50 \%$), and heat load ($100 \mathrm{~W}-500 \mathrm{~W}$) on the flow pattern is investigated. It is found that the flow pattern in the riser is generally two-phase (plug/churn to churn flow) and can be single-phase under certain conditions. In the downcomer, the liquid level is observed to be fluctuating.

title: YOLO-DW: An Improved Defect Detection Algorithm Based on YOLOv11
authors: Kailin Liu, Haisheng Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: Steel is a widely used industrial material in the construction, home appliance and automotive industries. Defects generated during production can pose safety hazards, so identifying surface defects is critical. In response to the challenges of high computational resource consumption and low detection accuracy in existing models for industrial quality inspection tasks, this paper presents a lightweight object detection model called YOLO-DW, which is based on the YOLOv11 algorithm framework. Firstly, the DSCB module was designed to reduce model parameters significantly while enhancing the extraction of features for subtle surface defects in steel. Secondly, the Wise-IoU loss function was introduced, leveraging its dynamic, non-monotonic focusing mechanism to quantify positional offsets and scale differences between predicted and actual defect bounding boxes, thereby improving regression accuracy. Finally, comparative and ablation experiments on the public NEU-DET dataset validated the effectiveness of the algorithm. The results show that YOLO-DW achieves an mAP of 79.4% at 50% and an mAP of 49.8% at 95%, with a computational complexity of just 5.9 GFLOPs. YOLO-DW strikes an efficient balance between detection accuracy and computational efficiency, meeting the demands of real-time, on-site detection in the steel industry and providing a highly effective technical solution for steel surface defect detection.

title: Dynamic Cost-Aware SQL Rewriting Algorithm for Multi-Cloud Query Optimization
authors: Sibaram Prasad Panda
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: SQL Query execution across heterogeneous cloud platforms becomes increasingly challenging with the adoption of multi-cloud platforms. Generally, the traditional query optimizers are not considering the varying pricing models and resource characteristics like I/O, CPU, and network egress costs offered by different cloud providers like AWS, Azure and Google Cloud. To address this gap, we propose a Dynamic CostAware SQL Rewriting Algorithm (DCAS) that adaptively rewrites SQL queries to minimize both query cost and execution latency in multi-cloud environments. The algorithm employs a cost model that estimates the monetary expense of a query by analyzing its resource consumption across different clouds. It applies to a combination of fixed and selective rewriting strategies, guided by historical performance data and current cloud pricing, to generate semantically cost-efficient query formulations. The system architecture enables seamless integration with existing query engines and supports asynchronous cost synthesis through region-specific repositories and runtime feedback loops.

title: Polymer-Based Thermal Interface Material Modeling and Selection
authors: Liangkai Ma, Brian Clark, Joe Sootsman
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Polymer-based thermal interface materials (TIMs) are polymeric matrix materials with heat-conducting fillers used to lower the operating temperatures of microelectronics by reducing the thermal resistance between contact surfaces. These thermal interface materials have experienced accelerated growth in recent years driven by the ever-increasing performance and functions of electronic systems pushing the thermal management requirements of devices at an unprecedented pace aligned with several megatrends such as the rapid global adoption of electric vehicles, autonomous driving, 5G, machine learning (ML), and artificial intelligence (AI). A proper selection of thermally conductive composites is critical to the thermal management performance, reliability, and safety of the devices in targeted applications. In this paper, we introduce a hybrid modeling approach that combines thermal finite element analysis (FEA) with statistical modeling. This approach was used to study and identify the critical factors impacting microelectronic device temperature and to guide the selection of TIMs for different applications. A 2D steady state heat transfer FEA model was first developed and validated using experimental data obtained from an in-house thermal test vehicle (TTV). A second FEA model was developed based on a land grid array (LGA) package design from literature. Parametric studies and numerical design of experiments (DOEs) were conducted using the second FEA model to build statistical models for analyzing the factors affecting device thermal management and TIM selection for different applications. An inverse model was developed from the statistical model using statistical software JMP to gain insights into TIM development and selection based on targeted applications. The insights gained from this work are valuable for engineers and researchers working in the field of thermally conductive composites and microelectronic device development and application.

title: Topology Optimization of EV Battery Immersion Cooling Channel
authors: Seunghwan Keum, Peter Andruskiewicz, Erik Yen, Ronald Grover
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Immersion cooling designs, wherein the battery cells and bussing are directly submerged in a circulated dielectric coolant, are a promising battery thermal management solution, especially for high performance vehicles due to its cooling potential. A topology optimization procedure has been developed to analytically design an immersion cooling passage for a prismatic battery cell module. The procedure utilizes a combined 2D-3D CFD approach. Starting from an empty cavity of a single cell, an optimizer first morphs a new cooling passage in 2D by solving a porosity transport equation based on a linear weighted merit function of cell temperature and flow pressure drop. Next, the 2D flow passage is converted into a 3D model and replicated over the entire prismatic cell module. The resulting thermal simulation is validated using rigorous flow and heat dissipation boundary conditions. Initial results show the optimized design has a 5 degC reduction in maximum temperature consistently over a range of coolant flow rates. However, it is found that the 2D topology solution can have regions of small, non-zero permeability interpreted as coolant seepage through walls. As a result, imposing small flow-through channels in the 3D model lowers maximum cell temperature and flow pressure drop at high flow rates when compared to a baseline design.

title: Performance Comparison Between Single and Dual-Transformer Configurations in DC-DC Half-Bridge LLC Resonant Converters
authors: Édwin Augusto Tonolo, Henrique M. V. D. B. Campos, André de Souza Leone, William Rafhael da Silva, Rômulo Francisco Lepinsk Lopes, Carlos Gabriel Bianchin
abstract: This paper compares the operational characteristics of a half-bridge LLC (HBLLC) resonant converter with a single and a dual-transformer configuration, series connected on the primary and parallel connected on the secondary. The operational characteristics of the converter depend on the coupling factor of the inductance ratio (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex>), which defines the ratio of the magnetizing and resonant inductances of the resonant tank and thus directly affects the converter behavior. Thermal performance, switching frequency range, magnetic component volume, and copper utilization are important parameters examined. A 3kW prototype was tested with fixed input and output voltages of 250V and 350V, respectively. The results indicate that increasing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex> improves efficiency at lighter loads but expands the switching frequency range. The dual transformer configuration setup promotes better thermal distribution and reduces peak temperatures by splitting the magnetic flux and current among the windings. However, this configuration increases the overall volume, weight, and component size. The results reinforce the balance that can be achieved between thermal performance, resonant efficiency, and size in resonant converters.

title: Map Formats and Landmark Cues: Their Influence on Spatial Memory and Wayfinding in Virtual Reality
authors: Sabah Boustila, Greg A. Jamieson, Paul Milgram
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Understanding how spatial representations and environmental cues influence wayfinding and spatial memory is crucial for designing effective XR navigation systems. While most Augmented Reality (AR) aids rely on turn-by-turn guidance, they often lack survey information that supports spatial learning.We compare two informationally equivalent map formats: a conventional head-down, track-up map and SkyMap, a quasi-world-aligned, head-up display (HUD) rendered above the user. In a controlled virtual reality study simulating urban wayfinding, we also manipulate the presence of tall, visually distinctive buildings to examine the role of landmarks in spatial orientation and memory.Results show that SkyMap supports comparable performance to conventional maps across all measures, including spatial recall, challenging previous assumptions that HUD hinder spatial knowledge acquisition. Landmark presence, however, had no significant effect on wayfinding or memory. These findings highlight the potential of HUD-based survey maps for immersive navigation tasks and provide design recommendations for enhancing spatial awareness in AR interfaces.

title: Chromoria VR: Biometric Evidence of the Psychological Benefits of Virtual Reality Coloring
authors: Daye Kim, Jusub Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Chromoria VR is a virtual reality (VR) coloring application designed to promote psychological relaxation through interactive 3D creative engagement. EEG and PPG data collected before and after the experience were analyzed for 30 adult participants. Results showed a significant decrease in heart rate and brain stress, along with an increase in brain score and concentration. These findings suggest that creative coloring activity in a virtual environment can positively influence emotional relaxation and concentration.

title: Autonomous Photovoltaic System for Water Pumping in Irrigating Remote Agricultural Areas
authors: Rhuan Gustavo Beling, Tailan Orlando, Fellipe Dos Passos Rosa, Denizar Cruz Martins, André Luís Kirsten, Lenon Schmitz, Roberto Francisco Coelho
abstract: This work presents the design of a 360 W twostage photovoltaic inverter for submersible vibrating pumps in irrigation. The architecture uses a high-gain DC-DC converter with a coupled inductor, followed by a full-bridge inverter to ensure a high-quality AC supply. A multi-mode control strategy integrates Maximum and Limited Power Point Tracking (MPPT and LPPT) algorithms, maximizing energy extraction while preventing overload under variable irradiance. By eliminating batteries, the system reduces cost, complexity, and improves reliability. Simulation results confirm the controller effectively regulates the DC bus and maintains stable, safe pump operation during rapid irradiance changes. The proposed solution offers a robust and efficient alternative for off-grid water pumping, particularly in resource-constrained environments.

title: Progress Towards Improving the C-reactive Protein Limit of Detection of an Optical Cavity-Based Biosensor
authors: Aidan Hagemann, Jenna Kleiss, Riley Wills, Emily Rogers, Makaylah Williams, Jonathan Harrison, Seunghyun Kim
abstract: An optical cavity-based biosensor (OCB) using low-cost optical components has been developed as a point-of-care biosensor for early disease detection. We initially demonstrated a limit of detection (LOD) of 43.3 ng/mL for C-reactive protein (CRP). In two more recent studies, the sensitivity was improved using two different methods. The first was enhancing the Q factor of the resonance cavity by increasing the thickness of the reflective layers used to fabricate the device. The second was investigating different APTES silanization processes which led us to select a methanol-based process that yielded more sensitive results due to the monolayer-like characteristics it produced. In this work, these two improvements are used together to improve the CRP LOD to 46.3 pg/mL, a nearly 1000 times improvement over our first findings. Having demonstrated such high sensitivity while using low-cost optical components, we believe our OCB shows great promise for use as a point-of-care biosensor.

title: Thermal Impedance Characterization of IGBT Modules: A Comparison Between Datasheet, Geometric, and Experimental Data
authors: Deivid F. de Souza, Itamar F. Soares Bollmann, Adalberto J. Rossa, Erick M. da Silveira Brito, Sérgio V. Garcia Oliveira, Allan F. Cupertino, João V. Matos Farias, Mauricio de Campos, Jose R. Pinheiro
abstract: This paper presents a comparative study of thermal impedance curves (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Z_{t h}$</tex>) in IGBT modules, obtained from datasheets, chip geometry, and experimental measurements. The first Cauer network is derived from a conversion of the Foster network data provided by the datasheet. The second is a Cauer network constructed using internal geometric data, material properties, layer stacking, and temperature-dependent layer characteristics of the module. Both networks are implemented in Piecewise Linear Electrical Circuit Simulation (PLECS) to generate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Z_{t h}$</tex> profiles, with notable differences observed in the transient region. Experimental measurements show that the application of a thermal interface material (TIM) significantly reduces <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Z_{t h}$</tex> and improves transient stability, whereas forced convection primarily decreases its steady-state component. The combined TIM and fan configuration yields the lowest overall thermal impedance. These results corroborate the trends predicted by the models, underscore the critical role of experimental validation, and provide guidance for the optimization of thermal management strategies in high-reliability IGBT applications.

title:
Round-Trip
                    <sup>2</sup>
                    Gesture: Inplace IMU Gesture Recognition with Visual Guidance for Out-of-FOV Interaction
authors: Taejun Son, Juyoung Lee, Seo Young Oh, Woontack Woo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We propose Round-Trip<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> Gesture, an interaction system that uses smartwatch IMU sensors to enable inplace gesture input free from the sensing FOV of devices. Current smartglasses input is limited by social unsuitability of voice commands and by the restricted sensing field-of-view inherent to hand tracking. Our system introduces a delimiter gesture based on specific wrist motions to achieve reliable interaction in real-world scenarios. Our system enables intuitive gesture interaction free from occulsion and physical constraints. We evaluated a set of 5 gestures with 8 participants. Four gestures showed over 90% accuracy in leave-one-subject-out cross-validation. We introduce the potential of the system through notification dismissal and video playback control applications, demonstrating seamless out-of-FOV interaction in Mixed Reality environments.

title: Enhancing Emotion Detection Through the Integration of Generative AI and Transformer Architectures
authors: Gunjan Sethi, Vikrant Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Recent advancements Generative Artificial Intelligence (Gen AI) and architectures built on Transformers have provided different approaches to increase the accuracy and contextual understanding of emotion recognition tasks. This paper aims to study a hybrid approach that incorporates Gen AI and Transformer models, both BERT and GPT, to improve the robustness and precision of emotion detection in text and multi-structured data. The limitations posed by traditional deep learning is mitigated by the proposed method which uses contextual learning of Transformers and data augmentation along semantic understanding by Gen AI. The outcome of experiments based on benchmark datasets of emotion reveals that the developed framework is efficient in integrating profound emotional understanding that enables the development of more human-friendly AI systems. Experiments on benchmark datasets Go-Emotions, Emotion-Stimulus, and MELD show that the proposed hybrid framework reached an average accuracy of 75.3 percent, with up to 8.8 percent F1-score uplift for underrepresented emotions, such as empathy and frustration, when compared to baseline Transformer based models.

title: Research on Frequency Stability of High Proportion Renewable Energy Power System Based on Virtual Inertia Control
authors: Xiaolong Huang, Boyuan Cao, Shuang Wang
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: With the high penetration of clean energy such as wind power and photovoltaic power generation, the energy supply mode has changed accordingly. The uncertainty of new energy output has a significant impact on the stability of the power system. To solve this problem, this article introduces a virtual inertia control strategy, which simulates the inertia characteristics of synchronous generators to enable high proportion new energy systems to provide frequency response similar to traditional synchronous generators. Establish models for wind turbines, photovoltaic systems, and hybrid energy storage devices based on the wind solar energy storage interconnection system, and analyze the power angle swing characteristics. Based on the principle of improving system stability through virtual inertia, an adaptive virtual inertia control strategy based on Linear Quadratic Regulator(LQR) is proposed. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed virtual inertia control strategy was verified through a case study in an industrial park.

title: Current Virtual Oscillator Control for Grid-Connected Inverters
authors: Igor Ribeiro Pereira, Daniel Alves Costa, Cláudio Henrique G. Dos Santos, João Marcus Soares Callegari, Sidelmo Magalhães Silva
abstract: The integration of renewable energy sources such as photovoltaic and wind power demands adequate inverter control strategies for reliable grid operation. Traditional currentcontrolled voltage-source inverters (VSIs) rely on synchronization mechanisms like phase-locked loops (PLLs), which may perform poorly under weak grid conditions and involve low-bandwidth dynamics. This paper introduces the Current Virtual Oscillator Control (cVOC), a novel current-mode control technique inspired by the Virtual Oscillator Control (VOC) method originally developed for voltage-controlled inverters. The proposed cVOC strategy synthesizes the reference current directly from the measured grid voltage waveform, enabling independent control of apparent power magnitude and power factor angle without requiring filtered calculations of active/reactive power or RMS quantities. This leads to faster dynamic response and inherent harmonic attenuation. Simulation results demonstrated that the cVOC accurately tracked power references and maintained stability despite voltage disturbances.

title: Real-Time Estimation of Power System Inertia and Damping Constant Using Forgetting Factor Rls
authors: Rodrigo P. Medeiros, Ricardo L. A. Ribeiro, Thiago O. A. Rocha
abstract: Renewable energy sources play a crucial role in facilitating the energy transition. These sources are interconnected to the grid through power converters that have zero inertia. In addition, renewable energy sources exhibit significant time variability, leading to frequency oscillations and variations in system inertia. This paper presents a real-time method for estimating the inertia and power system damping constant using a state observer that employs a forgetting factor recursive leastsquares method. The proposed approach utilizes voltage and current data from a point of common coupling (PCC) microgrid within a laboratory experimental setup. The system is excited by controlled transients generated to provoke modifications in the system load. Experimental results from the microgrid laboratory setup validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Analysis and Design of State Observers Applied to a Six-Phase Permanent Magnet Synchronous Machine
authors: Arthur de Carvalho Batista Dias, Letícia Duque Giovannini, Gustavo Miranda Auler, Gabriel Azevedo Fogli
abstract: This paper proposes to study two topologies of state observers in order to evaluate their accuracy for a six-phase permanent magnet synchronous machine (PMSM). Namely, the Luenberger observer and the Unknown Input Observer (UIO). The dynamic model of the machine and the design equations of the observers are presented along with the closed-loop strategy using two independent voltage source inverters (VSIs). Experimental results, obtained with a digitally controlled hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) implementation, are also shown. The results suggest that the UIO should be preferred in control and fault diagnosis applications due to its robustness to exogenous inputs.

title: Three-Phase Four-Wire Shunt Active Power Filter Based on Cascaded Half-Bridge Converters
authors: Aléssio Trajano Sousa Soares Santos, Cursino Brandão Jacobina, Jean Torelli Cardoso, Brenda Mayra da Silva Pereira, Douglas de Souza Sesion
abstract: This paper proposes a modified configuration of a three-phase shunt active power filter (SAPF), employing halfbridge cells per phase combined with a three-phase converter, designed for four-wire electrical systems. The converter topology reduces the number of semiconductor devices by eliminating legs through clamping techniques, while also mitigating harmonic distortion and compensating reactive and harmonic power in four-wire systems. A scalar PWM modulation technique is applied for switching control. Simulation and closed-loop experimental results under unbalanced load conditions demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed solution in maintaining unity power factor and balancing the DC link voltages.

title: Estimation of DC-Link Capacitor Temperature in PV Inverters from Datasheet Parameters
authors: Thalisson Glória De Almeida, Charles Schardong, Lucas Vizzotto Bellinaso, Leandro Michels, Rodrigo Cassio De Barros, Heverton Augusto Pereira
abstract: The thermal behavior of dc-link capacitors critically impacts the reliability of photovoltaic (PV) inverters. However, key thermal parameters used in component lifetime evaluation are often absent from manufacturer datasheets. Furthermore, the converter's power circuit topology, which is essential for accurate thermal modeling, is also generally not provided. In this context, this work proposes a simplified method to estimate the dc-link capacitor temperature using only available datasheet values, enabling the derivation of equivalent series resistance (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$E S R$</tex>), thermal resistance (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R_{t h}$</tex>) and thermal capacitance (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$C_{t h}$</tex>) from nominal operating conditions. The method's effectiveness is validated through both simulations and experiments on 5 kW single-phase PV inverters. In addition, the results demonstrate that considering <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$C_{t h}$</tex> improves transient response accuracy and reduces the maximum temperature estimation error by 0.64° C compared to conventional steady-state models. This approach offers a practical, datasheet-based solution for thermal analysis in power electronics design.

title: Photonic Entanglement Using Transition Metal Dichalcogenide Quantum Dots for Advanced Quantum Computation
authors: Choudhury Jayant Praharaj
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: This paper presents numerical calculations of quantum biexcitons in h-BN/monolayer WSe2 quantum dots for use in ultrafast photonic quantum computation. Polarization-entangled photons can be generated from biexciton states for two-qubit entanglement needed for many quantum computation frameworks. Biexciton binding energies are calculated and compared with thermal energies for quantifying the high-coherence quantum computation possibilities. Binding energies of 60-100meV are achievable, leading to stable quantum computer designs. Calculated decoherence parameters show that high-fidelity quantum computation is achievable using this technology. Various 2D materials are compared for implementation of quantum computation using the dot-photon-gate methodology.

title: Operation Optimization of Integrated Energy Systems Considering Molten Salt Heat Storage
authors: Zhongguang Yang, Weipeng Liang, Yang Du, Lingyu Guo, Simin Wu, Shuze Du, Haojun Jin, Hongbo Ren
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: With the increase in the penetration of volatile and interstitial renewable energy in the integrated energy system, the buffer role of energy storage becomes more and more prominent. To this end, this study proposes an integrated energy system incorporating molten salt thermal storage and explores its operation optimization method. Firstly, this paper constructs the technical architecture of the integrated energy system covering molten salt thermal storage; secondly, taking the lowest annual discounted total cost of the integrated energy system as the optimization objective, and considering multiple constraints such as the energy balance, equipment operation, and so on; thirdly, focusing on the system optimization operation strategy and the operation optimization method of the energy storage equipment; Finally, the rationality of the method is verified by a typical case, and three typical days are selected for analysis, focusing on the optimal operation strategy of the system and the scheduling strategy of the energy storage equipment.

title: Experimental Study Of Oil Cooling of Large Electric Machine For High Power Application
authors: Stéphane Saddour, Riadh Boubaker, Safouene Ouenzerfi, Aurelie Fasquelle, Daniel Loloy, Hakim El Bahi, Souad Harmand
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: As power density in electric machines continues to rise, particularly in the static components housing copper, the development of efficient and reliable cooling strategies becomes imperative. This paper focuses on the experimental investigation of oil-jet cooling applied to a segment of winding representing the end-windings of a high-power electric machine’s stator. The coils subjected to the oil jet are meticulously instrumented, enabling comprehe nsive monitoring of temperature distribution across the entire coil surface. Our study showcases the effective ness of this cooling technique, revealing a maximum temperature of $84^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ on the end-windings under oil jet. Additionally, we conduct evaluations using various oils characterized by different viscosity ranges and thermal conductivities. Our findings culminate in a comparative analys is of oil-jet cooling against alte rnative methods, including air jet cooling and parallel air flow.

title: Frequency Regulation of Battery and SSSC based Renewable System with MFOTID Controller
authors: Subhranshu Sekhar Pati, Umamani Subudhi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: The proposed study presents the design and frequency control of a two-area interconnected power system comprising both conventional and non-conventional energy sources, including thermal in conjunction with small hydro, and solar thermal power plants. In addition to generation sources, the system incorporates energy storage and Flexible AC Transmission System (FACTS) devices, such as battery storage system and Static Synchronous Series Compensators (SSSC), to reflect modern power system configurations. The integration of these devices not only enhances system reliability but also effectively mitigates large frequency oscillations in the transmission lines. A Modified Fractional Order Tilt Integral Derivative (MFOTID) controller with a filtering mechanism is employed to ensure precise and stable frequency regulation. The controller parameters are optimized using a simple yet effective optimization technique. Comparative performance analyses with various control strategies confirm the superior efficiency of the proposed MFOTID-based approach.

title: Optimization of copper filled Through Package Via geometry to minimize thermal induced stresses at Glass - TPV interface in Borosilicate glass interposer
authors: Krishna Bhavana Sivaraju, Pratik Bansode, Sai Abhideep Pundla, Akhil Kalapala, Rabin Bhandari, Dereje Agonafer
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: With the heterogenous integration roadmaps claiming the decline of Moore’s Law is inevitable, industries are looking at alternatives to pack more functionalities into the electronic packages. As they head towards 3D integration, interposers play a pivotal role in enabling the connections between different chips. Over the last two decades organic and silicon interposers have gained wide popularity and applications, but they are not devoid of limitations. The high cost of silicon interposer and relatively low interconnect density in organic interposer have propelled researchers to look at glass as interposer material. Glass interposers have high electrical resistivity, low cost and low insertion losses. Among a wide variety of glass interposers available, Borosilicate glass interposer with high thermal resistance, optical transmission and high chemical durability, is widely used in the electronic industry, especially in LCD panels owing to its CTE match with silicon and ease of panel-based processing. Copper filled Through Package Vias (TPVs) in glass interposers enable the communication between vertically stacked chips when the lateral communication is taken care of by redistribution layers. But the Coefficient of Thermal Expansion (CTE) mismatch between copper (~ 17.3 ppm/°C) and glass (~ 3.3 ppm/°C) contribute to non-uniform expansion at the interface of TPV and contribute to stresses during thermal cycling. The present study aims at using finite-element method to optimize the copper filled Through Package Via geometry by investigating radial stress and axial strain at critical corners of the interface for different height to diameter ratios of TPV under thermal cycling.

title: Direct Torque Control Strategy of Switching Reluctance Motor Based on Self-Disturbance
authors: Jinlin Cong, Zengrui Zhang, Xiaoyun Sui, Baojiang Sun
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Manufacturing System (ICAMTMS)
abstract: Aiming at the problem that the torque fluctuation in the commutation zone is caused by the overshoot of hysteresis control when the four-phase switched reluctance motor (SRM) is used by traditional direct torque control (DTC), the traditional hysteresis loop rule is improved in the inner loop control strategy, that is, a three-level hysteresis loop control method is proposed. At the same time, in order to solve the problem of slow response of proportional integral (PI) control by the speed outer ring, the self-interference immunity control (ADRC) and sliding mode control (SMC) technology are integrated in the outer ring design, and the sliding mode self-interference immunity (SM-ADRC) outer ring control method is proposed. The simulation results show that it can effectively shorten the response time, improve the anti-interference ability of the system and inhibit the SRM torque pulsation.

title: A Novel Hybrid Architecture for Breast Cancer Detection Using Machine Learning and Deep Learning
authors: K Sonali, Sujata Chakravarty, Trilochan Rout, A. Subhashree Patro, Amarjit Dalai, Soubhagya Ranjan Mallick
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: One of the main causes of death for women globally is breast cancer, and better treatment results depend on early and precise identification. In order to classify breast cancer using medical imaging data, this study compares machine learning (ML) with deep learning (DL) approaches. Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), and K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) algorithms were used to classify the features that were retrieved using the Gray Level Co-occurrence Matrix (GLCM) in the machine learning technique. Among these techniques, the best accuracy attained was 85.17%. Using pre-trained architectures like VGG16 and ResNet16, convolutional layers were used in the DL technique to automatically extract features. These models performed quite well, with a maximum accuracy of 96.55%. The findings unequivocally show that deep learning models perform better than conventional machine learning methods that depend on manually created features since they can instantly learn intricate patterns from photos. This study supports the incorporation of DL into computer-aided diagnostic systems for clinical usage and emphasizes its potential to improve breast cancer diagnosis.

title: Day-Ahead Optimal Scheduling of Integrated Energy Systems under a Load Factor-Based Transmission and Distribution Pricing Mechanism
authors: Min Yang, Xiaoyu Shao, Bao Wang, Qixing Sun
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: The rapid development of Integrated Energy Systems (IES) has led to increased load volatility and complicated cost allocation mechanisms for transmission and distribution, thereby imposing higher demands on the economic efficiency and operational reliability of system operation. To address this, this paper proposes a load characteristic-oriented transmission and distribution pricing mechanism, which integrates flexible load scheduling to establish a day-ahead optimal scheduling model for IES.In the pricing mechanism design, a BARY curve-based capacity cost allocation method is adopted under user load factor considerations, enabling the formulation of a scientifically rational two-part tariff scheme. By incorporating a flexible load model, the proposed framework optimizes both the economic performance andflexibility of load management. The IES optimization model minimizes operational costs as its objective function, solved using the Gurobi solver within a Python-based simulation platform. Case studies demonstrate that the proposed approach effectively improves the load factor of IES, optimizes the load profile, and enhances the allocation of energy resources. Economic analysis further verifies that the method achieves significant improvements in system profitability by reducing redundant capacity investments and operational losses.

title: Perceptual-Semantic Adaptive Rendering Model-Based Digital Display System for Excellent Traditional Chinese Culture
authors: Yan Zhou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The integration of digital technologies into cultural heritage has created new opportunities for immersive preservation and dissemination of traditional Chinese culture. However, existing Level-of-Detail (LOD) with Occlusion Culling Virtual Reality (OC-VR) display systems often straggles with semantic information loss, abrupt visual transitions and reduced user immersion under bandwidth constraints. To overcome these limitations, this research proposes the Perceptual-Semantic Adaptive Rendering (PSAR) method to design the application of a digital display system for excellent traditional Chinese culture. Initially, the system architecture incorporates Data Capture and Asset Packaging (DCAP) for high-fidelity models and annotations. Then, system integrates Semantic Importance Graph (SIG) to protect culturally significant motifs, and a Perceptual Importance Estimator (PIE) to model user gaze and task focus. These are combined by a Gaze- and Task-driven LOD Selector (GT-LS) to balance perceptual attention with semantic value to guide rendering. A Hybrid Rendering Manager (HRM) and Neural-Enhanced Reconstruction (NER) ensure efficient, high-quality visualization across diverse platforms. Finally, an Interaction & Semantic User Interface (IS-UI) layer enhances traditional Chinese cultural understanding. Results demonstrates that the proposed PSAR achieved improved rendering performance in term of Frames Per Second (FPS) of 118.3, when compared with the existing LOD-VR model.

title: Digital Transformation in the Supply Chain: Leveraging AI and Blockchain for Operational Efficiency
authors: Devidas Bhat, Ninad Thorat, Sudheendra Mouli. H. C, Ganesha. B. B, Kamal Sutaria, Sathish Kannan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The digital transformation of supply chains is revolutionizing operational efficiency by integrating advanced technologies such as Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Blockchain. This study explores a comprehensive framework that combines AI-driven analytics and Blockchain's decentralized ledger capabilities to address challenges in supply chain transparency, traceability, and decision-making. AI enables predictive analytics for demand forecasting and dynamic optimization, achieving a 20% reduction in inventory costs and a 15% improvement in delivery times. Blockchain ensures end-to-end visibility and data integrity, reducing fraud risks by 30% and enhancing trust among stakeholders. Experimental results from a simulated supply chain network validate the proposed framework's effectiveness in improving supply chain agility and resilience, paving the way for future digital transformation in global supply networks.

title: Advancements in Image Denoising Using Deep Learning: Models, Challenges, and Future Directions
authors: M Kristappa, Krishnanaik Vankdoth
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Because deep learning approaches are better at handling complicated noise patterns, the field of picture denoising has embraced them more and more. When it comes to handling different kinds of noise, especially Gaussian and realworld noise, different deep learning models show distinct advantages. Large-scale datasets and sophisticated optimization techniques help these models perform better when it comes to estimating and reducing noise artifacts. Although significant progress has been made in the domain of image denoising, a comprehensive and structured classification of the diverse methodologies remains underdeveloped. This study seeks to fill that gap by offering a critical and organized review of recent advancements in deep learning-based denoising techniques. It highlights both traditional approaches and more recent hybrid models. Through the use of widely recognized benchmark datasets, this review examines the performance of leading denoising algorithms, especially in complex scenarios where images suffer from multiple forms of degradation. In addition, the work explores how convolutional neural networks (CNNs) manage various types of noise, providing insights into their practical effectiveness. The paper concludes by identifying key challenges that continue to hinder progress in the field and suggests promising avenues for future investigation.

title: Current Status and Future Prospects of Coal Mine Big Data Research and Application
authors: Yunqi Chen
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Based on an overview of the connotation and characteristics of coal mine big data, this paper expounds on the key technologies of coal mine big data in five aspects, including data collection, preprocessing, storage management, analysis and mining, and visualization, and makes a comparative analysis of some of the main algorithm models; summarizes the typical application scenarios of coal mine big data in disaster monitoring and early warning, electromechanical equipment fault diagnosis, machine vision recognition and analysis, hidden danger and accident correlation analysis, etc.; analyzes the problems and future development directions of coal mine big data in data standards and specifications, efficient processing and storage of massive data, and application of large models and new artificial intelligence technologies, in order to provide useful reference for related research and further promote the innovation and application of coal mine big data technology.

title: Discussing Native Visual Language for Visual Acceptance in Extended Reality
authors: Francesco Musolino, Michele Fiorentino
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Extended Reality (XR) faces adoption barriers in professional workspaces, a challenge beyond mere technical limitations. This position paper discusses that an underestimated limitation could be Visual Dissonance: a fundamental conflict between the consumer-grade aesthetics of many XR systems and the established visual culture of professional workspaces. This dissonance may undermine XR credibility and trigger user distrust, an issue that traditional technology acceptance models are not adequately able to capture. As contribution, we discuss theoretical backgrounds and speculate methodological solutions for achieving Visual Acceptance, which requires the development of a Native Visual Language for professional workspaces XR based on: (1) Visual User-Centered Design to respect professional aesthetic boundaries; (2) the formulation of a Native Visual Language that leverages XR’s unique spatial affordances instead of replicating 2D paradigms; and (3) Dynamic Visual Scaling, a method for contextually adapting visual formality. By defining this agenda, this paper aims to shift the research focus from purely technical optimization toward a design-centric approach, paving the way for the validation of adaptive visual systems and the establishment of new metrics for long-term XR adoption in workspaces.

title: Balancing Innovation and Responsibility: Framework for Designing User-Centred Virtual Reality Applications for Forensic Mental Health Care
authors: Dilshani Kumarapeli, Ivana Nakarada-Kordic, Stephen Reay
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Forensic Mental Health Services (FMHS) work to rehabilitate individuals with mental health disorders who are involved in the criminal justice system. The use of immersive technologies, especially virtual reality (VR), presents new opportunities for therapeutic interventions but also raises significant legal, ethical, and technical challenges. Addressing these challenges requires coordinated input from clinicians, engineers, legal experts, and service users, which could be challenging for small development teams. Hence, as a solution, we propose the Forensic Immersive Framework (FIF), a structured guideline designed to integrate legal compliance, ethical safeguards, and technical best practices. This framework aims to support the development of user-centred VR applications in FMHS contexts. FIF emphasises actionable strategies to ensure privacy, autonomy, cultural inclusivity, and system reliability within secure environments. Following these guidelines is vital to ensure that VR solutions comply with regulatory standards while providing safe, effective, and patient-focused care.

title: FloatMind: AI-Driven Emotional Engagement for Gamified Meditation in Mixed Reality
authors: Liuchuan Yu, Shuqi Liao, Yan Zeng, Tingting Luo, Zihan Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: FloatMind is a mixed reality (MR) meditation experience that combines large language models (LLMs), gamification, and immersive environments to promote emotional well-being. The system features an empathetic AI avatar that initiates personalized conversations and generates emotion-driven floating bubbles. When interacted with, these bubbles open portals, seamlessly transitioning users from their physical surroundings into a serene virtual forest. Within this space, intuitive hand tracking enables natural interaction with calming elements—such as trees, auroras, and flowing particles—enhancing mindfulness and reducing stress. By blending AI-driven guidance, mixed reality, and interactive design, FloatMind reimagines meditation for modern lifestyles.

title: ARGESH: A scaffolded System for Interactive Geometry Learning in AR
authors: Jalal Safari Bazargani, Seyyed Rasoul Mousavi, Abolghasem Sadeghi-Niaraki, Soo-Mi Choi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Understanding basic geometric shapes is critical for elementary learners, yet traditional classroom methods often struggle to convey abstract concepts in an engaging and comprehensible manner. ARGESH is a marker-less Android AR application designed to support 8–9-year-old students through interactive tutorials, real-time feedback, and scaffolded shape construction tasks. In a controlled study with 64 participants, ARGESH users demonstrated 20% higher immediate gains and 24% better retention compared to a textbook-based control group. Attitudinal measures indicated increased enjoyment and perceived educational value, suggesting that AR interventions can both reduce cognitive load and foster spatial reasoning.

title: A Comparison of CNN Architectures in Edge Computing Environments: Health Care Prospect
authors: Nur Syahidah Yunos, Sumendra Yogarayan, Nazrul Muhaimin Ahmad, Subarmaniam Kannan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: Wearing a face mask has become an essential accountability for ensuring public safety in view of developing health regulations and the necessity for proactive safety measures. This research conducts a comparison of several lightweight neural network architectures, with a specific focus on their application in face mask detection for edge computing. Considering the intrinsic processing limits of edge devices such as raspberry pi, this research carefully evaluates the complexity of models and computational overhead. Through extensive evaluation using a balanced dataset of 11,792 images, we investigate the performance of architectures including CNN (Convolutional Neural Network), MobileNetV2, and EfficientNetB0. This includes model accuracy, Training time, inference time and model size. The results provided show that there are trade-offs, with some models has less time training but potentially less precise, and others being more accurate but slower. The work concludes by proposing potential future research directions, which include the investigation of novel architectures and advanced model optimization techniques.

title: PQACLA: Post-Quantum Anonymous and Robust Certificateless Identity Authentication for the Internet of Vehicles
authors: Yuqian Ma, Qingfeng Cheng, Xinghua Li, Zhiquan Liu
abstract: Boosted by the explosive development of the Internet of Things (IoT) technology, the Internet of Vehicles (IoV) has become mature. Various and heterogeneous devices are increasingly included in IoV, which greatly facilitates people's lives, from navigation, charging, refueling, and other aspects. However, numerous devices in the IoV also bring serious security problems. Communications between vehicle entities and service entities are always exposed to powerful adversaries who can eavesdrop, intercept, and tamper communication messages. Besides, users' personal information faces leakage risks that seriously threaten people's life security (either passengers or pedestrians). Authentication and key agreement schemes for IoV are neither able to resist quantum attacks nor communication efficient. Therefore, in this paper, we propose a lattice-based anonymous certificateless authentication and key agreement scheme, PQACLA, for secure communication between vehicular entities and service entities. The PQACLA scheme leverages pseudonym identity technology and conditional malicious tracking to realize and guarantee the vehicle entities' anonymity and untraceability. Adopting provable security, the PQACLA scheme is proved secure under the random oracle model. Its security is also verified using the Scyther formal tool and informal security analysis. Compared to relative schemes, the PQACLA scheme behaves better, as its communication cost and computation cost are well balanced in total.

title: Learning-Based Locomotion Transition Detection: Offline Optimization to Tackle System- and User-Specific Variability in Lower Limb Exoskeletons_supp1-3628049.pdf
authors: Andrea Dal Prete
abstract: Accurate detection of locomotion transitions (e.g., walk-to-sit, stair ascent/descent) is critical for controlling lower limb exoskeletons, as each mode requires specific assistance. Variability in sensor data due to user- and system-specific factors challenges nonadaptive classifiers in maintaining accuracy without latency. We evaluated a threshold-based finite-state machine trained via machine learning across 18 subjects using two exoskeletons, eWalk and autonomyo. Transition detection exceeded 90% in most cases, but some transitions reached only 70% median accuracy. The performance was influenced by user behavior and exoskeleton design. To address this, we introduced two offline adaptation methods: a statistics-based approach (SBA) and Bayesian optimization (BO). For eWalk, SBA improved mean accuracies by $2\%\text{--}8\%$ (e.g., walk-to-sit $92\%\to 94\%$, sit-to-walk $86\%\to 90\%$, stair ascent-to-walk $80\%\to 88\%$). BO achieved similar gains and further enhanced stair descent (W–SD $88\%\to 96\%$, SD–W $92\%\to 98\%$). For autonomyo, SBA showed no effect, while BO improved accuracies by 7.5%–15% (e.g., walk-to-sit $77.5\%\to 90\%$). At the individual level, BO’s effect ranged from no benefit to improvements up to 80% for specific transitions. By integrating subject- and system-specific data, this approach provides a reliable, interpretable solution for locomotion transition detection, enhancing personalization and exoskeleton performance.

title: Quantum-Driven Multihead Inland Waterbody Detection With Transformer-Encoded CYGNSS Delay-Doppler Map Data
authors: Chia-Hsiang Lin, Jhao-Ting Lin, Po-Ying Chiu, Shih-Ping Chen, Charles C. H. Lin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Inland waterbody detection (IWD), which aims at identifying and mapping waterbodies such as rivers, lakes, and reservoirs, is critical for water resources management and agricultural planning. However, the development of high-fidelity IWD mapping technology remains unresolved. We aim to propose a practical solution using only the easily accessible delay-Doppler map (DDM) data provided by NASA’s Cyclone Global Navigation Satellite System (CYGNSS), which facilitates effective estimation of physical parameters on the Earth’s surface with high temporal resolution and wide spatial coverage. Specifically, as quantum deep network (QUEEN) has revealed its strong proficiency in addressing classification-like tasks, we encode the DDM using a customized transformer, followed by feeding the transformer-encoded DDM (tDDM) into a highly entangled QUEEN to distinguish whether the tDDM corresponds to a hydrological region. In recent literature, QUEEN has achieved outstanding performances in numerous challenging remote sensing tasks (e.g., hyperspectral restoration, change detection, and mixed noise removal, etc.), and its high effectiveness stems from the fundamentally different way it adopts to extract features (the so-called quantum unitary-computing features). The meticulously designed IWD-QUEEN retrieves high-precision river textures, such as those in Amazon River Basin in South America, demonstrating its superiority over traditional classification methods and existing global hydrography maps. IWD-QUEEN, together with its parallel quantum multihead scheme, works in a near-real-time manner (i.e., millisecond-level computing per DDM data). To broaden accessibility for users of traditional computers, we also provide the non-quantum counterpart of our method, called IWD-Transformer, thereby increasing the impact of this work. In terms of quantitative evaluation, IWD-QUEEN leads the IWD-Transformer by approximately 7% and 8% in F1-score and Cohen’s kappa, respectively, alluding the promising role of QUEEN in achieving high-performance detection. Source codes: https://github.com/IHCLab/IWD-QUEEN.

title: ADP-QFed: Privacy-Preserving Quantized Federated Learning for Intelligent Edge Sensing IoT Systems
authors: Omer Tariq, Muhammad Bilal Akram Dastagir, Dongsoo Han
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) enables decentralized model training but faces critical challenges in jointly optimizing privacy, accuracy, and communication efficiency, essential for resource-constrained wireless IoT deployments. We introduce ADP-QFed, an Adaptive Differentially Private Quantized Federated Learning framework that addresses these challenges through layer-wise adaptive noise injection and dual-bit deterministic quantization. By computing layer-specific sensitivity and importance scores, ADP-QFed dynamically calibrates privacy noise to minimize accuracy loss while ensuring rigorous (ε, δ)-differential privacy guarantees. The framework employs n-bit quantization for local computation and m-bit quantization for transmission, reducing communication overhead by up to 75%. Experiments on MNIST, FMNIST, and CIFAR-10 achieve test accuracies of 99.41%, 91.06%, and 82.94%, respectively, outperforming existing privacy-preserving FL methods by an average of 3.5%. These results are obtained while maintaining a privacy budget under ε = 2.25, representing a 40% reduction compared to state-of-the-art methods at similar accuracy levels. ADP-QFed advances practical privacy-preserving FL for edge sensing in low-altitude IoT systems by simultaneously optimizing privacy guarantees, model utility, and energy efficiency in wireless environments.

title: Object-Guided Semi-Supervised Bird’s-Eye View 3D Object Detection With 3D Box Refinement
authors: Zhao Yang, Yinan Shi, Weixiang Xu, Jiangtong Zhu, Haonan Zhang, Longjun Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Recently, Bird’s-Eye View (BEV) representation has received increasing attention in multi-view 3D object detection. However, training high-performance camera-based BEV 3D detectors typically requires cumbersome annotated training samples. In this challenging scenario, we are the pioneers in addressing the problem of semi-supervised BEV 3D object detection. To this end, we propose object-guided semi-supervised BEV 3D object detection (OSS3D), which trains the 3D detectors by using a small amount of labeled data and a large amount of unlabeled data to reduce the cost of data labeling. Firstly, our approach employs an object-guided Gaussian-like mask generation paired with multi-perspective geometric correspondence to emphasize foreground regions and mitigate background noise, ensuring accurate object alignment across different spaces. Additionally, this Gaussian-like mask is integral to our object-guided deep feature map supervision strategy. Secondly, in order to avoid the impact of unreliable pseudo-labels on student network training and improve the importance of object depth information in real space, we propose a self-training depth-based refinement algorithm to generate high-quality and stable pseudo-labels. Finally, our method can be easily inserted into a variety of BEV 3D detection networks. Several experiments demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms current semi-supervised approaches by 2.59% mAP and 2.94% NDS in the nuScenes dataset, achieving new state-of-the-art (SOTA) compared to various camera-based 3D detectors. Code will be available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/yangzhaojason/OSS3D</uri>

title: High Coverage and Privacy-Preserving IoT-Based Fall Detection System With Two-Thermal-Sensor Configuration
authors: Yuen Wing Lo, Chun Yin Lai, Man Ho Tsoi, Steve W. Y. Mung
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: This study proposes a simple Internet of Things (IoT)-based fall detection system with high coverage and privacy preservation to detect people’s status in private areas, such as washrooms. Human detection is crucial to prevent treatment delays because falls can lead to serious injuries or death. The proposed system utilizes a two-thermal-sensor configuration with top and side sensors to detect humans and perform fall detection. The number of top and side sensors used depends on the size of the detected area. The system incorporates the narrowband (NB)-IoT technology to facilitate communication between servers and sensors as a bridge in this system. The fall detection circuit includes an NB-IoT module, a microcontroller unit (MCU), and a two-thermal-sensor configuration. This low-cost MCU connects to the sensors and performs computations to determine if a private area is occupied or not. Apart from high coverage and privacy preservation, a two-thermal-sensor configuration enhances the accuracy of the fall detection system. A convolutional neural network (CNN) can be added as an additional fall detection metric. This fully integrated system was already implemented in different commercial places, and four commercial places are demonstrated in this article. Experiments were performed via five cases to verify the performance of the proposed fall detection system. This system, compared with other technologies, has simple installation, low cost, high coverage, and privacy-preserving features.
