title: ISO/IEEE International Standard--Health informatics--Device interoperability--Part 10103: Nomenclature, implantable device, cardiac
authors: N/A
abstract: The base nomenclature provided in IEEE 11073 to support terminology for implantable cardiac devices is extended in this standard. Devices within the scope of this nomenclature are implantable devices such as pacemakers, defibrillators, devices for cardiac resynchronization therapy, and implantable cardiac monitors. The discrete terms necessary to convey a clinically relevant summary of the information obtained during a device interrogation are defined in this nomenclature. To improve workflow efficiencies, cardiology and electrophysiology practices require the management of summary interrogation information from all vendor devices and systems in a central system such as an Electronic Health Records (EHR) system or a device clinic management system. To address this requirement, the Implantable Device, Cardiac (IDC) Nomenclature defines a standard-based terminology for device data. The nomenclature facilitates the transfer of data from the vendor proprietary systems to the clinic EHR or device clinic management system.

title: Unveiling Megaproject Innovative Collaboration through Game Theory: Evidence from China_supp1-3629551.docx
authors: Xiaoyan Chen
abstract: Understanding collaboration strategies and dynamic patterns among organizations with unequal status in megaproject technological innovation networks represents a critical research issue, as it profoundly influences the innovation performance and ultimate success of megaprojects. However, existing research inadequately addresses the significant impact of network characteristics and organizational status disparities on megaproject innovations. To address this gap, the study develops a complex network evolutionary game-theoretic model and leverages Tien-yow Jeme Civil Engineering Prize data to simulate stability conditions and dynamic patterns of inter-organizational collaboration. This paper verifies the model's equilibrium and stability conditions on random and scale-free networks, and conducts sensitivity analyses of several key factors in an empirical network, further confirming their robustness. Findings indicate that rationalizing the benefit-distribution system, reputation and punishment mechanisms can promote active collaboration within core organizations, while controlling spillover benefits helps to curb free-rider behavior in general organizations. Moreover, the appropriate configuration of these elements shall balance the fluctuations and inconsistencies between network-level indicators, not merely the organizational strategic transitions. This study offers project managers and scholars a novel theoretical lens for strategy evolution in collaborative networks and provides actionable insights for designing mechanisms that consider organizational heterogeneity to enhance innovation outcomes in megaprojects.

title: Highly Sensitive Flexible Strain Sensing Systems Based on HfSe&#x2082;&#x2013;Carbon Nanomaterial Composites for In Situ Tension Monitoring in Advanced Chain-Link Structural Interconnects_supp1-3631645.docx
authors: N. Hu
abstract: Mining chains operating in adverse underground environments and experiencing elevated coal transportation volumes are susceptible to critical failures including overloading, chain jamming, and fracture due to their role as essential transmission components. Real-time chain strain monitoring systems provide continuous assessment capabilities and early warning of potential failure events. Conventional strain sensors employed for tension monitoring exhibit significant limitations including insufficient sensitivity, excessive power requirements, and substantial dimensional constraints. In this investigation, we have synthesized strain sensors specifically engineered for downhole applications by leveraging the exceptional properties of graphene and HfSe₂. The integration of HfSe₂ into graphene-based composites resulted in the formation of heterointerfaces, which enhanced the sensors' sensitivity and linearity. These sensors demonstrate superior performance characteristics, including enhanced gauge factor (GF=22.8) within the linear strain range of 0–2000 με, exceptional linearity (RL²=0.98), ultra-low detection threshold (100 με), and minimal power consumption (2.05 mW), while maintaining measurement accuracy across extreme thermal conditions (0°C-60°C). The acquired strain signals underwent Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) analysis, with subsequent application of a Butterworth filter to attenuate high-frequency components and mitigate environmental noise interference. The developed graphene/HfSe₂-based strain sensor substantially enhances monitoring precision and operational safety, presenting significant implementation potential for advanced mine intelligence systems.

title: ROOT: Region-word Alignment with Partial Optimal Transport for Open-vocabulary Object Detection
authors: Jinhong Deng, Yinjie Lei, Wen Li, Lixin Duan
abstract: Open-vocabulary object detection (OVD) aims to detect novel object concepts by mining region-word correspondences from image-text pairs, yet current methods often produce false correspondences. While some strategies (e.g., one-to-one matching) were proposed to mitigate this issue, they often sacrifice numerous valuable region-word pairs during the matching process. To overcome these challenges, we propose a novel comprehensive alignment method, named Region-word Alignment with Partial Optimal Transport (ROOT) framework, which reframes the region-word matching task as a problem of partial distribution alignment. Unlike traditional optimal transport, which shifts the full mass of the distribution, partial optimal transport enables selective matching, making it more robust to noise in region and word alignment. Specifically, ROOT first employs partial optimal transport to obtain an optimal transport plan for region and word feature alignment. This transport plan is then used to compute a matching reliability score for each region-word pair, which reweights the contrastive alignment loss to enhance accuracy. By enabling more flexible and reliable region-text matches, ROOT significantly reduces misalignment errors while preserving valuable region–word correspondences. Extensive experiments on standard benchmarks OV-COCO and OV-LVIS show that our ROOT outperforms the previous state-of-the-art works, demonstrating the effectiveness of our approach.

title: Multi-Mode Radar Network Control with Restless Contextual Combinatorial Multi-Armed Bandits
authors: Samuel R. Shebert, Benjamin H. Kirk, R. Michael Buehrer
abstract: In congested or contested spectrum, radar is costly to operate due to high power usage, low spectral efficiency, and low covertness compared to passive sensors. For this reason this work proposes a multi-mode radar sensing strategy, in which the sensors can choose between a monostatic radar mode and a passive Electronic Support Measure (ESM) spectrum sensing mode. In ESM mode, a target is localized with a network of multi-mode sensors, which creates opportunities to reduce radar measurements. Radar and ESM measurements are rigorously compared using the Cramer-Rao bound to quantify the localization error of each mode. The best mode for each sensor is chosen using a Restless Contextual Combinatorial Multi-Armed Bandit (RCC-MAB) online learning algorithm. The RCC-MAB increases the flexibility of the network by adapting to the target in real-time based on recent radar and ESM measurements. Two variants, the ϵ-Greedy and Covert RCC-MABs, were created to fulfill different tracking objectives. The ϵ-Greedy RCC-MAB variant seeks to minimize the tracking error by selecting the best sensing modes based on the quality of previous measurements and the current context of the tracking filter. The Covert RCC-MAB variant significantly reduces radar usage to stay covert, or minimize access to a shared spectrum, by only exploring radar measurements when the tracking error approaches a predefined maximum error. The ϵ-Greedy RCC-MAB consistently achieved the lowest tracking error of the tested mode controllers, 58% and 16% lower than a single-mode radar and ESM network, respectively, when the radio emissions of opportunity were available during 50% of measurement opportunities. In the same scenario, the Covert RCC-MAB had 55% lower tracking error than single-mode radar, while using 82% less radar than the ϵ-Greedy RCC-MAB.

title: Safeguarding E-Voting with Blockchain: A Transparent and Reliable Solution
authors: Manjula V, Mahammdsalman Warimani, Mohammed Zakir Bellary, Naveen kumar B, Asia Hazareena, Talha Shaikh
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
abstract: Voting and elections are crucial to the growth of a independent society because they allow the people to voice their sentiments and take part in the decision-making procedure. In order to maintain the integrity of votes and promise a safe, open, and verifiable process, voting methods have changed from paper ballot systems to electronic voting systems. The progress of a safe electronic voting system that prevents fraud endeavors and yields dependable vote results has been in progress. In order to solve these problems, we present a novel strategy in this work that uses a association blockchain, smart contracts (SCs), and cryptographic approaches to protect votes, improve voter privacy, and speed up outcome collecting. Each vote is recorded as a operation on a decentralized ledger by the planned electronic voting scheme, which makes use of blockchain technology. The system architecture is shown in Figure 1, where voters can safely register and cast their ballots via a frontend user interface. The procedure is controlled by smart contracts, which pledge that votes are verifiable and unchangeable. Data confidentiality is protected by a cryptographic layer, and voter eligibility is verified by the system's integration with government databases. Our implementation findings show that our suggested method outperforms the state-of-the-art in terms of energy usage, execution time, and scalability.

title: Control Strategy for Switched Reluctance Motor Based on Dual Sliding Mode Controller with Composite Convergence Rate
authors: Ruobin Yan, Qizhi Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Manufacturing System (ICAMTMS)
abstract: Aiming at the traditional control strategy of switched reluctance motor with slow response speed, easy to generate large torque pulsation and poor dynamic performance. In this paper, a torque pulsation control strategy based on the composite convergence law with double sliding mode controller is proposed. In the speed control layer, the sliding mode speed controller is constructed to eliminate the sliding mode arrival stage, combined with the non-singular fast terminal sliding mode function to realize the fast convergence of the system in all stages, and the composite convergence law and the segment switching function are designed to optimize the convergence speed and suppress the jitter in collaboration; in the torque control layer, the improved hysteresis loop strategy of demagnetization signal is introduced to suppress the torque overshoot phenomenon of the rotor during the unidirectional conduction interval. In order to enhance the system anti-disturbance capability, a sliding mode disturbance observer is designed for real-time observation of internal and external disturbances such as load fluctuation and parameter mismatch, and the disturbance valuation is feed-forward compensated to the double-sliding mode controller, forming a closed-loop observation-compensation mechanism. A 6/4 motor is simulated and verified, and the results show that the new control strategy can effectively reduce the torque pulsation, and compared with the traditional sliding-mode control and the improved sliding-mode control, the dual-sliding-mode control method using the composite convergence law not only improves the dynamic performance of the system, shortens the dynamic response time, but also strengthens the anti-disturbance performance of the motor and further reduces the torque pulsation.

title: Performance Assessment of Classic and Modified Modulated Predictive Torque Control for an IM Fed by a VSI
authors: Jakson Bonaldo, Marco Rivera, Rogerio Lima, Raul Monteiro, Alex Ferreira Silva, Pat Wheeller
abstract: Model predictive control (MPC) strategies have been extensively adopted for the control of electrical drives due to their intuitive design and straightforward implementation. In this work, a comparative performance evaluation between the conventional Predictive Torque Control (PTC) and a modified version of Modulated Predictive Torque Control (MPTC) based on Space Vector Modulation (SVM) is conducted for the speed and torque control of an induction motor (IM) considering torque ripple and current total harmonic distortion (THD) as the performance indices indicators. Real-time simulation results obtained using a hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) platform demonstrate that MPTC preserves the fast transient behaviour of conventional FCS-MPC while achieving a 50 % reduction in both current distortion and torque ripple. These findings highlight the suitability of MPTC for high-performance applications where precise and efficient control is required.

title: Adaptive Motion Control of Double-Driven Gantry Machine Tool Based on Flexible Multibody Dynamics
authors: Yangbo Yu, Qingzhen Bi
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: Stable and efficient control strategies for machine tools form the foundation of high-precision machining. Due to the large structural components and high flexibility of large gantry machine tools, component deformation during motion cannot be ignored. This paper proposes a novel motion control method for double-driven gantry machine tools based on flexible multibody dynamics. A dynamics model incorporating component flexibility is developed to accurately capture the system's dynamic behavior and deformation effects during operation. To enhance control robustness and adaptability, an adaptive sliding mode controller utilizing radial basis function (RBF) neural networks is designed. Additionally, cross-coupling synchronization control is implemented to ensure precise coordination between the dual drives. The results demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly improves dynamic performance and stability, offering considerable advantages over conventional rigid-body model-based control strategies.

title: Segmenting Customers with K-Means, Hierarchical, and Density-Based Clustering Techniques
authors: Abhishek Tripathi, K. Nikhil, K. V. S. Sai Ram Santosh Babu, C. Sai Prathap Reddy, D. Haritejaswar Reddy, D. Venkata Poorna Sukesh, R. C. Gurjar, Gireesh G Soni
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: This research examines clustering techniques in client segmentation to help organizations make strategic decisions. Different segmentation patterns were seen with KMeans, Hierarchical Clustering, and DBSCAN. K-Means effectively processed large data sets, Hierarchical Clustering found consumer group hierarchies, and DBSCAN found nonlinear trends and outliers. These methods optimized resource use, targeted marketing, and client retention. Age-based segmentation and demographic trends affect customer choices. Gender segmentation allows individual interaction with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 6 \%}$</tex> female and 44 % male. Spending behavior studies reveal financial methods with different income-spreading correlations. Regional segmentation of Bangalore (46), Chennai (36), Hyderabad (44), Kolkata (43), and Madurai (31) shows locationbased approaches. Results show that age and income are correlated and that spending patterns vary per group. Clustering improves data-driven tactics, consumer control, and green business growth. By encouraging educated, inclusive marketing strategies and resource allocation through intelligent consumer segmentation, this approach supports SDG 8 and SDG 12.

title: Experimental Investigation of Power-Over-Fiber Systems for Safe and Remote Electrical Power Delivery
authors: F. B. F. Pinto, E. S. Lima, Arismar Cerqueira S.
abstract: This paper reports an experimental investigation of Power-over-Fiber (PoF) systems for electrical power delivery in hazardous and electromagnetically sensitive environments. The study investigates system performance across different multimode fiber (MMF) lengths (500 m and 1000 m), employing a 100 W laser diode at 976 nm and a 20 W photovoltaic power converter (PPC). Key performance metrics, including power transmission efficiency (PTE), voltage stability, and PPC conversion efficiency, are analyzed. Results demonstrate high stability and efficiency under varying power levels, with thermal effects becoming a limiting factor at higher optical inputs. The findings support PoF as a reliable solution for safely energizing remote and isolated electronic systems, including those in industrial, energy, and mobile network infrastructures.

title: Exploring the Agency in VR Co-embodiment Rehabilitation Based on First- and Third-person Perspectives
authors: Yijun Zhou, Shuling Su, Jingjing Zhang, Xinyue Luo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Upper limb motor dysfunction in patients with stroke could limit their daily activities, and virtual reality (VR) has been proven to provide interactive training for enhancing rehabilitation. However, many studies presume independent tasks, which can be challenging for patients with limited motor control. The virtual co-embodiment method in VR has the potential to allow patients and therapists to share the same avatar to collaboratively perform rehabilitation tasks. Specifically, this method could impact the patients’ agency (feeling of controlling virtual avatars) and enable therapists to compensate for patients’ limited mobility. Prior research has shown that the avatar’s first or third-person perspective can affect the agency, but studies on co-embodiment have not yet examined how these two users’ perspectives influence their experiences. Our study investigates how first or third-person perspectives for both patients and therapists moderate the agency during VR co-embodiment. We found that differences in participants’ roles and objectives influence participants’ perspective preferences during VR co-embodiment. These findings inform the design of multi-user collaboration to enhance patients’ motor recovery in VR rehabilitation.

title: Development of Solar Carport System for Direct DC-Link Connection to EV Charging Station
authors: Lucas Cordeiro de Arruda, José Antenor Pomilio, Joel Filipe Guerreiro
abstract: The electrification of vehicles and the resulting highpower demand from the grid create the opportunity to combine local generation using renewable energy sources (RES) with charging stations. This work aims to develop a 5 kWp solar carport to be connected to a 33 kVA electrical vehicle (EV) fast charging station. The development is carried out by designing the solar array based on a commercial module, then a boost converter combined with a perturb and observe (P&O) maximum power tracking (MPPT) algorithm is used to transfer power to the charging station dc bus. The key findings include that the power generated by an area of 3 car spaces <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(32 m^{2}\right)$</tex> can charge, on average, 2.8 cars per day. The converter works well in the full voltage range of the dc bus [400-900] V. The research supports the feasibility of directly integrating solar carports into the EV charging station dc-bus.

title: Research on Design and Positioning Methodology of Intelligent Positioning System for Converter Body
authors: Yi Zheng, Long Liang, Jiong Kong, Sixian Rao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Manufacturing System (ICAMTMS)
abstract: This study develops an intelligent converter body positioning system and corresponding methodology to overcome the low precision, inefficiency, and high safety risks of manual installation. Firstly, a dual-system collaborative framework is established based on the requirement for high-precision positioning: The intelligent pushing system enables steady movement and automatic deviation correction of the ladle car through a hydraulic coordination-controlled pushing trolley and pushing cylinders featuring differential hydraulic pressure deviation compensation; the multi-source position detection system integrates data from laser and ultrasonic sensors to establish a real-time motion attitude perception model for the ladle car. On this basis, a dynamic braking threshold and bolt pattern matching criterion are proposed. The system eliminates ladle car deviation errors through dynamic fusion of longitudinal distance and lateral deviation data, coupled with differential control of pushing hydraulic cylinders, ensuring precise alignment between the bolt holes on the converter trunnion ring and those on the base. Finally, engineering applications validate the system’s significant effectiveness in enhancing installation automation, ensuring construction safety, and reducing project duration.

title: EfficientNetV2-ResNet50V2 Ensemble Framework for Parkinson's Disease Detection: Optimized Class Balancing and Test-Time Augmentation
authors: Deepak N A, V R Tejas, N R Venkatesh Raju, Sagar Ganiga, Safwan Sayeed
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
abstract: Early detection of Parkinson's Disease (PD) remains a significant c linical c hallenge d espite i ts i mpact o n treatment efficacy and patient outcomes. This study presents a specialized computational framework utilizing dual-network architecture to identify diagnostic biomarkers from functional MRI (fMRI) data. The research addresses critical neuroimaging constraints—the scarcity of annotated samples and pronounced class imbalance—through a purpose-built methodology integrating adaptive data augmentation with an architecture-optimized ensemble approach. By strategically combining the distinct feature extraction strengths of EfficientNetV2a nd R esNet50V2n etworks with custom regularization techniques, the system achieves exceptional diagnostic performance: 94.3% accuracy, 93.1% precision, and 95.7% recall on independent validation data. The diagnostic algorithm demonstrates robust discriminative capabilities with an area under the curve (AUC) of 0.968, surpassing existing methodologies by 7.2%. These findings s uggest p otential clinical utility as an assistive diagnostic instrument that could facilitate earlier intervention for PD patients.

title: Hybrid Static Immersion Cooling of a Single Lithium-Ion Prismatic Battery Cell
authors: Rajesh Nimmagadda, David W. Salter, Kantharuphan Annathurai, Daniel Trimble, Seamus M. O’Shaughnessy
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Effective thermal management of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) is critical to maximize their performance, lifespan, and safety. Rapid charging and discharging of LIBs generates heat, affecting battery function and safety. LIBs must be maintained within a $20-40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ temperature range, limiting temperature gradients within a cell and between cells to $\lt 5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. The study uses the Newman, Tiedemann, Gu. and Kim (NTGK) Multi-Scale Multi-Domain (MSMD) battery model in ANSYS Fluent to simulate a static immersion cooling system employing natural convection heat transfer. First, a $50 \mathrm{Ah} \mathrm{LiFePO}_{4}$ prismatic battery is fully immersed in air, with performance compared to immersion in the dielectric liquids deionized water and Novec 7000 for discharge rates of 1 to 3 times the nominal current. Then, two hybrid systems combining both dielectric liquid and air are investigated for comparison. The hybrid systems use smaller volumes of dielectric liquid, and a configuration that requires only $68 \%$ of dielectric liquid in comparison to full immersion cooling exhibited good performance by maintaining a maximum battery surface temperature difference of less than $5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and limiting the maximum battery temperature to $\lt 40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. However, the hybrid system using the smallest volume of those investigated, in which static liquid cooling is applied only to the top face of the battery, leads to poor thermal performance.

title: State-Space-Based Repetitive MPC for DFIG
authors: Amanda Silva Real, Lucas Lima Rodrigues, Alfeu J. Sguarezi Filho, Elmer O. Hancco Catata, Yuri de Oliveira Cota, Omar A. C. Vilcanqui
abstract: Model Predictive Control (MPC) is highly popular in Doubly Fed Induction Generator (DFIG) applications, and State-Space (SS) models are an efficient approach for modeling Multiple Input Multiple Output systems like DFIG. Due to Space Vector Pulse Width Modulation, control decisions can introduce high-frequency periodic disturbances in rotor currents, resulting in harmonics in the current generated by the DFIG. To mitigate rotor current periodic disturbances, this paper proposes an MPC with an augmented SS model with embed repetitive action, combining the principles of Repetitive Control and MPC.

title: Development of a DC Islanded Microgrid for Hydrogen Production using Solar and Energy Storage System
authors: Babita Gupta, Divya Sri Lakavath, Yukthakshary. B, Zainab Falak, Kumbha Shirisha
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: This project tackles the design of a stand-alone, or "islanded," DC microgrid system for green hydrogen production utilizing renewable solar energy and an energy storage system (ESS). The system is designed to create a clean, efficient, and independent energy source that is not dependent on the conventional power grid. The system uses solar photovoltaic (PV) panels to harvest solar energy and convert it into electricity. As solar energy is not always present, particularly during cloudy weather or nighttime, a battery-based energy storage system is incorporated to accumulate excess electricity and release it during demand. The stored energy supplies an electrolyzer, a device that decomposes water into hydrogen and oxygen. The generated hydrogen can be stored and utilized later as a clean energy source for multiple applications, such as in fuel cells, transportation, or industrial processes. The entire system is regulated by a control unit that coordinates energy generation, storage, and utilization to achieve stable and efficient operation even under fluctuating solar conditions. Simulation results indicate that the system can supply a continuous power supply to the electrolyzer, resulting in continuous hydrogen production with negligible wastage of energy. Such a microgrid configuration is particularly beneficial in remote or off-grid locations where conventional energy sources are not available. It complements the world's transition towards renewable energy and presents a viable means of decentralized hydrogen production utilizing renewable resources.

title: Single-Phase Five-Level Voltage Inverter Based on the Three-State Switching Cell with Low Device Count
authors: Wesley Henrique Maciel, Henrique Antônio Carvalho Braga, Fernando Lessa Tofoli
abstract: This paper presents a novel single-phase fivelevel voltage-fed inverter based on the three-state switching cell (3SSC) and space vector modulation (SVM). The interleaved operation of the high-frequency switches associated with the 3SSC allows for reducing current stresses, while the autotransformer ensures automatic current sharing. The topology includes a low-frequency leg to minimize switching losses. The output voltage waveform achieves five levels, while the operating frequency of the low-pass filter is twice the switching frequency, resulting in reduced filtering requirements. Hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) results confirm the feasibility of the proposed inverter.

title: Density Map Modeling on the Edge: Towards Sustainable Agri-Food Supply Chains
authors: Tala Jano, Ridha Hamila, Muhammad Asif Khan, Farid Touati, Mohamed Kharbeche
publish: 2025 13th European Workshop on Visual Information Processing (EUVIP)
abstract: While food waste remains a significant global climate burden, effective demand planning in retail can reduce overstocking, propagating toward sustainable Agri-Food Supply Chains (AFSCs). From here, this paper employs density map modeling with Edge Intelligence (Edge-AI) technology to identify the On-Shelf Availability (OSA) index in retailers. A lightweight and efficient variant of the Multi-Column Convolutional Neural Network (MCNN), referred to as Modified Multi-Column Convolutional Neural Network (mMCNN), is proposed for edge-based density estimation. Moreover, a novel dataset called AgriShelf is curated to serve as a benchmark for this application. Extensive tests on edge platforms, Jetson Nano and Jetson Orin Nano, show that mMCNN outperforms the original MCNN in computational efficiency, with only a nominal drop in counting accuracy. Notably, Jetson Orin Nano achieves superior performance, reaching an inference speed of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 0 1 5}$</tex> seconds. To this end, the integration of Edge-AI and density map modeling provides real-time insights that reduce food waste, optimize replenishments, and drive sustainable policy decisions across AFSCs.

title: Optimal Scheduling of Integrated Energy System Considering Demand Response and Carbon Trading
authors: Peng Chen, Li Lan, Yanyuan Qian, Mingxing Guo, Xuxu Zhou, Longlong Guo, Lili Miao, Hongbo Ren
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Under the "dual-carbon" goals, integrated energy systems play a pivotal role in achieving energy transition by coordinating multi-energy flows. This paper proposes an optimal scheduling model for IES that integrates demand response and carbon trading mechanisms. A dynamic pricing framework and carbon quota allocation model are established to minimize total operational costs and carbon emissions. Case studies demonstrate that collaborative demand response and carbon trading strategy reduces total costs by 5.8% and carbon emissions by 9.7% compared to traditional approaches. The results highlight the synergistic benefits of coupling demand-side flexibility with carbon market incentives, providing actionable insights for low-carbon energy system optimization.

title: Design and Development of Siamese Bert Model for Business English Course Learning and Sharing Platform
authors: Yan Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Business English education demands very specialized learning systems capable of understanding semantic relationships, contextual meanings, and most importantly domain-specific terminology to facilitate effective knowledge acquisition and sharing. Traditional learning systems fail to capture the semantic similarities, which tends to misconceptions of specific domains. To solve the above problem, this research study proposes a Hybrid Siamese BERT systems for enhancing the understanding ability of the Business English language that can be integrated with online education systems with the resource sharing capabilities. The proposed framework consist of four components:1) English Data collection system 2) English Pre-processing 3) Siamese Networks 4) Recommendation process. The comprehensive experimentation has been carried out by collecting the real time business English courses from the different online learning platforms Furthermore, students' feedbacks are collected to aid for the further enhancing in the online learning systems. The evaluation metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall are calculated and compared with the other learning models. Evaluation results demonstrates the performance of the model has achieved the accuracy of 0.972, precision of 0.966, recall of 0.963 in effectively predicting the student's proficiency levels with personalized recommendation of improvement

title: Research on Quality Control Methods for Large Ship Software Based on Lifecycle Selection
authors: Qiuning Wu, Huihui Zhang, Weiqi Li, Ting Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Manufacturing System (ICAMTMS)
abstract: Large ship software quality is directly critical to the success of missions. The high complexity poses substantial challenges to the quality control. This paper focuses on the quality control methods based on lifecycle selection of large ship software, aims to comprehensively enhancing quality assurance capabilities. The modified quality evaluation model is used to validate the effectiveness of quality control methods. The results provide precise and reliable support for enhancing the performance and dependability of next-generation ship systems by establishing a quality control framework.

title: Enhancing Thermal Performance of FPMHP via Fin Structure Optimization for Low-Carbon Energy Systems
authors: Jie Ji, Minghou Liu, Canlong Lai, Chang Liu, Qixuan Dong
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: To enhance the operational efficiency of heat transfer devices in energy systems, this study conducts numerical simulations and performance analyses focusing on the effect of wick geometry on flow and heat transfer of flat plate micro-groove heat pipe (FPMHP). The results demonstrate that the rectangular fin structure, owing to its larger contact area and more uniform gas-liquid distribution, exhibits a lower steady-state operating temperature and thermal resistance, indicating superior thermal conduction capability. The triangular-fin structure demonstrates faster thermal responsiveness and stabilization tendencies. The sharp-edge design effectively facilitates bubble nucleation and rapid detachment during the heating phase, accelerating the establishment of a stable circulation loop. However, it also leads to non-uniform temperature distribution and elevated local thermal resistance, thereby reducing overall thermal uniformity. This study provides theoretical support and technical guidance for the structural design of FPMHP in high-efficiency, energy-saving thermal management systems

title: An Efficient Battery SOC Estimation Method Based on Steady-state Kalman Filter
authors: Qinglu Ren, Ya Liu, Rui Zhu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Traditional Kalman filters require real-time computation of prior error covariance, posterior error covariance, and Kalman filter gain when estimating the state of charge (SOC) of lithium-ion batteries. This involves a large number of matrix operations, necessitating the deployment of battery management system (BMS) on high-performance embedded hardware systems and thereby increasing the system implementation cost. To address this issue, this paper proposes an battery SOC estimation method based on the steady-state Kalman filter (SKF). The method calculates the steady-state Kalman gain offline using the Hamiltonian algorithm and embeds it into the filter, thereby avoiding a large number of mathematical operations during runtime. Experimental results show that this method has a SOC estimation accuracy comparable to that of the linear Kalman filter (KF), but it exhibits significant advantages in terms of runtime and memory usage, with a runtime of only 1.9% and a memory usage of only 14.6% of the KF. The new method can achieve efficient SOC estimation without the need of high-performance embedded hardware platforms, and it has high practical value and broad application prospects.

title: A Review of Image Segmentation Techniques Based on Optimization Techniques with Otsu’s Method
authors: Dussa Sudha Mohan, K. Punnam Chandar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: In the majority of computer vision and image processing tasks, image segmentation is a key process that attempts to partition an image into separate and meaningful parts for more convenient analysis and interpretation. Multilevel thresholding is among the strongest image segmentation techniques for grayscale and color images with complicated intensity distributions. By selecting many optimal threshold values, multilevel thresholding segments an image into several regions. To find optimal threshold values, optimization algorithms have been used. This paper presents a thorough evaluation and comparison of different methods by considering the integration of optimization techniques into multilevel thresholding systems. Based on objective quality metrics such as PSNR, SSIM, FSIM, and VoI, we compare the performance of Jaya Algorithm (JA), Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Artificial Bee Colony Optimization (ABC), Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA), and Moth Flame Optimization (MFO)and discuss their results. The research indicates how optimization methods enhance segmentation quality and computational efficiency. Through presenting a formalized survey of efficiency-driven multilevel thresholding approaches.

title: Structural Deviations in immersive environments: Breaching Plausibility and Place Illusion of outdoor and indoor spaces
authors: Francesco Musolino, Dario Gentile, Fabio Vangi, Mine Dastan, Michele Fiorentino
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Structural deviations are atypical patterns known in environmental psychology literature to cause discomfort in physical spaces, however their impact on user perception within immersive virtual remains under-explored. Therefore, this work contributes by exploring how Structural deviations (Void, Defeatured, Symmetry, Repetition, Displacement, Big, Small, Presence) known in literature disrupt the Plausibility Illusion (PI the sense that virtual space seem real) and Place Illusion (Psi the feeling of being present). We designed two Metaverse inspired case studies: outdoor city avenue and an indoor pub, both with nine scenes each implanted by a single structural deviation. We ran a mixed-methods user study (N=46), in which participants were assigned to a Metaverse (between-subjects). All viewed a baseline, then several counterbalanced SDs (within-subjects), rating perceived realism (for PI) and uncanniness (for breaches of Psi). Statistical analysis (RM-ANOVA, Bonferroni) showed that all Structural Deviations significantly increased uncanniness and weakened Psi (p ≤ .001). Only Displacement and Big significantly reduced PI, with GLM identifying them as the strongest predictors of uncanniness. This work showcased how Structural deviations can be used as deliberate design choices to affect significantly the user experience, and how further studies in perception theory are needed to further explore designers’ tools for crafting next-gen IVEs.

title: Low-Power GaN Current Power Supplies for Proton Therapy Accelerators
authors: Felipe S. P. De Oliveira, Bruno Edson Limeira, Bruno Valverde, Jose A. Pomilio
abstract: Proton therapy accelerators have treated thousands of cancer patients worldwide since their conception. Brazil doesn't have such a type of machine, but many efforts are beginning towards reversing this scenario. In such a way, studies concerning current PS in those machines are running, especially regarding low-power current PS for the corrector magnets. The main goals of this project are a good compromise between prototype costs and the use of the newest power converter technology, whose design will be the focus of this work.

title: Bidirectional Off-Board EV Charging System for Enhanced Grid Power Quality
authors: Ashutosh Patra, Pratap Ranjan Mohanty
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: This paper presents a high-performance, three-phase grid-connected EV charging system capable of bidirectional power transfer, supporting both Grid-to-Vehicle (G2V) and Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) operations. The system integrates a bidirectional Voltage Source Converter (VSC), an LCL filter, and a battery-side bidirectional DC-DC converter, coordinated through a cascaded control strategy based on Synchronous Reference Frame (SRF) theory and PI controllers. A Phase-Locked Loop (PLL) ensures synchronization with the grid, while the control scheme maintains unity power factor and low Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) in grid currents. Simulations confirm sinusoidal, balanced, in-phase current waveforms in both directions, with DC-link voltage regulated within ±5–6 V. Battery charging/discharging is precisely managed, achieving 94% and 91% efficiency respectively, with SoC maintained within safe limits. These results validate the system’s ability to deliver high-quality power exchange, grid stability, and reliable battery control—making it suitable for smart grid applications with high EV penetration.

title: EEG Analysis of Cybersickness: A Quantitative Evaluation of Brainwave Changes in Head Mounted Display and Curved Monitor Display
authors: Dong-Hyun Lee, Kyoung-Mi Jang, Hyun Kyoon Lim
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Cybersickness is an adverse side effect of Virtual Reality (VR). This study evaluated and compared cybersickness between a Head-Mounted Display (HMD) and a curved monitor using the Simulator Sickness Questionnaire (SSQ) and Electroencephalography (EEG). Thirty-one male participants (25±1.9 years) with high motion sickness susceptibility were recruited to minimize hormonal influences. Each completed baseline (rest) and cybersickness (VR content) conditions. EEG was recorded using 256 channels and analyzed across Delta, Theta, Alpha, Beta, and Gamma bands. In both displays, significant EEG changes were observed: increased Delta in the Frontal region (p<0.05), decreased Alpha in Central, Parietal, Occipital, and Temporal regions (p<0.01), and increased Gamma in Frontal and Central regions (p<0.01). By identifying significant common changes across both displays, this study provides an initial step toward quantitatively evaluating cybersickness. These results suggest consistent brain region involvement during cybersickness and align with previous EEG findings.

title: Stability Analysis of Droop Control of DFIG Considering Wind Speed Variations
authors: Ming Chen, Weiyu Bao
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: With the increasing penetration of wind power in modern power systems, grid inertia is significantly reduced, posing a serious challenge to frequency stability. The Doubly-Fed Induction Generator (DFIG) has flexible control capability, but the decoupling of its rotor speed from the grid frequency results in a lack of inertial response. Although the droop control technique can engage the DFIG in frequency regulation by releasing the rotor kinetic energy, most of the existing studies are based on the assumption of constant wind speed, which ignores the effect of actual wind speed fluctuations on the stability of the wind turbine. In this paper, the problem of DFIG rotational speed stability using droop control under variable wind speed conditions is investigated, and a frequency response model is developed and the nonlinear aspects such as mechanical power and maximum power tracking (MPPT) are linearised. The steady state rotational speed as a function of wind speed is revealed through theoretical derivation, and the value of the droop coefficient K<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf> is determined based on the range of wind speed fluctuation. A simulation model of the system was built in DIgSILENT, and the simulation results show that the stability of the turbine's own operation can be ensured even in variable wind speed scenarios.

title: Temperature Control of an Alkaline Electrolysis System Considering Electrolyte Circulation
authors: Yurun Ye, Hao Li, Ang Lu, Wenxin Liu, Zhiyao Zhong, Jiakun Fang
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Hydrogen production by water electrolysis faces challenges in dynamic thermal management due to operating condition variability and model nonlinearity, hindering large-scale renewable energy water electrolysis. While existing alkaline electrolysis thermal models focus on the interactions between electrolyzer stack and auxiliary equipment, the role of electrolyte circulation in energy balance remains understudied. In this paper, the dynamic electrical-thermal-fluid coupling in the alkaline electrolysis system model is analyzed, and the electrolyte circulation is controlled to enhance the temperature control responsiveness. Furthermore, the coordinated proportional-integral-derivative (PID) controllers are designed, integrating stack temperature regulation with chiller and circulating pump power control to address nonlinear thermal dynamic control. By leveraging thermal-fluid interaction through active electrolyte flow rate adjustment, the controllers achieve improved temperature stabilization under variable operating scenarios. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed controllers significantly enhance control responsiveness and accuracy compared to conventional controllers in a MW-scale alkaline electrolysis system.

title: A Novel Graduation Design System Based on Personalized Recommendation Algorithm
authors: Yinhong Xiong, Xin Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Due to the short time frame of the graduation project, users need to filter through a large amount of information in a short period of time, which can lead to a certain degree of blindness. So, if personalized recommendation technology is applied to screening methods to recommend content that suits users' own characteristics and interests, it can effectively reduce the blindness of user selection and improve selection efficiency. This study uses the personality combination system of online course content based on remote block search and wireless intelligent technology, deeply analyzes the construction and application of personality combination system of online design system. The results indicate that taking the application scheme of personality combination system of online online design system, considering the sustainability of remote block search and wireless intelligent technology, so the specific operation method is according to the application of online online design system so as to promote the subsequent tasks of personality combination system of online online design system.

title: BIM-Assisted Hybrid Path Planning for UAV Navigation in Indoor Fire-Rescue Scenarios Using Reinforcement Learning
authors: Lin Ge, Swee King Phang, Ji Zhang, Nohaidda Sariff
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: Fire-rescue operations in high-rise buildings face challenges due to unpredictable fire spread, dense smoke, and changing obstacles. This paper presents a new framework that integrates Building Information Modeling (BIM) with a hybrid UAV navigation and path-planning system. The framework optimizes search and rescue efforts in indoor environments affected by fire. It combines graph-based global search algorithms with reinforcement learning (RL) for adaptive local path adjustments, allowing UAVs to navigate autonomously in complex settings. MATLAB simulations used a vowelized BIM model to test UAV responses to real-time sensor data, including smoke density and temperature changes. The results show improved path efficiency, better coverage of high-risk areas, and reduced response time compared to traditional methods. The UAVs' ability to adapt to changing conditions, driven by real-time sensor data and BIM-based structural information, proves the effectiveness of the approach. This framework can enhance emergency response and has potential for practical use in fire rescue operations.

title: Retrieval-Augmented Generation: A Comprehensive Survey of Foundations, Evolution, Applications, Limitations, and Future Directions
authors: Junzhe Feng, MohammadMahdi Ariannejad, Intan Izafina Idrus, Zhe Kai Goh, Jian Ding Tan, Chia Chao Kang, Mohammad Arif Sobhan Byuiyan, Wei Hown Tee
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) is one of the best methods for performing language tasks these days. RAG uses large language models with external tools for better accuracy, correctness, and contextual understanding. The review discusses key concepts in RAG, how RAG differs from previous systems that retrieved or generated content, how RAG is utilized in question answering, knowledge management, and content generation, and it discusses some limitations, including quality of retrieval, requirement for high-performance computers, complicated integration, as well as data privacy problems, and presents new approaches to address these limitations. The review examines over a quarter-century of key recent studies and concludes with some future research areas, such as multimodal RAG, novel methods for retrieval, personalization, ethics, explanability, as well as incorporating human feedback. The review seeks to make the reader understand RAG's current state as well as future research areas through intensive discussion as well as lucid examples.

title: Study on the Use of ‘Non-Generated’ Energy by Constrained-Off in Photovoltaic and Wind Power Plants in Paraíba with Storage Systems
authors: Emilly Modesto Pereira, Flávio da Silva Vitorino Gomes, Camila Seibel Gehrke, Kleber Carneiro de Oliveira, João Victor Frutuoso Kuhnen
abstract: The use of renewable energy sources, such as wind and solar photovoltaic, for electricity Generation in Brazil has grown exponentially over the last few years. However, the full integration of these sources into the National Interconnected System (SIN) has been challenged mainly by the unavailability of instantaneous allocation of all energy generated in the load. As a result, events restricting the operation of centralized power plants, defined as constrained-off, have occurred increasingly over the last four years, generating significant financial losses. In this context, this article aims to propose a technical and financial analysis of the use of energy not generated in the system due to constrained-off in photovoltaic and wind power plants located in Paraíba, through the use of energy storage systems. The system is designed to operate in three scenarios, the viability of which has been proven when the three are integrated into a single approach.

title: Active Thermal Control of a PV Inverter with Alternating Modulation Strategies to Improve Lifetime
authors: Christian Di Salvo, Mateus Andrade Ferreira, Erick Matheus Da Silveira Brito, João Victor Matos Farias
abstract: The continuous advancement of photovoltaic energy sources demands constant improvements in their systems to ensure efficiency and reliability. This article investigates the implementation of a transition between continuous and discontinuous modulation techniques in a photovoltaic inverter to improve its reliability, triggered by an active thermal control system. Typically, the semiconductors used in photovoltaic inverters are subjected to high operating temperatures due to conduction losses and, mainly, switching losses. Discontinuous modulation techniques are well-known for mitigating switching losses, although this comes at the expense of reduced power quality. The proposed transition between modulation strategies seeks to enhance the reliability of the system's components while ensuring that the generated power quality remains within the limits defined by current technical standards. The main objective is to reduce thermal impacts that affect their reliability. The evaluation of the methodology is based on the analysis of semiconductor device junction temperature, allowing for the estimation of their lifetime and the examination of the effect of total harmonic distortion on the power grid. Using the proposed model in a two-level photovoltaic inverter, based on simulation results, improvements in its useful life of up to 44.44 % were obtained, while maintaining the THD below 5 %. The obtained results are expected to encourage the adoption of the proposed strategy, contributing to the longevity of photovoltaic inverters and, consequently, to greater stability and reliability of power generation systems. The approach aims to drive significant improvements in photovoltaic technology, strengthening its large-scale application.

title: Analysis of $\mathrm{D}^{2} \text{VC}$ and D-STATCOM in Medium-Voltage Distribution Grids with Photovoltaics Systems Integration
authors: Igor Silva Rodrigues, Anna Dulce Espindola, Silvangela L. Barcelos, Edson Hirokazu Watanabe
abstract: The increase of variable sources, such as photovoltaic generators, connected to the electrical distribution system directly impacts the voltage control at the Point of Common Coupling (PCC). To ensure the quality and reliability of the energy, it is essential to control it. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{D}^{2} \text{VC}$</tex> is a controller that directly adjusts the magnitude and phase of the voltage, while the D-STATCOM, a power electronics-based controller, regulates the voltage through reactive power compensation by injecting or absorbing reactive currents. This study presents a comparative performance analysis between the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{D}^{2} \text{VC}$</tex> and D-STATCOM controllers, aiming to evaluate which one is more effective in compensating voltage in medium voltage systems with variable generation. The analysis is based on computational simulations and theoretical studies, focusing on maintaining the voltage within regulatory limits.

title: Deep Ensemble Approach for Alzheimer's Disease Monitoring Using Microwave Radar Data
authors: A. Sriram Chowdary, A. Srihitha, G. Pavan Kumar, M. A. Jabbar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Diagnosis for Alzheimer disease in early and hidden phases is one of the complicated among neuro genitic disorders.Conventional approaches often involve invasive procedures, expensive scans, or subjective judgments, making early detection harder.This paper proposes a novel non-invasive hybrid framework that combines radar-based physiological data with clinical metadata to improve the accuracy of Alzheimer's disease detection.The main architecture uses Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) to extract spatial features, while Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) contextualize the clinical data. It combines physical and semantic information by merging radar signals from non-contact microwave sensing with structured clinical input. Our hybrid CNN-BERT model processes radar spectrograms and clinical metadata to enhance Alzheimer's risk classification, achieving 88 % accuracy with high sensitivity and specificity, outperforming traditional and unimodal methods, and enabling early, real-time, non-intrusive patient monitoring. This work brings hope for scalable, accessible Alzheimer's diagnosis through smart sensing and deep learning.

title: GreenSterz: Solar Driven Autoclave for Medical Sharps Sterilization in Rural Healthcare
authors: Anjali Ashank Chandane, S.B. Abitha, R. Santhoshi, G. Sudha, K. Shivashanker, A. Swetha Anand
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: The healthcare sector in rural areas faces significant challenges due to unreliable electricity, inadequate medical sharps waste management, and limited access to essential resources. This paper presents GreenSterz Solution, an integrated approach that utilizes a data handling system for medical sharps waste management and a solar-powered autoclave system for sterilization. The proposed system aims to address two critical issues: improving the transparency and efficiency of waste disposal processes through a web application and reducing reliance on unstable energy sources by utilizing solar energy for autoclave operation. The integration of Internet of Things sensors enables real-time monitoring of waste metrics and autoclave operations, ensuring consistent performance and accountability. By employing a monocrystalline Photovoltaic array, the system generates sustainable energy for autoclave operation, while a battery stores energy for continuous use. The application platform provides a secure, decentralized ledger to track medical waste disposal, ensuring compliance with regulatory standards. The solar-powered autoclave, optimized for rural settings, reduces the dependency on local electricity grids and ensures effective sterilization of medical instruments. This research demonstrates the feasibility and impact of this integrated solution, offering an eco-friendly and cost-effective approach to healthcare in resource-limited regions. Future work will focus on scaling this solution for broader applications and conducting field trials to assess its long-term performance.

title: An Improved DFS-Based Path Planning Method for UAV Mapping Tasks
authors: Mian Ye, Haoyu Li, Shirong Guo, Jinchen Zhao, Heng Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: With the widespread application of unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) technology in the field of surveying and mapping, path planning capability has become a key factor restricting the quality of mapping operations and the level of energy consumption. To address issues such as high path redundancy, frequent directional changes, and excessive energy usage in large-scale UAV mapping tasks, this paper proposes a path planning method based on an improved Depth-First Search (DFS) algorithm. Specifically, a connectivity-based labeling function is introduced to constrain the path expansion direction and reduce invalid searches; in addition, a directional search function is designed to optimize the search order of neighboring nodes, thereby improving path continuity and planning efficiency. Simulation results show that the improved algorithm outperforms the traditional DFS in terms of path redundancy, number of turns, and total steps.

title: Dynamic Threat Modelling and Vulnerability Assesment in Smart Microgrid
authors: Soumya K T, Vinay Kumar Jadoun, N.S Jayalakshmi, Surendra S
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
abstract: A smart microgrid is a localized system that is a scaled-down version of a smart grid that integrates power-related technology with information and communication technology in a controlled area, such as a campus, neighborhood, or small community. However, the network connectivity that empowers smart microgrids also introduces security vulnerabilities that make microgrid systems prime targets for cyberattacks. The attackers can target the microgrid system to disrupt energy distribution, and compromise the communication channel, which may lead to severe consequences for the local communities. In literature, significant research has been conducted on cybersecurity in broader power systems, but fewer studies have focused specifically on the unique challenges of smart microgrids. The localized nature and small scale of microgrids require customized cybersecurity approaches, which are still under-explored. The proposed research addresses the challenge of deploying reliable and efficient smart microgrids in real-world scenarios by introducing a dynamic threat modeling framework. The purpose of this framework is to simulate and analyze potential cyber threats to smart microgrids and assess vulnerabilities in terms of risk and impact. Significant progress has been made in the development and simulation of this dynamic threat modeling framework.

title: Few-Shot Action Scene Graph Generation from Video via Multimodal Language Models for Structuring Spatial Experience
authors: Jinseok Hong, Hyerim Park, Heejeong Ko, Woontack Woo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We present a multimodal framework that uses few-shot language models to generate action scene graphs from raw video for structuring spatial experiences in extended reality (XR). The system integrates unsupervised action segmentation, multimodal captioning with a vision-language model (VLM) guided by speech and motion cues, and scene graph generation from captions using a large language model (LLM), both leveraging few-shot prompting. By combining visual, verbal, and motion inputs, the framework produces semantically rich and accurate representations of spatial experiences without requiring annotated data or model fine-tuning. The resulting outputs will support a range of downstream XR applications, including adaptive playback, intent-driven retrieval, and flexible content reconstruction.

title: Two-Phase Cooling System Performance Under Different Operating Scenario
authors: Pritish R. Parida, Timothy Chainer
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Performance needs of today’s AI systems is driving an increase in power density of high-performance processing units and integration into dense 2.5 D and 3D heterogeneously integrated packages that exceeded the capability of traditional energy-intensive air-cooling solutions used in Data Centers. There is a need to develop both single- and two-phase liquid cooling solutions to provide energy-efficient thermal management of high-performance AI systems while eliminating water consumption and maintaining system reliability in any geographical location. In this work, previously developed component-/system-level modeling tools were adapted to evaluate the performance of above-ambient pumped two-phase liquid cooling of a multi-server rack under different operating scenarios and geographical locations. The tool was used to compare both component level and system level cooling performance (thermal resistances, pumping power, cooling coefficient of performance, etc.) of utilizing different dielectric coolants (such as R1234ze(E), R1234ze(Z), R1233zd(E), etc.) in the two-phase cooling loop. The system level model was utilized to understand the two-phase cooling system performance under different operating scenarios including (i) for an exemplar control scheme where facility side temperature was controlled to a set-point, (ii) for different internal/external loop pump and dry-cooler fan speeds, (iii) over a typical meteorological year at different US cities, and (iv) for performance comparison among different refrigerants at the same target exit vapor quality, etc. Results indicate medium-pressure (e.g. R1234ze(Z)) or high-pressure (e.g. R134a, R1234ze(E)) refrigerants produce better component as well as system level performance compared to lowpressure (e.g. $\mathbf{R 1 2 3 3 z d}(\mathbf{E}), \mathbf{R 1 3 3 6 m z z}(\mathbf{Z}))$ refrigerants.

title: Fibonacci Retracement and RSI Optimized Strategy for Indian Mid-Cap Stocks for Swing Trading
authors: Sukhendu Mohan Patnaik, Amar Kumar Behera
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: Trading in the capital market is fraught with uncertainty. Traders and investors across the globe keep on exploring ways to improve the trading outcome through various methods. Fibonacci ratios is one of the most interesting approaches in this space. This is also one method which is understood and interpreted in many diverse ways. Some practitioners believe that Fibonacci method has no utility in the capital market. This paper proposes a strategy using Fibonacci retracement and RSI combination with a customised setting on NSE mid cap stocks for swing trading. This study indicates that such a strategy significantly improves the return on investment compared to only using RSI or Fibonacci retracement alone.

title: Enhancing Burmese Word Segmentation through a Hybrid BiLSTM-CRF Model
authors: Hein Htet Arkar Mg, Win Lai Lai Phyu, Zaw Min Khaing
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: Word segmentation is a crucial foundational step for linguistic analysis. It is a challenging task for Myanmar (Burmese) and other Asian languages such as Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Thai, which lack whitespace to mark word boundaries. This paper aims to identify the most accurate approach for Burmese word segmentation by evaluating six models based on neural and statistical methods. Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) represent the neural approaches, while Conditional Random Field (CRF) serves as a statistical method. Three hybrid models—BiLSTM-CRF, BiLSTM-Attention, and BiLSTM-Attention-CRF—are also developed and examined. In addition to standard evaluation metrics, a boundary-based error analysis is employed to assess missed, false, and shifted boundaries, providing a finer measure of segmentation accuracy beyond token-level evaluation. The models are tested on a manually segmented corpus derived from a cleaned raw dataset. Experimental results show that the hybrid BiLSTM-CRF model achieves the best performance, with a precision of 97.12%, recall of 97.91%, and F1-score of 95.2%. These findings demonstrate that the hybrid approach is robust and effective, supporting accurate segmentation for real-world Burmese NLP applications and improving foundational tools for downstream language processing tasks.

title: Research on the Construction Technology of Expert Knowledge System for Aviation Equipment Quality Issues
authors: Mengmeng Zhou, Changlin Qian, Jiewei Tian, Chenguang Hou, Siyuan He
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: The frequent occurrence of quality problems in aviation equipment has led to a decline in the quality of aviation equipment. Both the military and industrial departments have carried out quality problem collection and analysis work and compiled a set of quality case studies. However, there are currently problems in the process of carrying out this work, such as low efficiency in analyzing and disposing of quality issues, inadequate information technology, insufficient knowledge sharing, and inconvenient information retrieval, which cannot effectively play the role of drawing lessons from quality issues. This article is based on a set of quality problem cases and uses an improved BBC (BERT-BILSTM-CRF) network and BERT model deep learning algorithm to identify problem elements and extract relationships between elements for quality problem information; integrate quality issue triplets and construct a knowledge graph of aviation equipment quality issues; and finally, integrate relevant functions to build a quality problem expert knowledge system software, achieving quality problem knowledge extraction and information sharing.

title: Design and Implementation of an Augmented Reality Tangible Game Utilizing Everyday Objects as In-Game Items
authors: Haruka Urushizaka, Taishi Iriyama, Takashi Komuro
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: In this paper, we propose an AR tangible game that enables players to use everyday objects as in-game items within a virtual space. The system performs generic object detection and recognition to deliver different in-game effects based on the object’s properties. We implemented a prototype application in which a pen-shaped object found in the environment is used as a weapon, with its color and length determining the type and reach of player attacks. In the game, the player moves around the room and swings the pen object like a sword to defeat enemy characters. User experiments with the implemented application showed that incorporating the color and length of real-world objects into the game design positively influenced players’ sense of immersion and enjoyment.

title: Aggregated Modeling of Two-Paralleled Grid-Forming Converters
authors: Wenjia Si, Qun Yu, Jingyang Fang
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Grid-forming converters (GFMCs) become the enabling units of modern power systems. In particular, they can operate as generators (e.g., photovoltaic generation) and loads (e.g., storage equipment). However, different from the well-studied dynamics of one-GFMC infinite-bus systems, the dynamics of paralleled GFMC systems are more complex and not fully explored. To address this challenge, we aim to simplify the paralleled GFMC system, thereby facilitating dynamic analysis. This paper establishes the models for both the one-GFMC infinite-bus system and the two-paralleled GFMC system. Moreover, by comparing the proposed models, we disclose the conditions under which these two models are equivalent, thus simplifying the two-paralleled GFMC system to a one-GFMC infinite-bus system. Finally, experimental results confirm the theoretical analysis.

title: Accuracy Analysis of Building Carbon Emission Prediction Based on Neural Network Algorithm
authors: Xiaoqing Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Climate change is becoming increasingly severe on a global scale, and the building sector, which is a significant contributor to carbon emissions and carbon footprint, has drawn significant attention for its potential to reduce emissions. This paper put forth a model that predicts building carbon emissions using a neural network algorithm in order to develop the prediction's accuracy. This study first explored the variables that affect building carbon emissions (BCE) in detail related to energy consumption, building materials, climate, and more. Next, two types of neural networks were constructed, specifically a multilayer perceptron (MLP) and a long shortterm memory (LSTM) network. The LSTM neural networks demonstrated a significantly higher accuracy when predicting BCE while the prediction trajectory was consistent with the actual values. The deviations consistently stayed within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$+5 \mathrm{t} / \mathrm{T}_{1}$</tex>, for breakpoints of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 9, 8 0}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0}$</tex> t/T. This finding increased overall prediction accuracy by 4 to 8 times, compared to other methods.

title: Federated Learning Framework with Prototype Clustering for Personalized Healthcare in IoT Wearables
authors: Heba Alasady, Chennaiah Madduri, Hari Suresh Babu Gummadi, Shweta Dhareshwar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: With the growing adoption of IoT-enabled wearables, the continuous monitoring of physiological signals has become a vital component of personalized healthcare. However, existing frameworks still face significant challenges, including non-IID data distribution across patients and high communication costs in resource-constrained wearables. To address these limitations, we propose a drift-aware prototype Clustering (DAPC)-enabled Federated Learning Framework (FL) for personalized healthcare diagnostics. Initially, data collected from the Medical Information Mart for Intensive Care III (MIMIC-III) raw wearable signals were denoised and normalized, followed by feature extraction from physiological and activity data. Each device then generates a lightweight prototype vector to summarize its data distribution. At the edge server, the prototypes are clustered using cosine similarity to form user groups with similar health patterns. Federated aggregation is performed within each cluster, and drift detection dynamically reassigns the devices during user behavior. Finally, a personalized adapter layer was fine-tuned on each device, and the optimized TinyML model was deployed for real-time lowlatency diagnostics. Experimental results show that the proposed DAPC-FL attains higher results than the existing model FL-Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) in terms of accuracy (98 %), precision (98 %), recall (97 %), and F1-score (97 %).

title: Intelligent Clothing Design using a CNN-Swin Transformer Hybrid with Pose-Adaptive 3D Garment Modeling
authors: Guanglin Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In the current era, intelligent cloth design has rapidly evolved with the integration of Deep Learning (DL) techniques, which enable automated fashion modeling to personalize fitting and garment production. However, the existing Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)-based 3D clothing design framework faces limitations, such as reliance on static body data, lack of ability to handle long-range dependencies, and limited applicability to dynamic clothing design. Hence, a novel hybrid Convolutional Neural Network with Swin Transformer (CNN-SwinTrans) is proposed for intelligent clothing design. First, real-world 3D body scans and 3D garments across multiple poses are collected from the CLOTH3D dataset. Next, the collected data underwent preprocessing through Laplacian smoothing to remove mesh noise and min-max normalization to ensure consistency. Furthermore, CNN-SwinTrans is employed for feature extraction, where CNN captures local features, while the transformer encodes global garment-body relationships. Body measurements are then computed to guide 3D garment modeling, which is further enhanced through void volume modeling and pose-conditioned adaptation. Finally, clothing pattern generation is performed using segmentation, least squares conformal mapping with as rigid as possible optimization for flattening seam adjustment, and nesting to minimize material waste. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed CNN-SwinTrans framework achieves greater recognition accuracy (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 6. 8 4 \%}$</tex>) by improving intelligent clothing design performance.

title: Understanding the Stability of Pyrolysis Oil from Guaiacol in a View Point of Free Radicals
authors: Longyi Liu, Zhongyang Luo, Feiting Miao, Wanchen Zhu, Longfei Li, Yuanlin Wang
publish: 2025 International Power and Sustainable Energy Technologies Conference (PSETC)
abstract: Bio-oil aging represents a critical indicator of its inherent instability, posing significant challenges for storage and upgrading. Free radicals may be responsible for triggering the polymerization of bio-oil components; however, detailed characterization of their dynamic evolution during prolonged aging remains underexplored. This study employed guaiacol as a model compound to detect changes in the quantity and types of free radicals in pyrolysis oil. The aging processes were classified to sealed and air-exposed at room temperature, respectively. Under sealed conditions, the results revealed a weak correlation between free radical presence and bio-oil aging progression, with radical characteristics demonstrating remarkable stability throughout the observation period. Conversely, atmospheric exposure induced significant alterations in radical behavior. Oxygen ingress triggered a progressive decline in radical spin concentration, stabilizing to equilibrium levels by day six. This attenuation pattern correlates with oxidative radical termination mechanisms and concurrent transformations of oxygen-containing functional groups during bio-oil degradation. These findings establish an analytical framework for elucidating the chemical kinetics of bio-oil aging through radical monitoring.

title: InGenCo : Integrated In-Place 3D Scenario Generation and Collaboration
authors: Raghav Mittal, Lokender Tiwari, Satyam Bhardwaj, Mritunjoy Halder, Brojeshwar Bhowmick
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Human-robot collaboration is essential in AI-powered Industry 5.0 and personal spaces, aiming to boost human creativity and efficiency. Traditional methods involve creating virtual scenarios in VR to simulate interactions, but they often rely on pre-defined 3D assets or procedural generation, which are time-consuming, expensive, and limited by restricted design options and the need for 3D expertise. Many systems are also desktop-based and lack intuitive interfaces, limiting interactive scenario creation and in-place testing. This paper presents an integrated XR-based system that combines GenAI based 3D scenario generation and human-robot collaboration in real-time. It allows users to create and modify virtual environments on-the-fly using voice and gesture inputs, and test collaborations directly in mixed reality, accelerating decision-making. The system, powered by Generative AI and XR, enables even non-experts to generate 3D assets, assemble them, configure robots, and perform collaborative tasks. It features an intuitive interface and multiple configuration options. Through experiments and ablations, the system’s effectiveness is validated, showing its potential for interactive 3D scenario creation and in-place collaboration in XR, with applications in robotics, gaming and other fields.

title: DenseNet201 Model for Classifying Fingernail Images as Disease Indicators
authors: James Neil B. Mendoza, Amy Lyn M. Maddalora, Albert A. Vinluan, Dorothy G. Buhat-Mendoza, Bouzeed S. Boukhazeem, Ahmed Mohammed M. Allafi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: Early detection of disease using the fingernail as an indicator of disease can potentially provide patients with better treatment.
