The study utilized CNN as a feature extractor using DenseNet201 to train and test a model for classifying fingernail images as a disease indicator. This experimental study utilizes 14 fingernail classes collected from image capture in Tobruk city and downloaded from the web, exploring transfer learning and hyperparameter tuning to enhance model training. The results of the study show that the average accuracy is 94.83%, precision is 94.90%, recall is 94.84%, and the F1-score is 94.83%. The model is an excellent classifier with a per-class AUC ROC of nearly 1.00 for all categories. DenseNet201 has proven to be a great classifier of fingernail images, now ready for a possible integration in the development of a web application capable of using fingernail condition as a disease indicator.

title: Design of Position and Attitude Algorithm for Micro Quadrotor with Visual Feedback
authors: Long Wang, Zhiwei Zhang, Jianwei Mei, Jie Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: Aiming at the autonomous landing of micro quadrotor aircraft in indoor or near-ground environment, GPS signal is unstable and cannot work, and the landing accuracy based on visual assisted positioning is low and its application is limited. This paper designs a target recognition algorithm based on HSV color model and Hough transform, and a position and attitude estimation algorithm based on visual feedback. In order to verify the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed algorithm, a micro-quadrotor experimental platform system was built based on STM32 microcontroller. The real-time online performance experiment results show that the target recognition algorithm and the visual feedback position and attitude estimation algorithm can effectively improve the application range, recognition rate and accuracy of the image. This promoted the development of quadrotor vision application field.

title: Interactive Java algorithms for dynamic visualization of parallel computing threads
authors: Liubov Evseeva, Vugar Salmanov, Zumrud Safarova, Sevinj Pashayeva, Pavlo Fedorka
abstract: In this study, approaches to the development of interactive Java algorithms intended for dynamic visualization of parallel computational threads were considered. The proposed interactive Java algorithms give an opportunity to create visual graphical representations of parallel processes, their interactions, and data distribution. Within the framework of the research the key approaches to visualization of parallel computational flows are analyzed, the peculiarities of the applied interactive components are estimated and the methods of integration with existing monitoring and debugging systems are considered. With the help of configurable visualization tools, developers and researchers can observe the evolution of computational threads, evaluate the performance of systems and timely react to changes in the structure of parallel tasks. Implementing algorithms on the Java platform ensures portability, broad applicability, and integration with existing frameworks for high-performance computing. The use of dynamic data structures, thread-safe collections and parallelism mechanisms implemented in the language and standard libraries allows efficiently processing large amounts of data in real time. In addition, Java Virtual Machine provides profiling tools that can be directly applied to optimize the visualized processes.

title: IGDNet: Zero-Shot Robust Underexposed Image Enhancement via Illumination-Guided and Denoising
authors: Hailong Yan, Junjian Huang, Tingwen Huang
abstract: Current methods for restoring underexposed images typically rely on supervised learning with paired underexposed and well-illuminated images. However, collecting such datasets is often impractical in real-world scenarios. Moreover, these methods can lead to over-enhancement, distorting well-illuminated regions. To address these issues, we propose IGDNet, a Zero-Shot enhancement method that operates solely on a single test image, without requiring guiding priors or training data. IGDNet exhibits strong generalization ability and effectively suppresses noise while restoring illumination. The framework comprises a decomposition module and a denoising module. The former separates the image into illumination and reflection components via a dense connection network, while the latter enhances non-uniformly illuminated regions using an illumination-guided pixel adaptive correction method. A noise pair is generated through downsampling and refined iteratively to produce the final result. Extensive experiments on four public datasets demonstrate that IGDNet significantly improves visual quality under complex lighting conditions. Quantitative results on metrics like PSNR (20.41dB) and SSIM (0.860dB) show that it outperforms 14 stat-eof-the-art unsupervised methods.

title: When Federated Learning Meets Quantum Computing: Survey and Research Opportunities
authors: Aakar Mathur, Ashish Gupta, Sajal K. Das
abstract: Quantum Federated Learning (QFL) is an emerging field that harnesses advances in Quantum Computing (QC) to improve the scalability and efficiency of decentralized Federated Learning (FL) models. This paper provides a systematic and comprehensive survey of the emerging problems and solutions when FL meets QC, from research protocol to a novel taxonomy, particularly focusing on both quantum and federated limitations, such as their architectures, Noisy Intermediate Scale Quantum (NISQ) devices, and privacy preservation, so on. With the introduction of two novel metrics, qubit utilization efficiency and quantum model training strategy, we present a thorough analysis of the current status of the QFL research. This work explores key developments and integration strategies, along with the impact of QC on FL, keeping a sharp focus on hybrid quantum-classical approaches. The paper offers an in-depth understanding of how the strengths of QC, such as gradient hiding, state entanglement, quantum key distribution, quantum security, and quantum-enhanced differential privacy, have been integrated into FL to ensure the privacy of participants in an enhanced, fast, and secure framework. Finally, this study proposes potential future directions to address the identified research gaps and challenges, aiming to inspire faster and more secure QFL models for practical use.

title: Robust Mean Change Point Testing in High-dimensional Data with Heavy Tails
authors: Mengchu Li, Yudong Chen, Tengyao Wang, Yi Yu
abstract: We study mean change point testing problems for high-dimensional data, with exponentially- or polynomially-decaying tails. In each case, depending on the ℓ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub>-norm of the mean change vector, we separately consider dense and sparse regimes. We characterise the boundary between the dense and sparse regimes under the above two tail conditions for the first time in the change point literature and propose novel testing procedures that attain optimal rates in each of the four regimes up to a poly-iterated logarithmic factor. To be specific, when the error distributions possess exponentially-decaying tails, a near-optimal CUSUM-type statistic is considered. As for polynomially-decaying tails, admitting bounded α-th moments for some α ≥ 4, we introduce a median-of-means-type test statistic that achieves a near-optimal testing rate in both dense and sparse regimes. Our investigation in the even more challenging case of 2 ≤ α < 4, unveils a new phenomenon that the minimax testing rate has no sparse regime, i.e. testing sparse changes is information-theoretically as hard as testing dense changes. Finally, we consider various extensions where we also obtain near-optimal performances, including testing against multiple change points, allowing temporal dependence as well as fewer than two finite moments in the data generating mechanisms. We also show how sub-Gaussian rates can be achieved when an additional minimal spacing condition is imposed under the alternative hypothesis.

title: Joint Active and Passive Beamforming for Energy-Efficient STARS with Quantization and Element Selection in ISAC Systems
authors: Li-Hsiang Shen, Yi-Hsuan Chiu
abstract: This paper investigates a simultaneously transmitting and reflecting reconfigurable intelligent surface (STARS)-aided integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems in support of full-space energy-efficient data transmissions and target sensing. We formulate an energy efficiency (EE) maximization problem that jointly optimizes a dual-functional radar-communication (DFRC)-empowered base station (BS), considering its ISAC-based active beamforming, along with the passive STARS beamforming configurations of amplitudes, phase shifts, quantization levels, and element selection. Furthermore, relaxed/independent/coupled STARS are considered to examine architectural flexibility. To tackle the non-convex and mixed-integer problem, we propose a joint active-passive beamforming, quantization and element selection (AQUES) scheme based on the alternating optimization: Lagrangian dual and Dinkelbach’s transformation tackle fractional equations, whereas successive convex approximation (SCA) convexifies the non-solvable problem; Penalty dual decomposition (PDD) framework and penalty-based convex-concave programming (PCCP) procedure solve amplitude and phase-shifts with the equality constraint; Heuristic search iteratively decides the optimal quantization level; Integer relaxation deals with the discrete element selection variables. Simulation results demonstrate that STARS-ISAC with the proposed AQUES scheme significantly enhances EE while meeting communication rates and sensing quality requirements. The coupled STARS further highlights its superior EE performance over independent and relaxed STARS thanks to its reduced hardware complexity. Moreover, AQUES outperforms existing configurations and benchmark methods in the open literature across various network parameters and deployment scenarios.

title: MSTCNet: Multiscale Transformer-CNN Network for Robotic Grasp Detection
authors: Maolin Li, Di-Hua Zhai, Sheng Yu, Yuanqing Xia
abstract: Existing robotic grasp detection methods often struggle with inaccurate predictions in complex scenarios involving multiple objects and textured backgrounds. Most existing methods attempt to enhance CNN-based architectures to improve grasp accuracy. However, their limited receptive fields and ineffective multiscale feature integration hinder handling objects of varying sizes, and performance degrades when local salient features are disturbed. To address these limitations, we propose a Swin Transformer-based grasp detection framework. It features a hierarchical Swin Transformer encoder that models both global contextual dependencies and local features through shifted-window and window attention mechanisms. In addition, we introduce a multiscale transformer pyramid pooling module that dynamically processes and fuses multiscale features, enabling the network to adjust grasp predictions based on object scales. Finally, a lightweight CNN decoder is designed to optimize multiscale feature fusion while maintaining spatial precision. Our method achieves accuracies of 98.9% and 96.7% on the Cornell and Jacquard datasets, respectively. Moreover, the network demonstrates real-time performance with a prediction rate of 27 fps. We conduct comparative experiments, ablation experiments, and real-world grasping experiments on the UR3 robot, achieving a 96.0% success rate.

title: Theoretical Estimation on Maximum-to-Maximum Ratio of the Total Electric Field to Its Rectangular Component Within Reverberation Chambers
authors: Peng Hu, Fujun Deng, Kai Guo, Shengyan Chen, Ru Wang, Manqi Xu, Liangliang Liu, Zhuo Li
abstract: For electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) standards, e.g., RTCA DO-160, MIL-STD-461, and IEC 61000-4-21, different maximum field strengths are defined as the test levels for radiated immunity/susceptibility testing in reverberation chambers. To provide the same baseline for comparison of the EMC performance across these standards, the maximum-to-maximum ratio of the total electric field to its rectangular component should be determined. For this, we propose the sampling-based and the solution-set-based methods for the estimation of maximum values, from which the maximum-to-maximum ratio can be derived. According to the numerical analysis, moreover, provided that a clear boundary, i.e., the quantile for a given probability, has been defined for the distributions of the electric field component and the total electric field, the sampling-based method can offer a simple and more intuitive solution that shows good agreement with the results reported in the literature.

title: Inter-Satellite Cooperation for Early Preamble Collision Detection in NTN IoT Random Access
authors: Jinkyo Jeong, Sangseok Yun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: In this paper, we propose an inter-satellite cooperation-based early preamble collision detector (ISC-eCD) designed for low Earth orbit (LEO) satellite-based non-terrestrial network (NTN) Internet of Things (IoT) random access (RA). ISC-eCD leverages cooperation between the serving and neighboring satellites to enable early preamble collision detection. By exploiting differences in round-trip times (RTTs) of preambles received at these satellites, ISC-eCD enables accurate preamble collision detection. We also propose a zero-correlation zone (ZCZ) design tailored to NTN RA that increases the number of available preambles and reduces preamble collisions without using additional root sequences. Extensive simulations demonstrate that ISC-eCD outperforms existing methods, achieving reduced RA delay, enhanced collision detection accuracy, improved physical uplink shared channel (PUSCH) resource efficiency, and an increased number of successful RA nodes.

title: Bare-Die Embedded PCB Technique: An EMI Perspective
authors: Shahid Aziz Khan, Feng Zhou, Mengqi Wang, Shivam Chaturvedi, DucDung Le
publish: IEEE Transactions on Components, Packaging and Manufacturing Technology
abstract: The key goals in developing power electronics converters for today’s demanding applications and industry are achieving high power density, high efficiency, and low cost. However, as power electronics become more integrated and closely packaged, they become more susceptible to the disruptive effects of electromagnetic interference (EMI), which is a challenge for embedded and integrated designs. This research focuses on the signal integrity and EMI performance evaluation of a new bare-die embedded PCB packaging technology, ensuring a very compact, high power density, and integrated design for the power electronics unit. The design incorporates the bare die of the switching devices into the PCB layers and uses multilayers for routing and cooling purposes. A Silicon (Si) MOSFET bare-die is embedded into the FR4 layers using the stomach cell approach, electrically connected, and cooled through laser-drilled micro vias and copper fills. The electrothermal codesign reduces the parasitic loop inductance by 74% and increases the power density by 113%. This research, through analysis and experimental results, evaluates the signal integrity and EMI performance, including conductive emissions, radiated emissions, insertion loss, reflective loss, cross talk, and susceptibility analysis, according to industry standards (CISPR25) to establish the superior performance of the proposed bare-die embedding technique through a benchmark comparison with the traditional PCB design. To the best of the author’s knowledge, this is the first paper to explore the EMI perspective on a system level for bare-die or active components embedded PCB design.

title: O-RAN-Enabled Adaptive Relaying for Robust V2X Communication in Urban NLOS Scenarios
authors: Abdul Rehman, Husnain Shahid, Barbara M. Masini, Piergiuseppe Di Marco, Fakiha Munawar
abstract: The Open Radio Access Network (O-RAN) introduces programmability and intelligence into wireless infrastructure, making it a promising enabler of reliable Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) communication in complex urban environments. Unlike traditional RAN, O-RAN’s disaggregated architecture and RAN Intelligent Controller (RIC) allow real-time adaptation to Non-Line-of-Sight (NLOS) challenges, an issue unresolved in many existing V2X systems. This paper proposes an adaptive relaying framework that leverages the near-real-time RIC to dynamically enhance V2X reliability through dynamic relay selection and interference-aware resource coordination. The architecture supports programmable fallback relaying using disaggregated O-DU/O-RU units at roadside infrastructure, enabling low-latency two-hop paths when direct sidelink communication fails. To evaluate performance, a semi-analytical model is developed based on Moment Matching Approximation (MMA), capturing the signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) under composite Nakagami-lognormal fading and stochastic co-channel interference. The framework integrates O-RAN with NR-V2X sidelink communication to bridge the gap between centralized and adhoc vehicular networks. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed O-RAN-aided relaying improves Packet Success Probability (PSP) in dense NLOS scenarios, consistently achieving a PSP above 90%. The framework outperforms conventional LOS and NLOS approaches while maintaining compatibility with 3GPP Release 18 and O-RAN Alliance specifications, ensuring practical deployability in future intelligent transportation systems (ITS).

title: Development of Acoustic Levitation Methods for Particle Stability and Positioning in Underwater Applications
authors: K. Sathish
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: This research investigates the optimisation of magnetic circuit topologies for underwater systems using COMSOL Multiphysics and metrics-based analysis. The goal of this study is to increase both performance and efficiency. The research makes use of simulation capabilities to optimise the circuit geometry in terms of magnetic field strength, energy efficiency, and structural stability. This is performed by iteratively updating the circuit architecture in response to pressure variations, salinity changes, and heat impacts, all of which are unique to underwater conditions. According to the results of testing conducted in a variety of marine settings, the optimised designs outperform conventional designs in terms of field intensity (by up to 25%), energy loss (by 15%), and material efficiency (by 10%). As a result of these discoveries, COMSOL has gained recognition as a potent tool for developing electromagnetic circuit designs that are both durable and highperformance in the field of marine technology. In addition, the benefits of topology optimisation for underwater applications have been highlighted.

title: Movement-Driven Interaction with a Virtual Pet: A Rehabilitation Prototype for Bedridden Patients
authors: Soi Choi, Donghyeong Kang, Mingi Kim, Seonjae Oh, Jean Ho Chu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Post-surgery rehabilitation is often limited by patients’ low motivation to engage in repetitive exercises. This study explores an interaction structure designed to encourage motivation in bedside contexts. Rather than relying on precise posture recognition, the system applies a forgiving-by-design approach, in which physical movements above a certain threshold are translated into actions performed by a virtual character. Instead of linking motion to a humanoid avatar, the prototype reflects user movements through a virtual animal character. This design is based on clinical feedback indicating that interaction with animals can enhance patient motivation. The system was developed using IMU and camera-based sensors to examine the feasibility of motion tracking in supine positions. It does not require precise avatar rigging, yet successfully generates meaningful responses within a virtual environment. This approach offers a practical interaction model for rehabilitation by connecting physical movements to actions within a virtual space.

title: Hybrid Grey Wolf Optimization-Based Hydro-Thermal Scheduling Integrating Wind and Solar Energy Resources
authors: Sunil Kumar Choudhary, Arindam Mondal, M Prakash
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: Modern power systems' dependability and efficiency depend on the best scheduling of many energy supplies, including hydro, thermal, and renewable sources like wind. This work provides a new hybrid Grey Wolf Optimization (H-GWO) method for integrated scheduling of hydro-thermal systems enhanced with wind energy resources. The suggested approach improves convergence speed, solution accuracy, and resilience in addressing complicated, nonlinear, and non-convex scheduling problems by including adaptive control parameters and elite opposition-based learning, thereby augmenting the standard Grey Wolf Optimization technique. The hybrid scheduling framework considers multiple real-world constraints like water discharge restrictions, thermal unit ramp rates, wind-solar power variability, and spinning reserve needs. Minimizing the overall running cost of the power system is the aim, while nevertheless preserving the demand-supply balance and guaranteeing environmental sustainability. Simulations on a conventional hydro-thermal-wind-solar system benchmark confirm the efficacy of the proposed H-GWO method. Comparative study of genetic algorithms (GA), Teaching Learning based Optimization (TLBO), and other metaheuristic approaches shows that H-GWO excels in terms of cost reduction, convergence stability, and computing efficiency. The daily fuel cost amounts to $33,886.71, inclusive of sustainable wind-solar energy costs of $41,932.4879. The establishment of a sustainable wind and solar park has led to a decrease in emissions from 16,097.0396 lb/day to 6,247.9701 lb/day. Moreover, the method shows great capacity in allowing the stochastic character of wind and solar power, thus guaranteeing consistent grid integration. This study helps to create smart energy management plans that fit the increasing need for sustainable, robust, and economically feasible power system operations in the period of the renewable energy transition.

title: Dual Count Down Clock System (DCCS) with Data Logger Interface
authors: Swathy S Nair, Abdul Mannan, Biswajit Biswas, Anupam Kumar Shrivastava
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: This technical paper, presents the design and implementation of an in-house developed dual countdown clock system using LabVIEW, with a data logger interface which is used to disseminate time to two different servers. A dual Countdown Clock System (DCCS) allows two separate timers to run concurrently with independent settings. This paper explores the design and implementation of such a system using LabVIEW, a popular graphical programming language for system design, especially in test, measurement and control applications. This application, which can independently manage two Count Down timers with separate timing sequences, is designed to be highly flexible, allowing users to set different start times, at different count down rates, and modes of operation for each timer. The application demonstrates how LabVIEW’s graphical programming environment can be leveraged to control multiple timed processes with ease. These dual CDTs are user friendly, time-efficient, cost effective and flexible.

title: Development of a Piezoelectric Energy Harvester using the Rotational Motion of a Kalesa Wheel using a Microcontroller and IoT Monitoring
authors: Jaquelyn J. Bermoy, John Raven M. Santos, John Christian Y. Nicdao
publish: 2025 International Power and Sustainable Energy Technologies Conference (PSETC)
abstract: As a practical alternative to conventional energy devices, this study presents a piezoelectric energy harvester (PEH) that converts mechanical energy generated from the rotational motion of a kalesa wheel into electrical energy. To address the brittleness of piezoelectric materials, the system incorporates an indirect gear-based striking mechanism to reduce mechanical wear. For real-time output voltage, current, and power monitoring, the prototype incorporates an ESP32 microcontroller with IoT capabilities. Results from the study show that the PEH can generate an output power of up to 0.33W, highlighting its potential for low-power off-grid uses such as remote sensors or illumination. Even under low-frequency rotational excitation, the system proves effective at the average tested speed of 6 km/h. This research helps promote clean sources of energy where the design is also applicable to other systems containing wheels with low rotational speed.

title: Optimized Energy Management in PV-Wind Hybrid Systems Using Quadratic Boost Converter and Electric Eel Foraging-Based Control
authors: C. Ebbie Selva Kumar, R. Brindha, R. Eveline Pregitha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Worldwide ecological variations, nuclear power hazards, transmission losses, and increasing energy expenses are making the shift to Renewable Energy Sources (RES) essential for sustainable electricity generation. Hence, this study describes a hybrid energy management system used to seamlessly integrate Photovoltaic (PV), wind, and battery storage subsystems for a more stable and reliable power supply. For enhancing voltage gain and maintaining DC link stability, the PV subsystem utilized a Quadratic Boost Converter (QBC). A Proportional-Integral (PI) controller optimized through the Electric Eel Foraging Algorithm (EEFA) is employed for improved dynamic performance and reduced deviations that occur during control. Wind energy is harnessed using a DoublyFed Induction Generator (DFIG) in combination with a PIcontrolled PWM rectifier for DC conversion. Additionally, the bidirectional battery converter balanced the energy between surplus and deficit scenarios. Simulations using MATLAB demonstrated the proposed method with 93.75 % efficiency under changing operational conditions.

title: Prediction of Biopharmaceutical Production Quality Using Residual LSTM with Optimized Feature Selection
authors: Qin Dong, Min Dou, Wei Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Ensuring consistent production quality in biopharmaceutical manufacturing has become a critical challenge, owing to the industry's dependence on complex, high-dimensional, and dynamic process data. Traditional methods often struggle to accurately capture nonlinear interactions among diverse features, leading to restricted predictive performance in real-world production environments. To overcome these limitations, this research presents a predictive framework that integrates Cheetah Optimization for feature selection with a Residual Long Short-Term Memory (Res-LSTM) network for quality prediction. The Cheetah Optimization algorithm is employed to identify the most discriminative and significant features from the Big Data Biopharmaceutical Manufacturing dataset, thereby enhancing the model's learning efficiency and minimizing redundancy. The Residual LSTM further strengthens predictive capability by improving gradient flow and enabling deeper model construction for accurate output estimation. The framework achieves superior performance with an Accuracy of 99.3 %, Precision of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 9. 1 \%}$</tex>, Recall of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 9. 2 \%}$</tex>, Specificity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 9. 4 \%}$</tex>, and F1-Score of 99.2 %, highlighting its reliability and scalability. This study provides a high-performance and intelligent solution for predicting biopharmaceutical production quality, advancing sustainable practices and supporting quality-by-design strategies in pharmaceutical manufacturing.

title: Signal-Transformer: Multi-Channel Sensor-Based Tool Health Monitoring
authors: Yuecheng Yin, Zhanji Yang, Jiaxu Dao, Qingsong Zhou
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Manufacturing System (ICAMTMS)
abstract: Tool condition monitoring is essential for intelligent manufacturing and directly impacts machining quality and productivity. This paper proposes a Transformer-based approach for tool state recognition, addressing the limitations of traditional sequence models in handling multi-modal sensor data. By fusing vibration, acoustic emission, and current signals, the model utilizes the self-attention mechanism of the Transformer to effectively learn global temporal dependencies. Experiments conducted on a milling dataset show that the proposed approach outperforms LSTM and GRU models in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score, particularly in identifying tool failures. These results validate the robustness and performance of the Signal-Transformer in tool condition monitoring, highlighting its potential as a reliable and generalizable solution for high-accuracy tool health management.

title: Multilingual Sentiment Analysis with XLM-RoBERTa: A Case Study on Myanmar and English YouTube Comments
authors: Win Win Thant
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: This research presents a multilingual sentiment analysis approach that effectively analyzes music comments written in both Myanmar and English. Music is a universal form of expression, and people often share their emotional responses to songs in their native languages. Analyzing these comments in multiple languages is essential to fully capture diverse listener opinions and emotional reactions across cultures. This study employs multilingual sentiment analysis to construct linguistic resources for low-resource languages, such as Myanmar, by utilizing the strengths of high-resource languages like English. A balanced dataset of 17,000 comments (8,500 Myanmar and 8,500 English) was compiled, and a pretrained multilingual transformer model (XLM-RoBERTa) was fine-tuned for sentiment classification. The model achieved 90.1% accuracy on English-only comments, 85.3% on Myanmar-only comments, and 88.5% on the combined Myanmar-English test set, demonstrating reliable cross-lingual generalization. Experimental results show that the model performs well on both Myanmar and English comments, highlighting the effectiveness of multilingual sentiment analysis in capturing cross-cultural musical sentiment.

title: A LiDAR-to-VR Pipeline for Environmental Simulation
authors: Kimia Naeiji, Erica Butts, Dahlia Musa, Ahmad Ibrahim, Abdul Razzak Doughan, Viravid Na Nagara, Michel Boufadel, Salam Daher
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We present an in-progress LiDAR-to-Virtual Reality (VR) pipeline that leverages immersive technology to educate users about the environmental role of rain gardens in urban planning. Our workflow begins with 3D scans captured via drone-based LiDAR and 2D image capture, which are processed using photogrammetry to generate a 3D mesh and GIS tools to extract building footprints and topography. These datasets are refined and optimized with low-polygon meshes suitable for real-time rendering and VR.The VR environment immerses users in an interactive raingarden simulation that dynamically visualizes water flow, retention volume, and ecological benefits. This pipeline is designed with performance constraints in mind reducing mesh complexity while maintaining architectural fidelity to ensure compatibility with commercial head-mounted displays. This paper discusses the feasibility of the pipeline and its potential to support interactive environmental education. Future work includes simulating watershed-scale drainage networks and conducting usability evaluations focused on technology acceptance and interaction design.

title: Exploring the Impact of Nanoscale Roughness on the Pool Boiling Performance of Femtosecond Laser Processed Copper in Dielectric Fluid
authors: Graham Kaufman, Josh Gerdes, Mohamed Marey, George Gogos, Craig Zuhlke
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: In this work, the effect that nanoscale roughness has on the key pool boiling metrics of heat transfer coefficient (HTC) and critical heat flux (CHF) is investigated for pool boiling performed in the developmental dielectric fluid Opteon ${ }^{\text {TM }}$ 2P50. A novel combination of the scalable fabrication techniques femtosecond laser surface processing (FLSP) and hydrogen annealing (H2A) are utilized to produce functionalized copper (Cu) surfaces that have metallic surface chemistry and hierarchical micro- and nano-scale topography. The degree of nanoscale roughness of the laser processed surfaces is tunable with the post-laser processing H2A technique, lending a unique opportunity to investigate the impact of the nanoparticle overlayer without changing the microscale topography or surface chemistry. Varying the annealing temperature yields surfaces with nanoparticle sizes ranging from approximately 100 nm at the lowest annealing temperature to approximately $2.9 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ at the highest temperature. The annealing does not impact the microscale structures, so the impact of the nanoscale roughness can be studied directly. The boiling curves produced when pool boiling with these surfaces have a unique bimodal nature. The degree of nanoscale roughness affects the maximum HTC and CHF. The surface with the finest layer of nanoscale roughness achieved a $176 \%$ increase in the maximum HTC and a $26.2 \%$ increase in CHF over a polished Cu reference surface. The surface with the coarsest nanoparticle layer achieved a $341 \%$ increase in the max HTC and a $33.4 \%$ increase in CHF over a polished Cu reference surface.

title: Unsupervised Deep Learning Approach for Transmission Line Fault Detection
authors: Zhiying Wang, Noraidah Binti Mohd Shariff, Anis Fariza Binti Md. Pazil
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: Modern power systems are increasingly complex and vulnerable to various types of faults, particularly on transmission lines. Traditional fault detection methods based on fixed-threshold relay protection are often inadequate in meeting the demands of high accuracy and reliability. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a novel end-to-end unsupervised fault detection framework combining a Hyena encoder for unsupervised feature extraction with a downstream liquid time-constant (LTC) neural network classifier. The model is trained and evaluated on a comprehensive dataset generated from the IEEE 39-bus system under diverse fault types and operating conditions. Experimental results show that the proposed Hyena-Ltc approach achieves superior classification performance, with accuracy exceeding 99.70%, and demonstrates remarkable robustness against noise and measurement errors. These findings confirm the method’s strong generalization ability and its practical potential for reliable and efficient fault detection in complex power system environments.

title: Research on the Pilot Protection Method for T-Connected Line in Distribution Networks Based on Cosine Similarity
authors: Guangfu Xu, Xueneng Su, Haiqiang Zhang, Jiayu Xiong, Lijie Ding
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: In order to solve the problems of low selectivity of overcurrent protection and large amount of data transmission of current differential protection after T-connected line fault in distribution network, a T-connected line protection method based on steady-state voltage transient current cosine similarity is proposed. By establishing the equivalent circuit diagram of the internal and external faults in the T-connected line area of the distribution network, it is found that the polarity of the transient fault current flowing through the switch measuring point device of the distribution line is different from that of the pre-fault steady-state voltage. Based on this, the cosine similarity is introduced to measure this difference, and the product sum of the similarity coefficients between the transient current fault component and the pre-fault steady-state voltage component at each switch is defined as the internal and external fault identification criterion of the T-connected line area. Based on PSCAD / EMTDC simulation software, the simulation model of distribution network with T-connected line system is built to verify the reliability of the proposed protection method. The simulation results show that the proposed protection method can accurately identify the internal and external faults within 5ms time window, and has strong resistance to transition resistance. At the same time, the proposed protection method has a small amount of data transmission, and has good speed and applicability.

title: Efficient Solution Method for Generalized Linear Models using Variational Inference in Large Sample Statistical Estimation
authors: Qingjun Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Generalized linear models (GLMs) face statistical estimation efficiency bottlenecks in large sample scenarios. This study constructs a Bayesian-frequency decoupling strategy, designs a parameter-sharing exponential family variational distribution family, and combines low-rank covariance decomposition to achieve sublinear growth of memory usage. The random natural gradient optimization mechanism is used to reduce the computational complexity, and the temperature parameter is introduced to adaptively adjust the balance between approximation accuracy and convergence speed. Experiments show that under a sample size of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0}^{\boldsymbol{7}}$</tex>, the iteration time of this method is only <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{56.2 ms}$</tex>; the memory usage is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 8 7. 3}$</tex> MB; the communication overhead reaches <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$856.9 \text{MB} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>, which verifies the efficiency of this method in large-scale data.

title: Short-Term Photovoltaic Power Prediction Based on VMD-PCA-Informer-LSTM
authors: Xiaoli Ren, Lixun Gao, Jianwei Yang, Longlong Lü, Xin Ma, Ni Li, Caixia Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: Accurate prediction of photovoltaic (PV) power is crucial for grid scheduling, energy management, and the optimal operation of photovoltaic power plants. However, the time-series data of PV power exhibit high nonlinearity and randomness, influenced by factors such as weather and sunlight. Traditional prediction methods often fail to meet the high accuracy requirements. To address this issue, this paper proposes a short-term PV power prediction method based on Variational Mode Decomposition (VMD), Principal Component Analysis (PCA) dimensionality reduction, and an Informer-LSTM hybrid model (VMD-PCA-Informer-LSTM). Firstly, VMD is applied to decompose the time-series data of PV power into multiple intrinsic mode functions (IMFs), effectively removing noise and capturing the frequency characteristics of PV power across different scales. Next, PCA is used to reduce the dimensionality of the decomposed data, extracting key features, reducing redundancy, and improving model training efficiency. Finally, by combining the advantages of the Informer and LSTM deep learning models, an efficient hybrid prediction model is designed. The Informer's self-attention mechanism captures long-term dependencies, while LSTM is used to handle short-term temporal dependencies. Experimental results show that the VMD-PCA-Informer-LSTM model performs exceptionally well on multiple PV datasets. Compared to traditional LSTM and other baseline models, it offers higher prediction accuracy and stability. This method not only improves the prediction accuracy of PV power but also provides effective technical support for intelligent scheduling and optimization management of PV power plants in China.

title: EmoMotion: Competing with Your Past, Feeling in the Present
authors: Crescent Jicol, Christopher Prendergast, Jakub Mazur, Aastha Gupta, Daniel Horne, Jinha Yoon, Anca Salagean, Christof Lutteroth
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We present a demonstration that combines our VR exergame, RaceYourselves, with EmoSense, our real-time physiological emotion recognition toolkit. RaceYourselves transforms indoor cycling into a motivating, immersive fitness experience by letting users race against representations of their own past performances. EmoSense unobtrusively collects physiological data—pupil dilation, heart rate, skin conductance and facial expression—via wearable sensors and head-mounted display (HMD)-integrated tracking to estimate arousal and valence in real time. Attendees will cycle through several virtual environments, while observing live emotion estimation feedback based on their physiological state. This demo illustrates how immersive experiences and affective computing can be integrated to evaluate and adapt VR user experiences in real time.

title: Thermal Performance Evaluation of Commercial Photovoltaic Inverters
authors: Alan Marques Leal de Sousa, Geyciane Pinheiro de Lima, Marcos Camargo Lima Filho, Diego Lucas de Carvalho Martinez, João Pedro Carvalho Silveira, Pedro José dos Santos Neto, Tárcio André dos Santos Barros
abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) inverters operating at high ambient temperatures can suffer degradation and energy losses, negatively affecting their performance and lifespan. Although inverter thermal behavior can be studied through various approaches, such as internal circuit analysis, semiconductor switch modeling, and thermal network development, in commercial contexts it is not feasible to consider the internal details of each inverter, as each model may have distinct components and technologies. Given this limitation, this study proposes to evaluate the thermal performance of commercial PV inverters using two factors derived from mathematical models: thermal capacity (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F_{\text {cap }}$</tex>) and thermal dissipation (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F_{\mathbf{d}}$</tex>), analyzing their potential as indicators of the thermal quality of the devices. To validate these models, four commercial inverters were tested, divided into two groups according to their nominal power. The results demonstrated that these factors have potential as indicators for evaluating the thermal performance of PV inverters.

title: A Macro-to-Micro Control Approach to Balance User Agency and Automation for Mobile AI-assisted Writing on Smart Glasses
authors: Chen Zhou, Wei Tsang Ooi, Shengdong Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Generative AI-assisted writing often requires post-generation editing. In a dynamic mobile environment, where user attention is divided, a key challenge is to reduce the cognitive load of such generate-edit cycle. To address the challenge, we propose a "macro-to-micro" control approach to balance user agency and automation in the AI-assisted writing process. This approach offers distinct interaction methods for macro-level adjustments (e.g., tone) and micro-level modifications (e.g., words). We conducted two user studies to evaluate its effectiveness in mobile text editing. Our preliminary results show that our approach significantly reduces cognitive load in demanding mobile situations. We identified a "control paradox": users felt more confident and preferred our approach, despite perceiving less direct operational control. Furthermore, our second study identified an important modality mismatch: the voice-centric modality for the micro-editing layer was a significant bottleneck. This finding suggests a key design principle for future systems: effective control is not about more or less, but about matching the interaction modality to the task’s required precision.

title: Power Electronics Building Block for Power-Hardware-In-The-Loop and its Application in Microgrid Research
authors: Julian David Ontibon Velasquez, Guillermo Andrés Jiménez Estévez, Ignacio Polanco Lobos
abstract: Despite recent advancements in microgrid research, several challenges still require practical and comprehensive solutions. While simulation tools provide valuable insights, hardware experimentation remains essential to capture phenomena that models may overlook. This work presents the development of a modular and cost-effective Power Electronics Building Block (PEBB), designed to support Hardware-in-the-Loop (HIL) based experimentation in microgrid applications. The proposed converter enables flexible reconfiguration into different topologies, facilitating studies on control, stability, and power management. The paper describes the design and integration of the device, as well as its validation through representative experiments, demonstrating its effectiveness as a scalable platform for advanced microgrid research.

title: Analysis of Influencing Factors on Online Monitoring Data of Dissolved Gas in Transformer Oil Based on Data Mining
authors: Mengqi Li, Xiaosheng Peng, Tao Xie, Meng Zhou, Ke Hu, Yingcan Si
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: While external environmental factors are known to affect field Dissolved Gas Analysis (DGA) data, leading to fluctuations and deviations that restrict reliable application, a quantitative understanding of these complex, often non-linear influences remains limited. This paper proposes an interpretable XGBoost-SHAP data mining framework to analyze the influence of environmental factors on DGA monitoring data. After an initial full-feature model confirmed the dominant role of companion gases, a refined model excluding these interferences was constructed to isolate environmental effects. XGBoost captures complex non-linearities and interactions between environmental factors and DGA readings, while SHAP interprets the model, quantifying each factor's direct impact. Analysis of long-term data from four Photoacoustic Spectroscopy (PAS)-based online DGA monitors reveals Ambient Temperature and Humidity as critical, non-linearly influencing environmental drivers. Notably, humidity and atmospheric pressure impacts suggest intrinsic environmental sensitivity of the PAS devices. Atmospheric Pressure and Seasonality also show considerable influence; Environmental Noise has a negligible effect. This study offers crucial insights for improving online DGA data accuracy and reliability.

title: Toward a Human-Centered Framework for Standardization in eXtended Reality (XR): Development, Measurement, and Evaluation
authors: Christos Gkoumas, Eleftherios Triantafyllidis, Alexandros Rouchitsas
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: The rapid growth of eXtended Reality (XR) offers transformative potential but is hindered by fragmentation and a lack of standardization, particularly regarding human-centered factors. This limits interoperability, evaluation of effectiveness, and comparability across studies, ultimately affecting broader adoption. To address this, we propose a human-centered framework for standardization, focusing on three pillars: (i) XR development processes, (ii) human behavior measurement, and (iii) evaluation procedures. To demonstrate its applicability, we provide an example showing how the framework can guide the implementation of an Industry 5.0 VR training simulation. We hope the framework serves as a starting point for improving effectiveness, comparability, and trust in XR systems, fostering a more standardized and reliable XR ecosystem.

title: Effects of TiC and Cr on Microstructure and Performance of Ni60 Alloy Coatings
authors: JianYong Guo, Siew Wei Phang, Amares Singh
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: This study aims to address the critical issue of wear and tear in soil-contacting agricultural machinery components, focusing on extending their lifespan and improving operational efficiency. The research investigates the microstructural and performance implications of adding TiC and Cr to Ni60 alloy coatings deposited on Q235 steel substrates. Coatings were formulated with varying concentrations of TiC at 5%, 10%, 20%, and 30% by mass and Cr at 5%, 10%, and 15%, to create composite layers with tailored properties. The results indicate that TiC significantly enhances the hardness and wear resistance of the coatings, with optimal performance observed at a 30% TiC content. Additionally, adding 15% Cr improves the coatings’ corrosion resistance. While Cr had a limited effect on reducing friction and wear loss, the presence of TiC created a hard-phase reinforcement within the alloy matrix, contributing to overall structural integrity. The alloy coatings exhibit a promising combination of high hardness and corrosion resistance, making them suitable for soil-engaging applications. This study provides valuable insights into the microstructural modifications achievable through laser cladding and highlights the potential of Ni60-based coatings as durable protective layers for addressing wear and corrosion challenges in agricultural machinery.

title: Joint-wise Comparative Analysis of Relative Local Velocity in the ‘Running Man’ Shuffle Dance
authors: Jin Kim, Joung Jun Kim, Youngho Chai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We analyze rhythmic control for realistic avatar motion via an expert-beginner comparison of the "Running Man" shuffle. Jointlevel local angular velocities are projected onto anatomical axes and normalized to [–1, 1] per subject-joint-segment across posture transitions. Experts show unimodal rise-peak-decay with few sign flips; beginners display early spikes and rebound. Peak placement and simple lead/lag metrics (DTW) concur. These findings yield practical cues for avatar control (avoid early peaks, suppress reversals, minimize offsets), with clear implications for synthesis and feedback, albeit from a two-subject pilot.

title: Early Detection of Alzheimer's and Parkinson's Diseases Using MRI-Based Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Saranya. E, Dharshini. N, Vethanarrthana. S, Sri Geethani. R, Adriannaa Anand
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases are common neurological disorders that progressively affect memory, movement, and daily functioning. Early diagnosis is difficult because symptoms often overlap with normal aging and other conditions. This study focuses on using brain Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) combined with convolutional neural networks (CNN), a type of pattern recognition technique, to improve early detection of these diseases. MRI scans from patients diagnosed with Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and healthy individuals were collected and analyzed. The CNN model was trained to identify subtle changes in brain regions linked to these disorders, such as the hippocampus and substantia nigra. Results showed that this approach outperformed traditional clinical methods by detecting early-stage disease markers with higher accuracy and consistency. Compared to manual diagnosis, the CNN method reduces human error and speeds up the diagnostic process by automatically highlighting affected areas. This technique also helps differentiate between Alzheimer's and Parkinson's, which can have similar symptoms but require different treatments. This research suggests that combining MRI with advanced image analysis provides a promising tool to support doctors in early, reliable diagnosis, enabling timely intervention and better management of Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases.

title: Multimodal Hybrid Summarization for Multi-Class Fake News Detection in Low-Resource Languages
authors: Laith Hussein Jasim, Mohan Kumar. A V, S. Trisheela, Mrinmoy Aich, Ranjitha. R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Recently, the rapid spread of fake news become a serious threat to society, mainly in low-resource languages, where annotated datasets and linguistic tools are threatened. Existing fake news detection models have focused significantly on binary classification and have struggled with noisy and long articles. To overcome these challenges, this research proposed a Multimodal Hybrid Summarization Framework (MHSF) to detect fake news in low-resource languages. Initially, multilingual text articles and associated images were obtained from the TALLIP dataset and from other multimodal sources. Subsequently, the collected text is pre-processed and condensed by utilizing a hybrid summarization strategy that integrates mT5-based abstractive and YAKE-based extractive to generate concise yet informative summaries. These summaries are then encoded with multilingual Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (mBERT) for contextual embeddings, whereas images are handled with a Vision-Language Model (VLM) to measure image-to-text consistency and extract visual features. Finally, multimodal embeddings were merged and fed into a fully connected neural network, which was trained with categorical cross-entropy for multiclass classification. The proposed MHSF achieved superior results in terms of accuracy (90.21), precision (90.16), recall (89.72), and F1-Score (90.07) compared to the existing Multilingual Fake News Detection (MFND) approach.

title: High-Efficiency Zeta Converter with Intelligent RBFNN - MPPT for Photovoltaic Based Grid Tied System
authors: S. Marisargunam, M. Manjusha, S. Sree Dharinya, Parthiban. B, Chelumala Nirosha, R. Venkateshwaran
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Global trend toward greener energy alternatives has led to the incorporation of sustainable power sources into a number of industries, including public transit and electrical networks. Photovoltaic (PV) systems have gained significant traction as a key element of this transition because of their abundant and clean energy output. Solar PV systems offer a compelling substitute for traditional power sources. The Zeta Converter is used to boost and regulate the output voltage level. It has been proposed that the Zeta converter is a superior alternate for MPPT. RBFNN (Radial Basis Function Neural Network) has been used for MPPT tracking to track a maximum power point with variations in irradiation. Simulation findings based on MATLAB indicate the efficient functioning of PV employing recommended control approaches in grid-connected mode with low reactive power regulation. This proposed work has a THD Value of 2.96% when the controllers are compared and the efficiency obtained using Zeta converter is 92.4%.

title: Gan Based Step-Down Dc Converter for Wind Tunnel and Electrolyser Application
authors: Gabryel Ferreira Alves, Luiz Henrique Silva Colado Barreto, Carla Freitas de Andrade, Menaouar Berrehil El Kattel, Francisco Olímpio Moura Carneiro, Mona Lisa Moura de Oliveira
abstract: The intermittency of renewable sources, such as wind energy, poses challenges to their integration into green hydrogen production. Power converters play a key role in regulating these fluctuations. This work presents the design of a gallium nitride (GaN)-based interleaved buck microconverter for a lab-scale wind turbine operating in a wind tunnel. The design of the converter was based on experimental data from the wind tunnel and is suitable for a broad operating range, considering two reference electrolysers of different rated power levels. A PI controller is implemented in simulation to stabilize the output voltage during wind speed variations. Computational results indicate the effectiveness of the proposed GaN-based solution over the operating range, making the converter appropriate for lab-scale studies on the integration of wind power into hydrogen production.

title: Development of a reduced-order nodal reliability framework for data center applications
authors: Tyler Schostek, Nirmal Rai, Kimberly Saviers, Davide Ziviani
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Data centers are facing an increasing demand for computational resources, especially due to the boom of AI/ML applications. High power electronics generate extreme heat fluxes that need to be dissipated, and advanced thermal management systems (TMS) are needed to maximize efficiency, to improve environmental friendliness (e.g., lower water consumption), and to reduce costs compared to traditional air-cooling systems. The reliability of traditional air-cooling systems is well known as a result of their wide adoption in industry. However, more advanced TMSs for data centers are less characterized, which presents an opportunity to study their reliability. In this work, an oscillating heat pipe (OHP) component and a data center rack TMS are implemented in a reducedorder nodal framework. This nodal framework, previously used for decision-making and exploring design spaces, uses directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) to represent causal relationships between model variables. Using a state-space representation, systems are transitioned through time, and degradation modes are applied stochastically based on user-defined probability density functions (PDFs). A basic OHP oscillator model with simple degradation modes is used to highlight the primary functional capabilities of the reliability framework. Subsequently, the implementation of a data center TMS consisting of OHPs for each CPU and a water-cooling loop (pump, heat exchanger, and cold plate) highlights the flexibility of the platform for larger or more complex systems. Thirty-year studies are simulated for the data center TMS with representative degradation severities and frequencies, and system uptime availability is computed. To explore the effects of degradation and system configuration on uptime availability, a series of parametric sensitivity studies are simulated while varying degradation frequency and component redundancy. Finally, an additional reliability metric, real-time compute capacity, is introduced, and its relevance is explained for data center TMSs that have component failures only applied to one or a few CPUs.

title: Hearing Material: Using Auditory Feedback to Induce Illusions of Material Perception in Virtual Reality
authors: Bocheng Zhong, Seungwoo Je, Marcel Zaes Sagesser
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Sound affects how humans perceive material when they physically interact with it. This paper examines how the use of dynamic auditory feedback in virtual reality (VR) can induce a sense of touching a material surface. We designed an interactive system with a 3D-printed PLA (polylactic acid) board, load cells, contact microphones, and three software algorithms that dynamically trigger auditory feedback upon users touching the PLA board. The system simulates four selected material surfaces, such as clay, by providing real-time auditory feedback made with pre-recorded audio of scratching the materials. A user study investigates the system’s effectiveness in enhancing the authenticity of material interaction in VR. The results demonstrate that dynamic auditory feedback significantly improves material perception in VR. Our research presents empirical evidence of sound as a substantial modality for multi-sensory interaction in VR, and we introduce a low-cost, scalable system for simulating material sensation.

title: Machine Learning-aided Classification of Edible Berries in Organic Agri-food Industries
authors: Srijita Bandopadhyay, Ritwika Mukherjee, Neepa Biswas, Suchismita Maiti, Soumen Banerjee
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: Edible berries play a significant role and have an expanding influence in the organic agri-food industries due to their nutritional value, health benefits and market demand. The versatility of edible berries is evident across industries such as jam, yogurt, beverage and bakery products with their application varying based on the type of berries. Hence, the classification of edible berries is a crucial task in the organic agri-food industries, demanding accurate and efficient techniques to distinguish between different types. The research explores a comparative analysis of classification of five different types of edible berries, namely tayberry, wineberry, blackberry, blueberry and white mulberry, through conventional machine learning classifiers. Data pre-processing was followed by feature extraction using pre-trained CNN models such as VGG16, ResNet50, and InceptionV3. The concatenated feature vectors were then used to train five machine learning classifiers, whose performances were evaluated using accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. Among the classifiers, SVM achieved the highest accuracy and consistently outperformed other models in precision, recall, and F1-score, making it the most reliable for edible berry classification.

title: Experimental Evaluation of Cooling System Failures in Commercial Photovoltaic Inverters
authors: Alan Marques Leal de Sousa, Geyciane Pinheiro de Lima, Diego Lucas de Carvalho Martinez, Arthur Ichiro Moreira Manabe, João Lucas de Souza Silva, Leandro Tiago Manêra, Tárcio André dos Santos Barros
abstract: Depending on the installation environment, photo-voltaic (PV) inverters may operate under conditions that restrict ventilation and hinder heat dissipation, potentially affecting their thermal and operational performance. The IEC 62109-1 and IEC 62109-2 standards establish criteria for testing under cooling system failures; however, experimental studies validating the effectiveness of thermal protection mechanisms remain limited. This study compiles relevant normative guidelines and presents experimental tests on a single PV inverter subjected to forced cooling failures. A dedicated test setup was developed, incorporating sensors for continuous monitoring of temperature and electrical parameters. This configuration enabled the assessment of the inverter's thermal behavior, the activation of protection systems, and its ability to limit temperature rise. Complete deactivation of the cooling fans resulted in a power derating exceeding 50 %, indicating an active thermal protection response. Similarly, the heatsink blanketing test induced power reduction, confirming the proper functionality of the protection mechanisms. The results provide insights for evaluating current standards and support the reassessment of criteria used in the certification of PV inverters.

title: Analysis and Solutions for Maloperation of Zero-Sequence Protection Caused by Intermittent Faults in Distribution Networks
authors: Tiejun Guo, Hongsheng Wang, Yahe Huang, Sirui Zhang, Kuo Zhang, Jing Xu, Botong Li, Xianyang Ke
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: This paper analyzes the maloperation of zero-sequence protection caused by intermittent discharges in 10 kV distribution networks and proposes effective solutions. The basic structure of the typical distribution system where the accident occurred was described, and the process of the accident development was clarified. The waveform characteristics of the actual recorded wave data were thoroughly analyzed to identify the causes of the fault and the maloperation of the zero-sequence protection. The differences in the zero-sequence current effective values calculated by the root mean square algorithm and the half-cycle integration algorithm are compared. The results show that using the half-cycle integration algorithm to calculate the zero-sequence current effective value can effectively reduce the risk of zero-sequence current protection alarms caused by intermittent discharge faults.

title: "When You Are the Plant": Encouraging Hydration Through Playful Virtual Reality Embodiment
authors: Yuchen Zheng, Ashlyn Doyle, Hongyue Wang, Jialin Deng, Don Samitha Elvitigala, Florian ‘Floyd’ Mueller
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Staying hydrated is essential, but maintaining water intake in daily life often lacks engaging feedback or personal motivation. We present PlantSelf, an interactive Virtual Reality (VR) system that encourages healthy hydration through playful embodiment. The system combines a capacitive-sensing straw, an ESP32-based wireless signal pipeline, and a mirror-based VR environment. Users see themselves in a virtual mirror as a "plant" that grows when they drink water. Real-time feedback links physical drinking action to virtual transformation, fostering intrinsic motivation. By merging sensing, self-representation, and metaphorical growth, PlantSelf aims to open new opportunities for turning hydration into an engaging, self-driven experience.

title: Isolated Full-Bridge DC-DC Converter Using Parallel Switches and Interleaved PWM for Electrolyzers in Green Hydrogen Production
authors: Joao Victor Teixeira Alves, Menaouar Berrehil El Kattel, Edilson Mineiro Sa Junior, Luiz Henrique Silva Colado Barreto, Demercil De Souza Oliveira Júnior, Fernando Luiz Marcelo Antunes, Paulo Peixoto Praça
abstract: This paper presents a study of an isolated fullbridge interleaved DC-DC converter with parallel switches and interleaved PWM, designed for water electrolyzers in green hydrogen production. The topology improves semiconductor loss distribution and reduces the volume and weight of passive components. It achieves high power density and low current ripple, with a ripple frequency four times the switching frequency, ensures galvanic isolation, provides high DC voltage gain based on the transformer turns ratio and duty cycle, and simplifies system design. Experimental tests were conducted with a DC bus voltage <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{d c}=380 \mathrm{V}$</tex>, electrolyzer voltage <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{V}_{\text{el}}=180 \mathrm{V}$</tex>, and a converter rated power of 2 kW. Results demonstrate that the converter is suitable for applications requiring a compact size and reliable operation under the dynamic conditions of renewable-energy-powered hydrogen production.

title: Fault Tolerant Data Driven Control Applied to a Six Arms Interleaved DC-DC Converter with an Adaptive PWM Scheme
authors: Paulo P. Praça, Davi C. Amorim, Wilkley B. Correia, Menaouar B. E. Kattel, Luiz Henrique S. C. Barreto, Demercil S. Oliveira
abstract: Interleaved DC-DC converters are widely adopted in power electronics due to their ability to deliver high output currents while evenly distributing electrical stresses. However, the multi-parallel switching branches along with a great number of inductors and capacitors elevate the modeling complexity due to the increase in the system's order and the number of stages. To overcome this challenge, data-driven control techniques, capable of designing nonlinear controllers directly from input-output data without a mathematical model, come as an indirect approach of the problem. In addition, maintaining robust operation under faults is critical, requiring fast fault detection with an adaptive system. This work proposes a control approach based on datadriven methods, integrated with a fault-tolerant PWM strategy. The methodology is implemented and experimentally validated in a simulation of a six arms interleaved DC-DC converter, demonstrating effective performance under fault scenarios.

title: Position Paper: Preparing XR Working Environments for the Industrial Metaverse Era
authors: André Stork
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: The vision of the Industrial Metaverse comprises integration of the physical and the virtual world and collaboration of multiple disciplines within and across companies as they are working in value creating networks [1],[2]. Vertical and horizontal integration-even beyond the borders of companies-poses new challenges for extended reality (XR) working environments. However, the Industrial Metaverse era also opens new potential for wider application of XR technology.This position paper discusses these two sides of the same medal and hints to research directions needing further exploration in the future to make XR workplaces an integral part of the Industrial Metaverse era.

title: Project LOCOMO AR: Augmented Reality with Carbon Metrics for Sustainable AI Use
authors: Somang Nam, Hyunggu Jung, Yunseo Moon, Chaeyoung Lee, Seilin Uhm
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: The rapid uptake of large language models (LLMs) has highlighted the considerable energy use and carbon emissions associated with inference, yet end-users remain largely unaware of these hidden costs. We present LOCOMO AR (LOwer COnsumption, More Optimization), an augmented reality application that integrates real-time computer vision, speech recognition and LLM reasoning with on-device visualization of the environmental footprint generated by each query. We demonstrate the system across assistive, cultural heritage, and healthcare scenarios. By integrating real-time estimates of carbon emissions, we offer a lightweight approach for promoting environmentally responsible AI use on consumer devices.

title: Design and Analysis of a GaN-Based Photovoltaic Microinverter Operating Up to 1 MHz
authors: Fellipe dos Passos Rosa, Rhuan Gustavo Beling, Mateus Constantino Orige, Julio Cesar Dias, Roberto Francisco Coelho, Lenon Schmitz, Telles Brunelli Lazzarin
abstract: This paper proposes a design approach for a photovoltaic flyback microinverter, focusing on the selection of low-loss components. The system operates with quasi-resonant control and a hybrid conduction mode strategy (DCM/BCM), with a variable switching frequency between 300 kHz and 1 MHz. GaN transistors, SiC diodes and superjunction MOSFETs were employed to reduce volume and losses. The obtained results validate the adopted operating strategy, demonstrating soft switching, near-unity power factor, low total harmonic distortion (THD) and estimated efficiency of 96.4%. Moreover, they support the effectiveness of the selected components for compact and efficient photovoltaic applications.

title: Measurement of the Digital Economy Development Level Using Hybrid Random Forest and ELM Methods
authors: Dengyin Kang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The digital economy and digital revolutions hold a prominent place in reshaping the global economic structures. This revolution encompasses the digital infrastructure and ecompass that fundamentally needs the innovations to change its consumption patterns. The conventional methods suffer from several bottlenecks such as inability to handle high-dimensional non-linear interactions and non-adaptability to the regional heterogeneity which fail to capture the complex and high dimensional data. Hence the intelligent framework is required for effectively identify the patterns in the digital infrastructure and innovating the economic patterns. To resolve this challenge, this paper proposes a novel ensemble of Random Forests and Extreme learning machines with the strong pre-processing techniques. The recommended approach comprises of four components like 1) Data Collection 2) Data-pre-processing 3) Hybrid Model Designs 3) Performance evaluation. The complete model was evaluated with Kaggles Digital economy datasets and performance was validated to identify the key indicators. Empirical validation demonstrates the model's superiority, achieving 97.5 % accuracy precision of 96.5 %, recall of 96.4 % and F1-score of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 7 \%}$</tex> for traditional methods, while providing interpretable insights for policy formulation.

title: Energy-Aware Multi-AGV Path Planning via Improved A* and Time-Window Coordination
authors: Weizheng Liu, Daiwei Li, Jun Lu, Yunchang Huang
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: To address inadequate energy optimization and redundant energy use in conflict resolution within multi-AGV path planning, this paper proposes an Energy-Aware Enhanced A* (EA-A*) algorithm. By explicitly modeling the relationship among load, motion state, and energy consumption, the algorithm establishes a quantitative energy consumption model. It further introduces dynamic weight coefficients to balance path length and energy cost and applies an energy-based classification strategy to achieve coordinated optimization across multiple AGVs. Simulation results indicate that the proposed method effectively reduces overall energy consumption with only a slight increase in path length, thereby supporting the efficient and low-energy operation of multi-AGV systems.

title: A Miniaturized 35uW Wirelessly Powered Chip for Implantable Neural Recording
authors: Iman Habibagahi, Roshan P Mathews, Hamid Jafari Sharemi, Aydin Babakhani
abstract: This work presents a miniaturized 35 uW wirelessly powered and controlled neural recording implant with an adjustable sampling rate. The analog front-end (AFE) has an input referred noise of 5.4 uVrms, an adjustable gain of 35-55 dB, and a bandwidth of (0.5-5 Hz) to 10 kHz. The AFE is followed by a 10-bit SAR ADC, serializer, and an UWB transmitter. The downlink for wireless power and data transfer operates at 40.68 MHz, while the UWB uplink uses 433 MHz, both within the Industrial, Scientific, and Medical (ISM) bands. The circular implant, with a diameter of 15 mm, successfully recorded biological signals while operating at a distance of 10 cm from the powering coil. Prerecorded action potential (AP) and electrocardiogram (ECG) signals, as well as live human electromyography (EMG) and electrooculography (EOG) signals, have been successfully recovered using the same fully wireless setup.

title: Prediction: Landslides and Floods Detection using Deep Learning Techniques
authors: R. Surekha, M. Giri, M. Kusuma, T. Naveena, E. Revanth Kalyan Gowd, N. Pavan Tej
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: Landslides and floods are frequently occurred in hill areas, it will damage the surrounding environment, loss of human lives, damage on infrastructure, health conditions, disturbed daily lifestyle, effects on transportation system, destroy crops, loss of properties, and many more. Predicting from landslides and floods is a one of the challenging tasks, early detection of such a disaster may help many peoples save their life, and the people who are living in that areas may shift to safe areas in advance.ML techniques like NB, SVM, LR, RF are used to predict landslides and floods, these methods perform well but there are these methods are not able to handle complex dataset and performance are also low when compared with DL techniques. In this research, we proposed a new approach to identify landslide and floods using deep learning techniques. Dataset flood.csv and GLC dataset are gathered from Kaggle data source. Experiments are carried out by using ML and DL techniques. Performance of ML and DL models are evaluated by using various metrics and the results RNN model shows better performance than conventional methods.

title: Multi-attribute Clustering Battery Sorting Method for Battery Energy Storage System
authors: Zhenyu Huang, Minda Shi, Yanglin Zhou, Baoping Ren, Chen Xu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Lithium-ion battery packs have the characteristics of high power and high energy density, and are widely used in electric vehicles and large-scale energy storage systems on the grid side. In order to obtain higher voltage and capacity, many battery cells are often used in series and parallel groups in practical applications. However, due to the differences in battery cell production and operating conditions, battery inconsistency is inevitable. Dynamical reconfigurable battery network (DRBN) technology provides a technical solution for battery cell-level control, which can achieve consistent sorting and reorganization based on battery difference status. This paper proposes an analysis method based on multi-attribute clustering of battery cells, completes multi-attribute standardized modeling and multi-attribute principal component analysis (PCA) dimensionality reduction analysis, and proposes a multi-period multi-attribute average modeling method based on time series information. During the experiment, the multi-attribute clustering method was verified based on the actual battery energy storage system operation data, and the battery sorting results were verified.

title: Comparative Analysis of Thresholding Methods on SAR Imagery for Diverse Water Body Conditions
authors: Aung Tayzar Phyo, Aung Myo Thu, Hline Htet Win
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: Flood mapping from Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) imagery is vital for disaster management and hydrological applications. Thresholding methods such as Otsu and Yen offer efficient separation of water and non-water pixels without ground truth or training data.
