This study evaluates their performance on Sentinel-1 imagery after radiometric calibration, speckle filtering, and geometric correction. A reference water mask derived from Sentinel-2 NDWI is used to assess the accuracy of the thresholding methods via Intersection over Union (IoU). Results show that Yen thresholding is effective under low water body conditions with skewed histogram distributions and also performs reliably in bimodal cases. Otsu achieves better performance in bimodal distributions but is less consistent when water extent is limited. Based on its superior performance, Yen thresholding method on VV polarization is selected for operational use. The key finding is that a method's efficacy depends directly on the backscatter distribution, which is influenced by the water proportion in an area. Overall, the study highlights the potential of thresholding-based methods as rapid and practical solutions for flood response.

title: Secure Authentication in IoT Devices Using Lightweight Multi-Factor Cryptographic Schemes
authors: Muhamed Ihsan, Chennaiah Madduri, Hari Suresh Babu Gummadi, Sudhakar. K, Muthulakshmi. D
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In this era of rapid expansion of Internet of Things (IoT) and its billions of connected devices operating on sensitive and non-sensitive information. Traditional cryptographic methods typically rely on heavy computation and operation by a central authority, which is not feasible in resource-constrained situations. Existing methods involve the use of multifactor schemes with mixed cascaded cryptographic primitives that are complex and carry high communication overhead, which may also compromise user privacy. This work proposes a Lightweight Authentication and Cryptography with Multi-Factor Authentication (LAC-MFA) framework, which evaluate on IoT dataset with healthcare sensor readings, environmental value monitoring, and logs of activity from devices. The Preprocessing steps included normalizing the data and removing noise to create a standardized, refined dataset that would be ready for analysis. Feature extraction is performed using statistical descriptors of normal traffic patterns and relevant contextual attributes to create compact authentication vectors. Finally, the LAC-MFA scheme performs two-factor authentication at gateway, produces dynamic session keys using lightweight hashes, and protects IoT data with Ascon AEAD encryption that provides confidentiality, integrity, and low computational overhead. The experimental results demonstrate that LAC-MFA achieves higher accuracy (98.77 %), precision (97.55 %), recall (98.45 %), and F1-score (98.76 %) than the existing model Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA).

title: Fault Diagnosis Method for Rolling Bearings Based on Continuous Wavelet Transform and Optimized Residual Network
authors: Xiaolong Cui, Xin An, Jie Hu
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: To address the issues in rolling bearing fault diagnosis where traditional methods fail to effectively extract bearing fault information and the receptive field of feature extraction by convolutional neural networks is limited by the size of the convolution kernel, an improved model combining continuous wavelet transform (CWT), axial attention (AA), and residual network is proposed. Firstly, the original signal is converted into a two-dimensional image through feature extraction using CWT, which can capture the high-frequency, lowfrequency, and temporal features of the signal simultaneously. Secondly, the generated two-dimensional image is concatenated with AA after passing through the first convolution layer of the residual network. AA processes the CWT image in both dimensions, preserving the long-range dependencies of the CWT image in the time and frequency dimensions, and avoiding the problem of limited receptive field of the local window in CNN. Finally, multiple residual blocks are used to further extract the deep features of the image, and the bearing faults are diagnosed by combining with the fully connected layer. The experimental results show that the CWT-AA-ResNet has high diagnostic accuracy and good generalization performance. The fault diagnosis accuracy rate can reach over 99% on the Case Western Reserve University dataset.

title: Immersive Blue Spaces: Developing a Mixed Reality Ocean Encounter to Improve Wellbeing in Adolescents and Young Adults
authors: Nina Fern
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: This research project investigates virtual blue spaces and their potential to positively affect human health. Blue spaces are defined as water-based outdoor environments, in this instance the focus is on natural water surface bodies, such as lakes, rivers, waterfalls, and the sea. Recent research has shown that activities in blue spaces can boost human wellbeing [1]. This project highlights art-based Mixed Reality (MR) spaces that mimic blue space environments or are inspired by them, and their potential to promote public health. These virtual blue spaces consist of a large-scale 270-degrees screen projection to create a virtual environment backdrop and digital elements that are displayed through an MR headset on pass-through mode to create an immersive environment and offer interactivity to users. User engagement is driven through exploration of the environment, narrative, and dance exercise. Further enhancement is achieved through spatial audio consisting of nature sounds and music. The project includes a series of user experience testing with a focus on emotional response/wellbeing, immersion, as well as embodiment/presence and risks of cybersickness.

title: Cross-Layer Security Assessment in IoT Ecosystems: Analyzing Vulnerabilities in the Zigbee Protocol
authors: Tolegen Aidynov, Saken Tleuberdin, Assel Nurusheva, Dina Satybaldina, Mamyr Altaibek, Zhandos Boranbay
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: The increasing integration of IoT devices in smart homes raises new security concerns, particularly around communication protocols such as ZigBee. In this paper, we propose a conceptual cross-layer security assessment model tailored for smart home environments, targeting vulnerabilities in firmware, network traffic, and user behavior. While the full multimodal framework remains under development, this study focuses on the implementation and evaluation of the network traffic analysis component. Using the UNSW-NB15 dataset, we validate a Random Forest-based anomaly detection method and demonstrate its strong performance in identifying suspicious traffic patterns, including potential ZigBee protocol attacks. Additional theoretical components, such as firmware analysis via entropy and API call extraction and user behavior modeling using graph neural networks, are outlined for future integration. The work highlights the feasibility of traffic-based detection and sets the stage for comprehensive, layered security analysis in resource-constrained IoT ecosystems.

title: Application of Deep Learning Techniques for Automatic Detection of Network Security Threats in Internet of Things Environments
authors: Tolegen Aidynov, Mamyr Altaibek, Saken Tleuberdin, Assel Nurusheva, Dina Satybaldina, Gulsipat Abisheva
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive investigation into the implementation of cutting-edge machine learning paradigms for fortifying cybersecurity on the Internet of Things (IoT) ecosystem, with a particular focus on two pivotal datasets: the extensively utilized IoT-23 dataset and the specialized CRAFTED—Cooja RPL Attack Framework Test and Evaluation Dataset. Employing empirical analyses of simulated cyber threats, this research constructs multiple machine learning models to predict and classify a wide spectrum of IoT attack vectors and parameters with enhanced precision. Through rigorous experimentation, we evaluate an array of deep learning architectures, including Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks and Residual Networks (ResNet), juxtaposing their efficacy against conventional machine learning models. The results showed that deep learning methods are good at identifying complex patterns in multidimensional data. However, traditional models such as Random Forest (RF) and Decision Trees (DT) have proven to be more efficient in terms of processing speed and classification accuracy in real time, making them the preferred choice for practical applications. The study also used methods for selecting features and adjusting model parameters, which significantly improved their accuracy. These approaches have provided useful technical insights and solutions for timely threat detection in IoT networks. The work carried out creates the basis for further research in the field of identifying cyber threats and anomalies, contributing to the development of reliable and intelligent cybersecurity systems.

title: Current-Sensorless MPPT Strategy Based on Inductor-Voltage Integration for Small-Scale Wind Energy Systems
authors: Murilo Paulo de Oliveira, Daiara Dyba, Michell Luiz Stiz, Alceu Andre Badin, Amauri Amorin Assef, Daniel Flores Cortez, Roger Gules
abstract: This paper proposes a maximum power point tracking (MPPT) strategy for small-scale wind energy systems that utilizes current estimation without the need for physical current sensors. The input current is obtained through digital integration of the voltage across the inductors of a three-phase dual interleaved boost converter operating in discontinuous conduction mode (DCM), a topology that enables a power factor close to unity without dedicated sensors. The estimated current is used to compute the instantaneous power, which feeds an MPPT algorithm based on the Perturb and Observe (P&O) method. Experimental validation was carried out using a 2 kW wind turbine emulator and a three-phase AC source under different load conditions. Experimental validation with a 2 kW FT-2000 turbine emulator and a three-phase AC source confirmed unity-close power factor and accurate sensorless current estimation, with input-power errors <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\leq 2.0 \%$</tex> relative to a Fluke Norma 4000. The MPPT tracked the maximum power point under different loads, converging to 198 W at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$40 \Omega, 160 ~\mathrm{W}$</tex> at 50Ω and 130 W at 60Ω, and maintaining stable operation over extended intervals. These results support eliminating physical current sensors while preserving accuracy, robustness, and reducing cost.

title: Interactivity of Virtual Reality Landscape Design Based on Computer Real Time Rendering Technology
authors: Jiaji Zhou, Jiabai Jin, Dongdong Jia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: This study employed a systematic approach to develop a virtual reality landscape design interactive system based on real-time computer rendering technology. First, a system framework was constructed based on the Unity3D engine, integrating multi-source geographic data and employing the WGS84 coordinate system for spatial data registration. Second, a quadtree-based Level of Detail (LOD) scene management algorithm was designed and implemented, optimizing rendering efficiency by dynamically adjusting the model's level of detail at different distances. GPU parallel computing technology was then used to achieve real-time rendering of large-scale terrain data, and physically based rendering techniques were employed to enhance the realism of materials. Finally, a gesture recognition module was developed based on Leap Motion, utilizing CNNs to accurately recognize a variety of basic gestures and designing a natural interaction mapping mechanism. In a test involving tens of millions of faces, the average frame rate was 45 fps, and the average response time for multi-gesture interaction was 90.5 milliseconds.

title: Research on the Status Monitoring Method of Nuclear Power Plant Speakers Based on Internet of Things and AI Technology
authors: Shen Zheng, Tingzhu Ju, Haopeng Zhang, Bowen Yuan, Yinwei Wu
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: The plant-wide broadcasting system in nuclear power plants plays a vital role in daily operations and emergency management, serving as an indispensable communication tool for issuing alerts, notifying personnel, and directing evacuations. However, the extensive distribution of loudspeakers across complex environments has long posed challenges for manual inspections, often leading to delayed fault detection that compromises information delivery and creates safety risks. Systematic speaker failures remain a key barrier to effective broadcast communication. The core objective of this research is to develop automated monitoring systems for loudspeaker operations, enabling timely identification of malfunctioning units. This ensures reliable and accurate message transmission to target audiences during routine operations, major maintenance, and emergency evacuation scenarios. This research integrates nuclear power industry information technology with acoustic monitoring expertise, leveraging rapidly evolving wireless communication technologies and the digital transformation trends in the sector. We propose an IoT and AI-based Speaker status monitoring system that constructs a distributed data collection network, designs standardized test sound sources, and employs advanced sound event detection, voiceprint similarity calculation, and Automatic Speech Recognitions to automatically assess speaker performance. The system evaluates operational status through comprehensive algorithm scoring. Analysis from wireless communication, safety redundancy, and algorithm robustness perspectives demonstrates its feasibility and effectiveness in real plant environments. Key innovations include: developing adaptive monitoring modules for high-noise, high-radiation conditions in nuclear plants; enhancing fault detection accuracy through multimodel fusion; and exploring predictive maintenance extensions via digital twin and edge computing concepts. This study not only provides engineering foundations for intelligent monitoring of nuclear power plant broadcast systems but also offers valuable references for health management of industrial acoustic equipment.

title: Domain-Specific Fine-Tuning of PubMedBERT for Neonatal Care Applications
authors: Tooba Ali Zahed, Bhupesh Kumar Mishra, Temitayo Matthew Fagbola
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: Integrating Artificial Intelligence (AI), particularly large language models (LLMs), into specialized medical domains like neonatology holds significant promise for enhancing clinical decision support, improving patient outcomes, and streamlining workflows. However, these models must possess extensive domain-specific knowledge and understanding of unique medical terminology. Despite recent advancements, current general-purpose and biomedical LLMs often fall short in capturing the critical nuances and contextual intricacies unique to neonatal care. This paper presents a comprehensive fine-tuning approach for adapting PubMedBERT specifically for neonatal care applications using structured and unstructured data from 57 international sources across six clinical categories. Our novel three-stage fine-tuning methodology transforms PubMedBERT into a neonatal specialist through progressive specialization: general adaptation, category-specific training, and knowledge integration. Empirical evaluation demonstrates that our fine-tuned model achieves 85.4 % clinical accuracy across six neonatal NLP tasks—a 22.6 % improvement over baseline PubMedBERT, while requiring only 18 GPU hours on a single NVIDIA A100. Analysis shows our 110M parameter model approaches the performance of models 1,000-5,000 times larger while requiring just 0.01% of their computational resources. This resource-efficient approach democratizes access to specialized medical AI, making advanced capabilities accessible to clinical environments with limited computational infrastructure.

title: A Dominant Broadband Oscillation Reduction Method Suitable for Grid-FORMING direct Drive Wind Farms
authors: Huifan Xie, Hongtao Liu, Yujia Tang, Qian Ma, Chao Luo
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: There is a risk of broadband oscillation when Grid-Forming direct drive wind farms for grid connection. In response to the issues of high model order and poor accuracy in preserving oscillation modes in this study, this paper proposes a dominant oscillation broadband oscillation singular perturbation reduction method based on participation degree singular values. Firstly, by analyzing the broadband oscillation modes and their damping characteristics of the full order small signal model, the extremely weak damping mode is determined as the reserved target; Then, by combining the contribution of the participating factors with the weight of Hankel singular values, the fast and slow state variables are divided; Finally, construct a reduced order small signal model in singular perturbation form. The results indicate that this method ensures a high degree of consistency in the dynamic characteristics of the system before and after order reduction, while ignoring the dynamic process of fast state variables and retaining the dominant broadband oscillation mode; The reduced order small signal model has the ability to analyze broadband oscillations that is highly consistent with the full order small signal model and electromagnetic transient model, and is suitable for the research of broadband oscillations in the grid connected system of matched grid type direct drive wind farms.

title: Adversarial VR: An Open-Source Testbed for Evaluating Adversarial Robustness of VR Cybersickness Detection and Mitigation
authors: Istiak Ahmed, Ripan Kumar Kundu, Khaza Anuarul Hoque
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Deep learning (DL)-based automated cybersickness detection methods, along with adaptive mitigation techniques, can enhance user comfort and interaction. However, recent studies show that these DL-based systems are susceptible to adversarial attacks; small perturbations to sensor inputs can degrade model performance, trigger incorrect mitigation, and disrupt the user’s immersive experience (UIX). Additionally, there is a lack of dedicated open-source testbeds that evaluate the robustness of these systems under adversarial conditions, limiting the ability to assess their real-world effectiveness. To address this gap, this paper introduces Adversarial-VR, a novel real-time VR testbed for evaluating DL-based cybersickness detection and mitigation strategies under adversarial conditions. Developed in Unity, the testbed integrates two state-of-the-art (SOTA) DL models: DeepTCN and Transformer, which are trained on the open-source MazeSick dataset, for real-time cybersickness severity detection and applies a dynamic visual tunneling mechanism that adjusts the field-of-view based on model outputs. To assess robustness, we incorporate three SOTA adversarial attacks: MI-FGSM, PGD, and C&W, which successfully prevent cybersickness mitigation by fooling DL-based cybersickness models’ outcomes. We implement these attacks using a testbed with a custom-built VR Maze simulation and an HTC Vive Pro Eye headset, and we open-source our implementation for widespread adoption by VR developers and researchers. Results show that these adversarial attacks are capable of successfully fooling the system. For instance, the C&W attack results in a 5.94× decrease in accuracy for the Transformer-based cybersickness model compared to the accuracy without the attack.

title: Designing Memory-Augmented AR Agents for Spatiotemporal Reasoning in Personalized Task Assistance
authors: Dongwook Choi, Taeyoon Kwon, Dongil Yang, Hyojun Kim, Jinyoung Yeo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Augmented Reality (AR) systems are increasingly integrating foundation models, such as Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs), to provide more context-aware and adaptive user experiences. This integration has led to the development of AR agents to support intelligent, goal-directed interactions in real-world environments. While current AR agents effectively support immediate tasks, they struggle with complex multi-step scenarios that require understanding and leveraging user’s long-term experiences and preferences. This limitation stems from their inability to capture, retain, and reason over historical user interactions in spatiotemporal contexts. To address these challenges, we propose a conceptual framework for memory-augmented AR agents that can provide personalized task assistance by learning from and adapting to user-specific experiences over time. Our framework consists of four interconnected modules: (1) Perception Module for multimodal sensor processing, (2) Memory Module for persistent spatiotemporal experience storage, (3) Spatiotemporal Reasoning Module for synthesizing past and present contexts, and (4) Actuator Module for effective AR communication. We further present an implementation roadmap, a future evaluation strategy, a potential target application and use cases to demonstrate the practical applicability of our framework across diverse domains. We aim for this work to motivate future research toward developing more intelligent AR systems that can effectively bridge user’s interaction history with adaptive, context-aware task assistance.

title: Semi-Supervised Deep Subspace Clustering for Hyperspectral Images
authors: Thomas Delaeter, Xianlu Li, Nicolas Nadisic, Aleksandra Pižurica
publish: 2025 13th European Workshop on Visual Information Processing (EUVIP)
abstract: Semi-supervised subspace clustering has achieved promising results in hyperspectral image (HSI) analysis by leveraging spectral structure with limited labels. However, most existing methods suffer from two key limitations. First, they separate feature learning and clustering, preventing joint optimization. Second, they rely on explicit self-representation matrices with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathcal{O}\left(n^{2}\right)$</tex> complexity, leading to significant memory and computation overhead. To address these issues, we propose an end-to-end semi-supervised deep subspace clustering framework tailored for HSI data. It unifies representation learning and clustering into a single trainable architecture, preserving contextual and subspace structures without computing large affinity matrices. The framework integrates cross-entropy loss, supervised contrastive learning, label-guided subspace modeling, and pseudo-label-based consistency regularization, enabling effective use of scarce labeled and abundant unlabeled data. Experiments on standard HSI datasets demonstrate that our method consistently outperforms existing unsupervised and semi-supervised clustering approaches under low-label regimes, illustrating the practical potential of semi-supervised deep subspace clustering for real-world HSI interpretation.

title: Rate of Thermal Energy Storage in Composite Phase Change Material Slabs
authors: Derian Morphew, Emmanuel Nwoye, Hyunji Park, Sophia Ahmed, Jonathan R. Felts, Choongho Yu, Patrick J. Shamberger
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Phase change materials (PCMs) are used to passively cool transient electromechanical systems by absorbing (releasing) heat over a narrow temperature range during the phase transition. Paraffins and salt hydrates, having large gravimetric and volumetric latent heats of fusion, are particularly well-suited for applications like heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) that demand efficient thermal management. However, even with large thermal capacitances, these materials are not commonly implemented at the system level due in part to their low gravimetric and volumetric power densities. One method to increase the rates of thermal energy charging (discharging) of these low thermal conductivity materials is to create a composite system, such as a thermally conductive porous network infiltrated with PCM. In this work, we report a comparative investigation of the heat transfer rates of a 3.50 mm thick paraffin-expanded graphite (EG) and salt hydrate eutectic-EG composite slab in a cold plate heat exchanger over 100 cycles. A custom flow loop setup is used to characterize the rate of heat transfer between the working fluid and PCM-EG composite slabs. Transient heat transfer is characterized for each material at temperatures $5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ above their melting points. This study demonstrates the improved thermal performance and system-level efficiency of PCM-EG composites, as well as their stability over hundreds of cycles. We observe similar thermal charge and discharge times for both PCM-EG composites, indicating that the heat storage rates are governed primarily by the conductive EG matrix and not the thermal conductivity of the PCM itself. Finally, we present the first reported heat absorption rate for a salt hydrate eutectic composite slab.

title: Development of an Offline Single-Phase UPS with Voltage Harmonics Suppression
authors: Eduardo Eller Behr, Julio Cesar Dias, Denizar Cruz Martins, Lenon Schmitz
abstract: This paper presents the design and validation of an offline single-phase Uninterruptible Power Supply (UPS) with enhanced voltage quality under non-linear loads. The proposed UPS utilizes a bidirectional Dual Active Bridge (DAB) DC-DC converter with a resonant CLLC network and a full-bridge DCAC inverter interfaced through an LCL+RC filter. A control architecture combining a Proportional Integral (PI) controller for DC bus regulation and a Proportional Multi Resonant (PMR) controller for harmonic compensation is implemented. The harmonic suppression strategy significantly reduces low-order voltage harmonics during islanded operation, thus improving power quality. Both simulation and experimental results demonstrate the working principle of harmonic compensation and effective voltage harmonic reduction. A phase synchronization scheme is also presented and validated with experimental tests by disconnecting and reconnecting the UPS on the grid.

title: Artificial Intelligence Algorithms in Intelligent Physical Fitness Training Platforms
authors: Lihong Zheng, Jianghao Chen, Aimei Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: While physical training is currently receiving significant attention in university student sports training, its effectiveness remains suboptimal. One of the key issues is the disconnect between many students' physical development and athletic ability. This paper examines the current state of physical training among university students in my country and explores approaches and strategies for improving their physical fitness. This research aims to identify a new path to scientific advancement in university student sports training: an intelligent physical training platform based on the particle swarm optimization algorithm. Experimental results demonstrate that, among the iterative approaches of the ant colony algorithm, the genetic algorithm, and the particle swarm algorithm, the particle swarm algorithm achieves the fastest performance. The PSO algorithm also converges quickly, reaching convergence at Epoch 20.

title: Human-Aware Inpainting for 3D Gaussian Splatting in Dynamic Scenes
authors: Pei-Ru Liao, Norihiko Kawai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Reconstructing 3D scenes from casually captured videos is common for virtualizing real environments. However, in crowded public spaces, human presence often degrades quality due to occlusions and artifacts. We present a human-aware 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) pipeline that reconstructs human-free scenes from real-world videos. Our method combines 2D inpainting with human detection, camera pose estimation using inpainted frames to avoid occlusion-induced errors, and masked training with guided pruning to suppresses residual artifacts while preserving scene quality. This enables high-quality, human-free reconstruction without requiring controlled capture conditions for MR/AR/VR applications.

title: An Embedded Device for Non-power Outage Retrofit of Bay Control Units in Substations
authors: Hang Chen, Min Zhang, Xi Hong, Yao Yin, Xu Yao
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: This paper proposes an embedded device for non-power outage retrofit of bay control units (BCU), addressing the challenges of prolonged downtime and operational inefficiencies in traditional substation automation retrofit systems. The operation process can be summarized as "connection, disassembly, connection and disassembly". During the seamless process, the functions of a BCU are not lost, and up to three BCUs in the bay panel can be replaced simultaneously. The functions of the proposed device were tested, and the accuracy requirements stated in the current standards for BCU were met. It was adopted for a 500kV hub substation automation retrofit system in Henan province and a 200kV one in Hebei province. This work provides a reliable solution for retrofitting substations of multi-voltage levels by making a non-outage retrofit for the BCUs, thus significantly improving the efficiency of power production.

title: Sensitive Data Protection Using AI: An Evaluation of Deep Learning and Metaheuristic-Based Leakage Prevention Techniques
authors: P S Saritha., R. Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Cloud-based services and digital information sharing have grown rapidly, which has raised the potential of sensitive data leaks in both personal and professional settings. It is frequently difficult for conventional rule-based and signature-driven Data Loss Prevention (DLP) systems to identify intricate and changing leakage patterns. A thorough analysis of Artificial Intelligence (AI)-based methods for successfully preventing sensitive data leaks is presented in this review paper, with an emphasis on Deep Learning (DL) and optimization models. DL techniques, such as transformer-based models, autoencoders, Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs), and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), provide strong capabilities for identifying anomalous behaviour and unauthorized data exposure by recognizing intricate patterns in unstructured and semi-structured data. To improve detection accuracy, optimize feature selection and fine-tune model parameters, metaheuristic optimization methods including Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), Dingo Optimization Algorithm (DOA) and Firefly Optimization Algorithm (FOA) are used concurrently. Leakage prevention frameworks that handle high-dimensional, heterogeneous data streams are now scalable and adaptive owing to the incorporation of various AI paradigms. Important issues including data privacy, adversarial attacks, interpretability, and regulatory compliance are also covered in this assessment. In order to create safe, intelligent, and privacy-preserving data environments, it concludes by outlining new developments and research prospects, such as federated learning, explainable AI, and lightweight AI models for edge-based DLP systems.

title: Integrating Explainable AI with Human-in-the-Loop Systems for Transparent Decision-Making in Autonomous Robots
authors: Vijaya Kumbhar, G. Sireesha, Varsha. D. Jadhav, Amit Barve, Rahul Sharma, Manzoore Elahi. M. Soudagar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: As autonomous robots become integral to complex applications such as healthcare, manufacturing, and disaster response, the need for transparent and interpretable decision-making has grown. This study explores the integration of Explainable AI (XAI) with Human-in-the-Loop (HITL) systems to enhance collaboration between humans and autonomous robots. The proposed framework incorporates XAI methods such as SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) and LIME (Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations) into HITL workflows, enabling real-time interpretability of robotic actions and decisions. Experimental evaluations conducted in a simulated robotic task environment demonstrate a 35% improvement in human trust, a 25% reduction in error rates, and a 20% increase in task efficiency compared to traditional autonomous systems. These results underscore the potential of XAI-enhanced HITL systems to achieve transparency, build trust, and facilitate robust decision-making in autonomous robotic systems.

title: Multi-Task Adversarial U-Net with Attention Gates for Brain Tumor Image Synthesis and Segmentation
authors: Jiten Kumar Mohanty, Ch. Sanjeev Kumar Dash, Jayashree Piri
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: Detecting early-stage brain tumor or minor abnormalities in MRI scans remains a significant challenge due to the subtle differences between healthy and diseased tissues. However, the availability of multi-modal MRI sequences, particularly FLAIR, is often limited due to acquisition constraints or patient condition. In this study, we propose a two-stage pipeline that synthesizes FLAIR images from T1-weighted MRI and subsequently performs multi-class tumor segmentation using an attention U-Net model. Using ground truth labels and common pre-processing and augmentation methods, the model is trained and assessed on slices from the BraTS 2020 dataset. Remarkably, the model achieved an SSIM score of 0.95, PSNR value of 32.6, MAE value of 0.02 and LPIPS with a value of 0.14, demonstrating strong performance on synthesis. In segmentation, the model has achieved a DSC score of 0.8799, 0.8867, 0.8544 and IoU score of 0.7954, 0.8187 and 0.8369 for ET, TC and WT respectively. The proposed GAN-based framework not only improves early detection capabilities but also proves to be a viable option when data availability is constrained.

title: A Personalized English Test Questions Resource Recommendation System Based on Deep Learning
authors: Yanru Li, Kemei Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The conventional English language assessments face significant and complex challeneges in providing the personalized learning experience due to non-adaptability nature of the individuals to learn its proficiency levels, learning patterns and cognitive preferences. To overcome this afforemntioned challenge, the paper presents the novel intelligent English test questions resource recommendation system that leverages hybrid deep learning techniques to deliver adaptive, individualized assessment experiences. The proposed multi-modal framework consists of Bi-GRU networks for capturing the short sequences of data patterns, Transformer based language model(BERT) for automatically assessing the question complexity including vocabulary, syntax and semantic related words. Finally the deep feed forward networks are proposed to classify the personalized student's ability forms. Experimental validation was conducted using a comprehensive dataset of 450,000 English language learner interactions across 10,000 test questions, encompassing proficiency levels from beginner (A1) to advanced (A3) according to the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR). Results demonstrate substantial improvements over conventional adaptive testing systems: 97.7% accuracy in difficulty level prediction, 96.3% precision in question-learner matching, and 87.6% learner satisfaction scores. The suggested research contributes to the advancement of intelligent learning systems and provides a scalable recommendation framework for personalized English language learning assessment that can be extended to other language learning domains.

title: Considerations on thermal analysis of inertial microsystems including microsensors and readout analog integrated circuit
authors: Jacek Nazdrowicz, Mariusz Jankowski
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: The paper continues to examine how the analog reading path of the MEMS accelerometer operates within the ASIC system. The study placed special emphasis on how temperature variations affect the useful output of digital data in the analog path of the ASIC system and its temperature dependence. The behavior of the system was examined using a new PCB with a QFN-100 socket, focusing on temperature-dependent values obtained from the ASIC’s analog-to-digital converter and the standard deviation reflecting noise. Physical modifications were also made to the system package to achieve better results with the influence of tiny packages on the stress caused by the socket. Statistical tools, particularly standard deviation, were employed in the analysis to demonstrate how the output from the analog-todigital converter changes with temperature.

title: Distance-Adaptive AR Navigation through UWB-ARMesh Fusion
authors: Yoshiyuki Ootani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We present an AR navigation system that integrates UWB positioning with real-time ARMesh environmental constraints for dual innovations: enhanced positioning accuracy through ARMesh-constrained filtering and distance-adaptive UI strategies. Our ARMesh-UKF fusion achieves 24.0% positioning improvement, enabling contextually appropriate interface modes: coordinate-based guidance (0-2.8m), area-based navigation (2.0-7.0m), and directional indicators (3.5m+). Evaluation across 19 valid experiments with 6,127 measurements validates effectiveness for practical AR navigation deployment.

title: A Data-Driven Intelligent Faults Identification Method for Power Grid Considering the Fault Characteristics of Inverter-Interfaced Renewable Energy Sources
authors: Li Zhang, Shengnan Li, Shoudong Xu, Xin Zhou, Shuyong Li, Qinlei Chen, Jiaze Yang
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: High proportion of renewable energy such as PV and PMSG are connected to the grid in the form of inverter-interfaced renewable energy source(IIRES), and their complex fault characteristics have a negative impact on traditional relay protection performance. Based on this, this paper analyzes the control strategy and fault current characteristics of inverter power sources, proposes a data-driven intelligent identification method for power grid faults that combines with Stacked Autoencoder (SAE) and Convolution Neural Networks (CNN) and Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU). On the basis of the traditional CNN-GRU model, the Stacked Auto-encoder embedded with a bisymmetric structure completes the capture and extraction of global features of information. Besides, the local perception, global extraction, update and reset, and accurate classification of fault features are realized in turn by the series network structure. The simulation results show that the proposed method has high identification accuracy and short running time, which can accurately and quickly realize fault type diagnosis and fault location identification.

title: Precision Marketing Strategies Driven by Intelligent Technology
authors: Huijuan Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Against the backdrop of the rapid development of intelligent technology, enterprise marketing faces problems such as complex data, unclear target customer positioning, and waste of marketing resources. This paper first explains the current status of precision marketing driven by intelligent technology, and then constructs a technical solution including automated data collection technology, precision advertising strategy, and market segmentation method. The research is carried out in the steps of background analysis, problem analysis, solution design, and experimental verification, aiming to solve the problems of low efficiency and poor effect of enterprise precision marketing. Through experimental investigation, it was found that the customer repurchase rate of enterprises using this technical solution was 15 % before implementation and reached 32 % after implementation, an increase of 17 percentage points, which verified the effectiveness of the solution.

title: Multiple Transmission Method for Wide-Area Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Cluster Inspection Data of Transmission Lines in Hybrid Network
authors: Xu Yuan, Yujun Yang, Yuqi Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: This paper adopts a dynamic network initialization method based on a combination of omnidirectional and directional antennas in a large-scale UAV formation reconnaissance environment. This method can be used to establish a network between large-scale UAV clusters and ground base stations, greatly reducing the workload of preplanning and initialization. In the communication model, the simultaneous transmission of multiple high-quality real-time images by inspection drones can cause network congestion, thereby affecting the imaging quality of the monitoring model. In severe cases, it can even cause distortion of the monitoring image, making it impossible for the inspection team to work normally. This paper adopts a refined automatic transmission line inspection model, which can compress the collected image data according to the current work requirements, thereby realizing multi-channel transmission of inspection data within a limited transmission bandwidth. The accuracy of this method for distribution line detection is 79%, and the false alarm rate is low at 3%.

title: Dynamic Analysis of Memristive Chaotic System
authors: Shu Peng
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: This paper proposes and designs a novel chaotic circuit based on the Wien-bridge system, and constructs the mathematical model of the circuit using the normalized parameter method. It analyzes the equilibrium points of the system and, combined with classical dynamic analysis methods such as bifurcation theory and Lyapunov exponent calculation, comprehensively investigates the dynamic characteristics of the system. During the analysis, several special phenomena are observed, including coexisting attractors and intermittent chaos, which are typical dynamic behaviors. Finally, hardware verification is performed on the system characteristics, realizing the transformation from the theoretical model to the actual circuit. The results demonstrate that this memristive chaotic circuit exhibits extremely rich and complex dynamic behaviors, providing a solid theoretical basis and data support for subsequent engineering applications.

title: Advancing MRI Super-Resolution with Generative Adversarial Networks
authors: Gaurav D. Tivari, Satvik V. Khara
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is a critical non-invasive imaging technique widely used in clinical diagnosis. However, the inherent limitations of acquisition time and hardware often restrict the spatial resolution of MRI, potentially impacting diagnostic accuracy. Super-resolution (SR) techniques have emerged as a promising solution to enhance image quality by reconstructing high-resolution (HR) images from low-resolution (LR) inputs. Among various deep learning approaches, Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) have demonstrated exceptional capabilities in learning complex data distributions and generating high-quality images. This paper presents a comprehensive review of GAN-based super-resolution methods applied to MRI. It systematically analyzes recent architectures, training strategies and evaluation metrics, while discussing critical challenges such as limited datasets, training instability and the need for clinical validation. Furthermore, it highlights the current research gaps and proposes future directions to enhance the integration of GAN-based SR techniques into routine medical imaging workflows.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Visionlanguage Model Based Trajectory Planning
authors: Yuchen Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: Vision-Language Models (VLMs) have shown promise in robot trajectory planning, but they often struggle with semantic-motion decoupling and long-horizon decision instability. To address these limitations, we propose a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework that integrates VLMs with end-to-end trainable motion planning. Our approach consists of: A high-level VLM-based policy that translates language instructions into semantic sub-goals, enhanced by cross modal attention alignment. A low-level RL controller (PPO-based) that generates executable trajectories while receiving hierarchical rewards. Key innovations include gradient propagation across layers and dense reward shaping to mitigate sparse reward issues. Experiments on the ALFRED benchmark show a 15.7% improvement in task completion rate compared to flat RL baselines, with 23% shorter path lengths in complex languageguided scenarios. Ablation studies validate the necessity of both hierarchical structure and VLM integration.

title: Model of a Soft-Open-Point for Utility Grid Applications
authors: Gustavo Viana Costa Teixeira, Hélio Marcos André Antunes, Sidelmo Magalhães Silva
abstract: The increasing penetration in distributed generation (DG) has highlighted the need for innovative devices that ensure greater robustness and operational flexibility in distribution networks. This paper addresses the modeling and control of Soft-Open Points (SOPs) as an alternative and promising solution to conventional interconnection switches. Details of the device topology, control scheme, and performance in representative distribution scenarios are presented. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the SOP in mitigating power quality issues and improving the fault-tolerant operation of distribution networks under the tested conditions.

title: A Hand-Gesture-Free Natural User Interface Using 3D Manipulator Widgets for Mixed Reality Surgical Applications
authors: Kwangtai Kim, Yejin Yoon, Seungho Lee, Kyu Eun Lee, Hyoun-Joong Kong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: In this study, we introduce a hand-gesture-free natural user inter-face for mixed reality (MR) surgical applications using a 3D manipulator widget. The system supports intuitive and precise control through a manipulator widget that dynamically aligns with the user’s head orientation and offers visual feedback for axis selection. Users can select a specific axis by gaze and perform discrete translation, rotation, and scaling operations via voice commands. Designed based on a thyroidectomy scenario, the interface supports both VR-based pre-operative training and AR-based intra-operative 3D registration. A pilot study (N=5) demonstrated the feasibility of the system, with all participants completing the task successfully, although some usability challenges were noted in rotation control and system feedback. These results highlight the potential of the proposed interface to enable precise 3D model manipulation in surgical environments where hand use is limited.

title: Design and Implementation of an Educational DC-DC Buck Converter
authors: Milton Brenner Machado Matoso, Rafael Concatto Beltrame, Fernanda De Morais Carnielluti
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of an educational platform for enhancing the teaching of power electronics and digital control systems. The proposed kit comprises of a DC-DC step-down (Buck) converter, an instrumentation and digital control module based on the STM32F103C8T6 microcontroller, and an isolated gate driver circuit for the power MOSFET switch. The primary objective is to provide a learning tool that bridges theoretical knowledge with practical application, providing a deeper understanding of converter operation and control algorithms. This platform is intended to support the academic development of engineering students through laboratory-based experimentation and real-time control implementation. Experimental results for open and closed-loop operation will be presented, with a simple compensator design to validate the hardware.

title: Comparative Analysis of Energy Management Strategies for Semi-Active Hybrid Energy Storage System Considering Aging Characteristics
authors: Jian Zhang, Xucheng Huang, Tao Zhang
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: The growing prevalence of PPLs in industrial and military applications, such as microwave weaponry, laser systems, and electric vehicles, poses significant challenges to power supply systems (PSSs) due to high instantaneous power demands and voltage stability issues. While hybrid energy storage system (HESS) combining batteries (BTs) and supercapacitors (SCs) offer a potential solution, their performance and aging behavior under dynamic loads remain inadequately addressed. This paper proposes a novel electro-thermal-aging coupled HESS model to accurately characterize system dynamics and aging effects under pulsed power load (PPL) conditions. Three control strategies— PID control, fuzzy logic control (FLC), and coordinated control (CC)—are designed and evaluated for system performance and aging mitigation.Simulation results demonstrate that the model effectively captures aging characteristics, with BT capacity decreasing from 2.5 Ah to 1.97 Ah and SC capacitance decaying from 198 F to 165 F. coordinated control achieves optimal system regulation with a settling time of 3.4 s and zero steady-state error, while fuzzy logic control mitigates BT aging, limiting capacity degradation to 0.0781 Ah. Coordinated control also minimizes SC capacitance degradation to 12.5921 F, outperforming other strategies. This study provides valuable insights for optimizing energy management and control of HESS, laying a foundation for future hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) validation and practical implementation.

title: Modeling and Techno-Economic Assessment of an Off-Grid Solar-Hydrogen Hybrid Energy System
authors: Puteri Nor Aznie Fahsyar, Jamal Alsheikh, Nohaidda Sariff, Denesh Sooriamoorthy, Intan Izafina Binti Idrus
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: This work successfully addressed the objective of optimizing a solar-hydrogen hybrid system for off-grid applications. Through MATLAB simulation, the study demonstrated that hydrogen production is highly sensitive to irradiance intensity, electrolyzer design, and PV configuration. The optimal design comprising 140 electrolyzer cells and a 130 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> separator area yielded 1.5 kg/day of hydrogen under standard irradiance with 30% system efficiency, outperforming several benchmarks from literature. The HOMER Pro analysis further confirmed that a PV-battery configuration, despite requiring higher initial capital, offered superior long-term cost benefits and environmental performance. With a payback period of 2.3 years and 100% renewable penetration, the PV-battery system proved more sustainable and economically viable than the PV-generator alternative. These results affirm the feasibility and scalability of the proposed hybrid system for sustainable hydrogen production in remote or grid-inaccessible areas.

title: Development of a Non-Invasive Sensor for Fault Detection in Induction Motors Based on Stray Magnetic Flux and Statistical Indicators
authors: Diego Greff, Wellington Rodrigo Gallo, Gustavo Valdatti Souza, Aline Durrer Patelli Juliani
abstract: Three-phase squirrel cage induction motors are extensively employed in the industrial sector; however, they are susceptible to malfunctions stemming from mechanical stress, environmental factors, and even natural aging. Early detection of motor faults is crucial for the prevention of critical failures while also maintaining its optimal functioning. This paper presents the condition monitoring of induction machines through the examination of stray flux by means of statistical indicators. A prototype composed of a coil-based magnetic transducer, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Sigma \Delta$</tex> ADC, and a microprocessor is used to capture the stray flux during the motor steady-state operation. Experimental results are obtained by testing the prototype against two motors of the same model, one of which is in good condition and the other has three broken bars. The statistical analysis revealed that the skewness of the signal was impacted by the rotor fault.

title: Block-Chain Based Certificate Issuance & and Verification
authors: Rahul, U Akshay Maiya, Annapurna D, Shashank S
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
abstract: This proposed work describes the design and development of a decentralized certificate issuing and verification system which is based on a private Ethereum blockchain. It utilizes React for the frontend, IPFS for storage and MongoDB for backend storage. The system verifies integrity, maintainability and availability of educational certificates, which enables safe dealings between customer/clients, master/servers, and administrators. The use of smart contracts and decentralized storages increases the user experience and modern web technologies provide tamper-proof records. The system also makes it possible to deliver via email and real-time verification through a dashboard.

title: Fabrication of Immunobiosensors by 2D Borophene-Induced Covalent and Oriented Immobilization of Antibody for Ultrasensitive Antigen Detection : 2D Borophene to achieve oriented immobilization of an antibody for better antigen-binding in Menstrual effluent
authors: Satheesh Natarajan, Ketan Dighe, Teresa Aditya, David Skrodzki, Purva Gupta, Pranay Saha, Nivetha Gunaseelan, Dipanjan Pan
abstract: Lateral flow immunoassays (LFIAs) are essential tools for the swift detection of clinically significant biomarkers, playing a vital role in point-of-care diagnostics. However, their effectiveness is often compromised due to the improper orientation of immobilized antibodies on nitrocellulose membranes, leading to diminished colorimetric signals. Enhancing the performance of LFIAs hinges on achieving precise antibody orientation, as correctly aligned antibodies exhibit superior antigen-binding capabilities compared to their randomly oriented counterparts. To address this issue, we employed borophene nanosheets—a two-dimensional nanomaterial—and functionalized them with antibodies using a photoinduced immobilization technique (PIT) to ensure optimal orientation. This method involves utilizing UV light to selectively break antibody disulfide bonds, revealing thiol groups that form stable covalent boron-sulfur bonds with the borophene surface. The resultant densely packed antibody layer maintains antigen-binding activity and enhances target interaction. We tested the effectiveness of this approach by applying antibody-coated borophene nanosheets onto a nitrocellulose membrane, creating a portable lateral flow assay aimed at detecting HMGB-1—a potential biomarker for endometriosis—in menstrual effluent. The assay delivered results in under 10 minutes and achieved a detection threshold of 40 pg/mL, markedly improving upon the sensitivity of traditional LFIAs. Specificity tests confirmed no cross-reactivity with common blood proteins such as albumin, fibrinogen, and gamma globulin, underscoring the assay's reliability and clinical relevance. This testing platform can also be adapted to identify other analytes, indicating its potential applicability across various women's health-related conditions that currently lack adequate diagnostic tools.

title: Adaptive Multi-AGV Scheduling With Enhanced A* Algorithm for Dynamic Warehouse Environments
authors: Yunchang Huang, Weizheng Liu, Jun Lu, Houfeng Tang
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: With the deepening of Industry 4.0 and the rapid development of intelligent manufacturing, Automatic Guided Vehicle (AGV) systems are becoming increasingly common in warehousing and logistics. However, most existing AGV scheduling algorithms are limited to optimizing single point transportation paths and are difficult to adapt to dynamic warehouse environments, often leading to congestion during peak hours and reducing overall system efficiency. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a three-stage dynamic path planning algorithm for adaptive AGV scheduling optimization. During the system startup phase, a priority based queuing algorithm is adopted to effectively prevent congestion at key nodes such as warehouse entrances and sorting areas. During the system operation phase, an open path algorithm was designed to guide AGVs to prioritize selecting routes with wider roads, reducing the risk of congestion in narrow passages. During idle or low traffic periods, applying temporary parking algorithms enables AGVs to automatically calculate and park in the least likely locations to cause congestion, thereby improving resource utilization. The experimental results show that compared with the traditional A * algorithm, the proposed three-stage dynamic path planning algorithm achieves average transportation time, reduces congestion rate, and improves overall system throughput in a dynamic warehouse environment. This study provides an innovative solution for AGV scheduling in intelligent warehousing logistics, which has significant practical value.

title: Thermal performance of liquid cooled and air cooled thermal ground plane-based battery thermal management systems for a high-power density Lithium-ion battery
authors: Arthur S. Labalte, Amrid Amnache, Alihossein Nihkkah, Nooshin Karami, Luc G. Fréchette
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: This work evaluates the performance of two battery thermal management systems (BTMS) based on thermal ground planes (TGP) in fast charging and high C-rate operation. The battery module considered consist of a matrix of cylindrical Li-ion cells sitting on four TGPs (also referred to as 2D flat heat pipe) for bottom-cooling. Heat is removed from the TGPs by coupling its extremity with a heat sink (air cooled) or a cold plate (liquid cooled). The battery module of 1.3 kWh is experimentally cycled with 0.7 C charge rate, 1 C and 2 C discharge rate in a CC-CV protocol. The thermal performances of the two heat-dissipation configurations are evaluated based on cell averaged temperatures, in-cell temperature differences and in-module temperature differences. The two systems showed comparable performances regarding the maximum cell averaged temperature. During the 2 C discharges, the maximum cell-averaged temperatures are $50^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $54^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ for air cooling and liquid cooling respectively, while the maximum in-module temperature difference are $8^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ respectively. These maximums all happen at the end of the CC phase of the cycling. This experimental work concludes that fast charging and high-power operation can be sustained with the use of TGPs. Also, given the comparable performances of the two heat dissipation configurations and the ease of implementation of air cooling, thermal ground planes can make air cooling a viable option in commercial electrical vehicle batteries.

title: Characterization of the Anand Model Parameters of SAC305 Lead Free Solder with Various Levels of Damage
authors: Golam Rakib Mazumder, Mahbub Alam Maruf, Souvik Chakraborty, Omma Sumaiya, Jeffrey C. Suhling, Pradeep Lall
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Solder joints in electronic packages are prone to fatigue failures due to mismatches in the thermal expansion coefficients during fluctuating temperature environments. In our previous works in ITherm 2022 and ITherm 2023, we showed that total energy dissipation that had occurred in the solder ($W=$ sum of $\Delta \mathrm{W}$ for all cycles) could be used as a governing degradation parameter, which is independent of the damage level applied during each cycle. Then, we identified a scalar damage parameter, $\mathrm{D}=\mathrm{D}(\mathrm{W})=0 \leq \mathrm{D} \leq 1$ using damage mechanics approach. This scalar damage parameter, D, can be used to accurately predict the observed material property degradations occurring during cyclic loading. The Anand viscoplastic constitutive model is often used to model solders as a part of FEA based reliability predictions for electronic packages. In our previous studies, we investigated the evolution of the Anand constitutive model in relation to thermal aging. However, the impact of mechanical cycling on the evolution of Anand model parameters has remained unexplored. Thus, understanding how cyclic damage influences the Anand parameters is crucial for accurately predicting the long-term reliability of solder joints, especially in environments where both thermal and mechanical stresses are present. In this study, we investigated the evolution of Anand model parameters as a function of the damage parameter, D. Four damage levels were considered ($\mathrm{D}=0.00,0.10,0.15$, and 0.20). Small uniaxial cylindrical samples of SAC305 solder were prepared by melting alloys, followed by a reflow solidification technique to attain joint-like microstructures. The samples were then subjected to mechanical cycling corresponding to each damage level. To assess the material’s response of the damaged specimens, uniaxial tensile tests were conducted across a range of strain rates $\left(\dot{\varepsilon}=0.001,0.0001\right.$, and $\left.0.00001 \mathrm{sec}^{-1}\right)$, and temperatures ($25,50,75,100$, and $125^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$). For each level of damage parameter D, a comprehensive test matrix of 15 combinations of strain rates and temperatures was developed, and tensile tests were performed on 10 samples per combination. The variations in Anand model parameters with damage due to mechanical cycling were characterized, and empirical relationships were established to model these changes. This study provides key insights into how mechanical damage affects the evolution of Anand parameters and contributes to more accurate constitutive modeling of solder materials.

title: AI-Driven Career Development: LLM-Powered Voice Interviews and Interactive Roadmap Generation for Student-to-Workforce Transition
authors: Hpone Khant Naing, Htet Myet Zaw, Aung Kaung Myat, Htet Paing Linn, San Myat Min, Chit Ko Ko Aung, Aye Chan Mon
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: AI-based platform functions as a solution to bridge educational-to-workplace readiness gaps through customized career development plans and interactive skill improvement activities. The system incorporates two essential operational components. The system delivers real-time voice-based mock interviews through AI-driven Interview Preparation that utilizes large language models (LLMs) along with automatic speech recognition and text-to-speech synthesis; the Smart Career Roadmap Builder allows users to manage skill acquisition through an interactive drag-and-drop interface supported by AI recommendations. The platform delivers an optimized user experience through AI-powered content generation and intelligent feedback. The system proves its reliability through comprehensive evaluation from testing with 95% accuracy in speech transcription (Deepgram Nova 2), 94% accuracy in conversational agent consistency (Claude Sonnet 4), and 92% accuracy in feedback quality assessment (Gemini 2.0 Flash Lite). The system provides learners with intelligent recommendations and structured feedback and dynamic visualization which helps them make confident workforce transitions.

title: Adaptive Augmented Reality Pathfinding for Parkinson’s Disease: Integrating Visual Cueing with User-Directed Navigation
authors: Dimah Bassal, Daniel Medeiros
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Parkinson’s disease (PD) affects millions worldwide, with gait impairments and freezing of gait (FOG) episodes representing debilitating symptoms that significantly compromise patient mobility, safety, and quality of life. Recent advances in augmented reality (AR) have demonstrated that visual cueing can effectively modify gait parameters in PD patients, with AR cues proving as effective as real-world cues for improving step length, gait speed, and crossing maneuvers. However, existing AR cueing systems, including applications like Holocue, rely primarily on static, pre-positioned cues or continuous cueing paradigms that require patients to adapt to predetermined patterns, poten- tially limiting patient autonomy and confidence in independent navigation. This paper presents a novel adaptive AR pathfinding system that integrates established visual cueing principles with user-directed navigation to enhance both therapeutic effectiveness and patient autonomy.

title: Hybrid Recurrent Neural Network Framework for the Deformation Prediction of Deep Foundation Pit Support
authors: Yanan Tang, Zhongliang Zhang, Qinyuan Xu, Wei Yang, Min Dou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The deep foundation of pits poses a serious hazard to every nation since it handicaps the smooth running of daily life of people. Among several methods, deep Foundation pits on the roads are considered to have more impact on the automobile and passengers since it may even turn to a major accident. Hence the several research has been brightened on the Foundation pits detection and intended to explore the intelligent systems for better identification of deep Foundation pits in the road scenario. With advent of deep learning models, the pits detection has taken a new dimension of detection but the computational complexity and overhead of these algorithms has prevented in deploying in the real time environment with the low accuracy of detection. To solve this problem, this paper offers a novel computational aware deep learning model on ensemble combination of bi-directional gated recurrent networks (BiGRU) and Attention maps. The implementation of the presented a deep learning model. Further, the intensive experimentation carried out using Kaggles' Pit Exacvation datasets, performance metrics are evaluated and analysed. To demonstrate the excellence of the proposed model, performance of the model is compared with the other traditional deep learning architecture results demonstrates effectiveness of the proposed model achieving accuracy of Deformation Prediction of Deep Foundation Pit Support is 99.7%. From the experimental results it is found that proposed model performed well than other models in terms of enables this proposed model to be implemented for real time Deformation Prediction of Deep Foundation Pit Support.

title: Automated Data Transfer Between Virtualized Advanced Driver Assistance Systems and in-Vehicle Infotainment Domains Over Data Distribution Service
authors: Ramakrishna Oggu, Megha S. Kumar, Prasad Patil
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
abstract: The growing integration of Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS) and In-Vehicle Infotainment (IVI) in modern vehicles introduces challenges in achieving reliable, real-time inter-domain communication. Traditional architectures often segregate these domains due to differing system requirements and constraints. This study presents a DDS (Data Distribution Service) based communication framework for secure and efficient data transfer between virtualized ADAS and IVI domains. Leveraging a publish-subscribe model within a hypervisor based virtualized environment, the proposed system enables low-latency, decoupled communication between domainspecific applications. Experimental evaluation using Fast DDS demonstrates communication between domains and validating the system's suitability for time-sensitive automotive applications. The architecture supports future zonal SDV designs, reduces hardware redundancy, and facilitates integration of safety and user interaction functionalities across domains.

title: Design and Implementation of Power Line Communication among Distributed H-bridges in a Cascaded Multilevel Converter
authors: Linchong Xu, Xing Zhang, Wei Zhao, Jun Xu, Jiacai Zhuang
abstract: In distributed cascaded multilevel converters, communication between converter modules is crucial for enabling distributed control. The most cost-effective approach for this communication is utilizing the series-connected power line. However, switching noise generated by the converter modules significantly disrupts the communication channel, posing challenges to achieving reliable transmission. This paper proposes a Power Line Communication (PLC) design method specifically tailored for converter modules operating in noisy environments. In each module, a Differential Balanced Bridge (DBB) structure is implemented to suppress noise, thereby enhancing the Signal-to Noise Ratio (SNR) of the PLC and enabling fast, low-latency communication. A system channel model is developed to analyze the transmission gains of both noise and signal, facilitating a comprehensive SNR evaluation. Finally, a prototype system consisting of eight H-bridge converter modules is constructed to demonstrate the practicality and effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Wireless Video Semantic Communication with Decoupled Diffusion Multi-frame Compensation
authors: Bingyan Xie, Yongpeng Wu, Yuxuan Shi, Biqian Feng, Wenjun Zhang, Jihong Park, Tony Q.S. Quek
abstract: Existing wireless video transmission schemes directly conduct video coding in pixel level, while neglecting the inner semantics contained in videos. In this paper, we propose a wireless video semantic communication framework with decoupled diffusion multi-frame compensation (DDMFC), abbreviated as WVSC-D, which integrates the idea of semantic communication into wireless video transmission scenarios. WVSC-D first encodes original video frames as semantic frames and then conducts video coding based on such compact representations, enabling the video coding in semantic level rather than pixel level. Moreover, to further reduce the communication overhead, a reference semantic frame is introduced to substitute motion vectors of each frame in common video coding methods. At the receiver, DDMFC is proposed to generate compensated current semantic frame by a two-stage conditional diffusion process. With both the reference frame transmission and DDMFC frame compensation, the bandwidth efficiency improves with satisfying video transmission performance. Experimental results verify the performance gain of WVSC-D over other DL-based methods e.g. DVSC about 1.8 dB in terms of PSNR.
