title: Automated Corrosion Feature Matching Based on In-Line Inspections Using Point Pattern Alignment and Proximity–Overlap Optimization
authors: Mohamad Shatnawi, Péter Földesi
abstract: Corrosion is a leading cause of pipeline failures, responsible for up to a third of reported incidents. Given the extensive length and limited accessibility of pipelines, operators rely on frequent in-line inspections (ILIs) to detect and quantify corrosion defects. Feature matching between successive ILIs is therefore utilized to align and compare this data, enabling the identification of corrosion evolution and behavior. However, measurement uncertainties, nonuniform corrosion growth, and spatial interactions between adjacent defects pose significant challenges in achieving accurate matching. This study proposes a two-phase feature matching model designed to address these limitations. The first phase performs Iterative Closest Point (ICP) alignment with a context-aware nearest neighbor selection strategy based on Directional Epsilon Neighborhood Clustering (DENC) to isolate stable feature pairs and minimize ambiguous associations in densely clustered defect regions. The second phase applies a novel proximity–overlap-informed correspondence optimization using linear programming to identify matches and outliers by jointly considering feature positioning and geometric attributes. The model’s effectiveness is evaluated on a 1116 m subsea pipeline segment involving two consecutive inspections reporting 1305 and 1491 features, respectively. Compared to three state-of-the-art models, the proposed approach achieves a recall, precision, and F1 score of 99.2%, demonstrating substantial improvements in accuracy, stability, and robustness to inspection and corrosion-related uncertainties. These results confirm the model’s ability to address critical limitations in existing approaches and underscore its potential to enhance pipeline integrity assessments.

title: A Novel Transformer Model Enhanced by Scaled-CNN and Bi-LSTM Hybrid Networks for Real-time Threat Identification within SCADA Systems
authors: Xiaochun Yin, Lin Zhang, Zengguang Liu, Junjie Qiu, Cuiying Wang
abstract: Modern Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems are essential for industrial automation and infrastructure monitoring, yet they confront escalating cybersecurity risks due to Internet of Things (IoT) integration. Their inherent vulnerabilities, such as insecure real-time protocols and endpoint-only protection mechanisms, result in traditional general-purpose network security solutions providing only partial safeguarding of data and traffic. To mitigate these weaknesses, a four-engine architecture featuring a self-adaptive PCA selector for automated feature filtering is first proposed. Subsequently, the novel Transformer model enhanced by Scaled-CNN and Bi-LSTM hybrid networks (Trans+scaled-CNN&bi-LSTM) is proposed, which combines spatial feature extraction by the Scaled-CNN, temporal pattern learning by Bi-LSTM, and dynamic weight optimization by Transformer for intrusion detection. Finally, this integrated approach is validated on SCADA-specific datasets, achieving an Accuracy of 99.14% and a Loss value of 0.0335. And the comparative and ablation experiments confirm the methodology’s superiority in real-time threat identification within SCADA systems.

title: Improved Machine Learning for Multiclass Fault Classification in Industrial Processes
authors: Khaled Dhibi, Radhia Fezai, Nour Basha, Gasim Ibrahim, Hanif A. Choudhury, Mohamed S. Challiwala, Byanne Malluhi, Hazem Nounou, Nimir Elbashir, Mohamed Nounou
abstract: Multiclass fault classification in complex processes is challenging due to many classes, nonlinear dynamics, overlapping fault signatures, and expanding fault taxonomies. Traditional machine learning models often struggle in such settings. The goal of this paper is to develop a model-agnostic, extensible framework. The proposed methodology aims to boost any base classifier via optimization, interval-based feature selection, and intelligent binary decomposition. By restructuring a multiclass task into hierarchies of binary subproblems and linking each boundary to automatically selected statistical features, the developed method improves diagnostic accuracy and generalization. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate improved performance compared to existing methods, achieving a high accuracy rate. Although the approach increases the computation time, the notable improvements in accuracy make the balance between precision and computation time advantageous for real-world use.

title: Low-Loss Extraction and Accurate Super-Resolution Localization for Extremely Weak Signals in High Dynamic Multi-Source Signals
authors: Zhexian Liu, Shuai Shao, Zizhuo Zhao, Jiaqi Wei, Hongwei Liu, Tao Su
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Weak signals often correspond to targets of interest in high-dynamic target detection scenarios. Low-loss extraction and accurate localization of these weak signals are critical for subsequent signal processing. In multi-source, multi-domain overlapping scenarios with a high dynamic range, precise extraction requires highly accurate amplitude estimation, as even minor errors in strong-source amplitude estimation can obscure extremely weak targets. However, existing algorithms focus primarily on parameter estimation in the space, time, and frequency domains, while neglecting precise amplitude estimation in the energy domain. This leads to insufficient strong-source cancellation and hinders the effective extraction of extremely weak signals. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a method for low-loss extraction and super-resolution localization of extremely weak signals and all multi-source signals simultaneously in high-dynamic scenarios. The key contributions are as follows: 1) An accurate super-resolution reconstruction and localization algorithm for multi-source signals in overlapping domains. It integrates Bayesian inference and least squares (LS) estimation under multiple measurement vector (MMV) model, achieving signal amplitude estimation performance approaching the Cramer-Rao Lower Bound (CRLB). A Generalized Beta Mixture (GBM) is employed as a sparse prior to further improve reconstruction accuracy, and fixed-point iteration for parameter updates accelerates convergence. 2) A framework for low-loss extraction and super-resolution localization of extremely weak signals. This framework overcomes the limitations of traditional sparse reconstruction approaches in high-dynamic scenarios. The proposed method exhibits robustness to various signal types, capable of separating, reconstructing, and localizing multi-source signals with diverse form of waveforms and energy distributions, demonstrating strong potential for practical applications.

title: Range Deception Interference Recognition and High-Speed Target Integration Detection Method for Multistatic Radar System
authors: Wei Li, Xiaolong Li, Fan Yang, Guolong Cui
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: The high-speed and stealth characteristics of target and the strong spoofing of deception interference are two significant factors that affect the target detection performance of multistatic radar system. In response, this study considers the problem of range deception interference (RDI) recognition and high-speed target integration detection in multistatic radar system. Firstly, the target echo model under RDI environment is established based on the range history model. Then, the intra-channel coherent integration of the echoes after pulse compression is realized by Radon Fourier transform (RFT). Next, the entropy circulation matching (ECM) algorithm is proposed to accomplish the multi-channel coherent integration, while obtaining the estimated location values of the target and RDIs in different channels. Further, the location values are processed by elliptic positioning (EP) to realize the recognition of the target and RDIs. Finally, simulation experiments verify the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed method, and the effect of factors such as multiple targets scenario, jamming-to-signal ratio and pulse number on the performance of the method are covered.

title: $\mathsf {RobustHealth}$: Non-Interactive Privacy-Preserving System for Heterogeneous Mobile Health Diagnosis
authors: Hongbo Jiang, Zhengliang Jiang, Wenjuan Tang, Yong Xie, Mengyuan Wang, Wenbin Huang, Ting Ye
abstract: The mobile health (mHealth) system, leveraging mobile edge computing, can monitor health status and provide diagnosis. However, due to the privacy of medical data and the resource limitations of mobile devices, patients are unable to access diagnostic services provided by untrusted servers in real-time. Existing schemes present significant challenges in private heterogeneous data aggregation, model training and inference in the presence of malicious participants, and expensive resource consumption. To address these issues, in this paper, we propose a non-interactive privacy-preserving system with the naive Bayesian model, i.e., <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathsf {RobustHealth}$</tex-math></inline-formula>, for heterogeneous mHealth diagnosis. Specifically, we extract homogeneous features from heterogeneous datasets to enable efficient encrypted aggregation. We propose a novel private model training algorithm with enhanced security to against collusion-then-differential attacks. We develop a novel non-interactive private model inference algorithm using minimal lightweight cryptographic primitives, designed for patients under unstable network environments. We provide formal security proofs for our system using the Universal Composable (UC) framework. To validate the performance of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathsf {RobustHealth}$</tex-math></inline-formula>, we conduct extensive experiments on real-world heterogeneous datasets, and compared with related works. The results demonstrate a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\bf {4.37\%}$</tex-math></inline-formula> improvement in model accuracy, along with significant reductions in computational and communication overheads of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\bf {21.18\times }$</tex-math></inline-formula> and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\bf {4.24\times }$</tex-math></inline-formula>, respectively.

title: An Efficient Autofocusing Technique for Through the Wall Radar Imaging
authors: Akhilendra Pratap Singh, Vineet Singh
abstract: In through the wall radar imaging systems, accurate knowledge of wall parameters such as thickness and dielectric constant is essential for producing well-focused images of targets behind walls. In practice, these parameters are often unknown, and using incorrect values during image reconstruction can cause target displacement, blurring, or smearing. Autofocusing is an image formation process with unknown wall parameters that iteratively adjusts parameters based on a focus evaluation function until the image with the optimal focus is achieved. The process typically involves the selection of discretized values from the equal interval ranges of wall thickness and the relative permittivity, forming parameter pairs. For each pair, a radar image is reconstructed and assessed using a focusing metric, with the image corresponding to the optimal metric selected as the final focused result. However, conventional autofocusing methods are computationally intensive due to their exhaustive iterative search, which hinders their real time use. To overcome this, we propose an efficient autofocusing algorithm that applies a criterion to select fewer parameter pairs based on the wall parameter range, thereby reducing the number of iterations and complexity. Experimental validation demonstrates that our method produces high-quality focused images with significantly lower computation time, even when wall parameters are initially unknown.

title: RoboPacker: An Autonomous Robotic Packing System for General Objects_supp1-3633306.pdf
authors: Haibin Yan
abstract: In this paper, we propose an autonomous robot packing system named RoboPacker designed to tightly store cluttered general objects into shipping boxes with high space utilization, which is a fundamental process in numerous industrial applications. However, achieving tight packaging for general objects often demands significant labor from human packers, particularly in high-throughput scenes. Compared to existing robot packing approaches, RoboPacker effectively overcomes challenges such as diverse object appearances, severe occlusion, and crowded packing spaces. Specifically, we propose an open-vocabulary shape estimation method to reconstruct complete point clouds for cluttered objects. We also design effective interactions with object clutter to gather informative visual clues for shape estimation under high uncertainty. Additionally, we introduce a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework to optimize packing order, location, and orientation for maximum space utilization. The robotic packing system integrates these techniques with feasible manipulation methods for real-world implementation. In this way, RoboPacker achieves efficient packing of novel and irregular objects, which is more suitable for real deployment environments. The Real-world experiments demonstrate RoboPacker can tightly pack 20 densely cluttered everyday objects from 8 seen and 4 novel classes into the 40×40×20 cm shipping box with a 73.3% success rate. The demonstration video can be found at https://gary3410.github.io/RoboPacker/.

title: Stabilization of Switched Affine Systems With Dwell-Time Constraint
authors: Antonio Russo, Gian Paolo Incremona, Patrizio Colaneri
abstract: This paper addresses the problem of stabilization of switched affine systems under dwell-time constraint, giving guarantees on the bound of the quadratic cost associated with the proposed state switching control law. Specifically, two switching rules are presented relying on the solution of differential Lyapunov equalities and Lyapunov-Metzler inequalities, from which the stability conditions are expressed. The first one allows to regulate the state of linear switched systems to zero, whereas the second one is designed for switched affine systems proving practical stability of the origin. In both cases, the determination of a guaranteed cost associated with each control strategy is shown. In the cases of linear and affine systems, the existence of the solution for the Lyapunov-Metzler condition is discussed, and guidelines for the selection of a solution ensuring suitable performance of the system evolution are provided. The theoretical results are finally assessed by means of three examples.

title: Optimizing Ad Spend: Using Predictive Models for Targeted Social Media Advertising
authors: Thin Yanant, Hlaing Htake Khaung Tin, Than Than Nwe
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: Since social media platforms, such as Facebook, are growing so quickly, digital advertising has become a highly data-driven ecosystem. Optimizing return on investment (ROI) and reducing wasteful advertising spending are two challenges that businesses face. A/B testing and manual adjustments are two examples of traditional campaign management techniques that are frequently reactive and ineffective. This paper investigates the use of predictive models to make proactive, data-driven decisions that maximize Facebook advertising spend. The proposed framework analyzes demographic, behavioral, and psychological data to forecast user engagement and conversion probabilities using machine learning techniques such as logistic regression, decision trees, and neural networks. To make sure that resources are focused on the most promising leads, the predictive insights are then used to adjust budget allocations across audience segments. According to a case study, predictive modeling can enhance click-through rates (CTR) and conversion performance while cutting advertising waste by as much as 30%. According to the results, this predictive strategy performs noticeably better than traditional methods, giving businesses a distinct competitive advantage as well as more accurate targeting and improved campaign efficiency. For researchers and marketers looking to use predictive analytics to improve social media advertising strategies, this study provides useful insights.

title: Secure Data Hiding in HTML Files using the Combination of Cryptography and Steganography
authors: Lwin Mar Thin
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: Information security has always been a key component in preventing unauthorized access, deletion, or inspection of private information. Due to the widespread use of web pages on the internet, a Hypertext Markup Language (HTML) web page is an excellent medium for a covered text that does not appear suspicious to invaders. To support data security, the most widely utilized methods are steganography and cryptography. Cryptography is the technique of encrypting data into a format that is difficult to decipher. On the other hand, the art and science of secret communication is called steganography, and it involves sending messages in a way that hides even their existence. So, this system is provided as a hybrid system architecture that combines encryption method and data hiding method to improve security. This system embeds special space codes in HTML files by encoding four-pair bits, which provides a string of seven secret bits for each letter in an encrypted secret message. In this system, secret message can easily retrieve and the original HTML file may be successfully rebuilt using this hybrid method, which provides a greater security.

title: An ABI-Level Approach: Implementing a UEFI Bootloader and Kernel from First Principles
authors: Myint Myat Aung, Aung Nway Oo, Win Win Thant, Thinn Thinn Wai
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: This paper presents the implementation of a minimalist UEFI x64 bootloader and kernel entirely in FASM assembly. The bootloader loads a simple kernel that displays "HELLOWORLD". The implementation is unique in that both the bootloader and kernel executables are created from simple flat binary output of the assembler. The generation of PE32+ and ELF64 executables and the interfaces required to interact with UEFI hardware are implemented from scratch by referring to their ABI specification documents without relying on libraries. This technique eliminates toolchain dependencies, grants full control to the system architect, and facilitates a deeper understanding of internal mechanisms. The work serves as both a foundation for the future development of a modern operating system free from legacy design decisions and an educational resource for understanding the esoteric nature of operating systems development.

title: Design and Experimental Research of Six-Degree-of-freedom Electric Drive Robotic Arm Underwater
authors: Xianglong Zhang, Hongwei Du, Kai Wang, Lianying Zhang, Bingju Lu, Menglei Ding
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Manufacturing System (ICAMTMS)
abstract: To meet the current domestic and international demands for underwater resource exploitation, equipment maintenance and operation, a six-degree-of-freedom electric-driven mechanical arm with high repeatability positioning accuracy and large load capacity has been designed. Based on the inverse kinematics solution of the mechanical arm and torque calculation theory, a torque model considering the weight of the body, water resistance, load gravity, additional mass and friction force was proposed. On this basis, the traditional PID control system was improved. A simulation environment was built based on the ROS Notic system, and a virtual-real combination test was carried out by synchronously communicating with the real joint motor.

title: A Survey of FPGA-based 3D CNN Accelerators and Hardware-aware Algorithmic Optimizations
authors: Dana Diaconu, Xue Lin, Michaela Blott, Miriam Leeser
abstract: 3D Convolutional Neural Networks (3D CNNs) can outperform 2D CNNs on several tasks, including action recognition, video captioning, abnormal event detection, and medical image interpretation. Compared to 2D CNNs, 3D CNNs have a larger number of parameters and higher computational complexity. For this reason, researchers have focused on designing efficient 3D CNN architectures and hardware accelerators. The purpose of this survey is to serve as a guide to recent work on 3D CNNs for action recognition with a focus on FPGA-based accelerators and hardware-aware algorithmic optimizations. We provide an overview of the state-of-the-art in 3D CNN architectures as well as the action recognition datasets used for training and testing the architectures. A performance comparison of 2D versus 3D CNNs on two datasets (Sports-1M and UCF101) is included. We explore the designs of FPGA-based accelerators and compare them in terms of achieved throughput, resource utilization and power. We survey current methods of optimization for 3D CNN architectures, which are meant to reduce the number of parameters and the memory requirements and to facilitate their deployment on FPGAs. Finally we highlight current challenges and potential areas of improvement in acceleration of 3D CNNs on FPGA platforms.

title: Hi-RQCT: Hierarchical Residual-Quantized Causal Transformer for High-Quality 3D Human Motion Generation
authors: Dongjie Fu, Tengjiao Sun, Pengcheng Fang, Yiyang Zhang, Hansung Kim
publish: Proceedings of the 22nd ACM SIGGRAPH European Conference on Visual Media Production
abstract: Recent advances in transformer-based text-to-motion generation have significantly improved motion quality. However, achieving both real-time performance and long-horizon scalability remains an open challenge. In this paper, we present Hi-RQCT (Hierarchical Residual-Quantized Causal Transformer), which generates high-quality lifelike 3D human motions by training a single transformer model. Hi-RQCT consists of only two main components: 1) RVQ-VAE, a hierarchical residual vector quantization variational autoencoder, which discretizes continuous motion sequences with high precision; 2) Hierarchical Causal Transformer, responsible for generating the base motion sequences in an autoregressive manner while simultaneously inferring residuals across different layers. Experimental results demonstrate that Hi-RQCT can generate smooth and continuous motion sequences up to 260 frames (13 seconds), surpassing the 196 frames (10 seconds) length limitation of existing datasets like HumanML3D. On the HumanML3D test set, our model achieves the best quantitative performance, and the generated motions also exhibit highly realistic and expressive visual quality in qualitative evaluations.

title: VR-based CPS Interface to Automate Flexible Grinding Processes
authors: Seongwon Jang, Huitaek Yun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Transferring human skills to robots remains a significant challenge due to their reliance on implicit and intuitive human knowledge that is difficult to formalize. In this study, a cyber-physical system(CPS) integrated with virtual reality(VR) and a haptic device is developed to digitize human skills in grinding operations, which especially require human insight and intuition in the process. First of all, a mesh generation method is proposed, where a workpiece that needs grinding operation is scanned in the real world and generated into mesh inside the CPS. The generated mesh of the actual workpiece is then combined with the ideal CAD model, where the target surface for grinding is visible and enabled to make contact with the tool inside the CPS. The haptic device was implemented in the simulation as a tool and directly generated force feedback to the operator. Our work can digitize human operations with realistic visual and force feedback, and has the potential to transform human knowledge to robots for autonomous grinding process.

title: Thermal Conductivity Measurements of CVD-grown h-BN Films
authors: Taeyeon Kim, Sungsan Kang, Minkyu Je, Jihyun Kim, Sangyeon Pak, Jungwan Cho
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Hexagonal-Boron Nitride ($\mathbf{h} \mathbf{- B N}$) is an emerging 2D material that has received considerable attention in futuristic applications in electronic power devicesgate dielectric, heat spreader, and encapsulation coating layer due to its outstanding properties such as wide bandgap ($\sim 5.9 \mathrm{eV}$), chemical stability, electric insulations, high-temperature stability, and high in-plane thermal conductivity ($\sim 420 \mathrm{~W} \mathrm{~m}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}$). Despite its promising characteristics, the accurate thermal conductivity of BN thin films, particularly under practical thicknesses relevant to device applications, remains underexplored. Precise characterization of the thermal transport properties is critical for assessing its viability in managing heat dissipation in high-power devices. In this work, we measure the thermal conductivity of h-BN film using frequency-domain thermoreflectance (FDTR), focusing simultaneous extraction of anisotropic thermal conductivity. The results provide valuable insights into the thermal performance of h-BN thin films and their potential to enhance thermal management in next-generation electronic devices.

title: Performance Analysis of KUI Speech Command Recognition Using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Subrat Kumar Nayak, Ajit Kumar Nayak, Smitaprava Mishra, Archana Rout, Nrusingha Tripathy, Soumyarashmi Panigrahi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: Speech Command Recognition (SCR) is becoming increasingly popular because of its many uses, including voice control of industrial machines, hands-free navigation, smart homes, and virtual assistants. With a primary focus on the KUI language, this study proposes a data-centric method for building SCR systems for low-resource languages. We describe a specialized voice command categorization method for KUI, a low-resource language, to tackle this problem. Researchers from various organizations have conducted extensive research over the past twenty years to test novel approaches and how they may be used in speech processing systems. The voice command dataset has been utilized by several academics who have attempted to improve the effectiveness of speech command-based systems. There haven't been any noteworthy attempts to identify KUI speech. The KUI brief speech commands data set used in this investigation was collected entirely from real-world recordings. This study explores the vital task of command recognition using machine learning techniques. Using raw waveforms as inputs for our models, we transform them into Mel Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs) to execute feature engineering. We test several methods, including Support Vector Machine, Naive Bayes, and K-Nearest Neighbors. The results of the experiments show that the highest performance may be obtained by combining MFCC with augmentation and a Support Vector Machine. The corresponding F1-score, accuracy, precision, and recall are 89.00%, 88.00%, 87.00%, and 89.00%. Furthermore, our investigations provide low-resource spoken language comprehension researchers with critical new perspectives on speech-to-intent categorization. Our approach may be used as a recipe to create personalized speech command datasets, even for languages with limited resources.

title: Demonstration of Multisensory In-Car VR: Repurposing the Vehicle’s HVAC System and Power Seat for Immersive Haptic Feedback
authors: Dohyeon Yeo, Gwangbin Kim, Minwoo Oh, Jeongju Park, Bocheon Gim, Seongjun Kang, Ahmed Elsharkawy, SeungJun Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We demonstrate a novel in-car Virtual Reality (VR) platform that provides multisensory feedback without requiring external hardware. Our system leverages the vehicle’s Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) and power seat systems to generate synchronized thermal, airflow, and motion feedback. These physical sensations are designed to operate in coordination with the visual experience, enhancing a passenger’s sense of presence while reducing the potential for motion sickness. This demonstration shows how existing automotive components can be transformed into an effective and scalable platform for immersive entertainment.

title: Resource-Efficient Benchmarking of Transformer-Based Image Captioning Models Across Standard and Noisy Datasets
authors: Khin Nwe Oo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: Evaluating vision–language models (VLMs) typically require large datasets and multi-GPU clusters, limiting reproducibility for researchers with restricted resources. This paper introduces a resource-efficient benchmarking framework for transformer-based captioning models under constrained conditions. Resource efficiency is ensured through the use of lightweight datasets (<2 GB), single-GPU evaluation (8 GB VRAM), and precision-aware configurations enabling reproducible experiments on consumer-grade hardware. Representative models across four categories including end-to-end, semi-modular, retrieval-based, and text-only approaches are systematically evaluated. Experiments are conducted on Flickr8k (clean, small-scale captions), the COCO Karpathy split (standard benchmark), and a reduced VizWiz subset (noisy, real-world captions). Performance is assessed using accuracy metrics (BLEU, METEOR, ROUGE-L, CIDEr, SPICE) and efficiency metrics (VRAM usage, latency, throughput). Results reveal clear trade-offs between accuracy and computational cost, highlighting lightweight yet competitive alternatives. By releasing lightweight scripts and evaluation protocols, this work promotes reproducibility and inclusivity in image captioning research.

title: An Experimental Approach to AC Line EMI Filter Design Using Common- and Differential-Mode Noise Separation
authors: Gustavo S. S. H. A. Neves, Stanislau De Lira Kaszubowski, Luis Carlos M. Schlichting, Joabel Moia
abstract: Electromagnetic Compatibility (EMC) ensures that equipment operates without causing or suffering from electromagnetic interference. When devices do not comply with standards, correction techniques must be applied, with AC line filter design being one of the most common yet complex solutions. The main challenge lies in identifying and addressing conducted noise—both common-mode and differential-mode—generated by static converters, which are widely used in equipment. This paper proposes a methodology for designing AC filters based on the measurement of conducted noise from a static converter, decomposing it into common and differential modes, and properly sizing inductors and capacitors. The goal is to support designers in developing more effective filters and ensuring compliance with EMC requirements.

title: Ideological and Political Education Teaching System for University Courses Based on You Only Look Once Version-7 with Virtual Reality Technology
authors: Xiaochen Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Background: The quality of Ideological and Political Education (IPE) in universities has been restricted by traditional teaching methods, which lack engagement with limited real-time feedback and fail to evaluate student participation. Challenges: Existing Radial Basis Function Neural Network (RBFNN)-based teaching systems are constrained by poor adaptability to dynamic classroom environments. Proposed Model: To address these challenges, this research proposes a university course IPE teaching system using the You Only Look Once version-7 model for object detection with Virtual Reality technology (YOLOv7-VR). Initially, student activities in class were directly captured in real-time through classroom video streams. The collected data are then fed into the YOLOv5-based object recognition model, which detects student actions such as head orientation, hand raising, and inattentiveness without relying on the preprocessing step. Subsequently, VR scene rendering for contextual teaching generates immersive socio-political environments to enhance student interaction and situational understanding. Finally, the Rule-based Adaptive Feedback (RAF) module analyzes recognition results and VR interaction logs to provide teachers with real-time insights and guide teaching strategies. Results: experimental results demonstrate that the proposed YOLOv7-VR model achieved a Mean Percentage Error (MPE) ratio of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{8 9. 3 5 \%}$</tex> and an Evaluation of Student's Ratio (ESR) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{8 1. 3 4 \%}$</tex> when compared with the existing RBFNN model.

title: Review of Self-Healing Mechanisms for an Enhanced Power Grid Resilience
authors: Jayasudha, Vishakh K H
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: Power grid resilience and dependability are essential for maintaining a steady supply of electricity, particularly when demand rises and natural calamities strike. With an emphasis on the many techniques and technologies used to improve grid dependability, this study provides an analysis of self-healing processes in power distribution networks. In order to identify and mitigate problems and stop cascading failures, the study explores fault detection and isolation strategies. Additionally, it looks at optimization techniques for self-healing, such as sophisticated mathematical models and algorithms intended to effectively manage loads and restructure networks in the event of a fault. The use of artificial intelligence, namely multi-agent systems and reinforcement learning are being investigated for its capacity to optimize grid operations and manage faults on its own. Furthermore, the incorporation of self-healing mechanisms into microgrids is examined, emphasizing how they might improve the adaptability and resilience of power distribution networks. The significance of cybersecurity and cyber-physical systems in preserving the dependability of self-healing grids is also covered in the study, with a focus on the necessity of strong management and communication frameworks to resist cyberattacks and guarantee ongoing functioning.

title: Analysis of Edge Length Distribution of Crypto-Compressed 3D Objects
authors: Khélian Larvet, Jean-Pierre Pedeboy, William Puech
publish: 2025 13th European Workshop on Visual Information Processing (EUVIP)
abstract: In order to remain format compliant, cryptocompression of 3D objects is a very smart solution to guarantee both a high compression rate and a very high level of security. In this article, we present the analysis of a crypto-compression method based on the Draco format proposed by Google. The proposed analysis consists to analyze the distribution of edge lengths of crypto-compressed 3D objects as a function of the number of bits encrypted for each vertex. Experimental results, based on the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test, show that 5-bit encryption per vertex coordinate achieves an optimal trade-off between security and compression efficiency.

title: Multi-Modal Approach for Fetal Health Monitoring Using Deep Learning
authors: Shrushti S Gunjal, Vidya S Handur, Vishwanath P Baligar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Monitoring fetal health is crucial to early detection of developmental risks and pregnancy complications. Conventional methods primarily rely on fetal heart rate analysis or ultrasound imaging, making them unimodal and susceptible to variability due to human interpretation. To address these limitations and improve diagnostic accuracy, this paper proposes a multimodal artificial intelligence system that integrates fetal brain ultrasound images, fetal heart rate signals, and fetal movement data. LSTM networks capture temporal patterns in physiological signals, whereas CNNs extract spatial features from ultrasound images. An ensemble of a Deep Neural Network, Random Forest, and XGBoost then distinguishes the combined features to predict fetal health status, growth, and risk level. Experimental results show accuracies of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 7 \%}$</tex> for DNN and RF, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 3 \%}$</tex> for XGBoost. These findings demonstrate that multimodal AI analysis can support more accurate, stable, and interpretable prenatal diagnoses.

title: Day-ahead Peak Shaving Dispatch of Photovoltaic-Hybrid Pumped Storage Hydropower Systems
authors: Zhanzhi Liu, Zhanxing Xu, Menglu Li, Haowei Wu, Qiang Liu, Yang Li
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: The inherent volatility of photovoltaic (PV) output exacerbates peak-valley load differences and affects power grid operational stability. Hydropower exhibits fast regulation and flexible output characteristics, enabling complementary operation with PV generation to reduce peak-valley load differences. However, with increasing grid-connected PV capacity, the regulating capability of cascade hydropower (CHP) becomes progressively inadequate. By retrofitting CHP stations with pumped storage (PS) units to form hybrid pumped-storage (HPS) systems, peak shaving and valley filling can be effectively achieved, significantly enhancing the regulating capacity of the CHP stations. However, HPS systems involve complex hydraulic coupling constraints that impact the day-ahead peak-shaving dispatch of PV-HPS power stations. In this paper, a day-ahead peak shaving scheduling model for PV-HPS is proposed. Firstly, the complementary operation of PV-HPS systems is introduced. Secondly, a day-ahead peak-shaving dispatch model for PV-HPS systems is proposed. Then, the model is transformed into a mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) problem using an efficient linearization method. Finally, case studies demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed PV-HPS model in achieving peak shaving and valley filling.

title: Designing xDR Challenge 2025 to Evaluate Localization Performance of Smartphone with Navigation Robot for People with Visual Impairment
authors: Satoki Ogiso, Ryosuke Ichikari, Akihiro Sato, Daisuke Sato, Takahiro Miura, Masakatsu Kourogi, Takashi Okuma, Takeshi Tanabe, Takeshi Kurata
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: The xDR Challenge 2025 introduces a novel benchmarking framework for pedestrian localization using dynamic reference points, specifically navigation robots, to assist individuals with visual impairments. Participants are tasked with estimating the 2D position and orientation (x, y, yaw) of a smartphone in real-time as users navigate through an exhibit environment with robotic guidance. The competition includes relative positioning accuracy, leveraging technologies such as ultra wide band (UWB) and sensor fusion from smartphones. Evaluation metrics include Error Accumulation Gradient (EAG), Relative Distance Error (RDA), and Relative Pose Accuracy (RPA), which are aligned with ISO/IEC 21134 standards. The dataset, collected at Miraikan –The National Museum of Emerging Science and Innovation–, includes sensor data from both people with and without visual impairment. The ground truth was measured by AR markers and mobile robots. This initiative aims to fill the gap in localization benchmarks involving moving reference entities and supports broader applications in indoor navigation and interactive exhibits.

title: Evaluation of Electrolytic Capacitors Reliability Based on Operational Profiles of HEV and PV
authors: Andressa Mara M. Alexandre, Paulo Soares Filho, Marcelo Vinícius de Paula, Thiago Belina S. Ramos, Pedro José dos S. Neto, Tárcio André dos S. Barros
abstract: The lifespan of capacitors is a critical factor in the reliability of power systems, as these components play an essential role in filtering, voltage stabilization, and energy storage. Electrolytic capacitors, widely used in hybrid electric vehicles, photovoltaic systems and other power applications, are particularly susceptible to catastrophic failures due to their construction and sensitivity to thermal and electrical stress. The reliability of these capacitors is heavily influenced by the operational profile they undergo, including factors such as temperature, ripple current, and voltage variations, which accelerate aging and wear. In this context, the present article evaluates the reliability of DC bus capacitors, emphasizing the impact of the operational profile. This approach enables the identification of the most critical conditions affecting the lifespan of these components.

title: Privacy-Preserving Federated Learning with Secure Aggregation and Homomorphic Encryption for Brain Tumor Segmentation
authors: T. Aditya Sai Srinivas, Ladly Patel, Zahraa Alkhafajy, N. Sasirekha, P. Umaeswari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In recent years, privacy-preserving medical image segmentation has become vital for confirming safety and dependability of multi-institutional collaborations. However, traditional models often fail maintain segmentation accuracy owing to noise injection and restricted parameter exchange. Hence, this research proposes a novel framework called secure aggregation and homomorphic entropy-based federated learning (SAHE-FL) for Brain Tumor (BT) segmentation. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scans were collected from Brain Tumor Segmentation (BraTS)2020 dataset. The collected data were then preprocessed using intensity normalization, bounding-box cropping, and uniform volume resizing, followed by widespread data augmentation to improve generalization. Subsequently, the processed data were fed into 3Dimensional Fully Convolutional Neural Network (3D U-Net) architecture to extract both local tumor boundaries and global contextual features from various MRI modalities. In addition, SAHE-FL incorporates secure aggregation with homomorphic encryption, which confirms client model updates remain encrypted and masked throughout training, thereby removing need for artificial noise while preserving accuracy. Finally, a secure aggregation mechanism combined with homomorphic encryption safeguards that only aggregated updates was revealed providing reliable privacy protection without reducing model accuracy. Experimental results show that proposed SAHE-FL model attained superior results in terms of sensitivity 0.90% than existing Differential Privacy and Partial Weight Sharing-based Federated Learning (DP-PWS-FL) model.

title: APT Attack Detection and Defense Techniques: A Review
authors: Gaurav D. Neelwarna, Sharmila K. Wagh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: APT (Advanced Persistent Threats) refers to a group of highly-skilled, well-funded cyber-attackers targeting a specific organization or individual over an extended period. These attacks are typically challenging to identify and thwart because they are crafted to bypass conventional security mechanisms and remain hidden for long periods. Significant progress has been made in detecting such threats. Academic research has been published and the security industry has developed effective cybersecurity products in various areas, such as SIEM, EDR, and UEBA. Still, in recent times, we have noticed an increase in APT activities, and APT detection time has not improved much in the last few years. To effectively detect APTs, a combination of multiple approaches is necessary, such as event correlation, data provenance, and malware analysis, etc. This paper reviews research literature on techniques, tools, and surveys for APT detection and defense. Applying machine learning techniques to each aspect of data in detection pipeline is important to improve the overall detection rate.

title: VRFlipAuth: Usable and Secure Authentication based on Flip Game in Virtual Reality
authors: Zibo Zheng, BoYu Gao, Huawei Tu, Hai-Ning Liang, Tingjie Wan, Jian Weng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: With the growing use of Virtual Reality (VR) in various applications, authentication is crucial, especially in immersive VR environments. We propose VRFlipAuth, a novel knowledge-based authentication scheme inspired by the flip game, using spatially located cubes as a password. The pilot study demonstrates that VRFlipAuth provides fast authentication, offering an initial solution for authentication in immersive VR environments.

title: Hierarchical Localization and Tracking for In-Vehicle Mixed Reality
authors: Daisuke Goto, Sungmin Lee, Akira Tsuge, Shuri Marui, Soko Aoki, Jeong Gil Ko, Tadashi Okoshi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Effective localization and tracking are cornerstones of immersive Mixed Reality (MR). However, existing systems often fail in environments with complex motion, such as the interior of a moving vehicle. This setting presents unique challenges, including conflicting visual information and corrupted inertial sensor data. We propose a novel hierarchical system for in-vehicle MR that separates the user’s pose relative to the vehicle from the vehicle’s global pose. By using an edge device with a high-precision Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) receiver and an Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) to estimate the vehicle’s state, and fusing gyroscope-based tracking with marker-based localization for the user, our system demonstrates a promising approach. Experiments show our method significantly outperforms a commercial solution, reducing the average localization error from 164.68m to 8.45m.

title: Predictive Torque Control with Bounded Switching Frequency
authors: João Pedro Brunoni, Rodolfo César Costa Flesch, Diogo Ortiz Machado
abstract: A novel method is proposed that allows the controller designer to directly define the minimum and maximum values for the switching frequency in a finite control set model predictive control (FCS-MPC)-based controller. If no solution exists, the method will relax the constraints to find a fair solution, avoiding infeasibility. The method was tested with an FCS-MPC formulation called predictive torque control (PTC), which was implemented to control a voltage source inverter that drives an induction motor. For the classical PTC implementation, the switching frequency components were distributed from 243 Hz to 12500 Hz. Using the proposed PTC with bounded switching frequency, it was possible to successfully meet the minimum switching frequency constraint of 1000 Hz, important to avoid mechanical resonance on an induction machine, and the maximum switching frequency constraint of 8333 Hz, considered to reduce the commutation power losses.

title: Novel Deep Learning Based Technique for Paddy Leaf Disease Detection
authors: Prithwijit Mukherjee, Anisha Halder Roy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Paddy is a major staple crop in India, and each year, its cultivation is significantly affected by various leaf diseases. Early detection of these diseases can play a crucial role in minimizing crop damage and improving yield outcomes. The goal of this paper is to design a deep learning-based model for automated diagnosis of five main paddy leaf diseases, i.e., bacterial leaf blight, brown spot, hispa, blast, and tungro. A MF-TLSTM (Modified tanh Long-Short-Term Memory)-based classifier model with attention mechanism has been designed for this purpose. First, preprocessing is performed on the paddy leaf images. The operations conducted during this stage include normalization, median filtering, and resizing. After preprocessing, a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)-based method is employed to extract features from the paddy leaf images. These extracted features are then used to train the designed classifier model. The obtained accuracy of the designed MF-TLSTM model is 95.55 %. A user-friendly Android application has also been developed to assist farmers in detecting paddy leaf diseases. The novelty of the paper lies in: 1) proposing MF-TLSTM, a robust variant of TLSTM, and employing it as a classifier, and 2) utilizing an attention mechanism to enhance the paddy leaf disease detection efficacy of the designed classifier.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning Shared Steering Control Strategy Considering Driver-Vehicle-Road Risk Assessment
authors: Sizhe Cheng, Neng Liu, Zhenwu Fang, Jinxiang Wang, Duanfeng Chu, Guodong Yin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Shared control provides a human-centered development direction for intelligent driving. However, existing shared control methodologies address the risk factors related to both the driver and the traffic environment inadequately. To this end, a shared steering control strategy is proposed based on the driver-vehicle-road (DVR) system risk assessment result. Firstly, the driver’s steering behavior is described through a two-point preview driver model. The key parameters are identified using real driving data. Meanwhile, the deep deterministic policy gradient (DDPG) algorithm is applied to train a reinforcement learning (RL) agent considering tracking accuracy, steering smoothness and vehicle stability as the autonomous driving controller. Afterwards, three time-varying risk factors are designed to evaluate the DVR system risk level, which represent driver risk, road risk and lane departure risk, respectively. Based on the system risk level, the control authority is initially calculated by a fuzzy inference method. Then, considering the smoothness of authority transition, a model prediction control (MPC) method is applied to optimize the initial authority level in real-time. Finally, simulation and the driver-in-the-loop (DIL) experiments are performed to validate the proposed strategy. The results demonstrate that the proposed shared control strategy could reduce driving burden and demonstrates distinct superiority in terms of human-machine collaboration, driving comfort and personalized support.

title: A Multimodal Deep Learning Framework for Pilot Task Performance Prediction in Within-Visual-Range Air Combat
authors: Jun Yao, Jinyi Ma, Yiqun Dong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: The advancement of artificial intelligence technology has driven modern within-visual-range (WVR) air combat to gradually transform from human-only operations to human-machine collaborative combat modes. Among these, the human-machine authority allocation remains a key focus of widespread attention. Pilot task performance prediction is crucial for optimizing the authority allocation. In this study, we explored the application of deep learning technology to pilot performance prediction in WVR air combat, proposing a multi-modal deep learning framework. First, we built a dedicated pilot multi-modal database for WVR air combat research, which includes 13 pilots. Then, we designed the hierarchical attention (HA), spatial frequency channel attention (SFCA), and edge-aware graph attention network autoencoder (EAGAT-AE) modules to extract intra-modal features from pilots' physiological states, control behaviors, and combat situations respectively.We also introduced a cross-modal gated attention fusion (CMGAF) module for adaptive fusion of cross-modal features. Finally, we developed a Transformer encoder-based fully connected predictor (TEFP) module to learn the temporal dynamics of cross-modal features and predict pilot task performance. Through 10-fold cross-validation and leave-one-subject-out cross-validation, our model achieved an average accuracy of 94.43% and 84.73% respectively, indicating our method provides an objective means of predicting pilot task performance and holds promise for application in real-world WVR air combat.

title: Exploring Spatial-Temporal Representation via Star Graph for mmWave Radar-based Human Activity Recognition
authors: Senhao Gao, Junqing Zhang, Luoyu Mei, Shuai Wang, Xuyu Wang
abstract: Human activity recognition (HAR) requires extracting accurate spatial-temporal features with human movements. A mmWave radar point cloud-based HAR system suffers from sparsity and variable-size problems due to the physical features of the mmWave signal. Existing works usually borrow the preprocessing algorithms for the vision-based systems with dense point clouds, which may not be optimal for mmWave radar systems. In this work, we proposed a graph representation with a discrete dynamic graph neural network (DDGNN) to explore the spatial-temporal representation of human movement-related features. Specifically, we designed a star graph to describe the high-dimensional relative relationship between a manually added static center point and the dynamic mmWave radar points in the same and consecutive frames. We then adopted DDGNN to learn the features residing in the star graph with variable sizes. Experimental results demonstrated that our approach outperformed other baseline methods using real-world HAR datasets. Our system achieved an overall classification accuracy of 94.27%, which gets the near-optimal performance with a vision-based skeleton data accuracy of 97.25%. We also conducted an inference test on Raspberry Pi 4 to demonstrate its effectiveness on resource-constraint platforms. We provided a comprehensive ablation study for variable DDGNN structures to validate our model design. Our system also outperformed three recent radar-specific methods without requiring resampling or frame aggregators.

title: MultiSafe: Multiple Flight Safety Events Prediction Based on Interpretable Deep Multi-Task Learning
authors: Youlin Huang, Jiaxing Shang, Xu Li, Linjiang Zheng, Chengxiang Li, Fan Li, Xinbin Zhao, Huabo Sun, Riquan Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Flight safety remains a central concern in civil aviation. Recently, increasing attention has been given to leveraging high-dimensional temporal flight data, typically collected by Quick Access Recorders (QAR), to predict safety events. However, most existing studies focus on individual events, overlooking the latent correlations among multiple events. For instance, during landing, a maneuver that reduces the risk of one event may inadvertently increase the risk of another. Predicting multiple events introduces three main challenges: 1)handling parameters recorded at inconsistent sampling rates, 2) learning task-specific parameter importance for interpretability, and 3) modeling complex temporal dependencies for accuracy. To address these, we propose MultiSafe, a deep multi-task learning model for predicting and interpreting multiple flight safety events. First, to process parameters with heterogeneous frequencies, we introduce a Multi-Scale Shared Encoder with adaptive convolutional kernels to unify representations across tasks. Next, a gating-based Parameter Selector learns task-specific parameter importance, enabling interpretable predictions. Finally, a Temporal Decoder with fine-grained attention captures intricate temporal dependencies among parameters. Experiments on a dataset of 37,518 A320 flight records demonstrate that MultiSafe outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in prediction accuracy, while its interpretability offers actionable insights to assist pilots in enhancing flight safety.

title: Aging Mechanism of Composite Insulated Cross-Arm Under Multi-Factor Coupling Effect
authors: Huijie Li, Yafeng Chao, Te Li, Fanghui Yin, Hongwei Mei, Liming Wang, Masoud Farzaneh
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: Composite insulated cross-arm (CICA) can be used in high voltage transmission lines to substitute composite insulators with iron cross-arms. In addition to its excellent insulation performance, CICA can also save on transmission corridors, etc. Nevertheless, due to the horizontal arrangement, CICA bears complex mechanical stresses in addition to the high temperature and humidity environmental factors. The aging mechanism under the multifactor coupling effect is studied in this paper based on a 110 kV CICA. The test results of the interface property show that the hygrothermal factor is the main reason for aging. In addition, stress affects the interface properties by promoting moisture penetration. The interfacial current changes can be divided into three stages: the voltage-current synchronous growth stage, the voltage-continuous current plunge stage, and the interfacial breakdown stage, during the multi-factor aging process. Besides, the CICA experiments show a synergistic effect between the hygrothermal and mechanical factors in the deterioration process of the silicone rubber and the core rod. Constant force and high and low circumferential cyclic forces mainly affect the mechanical properties. This work can be helpful for the application and promotion of CICA.

title: Guided Neck and Shoulder Rehabilitation in VR with Real-Time Corrective Visual Feedback
authors: Sabah Boustila, Daminique Bechmann
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Although Virtual Reality (VR) has been widely explored for physical rehabilitation, few systems provide real-time corrective feedback to guide users during exercises. This work addresses that gap by presenting the design and implementation of a VR system for neck and upper limb rehabilitation. The system delivers guided exercises with visual cues and real-time feedback to ensure proper posture. Users perform six fundamental head and shoulder movements while maintaining focus on a calibrated sphere, which changes color to indicate misalignment and prompts corrective action. The system adapts to individual limitations and increases task complexity as recovery progresses, supporting more effective rehabilitation.

title: Self-Powered Flexible Paper-Based Humidity Sensor for Real-Time Respiration Monitoring
authors: Yang Gao, Seokheun Choi
abstract: Respiration is a vital physiological process, and continuous monitoring provides essential insights into respiratory health. Here, we develop a self-powered, paper-based humidity sensor that harnesses moisture-enabled electricity generation for real-time respiration tracking. The sensor integrates biosynthesized TiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">₂</inf> nanoparticles onto microbial spores, enhancing functional groups to improve moisture absorption and trigger ion dissociation. The paper’s natural capillary action facilitates a controlled gradient formation of dissociated ions, optimizing charge transport. When embedded in a face mask, the sensor sensitively generates electricity in proportion to moisture levels, enabling precise, equipment-free respiratory health monitoring.

title: Thermal Challenges In Co-Packaging Of Si-Iii/V Components In Silicon Photonics
authors: Krishna Bhavana Sivaraju, Sai Abhideep Pundla, Akhil Kalapala, Pratik Bansode, Gautam Gupta, Dereje Agonafer
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: In the modern semiconductor industry, Silicon photonics stands at the forefront as an emerging interdisciplinary department that seeks to combine photonics and electronics on a singular silicon substrate. This combination of conventional electronic circuits and the rapid data transmission capabilities of optical communication has attracted substantial attention due to its potential to transform data communication, computing, sensing and more. Silicon photonics attempts to convert electronic signals into optical signals, facilitating data transmission at remarkable velocities. This is achieved by leveraging photonic components such as waveguides, modulators, detectors, and multiplexers all meticulously engineered using conventional silicon fabrication methodologies. The major component in silicon photonics is the silicon waveguide, a small structure that steers light, enabling its propagation with minimal attenuation. Silicon’s compatibility with complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) processes expedites the integration of photonic and electronic components on a single chip. III-V materials such as Gallium Arsenide (GaAs) and Indium Phosphide (InP) are used as substrates of opto-electronic devices like vertical cavity surface emitting lasers (VCSEL), edge emitting lasers and light emitting diodes. System in Package integration of the III-V materials to silicon requires a reliable bonding technique. The present study proposes four different interconnect design namely Annular, semiannular, flat pad and solder balls between GaAs substrate and SOI wafer. A finite element model of the package is created using Ansys and analyzed using Ansys Thermal module. Different designs are evaluated for their thermal and reliability performances in the GaAs/Si integrated circuits. The advantages and short comings of each interconnect design is discussed and suggestions are made about the aafinity of each configuration for different applications.

title: Design and Development of Automatic Machine Translation System for Medical and Pharmaceutical Specialties Based on Hybrid Nmt Techniques
authors: Yalin Zhai, Ruichen Feng, Bairu Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: An Automatic Machine Translation System for Medical and Pharmaceutical Specialties is imperative to break through language barriers in worldwide healthcare and research. It is applied to translate highly specialized documents like clinical trial reports, patient records, drug monographs, and research articles precisely between languages. It is used through sophisticated neural machine translation models that are particularly trained on huge, human-curated corpora of medical language, abbreviations, and terms in order to be accurate. This is necessary because of the possibility of incorrect translation in this area resulting in misinterpretation of vital information, misdiagnosis, or patient harm. In this regard, this research paper proposes a novel intelligent online NMT framework for medical and pharmaceutical studies. The suggested framework incorporates the Golden Jackal Triggered M2M-100 language model for an efficient understanding of the complex grammars and semantic nuances of medical prescription. The suggested architecture fine-tuned on medical records corpora to capture deep contextual semantics in reading passages, comprehension tasks, and learner responses. The extensive experimentation has been carried out using Large English Corpus Datasets and ensures the high accurate learning process. To prove the excellence of the suggested model, metrics such a BLEU, ChRF, WER are measured and compared with the other learning models. Experimental results demonstrates the BLEU score of the model is found to be 0.922, ChRF score is 0.92 and low WER score which indicates the efficient reading ability of learners in English languages.

title: Implementation of Ternary Neural Networks Based on Ferroelectric Capacitors
authors: Jaemin Yeom, Jae Seung Woo, Jin Wook Lee, Changhyeon Park, Jiwon Park, Minjeong Ryu, Woo Young Choi
abstract: An implementation method of a capacitive ternary neural network (TNN) is proposed, utilizing two-metal-ferroelectric-metal capacitors (FeCaps) per synapse. Unlike conventional one-FeCap synapses, two-FeCaps synapses operate as a differential pair, achieving a >19× increase in sensing margin and enabling the implementation of the weight ‘0.’ The proposed TNNs exhibit enhanced inference accuracy and improved robustness to bit error rate (BER) compared to binary neural networks (BNNs) with one-FeCap synapses, resulting in a maximum accuracy difference of 5.61%p.

title: Dim-to-Warm LED Driver Based on a Quasi-Resonant Boost Converter in Combination With a Low-Dropout Current Regulator for Integrative Lighting Systems
authors: Pablo Quintana-Barcia, Javier Ribas, Diego Rodriguez-Fuertes, Jesus Cardesin, Antonio J. Calleja, Hector F. Chinchero
abstract: This article presents a cost-effective postregulator designed for dim-to-warm (D2W) solid-state lighting applications, where conventional pulse-width modulation (PWM) dimming may be inadequate. D2W lamps aim to replicate the natural shift in sunlight’s color temperature throughout the day, enhancing visual comfort and well-being. The proposed solution combines a dc–dc quasi-resonant boost (QRB) converter with a low-dropout current source (LDOCS), enabling precise current control and eliminating flicker. This architecture ensures zero-voltage switching (ZVS) on the main transistor and zero-current switching (ZCS) on the output diode, thereby improving efficiency and reducing electromagnetic interference. To analyze the converter’s behavior, a simplified energy-balance model is employed, avoiding the complexity of full harmonic analysis while maintaining accuracy. The control strategy (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{ZC-}t_{\textsc{on}}$</tex-math></inline-formula>) uses general-purpose op-amps and a low-cost IC originally intended for power factor correction to regulate the on-time of the main switch, triggered at the zero crossing of the resonant capacitor voltage. To facilitate the design of the converter, a complete methodology is presented and validated through a prototype implementation. Experimental results demonstrate 93.5% peak efficiency, consistent ZVS/ZCS operation across the entire dimming range, and compliance with CIE S 026:2018 standard. This solution offers a practical and scalable approach for high-quality, human-centric lighting systems.

title: Intelligent Beamforming Design for Integrated Sensing, Communication, and Computation
authors: Xiangnan Liu, Haijun Zhang, Haojin Li, Chen Sun
abstract: This paper presents a novel beamforming design that seamlessly integrates sensing, communication, and over-the-air computation (AirComp), enabling a critical multi-purpose functionality for next-generation wireless networks. Firstly, we formulate an optimization problem with the objective of minimizing the mean squared error of AirComp, subject to constraints that ensure the performance of both sensing and communication. The optimization problem is then parameterized and solved using unsupervised learning, employing real-valued and complex-valued deep neural networks (DNNs), respectively. For the complex-valued DNNs, we introduce its mechanism and then apply it for an intelligent beamforming design. Numerical results validate the convergence, ergodic rate, and ergodic mean square error of the proposed algorithms for the integrated sensing, communication, and computation. Also, our findings show that complex-valued DNNs outperform real-valued DNNs.

title: Integrated Motion Control Framework of Wheel-Legged Biped Robot on Rugged Terrain
authors: Zhitai Liu, Hanhai Zhong, Xiaotian Lin, Xinghu Yu, Juan Rodríguez-Andina
abstract: As a novel robotic architecture, the wheeled–biped robot (WBR) offers the potential for rapid locomotion in complex environments. However, existing control schemes still exhibit limited mobility on rugged terrain with vertical drops and obstacles. This work proposes an Integrated Motion Control Framework (IMCF) based on a wheeled–legged floating base dynamic model, incorporating a three-phase balance control system and a composite motion state estimator. The IMCF was implemented on the WBR platform Lustin, and experimental results demonstrate outstanding robustness and superior trajectory-tracking performance. The robot achieves high-speed, stable traversal of rugged terrain with drops and obstacles while maintaining stability and exhibiting strong adaptability and robustness to external disturbances.
