title: Session-Invariant EEG Biometric Identification Using an Enhanced Siamese Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Qassem Alattabi, K Mythili., M N Harshavardhana., K G Parthiban., G Aarthy.
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Over the past few years, Electroencephalography (EEG)-based biometric identification has gained increased attention owing to its uniqueness and resistance to spoofing. However, traditional Deep Learning (DL) models often face session-to-session variability, where electrode shifts and recording situations present domain shifts that decrease the reliability. To address these challenges, this research proposes a Session-Invariant Electroencephalography (EEG) Biometric (SIEB) framework that incorporates a Siamese Convolutional Neural Network (SCNN) with a domain-adaptive (DA) module for robust subject identification. Initially, EEG signals were collected from the PhysioNet Motor Movement dataset, which consisted of 1,500 recordings from 109 individuals. Then, the collected data were preprocessed using bandpass filtering, artifact removal, normalization, and segmentation to remove noise from the data. Subsequently, the preprocessed signals were fed as input into the SCNN, which was enhanced using a gradient-reversal adversarial head to implement session-invariant embeddings. In addition, a prototype alignment loss was employed to stabilize each subject's features and maintain consistency across the recordings. Finally, the proposed Domain-Adaptive (DA-SCNN) attained accurate identification of biometrics. Experimental results show that proposed DA-SCNN attained 95.7% accuracy in delta-band baseline identification and established greater robustness under cross-session conditions when compared to conventional Siamese models.

title: Architecture and Algorithm Optimization of Realtime User Behavior Analysis System for Ecommerce Based on Distributed Stream Computing
authors: Fuzheng Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: With the continuous deepening of digital transformation in the e-commerce industry, user interaction data is showing a trend of high frequency and massive growth, which puts forward higher requirements for platforms in realtime analysis and precise decision-making. Traditional batch processing architectures often exhibit issues such as high latency, insufficient scalability, and lagging feedback when dealing with high-concurrency data streams, making it difficult to meet the demands of refined operation and intelligent decision-making. To this end, this paper proposes an ecommerce real-time user behavior analysis system based on a distributed stream computing framework. This system builds a task scheduling-driven stream structure relying on an inmemory computing engine and significantly enhances the realtime processing capability of large-scale behavioral data by leveraging multi-node parallelism and fault-tolerant mechanisms. In terms of algorithm design, the system introduces an improved initial centroid optimization strategy to enhance clustering accuracy and combines the feature patterns of user behavior sequences to achieve dynamic modeling, which can effectively depict user preferences and behavioral tendencies. Meanwhile, in response to the detection requirements for abnormal traffic and malicious operations, the system has designed a dynamic discrimination mechanism based on time Windows, and combined it with a threshold perception-driven blacklist filtering strategy and asynchronous statistical methods to predict the popularity trend of user interaction content, thereby supporting precise decision-making in key business scenarios such as advertising placement and resource scheduling. The experimental results show that the system demonstrates excellent real-time response capability and behavior recognition accuracy in a high-concurrency environment, with stable algorithm performance and high deployable value. It can provide strong technical support for ecommerce enterprises to build an efficient and intelligent user behavior analysis and operation support system.

title: Immersive Collaboration in Mixed Reality: Enabling Dyadic Decision-Making in B2C Product Configuration
authors: Fabio Vangi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: This doctoral research investigates how Mixed Reality (MR) can enhance collaborative product configuration in business-to-consumer (B2C) settings. Building on MR-CoCo, a co-located MR system tested with 24 couples, early results show strong usability and engagement. The work aims to extend the system to remote scenarios, integrate intelligent agents, and develop novel metrics to evaluate collaboration quality. Feedback is sought to refine methods and explore broader applications in MR-supported decision-making.

title: Comprehensive Energy Optimization and Scheduling Considering Hydrogen-Doped Natural Gas in Multi-Transaction Mechanisms
authors: He Yang, Buwei Ou, Xin Huang, Bensheng Zheng, Junyu You, Haocheng Yu
publish: 2025 International Power and Sustainable Energy Technologies Conference (PSETC)
abstract: In the context of "dual carbon" goals, achieving deep carbon reduction in integrated energy systems (IES) and optimizing the complex coupling and synergy between multiple energy carriers such as electricity, heat, and natural gas are pressing issues in the current field of IES operation and scheduling. To address these challenges effectively, the integration of market mechanisms (e.g., green certificate-carbon joint mechanism) with advanced energy technologies (e.g., hydrogen-doped natural gas utilization) is considered an effective approach to enhance the low-carbon economy, operational flexibility, and renewable energy absorption capacity of IES. This paper aims to construct an innovative IES optimization scheduling model, which deeply couples hydrogen-doped natural gas into a green certificate-carbon joint mechanism for the first time and integrates relevant technologies to achieve carbon cycle and energy transformation. The study intends to realize low-carbon operation, economic enhancement, and efficient absorption of renewable energy through multidimensional collaborative optimization. It establishes a mathematical model of IES that includes electrical, natural gas, thermal, and hydrogen energy flows, converting the system's environmental benefits into quantifiable economic incentives by introducing a green certificate-carbon joint trading mechanism. The research results will validate the effectiveness of the proposed strategy in significantly reducing total system operating costs and carbon emissions, greatly enhancing renewable energy absorption capacity. This study fills the current literature gap in IES optimization scheduling by simultaneously considering the green certificate-carbon joint mechanism and hydrogen-doped natural gas, providing important theoretical and technical support for the green and sustainable development of future IES.

title: Fuzzy Logic-Based Charging Control to Prevent Lithium-Ion Battery Swelling
authors: Janislley Oliveira De Sousa, Georgio Sá Colares, Raphael Barroso Santana, David Alan De O. Ferreira
abstract: Lithium-ion pouch cells used in mobile devices often swell due to electrolyte decomposition and gas formation. Traditional CC-CV methods use fixed temperature thresholds, reacting only after unsafe conditions arise to mitigate the risk of battery swelling. This study proposes a charging control method based on fuzzy logic to prevent battery swelling. The method combines a Power Management Integrated Circuit (PMIC) and a fuzzy controller to dynamically adjust the charging current using real-time temperature and voltage data based on fuzzy inference. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed fuzzy logic controller reduced charging time by 14.7 % at an ambient temperature (25° C), with an increase in peak current from 2079 mA to 2761 mA. Under elevated thermal conditions (35° C), charging time was reduced by 26.5 %, while the maximum battery temperature decreased from 41° C to 38° C. Additionally, the fuzzy method exhibited lower current variability, indicating improved thermal regulation to avoid the swelling effect and enhanced charging stability for mobile devices.

title: Privacy-Preserving Strategies for Secure Cloud of Things: A Review of Current Approaches
authors: Bhabatosh Mahanta, Samruddhi Bhagat, Soubhagya Ranjan Mallick, Princy Diwan, Rakesh Kumar Lenka, Anupreet Paulkar, Swagat Ranjan Sahoo
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: The Cloud of Things (CoT) has changed data-driven applications in many different industries by making it easier to use cloud computing with the Internet of Things (IoT). The enormous data sets produced by IoT devices can’t be stored or processed without cloud infrastructure. Because of the massive amounts of personally identifiable information that are transmitted and stored in the cloud, this integration does, however, bring up a number of privacy and security concerns. Sharing computing and networking resources remotely between users and IoT devices might lead to security issues in the CoT ecosystem. This study offers a comprehensive overview of the current privacy-preserving strategies to guarantee the security of CoT ecosystems. In order to secure its adoption, this paper investigates privacy and security issues with CoT and highlights potential risks and barriers. Along with exploring many unresolved difficulties, it offers the necessary measures to enhance the security and confidentiality of CoT systems. Furthermore, it sheds light on possible directions for further study toward building privacy-aware, scalable, and robust CoT systems by reviewing various approaches.

title: Direct printing of wick structures onto the silicon chips for two-phase jet impingement cooling
authors: Harish Kumar Lattupalli, Emily M. Stallbaumer-Cyr, Md Asif Iqbal, Sina Ghadi, Tiwei Wei, Scott N. Schiffres
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: As cloud computing grows, data centers face new challenges in energy consumption, particularly with cooling. Data center electricity consumption is forecast to rise to $\sim 1300 \mathrm{TWh}$ by 2030; sufficient energy is needed to supply electricity to approximately 123 million homes for a year. The objective of this project is to develop an energy efficient two-phase cooling system for data centers to reduce cooling energy consumption from 40% to less than 5% of the total energy expenditure consumed. Moreover, this technology enables greater utilization of the processing power by reducing core throttling. To achieve this objective, a novel additively manufactured two-phase wick structure and manifold were developed. Building on our prior work, the copper wick structure was printed directly onto the silicon chip without a thermal interface material (TIM) to achieve a low total thermal resistance (below $0.01 \mathrm{~K} / \mathrm{W}$), where thermal resistance represents the resistance to heat flow from the heat source (e.g., a chip) to the surrounding environment. A novel laser printed inter-material bonded to silicon by rapid formation of nm thin silicide. The wick structure was then printed directly onto the inter-material by rapid intermetallic bonding. The required porosity and microstructure in the wick structure were achieved through a parameter optimization study. Complementary microscopy (optical, SEM) was used to analyze the wick structure. A porosity of 38% was achieved. This porosity is within the desired range. Thermal conductivities varied between $16.4 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m} \cdot \mathrm{K}$ and $127.5 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m} \cdot \mathrm{K}$ as the porosity varied from $26-38 \%$. The coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) plays a crucial role in the reliability and mechanical stability of the bonded wick structure. A mismatch in CTE between the wick structure and the silicon chip can lead to thermal stresses during operation, potentially causing delamination, interfacial cracks, or mechanical failure over time. The measured CTE of $16.7 \times 10^{-6} 1 /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ at 38% porosity indicates good compatibility with silicon, minimizing thermal stress and enhancing bond strength. This ensures long-term structural integrity and reliable heat dissipation, making the two-phase cooling system more robust for high-performance data center applications.

title: Single-Phase Single-Stage NPC AC-DC Converter Applied as Electric Vehicle Battery Charger
authors: José Janiere Silva De Souza, Luan Carlos Dos Santos Mazza, Welton Da Silva Lima, Samanta Gadelha Barbosa, Fernando Luiz Marcelo Antunes
abstract: This paper explores the application of a bidirectional single-phase single-stage NPC ac-dc converter for electric vehicle onboard chargers. The ac side consists of two NPC arms with an autotransformer, providing reduced voltage and current stress on switches while generating a five-level waveform and increasing current ripple frequency. The battery side employs a full-bridge converter and the power transfer is based on the dual active bridge principle. A theoretical study of the structure and operating principles is presented, along with descriptions of the modulation and control strategies. A dedicated control loop implements real-time monitoring of battery voltage and current on the secondary side, ensuring safe charging operation for OBC applications. The mathematical analysis and control strategy are validated through simulations and a 750 W small-scale experimental prototype.

title: Semantics-Aware Adversarial Training Using Convolutional Neural Networks for Cybersecurity Intrusion Detection
authors: Kavitha Thiyagarajan, Ali Alkwzahy, Shruthi. B S, S. Gayathri, Kiruthuka S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Nowadays, the Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) have been widely employed for network intrusion detection due to their ability to capture spatial and sequential traffic patterns. However, existing intrusion detection systems often fail when subjected to adversarial perturbations, where attackers slightly manipulate the traffic features to evade detection. This vulnerability highlights the pressing challenge of building adversarially robust cybersecurity models. Hence, this research proposes Semantics-Aware Adversarial Training using CNN (SAAT-CNN) for intrusion detection. Initially, the input data were collected from the CICIDS2017 dataset, which contains realistic benign and malicious traffic. Then, the collected data are preprocessed to handle the missing values, numeric features are normalized using Standardscaler, label encoding is employed to transform the categorical features, and domain constraints are defined to preserve feature semantics. Furthermore, a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \mathrm{D}-\text{CNN}$</tex> is trained for initial intrusion classification, and adversarial examples are then generated using the Fast Gradient Sign Method (FGSM) and Projected Gradient Descent (PGD) within domain-preserving bounds. Finally, adversarial training was employed on the mixed clean and perturbed data to minimize false negatives. The proposed SAAT-CNN provided better results in terms of detection accuracy (99.99 %) when compared to the existing 1D-CNN model.

title: RIS-Aided RSMA Boosted Covert Communication and Physical Layer Security in Multi-Malicious Users Networks
authors: Tao Xu, Xiaosen Xue, Changyu Qu, Xiang Li, Xuanli Wu
abstract: Reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) is emerging as a promising technique for strengthening the security transmission of the wireless networks. This work investigates the covert communication and the physical layer security of the RIS assisted rate splitting multiple access (RSMA) system at the presence of multiple randomly distributed malicious users, where the non-colluding and the colluding behaviors of malicious users are considered. To characterize the channel statistics, we derive a Gamma distribution to approximate the Nakagami-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$m$</tex-math></inline-formula> channel for RIS assisted links. For the covert communication performance analysis, we first derive the closed form expressions of the detection error probability (DEP) for the non-colluding and the colluding wardens. Then the analytical ergodic covert rate (ECR) is also deduced. For the physical layer security performance analysis, we obtain the theoretical expressions of the secrecy outage probability (SOP) for the non-colluding and the colluding eavesdroppers. And the closed form expressions of the asymptotic SOP in the high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) region are derived to provide more insightful guidelines. The analytical results show that RSMA is able to meet different demands of covert performance, and the detection threshold depends on the number of RIS elements and the power distribution coefficient of RSMA to maximize the DEP. The numerical results illustrate that: 1) RIS-RSMA can realize a higher covert performance than RIS assisted transmissions; 2) a lower SOP can be achieved by deploying RIS with more elements.

title: Fusion of ViT-Based Deep Features and Phi-Grid Handcrafted Features for Osteoporosis Detection Using Attention-Infused ResNet MLP and Autoencoder
authors: Lipika Dinda, Jitesh Pradhan, Tapan Kumar Dey, Manish Raj
abstract: Osteoporosis is a progressive skeletal disorder characterized by reduced bone mass and deterioration of bone microarchitecture, significantly increasing fracture risk, particularly among the elderly. Early detection of osteoporosis is vital for preventing fractures, reducing healthcare burdens, and improving patient quality of life. Medical imaging, particularly X-ray analysis, offers a non-invasive and accessible approach for screening. In this research, we propose a robust feature extraction and classification framework for osteoporosis detection using publicly available knee X-ray osteoporosis datasets. We employ a Phi-grid based block division method to partition X-ray images into meaningful regions, from which handcrafted local features (texture, frequency, statistical, spatial, and structural descriptors) are extracted. These handcrafted features are combined with Vision Transformer (ViT)-enabled features to effectively capture both local and global image representations. The resulting feature sets, considered individually and in combination, are fed into a deep learning-based hybrid GAMLP-Net classifier, which integrates ResNet MLP and Autoencoder blocks enhanced with attention mechanisms to improve feature representation and classification robustness. The model performs classification for both binary class (Normal vs. Osteoporosis) and multiclass (Normal, Osteopenia, Osteoporosis) tasks. Experimental results demonstrate that the combined feature representation significantly improves classification accuracy and outperforms several state-of-the-art methods, validating the effectiveness of the proposed approach for automated osteoporosis diagnosis.

title: Noise Separation and Defect Recognition in AC Partial Discharge Pattern Signals Using Continuous Wavelet Transform
authors: Tae-Yun Hong, Young-Woo Youn, Jong-Ho Sun, Jin-Gyu Kim
abstract: Separating noise and partial discharge signals is essential for partial discharge analysis. However, the presence of conductive and radiative noise, such as switching pulses, electromagnetic interference, and network communication, makes this difficult in high-voltage systems. This paper presents an AC partial discharge pattern image analysis method using continuous wavelet transform and the element wise maximum method. This method combines the advantages of both frequency spectrum and AC partial discharge pattern analysis. Defect classification was performed using a convolutional neural network model under conditions with both noise and partial discharge signals. Additionally, explainable artificial intelligence technology was applied to visualize the regions influencing the pattern classification process. Extending the time-series partial discharge signals into the frequency domain effectively separates partial discharges from noise and classifies them under low signal-to-noise ratio conditions.

title: Prediction of IDH and 1p/19q Status in Gliomas Based on Dual Structural Feature Exploration and Alignment Network_supp1-3629805.pdf
authors: Meiyan Huang
abstract: Noninvasively predicting the status of isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) and chromosome arms 1p/19q preoperatively on multisequence magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) images is helpful for prognosis and optimal therapy planning of patients with gliomas. However, effectively learning discriminative features from MRI images for predicting IDH mutation and 1p/19q codeletion status remains challenging due to the high heterogeneity of gliomas. A dual structural feature exploration and alignment network (DSFEAnet) was proposed to effectively explore representative features associated with the intratumoral and marginal heterogeneity of gliomas for accurate prediction. First, a match and mismatch feature extraction (MMFE) module was introduced to extract image structural features related to intratumoral heterogeneity, such as information associated with tumor core localization and T2-fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) mismatch sign. Second, a graph-based geometry exploration (GGE) module was developed to explore graph structural features related to marginal heterogeneity. In this module, the vertex associations and variations perpendicularly along a 3-D tumor surface were integrated as a graph, which can effectively perceive changes in locations, sizes, and marginal textures of gliomas, thus enhancing the feature representational ability to describe glioma heterogeneity. Finally, a dual structural feature alignment (DSFA) module was incorporated to narrow the gaps among intra- and interstructural features. It can adaptively align and fuse different features and thus further improve the overall prediction performance. The proposed DSFEAnet was evaluated using a multicenter dataset, and its robustness was demonstrated on an independent clinical dataset. Specifically, preoperative MRI images of 560 glioma samples were collected from publicly available The Cancer Imaging Archive (TCIA) (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$n =203$</tex-math> </inline-formula>, age: 51.82 (15.21) years, male/female: 109/94, IDH-mutant/wild-type: 90/113, 1p/19q-codeleted/noncodeleted: 27/176), Nanfang hospital (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$n =136$</tex-math> </inline-formula>, age: 41.96 (12.29) years, male/female: 80/56, IDH-mutant/wild-type: 53/83, 1p/19q-codeleted/noncodeleted: 31/105), and Zhujiang hospital (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$n =221$</tex-math> </inline-formula>, age: 43.82 (17.36) years, male/female: 134/87, IDH-mutant/wild-type: 94/127, 1p/19q-codeleted/noncodeleted: 34/187). Our DSFEAnet achieved an AUC of 87.72% for IDH mutation status prediction and an AUC of 80.52% for 1p/19q codeletion status prediction in the Nanfang hospital dataset. Finally, the interpretability of the proposed modules was assessed to highlight the effectiveness of our method. Overall, the DSFEAnet exhibits great potential for predicting IDH mutation and 1p/19q codeletion status.

title: 1-bit DSM-Encoded High-Order QAM Over a 4.6-km D-Band Wireless Link
authors: Rahim Uddin, Jianjun Yu
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: We report an experimental realization of a photonic-aided millimeter-wave (MMW) wireless system in the D-band (~130 GHz), utilizing 1-bit delta-sigma modulation (DSM) to deliver high-order quadrature amplitude modulation (QAM) signals across a 4.6 km line-of-sight (LoS) link. Alow-pass DSM [order 4, oversampling ratio (OSR) 8] encodes baseband high-order QAM into an oversampled 1-bit waveform, achieving a net payload rate of 18.75 Gbit/s. The approach mitigates nonlinear distortion, especially power amplifier (PA) saturation, without relying on nonlinear digital signal processing (DSP). This is the first D-band wireless transmission of 512-QAM and 1024-QAM over a multikilometer distance enabled by 1-bit quantization, offering a reduced-resolution RF front-end for long-range, high-capacity terahertz (THz) communication.

title: Adaptive Iterative Learning Control for Nonlinear Nonsquare Systems Subject to Unknown Control Gain Matrices with Applications to PMSM
authors: Xuefang Li, Ruohan Shen, Xiao-Dong Li, Deyuan Meng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This work presents a novel adaptive iterative learning control (AILC) approach for a class of nonlinear nonsquare systems with unknown control gain matrices. The proposed strategy avoids explicitly incorporating the control gain matrices into the control algorithms and does not require them to be invertible, thereby significantly broadening the applicability of AILC. In the proposed AILC method, a newly designed virtual control gain matrix is introduced, enabling the transformation of the unknown control gain matrix into a form of norm-bounded system uncertainty while accounting for input saturation. Building on this reformulation, a structurally simple AILC scheme is developed, incorporating an input-dependent auxiliary system to mitigate the effects of input constraints. Moreover, the proposed method is extended to nonaffine nonlinear systems by integrating neural network techniques. The convergence of the proposed AILC laws is rigorously analyzed within the composite energy function (CEF) framework, and its effectiveness is demonstrated through implementation on a permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) and a numerical example of a nonaffine system.

title: WCEDNet: A Weighted Cascaded Encoder-Decoder Network for Hyperspectral Change Detection Based on Spatial-Spectral Difference Features
authors: Bo Zhang, Yaxiong Chen, Ruilin Yao, Shengwu Xiong
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: The core of hyperspectral change detection lies in accurately capturing spectral feature differences across different temporal phases to determine whether surface objects have changed. Since spectral variations of different ground objects often manifest more prominently in specific wavelength bands, we design a Weighted Cascaded Encoder-Decoder Network based on spatial-spectral difference features for hyperspectral change detection. Firstly, unlike conventional change detection frameworks based on siamese networks, our proposed single-branch approach focuses more intensively on extracting spatial-spectral difference features. Secondly, the weighted cascaded structure introduced in the encoder stage enables differential attention to different bands, enhancing focus on spectral bands with high responsiveness. Furthermore, we have developed a spatial-spectral cross-attention module to model intra-feature correlations within spatial and spectral domains. Our method was evaluated on three challenging hyperspectral change detection datasets, and experimental results demonstrate its superior performance compared to competitive models. The detailed code has been open-sourced at https://github.com/WUTCM-Lab/WCEDNet.

title: A Tactile-Proximity Dual-Mode Photoelectric Sensor: Implementation and Applications_supp3-3629784.mp4
authors: Long Cheng
abstract: Tactile and proximity sensing is essential for robotic tasks involving human-robot interaction (HRI) and manipulation. However, existing dual-mode sensors often face challenges such as environmental interference, large sizes, and task-specific limitations. This study proposes a dual-mode photoelectric sensor that integrates tactile and proximity sensing. The tactile sensing mechanism is based on a variable optical path structure, while the proximity sensing relies on the surface light reflection. The sensor exhibits a high sensitivity (up to 1.12 V/N), compactness (4 mm thickness), and desirable stability with a drift of less than 1% over 8,000 repetitive cycles under pressures ranging from 0 to 63 kPa. A general tactile-proximity servoing framework is also proposed for the dual-mode sensor array which enables tactile servoing, proximity servoing and hybrid tactile-proximity servoing. Under this framework, parameters can be flexibly adjusted to adapt to different servoing tasks including position and orientation control of the robotic arm's end-effector. In more complex robotic tasks, a real-time fruit ripeness classification method is developed based on the proposed sensor. Using the proposed TPNet, the classification method can achieve an accuracy of 94.4% in a four-level tomato ripeness classification task during grasping.

title:
A 3.3 Gb/s/mm
                    <sup>2</sup>
                    Area-Efficient Non-Binary LDPC Decoder Using Column-Layered Processing
authors: Jeongwon Choe, Youngjoo Lee
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: Non-binary low-density parity-check (NB-LDPC) codes are a prominent class of error-correction codes, offering superior error-correcting performance compared to their binary counterparts. However, previous NB-LDPC decoders suffer from high processing complexity and significant memory overhead when supporting high-order Galois fields and long codeword lengths. To address these challenges, the proposed decoder leverages the trellis min-max algorithm and adopts a column-layered decoding schedule with on-the-fly message computation to reduce memory requirements. Additionally, the proposed column-layered algorithm shares up-to-date information among columns, enhancing the convergence speed of the baseline design. Considering the structure of high-rate NB-LDPC codes, we introduce multi-column processing with an optimized banked memory architecture while minimizing parallel processing overhead through submodule optimization. Fabricated using a 28-nm CMOS technology, the prototype 4KB 0.9-rate decoder achieves a 1.42-fold improvement in area efficiency compared to state-of-the-art designs. While the proposed design is motivated by the requirements of storage applications, its modular organization and scalable parallelism also allow adaptation to diverse domains such as wireless and optical communications.

title: Multi-Task Attention-Guided Deep Learning for Simultaneous Breast Cancer Detection and Density Estimation in Mammography
authors: Marat Nurtas, Gani Esen, Laura La Paglia, Jandos Amankulov, Bazargul Matkerim, Aizhan Altaibek
abstract: Early detection of breast cancer is critical for improving patient outcomes, and deep learning (DL) has shown promise in mammographic analysis. However, many existing systems tackle a single task (e.g., malignancy classification) and provide limited interpretability, which hinders clinical adoption. We present a multi-task, attention-guided framework that jointly predicts malignancy (benign vs. malignant) and BI-RADS breast density (A–D) from a single mammogram while producing interpretable attention maps. The architecture couples a pretrained convolutional backbone with lightweight channel–spatial attention and two task-specific heads. We evaluate six backbones (ResNet-50, DenseNet-121, EfficientNet-B0/B3/B7, MobileNetV3-Large) under a rigorous evaluation protocol with stratified hold-out split (64%/16%/20%) and 5-fold cross-validation. To support reliable deployment, we report comprehensive metrics including discrimination measures (ROC-AUC, PR-AUC, F1-score, sensitivity, specificity), calibration metrics (Brier score, Expected Calibration Error), and ablation studies contrasting single-task vs. multi-task learning and models with vs. without attention mechanisms. Across all evaluation protocols, multi-task learning consistently outperforms single-task baselines by 2.8% in pathology accuracy and 3.5% in density estimation, indicating that density cues provide complementary information for malignancy assessment. Among backbones, EfficientNet-B3 attains the strongest discrimination (AUC=0.962, accuracy=93.6%) on hold-out test with excellent calibration (Brier=0.010), while MobileNetV3-Large achieves competitive performance (AUC=0.940, accuracy=91.2%) with only 4.26M parameters—an optimal accuracy–efficiency trade-off for resource-constrained deployment. Cross-validation results demonstrate robust generalization (AUC=0.954 ± 0.003, accuracy=93.0 ± 0.3%). Attention maps highlight diagnostically relevant regions including architectural distortions and suspicious calcifications, offering interpretable visual rationale aligned with radiological assessment. We discuss limitations including dataset size (410 images), class imbalance in rare density categories, and calibration challenges (ECE=0.365–0.419), and outline directions for external validation on multi-institutional cohorts and integration of uncertainty quantification methods.

title: Personalized Location Privacy-aware Task Offloading: A Dual-agent DRL Approach
authors: Minghui Min, Peng Zhang, Yue Zhang, Wenmin Kuang, Hongliang Zhang, Shiyin Li, Dusit Niyato, Zhu Han
abstract: Multi-access Edge Computing (MEC) enables users to handle resource-intensive and latency-sensitive tasks. However, the offloading behaviors, which are closely correlated with wireless channel conditions, can inadvertently reveal users' location information to untrustworthy MEC servers. Existing location privacy-aware task offloading (LPTO) mechanisms have not fully considered and comprehensively analyzed personalized location privacy protection requirements. To address this gap, this paper proposes a differential privacy (DP)-based personalized LPTO mechanism for MEC environments that jointly optimizes the perturbation region, privacy budget, and offloading rate while maximizing the offloading utility. We quantify personalized privacy requirements by incorporating task sensitivity, user privacy preference, and task priority. Then, we propose a two-timescale (2Ts) optimization framework to solve the complex personalized location privacy-aware task offloading optimization problem. Specifically, we optimize the perturbation region on a long timescale to align with long-term privacy requirements. In contrast, the offloading ratio and privacy budget are dynamically optimized on a short timescale based on instantaneous channel states and offloading workloads. Furthermore, we model the privacy-aware offloading problem as a Markov decision process (MDP) and develop a dual-agent deep reinforcement learning (DRL)-based personalized LPTO mechanism (DDPLM) to optimize strategies under dynamic MEC systems. Simulation results validate that the proposed DDPLM achieves personalized location privacy protection while reducing computational costs.

title: Evaluating Ascon in Secure Multi-Party Computation using Reverse Multiplication-Friendly Embeddings
authors: Peter Schwarz, Erik Pohle, Aysajan Abidin, Bart Preneel
publish: Proceedings of the 24th Workshop on Privacy in the Electronic Society
abstract: We present the first systematic study on communication-efficient evaluation of the lightweight cipher family Ascon within secure multi-party computation (MPC). By leveraging Ascon’s parallel, bit-oriented structure, we adapt its design using Reverse Multiplication-Friendly Embeddings (RMFEs, introduced by Cascudo et al. in CRYPTO’18) in a single-circuit evaluation, enabling efficient packing of groups of bits into field elements. Our protocol, which uses relatively small RMFEs, achieves substantial reductions in communication cost compared to baseline MPC protocols. For example, in a medium-sized setting (with n = 13 MPC parties), our protocol reduces the communication cost for an Ascon permutation by roughly 38%. For large amounts of parties (e.g., n = 255), the reduction can reach 50%. These improvements are achieved even though RMFEs only pack a few bits per field element, due to favorable amortization of both substitution and linear layers. We also provide a Boolean circuit implementation of Ascon in the MP-SPDZ framework, enabling straightforward benchmarking. Our findings are particularly beneficial for bandwidth-constrained environments where the use of lightweight ciphers, such as Ascon, is necessary due to the resource limitations of client devices, as in the case of transciphering data from IoT sensors. Since our optimizations target the Ascon permutation, they naturally extend to all cryptographic modes (encryption, decryption, hashing) defined for the standard.

title: Crisis Companion: AI-Powered Chatbot for Disaster Response and Therapy
authors: Min Khant Kyaw Thu, Myat Shwe Yi Moe, Hnin Shwe Yi Wint, Thiri Myat Thu, May Myat Thu, Aye Chan Mon
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: Disasters such as earthquakes, floods, and storms can strike suddenly, upending communities and creating urgent survival challenges while leaving lasting emotional and psychological impacts. Earthquakes are the most devastating due to their unexpected nature and scale, which render survivors with little access to believable information and a lack of mental health care. This paper introduces an AI-powered Disaster and Therapy Chatbot that addresses both requirements. The system provides real-time readiness and safety guidelines, displays current earthquake news, warns earthquake warnings in user location and assists with crack analysis and survival needs. It also offers psychological first aid, including empathetic conversations and practical stress-relief techniques. The chatbot is designed for use both during disaster events and in the post-disaster recovery phase to help communities stay resilient, reduce stress, and address critical gaps in disaster relief and mental health care.

title: VisionStorage Classroom: MR-Based Educational System for MMCA Cheongju Korea
authors: Sangah Lee, Jaewon Choi, Hayoung Bae, Dayoung Lee, Jusub Kim, Sangyong Kim, Yongsoon Choi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: VisionStorage Classroom is a mixed reality (MR) educational system developed for Apple Vision Pro. It allows users to explore the storage environment and collection management of the National Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art (MMCA), Cheongju. Through seated interactions using gaze and hand gestures, users engage with video footage, MR-based artwork viewing, interactive 3D spaces, and AI-generated Skybox visuals. The experience offers insight into curatorial layouts, preservation activities, and rarely seen artworks. A demonstration is scheduled for late 2025, with future plans for expanded content and adaptive guidance features to support immersive and accessible museum education.

title: The Study of Cold Plate Liquid Cooling Solution for Optics and ASIC on Next-generation Switch
authors: Yan Liu, Peng Xiao, Yaoyin Fan
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: The bandwidth requirement of cloud compute and converged Artificial Intelligence(AI) / Machine Learning(ML) is growing dramatically in recent years. Higher bandwidth comes with higher power consumption of optics and switch Application Specific Integrated Circuit(ASIC). Conventional air cooling solution is more and more challenging to meet the thermal requirement for next-generation 1.6T optics and 102.4T switch ASIC. In response to the high-performance computing and energy-saving requirements of the Information Technology(IT) industry, liquid cooling technology has emerged rapidly in recent years. In this paper, single-phase cold plate liquid cooling solution is studied to identify thermal feasibility and thermal improvement for 30 W Octal Small Form Factor Pluggable(OSFP) optics and 750 W Tomahawk 5(TH5) ASIC in a 2 U switch system. First, 2 kinds of cold plates for OSFP are explored and optimized by Computational Fluid Dynamics(CFD) simulation analysis to achieve the optimal thermal performance and pressure drop. Second, experiments are carried out to investigate the effects of power consumption, coolant inlet temperature, and coolant flow rate on the thermal performance. The cold plate solution can support higher power consumption of $35 \mathrm{~W}+$ OSFP with a flow rate of 2 LPM at $40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ coolant inlet temperature, while 20 W by air cooling. The thermal performance of TH5 cold plate is $0.026^{\circ} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{W}$, which is 8% better than the first-generation cold plate and 48% better than the air-cooled solution [1]. Furthermore, thermal correlation analysis between simulation and experiments has a high agreement with a deviation within 5%, which can provide a significant reference for the future development of single-phase cold plate liquid cooling solution.

title: An Enhanced Quality Evaluation Model English Classroom Teaching Based on Ensemble BP Neural Network
authors: Xiao Yu, Jian Xi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The evaluation of English Classroom teaching (ECT) quality in higher education is a complex, multidimensional task that requires robust, adaptive models. This study presents an Enhanced Evaluation Model for ECT based on an Ensemble Backpropagation (BP) Neural Network designed to improve the accuracy and reliability of teaching effectiveness assessments. The model integrates multiple BP networks trained with different initial weights, learning rates, and activation functions, and combines their outputs using ensemble strategies such as bagging and weighted averaging. The key evaluation indicators, including student engagement, teaching content clarity, value orientation, and critical thinking cultivation, were extracted and normalized from survey data collected across multiple colleges. To validate the model, this research used benchmark datasets constructed from real classroom feedback, expert scoring, and academic outcomes, comprising over 6,000 records from 14 universities. Experimental results demonstrate that the ensemble BP model outperforms traditional single neural networks and statistical methods, achieving an overall accuracy of 96.5%, a mean squared error (MSE) reduction of 28%, and a significant improvement in generalization across diverse student populations. The enhanced evaluation model offers practical insights for education administrators and policymakers aiming to optimize IPE curricula and teaching strategies.

title: Using Parallel Computing Approaches to Enhance Brute Force Algorithm for Optimal Scheduling in Asynchronous Hierarchical System
authors: Aye Min Thike, Sergey Lupin
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: Hierarchical management systems are employed in complex multi-level operations like industrial workflows and emergency response coordination, where effective task allocation is critical to minimizing processing times and maximizing resource utilization. This paper first provides an overview of three hierarchical models: HS<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sup> (parallel), HS<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup> (sequential dependency), and HS<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> (asynchronous), emphasizing their computational characteristics and practical applicability. Among these models, the HS<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> model allows senior-level elements to start their tasks as soon as at least one subordinate completes its assignment, reduces system idle time, and provides more flexibility than the HS<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sup> and HS<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup> models. Using this asynchronous approach, we address the problem of optimal task distribution in emergency response scenarios using a brute force algorithm that explores all possible assignments, ensuring minimal mission completion time while respecting node capacity constraints. The application of parallel computing techniques based on distributed and shared memory models, specifically MPI and OpenMP, respectively, has enabled us to perform exhaustive searches more efficiently by significantly reducing execution time relative to sequential execution. Combining the HS<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> model’s flexibility and the proposed computational strategies shows its potential for effective hierarchical task allocation in various real-world domains, including logistics and healthcare.

title: Embedded Cooling of Planar Magnetic Components for High Power Density Power Converters
authors: Yanghe Liu, Tianzhu Fan, Feng Zhou, Shailesh Joshi, Ashwini Kumar Dubey, Sayan Paul, Dragan Maksimovic, Ercan M. Dede
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: The thermal management of planar magnetic inductor or transformer components is a critical factor in increasing the power density and enhancing the performance plus reliability of power electronics. This paper comprehensively investigates the thermal management of printed circuit board (PCB)-based planar inductors used in high-power converters through active liquid cooling. The study specifically explores embedded cooling technology to improve the heat dissipation efficiency of a planar inductor design. Three cooling configurations are analyzed: 1) a baseline case with single-sided active liquid cooling of the component package; 2) an improved case with double-sided liquid cooling of the package; and 3) a novel proposed method utilizing hybrid double-sided cooling with embedded liquid cooling of the component. Thermal modeling and simulation results are presented for all three cases to evaluate their effectiveness in dissipating heat. The initial numerical results demonstrate that the proposed hybrid cooling technique significantly enhances thermal performance by reducing hot spots inside the planar magnetic component and provides more uniform temperature distribution across the inductor windings. This method shows promise for high-power density applications where efficient thermal management is essential.

title: Subtle Cues for Navigation in Virtual Reality: How to Effectively Guide Users in VR?
authors: Agnieszka Dubiel, Grzegorz Zwoliński, Dorota Kamińska
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Scene exploration is vital in virtual reality but can be cognitively demanding without physical reference points. This study evaluates micro-guidance cues—minimal visual, auditory, and tactile signals that aid navigation without overt distraction. In a custom VR environment, 198 participants searched for a hidden anchor while flying over a deserted island, guided by one of six conditions: no cue (control), visual light cue, visual motion cue (sand vortex), auditory white noise, auditory sonar, or haptic compass. All cues significantly improved accuracy over no cue, and sonar, haptic compass, and visual light also reduced task times. Findings suggest micro-guidance can enhance VR navigation while preserving a smooth, immersive experience, with potential for personalized multisensory design.

title: Analog/RF Performance analysis of a DMG-FinFET
authors: Dhananjaya Tripathy, Debiprasad Priyabrata Acharya, Prakash Kumar Rout, Debasish Nayak
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: Device topologies beyond traditional bulk MOSFETs have evolved in response to the growing need for high-performance and low-power electronic systems. When it comes to improved carrier transport, suppression of short-channel effects, and electrostatic control, the Dual-Material Gate FinFET (DMG-FinFET) is one of the most promising new technologies. Through a thorough simulation-based examination, this study provides a thorough analysis of the analogue and radio frequency (RF) performance parameters of DMG-FinFETs. Important characteristics are extracted and contrasted with their single-material gate FinFET (SMG-FinFET) counterparts, including transconductance, output conductance, intrinsic gain, cutoff frequency, and gain-bandwidth product (GBW). The findings show that DMG-FinFETs have excellent analogue properties and RF figures of merit, which makes them attractive options for mixed-signal and next-generation analogue circuit applications. Furthermore, the impact of material work function engineering and device geometry on performance measures is examined, emphasising the ability of DMG structures to scale down while preserving reliable analog/RF behaviour.

title: Finite Control Set Model Predictive Control for Split-Phase NPC-Based Rectifier
authors: Bruna Seibel Gehrke, Nady Rocha, Marco Rivera, Edison Roberto Da Silva
abstract: This paper presents a model predictive control (MPC) strategy based on the Finite Control Set (FCS) concept for a single-phase three-wire neutral-point-clamped (NPC) power converter. The proposed FCS-MPC algorithm simultaneously addresses both the grid current errors and the DC-link capacitor voltage balance, ensuring sinusoidal grid current and zero neutral-point voltage. A PI controller is employed to regulate the overall DC-link voltage, while a Phase-Locked Loop (PLL) is used to synchronize the grid voltage and current, thus maintaining a high power factor. Simulated results under different scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed strategy.

title: Design of an Economical Non-Isolated Bidirectional DC/DC Power Converter
authors: Jinxiang Wang, Huan Cheng, Zhengxiong Chen, Jiaxin Chen
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: At present, the rise of new green data centers, electric vehicles, photovoltaics, energy storage, micro grids and other popular industries are driving the development of system power supply solutions toward wide input, wide output, high density, high efficiency, etc., and the DC/DC bidirectional power converter is playing an increasingly important role in the above fields. In order to explore the technical solution of high frequency, high efficiency, high power density and parallel control DC/DC bidirectional power converter, this paper designs a Buck/Boost bidirectional DC/DC converter circuit, which realizes the bidirectional flow of energy between the high voltage side and the low voltage side of the circuit through the voltage and current double closed-loop PWM control, thus realizing the charging and discharging of the battery. In this paper, according to the design requirements of the bidirectional DC/DC converter, the simulation software MATLAB/Smiulink is used to establish the simulation model of the bidirectional DC/DC converter, and the simulation results prove the correctness of the theoretical analysis and calculation.

title: Efficient Stress Level Classification with Class-Imbalance-Aware Using CNN on HPC Platform
authors: May Thet Swe, Aye Myat Myat Paing
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: Early stress detection and measurement is a crucial strategy because it is important to take action immediately to prevent stress from increasing and leading to potential health issues. The system relies on heart rate variability (HRV), which is collected from ECG. The system presents the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) as a Machine Learning (ML) model for stress level classification using features selected by lasso regression. CNN directly receives feeds from some cases that have known the imbalanced class issues. An important part of the system deals with the distribution of class imbalance in the training data. In training data, some classes of user stress levels have fewer samples than others. This aspect is addressed by the method of stratified k-fold cross-validation. Stratified k-fold cross-validation is a method of cross-validation in which each fold of the cross-validation keeps the same ratio as the original dataset, including the smaller classes in reasonable representation in both training and evaluation. The system provides fair representation of all classes while providing precise real-time stress detection. However, the need for a several-fold increase in the total amount of time resulting in a longer duration. The High Performance Computing (HPC) parallel execution is used by the system to address this problem. Because the HPC architecture distributes tasks among several processors, it maximizes resource usage and drastically cuts down on total elapsed time. From the experimental results, 5-fold stratified cross-validation on ML with HPC parallel processing based on the Message Passing Interface (MPI) achieves the highest accuracy (0.9999) and the lowest MAE (0.0001), showing superior reliability and efficiency for stress level classification.

title: Development of a 30W SEPIC LED Driver for High and Low Beam Lighting Applications
authors: Mehmet Yıldırım, Onur Akiner, Omer Cihan Kivanc
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: In recent years, rapid advancements in LED (Light Emitting Diode) technology have enabled high-brightness white LEDs—with superior features such as energy efficiency and long lifespan—to replace incandescent, halogen, and fluorescent lamps. However, with this transformation, the requirements for high power factor (PF) and low total harmonic distortion (THD) have become prominent to achieve energy savings and reduce environmental impacts. In this paper, the development of low-cost and highly efficient power converter topologies has emerged as a valuable research area. The SEPIC (Single-Ended Primary-Inductor Converter), which offers a single-stage structure, stands out as an ideal solution in non-isolated applications due to its ability to perform both boost and buck operations. Operating the SEPIC topology in discontinuous conduction mode (DCM) allows the input current too closely follow the input voltage, thereby reducing harmonic distortion and enabling a high-power factor. In this study, A 30W SEPIC-based LED driver for automotive lighting systems is designed and implemented, achieving an output voltage of 21V from a wide input voltage range of 9V to 36V. Experimental results show a high efficiency of 91.3% at full load, 94.6% at half load, and up to 95.2% during low-beam dimming operation. This study introduces a robust and efficient reference design for LED drivers supporting high-beam, low-beam, daytime running light (DRL) functions, offering valuable insights for both academic and industrial applications.

title: Towards Expert Knowledge Capture with Virtual Reality: Exploring Immersive Elicitation of CAD Models for 3D Printing
authors: Adya Hegde, Rolando Bautista-Montesano, Thomas Bohné, Sebastian W. Pattinson, Ziling Chen, Yeo Jung Yoon, Sławomir K. Tadeja, John Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) enables the rapid fabrication of complex geometries that are unattainable through conventional manufacturing methods, such as computer numeric control (CNC) machining. Despite widespread potential for adoption across industries, including aerospace, biomedical, automotive, and architecture, AM still faces critical design challenges and expertise bottlenecks. This study examines how immersive virtual reality (VR) can facilitate the capture of expert knowledge in design for additive manufacturing (DfAM), where computer-aided design (CAD) software remains pivotal in addressing these complexities. However, traditional CAD systems pose limitations in intuitively exploring novel designs or complex geometrical contexts. CAD software remains pivotal in addressing these complexities, yet traditional CAD systems pose limitations in intuitively exploring novel designs or complex geometrical contexts. We conducted an observational user study with nine AM experts using a custom-developed VR environment. Participants evaluated three CAD models of varying complexity, highlighting the effectiveness of VR for detailed inspection, spatial understanding, and manufacturability assessments. Results showed high usability, low cognitive load, and effective spatial exploration. Experts identified further improvements, including integrated scaling references, component-level inspections, and enhanced slicer software functionality. Our findings highlight the potential of VR to streamline AM workflows by intuitively capturing and applying critical manufacturing expertise.

title: Comparison Between Different Metaheuristic Algorithms for Parameter Estimation in Empirical Arc Models
authors: Mauricio Taconelli, João A. F. G. Da Silva, Tarcio A. S. Barros, Denis Gustavo Fantinato
abstract: Photovoltaic systems are increasingly prevalent in renewable energy applications; however, their operation is vulnerable to DC arc faults, which can lead to catastrophic failures. Accurate understanding and modeling of these arcs is critical for effective fault detection and system safety. In this context, this paper presents a comparative study on the application of metaheuristic optimization algorithms for parameter estimation in empirical electric arc models. Given the inherent challenges posed by model complexity and non-linear parameter interactions, genetic algorithms (GA), differential evolution (DE) and particle swarm optimization (PSO) are evaluated using synthetic voltage-current data. Although GA and PSO have been extensively employed in physics-based arc modeling, the use of DE in empirical models remains underexplored. The results demonstrate the potential of these methods to improve parameter identification accuracy, thereby offering a promising approach to improve arc modeling and associated fault detection strategies.

title: Leveraging Natural Language Processing and Machine Learning for Stress Identification in Social Interactions
authors: M. Chandu, Md. Sajeed, L. Sai Nikhil, Prakash Kumar Sarangi, M.A. Jabbar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Stress detection in online discourse has gained significance with the rapid rise in numbers of people using social media to express their feeling, ideas. However, it becomes difficult to identify stress in text because it often shows through emojis, slang, sarcasm, informal language, and emotional tones. The task is challenging for detecting stress from the text as, it can be informal, sarcasm, slang, emojis and emotion tone. The proposed framework overcomes the challenges by using the machine learning (ML) and natural language processing (NLP) approaches to identify stress indicators of stress in text-based social interactions. In this paper “Stress” is defined as the way people express psychological strain, emotional exhaustion, or pressure in social interactions, which makes stands out it from general negative sentiment. The RoBERTa, T5 and BERTopic transformers models are used for a specific tasks: sentiment analysis, emotion classification, sarcasm detection, spam filtering, and emoji mapping. These models are trained on different open source datasets. The output of five sub-models is combined, the final binary class output: Stress or Not Stress is provided for each input. The model is implemented and their performance is measured by using metrics like f1 score and accuracy. The experimental results of the proposed integrated multi-Stage framework system gained accuracy of 94.42%, with precision and recall scores averaging 0.94. A real time web interface, developed using Streamlit which allows user friendly interaction.

title: Channel Potential-based Mobile Charge Density Analysis for Junctionless Double Gate Dual Material (JL DGDM) MOSFET
authors: Srikrishna Bardhan, Pradipta Kumar Jena, Sarita Misra, Sanghamitra Das, Sudhansu Kumar Pati
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: This paper demonstrates about the analysis of 2-D channel potential based mobile charge density for junctionless double gate dual material (JL DGDM) MOSFET structure with respect to different values of device parameters such as channel length, channel doping density, channel thickness, oxide thickness, and drain voltage. The suggested device's channel potential model is used to develop an analytical model of mobile charge density. The proposed model is verified by comparing the model data of drain current as a function of gate-to-source voltage with simulation results. According to the findings of the mobile charge density analysis, the mobile charge decreases as channel length and doping concentration rise, which results in low drive current and subpar device performance. But the device performance improves with the increase in mobile charge density when channel thickness, oxide thickness, and applied drain bias enhances.

title: A Real-Time Screening System for Large Minerals Based on the Light-YOLOv8 Model
authors: Hui Pan, Mingyue Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: Mineral supply is a critical part of the mineral production process. Large-sized minerals can cause disruptions in downstream processing operations, making real-time detection of oversized mineral highly important. Based on this, a system for screening large mineral particles was proposed. Firstly, image acquisition was completed using a depth camera. Then, target detection was performed to identify large mineral blocks based on an improved Light YOLOv8 model. Finally, robotic arm automatically operates to screen out the large mineral with the detection results. In the improved Light-YOLOv8 model, the attention mechanism and convolution module were innovatively integrated to reduce the model's parameters and computational complexity, thereby enhancing its real-time detection efficiency. Experimental results indicate that, the parameters of the improved Light-YOLOv8 reduced <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5. 3 \%}$</tex> and computational complexity (GFLOPs) reduced 19.5 % compared with the original YOLOv8 model. Meanwhile, The model can maintain its detection accuracy. This demonstrated the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed enhancements. This study provides certain guiding significance and reference value for the real-time screening of large-grained mineral in the mineral supply process.

title: Hybrid Distribution Transformer Based on Direct Frequency Converters: Analysis of Voltage Regulation and Power Factor Correction
authors: Ivo Barbi, Cláudia Luana Schimuneck Da Rosa, Giovanna De Oliveira de Brito, Angélica Paula Caús, Leonardo Freire Pacheco, Hugo R. E. Larico
abstract: This paper presents the development and analysis of a hybrid distribution transformer, proposed as an alternative to the conventional transformer. The solution is based on the integration of two direct and bidirectional AC/AC power converters, connected to the transformer's secondary and tertiary terminals. These converters enable the regulation of the load's RMS voltage and the correction of the grid's power factor. The work includes the theoretical modeling of the system, the main operational stages, the adopted modulation strategy, and a study of commutation using RC clamper circuit. Simulation results are presented to validate the performance of the proposed solution and demonstrate its feasibility for real-world applications.

title: Emotion Detection From EEG Signals Using Advanced Deep Learning Techniques
authors: Amulya J, M. Shobha Rani
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
abstract: Understanding human emotions through brain signals is an emerging field in neuroscience and artificial intelligence. Electroencephalography (EEG) provides a safe way to capture brain activity. deep learning has shown strong ability in decoding these signals for emotion recognition. This study aims to develop and compare hybrid deep learning models for EEG-based emotion classification, identifying the most effective approach for recognizing emotional states (Negative, Neutral, Positive) from EEG signals. We implemented and evaluated several deep learning architectures, including LSTM, GRU, Bi-LSTM, DNN, and hybrid models (DNN-LSTM, DNN-GRU) these hybrid models are compared against traditional deep learning architectures. The models were trained and tested on an EEG dataset, and their performance was assessed with the help of recall, F1- score, accuracy and precision. Techniques such as one-hot encoding, batch normalization, and learning rate scheduling were applied to optimize training. Our findings indicate that Bi-LSTM achieved the highest accuracy of 96.72 %, followed by DNN-LSTM and DNN.

title: Analysis of the Thermal Resistance Network of Packaged GaN HEMTs
authors: Seokjun Kim, Daniel C. Shoemaker, Husam Walwil, Bill Zivasatienraj, Isaac Wildeson, Sukwon Choi
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Gallium nitride (GaN) high electron mobility transistors (HEMTs) have been paving the way for 5G radio frequency (RF) wireless communication technologies. However, the extremely high operational heat flux leads to device overheating, which makes it necessary for GaN HEMTs to be operated under derated power conditions. Therefore, it is necessary to understand which component of the internal thermal resistance network primarily contributes to the channel temperature rise. In this work, the junction-to-heat sink thermal resistances of GaN HEMTs mounted on a high-power laminate CuMo base package were analyzed using micro-Raman thermometry and device thermal modeling. It was found that the thermal resistance associated with the GaN buffer layer, and the substrate primarily contribute to the junction-to-heat sink thermal resistance, respectively. In addition, the thermal resistance associated with the die attach material exhibits a notable effect ($\sim 10 \%$) on the device channel temperature rise. The findings of this work shed insight into the design of device-topackage level thermal management solutions for GaN monolithic microwave integrated circuits (MMICs).

title: Hybrid Lstm and Manta Ray Optimised Deep Belief Networks for Evaluate Ideological and Political Teaching
authors: Min Dou, Wei Yang, Qin Dong, Yanan Tang, Zhongliang Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: As online learning platforms have expanded very quickly, effective categorization of political and ideological teaching materials has become essential to achieve personalized learning and knowledge sharing. Current systems mostly utilize manual labelling or simple machine learning techniques, resulting in limitations such as low precision, excessive redundancy, failure to process high-dimensional semantic features, and poor adaptability to dynamic resource changes. The conventional algorithms like Decision Trees, Naïve Bayes, and Support Vector Machines lack semantic meaning and incur scalability problems, whereas CNN or RNN-based models are hindered by issues in feature interpretability. To overcome these limitations, a Hybrid LSTM and Manta Ray Optimised Deep belief networks to evaluate the online teaching methods based on the ideological and political courses. The comprehensive experimentation has been conducted using Kaggle datasets and it is compared with the existing learning models. Experimental results show remarkable improvement over classical classifiers, with 98.72 % accuracy, precision of 98.6 %, recall of 98.5 % and F1-score of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 8. 8 \%}$</tex>, surpassing traditional models. The high-performance mechanism is the ability to exploit global dependency, semantic correlation, and hierarchical structure, achieving high precision and robust classification of heterogeneous educational resources.

title: Synchronization in Hybrid Feedforward-Recurrent Neural Networks with Stochastic Temporal Modulation
authors: Rakesh Sengupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive theoretical and computational investigation of oscillatory behavior in hybrid feedforward-recurrent neural networks under stochastic modulation. We establish a rigorous mathematical framework based on three fundamental theorems that characterize the stability, resonance properties, and synchronization behavior of these networks. Through extensive discrete-time simulations of a 50 -neuron network, we demonstrate excellent agreement between theoretical predictions and numerical results. Our findings reveal that the network maintains stability across a wide range of feedback strengths while exhibiting precisely predictable scaling relationships: linear scaling of deviation from reference orbits and quadratic scaling of synchronization measures. The network demonstrates robust frequencyselective response to input signals, with clear spectral peaks at the stimulus frequency and no spurious oscillations. Lyapunov stability analysis confirms the theoretical predictions, and resonance characteristics show safe operational margins from critical conditions. These results provide concrete design principles for constructing stable oscillatory networks and establish a foundation for applications in signal processing, pattern recognition, and computational neuroscience. The work bridges theoretical mathematics with practical neural network implementation, offering insights into temporal processing mechanisms in both artificial and biological neural systems.

title: IEEE Standard for Bushings for High-Voltage (Over 1000 Vac) Circuit Breakers and Gas-Insulated Switchgear
authors: N/A
abstract: This standard is applicable to bushings intended for use in high-voltage circuit breakers and gas-insulated switchgear. These bushings are intended for indoor and outdoor use, operating on alternating current with a rated voltage greater than 1000 V and a frequency of 50 Hz or 60 Hz. These bushings are usually a part of an apparatus and tested according to the apparatus of which they form part.

title: Comprehensive Online Vocational Education System Based Multi-Modal Deep Learning Algorithm
authors: Can Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The Online Vocational Education System is an electronic platform created to impart practical skills training and career-oriented education directly to students over the internet. It is employed to offer flexible, scalable, and accessible vocational education to students, career switchers, and professionals in need of upskilling. But the traditional Online vocational education faces critical challenges in delivering personalized learning experiences that align with individual career goals, skill levels, and industry demands while addressing the diverse needs of adult learners seeking career transitions or skill enhancement. To meet this above criteria, this research presents a comprehensive online vocational education system based Multi-modal deep learning algorithm designed to optimize learning pathways, improve course completion rates, and enhance employment outcomes through intelligent content personalization and adaptive learning support. The proposed networks combines the powerful features of Swin Models and Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) model for learning the multi-modal inputs to support for an emergent teaching and evaluation systems. The comprehensive experimentation is carried out using Vocational Materials and performance of the model is evaluated. To prove the efficacy of the suggested model, existing architectures are experimented and their performance were compared with the suggested framework. Experimental results demonstrates the superiority of the suggested model by achieving the accuracy of 97.7%, precision of 97.6%, recall of 97.5% and F1-score of 98% and outperforms the other learning model. The present research provides the new paths for smart classroom assessment, providing real-world implications for teachers and institutions seeking to enhance vocational education quality.

title: Anomaly Detection in Photovoltaic Power Plant Using Machine Learning in an IoT-Based SCADA Platform
authors: Flavio De Castro Alves Filho, Bruno Falqueto Busato, João Lucas De Souza Silva, Leandro Tiago Manêra, Tárcio André Dos Santos Barros
abstract: The reliable operation of photovoltaic (PV) power plants requires effective monitoring, since anomalies can reduce energy yield and increase maintenance costs. Traditional Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems often lack advanced data-driven tools to detect abnormal conditions in real time. This paper presents the development and integration of a machine learning (ML)-based anomaly detection algorithm into an Internet of Things (IoT)-enabled SCADA platform. The objective is to support operation and maintenance (O&M) by enabling near real-time identification of faults. The proposed algorithm combines a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex>-Nearest Neighbors (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex>-NN) approach with a rule-based inference machine, using plane-ofarray (POA) irradiance and inverter apparent power as input features. The system architecture includes the integration of the ML module into the SCADA platform and the implementation of a simulator for validation. The approach was evaluated using historical data from a 30 MW commercial PV plant. Results show that the integrated algorithm successfully detects anomalies in a simulated real-time environment, with performance consistent with offline analysis. In addition, the SCADA interface provides dashboards for visualization and anomaly alerts, supporting proactive O&M strategies in utility-scale PV systems.

title: Visualizing Motion Intent in Heterogeneous Multi-Robot Environments
authors: Malte Riechmann-Thom, Jan Rexilius
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: As robots play a growing role in human environments, effectively conveying their intent can improve user comfort and safety—especially in scenarios involving multiple robots with different appearances and movement types, such as ground-based and aerial. This work targets the visualization of motion intent for heterogeneous robots to enhance safety perception in shared spaces. We present a framework that integrates real robots into augmented reality and allows users to extend real-world setups with virtual robots, enabling varied test scenarios. To support safety, we propose several path augmentation techniques to represent intended robot movements without overwhelming users. A user study with 18 participants evaluates our approach in a mixed-reality scenario using both real and virtual robots.

title: VRodoro: Designing an Ambient Time Management Tool for Productive and Healthy Work in VR
authors: Dang Tran-Hai, Donghyeon Ko
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) offers deep immersion and enhances user focus and productivity, making it a promising next-generation platform for productivity tools. At the same time, this immersion can lead to "time compression," causing users to underestimate session duration and resulting in prolonged exposure, fatigue, and discomfort. To explore how time management tools can support productive and healthy VR work, we preliminarily compared physical and VR-integrated Pomodoro timers. We identified a key design trade-off: the VR timer improved time awareness but introduced distractions, while the physical timer supported sustained focus yet caused discomfort due to abrupt alerts and limited continuous awareness. Based on these findings, we propose VRodoro, an ambient VR Pomodoro timer that subtly communicates session progress through natural environmental transitions, aiming to balance immersive continuity with unobtrusive time awareness.

title: Simulation Study on The Influence of Different Environments and Parameters on The Current Ampacity of Parallel Cable
authors: Jue Zhang, Jiayin Bian, Meng Wang, Defeng Zang, Zebin He, Wanlin Quan, Yan Xu, Jinhao Zhang
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: The current ampacity of cables limits their application in long-distance and high-voltage transmission. The environment of cable tunnels has a direct impact on the current ampacity of cables. This article explores the effects of environmental parameters such as soil thermal conductivity, tunnel wall thermal conductivity, tunnel air temperature, ground surface temperature, and ground surface convective heat transfer coefficient on cable current ampacity. By adjusting the range of these parameters, analyze their impact on cable heat dissipation and current ampacity. And by calculating cables with different arrangements, provide the steady-state current ampacity results of the cables. The research results indicate that increasing the thermal conductivity of soil and tunnel walls, controlling the air temperature and surface temperature inside the tunnel, can all improve the heat dissipation effect of cables and significantly increase their current ampacity. The research provides scientific basis for optimizing the environment of cable tunnels, which is of great significance for designing more efficient and safe cable transmission systems.
