Future research can further explore other environmental parameters and their complex interactions to construct more comprehensive theoretical models, providing systematic support for optimizing cable current ampacity in practical engineering.

title: Firing Pulse Synchronization for Low-Frequency DC Ripple Reduction in Microcontroller-Based Six-Pulse Battery Chargers
authors: J. N. Rodrigues Matheus Alexsander de, Edgard Luiz Lopes Fabricio, Samuel Carvalho Silva Junior, Emerson de Lacerda Soares, Cicero Alisson dos Santos, Italo Andre Calvacanti de Oliveira, Bruna Seibel Gehrke, Nady Rocha
abstract: This paper proposes a digital synchronization strategy for six-pulse rectifiers to reduce low-frequency ripple in battery charging applications. In microcontroller-based rectifiers, sampling and triggering delays introduced by digital control systems can amplify low-frequency oscillations that are not effectively attenuated by conventional passive output filters. To address this issue, a compensation technique is introduced by inserting a variable-width pulse at the beginning of the firing pulse train, correcting the timing error without requiring additional hardware. Experimental results demonstrate a significant reduction in output voltage and current ripple, leading to improved performance of battery charging systems and validating the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Synchronous SEPIC DC-DC Converter with Multilevel Flying Capacitor Switching Cell and Soft Switching
authors: Rhavél Batista Morais, Montiê Alves Vitorino
abstract: This paper proposes a new three-level synchronous SEPIC DC-DC converter, integrating a switching cell with a flying capacitor, designed to operate under Zero-Voltage Switching conditions. The topology leverages the pseudo-resonant behavior between the parasitic capacitances of the switches and the filter inductance to achieve soft switching. This resonant interval occurs during the dead time between the two complementary switches of the flying-capacitor structure and is sufficient to ensure that both are switched at zero voltage. The converter employs a dual-loop control strategy to regulate both the output voltage and the voltage balance of the flying capacitor. Theoretical foundations supporting its operation are presented, along with simulation and experimental results.

title: Quantitative Evaluation of Frequency Regulation Capability in Wind Farm Considering Wake Effect
authors: Chunyi Han, Gang Zhang, Lin Cheng, Haijun Chang, Zhenxing Shao, Yujun Li
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Due to the influence of the wake effect, there is a coupling of the actual captured wind speed of wind turbines in the wind farm, which brings difficulties in the evaluation of wind farm's frequency regulation capability. In order to solve this problem, this paper firstly establishes the Jensen-Gaussian wake model to analyze the wind speed distribution in wind farm. The second norm method is introduced to aggregate multiple wake streams. Then, the upward frequency regulation capability of the wind farm is quantified and analyzed under MPPT mode and overspeed deloading mode, respectively. Under MPPT mode, the frequency regulation capability can be explicitly calculated, and under overspeed deloading mode, the upper bound of the frequency regulation capability can be evaluated by solving the optimization model with the deloading rate of each WT as decision variable. Finally, the wind speed distribution of the wind farm and the frequency regulation capability under different modes are analyzed by simulation.

title: Enhancing Farming with Predictive Analytics and Artificial Intelligence
authors: R. Sri Bhargava, R. Sidhartha, R. Srinivas, Alakuntala Raja Shekar, M. A. Jabbar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Farming is vital to global food systems, especially in agrarian economies like India, where it remains the economic backbone for millions. However, challenges such as unpredictable weather, soil nutrient depletion, and limited access to expert agricultural advice continue to affect productivity. This paper proposes a machine learning-based framework to address these issues by offering accurate crop and fertilizer recommendations. The system employs two Random Forest Classifiers that analyze critical agricultural variables, including soil nutrients (nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium), temperature, humidity, pH level, and rainfall. Based on these inputs, it suggests the most suitable crop for prevailing conditions and recommends fertilizers to correct soil nutrient deficiencies, thereby ensuring optimal growth with minimal environmental impact. Built on open-source libraries and deployed via cloud infrastructure, the framework is scalable and user-friendly, enabling farmers to make data-driven decisions. By improving resource utilization and yields, it fosters sustainable agriculture and strengthens long-term food security.

title: Hybrid Control of Multi-Chemistry Batteries and Supercapacitor for ESS with Transient Support, SOC-Based Current Weighting and Active Supercapacitor Voltage Recovery
authors: Vinícius Dário Bacon, Fernando Marcos Oliveira, Aleksander Da Silva Toth, Jonas Villela De Souza, Guilherme Gemi Pissaia, Anderson De Camargo Bortoluzzi, Henrique Peron, Tales Gottlieb Jahn
abstract: This paper presents a novel control strategy for a Hybrid Energy Storage System (HESS), composed of multichemistry energy storage systems and supercapacitors, interconnected via a multiport DC/DC converter architecture. The proposed control strategy aims to mitigate battery degradation by distributing the power flow based on the state of charge (SOC), state of health (SOH), and storage capacity of each unit. Additionally, a continuous voltage regulation loop is implemented for the supercapacitor, enabling it to handle fast transient events and thereby reduce stress on the batteries. The main contributions of this work include: (i) the integration of current weighting based on real-time SOC, SOH, and capacity indicators for multi-chemistry energy storage systems; and (ii) the implementation of an active voltage recovery mechanism for the supercapacitor without interrupting operation. Both simulation and experimental results validate the effectiveness of the proposed strategy in enhancing operational efficiency, reliability, and the lifespan of hybrid storage systems.

title: Multi-Layer Deep Feature Ensemble for Multiclass Fruit and Vegetable Freshness Classification
authors: Ahmed Abdulhakim Zaid Baker AlSalahi, Somaya Al-Maadeed, Faseela Abdullakutty
publish: 2025 13th European Workshop on Visual Information Processing (EUVIP)
abstract: Vision-based assessment of fruit and vegeTable freshness plays a critical yet challenging role in agriculture and food supply chains, as natural variability in appearance and subtle spoilage indicators make objective evaluation difficult. In this work, we present a deep learning ensemble approach that leverages intermediate feature representations from a MobileNetV3Small model to classify produce freshness across 20 distinct classes, each corresponding to a specific produce type and freshness level. Unlike conventional methods that utilize only the final output layer, our approach trains lightweight classifiers at multiple intermediate layers and combines their outputs through a majority voting scheme. This multi-level strategy harnesses diverse feature information and improves robustness to variations in visual freshness cues. In experiments, the ensemble classifier achieved a classification accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 6. 1 7 \%}$</tex> under the majority voting strategy. Using the final network layer's prediction in isolation, the model attained <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 8. 0 9 \%}$</tex> accuracy. These results demonstrate a high-performing yet efficient solution. By exploiting the lightweight MobileNetV3 backbone, our method enables real-time inference on resource-constrained devices, making it practical for deployment in supply chain environments to automate freshness monitoring and reduce food waste.

title: Neuronexus: Federated Learning for Scalable Brain Tumor MRI Analysis
authors: Aman Dubey, J. S. Yadav
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
abstract: Brain tumors, characterized by abnormal cellular growth in the brain or its surrounding tissues, represent a major global health challenge, with over 300,000 new cases annually. Accurate and timely diagnosis using Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is critical but often limited by scarce radiological expertise and computational resources, particularly in underserved regions, affecting Sustainable Development Goal 3 (Good Health and Well-being). Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) excel at classifying brain tumors from MRI scans by extracting complex spatial features, yet centralized training requires large, aggregated datasets, raising privacy and logistical concerns. This paper proposes a federated learning (FL) framework for brain tumor classification, utilizing a harmonized dataset of 7,023 MRI scans from figshare, SARTAJ, and Br 35 H repositories, covering glioma, meningioma, pituitary, and no-tumor classes. Using MobileNetV2 with finetuned layers, we simulate four healthcare institutions collaborating via federated averaging (FedAvg). In an IID setup with balanced data, the global model achieves 99 % accuracy, with precision, recall, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex>-scores averaging <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 9 9}$</tex>. In a nonIID setup reflecting real-world heterogeneity, the global model reaches 96.18 % accuracy after 20 rounds. Personalized finetuning improves local client performance, with accuracies up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 3. 4 4 \%}$</tex> on the global validation set, demonstrating its efficacy in addressing data heterogeneity. This work highlights the impact of data distribution on FL and advances equitable healthcare by enabling resource-limited facilities to leverage privacy-preserving AI diagnostics.

title: A Transmission Corridor Object Detection Model Based on an Enhanced RT-DETR
authors: Xiangyu Chen, Haina Rong, Gexiang Zhang, Kaiyi Xian
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: Abstract-Detecting the presence of construction-related risks to cables in transmission corridors is crucial for the security of power systems. When unmanned inspection vehicles are deployed to detect potential hazards, multiple objects such as engineering vehicles, pedestrians, and utility covers need to be considered. To address the challenges of significant scale variations (due to changing distances) and strong background noise, this paper proposes an enhanced object detection model based on RT-DETR. The proposed model improves detection accuracy and robustness in such complex environments. Specifically, a C2f-PKI module is introduced in the backbone network to enhance feature retention for small objects. In the neck network, an AIFI-ASSA module is designed to improve feature extraction capability and suppress background interference. Additionally, an HAFB module with multi-branch extraction and hierarchical attention mechanisms is developed to strengthen the detection of dynamic targets and effectively integrate multi-scale features. Experimental results show that the proposed method achieves a 4.5% increase in recall and a mean average precision (mAP) of 91.8% compared to the baseline, outperforming YOLO series algorithms in transmission corridor object detection tasks.

title: IoT enabled Water Quality Assessment System Using Multilayer Perceptron
authors: Aye Thet Zaw, Amy Tun
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: This paper presents a real-time water quality assessment system that integrates these technologies such as Internet of Things (IoT), cloud computing, and machine learning. A custom-built floating device equipped with embedded sensors measures critical water quality parameters, including pH, turbidity, Total Dissolved Solids (TDS), and temperature. The collected data is transmitted wirelessly and stored in Firebase Firestore, a scalable, cloud-based NoSQL database. A key component of the system is the implementation of a Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) model which is trained on a public dataset to accurately classify the water as either "potable" or "not potable." This approach provides an automated, low-cost, and real-time solution for continuous water quality assessment. The system's real-time capabilities also enable the potential for smart alert systems, ensuring immediate notification of water quality issues.

title: Switching Loss Optimization and Soft Switching Range Extension of a Current-fed Triple Active Bridge Converter
authors: Dongrui Du, Yu Chen, Xiaoyong Ren, Zhiliang Zhang, Qianhong Chen
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: On-board charger (OBC) and auxiliary power module (APM) are crucial power electronic components in electric vehicles. The OBC converts AC input into DC output to charge the High-Voltage (HV) propulsion battery; while the APM connects the HV side and Low-Voltage (LV) side to charge the LV battery. To reduce costs, minimize size, and enhance power density, this paper studied a three-port current-fed triple-active bridge (CF-TAB) converter for integrating the OBC and the APM. This converter offers a streamlined structure and simplifies transformer design compared to traditional integration methods. In this paper, a five-control-variable optimal control scheme utilizing a look-up table method is proposed for the converter with the objectives of minimizing the switching loss of the converter. In addition, a hardware experimental platform for 3kW/200V-500V OBC plus 1kW/8V-16V APM is built and allows for the verification of the proposed control scheme's effectiveness. The results indicate that, in comparison to conventional DPS control, the new control scheme significantly reduces switching losses and extends the soft-switching range.

title: Enhancing Bus Performance Analysis Using GPS Data: Insights and Recommendations
authors: Shreya G. Tendulkar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: This study investigates the application of GPS data from the MTA BusTime system to evaluate bus performance and reliability in New York City. By analyzing a year's worth of bus location data, the research aims to assess various performance metrics such as headways, wait assessments, and travel speeds. Key findings include the identification of performance variations along different segments of bus routes and the challenges of analyzing large datasets, including issues with data accuracy, frequency, and gaps. The study employs big data technologies, primarily Spark, to process the vast amount of data and highlights the potential for improved performance analysis through better data acquisition and processing techniques. Future work is suggested to include examining the effects of traffic conditions on reliability, enhancing visualization tools, optimizing algorithms, and adapting the methodology for different transit systems and modes.

title: ActivePaws and Playcuff: Pilot Evaluation of a Non-Immersive Exergame Suite Controlled by a Wearable Device
authors: Marianna Pizzo, Andrea De Filippis, Fabio Lazzari, Jacopo Romanò, Lorenzo Garavaglia, Eleonora Diella, Giuseppina Sgandurra, Sabrina Signorini, Fabio Solari, Simone Pittaccio, Manuela Chessa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: ActivePaws is a suite of exergames, controlled by Playcuff —a wearable orthosis for upper limb rehabilitation —designed for the detection, classification, and exploitation of a wide range of 3D upper limb gestures. In ActivePaws, specific synchronized forearm movements are required to play the games, thus combining rehabilitation with gamification. Here, we present the results of a pilot study conducted with a group of healthy young participants to gather preliminary feedback about engagement, game design, usability, and movement-based interaction. Results show a high level of enjoyment, engagement, aesthetic appreciation, positive experiences, and minimal frustration. This work is a preliminary step in preparation for a multicenter, exploratory, prospective, case-control, non-profit clinical investigation within the Fit4MedRob project.

title: Direct Instantaneous Torque Control of Switched Reluctance Machines for One Switch C-Dump Converter
authors: Elmer O. Hancco Catata, Pedro J. Dos Santos Neto, Lucas Lima Rodrigues, Igor Mesquita Da Rocha, Omar C. Vilcanqui, Tárcio A. Dos Santos Barros
abstract: This study presents the implementation of the Direct Instantaneous Torque Control (DITC) strategy for a C-dump converter applied to a Switched Reluctance Machines (SRMs). The proposed control approach is comprehensively evaluated under both motoring and generating conditions. The switching states of the C-dump converter are systematically analyzed for each mode of operation. Based on the excitation states, dedicated hysteresis controllers are designed for each excitation period of the DITC. The control scheme is developed and simulated in the Matlab/Simulink environment. Simulation results for both operational modes validate the effectiveness of the approach.

title: Thermohydraulic Characterization of 3D-Printed Metallic Wick Flow Condensers
authors: Durga Prasad Ghosh, Behzad Ahmadi, Vivek Mano Mohan, Mohammad Reza Shaeri, Sajjad Bigham
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Flow condensation of low surface tension fluids leads to filmwise condensation with inferior thermal performance. Here, 3D-printed converging wick structures are proposed to enhance the condensation heat transfer performance of low surface tension fluids. The metallic wick structure improves the effective condensate-wick thermal conductivity. The converging topology augments the convective effects as the vapor quality decreases along the condenser flow length. The outcome is a condenser with improved heat transfer performance. This study focuses on the thermal and hydraulic performance of two 3D-printed wick flow condensers made of GRCop-42, a high-thermal-conductivity copper alloy, and 17-4 PH, a stainless-steel alloy known for its superior corrosion resistance. Experiments were conducted over a range of dielectric mass flow rates ($0.1-1.1 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{s}$) while subcooling was fixed at $\boldsymbol{-} \mathbf{5 . 5 ^ { \circ }} \mathbf{C}$ to evaluate heat transfer and pressure drop characteristics. The GRCop-42 wick flow condenser exhibited significantly better heat transfer performance, achieving a heat flux of $24 \mathrm{~kW} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\left(2.4 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}\right)$ and a heat transfer coefficient (HTC) of $4.2 \mathrm{~kW} / \mathrm{m}^{2}-\mathrm{K}$ at a mass flow rate of $0.6 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{s}$ and $1.1 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{s}$, respectively-$300 \%$ and $250 \%$ higher than the 17-4 PH wick structure. These enhancements are attributed to the superior thermal conductivity of GRCop-42 ($\sim 350 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}-\mathrm{K}$) compared to $17-4 \mathrm{PH}(\sim 15 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}-\mathrm{K})$. Complete condensation with near-zero exit vapor quality was achieved with GRCop-42 across all flow rates, whereas the 17-4 PH wick exhibited increasing vapor exit quality (0 to 0.7) as the mass flow rate increased from 0.1 to $0.7 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{s}$. The higher thermal performance of GRCop-42 came with an increased pressure drop penalty, rising to 17 kPa at $0.6 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{s}$, compared to 8 kPa for 17-4 PH. These results underscore the trade-off between thermal performance and pressure drop for GRCop-42 and highlight the potential of $17-4 \mathrm{PH}$ as a corrosion-resistant alternative for applications requiring moderate thermal performance. This work offers critical insights into the design and material selection of advanced 3D-printed wick condensers for demanding thermal management applications.

title: Supply-Demand Collaborative Response of Integrated Energy Systems Based on Carbon Emission Flow Theory
authors: Peng Chen, Li Lan, Yanyuan Qian, Mingxing Guo, Xuxu Zhou, Lili Miao, Longlong Guo, Hongbo Ren
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: In the context of the global "dual-carbon" imperative, this research is dedicated to optimizing the low-carbon economic dispatch of integrated energy systems. It innovatively develops multi-energy flow models for key components like wind turbines and photovoltaics, while refining the carbon emission flow theory. A novel synergistic optimization model integrating low-carbon demand response and carbon trading mechanisms is established. This model incorporates two - dimensional demand response strategies on the demand side and a stepped carbon trading model on the supply side. Through simulations on an enhanced IEEE 14 - node system, the model's efficacy in reducing costs and carbon emissions is validated. The sensitivity analysis further uncovers the impact of carbon prices and other factors. This study offers crucial methodological and technical insights for the low-carbon transition of integrated energy systems.

title: Real-time Indian Sign Language Alphabet Detection using Transfer Learning with YOLOv8
authors: Abhijit Joshi, Soumya Ranjan Bhoi, Debabrata Dansana, Gyana Ranjana Panigrahi, Rakesh Deep, Tanmaya Bhoi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: For individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing, hand movements, facial expressions, and body language serve as essential modes of communication. Indian Sign Language (ISL), like other sign languages, possesses rich linguistic characteristics with its own grammar and syntax. Recent advancements in real-time ISL gesture recognition have increasingly leveraged computer vision and deep learning methods to enhance communication accessibility. This study presents a computer vision–based system for recognizing ISL alphabet gestures using YOLOv8 as the core deep learning model. The ISL hand gesture dataset used in this research was sourced and annotated via Roboflow, providing a diverse and consistently labeled collection for training. The proposed model achieved excellent performance metrics, including a precision of 98 %, recall of 98 %, F1-score of 99 %, mean Average Precision (mAP@50) of 98 %, and mAP@50–95 of 93 %. These results demonstrate the model’s high accuracy and its potential for real-time ISL recognition applications, promoting more inclusive and accessible communication technologies

title: Novel Multi-Nozzle Jet Impingement Liquid Cold Plate for Cooling of High-Power Density Electronic Chip
authors: Sangram Kumar Samal, Chi-Chuan Wang, Yogesh Fulpagare
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: This work presents a novel multi-nozzle jet impingement liquid cold plate (MJILCP) designed to improve the cooling performance of high-power electronic chips. The proposed cooling system focuses on addressing thermal hotspots and ensuring uniform temperature distribution, challenges often encountered with conventional cooling technologies such as traditional microchannel liquid cold plates. Three-dimensional numerical investigations were conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of the MJILCP for a thermal design power (TDP) of 1000 W. Its performance was compared with a skived-fin-channel liquid cold plate (SFCLCP). The liquid coolant used in the study is PG25 at an inlet temperature of $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, with a volumetric flow rate ranging from 0.75 to 2 LPM. The results demonstrated that the MJILCP significantly enhances thermal performance while reducing the pumping power requirement compared to the SFCLCP. The proposed MJILCP can achieve a maximum reduction in thermal resistance of 14.3% and a decrease in pumping power by 19.3% relative to the SFCLCP. Notably, to attain a thermal resistance of $0.0236{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{W}$, the MJILCP requires 48% less pumping power than the SFCLCP. The MJILCP exhibits maximum chip temperatures of $61.72^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $45.26^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ at flow rates of 0.75 and 2 LPM, respectively. This innovative design paves the way for more efficient thermal management solutions in the electronics industry, meeting the increasing demand for highperformance cooling systems in data centers, power electronics, and telecommunications equipment.

title: Exploring the Enforcement of Cookie Notices across Continents: An Empirical Study
authors: Jean Luc Intumwayase, Imane Fouad, Pierre Laperdrix, Romain Rouvoy
publish: Proceedings of the 24th Workshop on Privacy in the Electronic Society
abstract: Regulatory frameworks, such as GDPR in Europe, CCPA in the United States, and LGPD in Brazil have made cookie notices a standard feature on the web. Websites display notices and sometimes seek user consent for their use of cookies and tracking technologies. However, the visibility and impact of these notices can vary based on the user’s geographical location. In our study, we introduce a novel automated visual detection technique to explore the enforcement of cookie notices. This methodology outperforms previous techniques that depend on manual observations or inspection of HTML/CSS elements. Our analysis of 70,390 web pages visited across five countries on different continents reveals geographical disparities in cookie notice visibility, with France exhibiting the highest prevalence at \(69\%\) and Japan the lowest at \(27\%\). This variation in visibility correlates with the state of cookies and tracking. In further examination of interaction with cookie notices, we analyze 351,950 web pages and find that third-party cookies increase when users interact with the notices, notably in the US. Conversely, France, with its stringent regulations, maintains the lowest number of third-party cookies. Tracking trends closely follow these patterns, highlighting a correlation between the visibility of cookie notices and user tracking. That correlation highlights the need for accurate detection of cookie notices in this domain, as we propose.

title: The Impact of Strategy-Oriented Videos Based on Electroencephalography Data on Human-Computer Interaction Performance
authors: Kuntong Li, Chenjie Yang
abstract: The growing integration of artificial intelligence and automation technologies has expanded the complexity of human-computer interaction, placing higher demands on users’ multi-tasking coordination and cognitive resource management. Although various training methods exist, most fail to account for differences in user proficiency or to incorporate neurophysiological mechanisms underlying performance. Therefore, this study introduces strategy-oriented demonstration videos as an intervention and investigates their differential effects on users with varying proficiency levels. A mixed 2 (proficiency: high/low) × 2 (intervention: video/no intervention) experiment was conducted on the Multi-Attribute Task Battery II multi-task platform, integrating electroencephalography features (including band power and brain network metrics), behavioral performance, and Task Load Index subjective workload into a multi-dimensional evaluation system. The results showed that (1) high-proficiency users outperformed low-proficiency users across all metrics, demonstrating more efficient electroencephalography features and lower subjective workload; (2) strategy-oriented videos significantly improved task performance, coordinated the optimization of multiple electroencephalography features, and reduced subjective workload for low-proficiency users; and (3) for high-proficiency users, the same video intervention elicited only isolated activation in EEG features without meaningful performance gains, reflecting a clear expertise reversal effect. These findings highlight the importance of tailoring Human-Computer Interaction training to user proficiency and provide neurocognitive evidence to support the design of personalized intervention strategies in complex interactive systems.

title: PageRank-based Unsupervised Deep Vertex Representations for Anti-Money Laundering Detection
authors: Batur Gezici, Emre Sefer
abstract: Anti-money laundering (AML) refers to a global framework of laws, regulations, and protocols designed to trace and expose illicit funds that have been concealed to appear legitimate. Enforcing anti-money laundering measures demands rigorous monitoring of financial transactions to detect potentially unlawful activities. However, conventional rule-based AML systems, while compliant with regulatory standards, generate excessive false positives that burden analysts and obscure subtle laundering patterns. To address these limitations, advanced machine learning techniques, particularly those based on graph structures like Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), offer a promising alternative. In this context, we introduce a novel method, referred to as AMLPD (Anti–Money Laundering with Personalized Diffusion), which utilizes Personalized PageRank and diffusion mechanisms to generate unsupervised node embeddings. This technique learns inductive graph embeddings for AML detection by taking into account the directionality of graph edges and incorporating both node and edge features, along with the graph’s structural information. AMLPD derives a node’s local representation by fusing diffusion processes with Personalized PageRank scores. This fusion captures critical information relevant to AML when transformed into a lower-dimensional embedding space. These embeddings are then used by a classifier to identify potential instances of money laundering. Our method is not only scalable to large datasets but also enables deeper analysis of the learned embeddings. Experimental results indicate that our method surpasses existing baseline models, particularly when positional encodings are integrated. A core objective of our work is to enhance the efficiency of AML investigations by offering AI-powered insights. As such, AMLPD demonstrates strong potential in improving the performance of GNN-based AML detection systems.

title: A Communication-Latency-Aware Co-Simulation Platform for Safety and Comfort Evaluation of Cloud-Controlled ICVs
authors: Yongqi Zhao, Xinrui Zhang, Tomislav Mihalj, Martin Schabauer, Luis Putzer, Erik Reichmann-Blaga, Ádám Boronyák, András Rövid, Gábor Soós, Peizhi Zhang, Lu Xiong, Jia Hu, Arno Eichberger
abstract: Testing cloud-controlled intelligent connected vehicles (ICVs) requires simulation environments that faithfully emulate both vehicle behavior and realistic communication latencies. This paper proposes a latency-aware co-simulation platform integrating CarMaker and Vissim to evaluate safety and comfort under real-world vehicle-to-cloud (V2C) latency conditions. Three communication latency models, derived from empirical 5G measurements in China and Hungary, are incorporated and statistically modeled using Gamma distributions. A proactive conflict module (PCM) is proposed to dynamically control background vehicles and generate safety-critical scenarios. The platform is validated through experiments involving an exemplary system under test (SUT) across eight testing conditions combining two PCM modes (enabled/disabled) and four latency conditions (none, China, Hungary, abnormal). Safety and comfort are assessed using metrics including collision rate, distance headway, post-encroachment time, and the spectral characteristics of longitudinal acceleration. Results show that the PCM effectively increases driving environment criticality, while V2C latency reduces ride comfort and, under extreme driving conditions, further aggravates safety-critical scenarios. These findings confirm the platform’s effectiveness in systematically evaluating cloud-controlled ICVs under diverse testing conditions.

title: A 0.25 pJ/bit Data-Rate-Dependent Reconfigurable Receiver with Dual-mode Divider for Low-Power DDR Memory Interfaces
authors: Giryong Lee, Won-Young Lee
abstract: This paper presents a data-rate-dependent reconfigurable receiver for low-power DDR (LPDDR) memory interfaces covering data rates of 0.8-to-9 Gb/s. The receiver comprises a clock buffer, a quadrature clock corrector (QCC), a reconfigurable decision feedback equalizer (RDFE), a dual mode divider, and a bidirectional transition controller (BTC). The proposed reconfigurable receiver can select the sampling mode according to the speed of the input DQ. At high speeds, intersymbol interference removal can be done through equalization mode, which performs DFE using quadrature clocks. However, at low speeds, power consumption can be optimized via amplification mode, which simply amplifies input DQ using a half-rate clock with DFE turned off. The test chip was fabricated in a 28 nm CMOS process. The measurement results of the chip show an energy efficiency improvement to the DFE at 800 Mb/s by approximately 55%. Hence, energy efficiency improved from 2.13 pJ/b to 0.96 pJ/b for the proposed method.

title: Electrical Instability in Flexible Polysilicon Thin-Film Transistors Under Random Mechanical Stress
authors: Moath Alathbah, Nahid Hossain Taz, Bakhsh Mohammed Mahanna, Muhammed Shafayat Jamil, Muntasir Amin, Md. Mahir Faiyaz Anon, Mohammad Masum Billah
abstract: This article presents a comparative investigation of flexible low-temperature polysilicon thin-film transistors (LTPS TFTs) fabricated using conventional excimer laser annealing (ELA) with surface protrusions versus protrusion-free blue laser diode annealing (BLDA) under random mechanical stress. Mechanical stress was applied to the TFT array surface using a controlled impact test, where a metallic ball was randomly dropped from a height of 5 cm through an acrylic guide tube. After 30 impact cycles, BLDA-fabricated TFTs maintain excellent stability (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol {\Delta } {V}_{\text {Th}} = 0.4~{V}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${I}_{\text {GS}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> variation <5%), while ELA counterparts suffer from substantial <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${V}_{\text {Th}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> instability (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol {\Delta }{V}_{\text {Th}} = 3.3~{V}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${I}_{\text {GS}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> variation >50%). Comprehensive electrical characterization reveals that BLDA-fabricated TFTs achieve superior electrical robustness compared to ELA devices through two key mechanisms: 1) significantly reduced defect generation at polysilicon grain boundaries (GBs) by Levinson–Proano analysis and 2) effective suppression of gate insulator (GI) leakage path formation near GBs. COMSOL Multiphysics verifies that due to BLDA-processed polysilicon films exhibit 40% lower GB density than conventional ELA films, resulting in correspondingly reduced mechanical strain during the flexibility test—a critical device dimensional advantage for flexible electronics applications.

title: Mask-RadarNet: Enhancing Radar Object Detection With Spatio-Temporal Context
authors: Yuzhi Wu, Jun Liu, Guangfeng Jiang, Weijian Liu, Danilo Orlando, Li Xiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: As a cost-effective and robust technology, automotive radar has seen steady improvement during the last years. Radio frequency (RF) images, serving as a radar data format with rich semantic information, have attracted considerable interest in radar object detection. Previous RF-based models heavily rely on convolutional neural networks, leading to the high computational cost. To solve this problem, we propose a model called Mask-RadarNet to fully utilize the hierarchical semantic features from the RF image sequences. Mask-RadarNet exploits the combination of interleaved convolution and attention operations in the encoder. In addition, patch shift is introduced to Mask-RadarNet for efficient spatial-temporal feature learning. By shifting part of patches with a specific mosaic pattern in the temporal dimension, Mask-RadarNet achieves competitive performance while reducing the computational burden of the spatial-temporal modeling. In order to capture the spatial-temporal semantic contextual information, we design the class masking attention module (CMAM) in our encoder. Moreover, a lightweight auxiliary decoder is added to our model to aggregate prior maps generated from the CMAM. Experiments on the CRUW dataset demonstrate that the proposed Mask-RadarNet achieves state-of-the-art performance with relatively lower computational complexity and fewer parameters.

title: Low Probability of Identification-Based Composed Resource Allocation for Multi-Target Tracking in C-MIMO Radar Network Under Suppression Jamming
authors: Lintao Ding, Chenguang Shi, Fei Long, Jian Wang, Jianjiang Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: How to efficiently schedule the transmit beams and power resources in colocated multiple-input-multiple-output (C-MIMO) radar network to achieve better multi-target tracking (MTT) accuracy is a critical research issue. However, in electronic countermeasure environments, excessive resource allocation may lead to the interception of transmit pulses by hostile receivers. As the number of intercepted pulses increases, the transmit signals of C-MIMO radar nodes would be identified and subject to precise suppression jamming, resulting in a sharp degradation in MTT performance. To overcome this shortcoming, we propose a low probability of identification (LPID)-based composed resource allocation (CRA) scheme for MTT in C-MIMO radar network. Closed-form expressions for the predicted conditional Cramér-Rao lower bound (PC-CRLB) and the radar signal identification probability under suppression jamming are derived. Based on the tactical significance map (TSM) function, we compute the comprehensive threat level for each target in real time. We then employ the sum of products between PC-CRLB values and threat levels, and the worst-case identification probability as the quantitative metrics for MTT performance and LPID performance, respectively. The LPID-CRA is developed to jointly balance these two metrics by dynamically allocating beam-pairing and power resources within each tracking frame. To address the resulting non-convex non-linear problem, we perform an equivalent transformation of the optimization model and develop an efficient five-stage solution method that incorporates the Zoutendijk methods of feasible directions (ZMFD) and the min-cost flow algorithm. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed LPID-CRA strategy significantly enhances overall system performance.

title: Adaptive Detection of Spread Spectrum Signals With General Array Configurationg
authors: Yutong Feng, Akihito Taya, Yuuki Nishiyama, Jun Liu, Kaoru Sezaki
abstract: This paper investigates the signal activity detection problem for spread spectrum signals in low probability of detection communication systems under Gaussian disturbance with unknown covariance matrix. We assume that the receiver is equipped with an adaptive antenna array with general array configuration, comprising of a primary array with high–gain antennas and a reference array with low–gain antennas. It has been shown that this reference array structure can benefit interference suppression. Since it is difficult to derive the uniformly most powerful detector for the detection problem, we resort to using the Wald test and generalized likelihood ratio test (GLRT) schemes to design the detectors. Analytical performance of the proposed Wald test and GLRT is derived, indicating that the proposed two detectors bear constant false alarm rate property. Finally, numerical simulations are carried out, which verify the correctness of the theoretical analysis. Besides, it is revealed that the use of reference channel can facilitate to enhance the detection performance, but an increasing in the antenna number does not necessarily lead to an improvement in detection performance.

title: Group Interaction Network with Wavelet Attention for Remote Sensing Image Change Detection
authors: Xinyu Du, Huihui Dong, Zhijie Li, Zongfang Ma, Sixiang Xu, Xu Liu, Licheng Jiao
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Remote sensing image change detection (CD), as a pivotal technology for monitoring Earth’s surface dynamics, plays a crucial role in urban planning, resource management, and disaster assessment. Despite the success of deep learning-based methods, they still suffer from two significant limitations. Firstly, the inadequate exploitation of frequency-domain information restricts their ability to capture subtle structural and edge changes. Secondly, the suboptimal interaction strategies that predominantly rely on attention mechanisms or direct feature exchange that fails to fully model complex semantic differences between bi-temporal images. To address these challenges, we propose a Wavelet Attention-based Group Interaction Network (WAGINet), which leverages wavelet attention for joint frequency-spatial domain feature learning and uses a group-wise feature exchange mechanism to optimize bi-temporal interaction. The wavelet attention module decomposes features into high-low frequency components and emphasize important ones to improve edge-aware feature extraction. In the meanwhile, the group interaction strategy enables both channel-group and spatial-group feature exchange to capture the correlation between bi-temporal features while better protecting structural integrity, so that promotes more discriminative change representation. Experimental results on public LEVIR-CD and WHU-CD datasets show that WAGINet outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods, providing an effective solution for high-precision remote sensing image CD in complex scenarios. Code available at https://github.com/yizhilanmaodhh/WAGINet.

title: High Strain Rate Property Prediction and the Effect of Bismuth Concentration on the High-G Level Shock Damage with Sustained High-Temperature Operation
authors: Vishal Mehta, Pradeep Lall, Jeff Suhling, David Locker
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Reliability of electronic components in the automotive, aerospace, and oil & gas industries, among others, becomes very critical due to the prevailing harsh operating conditions. In these extreme temperatures, from $-65^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $200^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, high strain rates up to $\mathbf{1 - 1 0 0}$ sec-1 may be experienced under exposure to shock and vibration. In such conditions, the weakest link is considered to be the solder joints in electronic assemblies. Long-term high-temperature exposure has turned the degradation of solder joints into a serious concern, which in turn has inspired the addition of active dopants to SAC solders to enhance their mechanical and lifetime properties. The emphasis of this work is on how active dopants such as bismuth can improve the performance of solder alloys like SAC-Q, SAC-R, and M758 to face up to increasingly severe application environments. The present study will deal with the detailed investigations of unaged and aged SAC305, SAC-Q, and M758 lead-free solders. This research focuses on the comprehensive testing of unaged and aged SAC305, SAC-Q, and M758 lead-free solders. Specifically, Ultimate Tensile Strength (UTS) and Elastic Modulus (E) were measured under varied strain rates of $\mathbf{1 0}, \mathbf{3 5}, \mathbf{5 0}$, and $\mathbf{7 5}$ per second, at temperatures ranging from $-65^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $+200^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. The experimental data were used in the development of predictive models that correlate the content of Bismuth with mechanical properties and thermal degradation rates. These models allowed for the prediction of properties in SAC solders with higher Bi % content, e.g., SAC + 4% Bismuth. In addition, the parameters of the Anand Model have been computed for both tested and predicted solder alloys, allowing for detailed characterization of their viscoplastic behavior. In the most published literature, researchers have studied the PCB-Package assemblies under drop/shock using the older JEDEC std. JESD22B111 (2003) states the test board size to be $132 \times 77 \times 1.6 \mathrm{~mm}$ (Krist et.al 2008, Krämer 2009, Cheng 2016). In this work, FEA simulations were conducted to model the drop events of the PCBCABGA208 assemblies by using the Input-G technique and the Anand viscoplasticity model. The assembly of the PCB Package is designed according to the latest JEDEC std. JESD22-B111A, which states the test board size to be $77 \times 77 \times 1 \mathrm{~mm}$. It is found that doped SAC solders with increased Bismuth content exhibit enhanced mechanical properties and improved resistance against thermal degradation.

title: Remotely Controlled Continuous Surveillance of Viral RNAs in Wastewater via LoRa Network
authors: Aneesh Kshirsagar, Anthony J. Politza, Ming Dong, Weihua Guan
abstract: Tracking the rapid spread of infectious diseases such as COVID-19 poses a significant global health challenge, as traditional testing methods struggle to detect asymptomatic carriers and effectively manage outbreaks. To address this, we present a scalable network for wastewater-based epidemiology, consisting of connected nucleic acid testing devices that enable Reverse Transcription - Loop-mediated Isothermal Amplification (RT-LAMP) assay directly on raw wastewater samples for SARS-CoV-2 detection. Each battery-powered analyzer monitors fluorescence emissions from the reactions in real-time on a microfluidic cartridge and transmits data via long-range radio (LoRa) to a gateway that uploads it to a No-SQL cloud database. A dashboard allows remote control of the analyzers and displays both live and historical spatiotemporal data through advanced geotagging, supporting the identification of emerging hotspots. RT-LAMP validation on the analyzer confirmed qualitative detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA across 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sup> to 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> copies per reaction, with moderate linearity (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.84). To the best of our knowledge, this innovative approach demonstrates for the first time a system that supports long-term, continuous, unmonitored surveillance and provides critical data to prompt proactive corrective measures while circumventing traditional resource-intensive testing methods.

title: Enhanced Capillary-Driven Boiling in Two-Phase Micro-cooler with Engineered Copper Inverse Opals (CIOs) Wick and Silicon 3D Manifold for High Heat Flux Cooling Application
authors: Heungdong Kwon, Daeyoung Kong, James Palko, Ercan M. Dede, Mehdi Asheghi, Kenneth E. Goodson
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Capillary-driven boiling using the microporous structures exhibits an exceptional two-phase heat transfer performance due to the presence of numerous nucleation sites and effective liquid-vapor separation. In addition, the high capillary pressure due to the small pore size enables passive liquid supply. Therefore, capillary-driven boiling is a promising candidate for energy-efficient microcoolers in high-heat-flux electronics. However, achieving area scalability is challenging due to significant viscous pressure losses along the wick, which hinder liquid transport across the boiling region. This limitation poses a major obstacle to contemporary large-area, high-performance chip cooling solutions and requires the development of the area-scalable capillary-driven two-phase cooler. In the present study, we have significantly improved the performance and expanded the cooling area of a capillary-driven micro-cooler with the augmented microporous layers over “sparse” and “dense” micro pin arrays to improve the two-phase heat transfer coefficient in conjunction with a capillary-based silicon open microchannel manifold (channel spacing of $\mathbf{5 7 0, 1 1 4 0}$ and $\mathbf{1 7 1 0 ~} \boldsymbol{\mu} \mathbf{m}$), for efficient liquid delivery and vapor extraction, targeting exit vapor quality, $x_{\mathrm{e}} \approx 1$. Infrared thermography is employed to characterize the spatial temperature distribution and to understand the underlying heat and mass transfer mechanism. To extract the contribution of the two-phase heat transfer from the applied heat flux, the flow rate at the drainages in the test vehicle is measured to estimate the boiling rate at the critical heat flux level. We demonstrated critical heat flux level $\approx 200 \mathrm{Wcm}^{-2}$ and a superheat of $\approx 4^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, achieving heat transfer coefficient $\approx 430 \mathrm{kWm}^{-20} \mathrm{C}^{-1}$ and $x_{\mathrm{e}} \approx 1$ with minimum inlet flow rates of $5 \mathrm{~g}^{(\mathrm{min})^{-1}}$. Even a higher CHF level of $\approx 450 \mathrm{Wcm}^{-2}$ with superheat $\approx 7^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, is achieved using inlet flow rate of $15 \mathbf{g}(\mathbf{m i n})^{-1}$ but with $x_{e} \approx 0.65$. The 3D manifold with microchannels spacing of $1140 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ provided the right balance of efficient liquid delivery for capillary wicking and open pathways for vapor extraction, showing the highest critical heat flux, given the same supplied flow rate. The two-phase cooler assisted by capillary-driven boiling in the previous studies typically supplied liquid across the perimeter of the wick, limiting their scalability and performance. The integration of a silicon microchannel manifold with a copper inverse opal porous layer overcomes these limitations by enhancing liquid flow distribution and preventing local dryout, enabling efficient two-phase heat transfer over larger areas. Therefore, the two-phase cooling scheme in this study demonstrates large-area capillary-driven boiling without compromising high heat transfer efficiency, making it a promising solution for contemporary high-performance chip cooling.

title: Efficient Vehicle Community Formation for Profit Maximization in Vehicular Cloud Computing
authors: Mohamed Facil T R
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
abstract: Vehicular cloud computing uses idle computational resources in vehicles to provide low-latency cloud-like services. We propose a dynamic, game-theoretic coalition formation mechanism in which vehicles merge or split coalitions based on individual profit maximization. Using a non-cooperative model and a merge-split strategy with an estimated Banzhaf value for fair profit distribution, our approach forms stable, high-profit communities. Simulations show that profits can be up to double those of a random allocation mechanism across various request sizes.

title: Gas Sensor with Integrated Preconcentrator for Time-Based Bacterial Growth Monitoring
authors: Christoforos Panteli, Marios Stylianou, Andreas Anastasiou, Chrysafis Andreou
abstract: Gas sensors are ideal for noninvasive and continuous monitoring applications, but are limited by low-abundance analytes. Preconcentrators can increase the local concentration of analytes, improving the response of gas sensors. Here, an in-house made preconcentrator is integrated on a commercial metal oxide gas sensor and boosts its response to bacterial culture gases. Tenax TA was packed inside a PTFE tube, and a nickel-chrome wire was wound around it as a heater. The preconcentrator was mounted on a custom PTFE chamber for a BME688 gas sensor on a PCB. As a control, a second sensor with no preconcentrator was connected in parallel via a T-connector. A vacuum pump was used to sample the gases released during clinical standard bacterial cultures inside an incubator at 37<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">→</sup>C. Microcontrollers logged the data from both sensors and controlled the heater to induce thermal adsorption/desorption cycles every 5 minutes. The time series data from the two sensors were analysed using change point detection. The preconcentrator-sensor showed 18.8 times signal enhancement compared to the bare sensor. Gas monitoring with preconcentrator-integrated sensors could enable more sensitive and timely detection of infections in time-sensitive settings.

title: A Physics-Informed and Pre-Training Graph Neural Network for Power System Security Verification
authors: Yongtao Chen, Xinyu Liu, Tao Chen, Yanan Yu, Tangyao Feng, Maosheng Gao, Juan Yu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Security verification is essential for the power system operation mode arrangement. To overcome the computational burden of massive verification criteria, the neural network is applied to accelerate their security verification calculation. However, the various verification criteria with different topologies challenge the learning of neural networks. To this end, this paper proposes a physics-informed and pre-trained graph neural network (GNN) to deal with the various topologies in different verification criteria. On one hand, the power flow models are embedded into the feature aggregation method in GNN, enhancing the topological feature extraction and improving the adaptability to various criteria. On the other hand, the unbalanced power injections calculated using the predictions of GNN are applied to measure the calculation precision, therefore pre-training the GNN with stochastic power injections to enhance its feature extraction ability. According to the simulation in the IEEE 30-bus system with different testing data, the proposed method shows better calculation accuracy and adaptability to different verification criteria compared to the existing methods.

title: Enhancing Transaction Fraud Detection in Digital Banking with Explainable AI
authors: Kaung Wai Thar, Thinn Thinn Wai
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: The rapid growth of digital banking has escalated financial fraud, necessitating detection systems that balance high accuracy with operational transparency. This paper presents a hybrid machine learning framework that integrates Hidden Markov Models (HMM) for sequential behavioral analysis with XGBoost for classification, specifically designed for highly imbalanced transactional data. A key innovation is the incorporation of SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) values, which provide both global and local interpretability of model predictions, addressing the black-box nature of conventional machine learning systems. Experimental validation on a real-world digital banking dataset demonstrates significant performance improvements, with our model achieving an F1-score of 0.83 and recall of 0.82, substantially outperforming baseline approaches. SHAP-based interpretation reveals that HMM-derived features— particularly transaction sequence entropy and log-likelihood scores—serve as pivotal indicators of fraudulent activity. The proposed framework not only enhances detection accuracy but also delivers actionable insights into model decision-making processes, offering a comprehensive solution that balances predictive power with regulatory compliance and operational trustworthiness in financial environments.

title: Exploring Multisensory Feedback for Robotic Ultrasound in XR
authors: Tianyu Song, Sasan Matinfar, Laura Schütz, Feng Li, Ulrich Eck, Nassir Navab
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Robotic ultrasound (RUS) presents new opportunities for remote diagnostics but introduces challenges related to perceptual transparency and operator trust. To address this, we explore the use of multisensory feedback by combining visual and auditory cues within an Extended Reality (XR) interface to support physicians during robot-assisted ultrasound procedures. We developed a prototype system that visualizes probe force and provides real-time sonification using both musical and physics-based approaches. A user study in a simulated XR environment evaluated five feedback conditions across concurrent imaging, force monitoring, and patient interaction tasks. Initial findings suggest that audiovisual feedback may reduce cognitive load and enhance task coordination. This work offers early insights into the design of multimodal interfaces for clinical human–robot interaction.

title: Network Sensor Abnormal Data Monitoring Application Based on Deep Learning Model
authors: Feng Zhang, Jinzhong Yang, Dong Zhang, Xiaohui Kang, Baojing Han
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: This study proposes an innovative three-dimensional convolutional autoencoder with temporal clustering (3D-CAE-TC) model. First, a spatiotemporal data cube is constructed using a sliding window. An encoder consisting of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1283 \times 3 \times 3$</tex> convolutional kernels is used to extract high-dimensional spatiotemporal features. After rectified linear unit (ReLU) activation and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 \times 5$</tex> max pooling for dimensionality reduction, the data is reconstructed using a symmetric deconvolutional decoder. A dynamic time warping (DTW) distance-constrained K-shaped clustering module is innovatively introduced to perform pattern segmentation on latent spatial features, enhancing the interpretability of anomalies. A dual-criteria anomaly scoring mechanism is constructed using reconstruction error and clustering confidence. In real-world testing on the Intel Berkeley Lab sensor dataset, the model achieved a maximum accuracy of 99.4 %, a minimum false alarm rate of 3.9 %, and detection latency within 11.5 ms. It successfully identified various anomalies, including temperature sensor drift and burst interference.

title: MRLingo: A Mixed Reality Approach for Situated Vocabulary Learning
authors: Ziad Elshereif, Busra Balaban, Shehabeldin Solyman, Michael Sedlmair, Carlos Quijano-Chavez
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We present MRLingo, a mixed reality vocabulary learning approach that uses real-time object recognition to offer vocabulary acquisition. MRLingo runs dynamically in real-life contexts, offering more flexibility than traditional devices like smartphones and desktops. Likewise, MRLingo offers visual word translations, audio pronunciation, and quizzes, reinforcing vocabulary memorization. A user study was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of MR-Lingo and compare it with a desktop-based prototype. Results show that MRLingo significantly outperforms engagement and usability, though challenges remain in cluttered or occluded contexts.

title: Current-Fed High-Gain DC-DC Converter Based on the Dual Active Bridge Topology for Green Hydrogen Applications
authors: Valdir De Santana, Moisés Magalhães, Samir Mussa, Gustavo Henn, Herminio Oliveira Filho
abstract: This paper presents a study of a bidirectional high-gain dc-dc converter with coupled inductors. Based on the Dual Active Bridge (DAB) topology, the phase-shift technique is applied to control the power flow, simplifying the control strategy and ensuring soft-switching operation. A mathematical analysis is performed to characterize both the power flow behavior and the dynamic model of the converter. To validate the proposed topology, a design example rated at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$28 ~\mathrm{V} / 180 ~\mathrm{V}$</tex> and 500 W is simulated. The results demonstrate that the converter can achieve high voltage gain while maintaining soft-switching operation and simplified control, confirming its potential for applications in energy storage and low- to medium-power systems.

title: Image Selective Encryption Analysis using Mutual Information in CNN Based Embedding Space
authors: Ikram Messadi, Giulia Cervia, Vincent Itier
publish: 2025 13th European Workshop on Visual Information Processing (EUVIP)
abstract: As digital data transmission continues to scale, concerns about privacy grow increasingly urgent-yet privacy remains a socially constructed and ambiguously defined concept, lacking a universally accepted quantitative measure. This work examines information leakage in image data, a domain where information-theoretic guarantees are still underexplored. At the intersection of deep learning, information theory, and cryptography, we investigate the use of mutual information (MI) estimators - in particular, the empirical estimator and the MINE framework - to detect leakage from selectively encrypted images. Motivated by the intuition that a robust estimator would require a probabilistic frameworks that can capture spatial dependencies and residual structures - even within encrypted representations - our work represent a promising direction for image information leakage estimation.

title: Improving Multilingual Speech Recognition for Cognitive Voice Interfaces Using Real Code-Switching Data
authors: Suresh Kurapati, Muhamed Ihsan, Monika Rani. H G, Srinju. M, Lakshmi Priya. N
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In recent years, Multilingual Speech Recognition (MSR) has become vital for allowing accurate and real-time cognitive voice interfaces, as it eliminates the need for distinct language identification modules. However, traditional approaches face challenges, such as phonetic confusion across languages and poor robustness in natural multilingual conversations. Hence, this research proposes an Artificial Intelligence (AI)-enabled MSR framework based on Waveform to Vector, version 2.0, with Cross-Lingual Speech Representation (Wav2Vec 2.0 -XLSR53) with real CodeSwitching (CS) training data to capture spontaneous language mixing more accurately. The gathered data were then preprocessed using silence trimming, normalization, and segmentation to standardize the input quality. This was followed by embedding generation by the Language-agnostic Bert Sentence Embedding (LaBSE) model in which every sentence pair over several languages was designed based on cosine similarity scores. After that, preprocessing was used to fine-tune the Wav2Vec 2.0 -XLSR53 model for efficient alignment among audio and transcripts. Finally, the proposed framework attained an enhanced Word Error Rate (WER), mainly in midsentence code-switching scenarios, which allowed accurate transcription for cognitive voice interfaces. Experimental calculations on Spanish, Portuguese, and Russian show that the proposed AI-MSRWav2Vec2-XLSR-CS system improves the WER by 12-15% under high-similarity conditions, significantly outperforming baselines trained solely on synthetic bilingual data.

title: Real Time Disease Monitoring and Alert System for Public Health Safety
authors: P. Shre Hari, M. Shyam Sankar, L. Srinivasan, V. Suresh, S.R.Ramya
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: Real Time Disease Monitoring and Alert System for Public Health Safety as health-focused project which applies real-time data processing alongside proactive alert procedures to contain infectious disease transmission. The swift prevention of disease spread becomes essential because of the rapid development of our contemporary world. The system includes two operational components which are admin panel together with hardware-based monitoring capabilities. The administrative interface helps handle disease information by letting them manage patient disease types and location records. The system enables authorized personnel to make database modifications by inserting new data and modifying existing obsolete information. This operation maintains database consistency with current information. All disease-spread information is stored within the system database which administrators need to monitor for accuracy. Each hotspot location receives a circular marking extending 400 meters which designates the zone as red alert area. The system delivers real-time mobile alerts to people who enter these areas containing protective instructions alongside crisis prevention tips the disease. The system operates to increase public awareness and accelerate actions throughout the community. The project provides information to users to improve public health safety and also halt disease spread location-based alerts system implemented. the system uses prevention steps for proactive health monitoring.

title: A Multi-Criteria Risk Assessment of Smart Grid Infrastructure to Ensure a Balance Between Innovation and Cybersecurity
authors: Dauren Sagidullauly, Nurkhat Zhakiyev, Zamira Mukhtarova, Dauren Gabdullayev
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: The greater digitalization of smart grid infrastructure offers opportunities to innovate, while simultaneously providing the potential to face severe cybersecurity challenges. In avoiding this issue, a proper risk assessment methodology is needed to provide a solution that will provide a proper balance between the advancements of technologies and the corresponding threats to the associated security. In this paper, a MCDM-based risk assessment system is provided that evaluates threats and can reduce the threats of smart grids. It integrates AHP, TOPSIS, and ELECTRE to properly consider various factors of threats, plan priority measures of security, and improve the decision-making approach to the best possible extent. The suggested approach actually offers the opportunity to the stakeholders to compromise between the security aspect and the advancements by analyzing the threats of cybersecurity threats, operational expenditures, and the advancements of technologies. It is demonstrated that a multi-criteria risk analysis increases the stability and effectiveness of the decision-making approach. Therefore, the suggested approach is needed to manage the smart grid security.

title: Screen-Printed In-Mold Electronics Reliability on Polycarbonate Substrates Under Sustained HighTemperature Conditions
authors: Shriram Kulkarni, Pradeep Lall, Scott Miller
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: In-mold electronics (IME) technology offers significant advantages in design flexibility and functionality for automotive applications, but ensuring the reliability of circuits after thermoforming and prolonged high-temperature exposure remains a challenge. This study addresses this challenge by evaluating the performance and durability of screen-printed circuits on polycarbonate (PC) substrates. Conductive traces and operational amplifier circuits will be screen-printed and assembled with surface-mount devices using a thermoformable conductive adhesive. The samples will undergo thermoforming to replicate the mechanical deformation typical of automotive components, followed by High-Temperature Operating Life (HTOL) testing at $\mathbf{8 5}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}} \mathbf{C}$ for $\mathbf{1, 0 0 0}$ hours following the AEC-Q100 Grade 3 standard. Electrical performance will be assessed before and after thermoforming and throughout thermal testing, while failure analysis will identify key degradation mechanisms. The results are expected to demonstrate that screen-printed IME circuits on PC substrates can withstand mechanical and thermal stresses, paving the way for their reliable integration into innovative and complex automotive components.

title: Multi-Class ECG Classification using Discrete Wavelet Deep Learning
authors: Ei Marlar Win, Amy Tun, Khant Kyawt Kyawt Theint
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: Electrocardiogram recordings can be applied to monitor the functions of the heart and circulatory system as a reliable measurement method. In recent times, there has been a lot of focus on accurate identification of heart beats. Feature extraction is the process of measuring specific features or properties. It is to reduce the specified original data and recognize one input pattern from another. The feature vector is generated by wavelet transform and statistical calculations. The Daubechies db4, db6, db16, symlet for discrete wavelet transform and morlet for continuous wavelet transform are used to compare the wavelet coefficients and their accuracies in this study. The proposed model combines band pass filter and normalization in preprocessing, wavelet transform for feature extraction, and a classifier model with CNN attention. This study utilizes the MIT-BIH dataset (48 half-hour recordings sampled at 360Hz). Compared to alternative wavelets, this feature extraction of db16 wavelet approach provides higher accuracy, enabling the model to reach 97% classification performance. The issue of dataset imbalance is managed by incorporating balanced class weights. Additionally, the wavelet with CNN used for comparative analysis is presented.

title: Exploring XR Applications in Healthcare and Well-being: A Systematic Review of IEEE VR and ISMAR (2020–2025)
authors: Md Alamin Hossain, M. Rasel Mahmud
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: The recent era has observed a significant amount of research activities in augmented reality (AR), virtual reality (VR), and mixed reality (MR) in several fields, including healthcare and well-being. Those works are getting published in renowned journals and conference proceedings. In this review paper, we have worked on the publications in IEEE VR and ISMAR since the year 2020, two premier venues for researchers in the AR/VR/MR field. We performed several stages of filtering through the proceedings of these conferences, and shortlisted 61 papers (30 from IEEE VR and 31 from ISMAR) for our work. According to the research scope, tool, application, and contribution, we have categorized the selected papers into several categories: surgical guidance, imaging, physical and mental rehabilitation, emotional improvement, etc. We have analyzed those papers categorically, explored the general trend, research gaps, limitations, future scope, overall contribution, citation count, country of origin, etc. This review paper will help researchers, academicians, healthcare professionals, practitioners, etc., to have better insight into present-day healthcare tools and applications, research trends, and future directions.

title: Intelligent and Boosted Learning Framework for Precise Marketing in E - Commerce
authors: Jiaqi Dong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: E-commerce precision marketing has opened huge avenues for brand promotions, due to the emergence of Artificial Intelligence(AI), and Big data analytics. Moreover, it is crucial to understand customer's interaction for improving the strategies and optimizing marketing campaigns. Sentimental analysis is the process of identifying the customers' behaviour through texts, which widely helps in improving the process of E-commerce precision marketing. In the recent times, Machine Learning and Deep Learning algorithms have performed a significant part in analysing the sentiments across the various digital and social platforms. But these algorithms need more enhancements in terms of high performance and computations, handling larger datasets. In this regard, the research paper proposes the novel Attention Evoked Boosted Gated recurrent Units (AE-BGRU) for analysing the sentiments across the larger datasets. The comprehensive experimentation was conducted using the Kaggle Marketing Campaigns datasets and evaluation metrics are measured. To prove excellence of proposed model, performance of the suggested boosted network was compared with baseline architectures. Empirical results illustrated suggested model has achieved the accuracy (0.99), precision (0.987), recall (0.986) and F1-score (0.99) also outperforms the other existing models. This research proves the strength of the optimized feedforward network is its potential to minimize overfitting, enhance generalization, and deliver a performance mechanism that guarantees efficient Precision marketing in e-commerce in significantly dynamic online settings.

title: Humidity and High-temperature Effects on non-PFAS Thermal Interface and Underfill Materials
authors: Padmanava Choudhury, Aathi Pandurangan, Pradeep Lall
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Per-polyfluoroalkyl substances, also known as forever chemicals, have uniquely useful characteristics that have made them ubiquitous in their use for industrial, commercial, and electronics applications, but there are several epidemiological studies linked to severe health effects such as liver diseases and thyroid malfunctions to these PFAS chemicals. A unified approach must be taken to remove these chemicals from electronic applications so that there is a minimum amount of waste generated by PFAS chemicals. Our solution is to show that non-PFAS materials have the same reliability in the end-use environment as in the case of PFAS so that the industry moves away from PFAS materials. In this study, we aim to show the interface between nonPFAS Underfills/Substrate and non-PFAS TIM/Cu have similar degradation properties when subjected to high temperature and humidity end-use conditions. The current state of the art shows there is a huge lack of literature in non-PFAS underfills. Most literature includes PFAS underfill reliability based on the material evolution of amine-based epoxies and a combination of interface mechanics developed from amine-based underfills and substrates. There are no long-term reliability studies conducted on non-PFAS underfills, and the degradation phenomena of non-PFAS underfill. Research presented in this paper includes (1) the development of non-PFAS interface samples between Underfills and Substrates, (2) test the UF/Substrate samples at $60 \mathrm{RH} / 60 \mathrm{C}$ and 85 R.H/85 C condition (3) develop non-PFAS interface sample for TIM/Cu substrate, (4) Arrhenius and peck model for accelerated factors (5) evaluate CZM parameters for interfaces (6) evaluate FTIR spectroscopy results for bulk TIMs. In addition, the evolution of mode-1 and mode-2 stress intensity factors is presented for non-PFAS underfills. Activation energy is calculated for the evolution of non-PFAS underfills in addition to the acceleration factors for temperature-humidity exposure.

title: Enabling Interoperability Within the Digital Twin Architecture for Emergency Management
authors: Iryna Osadcha, Eilif Hjelseth, Caroline McMullan, Andrius Jurelionis
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: This study investigates the application of digital twin technology for emergency management, focusing on interoperability from a human-centric perspective. Traditionally, research on digital twins has emphasized semantic and technical interoperability, often overlooking the critical aspect of how human users interact with systems. This paper explores how digital twin systems can enhance emergency response by delivering relevant information at the right time. The research focuses on large-scale evacuation strategies, particularly for university campuses, and examines how static and dynamic data about buildings and the environment can be better organized and communicated. By shifting the focus from "system-to-system" to "person-to-system" interoperability, the study proposes a framework based on Levels of Information Systems Interoperability (LISI) and autonomy levels of digital twins. It introduces the "APAR" criteria—amount, priority, accuracy, and reuse—for assessing data needs during emergencies, aiming to improve decision-making and information delivery to the first responders.

title: Transformerless Single-Phase Unified Power Quality Conditioner Based on Two-Leg Converter with a Single DC-Link Capacitor
authors: Ademar Alves dos Santos Júnior, Cursino Brandão Jacobina, Jean Torelli Cardoso, Amanda Pereira Monteiro, Reuben Palmer Rezende de Sousa
abstract: This paper proposes a transformerless single-phase unified power quality conditioner (UPQC) based on two-leg converter with a single DC-link capacitor. This topology eliminates the connection to the DC-link midpoint by using a coupling capacitor to block the DC component introduced by the new configuration. As a result, the voltage established across the capacitor, especially under inductive load conditions, allows for a reduction in the DC-link voltage compared to other topologies already presented in literature. The proposed control scheme ensures a stable load voltage, unity power factor operation at the grid side, and regulation of the DC-link voltage under voltage sags and swells. Preliminary simulation and experimental results are provided in order to validate the performance and feasibility of the proposed topology.

title: Effect of two-step methane concentration on the quality and growth rate of diamond film grown by hotfilament chemical vapor deposition (HFCVD)
