authors: Dipa Devkota, Florence Nugera, Jonathan Anderson, K.C. Anupam, Anival Ayala, Biddhut Lamichhane, Chris Engdahl, Edwin L Piner, Mark W Holtz
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: We present a novel work on growing diamonds using two-step methane concentration. Previously, it was found that lower methane percentage growth gives better-quality diamonds but at the expense of a lower growth rate. Using this two-step methane, we got a similar quality as a lower methane percentage growth but at a faster growth rate.

title: From Waste to Watts: Hybrid MSW-PTC Power Plants for Decarbonization and Sustainable Energy Generation
authors: Brunella Bermudes Prati Sant'Ana, Jussara Farias Fardin
abstract: This study evaluates the GHG's emissions and energy generation of a hybrid MSW-PTC power plant in Espírito Santo. Compared to landfilling - which emits from 0.90 up to 1.26 kg of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2} e q$</tex> per kg of MSW - the hybrid system reduces net emissions to 0.769 kg of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2} e q$</tex> per kg of MSW, achieving up to 39 % reduction while generating around 77 MW of continuous renewable energy. By processing MSW, the plant avoids landfill expansion costs and leverages the region's high solar irradiation. The results demonstrate that waste-to-energy conversion, when paired with solar thermal input, offers a scalable solution for decarbonization in developing regions, simultaneously addressing waste management crises and clean energy transitions.

title: Design and Development of a Privacy-Preserving Health Record Exchange Framework Using Blockchain for Smart Healthcare
authors: Shankar Gadve, Goldi Soni
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The rapid growth of electronic health systems has significantly transformed healthcare by digitizing patient records into Electronic Health Records (EHRs), thereby improving clinical efficiency, accessibility, and real-time disease monitoring. Despite these advancements, existing health record exchange systems face persistent challenges, including privacy breaches, limited interoperability, high storage overhead, and scalability constraints. Addressing these issues requires a comprehensive solution that ensures both robust security and seamless data sharing across healthcare environments. This study introduces a blockchain-enabled, privacy-preserving framework that integrates advanced cryptographic methods such as ciphertext-policy attribute-based encryption (CP-ABE), federated learning, and a hybrid blockchain architecture. The design emphasizes fine-grained, patient-centric access control, safeguarding sensitive health information while employing smart contracts for automated policy enforcement and compliance monitoring. To validate its effectiveness, comparative analyses were conducted against state-of-the-art models, including lightweight encryption with federated learning, Blowfish-based blockchain, IPFS-enabled HealthRecChain, and homomorphic encryption techniques. Performance evaluation covered twelve key parameters, including privacy preservation, scalability, latency, computational efficiency, encryption speed, storage utilization, interoperability, and auditability. Experimental results show that the proposed framework delivers superior outcomes, achieving 96% data privacy, supporting up to 1200 transactions per second (TPS), reducing latency to 180 ms, and providing enhanced brute-force resistance with a score of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.5 / 10$</tex>. Additionally, it demonstrated improved efficiency in encryption/decryption, key management, and secure data exchange across heterogeneous systems. In conclusion, the framework offers a scalable, secure, and ethically aligned solution for health record exchange. By balancing decentralization, high performance, and patientcentered governance, it lays a strong foundation for nextgeneration smart healthcare ecosystems.

title: Digital Transformations in Urban Mobility and Logistics
authors: Olexiy Kuzkin, Carsten Wolff, Serhii Tabunshchyk, Kinga Kornienko, Dariusz Mierzwinski, Rafal Bogucki
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: The paper highlights the main approaches, gains, and problems in leveraging digital technologies regarding urban mobility and logistics. The authors systematized evolution of the technological changes from Mobility 1.0 to 4.0 in conjunction with the Industry 1.0 to 4.0 development. This evolution emphasizes the need for changes in the conventional approaches of transport and logistics operators regarding their operational activity and business models towards to new digitalized ones which are based on the technologies of Industry 4.0.

title: Review of Filter Topologies for Multi-Megawatt Inverters with Passive and Active Damping Methods
authors: Luiz Guilherme Albino De Souza, Tamiris Grossl Bade, Telles Brunelli Lazzarin
abstract: The design of output filters for multi-megawatt inverters faces significant challenges due to their low switching frequency, which leaves a narrow band between the low-frequency control loop and the switching harmonics. This paper reviews and compares third- and fourth-order filter topologies, including LCL and LLCL configurations, with emphasis on offshore wind power systems operating around 1 kHz. Key sizing criteria reported in the literature are summarized, and both passive and active damping methods are evaluated in terms of total harmonic distortion (THD), losses, and implementation complexity. The analysis highlights promising trade-offs, identifying two passive damping topologies with reduced losses as superior, alongside the virtual-resistor active damping as a highly effective control-based technique. The results provide practical guidelines for the design of efficient filters under harsh offshore conditions and establish a foundation for future simulation and experimental validation.

title: Presenting Intangible Cultural Heritage of Megalithic Sites using Immersive XR Environments
authors: Masood Masoodian, Inkeri Aula, Alicia Núñez García, Sofia de la Fuente García, Saturnino Luz
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: This poster showcases an immersive XR museum installation that presents the emotional, experiential and environmental dimensions of intangible cultural heritage associated with the Calanais megalithic cultural heritage sites, located in Scotland. The installation consists of an XR mobile app on a tablet device, a large interactive display app, and a directional speaker sound system that collectively create the immersive environment in which a range audiovisual media content – including animations based on human narratives of related intangible cultural heritage – is presented.

title: Robust Predictive Control Applied to Three-Phase Induction Motor
authors: Alana de Oliveira Ferro, Francisco Amaury Rios Filho, Vanessa Siqueira De Castro Texeira, Ícaro Bezerra Viana
abstract: This article applies a robust finite control set model predictive control (FCS-MPC) technique to a three-phase induction motor (IM), comparing the performance of two rotor flux orientation strategies: direct (based on flux estimator) and indirect (slip-based). The machine model and control strategy were implemented in Simulink/MATLAB, and the system was subjected to parametric variations of the stator and rotor resistances. The results demonstrate the robustness of predictive control, with fast settling times and low sensitivity to variations in machine parameters. In this case, the direct orientation was superior in accuracy and dynamic response, while the indirect orientation was simpler to implement. The contributions include systematically comparing flux orientation strategies and validating the predictive control scheme under parametric uncertainties.

title: Reliability of Opto-electronics Thermal Cycles plus Vibrations
authors: Alireza Azizi, Reza Ghaffarian
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: This paper presents reliability test results for three different commercial opto-electronic switches under sequential thermal cycles either in vacuum or in air chamber followed by vibration to determine their robustness for use in space environment. Details of switching mechanisms are suppliers’ proprietary, but most are selected to cover advanced device technologies commonly known as MicroelectroMechanical Systems (MEMS) or opto-electrical. Switching of the light occurs by mechanical movement of the mirror or electro-optical mechanism to route laser light to a selected channel. For high-reliability space applications, it is critical to determine reliability of these devices, especially under vacuum and vibration as well as to characterize their failure mechanisms for better definition of risk for a mission. All the switches were characterized before and after each environmental test for performance and comparison. The sequential approach started with the performance characterization at temperatures in vacuum since the outgassing could affect reflectivity of the mirror and degrades output power. After initial characterization, it followed with 6 thermal vacuum cycles, started at the lowest functional temperature ranges and were increased to their maximum operation temperature $\left(-5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} / 70^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)$. The three devices were then subjected to vibration level of 9.8 Grms for 4 minutes to establish the level of robustness. The sequential steps allowed to not only establish the mission requirement steps, e.g. launch (vibration), and use (thermal vacuum), but it also established the cycling and vibration synergism on time to failures if Miner’s rule applies and to determine interaction of failure mechanisms. The performance tests were followed with X-ray inspection to verify its integrity condition as well as to determine the internal build configuration. The test data with detailed procedure of test results are presented. Detailed failure analyses with failure mechanisms are also presented.

title: Influence of a Visual Cue and Agency on the Ventriloquism Effect for a Projected Extended Hand
authors: Ao Ishikawa, Yushi Sato, Kosuke Sato, Daisuke Iwai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Human auditory localization is strongly influenced by visual cues, as demonstrated by the ventriloquism effect. With the development of augmented bodies, users can interact with distant objects in novel ways. However, the perceptual mechanisms of sound localization in these augmented body contexts remain unclear. In this study, we examined the influence of a visual cue and the user engagement type (manual action vs. passive observation) on the ventriloquism effect. Our results showed that the presence of the projected extended hand significantly enhanced the ventriloquism effect, whereas manual action did not affect its strength compared to passive observation, which contrasts with previous findings.

title: A step towards biocompatible and bioresorbable MIP-based sensor for in vivo sensing
authors: T. Di Giulio, I. Muhammad Asif, F. Gagliani, F. Persano, C. Malitesta, M. Corsi, G. Barillaro, E. Mazzotta
abstract: This work presents a novel, room-temperature vapor-phase polymerization method for fabricating molecularly imprinted polymers (MIPs) on nanostructured transducers, offering a transformative approach to biosensor development. By employing pyrrole (Py) as a functional monomer in vapor form, our technique circumvents the limitations of conventional liquid-phase deposition—such as uneven film growth and pore blockage—thereby ensuring uniform coating and preserving the integrity of sensitive template molecules. The innovative process yields a polypyrrole (PPy)-based MIP with high specificity and sensitivity, as demonstrated by its application in a nanostructured porous silicon optical transducer for the in vitro detection of human hemoglobin (HHb). This sensor not only exhibits remarkable reliability and reusability over a one-month period in human plasma but also paves the way for integration into advanced, miniaturized diagnostic platforms. Moreover, we are extending our approach to functionalize novel bioresorbable transducers based on PLGA-embedded nanostructured PSiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>. The combination of PPy-based MIPs with PLGA/PSiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> offers a dual advantage: the creation of highly selective recognition sites and complete biocompatibility, which is essential for in vivo applications. This development is a key component of the RESORB project (https://www.resorb-project.eu/), aimed at real-time, in vivo drug monitoring, and represents a significant leap forward in implantable biosensor technology. Our innovative method not only enhances sensor performance in terms of sensitivity, selectivity, and stability but also promises to bridge the gap between laboratory-based sensor research and practical clinical applications. This breakthrough opens new avenues for next-generation diagnostics and personalized therapeutic management, marking a paradigm shift in the design and implementation of biosensing platforms.

title: DUCK-U-Net: A Deep Learning Framework for Multiclass Brain Tumor Segmentation
authors: Diptendu Majumdar, Tanuj Chaudhuri, Arpan Piplai, Debdeep Bhowmick, Sukanya Mitra, Deboleena Sadhukhan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: Brain tumors are heterogeneous and intricate, and therefore precise segmentation in Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) images is important for diagnosis and treatment. Automated and prompt segmentation with high accuracy scores is commanding in today’s era. This paper is focused on achieving a successful multi-class brain tumor segmentation with the help of the BraTS 2020 dataset, which consists of annotated multi-modal Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scans. This work is based on DUCK-U-Net, which is the fusion of DUCK-Net and the traditional U-Net and offers good performance on the multi-class brain tumor segmentation database. e. The proposed DUCK-U-Net architecture has been shown to outperform conventional models such as U-Net, U-Net with Inception blocks, and U-Net with ResNet blocks, having a Dice Score of 0.74, IoU Score of 0.61, Sensitivity of 0.85, and Specificity of 0.98. Furthermore, the DUCK-U-Net model reports reduced computational time compared to other popular networks. The proposed DUCK-U-Net reports accurate and efficient brain tumor segmentation. Therefore, this model could be employed for real-time clinical applications soon. An application is also being proposed based on this study.

title: Model Predictive Control for Reactive Power Compensation Using Three-Level NPC Converters
authors: Jairo De Oliveira, Matías Aguilar, Juan Insfran, Raúl Gregor, Leonardo Comparatore, Osvaldo González
abstract: Harmonic and reactive power compensation are key practices for improving efficiency and power quality in electrical systems. This study presents the implementation of Finite Set Model Predictive Control (FCS-MPC), an advanced nonlinear technique, combined with Shunt Active Power Filters (SAPF) and three-level Neutral Point Clamped (NPC) converters, in order to optimise power quality in a three-phase network. Unlike conventional controllers, the proposed approach exploits the discrete nature of the NPC converter, allowing a faster dynamic response and optimal selection of switching vectors. The study focuses on reactive power and harmonic compensation at the grid input of a reactive load. Simulation results obtained in MATLAB-Simulink<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">®</sup> show that the proposed system significantly reduces total harmonic distortion (THD), reaching a value of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 8 4 \%}$</tex> at the grid input and improving the power factor to unity, while complying with standards such as IEEE 519-2022. These results demonstrate that the implementation of FCS-MPC with NPC converters delivers excellent performance and provides a solution for the continuous improvement of power quality in electrical systems.

title: Optimal Dispatch of Regional Integrated Energy System Incorporating Green Certificate Trading, Stepwise Carbon Trading, and Demand Response
authors: Zhao Yueting, Wang Qi, Li Gang
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: To enhance renewable energy accommodation capacity and achieve coordinated optimization of low-carbon and economic performance in energy systems, this paper proposes a regional integrated energy system (RIES) optimal dispatch model incorporating stepwise carbon trading, green certificate trading (GCT), and integrated demand response. First, operational models for multi-form energy conversion, including electricity, gas, cooling, and heat, are established. Subsequently, mechanisms for stepwise carbon trading and green certificate trading are analyzed, along with demand-side response strategies that enable peak-shaving and valley-filling operations for electrical, thermal, and cooling loads. Taking daily total cost minimization as the objective function, five different scenarios are analyzed through mixed-integer linear programming using the CPLEX solver. Case study results demonstrate that the proposed model effectively constrains carbon emission intensity, reduces system peak-valley differences, and decreases operational costs. This validation confirms the model’s effectiveness in achieving dual objectives of low-carbon operation and economic optimization.

title: Going and Returning: Lakota Travel Verbs in Virtual Reality
authors: Milan Wolff, Jessica Fae Nelson, Will Greiner, Amy Banic
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Lakȟótiyapi, the Lakota language, is an Indigenous language endangered by the loss of fluent speakers from elder generations. We describe the process of designing a virtual reality (VR) environment to aid new Lakota learners in learning specific linguistic features, such as spatially-oriented travel verbs. Furthermore, we assess the feasibility of using a virtual environment (VE) and real walking navigation techniques with a small user study. We present positive feedback and qualitative results from this initial user study (n = 7), while noting that other locomotion techniques, increases in the size of the tracked area, and embodiment within the VR environment present avenues for future work to improve quantitative learning assessments.

title: Reducing Stress in Annual Performance Reviews through AI-Enabled Avatar Interaction
authors: Yoto Mizuno, Richard Roth, Maxime Cordeil, Nilufar Baghaei
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has gained significant attention in recent years as a potential tool to improve interview skills for employment. Interviewees facing challenges during the job application process, especially those with high anxiety, can benefit from VR-based training platforms that simulate interview scenarios. We investigated the integration of VR avatar design and Generative Artificial Intelligence (GAI) in the context of annual performance reviews (APR). The study evaluated user experiences across three APR settings: a face-to-face APR without VR, a realistic AI-enabled avatar in a VR environment, and a stylised AI-enabled avatar in a VR environment. The VR avatars were connected to a GAI system, which facilitated audio-based interactions during the APR process.A within-subject experiment involving 20 participants compared these settings through questionnaires, assessing system usability, sense of presence, ease of self-disclosure, intimacy, stress levels and acceptance of opinions. The results showed that in-person APR was preferred for self-disclosure, intimacy, and acceptance of opinions during the performance evaluation. VR APRs with realistic and stylised avatars received positive usability feedback and were favoured for reducing stress and pressure. Participants provided qualitative feedback emphasising the need to improve the VR avatars’ responses, facial expressions, and eye contact.The findings suggest that VR APR systems hold promise as an alternative or complementary approach to traditional methods, offering potential benefits such as reducing stress for employees during performance evaluations.

title: Robust IGDT Planning for Stand-alone Microgrid with Hydrogen Energy Storage
authors: Jianbo Zou, Chenyang Sun, Yanjuan Qi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: In the process of planning for stand-alone microgrid with high percentage penetration of renewable energy, the uncertainty of scenery output poses difficulties in achieving lean planning objectives. To this end, an optimal planning method for stand-alone microgrid with hydrogen storage based on information gap decision theory is proposed. Firstly, construct the basic structure of stand-alone microgrid with hydrogen energy storage, based on which the basic working principle of hydrogen storage system is explained and its simplified mathematical model is established; Secondly, a two-layer optimal planning model of the stand-alone microgrid with incentive-based demand response is established, in which the outer model minimizes the annual value of the integrated cost of the microgrid as the optimization objective, while the inner model introduces the information gap decision theory to simulate the uncertain parameters and minimizes the annual operating cost of the microgrid as the optimization objective; Finally, a genetic algorithm with embedded mixed integer linear programming is used to solve the two-layer optimal planning model. The algorithm results verify the rationality and validity of the proposed model and provide a reference for the optimization planning of stand-alone microgrid containing hydrogen energy storage.

title: Intelligent Prediction of Bearing Capacity of Reinforced Concrete Beams Using Beluga Whale Optimized Bi-LSTM Network
authors: Xiangyu Xu, Yinan Guo, Xiong Zhou, Shuai Xu, Heng Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Concrete Compressive Strength (CCS) prediction is crucial for construction design. quality control, and safety of civil engineering structures. Conventional laboratory testing is also time-consuming, expensive, and destructive in nature, making these methods not ideal for today's construction, which requires the fastest methods to be more efficient. Machine learning (ML) has become a valid replacement but has a delicate hyperparameter tuning process that will often lead to poor generalization across datasets. Bi-Long Term Short Memory (Bi directional LTSM) can model complicated nonlinear relationships between the Bearing Capacity of Reinforced Concrete Beams and strength; however, performance and accuracy heavily depend on hyperparameter tuning. This research presents a Beluga Whale Optimization-Bi-LSTM (BWO-LSTM) modelling framework for predicting Bearing Capacity of Reinforced Concrete Beams that will maintain hyperparameter tuning, and, thus, incorporate a secondary efficiency gain in preparation time. This paper employed BWO and systematically tune needed hyperparameters of the mixed model Bi-LSTM, where BWO is realized through systematic exploration of the hyperparameter search space. The proposed unified learning model was trained and validated using 2 benchmark datasets (Kaggle Concrete Compressive Strength dataset, UCI Concrete Compressive Strength dataset) that also included a variety of mix proportions and curing ages. Experimental results demonstrate that the BWO-LSTM model outperforms conventional ML models and manually tuned Bi-LSTM, achieving higher prediction accuracy of 97.6 %. This study highlights the potential of hybrid optimization-learning frameworks in Prediction of Bearing Capacity of Reinforced Concrete Beams.

title: Understanding Chatbot Model Behavior Through Intent and Pattern-Based Dataset Evaluation
authors: Sowmya P, Vasudeva
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
abstract: The performance of chatbot systems is significantly influenced by the quality and structure of the underlying dataset, particularly the definition of intents and the diversity of associated patterns. This study presents comparative evaluation amidst multiple machine learning algorithms and deep learning models—namely traditional classifiers (e.g., Naïve Bayes, Logistic Regression), neural architectures (LSTM, Simple RNN, GRU), and transformer-based models (e.g., BERT)-on a standardized intent-pattern JSON dataset for a university domain chatbot. We systematically analyze how variations in the number of intents, the number and linguistic diversity of patterns per intent, and the semantic similarity between intents affect model performance. Evaluation metrics accuracy, F1-score and intent-wise confusion matrix provides a granular understanding of model behavior. Our findings reveal that while transformer-based models generally outperform others in accuracy and generalization, simpler models perform competitively when intents are well-separated and patterns are sufficiently varied. The paper offers insights into optimal dataset design strategies and model selection guidelines for intent-based chatbot systems, contributing to improved performance and user satisfaction in conversational AI applications.

title: Modeling and Simulation of Pi Control for Mmc-Based Statcom
authors: Alisson Magno Dominghetti, Robson Bauwelz Gonzatti, Yago Araújo dos Santos, Daniel Augusto Pereira
abstract: This paper provides a tutorial on the design and implementation of proportional-integral (PI) control for an MMC-based STATCOM. It covers the operating principles and mathematical modeling of the converter, the design of the PI controller for voltage regulation and stability support, and validates the approach through simulations. Results show effective reactive power regulation and improved dynamic performance.

title: Design and Development of IoT-Based SCADA Platform for OM in Photovoltaic Utility Plants
authors: Arthur Ichiro Moreira Manabe, Flávio De Castro Alves Filho, Geyse Mirelle Rezende Brito, Marcel Veloso Campos, Leandro Tiago Manera, Tárcio André Dos Santos Barros
abstract: This paper details the design and development of an Internet of Things (IoT)-based SCADA platform aimed at enhancing Operation and Maintenance (O&M) in photovoltaic (PV) power plants. Addressing the limitations of traditional SCADA systems, the proposed platform integrates technologies such as LoRa, WiFi, cloud computing, and data analytics. The architecture features an IoT gateway for versatile data acquisition and a cloud-based system for data storage, processing, and visualization. Robust security is implemented using VPN and X. 509 certificates. The development followed a structured methodology including design, hardware/software creation, integration, and validation. Key results include an IoT gateway hardware and a complementary web-based monitoring interface. This platform provides a comprehensive solution for real-time monitoring and control, with the goal of improving the efficiency, reliability, and overall performance of O&M operations in large-scale PV installations.

title: Evaluating on the Emergency Logistic System Capacity in the Greater Bay Area Urban Agglomeration Based on Neural Network
authors: Feng Gao, Chaoqun Deng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The Greater Bay Area Urban Agglomeration emergency logistic system, an economically developed and highly populous region of China. The overarching objective of this system is to ensure the rapid and efficient mobilization and deployment of the essential supplies—medico-diagnostics, food, and water—during a catastrophic disruption event, including natural disasters, public health crises, or mass accidents. It's worth is demonstrated in cooperative response mechanisms that integrate transportation systems, information technology infrastructure, and strategic stockpiling in the region's 11 cities. This emergency logistics capabilities is basically deployed to enhance regional resilience, minimize human suffering and economic expenses by providing life-saving commodities to affected populations in a timely manner. Finally, a robust emergency logistic system is important to safeguard this pivotal urban cluster's socio-economic stability against sudden threats.

title: Eliminating the Distance-Precision Trade-off in Distant Object Placement and Manipulation in Virtual Reality
authors: Jalal Safari Bazargani, Abolghasem Sadeghi-Niaraki, Soo-Mi Choi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: This paper proposes a portal method that enables users to grab nearby objects and place them at a distance, in contrast to existing approaches that focus solely on selecting and manipulating distant objects. This is achieved by introducing a secondary viewport that allows both precise object handling and post-placement adjustments. Through a user study (n=54), we compared our approach against HOMER across three experimental tasks at three distances (3m, 6m, and 9m): a multi-directional tapping task, a six-degree-of-freedom docking task, and a color brick tower assembly task. Results demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms the baseline settings in terms of selection time, error rates, task completion rates, and cognitive demand, with the performance gap widening as distance increases.

title: Dynamic Credit Management Using Deep Q-Networks and Random Forest Feature Selection
authors: Anand Raj Dubey, Aditya Raj Kashyap, Rustam Mahilane, Girish K K, Biswajit Bhowmik
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
abstract: Financial Technology (FinTech) innovations are revolutionizing the way financial services are delivered, enabling more efficient, personalized, and data-driven solutions. These services encompass lending, payments, wealth management, and risk assessment, transforming traditional financial ecosystems. Among these, credit management remains a critical function, aiming to balance customer needs with financial institution risk exposure. However, existing credit management systems often suffer from limited adaptability, insufficient use of behavioral data, and challenges in accurately predicting default risk, leading to suboptimal credit decisions. This paper proposes a novel hybrid framework that combines Random Forest (RF)-based feature selection with a Deep Q-Network (DQN) reinforcement learning (RL) model to enhance credit risk prediction and optimize credit limit allocation. The approach leverages key demographic and transactional features to accurately classify default risk, while the RL agent dynamically learns credit adjustment policies that maximize long-term rewards. Experimental results demonstrate superior performance in default prediction, achieving an AUC of 0.90, and effective credit limit optimization with stable cumulative rewards.

title: Fixed Switching Frequency MPC for Grid-Connected Cascaded H-Bridge Converter
authors: Pedro A. De Oliveira, Robson B. Gonzatti, Yago Araujo Dos Santos, Silvia Costa Ferreira, Rondineli Rodrigues Pereira, João Gabriel Luppi Foster
abstract: Finite control set model predictive control (FCSMPC) applied to multilevel cascaded H-bridge converters has proven to be an effective control strategy. However, the absence of modulation results in variable switching frequency, which is a significant disadvantage for this type of power electronics system. This paper presents a simple solution for fixed-frequency MPC to address this inconvenience in the design and control of multilevel converters using model predictive control. The proposed method not only maintains a comparable dynamic response but also reduces current distortion (THDi) as a result of its constant switching frequency.

title: Analyzing the Strategic Use of English in Business Communication Using Hybrid Deep Learning and Ensemble Techniques
authors: Sabina A. Nair, Erugu Krishna, Neelam Bharathi, Kumaran Thayumanavan, S. Vinayagam, S. Kaliappan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In the last few years, a number of groundbreaking changes have been made to English in Business Communication. Genre theory currently encompasses more than just text analysis; it also contains insights from context and professionals. ESP and Business Communication studies have come together, which supports this change. This trend is also happening because businesses are using new media and because schools need to teach students how to communicate in the workplace. A hybrid neural network model based on GRU-CNN estimates how much business English will be used to deal with these developments. There are three processes in the model: preprocessing the data, extracting features using term weights, TDF, and GR, and training the model. GRU layers find features that change over time, whereas CNN layers find features that are in space. To test the model, it had to split the dataset into two parts: training and testing. The GRU-CNN model did better than other deep learning methods in tests, with a prediction accuracy of 96.56 %. This study suggests that the model can make English in Business Communication classes better by connecting theory to practice.

title: Tracking Regional Competitiveness in Ukraine: An Integral Indicator Approach to Assessing Disparities and Development
authors: Larysa Zomchak, Nataliia Yehorchenkova, Oleksii Yehorchenkov, Viktoriia Kubych, Vladimír Ondrejička
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: This research investigates the competitiveness of the regions of Ukraine, focusing on the period from 2012 to 2023. It employs an integral indicator to assess the economic performance and competitive position of Ukrainian regions, with a particular emphasis on how these dynamics have changed over time, especially in light of geopolitical events such as the 2014 annexation of Crimea and the 2022 full-scale war started by russia. The study aims to analyze the competitiveness of Ukrainian regions by developing a multidimensional ranking system based on a set of twelve economic and social indicators. A comparison of the integral indicators of regional competitiveness in Ukraine for the years 2012 (the year before the Revolution of Dignity and the war), 2021 (the year before the full-scale war), and 2023 (the most recent year for which some regional statistical data are available) enables an evaluation of the war’s impact on regional competitiveness at different stages. The study results showed a significant disparity between regions that needs to be reduced. The integral indicators indicate that in both 2012 and 2021, Dnipropetrovsk region was the leader, while in 2023, Lviv region exhibited the highest performance indicators. This shift is closely linked to the ongoing war in Ukraine, which has caused substantial losses across all regions.

title: Predicting Flow Boiling Heat Transfer Coefficient Utilizing Physics-Informed Machine Learning model
authors: Thanh-Hoang Phan, Logan Pirnstill, Jiayuan Li, Chirag R. Kharangate
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Flow boiling in mini and micro-channels is an efficient solution for meeting the high heat dissipation demands of advanced thermal management systems. However, accurately predicting heat transfer coefficients remains a significant challenge due to the complex fluid and thermal dynamics in these two-phase systems. Conventional approaches, including physicsbased correlations and theoretical models, often fall short in providing reliable predictions. Although machine learning (ML) offers a compelling alternative, its ‘black-box’ nature can lead to outcomes that may conflict with established physical principles. This study investigates hybrid physics-informed machine learning (PIML) algorithms, which integrate ML techniques with physical models. Three selected physical models for predicting heat transfer coefficients are combined with an artificial neural network (ANN) and trained using a comprehensive database. The database, consisting of 16,953 data points on flow boiling heat transfer in mini and micro-channels collected from 50 sources, is utilized for training and testing. The results indicate that PIML algorithms consistently achieve similar Mean Absolute Errors of $\mathbf{7 \%}-\mathbf{8 \%}$, outperforming physical models. Additionally, the PIML models demonstrate slightly better performance in predicting unseen data compared to the pure ANN models. Overall, the quality and diversity of the training dataset significantly influence the performance of both PIML and pure ANN models.

title: Point of care nucleic acid test using Single Stranded DNAs paper microfluidics for differential detection of Mpox Virus Clades under low resource setting : Development of a ssDNAs-based molecular assay for the simultaneous detection and differentiation of Mpox virus Clade I and II
authors: Satheesh Natarajan, Ketan Dighe, David Skrodzki, Dipanjan Pan
abstract: Since 2022, the Mpox outbreak has resulted in multiple fatalities and has spread to 107 countries across all six World Health Organization (WHO) regions. In response, the WHO declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern, emphasizing the urgent need for rapid and precise detection of different Mpox virus (Mpox) clades. Early diagnosis, particularly through point-of-care molecular testing (POCT), is crucial for controlling its transmission. Here, we present the development of a colorimetric lateral flow assay detectable by the naked eye, utilizing gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) capped with single-stranded DNAs (ssDNAs) to specifically identify and differentiate Mpox Clades I and II. The ssDNAs, functionalized with thiol groups and conjugated to AuNPs, selectively agglomerate in the presence of target Mpox DNA, inducing a shift in surface plasmon resonance. This optimized assay achieves a detection limit of 100 copies/μl across all clades and exhibits high specificity for Mpox, with no cross-reactivity to other pathogens. These assays hold great potential for clinical applications, enabling rapid and reliable viral detection.

title: HALT with PoF for Class P Electronics Assembly
authors: Reza Ghaffarian
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: This paper presents reliability test results for an evaluation functional electronics assembly using highly accelerated life test (HALT) for rapid testing of Class P technologies. Ruggedization for vibration resistances were made based on understanding physics of failure (PoF) mechanisms of packages at assembly level. Class P, a nonhermetic plastic encapsulated microcircuit (PEM), was recently introduced into Mil-PRF-38535, Rev M. An evaluation board was selected to have numerous advanced PEM packaging technologies. It had a Flip-Chip Ball Grid Array (FCBGA), a few Fine Pitch BGAs (FPBGAs), a few Quad Flat No-Leads (QFNs), and passives. The New HALT with PoF follows conventional methods, but with different philosophy. It uses mature electronics hardware and mitigation methods at assembly level. It allows avoidance of early failures, especially those latent defects only detectable under simultaneous thermal cycling and vibration. The following steps were implemented on the evaluation board and the test results are presented in detail. First, it established cold/hot temperature limits using a stepwise approach. Second, it established survivability under TCs with increasing the cycling ranges, first, 100 cycles in the range of $-30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $70^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and then additional 100 cycles in the range of $-40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $85^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Third, removed fan and heat sink from FCBGA in preparation for ruggedization. Ruggedization approaches including FCBGA corner filling and bonding the heat sink are discussed. Finally, first, established vibration limit from 5 to 50 Grms, then, performed simultaneous vibration at 25 Grms with thermal cycling in the range of $-40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $85^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. The paper presents detailed results for each step including temperature at which soft failures occurred during cold/hot evaluation for limits, results of inspection by X-ray to determine package types, and define ruggedization methods for vibration resistance improvement using corner staking, corner filling, and underfilling for FCBGAs and FPBGAs.

title: Experimental parametric study of direct dielectric fluid cooling of lithium-ion batteries for electric vehicles
authors: Ouenzerfi Safouene, Amorim Dias Rodrigo, Plet Julien, Harmand Souad
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Battery Thermal Management Systems (BTMS) are critical for maintaining temperature stability and heat dissipation in high-performance electric vehicle batteries. Traditional cooling methods, such as active air cooling and liquid-based systems, vary in effectiveness, with liquid systems generally offering superior heat dissipation due to their higher heat transfer properties. However, these systems can be complex and add weight. An emerging alternative is immersion cooling, where battery cells are directly immersed in an electrically insulating fluid. This approach enables efficient heat transfer through direct contact and can also provide additional safety by acting as a thermal barrier if the fluid is low in flammability. The effectiveness of immersion cooling depends on fluid properties such as viscosity, thermal conductivity, heat capacity, and flammability, as well as key system parameters like fluid circulation, flow rate, and geometry. This study focuses on designing an experimental setup to explore immersion cooling for battery modules, with the goal of developing optimized cooling fluids and evaluating key performance factors such as heat transfer efficiency. Experimental results highlight the importance of fluid flow rate, power dissipation, fluid type, and system configuration in enhancing cooling performance.

title: 3D Printing of Cellular Scaffold as In Vitro Cancer Model
authors: Zeynab Tahir, Hui Leng Choo, Yin How Wong, Asseel Hisham Alregib
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women globally, and the most prevalent cancer type in Malaysia, thus highlighting the need for novel treatment options. Traditional 2D cell culture models fail to replicate the complex in vivo environment, whereas 3D cell cultures provide better cell-cell and cell-environment interactions. However, current 3D tumour models are limited to small sizes of a few microns. This study aims to design and 3D print a cellular scaffold capable of successful cell attachment and growth using GelMa hydrogel with lithium phenyl (2,4,6-trimethylbenzoyl) phosphinate (LAP) photoinitiator. GelMa is cured using blue light of 405 nm wavelength via the vat photopolymerization process. Different LAP concentrations (0.5 %, 0.2 %, 0.1 % and 0.05 % w/v GelMa) and light exposure times (10–100 s) are tested, and scaffold designs included cubic and triply periodic minimal surface (TPMS) structures, generated using MATLAB and Autodesk Netfabb. The printed scaffolds are sterilized, cultured with breast cancer cells, and monitored for cell attachment and growth over 1–2 weeks. By the end of the study, the optimal LAP concentration and exposure time for scaffold integrity are identified, and the effects of TPMS scaffold designs on cancer cell behaviour are compared to traditional cubic scaffolds. This research will advance cancer studies by improving tumour models and enabling better drug response analysis.

title: ShadAR: LLM-driven shader generation to transform visual perception in Augmented Reality
authors: Yanni Mei, Samuel Wendt, Florian Müller, Jan Gugenheimer
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Augmented Reality (AR) can simulate various visual perceptions, such as how individuals with colorblindness see the world. However, these simulations require developers to predefine each visual effect, limiting flexibility. We present ShadAR, an AR application enabling real-time transformation of visual perception through shader generation using large language models (LLMs). ShadAR allows users to express their visual intent via natural language, which is interpreted by an LLM to generate corresponding shader code. This shader is then compiled real-time to modify the AR headset’s viewport. We present our LLM-driven shader generation pipeline and demonstrate its ability to transform visual perception for inclusiveness and creativity.

title: Guiding, Not Deciding: User Preferences in AI-Assisted Roles
authors: Ze Dong, Binyang Han, Jingjing Zhang, Kazuyuki Fujita, Robert W. Lindeman, Barrett Ens, Adrian Clark, Thammathip Piumsomboon
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: As artificial intelligence (AI) integrates into extended reality (XR), or known as XR×AI, a central design challenge emerges: how to balance AI assistance with user autonomy. This challenge presents a core dilemma: unassisted interfaces risk creating "hollow autonomy," where overwhelming choice undermines user confidence, while fully automated systems can impose a "tyranny of efficiency" that erodes agency. To investigate this tension, we conducted a study with 32 participants, comparing four distinct XR×AI strategies along a spectrum of intervention, from passive information display to direct recommendation, across two levels of task complexity. Our findings reveal a clear user preference for a collaborative middle ground that avoids the pitfalls of the extremes. While high intervention was decisively rejected for undermining agency, minimal support proved ineffective under complexity, leading to high cognitive load and low confidence. The most successful interfaces were those that acted as a "cognitive scaffold," collaborative partners that curated the decision space to reduce cognitive load and prevent errors, while leaving the final, empowering act of choice to the user. These results demonstrate that the goal of XR×AI design is not to create a system that thinks for us, but a partner that helps us think better.

title: Improved Power Performance in Bidirectional Gridforming Converters via Modified Voltage Control
authors: Amiron Wolff dos Santos Serra, Khristian Augusto Freitas Nascimento, José Gomes de Matos, Luiz Antonio de Souza Ribeiro, Hércules Araújo Oliveira
abstract: This paper presents a control strategy for a bidirectional grid-forming converter operating as a virtual synchronous generator, featuring an improved voltage controller to enhance active and reactive power dynamics. Theoretical analysis and real-time simulations show that the control strategy, based on disturbance input decoupling, improves disturbance rejection. Additionally, virtual impedance is used to limit the current during grid transients.

title: Proposal of an Experimentally Aided Methodology for Learning Self-Commutated DC/AC and DC/DC Converters in Undergraduate Classes
authors: Lourenço Matakas Junior, Vinicius Negri Machado, Wilson Komatsu
abstract: This paper proposes a learning environment and methodology, with fully integrated experimental and theoretical classes, for an undergraduate course of Self-Commutated Converters. The proposal merges theory and laboratory classes, not using the laboratory class only to confirm the theory, but also introducing new theoretical aspects during the experiments, and allowing the Student to actively participate, increasing motivation and assimilation of multidisciplinary knowledge in a restricted time frame. During theory classes the Students, guided by the Lecturer, draw the main waveforms and develop equations for system and component modeling. They are validated with experimental and simulation tools, during laboratory classes, always allowing model improvement.

title: Strategies for Enhancing Thermal Comfort in Bus Stops Through Sustainable Design and Material Selection
authors: Nour El-Din Awad, Mirette Asser Esmat, Amany Micheal
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: Global warming is an undeniable reality, necessitating innovative solutions to enhance thermal comfort while minimizing environmental impact, and avoiding the rapid reliance on fossil fuel based approaches. This research specifically addresses the challenge of improving thermal comfort at bus stops in Egypt’s arid climate, where high temperatures, intense solar radiation, and wind cause significant discomfort for passengers waiting for public transportation. The study focuses on implementing passive design strategies, including shading devices and ventilation techniques, tailored to the region’s wind patterns and solar conditions. Additionally, this research introduces a novel, sustainable composite material made from sugarcane bagasse and epoxy resin, which is lightweight and has low thermal conductivity, for use in the roofs and walls of bus stop structures. Louvers are constructed from wood, while aluminium is utilized for seating and the main structural components. Using Ladybug software, computer simulations were conducted to compare two new design prototypes with the current bus stop design, considering different street orientations. The findings reveal that the Universal Climate Index (UTCI) for the current design for a big portion of the year lies between 35oC and 40oC. While the UTCI ranges between 28°C-30°C and 26°C-34°C for the first and second prototype respectively. Thermal comfort improved to 80% with the proposed designs, in contrast to just 37% for the conventional existing bus stop, while stress levels throughout the year decreased from 50% to 6%. These results offer practical insights for improving bus stop thermal comfort and help promote sustainable public transportation in Egypt.

title: Requirements Engineering in Digital Transformation Projects – A Single Case Study in the Healthcare Sector
authors: Jubayer Alam, Florian Rüttger, Jan Christoph Albrecht
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: Digital transformation initiatives reshape industries, including healthcare organizations, by integrating advanced technologies. These initiatives are known as Digital transformation projects. Their nature and boundary conditions require a robust requirements engineering approach to handle diverse stakeholder groups, regulatory constraints, and organizational needs. Digital transformation projects are complex to manage and introduce significant challenges, particularly in requirements engineering. A common challenge is that customers and developers often use different terminology, which can lead misunderstandings. A case study was conducted within a department of a public hospital in Germany to identify the key RE challenges experienced in healthcare digital transformation projects. Some common issues were the lack of standardized processes, clear documentation, and stakeholder engagement. The article contributes to the research in the field of digital transformation by revealing challenges that practitioners face during the requirements engineering process. Based on the empirical insights we propose (conceptual) recommendations to mitigate these.

title: Machine Learning-Enabled Immunosensor for Label-Free Quantification of Virus Titers
authors: Rajendra P. Shukla, He Sun, Junhyeong Wang, Jack Twiddy, Shriarjun Shastry, Stefano Menegatti, Michael Daniele
abstract: In this study we present the performance of multiple machine learning (ML) models applied to an electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) dataset for predicting the titer of adeno-associated virus serotype 2 (AAV2). The immunosensor was fabricated by conjugating anti-AAV2 antibodies on a PEG monolayer self-assembled on gold electrodes. EIS was conducted across a wide range of AAV2 titers (10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">8</sup> – 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">12</sup> capsids/mL) and buffer conditions (pH 4-9). Among the ML models tested on the training dataset, Random Forest regression emerged as the most effective, demonstrating a high prediction accuracy with an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> value of 0.98 and a root mean square error (RMSE) of 4.3•10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">9</sup> capsid/mL. The models were subsequently validated by predicting the AAV2 titers on a discrete, blind dataset. Notably, these models facilitated precise prediction of AAV2 titers from 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">11</sup>-10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">12</sup> capsids/mL. Such capabilities have significant implications for process manufacturing, offering potential solutions to the critical challenge of quality control and providing a promising avenue for accelerating process analytics.

title: Open-Source Web Lab for Remote and On-site Robotics Practice in a Realistic Zero-Setup ROS2 Development Environment_supp2-3629341.mp4
authors: s Davis Krumin
abstract: Robot Operating System 2 (ROS 2) has become the standard framework in modern robotics, but its steep learning curve and complex development environment present significant barriers to newcomers. This paper presents an open-source web lab through which learners can start practicing ROS2 program ming on real robots right away with no development environment setup. The web lab offers realistic ROS2 development experience by serving browser-based Linux desktop workstations linked to physical remote robots. We also show how the web lab system can be leveraged to create portable infrastructure for hosting ad-hoc on-site robotics workshops that require zero setup time from the participants.

title: HMMamba: Hierarchical Multi-Scale Mamba Network for Joint Classification of Hyperspectral and LiDAR Data
authors: Cuiping Shi, Yeqi Lei, Fei Zhu, Diling Liao, Chenyang Fu, Liguo Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: The joint classification of hyperspectral images (HSI) and LiDAR data is an important research direction in the field of remote sensing image processing. However, existing methods are mostly limited to inadequate feature extraction or simple serial fusion strategies, failing to fully exploit the deep cross-modal relationships between LiDAR and HSI data. Meanwhile, global modeling based on Transformers, despite capturing long-range dependencies, faces difficulties in handling high-dimensional remote sensing data due to quadratic computational complexity, leading to constrained global-local feature collaboration. To address these issues, this paper proposes a novel hierarchical multi-scale Mamba network (HMMamba) for joint classification of HSI and LiDAR data. First, the method adopts a hierarchical design to obtain rich multi-level feature representations through multi-scale feature extraction. Second, it utilizes adaptive weight allocation to achieve dynamic cross-modal feature integration. Finally, it constructs a Fused Feature enhancement Mamba Block (FFMB), which integrates a dual-branch attention mechanism and selective state space modeling to achieve efficient global context modeling under linear computational complexity Extensive experiments on four public datasets (Houston2013, MUUFL, Trento, and Augsburg) demonstrate that HMMamba significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in terms of classification performance. Specifically, on Augsburg dataset, the OA improvement is 3.24% compared to the suboptimal method, fully validating the superior performance of the proposed method. The codelink of the proposed method is https://github.com/leiyeqi/HMMamba.

title: Early prediction of pathologic complete response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy in breast cancer based on multimodal ultrasound and pathological image_supp1-3630745.docx
authors: Zhigang Zhu
abstract: Accurately predicting pCR to neoadjuvant chemo-therapy (NAC) in breast cancer patients is crucial for achieving personalized treatment strategies. pCR is defined as the absence of residual invasive cancer in the breast. To this end, we propose a dual-path GCN–Transformer network (DGT-Net) to integrate ultrasound and pathological image features for early pCR prediction. In the ultrasound pathway, DGT-Net constructed a multimodal knowledge graph to aggregate information on tumor macromorphology, blood perfusion patterns, and tissue elasticity. In the pathology pathway, DGT-Net extracted microhistological patterns and their spatial structures from hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained pathological slides. By introducing an attention score–based dynamic key-patch selection method, a pathology graph is constructed to identify highly discriminative tissue regions. Both pathways employ Transformer encoders to capture complex relationships across modalities, and the outputs are fused through a weighted soft voting strategy to produce robust pCR prediction results. This study included data from 181 breast cancer patients, and experimental results show that DGT-Net outperforms several advanced models, achieving an AUC of 0.891 and an accuracy of 86.2%. Moreover, the diagnostic performance achieved by combining multimodal ultrasound and pathological image information exceeded that of using ultrasound alone (AUC: 0.880) or pathology alone (AUC: 0.786). DGT-Net provides a reliable, non-invasive method for early pCR prediction and has the potential to support clinical decision-making in NAC regimen design.

title: Improving the Performance of Heterogeneous LPWANs: An Integrated Small-World and Machine Learning Approach
authors: Naga Srinivasarao Chilamkurthy, Shaik Abdul Hakeem, Sreenivasulu Tupakula, Sunil Chinnadurai, Om Jee Pandey, Anirban Ghosh
abstract: The rapid expansion of Internet of Things (IoT) applications has driven advancements in networking technologies like Low-Power Wide-Area Networks (LPWANs) to extend coverage and enhance the lifespan of IoT devices (IoDs). However, real-world IoT networks are typically heterogeneous, comprising static and dynamic IoDs leading to variations in network topology. These fluctuations cause challenges like increased data latency and energy imbalances, which hinder efficient information flow. To overcome these issues, this paper presents a novel approach that integrates Small-World Characteristics (SWC), inspired by social network theory, into heterogeneous LPWANs using reinforcement learning. Specifically, the Q-learning technique is employed to introduce new long-range links into the network, enhancing connectivity and optimizing performance. Different conventional networks with varying numbers of mobile nodes are studied in this work followed by their subsequent transformation to small-world versions. The performance of the networks is optimized in terms of energy efficiency and latency in data routing. It is observed that, irrespective of the network (conventional or small-world), the performance is better if the number of static nodes is greater. Furthermore, independent of the degree of dynamicity, the SW-LPWAN is more energy efficient and has lower transmission delay than the corresponding conventional network. Numerically, SWLPWANs achieve up to 14.6% faster data transmission speeds, supporting 19.7% more active IoDs, and maintaining 15.5% higher residual energy compared to conventional networks.

title: A Study on the Design of Industrial Servo Motor Using Anisotropic Bonded Magnets
authors: Ye-Seo Lee, Jae-Kwang Lee, Ki-Deok Lee, Won-Ho Kim, Dong-Hoon Jung
abstract: This paper proposes a high-performance servo motor design to suppress control instability caused by harmonic components of the induced voltage in the In-Out Core (closed-slot) stator, using anisotropic bonded magnets without heavy rare-earth elements. The In-Out Core stator improves slot fill factor in small motors, enhances winding manufacturability, and reduces cogging torque. However, it introduces harmonic components in the induced voltage due to flux circulation around the slot region. To address this, a method was applied to increase air-gap flux density and saturate the slot opening region, making it electromagnetically behave as if no slot opening exists. Harmonic characteristics of surface-mounted permanent and interior permanent magnet rotor structures were analyzed, showing that both magnet thickness and sufficiently high remanent flux density are critical for harmonic suppression. As bonded magnets without heavy rare-earths limit remanence, a flux-concentrating spoke-type rotor was applied.

title: Hybrid Access MAC Protocol in Wi-Fi: Analysis and Optimal Resource Allocation Policy Design
authors: S. Arthi, Neelesh B. Mehta, Chandramani Singh
abstract: The hybrid medium access control (MAC) protocol, which was first adopted in the IEEE 802.11ax standard, combines contention-based random access (UORA) and contention-free scheduled access (SA) transmissions over orthogonal resource units (RUs). We present a novel fixed-point analysis of saturation throughput and average access delay of hybrid access that accounts for discrete rate adaptation, packet decoding errors, and scheduling. Using this analysis and Markov decision process (MDP) theory, we design a novel dynamic RU allocation policy (ODRAP) for hybrid access. Our analysis and policy design are the first to capture the dynamic flow of users between UORA and SA, and its dependence on the RU allocation. The existing literature has modeled UORA or SA, but not both, or has assumed a fixed number of SA users. We first develop the analysis when the number of packets reported in the buffer status report (BSR) of a user is a geometric random variable. We then present an iterative approach to handle application-specific general distributions. Our numerical results verify the accuracy of the analysis despite its simplicity. Furthermore, they highlight the impact of the number of allocated RUs on the scheduler. ODRAP optimally trades off the throughput with the access delay compared to several benchmark policies.

title: A Compact 2.45-/5.8-GHz Dual-Band RF Energy Harvesting Front-End With On-Chip IMN
authors: Zushuai Xie, Ying Zhou, Guoqing Li, Tinghuan Chen, Zhikuang Cai, Zixuan Wang
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: This letter proposes a fully integrated on-chip dual-band RF energy harvesting (RFEH) front-end based on 0.15-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>m pHEMT GaAs technology. To realize a flexible design of dual-band RFEH front-end, a T-shape-like impedance matching network (IMN) with two symmetric series–parallel <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$LC$</tex-math> </inline-formula> networks is proposed. An odd–even-mode analysis theory for symmetrical T-type IMN is introduced, enabling rapid construction of dual-band IMN. Since the frequency bands in both modes remain mutually unaffected, this approach significantly reduces dual-band iteration time. A highly efficient dual-band GaAs on-chip RFEH front-end operating at 2.4 and 5.8 GHz was fabricated with a chip area of only <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$700\times 700~\mu \text {m}^{2}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>. Measurements validate the RFEH front-end achieves a peak power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 64.3% and 40.8% at 2.4 and 5.8 GHz, respectively, with 19 dBm of input power level (Pin) and 2.2-k<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\Omega $</tex-math> </inline-formula> load resistive (RL).

title: Circularly Polarized Folded Reflectarray Antenna With Improved Aperture Efficiency
authors: Makoto Sano
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper presents a method for improving the aperture efficiency of circularly polarized folded reflectarray (CPFRA) antennas. The reflection-phase distribution of the circular polarization selective surface (CPSS) constituting the CPFRA antenna is modified to maximize the aperture efficiency. CPFRA antennas designed with the proposed and conventional methods are simulated. Compared with the conventional CPFRA antenna with uniform CPSS reflection-phase distribution, the proposed one with the optimized non-uniform distribution has less spillover and higher aperture efficiency. The directivity and the corresponding aperture efficiency of the proposed CPFRA antenna are 28.7 dBic and 72.7% at 18.95 GHz, respectively. The CPFRA antennas designed with the proposed and conventional methods are fabricated and measured. Less spillover and higher gain are also observed in the measurement of the proposed CPFRA antenna.

title: Comprehensive Extraction of Resonator Elements and Anomalies in Ladder-Type Acoustic Filters
authors: Laia Garcia, Santi Cano, Jordi Verdú, Pedro de Paco
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: This letter presents a methodology for advanced diagnostics and modeling of ladder-type acoustic filters based on S-parameter analysis. The proposed approach extracts the individual components of acoustic resonators by deriving the Butterworth–Van Dyke (BVD) model through parameter extraction. This enables accurate determination of key filter characteristics, including resonance frequency and coupling coefficient. Furthermore, the method facilitates the detection of anomalies in resonator elements, which may result in shifts in resonant frequency or deviations in transmission zero positions. These deviations can lead to performance degradation, positioning the method as a valuable tool for fault diagnosis and reliability assessment in acoustic filter design.

title: Cyberbullying Detection and Identification using Machine Learning-based Hybrid Framework
authors: Elham Abdullah Alotaibi, Aida Al-Samawi
abstract: Cyberbullying has a significant impact on the many people who use social media, especially teenagers. Therefore, this study introduces a hybrid system that combines a support vector machine (SVM) and a long short-term memory (LSTM) network to detect cyberbullying on social networks, particularly on X (Twitter). The proposed model combines the deep contextual analysis capability of LSTM networks with the powerful classification performance of SVMs, using features extracted via the TF-IDF technique. A data set of English-language tweets was pre-processed and analyzed to train and consequently assess the hybrid system. The results demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves high accuracy and can effectively identify cyberbullying, even in subtle cases such as sarcasm. This study contributes to enhanced online safety by leveraging the strengths of both models in the hybrid framework, providing a scalable solution for real-time cyberbullying detection. Future recommendations include expanding the data set and exploring multi-modal approaches to improve the model’s detection capabilities.

title: Persistent Clean-Label Backdoor Attacks on Semisupervised Social Graph Node Classification
authors: Xiao Yang, Gaolei Li, Xinzheng Feng, Xiaoyu Yi, Jianhua Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Semisupervised social graph node classification (SSGNC) attempts to deduce node-related information of social graph with limited labeled training samples. It is primarily deployed in large-scale graph processing, e.g., malicious client detection, knowledge graph, and recommender system. However, in this article, we identify that the SSGNC model is also extremely sensitive to backdoor attacks. We present a novel persistent clean-label backdoor attack (PerCBA) on SSGNC, which selectively poisons unmarked training nodes before learning to compel the trained model to misclassify trigger-embedded inputs into malicious class. Specifically, PerCBA employs a style-agnostic trigger generator with adjustable perturbation strategy to produce perturbed triggers. These triggers are pasted onto a small subset of unmarked nodes (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$< \, 4\%$</tex-math> </inline-formula>), enabling the adversary to covertly poison the training graph and implant backdoors into the model without modifying labels. Additionally, to ensure SSGNC robustness when confronted with homogenous threats, we present a testing sample filtering-based defense strategy for PerCBA. It employs feature distribution to identify poisoned nodes and applies Gaussian blur and thresholding to remove the trigger fraction, thereby restoring suspicious data to clean states. Extensive experiments on SOTA SSGNC models and datasets indicate that PerCBA performs high attack success rates (maxima 96.25%) while remaining evasive, and the defense method can effectively mitigate attacks and purify backdoored models.

title: Clock Resonance Suppression in Dispersive Time-Delay Reservoir Computing
authors: Song-Sui Li, He Nie, Liyue Zhang, Xihua Zou, Wei Pan, Lianshan Yan
abstract: Due to the use of time-delay architecture, the performances of time-delay reservoir computing (TDRC) have inherent limitation from the unwanted clock resonances at critical time ratios between the input clock cycle (i.e. mask repetition period) and the feedback delay time. Here, we propose and investigate a novel dispersive TDRC by employing a vertical cavity surface emitting laser with dispersive feedback from a chirped fiber Bragg grating (CFBG). The CFBG provides dispersive feedback, which leads to fuzzification of feedback delays thus effectively suppresses the clock resonances at critical time ratios. The feasibility of proposed scheme is first evaluated by memory capacity, and then further verified in popular benchmark tasks of nonlinear autoregressive moving average and nonlinear channel equalization. The results show that the proposed dispersive TDRC successfully enhances the computing performances with respect to conventional TDRC at critical time ratios.

title: SEU Vulnerability for One-fin and Two-fin D-FF Designs at a 3-nm FinFET Technology Node
authors: Solomon L. Tolson, Jenna B. Kronenberg, Nicholas J. Pieper, Yoni Xiong, Dennis R. Ball, Bharat L. Bhuva
abstract: Single-event upset (SEU) cross-sections are investigated for alpha particles, heavy-ions, and high-energy neutrons as a function of supply voltage and particle linear energy transfer (LET) values for one-fin and two-fin conventional D-Flip-Flop (D-FF) designs at a 3-nm FinFET technology node. Results show that one-fin D-FF designs are less vulnerable than similar two-fin D-FF designs for all tested conditions. Differences in capacitance, drive current, collected charge, critical charge, and sensitive volume lead to the one-fin D-FF outperforming the two-fin D-FF in terms of SEU vulnerability. Specifically, the reductions in drive current and collected charge are significantly greater than reductions in nodal capacitances, resulting in higher SEU cross-sections for two-fin D-FF designs compared to one-fin D-FF designs. 3D Technology Computer-Aided Design (TCAD) simulations show the differences in sensitive areas for each design responsible for the SEU response.

title: Towards Content Placement Optimization and Beamforming Design for IRS-Aided Caching Systems with Imperfect CSI
authors: Meng Gao, Huafu Li, Yang Wang, Junqi Guo, Xu Zhu
abstract: Edge caching in wireless networks struggles to reduce backhaul burden and enhance edge node QoS under deep fading and blocking of offloading links. Intelligent reflecting surfaces (IRS) address this challenge by reconfiguring propagation environments to improve transmission link quality. This study formulates a network cost minimization problem with imperfect CSI, in which content placement and hybrid beamforming are jointly optimized to balance backhaul capacity and transmission power.The problem decomposes into two subproblems: 1. The first subproblem employs probabilistic content placement strategy based on Zipf-distributed popularity, where backhaul capacity is modeled as a function of cached content probabilities, and it is solved by leveraging Karush-Kuhn-Tucker optimality conditions; 2. Hybrid beamforming is tackled using alternating optimization. Specifically, fixing IRS phase shifts transforms the transmission power subproblem into a convex form to optimize precoder. Conversely, fixing precoder enables solving the reflection beamforming subproblem using a penalty-based convex-concave procedure (CCP) to handle non-convex phase constraints. Numerical results show that the proposed scheme significantly reduces transmission power and backhaul capacity compared to baseline schemes, yielding substantial network cost savings. This work advances caching optimization and transmission robustness in cost-efficient wireless networks under channel uncertainty, demonstrating practical gains via IRS-aided joint design.

title: Feature Selection of Insulating Paper Near-Infrared Spectroscopy by SHAP for Enhancing the Interpretability
authors: Jia Cheng, Xiyuan Chen, Haifan Li, Yanqun Zhao, Han Li, Weizhe Sun, Yuan Li
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: In recent years, near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy has been used for the nondestructive assessment of the degree of polymerization (DP) of insulating paper, which is a key indicator of its aging degree. The NIR spectra of insulating paper typically contain hundreds or even thousands of spectral features, and the complex nonlinear relationship between these high-dimensional features and DP can be captured by machine learning algorithms, enabling DP prediction model. However, only a small subset of these features is truly relevant to the aging of insulating paper. Identifying and selecting these key features can improve model’s accuracy and interpretability. In this study, SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) was used to interpret the impact of spectral features on the DP prediction model and extract key features. Insulating paper samples with different aging degrees were prepared by accelerated thermal aging experiment, their NIR spectra were collected, and their DP was determined. A DP prediction model was then developed using all spectral features and Random Forest. SHAP analysis was used to evaluate feature contribution to the model’s predictions of the entire dataset, as well as high and low DP subsets. Based on SHAP feature importance, key features were selected for further modeling, and the performance of models using different numbers of features was compared. The results show that the feature at 1115 nm is the key feature for identifying the aging degree of insulating paper, and the root mean square error of the model modeled using the key features is lower than that of the model modeled using all features (60.0725 vs. 68.2673).

title: Authentication with Adaptive Fusion and Liveness Detection
authors: Vidyadevi G. Biradar, Mohan Sankaran, Taqy Aleobahaey, Senbagam K., Ponmurugan Panneer Selvam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In the modern era, multimodal biometric authentication has played an essential role in traditional systems, including face or fingerprint recognition, which face challenges such as spoofing, noise sensitivity, and limited performance. The existing multimodal system integrates Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for feature extraction, followed by score level fusion mechanism. However, this system failed to include voice modality, relied on fixed fusion rules, and lacked the ability to detect liveness. Hence, this study proposes a transformer-based tri-modal biometric authentication (T-BA) framework that includes face, voice, and fingerprint data. The collected face data is preprocessed using face alignment and illumination normalization, voice silence removal, MelFrequency Cepstral Coefficients for voice data, and fingerprint ridge enhancement with normalization of fingerprint data. Next, modality-specific encoders are employed for the extraction of feature embeddings and integrated through a shared transformer encoder with attention-based adaptive fusion to enable the dynamic weighting of modalities. Finally, classification of the fused representation is performed using a decision module for authentication. The experimental results demonstrated that the proposed Adaptive Voice-FaceFingerprint with Transformer (AVFF-T) framework achieved higher accuracy (99.8 %), reduced Equal Error Rate (0.05 %), and improved Area Under Curve (0.998).

title: Avatar Closet: An Augmented Reality Based Multi-Modal Virtual Try-On System for Fashion Retail
authors: Sushma Vittal, Babitha Ganesh, Guruprasad Bhat, Sneha Shanbhag, Swati Shet, Vasudeva, G K Aruna Kumari
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
