abstract: The rapid advancement of immersive technologies has paved the way for innovative solutions in the fashion retails industry, particularly in enhancing user engagement and personalization in online shopping. This article proposes an innovative virtual try on system that can revolutionize the online shopping experience by integrating Augmented Reality (AR), Artificial Intelligence (AI) and modern web technologies. This system is architected using ReactJS for a dynamic frontend interface, supporting features such as user registration, authentication, and a wish list mechanism for storing preferred apparel selections. A distinguishing aspect of the platform lies in its multi-modal virtual try-on capabilities, designed to accommodate valid user preferences and technological accessibility. The avatar mode enables the users to create a customizable 3D avatar, offering a simulated preview of garments in virtual environment. The AR mode, built on Snapchat's Lens studio, facilitates real time outfit projection onto the user through the device's camera, enhancing realism and engagement. Additionally, the Image dressing mode allows users to upload personal photographs and digitally overlay selected outfits, offering a simplified but effective try on experience. To support accurate and responsive interaction, the system incorporates the Haar Cascade classifiers for real time body and facial recognition. Furthermore, the integration of the Gemini conversational assistant introduces a layer of intelligent interaction, providing outfit recommendations based on user preferences and guiding them through the application workflow. The fusion of these technologies results in scalable, user-centric and robust system aimed at transforming the virtual shopping landscape.

title: Two-Phase Counter-Flow Expanding Channels for Compliant Direct Attach
authors: Mark. D. Schultz, Pritish R. Parida, Shurong Tian, Cory VanDeventer, Brian Werneke, Timothy Chainer
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Compliant direct attach implemented with single phase coolant has been shown to be an effective means of achieving reliable cooling of high-power components. Primary targets of such cooling systems are high power CPUs which have highly nonuniform power densities. While single phase water cooling is effective thermally, it comes with potential issues associated with water leaks. A desirable solution to this problem would be an approach capable of at least similar performance at high local power (core) densities utilizing a non-conductive fluid. Two phase cooling is a candidate but can have instability and dry-out concerns with very high local power densities when implemented in conventional parallel channel form. Expanding channels in a radial configuration have been demonstrated to effectively mitigate these concerns but are difficult to implement in a compliant direct attach configuration due to the central inlet and are best implemented when the device to be cooled is close to square rather than rectangular. In this work we present a cold plate approach implementing multilayer counter-flow expanding channels with a load-supporting outlet plenum which allows compliant direct attach in a small footprint. The design process included multiple rounds of modeling and revision to bring the single-phase and two-phase pressure drops at the flow rate associated with a $50 \%$ full power vapor quality into the desired range. A thermal test vehicle comprised of an array of 4.2 mm by 4.2 mm heaters of total size 25 mm by 42 mm was used to generate heat distributions of the type seen in large CPU’s, with core “rows” implemented at high power densities and remaining chip areas at low power densities. Effective local cold plate thermal resistance (measured local temperature increase relative to inlet fluid temperature over local power density) as low as $18^{\circ} \mathrm{C}-\mathrm{mm}^{2} / \mathrm{W}$ was measured which includes both the silicon die resistance and the pad thermal interface material thermal resistance. When the coolant pre-heat impact on the downstream core temperature is included in evaluation of a similar format high-performance single-phase water cold plate, the thermal performance is nearly identical. Overall, this approach appears very promising for water-free high-performance cooling of high local power density devices.

title: Evolutionary Multi-Agent Dispatching for Low-Carbon Microgrids: A Joint Electricity–Carbon–Green Certificate Market with Heterogeneous Demand-side Incentives
authors: Tingting He, Hui Hwang Goh, Wai Leong Pang, Swee King Phang, Lingyu Wen, Xiaowen Zhong
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: The increasing integration of distributed energy resources and the pursuit of carbon neutrality have highlighted the need for efficient and low-carbon dispatch strategies in microgrids. This study proposes an evolutionary multi-agent dispatch framework that jointly integrates the electricity, carbon, and green certificate (GC) markets. A coupling mechanism is developed to facilitate coordinated pricing and resource allocation across energy and environmental domains. The dynamic behavior of heterogeneous agents—including renewable generators, conventional units, and responsive users—is captured through an evolutionary game-based strategy updating process. A demand-side incentive mechanism, designed with consideration of user preferences and risk sensitivity, promotes active participation in GC trading. Simulation results on a benchmark microgrid demonstrate that the proposed method significantly reduces operational costs, enhances renewable energy utilization, and improves GC compliance. The proposed framework provides a practical pathway for sustainable microgrid operation and integrated market coordination.

title: Flap-Assisted Multiplexed Digital Methylation-Specific PCR for Sensitive Detection and Methylation Analysis of Biomarker Panels
authors: Weiwen Cui, Yang Zhao, Fan-En Chen, Jamie Cheng, Ludmila Danilova, Leslie Cope, Sonali C. Joyce, James G. Herman, Thomas R. Pisanic, Tza-Huei Wang
abstract: Liquid biopsies offer a noninvasive method for detecting cancer biomarkers like DNA methylation, but reliably detecting rare circulating tumor DNA remains challenging. While digital PCR (dPCR) provides unparalleled single-copy sensitivity at low cost, its limited multiplexing capacity undermines its detection in early-stage tumors. Here, we introduce FAM-dMSP, a digital methylation-specific PCR-melt platform combining multi-color fluorescence and flap-encoded melting temperatures for enhanced multiplexing. With only three fluorescent colors, we demonstrate its application in a 15-biomarker panel, achieving single-copy sensitivity for accurate ctDNA detection and quantification. This platform leverages the high sensitivity of dPCR for highly-parallelized analysis of methylation biomarkers, offering a streamlined, low-cost approach for detecting and monitoring cancer.

title: Wearable System for Continuous Cortisol Monitoring
authors: Shingirirai Chakoma, Jerome Rajendran, Xiaochang Pei, Anita Ghandehari, Jorge Alfonso Tavares Negrete, Rahim Esfandyarpour
abstract: Continuous health monitoring plays a critical role in early diagnosis, disease prevention, and personalized healthcare. While current wearable devices typically track physical parameters like heart rate or skin conductance, these signals provide only indirect insight into physiological conditions and are often influenced by external factors. Molecular biomarkers offer a more direct and accurate reflection of the body’s internal state, but most existing sensing methods are invasive, require complex fabrication, or depend on unstable biorecognition elements such as enzymes or antibodies. These limitations hinder long-term, on-body use and integration into practical wearable systems. To overcome these challenges, we present a battery-free, flexible, and wearable sensor for real-time cortisol monitoring in sweat. The sensor features stable and cost-effective artificial biorecognition elements, integrated with a 3D-nanomaterials printed transducer for capacitance-based cortisol sensing. An integrated 3D-printed microfluidic channel enables sweat collection for on-demand sensing. A readout circuitry was designed for wireless power and data transmission to a smartphone for real-time data visualization. We successfully demonstrated the sensor’s reliability in detecting stress-related changes, highlighting its potential for personalized, real-time health tracking in daily life.

title: Experimental Evaluation of Droop Control in Output-Parallel DAB Converters
authors: Henrique M. Rocha, Adriano F. Nardoto, Lucas F. Encarnação, Walbermark M. Dos Santos, Daniel Carletti, André Silva, Arthur Amorim, Rodrigo Fiorotti, Nelson H. B. Santana
abstract: This paper presents the application and experimental validation of two droop control strategies, traditional droop and RC-mode droop, for the parallel operation of Dual Active Bridge (DAB) converters in the DC/DC stage of a Solid-State Transformer (SST) using the Output-Parallel DAB (OP-DAB) topology. The RC-mode droop control demonstrated improved power sharing and enhanced dynamic response compared to the traditional method, with reduced voltage sag and smaller oscillations during transients. Experimental results validate the practical feasibility of both control approaches and confirm the advantages of the RC-mode droop strategy under different load conditions. The study highlights the relevance of experimental validation for modular power conversion systems.

title: Using the Transformer Model to Optimize the Graphic Element Combination and Creative Generation Process in Cultural and Creative Design
authors: Nazi Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In the traditional graphic design process, creative generation is monotonous. This paper proposes a model optimization design process based on Transformer, which uses the correlation between graphic elements and text descriptions and adopts a graphic-text joint encoding strategy to enhance the model's ability to generate graphic design ideas. By optimizing the loss function of contrastive learning and graphic content reconstruction, the matching degree between the graphic elements generated by the model and the design theme is further improved. Finally, the generative adversarial network (GAN) is used to optimize the combination of graphic elements. After applying GAN, the diversity scores of all samples are significantly improved, among which the diversity scores of design samples 1 and 3 are increased from 3.2 and 3.5 to 4 and 4.2 respectively. It provides feasible technical support for the automation and intelligence of cultural and creative design.

title: BERT Based Forensic Information Extraction and Visualization
authors: Parimalla Abhijith, S Likhil Kumar, E Sai Shrujana, N S S S Girish Kumar, M.A. Jabbar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Forensic investigations overwhelm investigators with textual evidence from case files, witness statements, and reports, requiring hours to examine written documents. The 'BERT Based Forensic Information Extraction and Visualization' provides the necessary solution by introducing Natural Language Processing into forensic investigation equipment, supporting human investigators with automated text comprehension systems that analyze documentary content and significantly accelerate information retrieval. Utilizing powerful models named BERT and RoBERTa, the system locates people, related locations, and items, recognizing unobvious emotional nuances and situational indicators. Developed with forensic experts and tested through systematic verification, the system allows analysts to focus on meaningful lead investigation as it automatically identifies meaningful relationships within extensive document volumes.Additionally, the paper emphasizes the ethical and legal significance of explainability, bias mitigation, and transparency-all of which are essential in forensic AI applications. In order to promote investigator trust and court-admissible insights, future work will concentrate on improving model interpretability.

title: Configuration Optimization and Low-carbon Operation Strategies of Renewable Energy Data Center
authors: Xiang Yuan, Chutian Yu, Lijun Zhang, Chenlin Gu, Meijin Gao, Jiarui Yang, Junjie Sun, Hao Zhang
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: In the context of the low-carbon transition, the deployment of green data centers (DCs) that rely predominantly on renewable energy sources is a pivotal approach to tackling carbon neutrality goals. The advancement of integrating renewable energy sources and the reduction of carbon emissions through synergistic grid operations have emerged as significant research priorities in this area. This research capitalizes on the inherent flexibility of DC energy usage to establish an optimized capacity planning framework for DCs powered by renewable energy, accounting for a range of energy supply contexts. A low-carbon operational strategy is proposed, with a focus on refining the interplay between DCs and the electrical grid. Through the development of energy consumption and carbon emission flow models, the study aspires to enhance system-wide efficiency while integrating constraints across multiple domains, such as DC infrastructure operations and energy system configurations. Additionally, a multi-energy complementary and coordinated optimization mechanism is examined to align energy capacity planning with data workload management across different scenarios, striving to reconcile economic sustainability with carbon neutrality objectives. The findings suggest that a hybrid configuration incorporating wind power, photovoltaic (PV) generation, and energy storage exhibits exceptional operational efficiency and low carbon emission costs.

title: 3D bioprinting of Insertable Oxygen, Glucose and Lactate Hydrogel Sensors
authors: Waqas Saleem, Ridhi Pradhan, Michael J. McShane
abstract: Continuous monitoring of physiological parameters is essential for effective diabetes management; however, current sensor platforms are limited by their invasive nature and associated complications. This study presents the fabrication of single-analyte-sensitive miniature barcode biosensors for the continuous monitoring of oxygen, glucose, and lactate. Two fabrication methods—soft lithography and 3D bioprinting—were employed, utilizing alginate microparticles embedded with phosphorescent assays. These microparticles were either integrated into a poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate (PEGDA) hydrogel casing or incorporated into a PEGDA-based ink formulation containing Laponite XLG for 3D bioprinting. Sensor performance was evaluated in a flow-through system using phosphorescence lifetime measurements under varying analyte concentrations: oxygen (0–210 µM), glucose (0–250 mg/dL), and lactate (0–20 mg/dL). Both fabrication methods produced analyte-responsive barcodes with comparable performance, while 3D bioprinting offered advantages in scalability and structural customization. These findings establish 3D bioprinting as a promising approach for fabricating implantable single-analyte sensors, providing a foundation for the development of next-generation multianalyte biosensors.

title: Blockchain Based on Encryption Scheme for Internet of Things Environment
authors: Kumar M P, Akila A
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In recent years, Internet of Things (IoT) technology has been widely used, especially in fields involving smart fitness and smart vehicles. IoT devices continuously generate real-time information and transmit it over the internet. IoT systems use a centralized design for statistical storage and processing within modern IoT processes. However, with the rapid development of network technologies, IoT environments have grown exponentially, ranging from military surveillance to e-smart health, traffic monitoring, and industrial control. Despite their numerous applications, improving IoT security remains a major concern. The reliance on third-party involvement in typical IoT systems to safeguard sensitive data during transmission has increased complex and significant concerns. Blockchain technology offers a modern solution for reducing third-party dependency in IoT environments and is essential for addressing security challenges. To address the aforementioned challenges, this study applies various approaches such as authorization, encryption, and validation, utilizing a blockchain-based encryption scheme within the IoT environment. The parameters considered in this study are storage cost, computation cost, throughput, latency, and correlation coefficient.

title: Experimental Study on the Distribution of Ground Total Electric Field Beneath a Unipolar Line at High Altitude
authors: Xiang Xiao, Zhixiong Huang, Xiaoxing Wei, Zhongyu Zeng, Xingming Bian
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Presently, there has been relatively comprehensive research on HVDC ion flow field both domestically and internationally. However, studies specifically focusing on the influence of air pressure on ion flow field remain limited. Existing measurements of ground-level total electric field at different altitudes are mostly based on full-scale field tests, which are inevitably affected by environmental disturbances. Moreover, the maximum altitude reached in these tests is only 4300 m, which falls short of the highest elevations encountered in current engineering projects. In this study, a measurement platform for the ground-level total electric field of a unipolar line-to-plate configuration was established in an artificial climate chamber with controllable temperature, humidity, and air pressure. A series of measurements and analyses were conducted. Finally, the variation of the ground-level total electric field magnitude directly beneath the conductor with respect to air pressure was analyzed. The results show that, under fixed voltage, the ground total electric field under the conductor increases linearly with the increase of altitude.

title: Real-Time Natural Disaster Prediction and Early Warning Using IoT and Graph Neural Networks
authors: Venkata Kiran Kumar Ravi, Sneh Gangwar, D. Sudheer Reddy, Love Kumar, Komali Lenka, R. Venkatesh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: More severe and frequent weather events and natural disasters are having an impact on governments and communities all around the world. They demolish infrastructure, murder people, and ruin economies. Reliable and accurate natural disaster prediction systems can help people get better at preparing for and responding to disasters. The proposed solution deals with this problem through preprocessing and training. Preprocessing, integration, purification, and feature extraction can all help make catastrophe data better. Graph signal processing is a great way to look at disaster data since sensor networks have geographic relationships. The next stage is to use a Graph Neural Network (GNN) to look at the data and make predictions about when natural disasters will happen. The model does a better job of predicting human deaths (mean value of 0.973) than more traditional methods. When utilised with strong machine learning models and graph-based data processing, it works well. This study says that GNNs can help us predict natural disasters better. GNNs make accurate and reliable predictions, which then lead to early actions that lower hazards to people and infrastructure.

title: Subway Passenger Flow Prediction Algorithm Based on Computer Vision
authors: Ning Guo, Xiaochen Hu, Decun Dong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: As an efficient public transportation mode, subways are experiencing continuous growth in passenger flow. Traditional manual scheduling models are no longer sufficient, and accurate passenger flow prediction algorithms are urgently needed to optimize operational management. This paper constructs a multi-dimensional fusion subway passenger flow prediction algorithm system based on computer vision technology. First, computer vision technology is used to collect real-time passenger data within subway stations, and deep learning algorithms are used to extract and analyze data features. Second, a spatiotemporal data fusion strategy is introduced to improve the model's adaptability to complex passenger flow patterns. Experimental results show that using parallel computing technology, the algorithm runs within 80 seconds when the data size is 1 million, providing effective support for intelligent scheduling and rational resource allocation in subway operations.

title: Correlation Between Abnormal Carbon Emission Data and Business Economic Growth Based on Artificial Intelligence
authors: Mingyi Xiao, Fanghao Xiao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: This paper aims to investigate the correlation between abnormal CE data and corporate economic growth using artificial intelligence (AI). By analyzing AI, CE data anomalies, and corporate economic growth, this method is applied to the correlation analysis between CE data and economic growth to address the issue of improving the level of low-carbon economic development. This paper analyzes AI, corporate economic benefits, and economic growth, experimentally analyzing the performance of this method and explaining it using relevant theoretical formulas. The results demonstrate a correlation between abnormal corporate economic benefit data and corporate economic growth. Among the four factors influencing corporate economic growth, industrial development scale is the most important factor influencing corporate economic benefit data, with the impact rate exceeding <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 0 \%}$</tex> across all regions.

title: RFC-YOLO: A Model for Rapeseed Flower Cluster Detection and Counting Based on UAV Images
authors: Yang Tian, Xinmeng Liu, Chenglong Li, Xiaoyong Sun
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: Rapeseed (Brassica napus L.) is a globally significant oil crop, and its flowering stage plays a critical role in determining yield. Accurate detection and counting of rapeseed flower clusters can assist breeders in predicting field yield and optimizing breeding strategies. We propose an automatic detection and counting method for rapeseed flower clusters based on UAV RGB images, named RFC-YOLO. First, we add the P2 detection layer and remove the P5 detection layer to enhance the model's ability to detect dense small targets while reducing model parameters. Second, a Feature Complementary Mapping (FCM) module was integrated into the backbone to more deeply incorporate spatial location information, thereby improving the localization of small targets. Finally, the SimAM attention mechanism was incorporated to enhance feature extraction efficiency and strengthen the focus on critical information. Experimental results on the test set show that our model achieved a Precision of 91.56%, Recall of 90.78%, and mAP@ 0.5 of 95.94%. Additionally, counting accuracy metrics R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, MAE and RMSE reached 0.984, 12.46, and 19.06 respectively. The parameters of RFC-YOLO reduced by 67.4%, the model size reduced by 62.0%, which effectively improves the detection and counting performance in complex scenarios while maintaining low computational overhead. The proposed RFC-YOLO model and online detection system provide an efficient and convenient solution for the detection and counting of rapeseed flower clusters.

title: A Study of Digital Filtering Techniques in DC-AC Converters to Mitigate Grid Voltage Harmonic Propagation
authors: André de Souza Leone, Henrique M. V. D. B. Campos, Édwin Augusto Tonolo, William Rafhael da Silva, Rômulo Francisco Lepinsk Lopes, Carlos Gabriel Bianchin
abstract: This paper aims to study the filtering resources used in the control loop of a DC-AC converter to avoid the propagation of harmonic voltage content in the connection to the power grid. A Dual Second Order Generalized Integrator (DSOGI) pre-filter is used to acquire the phase and frequency of the power grid, eliminating part of the harmonic content. Then, a voltage feedforward loop is applied to reduce noise in the current control loop. The filters effectively maintained the harmonic content produced by the converter current below the limits established in the IEEE 1547-2018 standard. In addition, the resulting total harmonic distortion (THD) of the current was 3.1% for a total voltage distortion of the power grid of 12.1%.

title: Multilingual ASR for Indic Languages Using OpenAI’s Whisper
authors: Kadwasra Swapna, Maha Lakshimi, Sheri Shiva Prasad Reddy, Gowthami, Bittu Kumar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: Speech-to-text technology has witnessed remarkable advancements with the advent of deep learning models such as OpenAI Whisper. However, developing speech recognition and translation systems for Indian languages poses challenges due to linguistic diversity, varying accents, and limited resources. This paper presents a web-based multilingual Speech-to-Text (STT) and translation application that operates without the need for API keys, enabling offline processing for major Indian languages. The application integrates automatic speech recognition (ASR) using the Whisper model and provides seamless translation between languages such as Telugu, Hindi, and English. We discuss system architecture, language model optimization, preprocessing techniques, and interface design to ensure accurate and efficient transcription and translation. This solution improves accessibility and usability, particularly in low-resource settings, empowering users to perform speech-to-text and translation tasks effectively.

title: Fraud Detection in Financial Transactions Using a Machine Learning
authors: Smita Rani Parija, Riya Kumari, Divyanshu Tiwari, Kumar Shubham, Prabhakar Rath, Lopamudra Das
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: With digital transactions becoming the norm, fraud in financial systems—especially credit card fraud— is growing fast. Traditional fraud detection methods are no longer sufficient. They’re too slow, too rigid, and not built to catch today’s evolving threats. This paper examines how machine learning can help bridge that gap. We’ve experimented with different ML models like decision trees, support vector machines (SVM), neural networks, and even advanced models like CNNs and RNNs. Our goal? To catch fraud faster, reduce false alarms, and build smarter systems that adapt as fraud patterns evolve. We also touch on the challenges and what’s next for this field—including combining models and using blockchain for added security.

title: $S D-\mathcal{H}_{2}$ Controller via DLMIS Applied to a Boost Converter with Integral Action
authors: Claudio Gabriel Venceslau Vale, Roberta R. T. Alves, Marcus V. S. Costa, René D. O. Pereira, Victor de P. B. Aguiar, Rosana C. B. Rego, Olympio Cipriano da Silva Filho
abstract: This work presents the development of a SampledData <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathcal{H}_{2}\left(S D-\mathcal{H}_{2}\right)$</tex> controller based on Differential Linear Matrix Inequalities (DLMIs), applied to a Boost converter. The proposed method aims to ensure robust performance under polytopic uncertainties and external disturbances, while maintaining the output voltage within the desired range. The controller demonstrated robustness against abrupt perturbations, with the control signals remaining within admissible bounds. Compared to the Switched Robust Model Predictive Control (SR-MPC) strategy proposed in [1], applied to the same converter, the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S D-\mathcal{H}_{2}$</tex> controller also exhibited robust performance, but with reduced control effort and lower computational cost, enabling a more efficient implementation.

title: FoodAnalyzer: A Smart Web-Based Nutrition Analysis System for Indian Cuisine Using AI and Open Datasets
authors: Suvam Neog
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: The FoodAnalyzer is a smart web-based nutrition analysis tool that helps users discover and enjoy the nutritional values of their food, with special attention to Indian food. Employing AI-based image analysis of GPT-4 Vision model and nutritional information from OpenFoodFacts, the FoodAnalyzer enables users to upload food images, log meals, and receive analysis that can encompass calories, macronutrients, glycemic index, etc. Based on the MERN stack(MongoDB, Express.js, React.js, Node.js) and projects 75–85% accuracy for Indian food recognition based on benchmark studies. Pilot tests revealed 80% user satisfaction, showing its potential to bridge AI and healthy food decisions.

title: The Combined Effects of High-Temperature Aging, Mechanical Cycling, and Exposure Sequence on the Constitutive Behavior of SAC305 Solder
authors: Mahbub Alam Maruf, Souvik Chakraborty, Golam Rakib Mazumder, Jeffrey C. Suhling, Pradeep Lall
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Lead-free electronic assemblies are prone to failure under cyclic loading at high temperature. In applications like automotive control modules, solder joints endure both cyclic mechanical stresses from vibrations and thermal transients due to power switching. At the same time, such electronics operate at very high temperature. The combined effects of cyclic mechanical stresses, thermal cycling-induced strain from CTE mismatches, and prolonged high-temperature operation accelerate fatigue, microstructural degradation, and ultimately lead to solder joint failure. While prior research has investigated the individual influences of isothermal aging or mechanical cycling separately, studies on their combined impact remain unexplored. This study explores how high-temperature aging, mechanical cycling, and their sequence (aging + cycling vs. cycling + aging) affect the constitutive behavior of SAC305 solder alloy. Cylindrical SAC305 uniaxial specimens with desired microstructure were cast in glass tubes utilizing a controlled reflow procedure. The prepared samples were separated into groups, and then subjected to one of two different preconditioning sequences: (1) isothermal aging followed by mechanical cycling (aging + cycling), or (2) mechanical cycling followed by isothermal aging (cycling + aging). The test matrix included high temperature aging exposures performed at $T=125{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ for durations from 0-20 days. The mechanical cycling loadings were performed at room temperature using a strain range of $\varepsilon= \pm 0.006$ and a strain rate of $10^{-3} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$. The test matrix included cycling durations of 0-300 cycles. After preconditioning, the specimens in each test group were subjected to either uniaxial stress-strain or creep testing. The associated mechanical properties for each preconditioning exposure were extracted from the test data, and then compared to the mechanical properties for pristine samples with no aging or cycling. Our results indicate that the order of aging and cycling exposures is important, and that the samples that underwent cycling before aging exhibited greater mechanical property degradation than those subjected to aging before cycling. For the samples that were cycled first, the microstructural damage during the initial cycling was observed to allow for more rapid IMC coarsening and breakdown of dendritic structure during subsequent aging.

title: Research on Economic Optimal Scheduling of Distribution Network with Distributed Renewable Energy Considering Demand Side Response and Energy Storage
authors: Hongqiang Tian, Ludeng Liu, Jindian Lu, Bo Wang, Qianjin Gui, Xiaoyang Li
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: In this paper, an economic optimization scheduling model of distribution network including distributed photovoltaic, wind power, energy storage system and demand side response is constructed. The model aims to minimize the total operating cost of the system under the premise of satisfying the operation constraints of the distribution network, and may take into account voltage stability and load fluctuation by collaboratively optimizing power generation, energy storage charging and discharging, and transferable and reducible loads. The model elaborates the output characteristics of renewable energy, the operation constraints of energy storage system, the implementation mode of demand response, the power flow equation and safe operation constraints of distribution network. The objective function comprehensively considers the power purchase cost, network loss cost, energy storage operation cost and incentive cost and benefit of demand response. Through a case study of an IEEE 33-bus distribution network, the effectiveness of the proposed model is verified, and the potential of demand-side response and energy storage in reducing operating costs, stabilizing load fluctuations, and improving renewable energy absorption capacity is evaluated. The results show that the rational use of demand-side resources and energy storage systems can significantly improve the economy and operational flexibility of distribution networks with high proportion of renewable energy.

title: Energy Function-Based Identification for Cascading Generator Out-of-Step Caused by HVDC Blocking
authors: Junyu Liu, Huijuan Quan, Jitai Li, Shiqi Fu, Ruizhe Yao, Haifeng Wang
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: With the application of high voltage direct current (HVDC) technology, the impact of HVDC transmission systems on the secure and stable operation of power grids has become increasingly significant. The complex coupling between AC and DC systems also complicates the analysis of cascading failures in AC/DC hybrid power grids. To address this issue, this paper proposes a method for identifying cascading failure mode of generator out-of-step caused by sending-end HVDC blocking, based on energy function analysis. First, the mechanism of generator out-of-step caused by HVDC blocking is analyzed. Then, an identification method of cascading failure mode is developed based on energy function method. Finally, the HVDC infeed system and its sending-end AC grid are modeled in PSD-BPA, and simulation results validate the effectiveness of proposed method in identifying cascading failure mode caused by HVDC blocking.

title: Predicting Cybersickness Susceptibility from Gaze Behavior
authors: Aisha Zahir, Brady Li, Wallace Lages
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We investigate whether differences in gaze behavior are correlated with stronger field dependence and the tendency to experience cybersickness sooner in virtual reality. Participants experienced a 30-minute roller coaster designed to induce cybersickness. Participants were asked to align two dots vertically while eye-tracking was collected. The results suggest that participants with stronger field dependence tended to focus more on the background and periphereal scenery, experienced greater sensory conflict, and dropped out sooner than those with more field-independent patterns of gaze. These findings point to a potential correlation between gaze strategies, field dependence, and cybersickness, motivating further analysis of gaze metrics as a predictive tool.

title: Smart Parking System
authors: Paras Goyal, Preet Taparia, Shivam Sharma, Divanshu Jain, Hanuman P. Agrawal, Gaurav Mani Khanal
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: Growing demands for effective parking management in the urban context demand intelligent solutions. The current paper describes an IoT, and machine learning-capable intelligent smart parking system intended to boost parking operations using automation and processing of real-time data. The system is configured in two modes: a convenient web platform for booking and payment and an IoT-integrated parking lot for smart vehicle monitoring and slot management. It uses sensors, a camera module, and Optical Character Recognition (OCR) for license plate detection, with Python-based algorithms for real-time validation. By facilitating automatic slot allocation, gate control, and dynamic fare calculation, the system enhances user convenience while avoiding urban issues like congestion and inefficiency.

title: Evaluating the Degradation of Thermal Interface Materials in Liquid Immersion Cooling Systems using Ultrasonic Methods
authors: Jacey Birkenmeyer, Bijay Chhetri, Shubhra Bansal, Luz D. Sotelo
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Immersion cooling systems for data centers are significantly more energy efficient and use less water than traditional air- or water-cooled systems. However, the long-term mechanisms of degradation of Thermal Interface Materials (TIMs) and the effects of the interaction between coolant fluid and TIMs have not been thoroughly studied and there are currently no nondestructive/noninvasive approaches to monitor degradation. Ultrasonic nondestructive evaluation uses high-frequency sound waves to detect defects in a part and characterize its material properties. This paper will discuss the use of ultrasonic nondestructive evaluation to detect changes in material properties in coolant fluids and TIMs as well as scanning acoustic microscopy to map defects in the TIMs. For this purpose, combinations of various commercially available coolant fluids and TIMs were evaluated. TIM samples were placed in coolant fluid and heated at $\mathbf{1 0 0}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}} \mathbf{C}$ for $\mathbf{5 0 0}$ hours and $\mathbf{1 5 0}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}} \mathbf{C}$ for $\mathbf{1 0 0 0}$ hours (in accordance with JESD22-A103C test standard) to simulate an immersion cooling system in a data center. Then, sound wave speed and attenuation measurements were collected and compared with optical spectroscopy and visual inspection methods to identify the sound metrics most sensitive to material changes. While established chemical and physical experimental characterization was used to provide insight into the fundamental mechanisms of degradation for each TIM-coolant combination, ultrasonic approaches enable more rapid, accessible, and nondestructive characterization. This information may provide the industry with additional methods of degradation characterization which may be leveraged for periodic and/or continuous monitoring.

title: Object Detection Method in Foggy Images with Dynamic Convolution Kernels and Crossdimensional Attention
authors: Ran Luo, Yifan Yang, Jiangpeng Du, Yawei Li
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: To address the issues of difficult extraction of effective image features and poor performance in small object detection caused by fog occlusion, an object detection method in foggy images with dynamic convolution kernels and crossdimensional attention is proposed. First, a dynamic convolution kernel module is designed, which multiplies the local attention scores with the convolution kernel parameters at corresponding positions, enabling adaptive adjustment of the convolution kernel parameters based on local features and enhancing the feature extraction capability of the kernels. Second, cross-dimensional attention is constructed to achieve multi-dimensional feature complementarity through the interaction and fusion of spatial and channel dimensions. Additionally, a dedicated small object detection head is introduced, which takes the cross-dimensional attention as input to improve the accuracy of small object detection. Experimental results show that the improved algorithm achieves mAP@0.5 scores of 73.1% and 52.5% on the public datasets RTTS and Foggy Cityscapes, respectively, representing improvements of 3.8 and 5.6 percentage points over the baseline algorithm.

title: Performance Evaluation of Alerting in Grafana and Prometheus for Kafka Monitoring
authors: Thandar Aung, Hnin Thiri Zaw, Aung Htein Maw, Myat Thida Mon
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: In big data era, real-time monitoring and alerting are the critical for quickly detecting and reacting to significant occurrences enabling organizations to reduce damage, increase efficiency, and preserve security. Apache Kafka is a real-time distributed streaming platform to prove high-throughput, low-latency data pipelines. Monitoring Kafka with Prometheus, Grafana, and JMX Exporter is a powerful technique to maintain the health, performance and reliability of real-time data. The system focuses on the performance evaluation of real-time alerting using Grafana, Prometheus and JMX Exporter for Kafka monitoring. The system configures real-time alert rules based on Kafka metrics and evaluates reliability, responsiveness and effectiveness of alert detection in various Kafka failure cases, such as broker failures, high under-replicated partitions, and JVM utilization of resources. The experimental results demonstrate when designed correctly, the integrated system provides accurate and timely alerts with low latency, replica configuration and a heap ratio for response time. These results indicate that open-source monitoring tools can offer a reliable and affordable Kafka infrastructure alerting strategy.

title: Study on Voltage Spike Suppression and Commutation Path Optimization for Inverters Based on ANPC-5L Topology
authors: Yiming Wang, Po Xu, Ke Yang, Daming Huang, Jingxia Wang, Haohui Yuan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: This study addresses the voltage spike issue caused by dead time during switching transitions in active neutral-point-clamped five-level photovoltaic inverters. Analysis of the conventional ANPC-5L topology's commutation paths reveals that the voltage spikes primarily originate from inductive freewheeling currents flowing through anti-parallel diodes. An improved switching control strategy is proposed to eliminate these spikes, optimizing the switching tube conduction modes and redundant state configurations. This approach reconstructs the freewheeling path during dead time, preventing transient overshoot voltage levels. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed strategy suppresses ±2E voltage spikes and significantly enhances the symmetry and linearity of the output current waveform, achieving a total harmonic distortion (THD) of only 1.01%. Notably, this strategy incurs no additional hardware costs and remains compatible with existing control systems, providing an effective solution for the reliable operation of high-voltage, high-power inverters.

title: A Model-Based Design Approach Towards Software-Defined Vehicles with Service-Oriented Architecture
authors: Tanuku SaiLakshmi Madhuri, Bala Vishnu J, Prasad Patil
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
abstract: The advent of Software-Defined Vehicles (SDVs) requires flexibility, scalability, and upgradability in advanced architectures.Traditional signal-based systems are tightly coupled to monolithic architectures, which limit adaptability and modular expansion. The paper proposes a change in architecture from monolithic to Service-Oriented Architecture (SOA) by ModelBased Design (MBD) and Adaptive AUTOSAR. The shift involves moving from signal-based to event-driven communication, enabling better modularization and integration. The modeling and code generation in an MBD environment and then an executable was obtained and exported onto a Linux-based system on the Raspberry Pi and QEMU for validation. The AEB (Autonomous Emergency Braking) model was considered to demonstrate this transition. Performance metrics, including latency, CPU usage, and service discovery time, were measured on both platforms to validate real-time suitability.

title: ERNIE-HGA: A Hierarchical Gated Attention Network With Multi-Granularity Feature Fusion for Chinese Sensitive Information Detection
authors: Xinren Peng, Yongzhong Huang
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: With the growing significance of network information security, sensitive information identification has become a critical challenge in safeguarding cyberspace security and fostering a healthy ecosystem. Traditional detection methods exhibit limitations in processing massive, dynamic, and contextually complex text data, and existing models struggle to effectively capture the multi-granularity features of sensitive information. In response to these challenges, this paper proposes E-HGA, an innovative architecture that integrates the ERNIE pretrained model with a Hierarchical Gated Attention (HGA) mechanism. The HGA module is designed with three parallel attention branches operating at the word, phrase, and sentence levels, respectively extracting keyword, local composition, and global semantic features. A gated fusion module dynamically aggregates these multi-scale representations, enabling the comprehensive capture of key semantic information from different granularities. Experimental results on the COLD and CSDD datasets demonstrate that the proposed E-HGA model achieves higher F1-scores than mainstream baseline models such as BERT and RoBERTa. This validates the effectiveness of multigranularity collaborative modeling in improving the accuracy of sensitive information identification.

title: Study of Rail Potential Suppression Based on DC Bus Voltage Droop Control
authors: Guilu Zhang, Qiaoyue Li, Tongtong Zhou, Fengchuan Xu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: In the DC traction power supply system, there is a common problem of abnormal increase of rail potential to ground, which makes the potential personal safety hazards to passenger, and the protection closure used in rail potential limiting device will cause a large amount of current leakage, and exacerbate the stray current corrosion. This paper studies the characteristics of DC traction power supply system and train operation, analyzes the rail potential problem under the influence of train braking using DC traction power supply model, and verifies the train operation condition and current flow rule through actual system test. Through the study, the rail potential inhibition measures based on DC bus voltage droop control are proposed, and the results show that the method can effectively inhibit the problem of abnormal elevation of rail-to-ground potential.

title: Optimization Design of Iot Sensor Front-End Circuit Based on Low Power Adaptive Algorithm
authors: Qin Hong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: To address the low energy efficiency and instability of IoT sensors operating in complex environments, this paper proposes a front-end circuit optimization design method based on a low-power adaptive algorithm. This method introduces an adaptive mechanism in the front-end signal conditioning and analog-to-digital conversion stages. Combined with signal feature extraction and feedback control techniques, the method dynamically adjusts key parameters such as amplifier gain, filter bandwidth, and sampling frequency by monitoring the input signal's amplitude and rate of change in real time. This ensures that the circuit enters a high-precision operating mode only when needed and automatically switches to a low-power state at all other times. Furthermore, a low-voltage power supply configuration and dynamic biasing techniques are employed to optimize the circuit topology at each stage, effectively reducing both static and dynamic power consumption. Experimental results show that when the input signal is 10 mV, the front-end circuit power consumption is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$16.3 \mu ~\mathrm{W}$</tex> with the adaptive function disabled, and the equivalent input noise level is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$15.8 \mu ~\mathrm{V}$</tex> rms at a gain of 40 dB. This demonstrates the design's reliable signal acquisition capabilities and efficient power management performance under varying signal strengths and environmental conditions. This research provides a feasible technical path for improving the stability and energy efficiency of IoT sensor systems under long-term operation and variable scenarios.

title: Diagnosis and Application of Storage Feeder Based on I/O-Link Technology
authors: Lei Liu, Jin Zhou, Kaihui Liu, Huan Yang, Yang Liu, Shuxian Fan, Yuehui Liang, Jianlin Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Manufacturing System (ICAMTMS)
abstract: The equipment detection system of the storage feeder features numerous detection points, with hidden fault risks that are highly concealed. In actual production processes, due to the production environment and other factors, the signal strength of the detection devices may weaken, leading to potential faults in the equipment detection system. To reduce the failure rate of the detection device on storage feeder equipment and enhance production efficiency, a diagnosis and application system based on I/O Link technology for storage feeder equipment is proposed. First, it diagnoses sensors or actuators, collects data such as process values and parameter information, and transmits data parameters such as detection signal on-off status and signal strength to the PLC processor. The program algorithm then utilizes these data to perform functions such as data diagnosis, information feedback, and early warning. Secondly, the control of the inlet and supply systems of the storage bin feeder is optimized. The status information of the sensors is discerned using the I/O Link module, and emergency response measures for the production of the inlet and supply systems are designed. Finally, the real-time status of the storage feeder is intelligently diagnosed, and functions such as intelligent early warning, data assessment, and visual output are implemented through the WinCC visualization interface. Ultimately, intelligent diagnosis of the tobacco storage feeder is achieved.

title: Femtosecond Laser Surface Processing (FLSP) of 6061 Aluminum Exhibits Flow Boiling Enhancement Using Opteon 2P50 for Various Mass Fluxes
authors: Josh Gerdes, Logan Pettit, Graham Kaufman, Craig Zuhlke, George Gogos
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: This work investigates flow boiling enhancement through surface modification of 6061 aluminum using Opteon ${ }^{\text {TM }}$ 2P50, a low global warming potential (GWP) developmental dielectric fluid. Femtosecond laser surface processing (FLSP) is utilized to create self-organized, quasi-periodic micro- and nano-scale structures on the aluminum. The FLSP manufacturing technique creates multiscale structures with nanoscale features covering microscale ones in a single processing step. These multiscale structures create additional nucleation sites while also increasing the surface area for fluid interaction. An FLSP surface was tested up to critical heat flux (CHF) with multiple mass flow rates and compared to a polished surface baseline to determine heat transfer improvements over the baseline. Results show enhanced performance for the FLSP surface compared to the polished reference surface with an increase in heat transfer coefficient of over $\mathbf{1 5 0 \%}$. Furthermore, the FLSP surface reduces temperature overshoot by more than 50% when compared to the polished surface. These results demonstrate how FLSP on an aluminum surface provides a solution for two phase heat transfer enhancement.

title: Development of an Experimental Platform of an Isolated DC Microgrid with Solar Photovoltaic Generation and Battery Energy Storage
authors: Renan R. Almeida, Maico S. Lima, Rodrigo C. Lobo, Andrei O. Almeida
abstract: In recent decades, the continuous development of renewable sources and energy storage systems has brought about the concept of microgrid. Specially the photovoltaic and wind energy sources, in addition with lithium-ion batteries and hydrogen-based energy storage systems, further encourage the development of microgrids. This paper aims to present an experimental platform of an isolated DC microgrid, developed at CEFET-MG, with photovoltaic generation and battery energy storage. In order for this project to be reproducible, the structure of the microgrid is presented, as well as the components used for its assembly. A centralized control strategy was used in this paper, in order to demonstrate the microgrid operation. The control strategy uses local controller at the converters and a general management system, which allows to optimize the energy use. Preliminary results are presented, with the battery submitted to completely charging process and the solar panel submitted to irradiance variation.

title: A Surface Acoustic Wave Biosensor for Early Cancer Diagnosis
authors: İsmail Bütün, Melis Hazal Porsuk, Sibel Çetinel, Ali Koşar
abstract: This study presents the design, development, and application of a surface acoustic wave (SAW)-based biosensor for early detection of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), which is a biomarker protein associated with hepatocellular carcinoma and ovarian cancer. The biosensor leverages the interaction between surface-bound receptors and target biomolecules (AFP proteins) to induce measurable shifts in the acoustic wave properties such as the frequency and insertion loss (IL). The sensing platform is integrated with a microfluidic system, enhancing its real-time detection capabilities and preventing exposure to external influences that affect the signal properties during the sensing process. To achieve high specificity in AFP recognition, the gold surface located at the center of the delay line, matching the size of the aperture, was functionalized. Experimental validations confirmed that the sensor is capable of detecting biomarker concentrations as low as 50 pg/mL (and potentially even lower). The findings highlight the potential of SAW biosensors for rapid, label-free, and non-invasive cancer diagnostics, with implications for early disease detection and clinical applications. Future work will focus on the improvements in biomarker selectivity and detecting lower concentrations, as well as on expanding the technology for broader oncological screening.

title: Low-Complexity Configuration for Implementing Odd-Order Variable Notch-Width Filters
authors: Tian-Bo Deng
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: An efficient design methodology is presented for implementing an odd-order variable notch-width (OO-VNW) filter. The OO-VNW-filter complexity is considerably reduced, while its accuracy keeps nearly unchanged. We first discuss how to guarantee the stability of the OO-VNW filter, and then show a 2-step technique for designing the OO-VNW filter. The OO-VNW filter has its coefficients represented using polynomial functions of the notch-width (NW) parameter. The 2-step technique has two goals. One is to reduce OO-VNW-filter’s complexity, and the other is to maintain OO-VNW-filter’s stability. The trick to reduce the complexity is to use the polynomials of unequal orders, leading to the reduction of the total orders. Furthermore, the trick to guarantee the stability is to perform parameter transformations. With the two tricks incorporated into the 2-step technique, a complexity-reduced OO-VNW filter can be designed, while it remains stable during filtering operations. The paper demonstrates an example for validating the 2-step technique, verifying the achieved complexity reduction and superior performance. As compared to the scheme that uses equal-order polynomial functions, the new technique can get an OO-VNW filter whose complexity is significantly reduced, while the performance almost remains the same.

title: Design and Optimization of a Ku-Band RF Energy Harvester for IoT Devices
authors: Manee Sangaran Diagarajan, Randee Nolan Law, Tee Wei Hown, Intan Izafina Idrus
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: This paper presents the design and optimization of a Ku-band RF energy harvester capable of powering low-power IoT devices operating at 3V. The proposed system integrates a high-efficiency microstrip patch antenna and a rectifier-based RF-to-DC conversion circuit. The antenna is designed to operate within the Ku-band frequency range (12–18 GHz), offering a compact footprint, directional radiation, and impedance matching optimized for maximum power capture. Simulations in High Frequency Structure Simulator (HFSS) indicate that the antenna achieves a peak gain of 5.97 dBi and a return loss of –22.9 dB at the center frequency of 14 GHz, with a bandwidth of 290 MHz. The harvested RF signal is fed into a 5-stage voltage multiplier circuit optimized using National Instruments (NI) Multisim which employs Infenion BAS3005B-02V Schottky diodes to minimize threshold losses. The RF-to-DC converter demonstrates a peak conversion efficiency of 61.2% at an input power of –5 dBm, delivering a regulated output voltage of 3.02V across a 1kΩ load. The integrated system is evaluated through co-simulation, confirming its potential to power ultra-low-power IoT sensor nodes in urban and indoor environments where Ku-band ambient RF sources are available.

title: Four-Quadrant Direct Instantaneous Torque Control for SRM Drives Applied to Electrified Vehicles
authors: Paulo Robson Melo Costa, Vinícius Augusto De Abreu Batista, Marcelo Vinícius De Paula, Tárcio André Dos Santos Barros
abstract: This work presents a four-quadrant Direct Instantaneous Torque Control (DITC) strategy for Switched Reluctance Machine (SRM) drives. The proposed DITC operates as a finite state machine that continuously evaluates the torque error, defined as the difference between the torque reference and the estimated instantaneous torque in each phase. Based on predefined rules and threshold values, the algorithm selects the appropriate switching states for the power converter. The conduction status of each phase is also considered to determine valid switching actions. The control logic is designed to prioritize the incoming phase in the torque production sequence, enhancing system efficiency. Furthermore, the DITC enables operation across all four quadrants of the torque-speed plane. Drive angles were optimized using a one-factor-at-a-time (OFAT) method to achieve a balance between high efficiency and low torque ripple. The proposed control strategy was validated through simulations and experimental tests in the context of an electric vehicle propulsion system.

title: In-Place Double Stimulus Methodology for Subjective Assessment of High Quality Images
authors: Shima Mohammadi, Mohsen Jenadeleh, Michela Testolina, Jon Sneyers, Touradj Ebrahimi, Dietmar Saupe, João Ascenso
publish: 2025 13th European Workshop on Visual Information Processing (EUVIP)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel double stimulus subjective assessment methodology for the evaluation of high-quality images to address the limitations of existing protocols in detecting subtle perceptual differences. The In-place Double Stimulus Quality Scale (IDSQS) allows subjects to alternately view a reference and a distorted image at the same spatial location, facilitating a more intuitive detection of differences in quality, especially at high to visually lossless quality levels. A large-scale crowdsourcing study employing this methodology was conducted, generating a comprehensive public dataset to evaluate perceived image quality across several compression algorithms and distortion levels. An additional contribution is the modeling of quality scores using a Beta distribution, allowing for the assessment of variability and subject consistency. Our findings demonstrate the effectiveness of the IDSQS methodology in achieving high correlation with more precise subjective evaluation benchmarks. The dataset, subjective data, and graphical user interface developed for this study are publicly available at https://github.com/shimamohammadi/IDSQS.

title: Towards Interpretable and Consistent Multi-Step Mathematical Reasoning in Large Language Models
authors: Xinyue Huang, Zeyu Wang, Xin Liu, Yueqi Tian, Qian Leng
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: Mathematical reasoning, particularly within the K-12 education context, demands models that provide not only correct answers but also transparent, interpretable solution paths. Existing large language models (LLMs) often struggle with multi-step math problems due to their limited capacity for symbolic manipulation and structured reasoning. To address these challenges, we propose MetaMath-LLaMA, a novel metacognitive modular framework designed to enhance the reasoning abilities of LLMs through dynamic task orchestration. This framework integrates three core components: a Transformer-based metacognitive scheduler that learns to allocate reasoning subtasks adaptively; a symbolic parser with semantic grounding that fuses syntactic structure with contextual embeddings; and a hybrid symbolic-neural computation unit that seamlessly transitions between deterministic symbolic logic and neural approximation. The entire model is optimized through a multi-task training scheme coupled with curriculum learning and multi-tiered selfvalidation to mitigate reasoning errors and improve interpretability. We expect MetaMath-LLaMA to improve classroom usability by producing clearer step-by-step solution paths, aiding educators in assessment and supporting student conceptual understanding. Our approach offers a more modular, explainable, and effective solution for handling diverse mathematical tasks in K-12 education, and it outperforms traditional monolithic reasoning systems in logical fidelity and conceptual clarity.

title: A Fast Volumetric Capture and Reconstruction Pipeline for Dynamic Point Clouds and Gaussian Splats
authors: Athanasios Charisoudis, Simone Croci, Kit Yung Lam, Pascal Frossard, Aljosa Smolic
publish: Proceedings of the 22nd ACM SIGGRAPH European Conference on Visual Media Production
abstract: We present a fast and efficient volumetric capture and reconstruction system that processes either RGB-D or RGB-only input to generate 3D representations in the form of point clouds and Gaussian splats. For Gaussian splat reconstructions, we took the GPS-Gaussian regressor and improved it, enabling high-quality reconstructions with minimal overhead. The system is designed for easy setup and deployment, supporting in-the-wild operation under uncontrolled illumination and arbitrary backgrounds, as well as flexible camera configurations, including sparse setups, arbitrary camera numbers and baselines. Captured data can be exported in standard formats such as PLY, MPEG V-PCC, and SPLAT, and visualized through a web-based viewer or Unity/Unreal plugins. A live on-location preview of both input and reconstruction is available at 5–10 FPS. We present qualitative findings focused on deployability and targeted ablations. The complete framework is open-source, facilitating reproducibility and further research.

title: Efficient and Flexible Multi-Qubit Entanglement Transmission in Quantum Networks
authors: Yanan Gao, Song Yang, Fan Li, Youqi Li, Liehuang Zhu, Stojan Trajanovski, Xiaoming Fu
abstract: The unprecedented advancements in quantum technology have opened new prospects for the widespread adoption of quantum applications, placing new demands on the information transmission capabilities of large-scale quantum networks. Long-distance and stable entanglements are deemed as the lifeline in quantum network communication. However, some weaknesses, e.g., quantum decoherence, scarce quantum memory, and uneven-quality entanglement, of the quantum entanglement hinder the development. In this paper, we propose Sophon, an online transmission framework for quantum networks, which utilizes high-dimensional entanglements to concurrently transmit multi-qubit data to satisfy the transmission requirements of the real-time request set. We first model the quantum network with multi-qubit entanglement represented by $W$ quantum state and then formulate the Entanglement Routing and Qubit Provisioning (ERQP) problem as a global-local optimization process. To solve the ERQP problem, we distributedly regard each network node as an RL agent for resource provisioning and extend the step-updating of the Markov Decision Process by introducing a centralized controller for entanglement route selection to optimize local and global objectives, respectively. Extensive simulations demonstrate, on the self-made simulation platform, Sophon achieves a $21.89\%-66.52\%$ decrease in the communication cost, and is more robust on different scales of the network topology and the request set than the baselines.

title: A Compact Subnanosecond Differential Pulse Generator With a Single-Power Supply
authors: Changbin Liu, Li Wang, Xiue Bao, Haijun Chen, Baiquan Wang, Zhensheng Shi, Xiaochao Tian, Anxue Zhang
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: This letter proposes a differential pulse generator based on a step recovery diode (SRD). Powered by a single supply, the differential pulse generator utilizes inverting and noninverting drivers implemented with metal–oxide–semiconductor field-effect transistors (MOSFETs) to form both forward and reverse bias loops for a single SRD. The SRD accumulates minority carriers in the forward bias loop and rapidly interrupts the current through symmetric inductors in the reverse bias loop. This process generates high-amplitude, subnanosecond differential pulses. Measurement results confirm the generation of high-quality differential pulses and demonstrate the suitability of the design for miniaturized ultrawideband (UWB) transceiver applications.

title: ALDS-YOLO: A Lightweight Defect Detection Model for Warehouse Carton Goods
authors: Binfang Cao, Minghui Tian, Jianqi Li, Weihao Li, Zhaoying Li
abstract: The integrity of carton packaging is critical to ensuring the efficient circulation of goods in large-scale warehouses. Due to the visual obstructions caused by high stacking of goods, Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are used for aerial visual inspection. However, limited by onboard computational resources, the detection model must be lightweight. Meanwhile, the diversity of printed patterns on cartons leads to complex backgrounds for defect detection and high inter-class similarity of defect features, so the difficulty of detection is further aggravated. Therefore, we propose an Adaptive and Lightweight Dynamic Sharing-You Only Look Once (ALDS-YOLO) method for visually inspecting large warehouses using UAVs. Firstly, an Adaptive and Lightweight Dynamic (ALD) module is designed to dynamically adjust the weight distribution of convolutional kernels. This effectively enhances the adaptive feature extraction ability of the model and the differentiation ability of the features with high similarity between classes, while reducing the computational complexity. Secondly, a Refined Lightweight Path Aggregation Network (RLPANet) is designed to strengthen the focus on channel and spatial information in bidirectional feature interaction. This enables the network to capture key defect features under complex backgrounds more accurately. Finally, a Lightweight Shared Convolutional Detection (LSCD) is introduced to reduce the computational complexity by using Shared Convolution with compensation mechanism, which avoids independent convolutional operations in each layer. Experimental results on the self-constructed Warehouse Storage Defect Inspection Dataset (WSDID) show that, compared with the baseline model YOLOv11n, the proposed ALDS-YOLO reduces the number of parameters by 11.54%, decreases FLOPs by 36.51%, and improves detection accuracy by 2.5%, which demonstrates that the proposed method better balances the detection accuracy and speed. In addition, the generalization experiments on three public datasets, Cardboard Defect, Welding Defect and GC10-DET, further verify the effectiveness and practicality of ALDS-YOLO in industrial scenarios.

title: Towards Generalizable Prompt Learning via Multi-regularization Guided Knowledge Distillation
authors: Xi Yang, Xinyue Zhong, Dechen Kong, Nannan Wang
abstract: Prompt learning has made significant progress in vision-language models (VLMs), enabling pre-trained models like CLIP to perform cross-domain tasks with few-shot or even zero-shot learning. However, existing methods tend to overfit the training data after fine-tuning on the target domain, leading to a decline in generalization ability and limiting their performance on unseen categories.To address these challenges, we propose a multi-regularization guided knowledge distillation towards generalizable prompt learning. This approach enhances the model’s adaptability and generalization through different stages of regularization while mitigating performance degradation caused by target domain training. Specifically, within the image encoder of CLIP, we introduce Residual Regularization, which binds additional residual connections to certain transformer blocks. This design provides greater flexibility, allowing the model to adjust to new data distributions when adapting to the target domain.Furthermore, during training, we impose Self-distillation Regularization to ensure that while adapting to the target domain, the model preserves its prior generalization knowledge. Specifically, we regularize the intermediate layer outputs of Transformer Blocks to prevent the model from excessively favoring target domain data. Additionally, we employ an unsupervised knowledge distillation strategy to enforce multi-level alignment between the teacher and student models by Direction Distillation Regularization. This ensures that both models maintain consistent visual feature orientations under the same textual features, thereby enhancing overall model stability and cross-domain adaptability.Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves more stable classification performance in both cross-domain few-shot classification and domain adaptation settings.
