title: Distributed Entanglement Routing Scheme with Fidelity Guarantee in Quantum Networks
authors: Jiesheng Tan, Zhonghui Li, Jian Li, Bin Liu, Nenghai Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Entanglement routing selects a path to establish entanglement connections between two arbitrary nodes in quan-tum networks, which plays an important role in quantum com-munication. In quantum networks, quantum decoherence and limited network performance make it challenging to distribute entangled pairs. Many entanglement routing schemes have been proposed to solve this issue but most of them are in a centralized and synchronized manner. However, they may be infeasible in large-scale quantum networks. Therefore, in this paper, we propose a distributed and asynchronous entanglement routing scheme called DFER in which quantum nodes manage requests autonomously. The major challenge is quantum nodes have little knowledge about entangled pairs, which hinders the ability to establish fidelity guaranteed entanglement connections. To ad dress this challenge, we develop DLFR algorithm which estimates the fidelity of end-to-end entanglement connections based on link-level fidelity and calculates link-level fidelity requirement based on the characteristic of purification. Among nodes which meet link-level fidelity requirement, we design DFPS path se lection algorithm to select next hop with the highest expected throughput to distribute entangled pairs. Numerous simulation results demonstrate that DFER can efficiently distribute fidelity guaranteed entangled pairs with high throughput.

title: Model Predictive Control of Aerial Manipulation via Hardware-in-the-Loop Simulation
authors: Jiwook Choi, Dongyoung Lee, Inho Lee
abstract: To perform aerial manipulation with an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV), it is essential to develop countermeasures against dynamic disturbances affecting the UAV. Aerial manipulation typically involves controlling the UAV’s attitude using an inertial measurement unit (IMU), adjusting the speed of each rotor, and managing the trajectory of the manipulator mounted underneath the UAV. Ensuring both manipulation and flight stability requires a robust control system and reliable state estimation algorithms. These algorithms can be developed either through simulation modeling or iterative real-world testing. While simulation is cost- and time-efficient, real-world testing provides more accurate results but is costly and risky due to the operational characteristics of aerial manipulation. This paper introduces a hybrid Hardware-in-the-Loop Simulation (HILS) framework, which enables real-time control design under near-real-world conditions. A UAV model is applied in the HILS to replicate actual flight and measure disturbances occurring during operation, and a control system is subsequently configured using Model Predictive Control (MPC). The primary objective of this study is to establish a hybrid HILS platform for UAV–manipulator systems and to employ it for rigorous evaluation and validation of control strategies. The novelty lies in integrating MPC within this HILS framework to assess robustness against manipulator-induced disturbances. MPC is benchmarked against a conventional PID controller, highlighting the advantages of the proposed approach. Validation is conducted by transferring the simulation results to a real UAV–manipulator platform and performing flight experiments.

title: Interoperability of Digital Twins for automation with digital twin schema
authors: Joel Mattila, Riku Ala-Laurinaho, Juuso Autiosalo, Kari Tammi
abstract: Digital Twin Descriptions (DTDs), such as Asset Administration Shell (AAS) documents, can enable collaboration between machines by presenting their properties in a standardised format. However, the existing DTD formats present information in an incompatible way, hindering interoperability between different Digital Twins (DTs). This paper focuses on enhancing the interoperability between DTs described with different DTDs to enable collaboration between DTs and the autonomous operation of smart factories. First, the paper identifies the necessary data fields for collaboration. Thereafter, the presence of these fields is examined in the current DTD formats. If a format lacks necessary data fields, the paper proposes how these data fields should be incorporated into the format. Finally, the paper presents how the fields in different DTDs could be mapped to enable interoperability between them. The collaboration of DTs is demonstrated by controlling an industrial machine. In the use case, the machine in the factory is represented using AAS and Web of Things Thing Description documents. These DTDs were hosted in a local area network. After the client retrieves the document from the hosting service, the necessary information is extracted from the DTD to enable further collaboration with the DTs. The use case demonstrates that the proposed approach is well-suited for facilitating collaboration in smart factories. Furthermore, it is demonstrated that with minor adjustments, the current DTDs can be made more interoperable. Future research should consider creating DTD templates for various types of DTs and making them publicly available. This would enable a consistent DTD structure for DTs that share the same type data field.

title:
Single-Pass Three-Level Recording with Granular FePt-L1
                    <sub>0</sub>
                    Medium
authors: Jian-Gang Zhu
abstract: Heat assisted magnetic recording with FePt-L1<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub> granular media offers a unique opportunity for single-pass multi-level recording. In this paper, we present a micromagnetic simulation based modeling study to investigate the viability of the scheme. Because of the L1<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub> ordering in the perpendicular direction, a FePt grain is essentially a set of Fe atomic monolayers exchange coupled via the Pt monolayers alternates in between throughout the grain height. Consequently, the exchange between adjacent Fe monolayers becomes dynamic if the magnetization within a grain becomes non-uniform during recording processes. It is shown that such dynamic exchange coupling leads to domain wall trapping in the absence of write head field, forming stable “zero-moment” grains. Such mechanism enables a three level recording with a single pass and raises linear recording density by over 50% without increasing flux change density.

title: LQR-Based Optimal Control with Experimental Validation for Single-Phase D-Q Inverter
authors: Victor Eduardo Cauvilla De Oliveira, Robson Bauwelz Gonzatti, Jeremias Barbosa Machado
abstract: This paper presents an optimal control strategy based on the Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR) technique for single-phase frequency inverters represented in the D-Q reference frame. The inverter model was developed using statespace representation and transformed through Park and Clarke transformations, considering an LC output filter. Experimental validation was performed using a Delfino TMS320F28379D controlCARD, evaluating its off-grid and on-grid performance. Experimentally, the results showed good robustness and effective performance, closely matching those predicted by MATLAB/Simulink simulations. This experimental validation contributes to the practical application of optimal LQR control in power electronics, demonstrating significant potential for realworld inverter implementations.

title: Design of Memristive DNA-Biosensors for in-Memory Sensing or in-Sensors Computing
authors: Junrui Chen, Sandro Carrara
abstract: DNA serves as an ultra-high-density storage medium for digital information, while memristive biosensors enable both sensing and memory functions in electronics. The integration of these two technologies presents a promising avenue for advancing the field of bio-memory as well as for advanced in-Memory Computing. This report explores strategies for utilizing silicon nanowire (SiNW)- to obtain memristive biosensors to recognize DNA sequences. By tuning the Schottky contacts, the sensing device exhibits distinct memristive behaviors, facilitating applications to in-memory sensing. On the contrary, the device may exhibits less memristive behaviour and, so, facilitating in-sensors computing. Therefore, this study underscores the critical importance of the Schottky barriers and the related biomolecule positioning for effective memristive sensing, paving the way for advancements in bio-memory technologies.

title: Multimodal Emotion Recognition Using Speech and Facial Dynamics Transformer-Based Architecture
authors: Suresh Kurapati, Samanvita. N, Abdolwadwd Alzubaidy, K. Rajkumar, Kanimozhi. M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In recent years, Multimodal Emotion Recognition (MER) has become essential for advancing affect-aware human-computer interactions by integrating complementary cues from speech and facial expressions. However, the existing Cascaded Multichannel and Hierarchical Fusion (CMC-HF) framework exhibits limitations in explicitly modeling temporal speech-facial dependencies and aligning modalities across variable time scales. To overcome these challenges, this research proposes a Speech-Facial Dynamics (SFD) transformer-based architecture that jointly processes acoustic and facial motion streams. Initially, data collected from the Interactive Emotional Dyadic Motion Capture (IEMOCAP) dataset consisted of approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2}$</tex> hours of audiovisual data recorded from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0}$</tex> professional actors engaging in scripted and improvised dialogues. The speech encoder processes Mel-spectrogram patches with local-global attention and auxiliary prosodic supervision, whereas the facial encoder integrates both appearance and dynamics through convolutional features and landmark-optical flow embeddings. A multiscale bidirectional cross-attention fusion module aligns temporal speech-facial cues, guided by a contrastive alignment loss, to produce robust fused representations for categorical and dimensional emotion prediction. Experimental results demonstrated that the proposed SFD transformer-based model showed an improved accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 2. 5 \%}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex>-score of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 1. 3 \%}$</tex> when compared with the existing CMC-HF model.

title: Analysis of Solar Charging Infrastructure for Shared Light Electric Vehicles: Accessibility, Usability, and Incentives
authors: Mansi Mehta, Noman Hanifa, Loredana Tiedke, Semih Severengiz
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: Today, increased carbon emissions are driving climate change, necessitating a transition to low emission energy sources requiring an acceleration of the expansion and supply of renewable energy. The transport sector can significantly contribute to decarbonization through electrification. Being resource-efficient for many applications, Light Electric Vehicles (LEVs) offer a promising solution. Most LEV sharing systems currently rely on a "milk run", where service trucks—typically powered by combustion engines—collect, centrally charge, and redistribute vehicles or batteries, ultimately increasing LEVs' environmental impact. Solar charging stations (SCSs) are a viable option that provide decentralized, renewable energy without requiring grid connections. The current study examined user satisfaction with existing SCSs for shared LEVs and the importance of factors related to SCSs shaping future preferences and behaviour. Data were collected via an online survey from users with and without prior experience at two SCS locations. Key themes of the survey included demographics, usage behaviour, accessibility, location, user-friendliness, communication, and incentives. Users were generally satisfied with the SCS, though location satisfaction was higher in Oberhausen than Essen (cities in the state of North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany). Accessibility and user-friendliness were rated highly, with simple language and intuitive operation deemed important. While appearance was less critical, visibility and parking were key concerns. Incentives, especially free ride minutes, were effective, with 65% considering them very important. Future locations for SCSs included residential areas and transport stops. Challenges included maintenance issues, vandalism and risk of scooters being unplugged, with users willing to spend an average of 15.9 minutes charging.

title: Photovoltaic Energy Forecasting Using Machine Learning: Application in a Federal Public Institution
authors: João Pedro da Silva Rodrigues, Renner Sartório Camargo
abstract: The evolution of photovoltaic generation in Brazil in recent years indicates a greater participation in the energy matrix and, as a consequence, requires attention to its impacts on the distribution system. It is necessary to guarantee the safety, reliability and management of the assets of this electricity generation. Therefore, the development of a forecasting model for photovoltaic energy generation is aligned as a pillar for studying the increasing insertion of this renewable source. This work proposes the application of machine learning models for forecasting (LSTM and XGBoost), in the short term, of a photovoltaic energy system using electrical and climatic variables. The data obtained are from a public teaching and research institution, Ifes Campus Serra. The models were trained with time windows of 1 hour, 12 hours and 24 hours. The LSTM obtained superior performance in all windows and demonstrative analyses (MAE, RMSE and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex>), with emphasis on short-term forecasting, when compared to XGBoost. The analysis shows that the model based on recurrent neural networks presents better performance for distributed generation systems containing temporal variability.

title: Solving Industry Pain Point of Water-Cooling AI Server System through Innovative SuperFluid Technology
authors: Justin Wu, Carrie Chen, Jun Zhang, Wenqing Lv, Levin Guo
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Cooling solutions for Gen AI server systems face challenges due to the immense power consumption and heat generated by high-performance GPUs and CPUs. Traditional cooling methods may struggle to keep up, leading to the need for more advanced liquid cooling or immersion systems to maintain efficiency, reduce overheating risks, and ensure system longevity. Nowadays, water, or a mixture of propylene glycol and water has been used as a coolant in indirect contact liquid cooling system such as cold plate assisted solution. However, water cooling systems in electronics face challenges like leakage, which can cause significant damage to sensitive components if not properly managed. Even minor leaks pose a risk of short circuits and corrosion, potentially leading to system downtime or costly repairs. The conventional engineering artwork to mitigate these risks is to ensure leak-proof connections, in time leakage detect, and regular maintenance, but not fully solve leakage issue. This is one of critical industry pain points of water-cooling solutions massively deployed with luxurious AI servers in data center.In this paper, a novel cooling solution featuring cold plate and centric distribution unit (CDU) design based on dielectric coolant with innovative SuperFluid technology is introduced. This solution has overcome water cooling leakage issues and lab validation results have proved its applications with more than 1500W TDP (Thermal Design Power) processors in high dense AI server system.

title: A Novel Single-Phase Buck Rectifier in Discontinuous Conduction Mode
authors: Valdecir Junior De Paris, Nícolas Baschera, Marco di Benedetto, Gierri Waltrich, Telles Brunelli Lazzarin, Alessandro Lidozzi
abstract: Low-power step-down converters are vital for devices needing lower voltages. Traditional designs use two stages: a rectifier and a flyback or buck-boost converter. Single-stage step-down rectifiers in single-phase systems struggle near zerocrossings of the AC voltage. This paper presents a novel singlestage, single-phase step-down rectifier in Discontinuous Conduction Mode (DCM), optimized for WBG MBS GaN transistors. The design leverages the brief periods when the input is below the output, making it ideal for low-voltage DC supplies (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5}-\mathbf{1 5 ~ V}$</tex>). It maintains acceptable THD and power factor across a wide input range (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$110-220 \mathrm{V}$</tex>).

title: A New Feature Selection Method for Electricity Load Forecasting Based on Dual Evaluation Fitness Function
authors: Haijing Zhang, Yufan Shi, Yuan Jiang, Xuemei Zhang, Meng Li, Yaqing Yue
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: The accuracy of power load forecasting is of great significance in the operation and planning of power systems, and feature selection is a key step in improving the performance of forecasting models. In this paper, a feature selection method based on the genetic algorithm dual evaluation (GADE) is proposed and applied to power load forecasting. The method considers the relevance and redundancy of features, designs the dual evaluation fitness function, and applies a genetic algorithm for feature selection to ensure that the selected features are not only highly relevant to the target data but also significantly reduce the redundancy between features to realize the globally optimal feature selection. In order to verify the effectiveness of the method, the power load curve prediction is carried out, and the Attention mechanism is introduced to eliminate the "the occurrence of anomalous volatility" in the load curve prediction. Finally, an experimental analysis is carried out with real load data of a province as an example, and it is verified that the prediction accuracy is improved by applying the feature selection method, and the influence of features on load prediction is further analyzed to enhance the interpretability of the model.

title: Real Time Health and Geolocation Monitoring in Animals Using a Multi-Sensor Collar
authors: Babitha Hemanth, K Athul Rai, G P Dhanush, Thrisha, Vamshith
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
abstract: The surveillance of animal health and mobility is more crucial in both wildlife management and domestic livestock care. This project proposes a smart, wearable collar system that could deliver real-time health and location information for animals from large wildlife species, such as elephants, to roaming cattle and vulnerable calves. Conventional monitoring techniques such as manual observation and tagging are time consuming, are not real-time, and do not track important health parameters. This solution fills those gaps with a technology-based, humane response. It combines lightweight, non-invasive sensors such as the MLX90614 for temperature, MAX30100 for oxygen saturation and heart rate, MPU6050 for motion tracking, and a GPS module for tracking location. All these are controlled by an ESP32 microcontroller that processes and sends data to a cloud platform for remote monitoring. This allows for timely detection of health irregularities, unforeseen patterns of behavior, or boundary crossings. Built for durability and nonintrusiveness in mind, the collar has scalable use in both forest and agricultural environments. For wild animals, the system can support migration studies and help detect signs of stress or disease. For farm animals and pets, it lets farmers track health and reduce losses, especially in young calves. Overall, it works as a practical and ethical tool for both conservation and livestock care.

title: ChronoFusion: Spatio-Temporal Super-Resolution Based on Graph VAEs and Gated Fusion
authors: Seyed Mohamad Moghadas, Leandro Di Bella, Bruno Cornelis, Adrian Munteanu
publish: 2025 13th European Workshop on Visual Information Processing (EUVIP)
abstract: Time series data often suffers from resolution limitations due to hardware constraints, sampling frequency restrictions, or economic considerations. While super-resolution techniques have seen significant advancements in computer vision, their application to spatio-temporal data presents unique challenges that remain under-explored. We argue that pure generative or auto-regressive approaches are subpar for the multi-modal super-resolution task. Hence, we introduce ChronoFusion, a novel hybrid model that simultaneously enhances both spatial and temporal resolution of time series data. Our approach leverages a graph variational autoencoder combined with adaptive attention mechanisms to generate high-resolution time series from low-resolution inputs. Unlike previous methods that handle spatial and temporal super-resolution separately, ChronoFusion integrates both dimensions through a proxy subspace. Extensive evaluation on traffic datasets in various locations demonstrates that ChronoFusion outperforms state-of-the-art methods by 10% on average in interpolation fidelity on unseen nodes while maintaining temporal consistency. Furthermore, our model demonstrates strong capabilities in handling missing data. The method's versatility across diverse spatio-temporal traffic applications makes it a valuable contribution to time series analysis and modeling. Github Repo

title: Thinking Outside the Eyebox: Evaluation of Perceptual Effects Deriving from Pupil Swim Distortions in Head-Mounted Displays
authors: Hunter C. Finney
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: My dissertation investigates the effect of optical distortions on human perception and action within VR/AR head-mounted displays (HMDs). This project employs the use of previously established and trusted methodologies to unpack how considerations for design, optical architecture, and manufacturing impact end-user experience and perception of virtual environments and objects. This project seeks to answer the following questions: (1) can we quantify spatial distortions from an image in an HMD when the image is viewed from outside of the eyebox across multiple HMD and lens types? (2) is any distortion that is induced from pupil swim or mismatched interpupillary distance (IPD) perceptible by a human observer? and (3) does distortion from pupil swim or mismatched IPD alter actions in ecologically relevant, behavioral tasks?

title: Large Model Scheduling Method in Collaborative Decision Making of Intelligent Agents
authors: Xianya Chen, Quanzhi Yang, Guolong Dang, Jinchao Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In multi-agent collaborative decision-making, increasing agent numbers and decision complexity exacerbate computational demands, causing resource competition and communication delays in traditional centralized scheduling methods. This paper proposes a hierarchical task scheduling architecture that decouples global intention reasoning from local behavior planning, integrating a dynamic priority allocation mechanism optimized via the PPO algorithm. To enhance computational efficiency, asynchronous gradient synchronization and model cache pooling are introduced for resource optimization. Experiments demonstrate a 60% reduction in communication delay, an 11.1% improvement in task completion rate, 56.3% lower GPU memory usage, and 60.8% higher computational efficiency compared to centralized approaches. The method significantly improves scheduling performance and resource utilization in large-scale multi-agent systems, though further adaptations are needed for highly dynamic environments.

title: Design of a Koch-Fractal Inspired Monopole Antenna for C-Band and RFID Applications
authors: Srivardan B, Tushar Kumar Singh, Sachin Naachimuthu E, Santhoshbharadhan B, Dhev Karthik M, Tanmaya Kumar Das
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
abstract: The article illustrates the construction of a Kochfractal inspired monopole structure. The suggested structure comprises of a Koch-fractal-based radiating element and a partial ground component designed on a low-cost FR-4 material. The simulated outcomes depict -10 dB bandwidth of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.48-8.94$</tex> GHz having stable omnidirectional radiation properties in the operational range. The largest realized gain of 5.97 dBi at 8.61 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{G H z}$</tex>, realized gain <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{>} \mathbf{2.37~dBi}$</tex> throughout the operating band, and stable radiation characteristics make the design useful for C -band and RFID reader applications.

title: Study on Partial Discharge Characteristics of Epoxy Resin for Dry-type Transformer
authors: Jin Li, Xiao Chen, Jiarui Dong, Yi Peng, Zihan Chen
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Dry-type transformers are often cast with epoxy resin to improve the insulation performance; however, internal defects may exist and cause partial discharges due to the limitations of the manufacturing process. In this paper, three type defect specimens are designed to simulate three typical discharges, including tip discharge, surface discharge and floating discharge. The experimental platform is established for non-partial discharge tests. The PRPD (phase-resolved partial discharge) patterns of three typical defects are obtained and their partial discharge characteristics are investigated. The insulating defects including the discharges in the air and epoxy resin are both considered; in addition, the initial and intense discharges are investigated. The results show that the PRPD pattern of the tip discharge has a polarization effect, and the corona discharge caused by high voltage affects the PRPD pattern during the intense stage of the discharge. The PRPD pattern of the surface discharge have a triangular distribution, and the phase forward shift occurs in the intense discharge stage. The amplitude of the floating discharge is relatively small, and the phases are concentrated at 0°-45° and 180°-270°. In comparison with the initial discharge stage, the corona present in the air during intense discharges exerts a significant influence on the PRPD patterns of various discharges at high voltage and leads to dispersion of the discharge.

title: Improved A-LOAM Algorithm Based on Radius Filter
authors: Jiabin Shao, Zhonghua Wang, Meng Li, Dongxue Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: This paper proposes an improvement to the A-LOAM algorithm based on radius filtering to address the issue of outliers in complex environments. During point cloud processing, the radius filtering algorithm is employed to remove outliers that are distant from the main point cloud, thereby achieving more accurate localization and navigation results. Simulation experiments demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed algorithm.

title: VR MRI Training for Adolescents: A Comparative Study of Gamified VR, Passive VR, 360° Video, and Traditional Educational Video
authors: Yue Yang, Mengyao Guo, Yuxuan Wu, Wally Niu, Emmanuel Corona, Bruce Daniel, Christoph Leuze, Fred Baik
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Meta Quest Store: https://www.meta.com/experiences/stanford-mri-simulator/8205539289482347/Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) can be a stressful experience for pediatric patients due to the loud acoustic environment, enclosed scanner bore, and a prolonged requirement to remain still. While sedation is commonly used to manage anxiety and motion, it carries clinical risks and logistical burdens. Traditional preparatory approaches—such as instructional videos and mock scans—often lack engagement for older children and adolescents. In this study, we present a comparative evaluation of four MRI preparation modalities: (1) a gamified virtual reality (VR) simulation that trains stillness through real-time feedback; (2) a passive VR experience replicating the MRI environment without interactivity; (3) a 360° first-person video of a real MRI procedure; and (4) a standard 2D educational video. Using a within-subjects design (N = 11, ages 10–16), we assess each method’s impact on head motion data, anxiety reduction, procedural preparedness, usability, cognitive workload, and subjective preference. Results show that the gamified VR condition has significantly lower head motion (p < 0.001) and yielded the highest preparedness scores (p < 0.05). Head motion data were significantly correlated with learning outcomes (p < 0.01), suggesting that behavioral performance in VR strongly indicates procedural readiness. While all modalities reduced anxiety and were rated usable, interactive VR was preferred by most participants and demonstrated unique advantages in promoting engagement and behavioral rehearsal. We conclude with design recommendations for designing immersive simulations and integrating VR training into pediatric imaging workflows.

title: Toward Safe, Trustworthy and Realistic Augmented Reality User Experience
authors: Yanming Xiu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: As augmented reality (AR) becomes increasingly integrated into everyday life, ensuring the safety and trustworthiness of its virtual content is critical. Our research addresses the risks of task-detrimental AR content, particularly that which obstructs critical information or subtly manipulates user perception. We developed two systems, ViD-DAR and VIM-Sense, to detect such attacks using vision-language models (VLMs) and multimodal reasoning modules. Building on this foundation, we propose three future directions: automated, perceptually aligned quality assessment of virtual content; detection of multimodal attacks; and adaptation of VLMs for efficient and user-centered deployment on AR devices. Overall, our work aims to establish a scalable, human-aligned framework for safeguarding AR experiences and seeks feedback on perceptual modeling, multimodal AR content implementation, and lightweight model adaptation.

title: Enhancing Sales Forecasting in Sustainable Supply Chain Management Using a Hybrid Random Forest–Support Vector Regression Model
authors: Sabina A. Nair, Erugu Krishna, Neelam Bharathi, Kumaran Thayumanavan, S. Vinayagam, S. Kaliappan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Effective resource planning, waste reduction, and ecologically responsible decision-making are all made possible by sales forecasting, making it a vital component of sustainable supply chain management. In this research, it present a methodology for sales forecasting with the goal of making supply chain operations more sustainable through more accurate sales predictions. To make sure the data is consistent and the model is ready to go, the methodology starts with data pre-processing, which includes scaling and encoding. Then, the most useful attributes from the dataset are extracted using feature extraction algorithms. A strong prediction framework is provided by a hybrid model that combines CNN and BiLSTM networks. This model captures both spatial and temporal patterns in the data. To evaluate the model's usefulness, it is subjected to testing using a prototype that was created in a lab. This allows for the simulation of real-world scenarios. The suggested CNN-BiLSTM model achieves a high accuracy rate of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 8. 4 2 \%}$</tex> in sales prediction, according to experimental results, which is a considerable improvement over previous models. Results like this show that the model can handle complicated sales data and could improve sustainable supply chain operations. In sum, the research shows that state-of-the-art ML models help improve sales forecasting, which in turn helps contemporary supply chain management systems achieve their sustainability goals.

title: A Workflow-Based Approach to Improving Remote Team Collaboration
authors: Andreea-Cristina Rădăcină, Anca Daniela Ionită, Iulia-Lidia Lacob
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: Teamwork is generally recognized as an efficient working style in most organizations, yet the shift to remote work has introduced challenges in maintaining team cohesion, effective communication, and service quality. This study examines the impact of team building activities on service quality and customer satisfaction in remote teams, addressing the challenges organizations face in virtual environments. The research follows a multistage approach, starting with a microstudy designed to investigate existing team building practices. Its results were used to model a workflow for planning teamwork activities. To address specific team needs, we applied an existing conceptual model integrating Tuckman’s model to assess a team’s current stage, and service quality dimensions. In this way, team building activities may be analyzed through specific Key Performance Indicators (KPIs), before and after the interventions. To assess the effectiveness of this method, a case study was designed and conducted in a remote environment. Its impact was observed by analyzing performance metrics, conducting to improvements both in team collaboration and service quality.

authors: Pravat Kumar Singh, Aditya Acharya, Jagyanseni Panda
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: Image enhancement plays a prime role in improving the visual quality and interpretability of digital images for both human perception and machine analysis. This paper proposes a novel method for dark image enhancement based on a Synthesized n<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> Root and n<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> Power Transform (SRPT) algorithm. The existing Gamma correction technique cannot enhance the darker and brighter regions simultaneously because it employs a single global value for the entire image. This problem can be effectively resolved using synthesized n<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> root and n<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> power transform algorithm. The proposed algorithm uses the fractional value of gamma for enhancing darker region and an inverse of the gamma factor for brighter region. The gamma factor for mid intensity region is kept one to retain the information in the region. Experimental results show that the proposed algorithm enhances both the darker and brighter regions properly by keeping the original relevant information. The proposed algorithm also outperformer may of the existing algorithm in term of Absolute Mean Brightness Error (AMBE), Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR) and Color fullness Metric (CM).

title: Engineering Smart Agricultural Systems: Leveraging IoT and AI for Sustainable Urban Farming
authors: Kuanysh Bakirov, Aruzhan Shoman, Tussupov Jamalbek, Ibraheem Shayea, Daniyar Dauletiya, Sagymbay Mekesh, Yan Kudashov, Aian Kenzhebai
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: This paper describes a comprehensive framework for the engineering of smart agricultural systems using the Internet of Things (IoT) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) technologies for sustainable urban farming. To address the increased issue of food scarcity, lack of arable land, and environmentally constrained space in urban areas, we aim to design and implement a vertical farming system with advanced IoT sensor networks composed of DHT11 temperature and humidity sensors as well as lux light intensity sensors, and manual measurement of plant height to monitor crucial environmental parameters in real time. Data was gathered constantly at one-minute intervals for two weeks with both cloud and local systems to ensure robust and scalable data acquisition for a variety of use cases. Afterwards, short-term temperature forecasting enabling proactive climate control to optimize resource use and crop yield was done with classical time series approaches (ARIMA) and deep learning techniques (LSTM) based models. Analysis showed that the baseline for ARIMA was strong, but the LSTM model performed somewhat better, demonstrating the advantages of AI enabled predictive control in indoor vertical farming. The model increases environmental stability and energy efficiency while laying the groundwork for smart urban agriculture systems that fosters sustainable development.

title: SLA-Aware DRL for Joint Slice Admission Control and Load Balancing in Multi-Service 5G RAN
authors: Manoj Prasad Kunasegran, Wai Leong Pang, Swee King Phang
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: The proliferation of 5G infrastructure demands increasingly intelligent and context-aware resource allocation strategies to satisfy the stringent and heterogeneous requirements of Ultra-Reliable Low-Latency Communication (URLLC), Enhanced Mobile Broadband (eMBB), and Massive Machine-Type Communication (mMTC). Building on our previous work on Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL)-driven Slice Admission Control (SAC), which prioritised URLLC traffic under gNodeB (gNB) congestion, this paper introduces key enhancements to support more realistic, large-scale deployment scenarios. Specifically, we integrate a load balancing (LB) metric directly into the DRL reward structure, enabling agents to optimise not only SLA satisfaction but also fairness in resource utilisation across gNB clusters. Additionally, we extend support to mMTC slices and evaluate the DRL framework's resilience under transient service disruptions. Using Monte Carlo simulations in our fully softwarised gNB environment, we benchmark three DRL algorithms, namely Advantage Actor-Critic (A2C), Deep Q-Network (DQN), and Rainbow, against a baseline LB heuristic. Results demonstrate a drastic reduction in slice block rates, rapid recovery post-disruption, and more stable load balance utilisation across all DRL-driven methods. These findings demonstrate the feasibility of joint SAC-LB-aware optimisation for dynamic Open RAN-based 5G networks.

title: E-STATCOM Voltage Control for Power System Applications: A Comparison of Grid Forming and Grid Following Control
authors: Janito dos Santos Ramos, Daniel Dobrochinski Maia, Emanuel Leonardus van Emmerik, Mateus Borges Franzosi, André Guilherme Peixoto Alves, Nicholas Delben de Andrade, Luis Claudio Gambôa Lopes, Robson Francisco da Silva Dias
abstract: This paper presents a comparative analysis of voltage control between Grid Following (GFL) and Grid Forming (GFM) control strategies for an Energy Storage-Based Static Synchronous Compensator (E-STATCOM). The study evaluates the dynamic response of both control approaches in maintaining voltage stability. The GFL strategy relies on a cascaded control structure in the dq reference frame, where voltage regulation is achieved through an outer-loop controller. The GFM approach, based on the Synchronverter concept, emulates the behavior of a synchronous generator, inherently providing voltage and frequency support. Simulations are performed using the IEEE 12-bus benchmark system to assess the impact of each strategy on power system stability. The simulations are implemented in PSCAD. The results contemplate voltage perturbations, large load connections, severe short circuits and current limitation during the fault for both control strategies, as well as for the system without E-STATCOM. The findings highlight the advantages and limitations of each method, offering insights into their suitability for modern power grids with high renewable energy penetration.
