Th thinner layers enable the energy-efficient solar cells up to 500 nm by improved V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">OC</inf> values at lower temperatures 260-280 K. Thicker layers shown more strong energy collecting as they significantly enhanced J<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">SC</inf> performance and peaked at 26.83 mA/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> at higher temperatures. Temperature and thickness clearly affected the FF; peak FF for layers 500 nm was 86%. Under optimal conditions 320 K and a 300 nm thick perovskite layer—the PCE, a major indicator of clean energy generation, peaked at 26.45%. These results allow PSC efficiency to be physically improved, therefore helping industry, innovation, and infrastructure. Our work promotes the worldwide shift towards more ecologically friendly energy sources by way of improved performance and sustainability of solar technologies. Using the knowledge provided, effective solar technology connected with climate action will be able to slow down global warming.

title: Self-Shading Induced Power Loss in Photovoltaic Plants with Fixed-Tilt Arrays and Single-Axis Sun-Trackers: A Case Study of Brazilian Cities
authors: Eslam Mahmoudi, João Lucas de Souza Silva, Gustavo Fraidenraich, Denis G. Fantinato, Tárcio André dos Santos Barros
abstract: This paper presents a simulation framework for estimating power loss induced by self-shading in photovoltaic (PV) systems, based on solar positions and PV array parameters, including module dimensions, mounting orientation (portrait or landscape), inter-row spacing, and bypass diode configuration. The framework consists of two sequential steps: (1) calculation of row-level shading fractions derived from solar geometry and array layout; and (2) estimation of power losses due to shadinginduced attenuation of plane-of-array (POA) irradiance and activation of bypass diodes. The proposed approach is applied to fixed-tilt and single-axis tracker PV plants in 12 Brazilian cities. Hourly shading fractions are calculated for multiple array configurations, and hourly power losses are estimated from reductions in POA values, which are obtained from global horizontal irradiance (GHI) using the top decomposition-transposition model combinations determined through statistical evaluation of 400 model combinations. The simulation tool quantifies shadinginduced losses across multiple PV array layouts at temporal resolutions from hourly to annual, thereby providing designers with a practical tool to optimize plant design and performance.

title: Best Practices on Indirective Experience for Virtual Healing
authors: Minjung Ro, Seungyeon Lee, Jimin Yim, Chaeyoung Lee, Chaeyun Seo, Janghwan Kim, Jihoon Kong, SungHee Ahn, R. Young Chul Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: In this moment, diverse systems are being developed that allow users to have indirect experiences of cities and tourist attractions that are difficult to visit in person. If this system also includes a personalized guide to city, country, and travel destination recommendations, it will help increase interest in travel. To achieve this, we propose a virtual travel experience simulation that presents the potential for vitalizing domestic tourism by leveraging personalization technologies and immersive content. This combines a user-customized Korean city recommendation system with virtual reality (VR) technology, and utilizes personalization technology tailored to individual interests, creating immersive content. With this, we may have just experienced a virtual world, even though we are staying at home and not spending a lot of time or money, until we start doing this. That is, we can virtually visit anywhere and at any time we want to go. By providing users with a healing experience through VR travel, we can spread a positive image of the destination, raise expectations about travel, and give psychological satisfaction. Through this, we expect to encourage actual visits and contribute to the revitalization of local economies.

title: Decoupled Nonlinear Control Strategy for Voltage Balancing in ISOS Modular DAB Converters
authors: Nelson N. N. Yamaguti, Pedro S. C. Coradin, Daniel J. Pagano, Kevin E. L. Marcillo
abstract: This work addresses the modeling and control of an input-series-output-series (ISOS) system formed by dual active bridge (DAB) DC-DC converter modules. Operated under single-phase-shift modulation, the topology is particularly suitable for high-voltage and high-power applications. To ensure proper power sharing among modules, a multivariable control approach is introduced that combines partial feedback linearization (eliminating the nonlinear dependence of power on the phase-shift angle) with small-signal linearization around the steady-state operating point to derive control-oriented models. These models enable the implementation of decoupled loops for output-voltage regulation and input-voltage balancing. The proposed strategy is validated through real-time Hardware-in-the-Loop (HIL) tests using a three-module ISOS converter.

title: Cloud Platform Automated Data Acquisition System Based on Artificial Intelligence
authors: Haihua Lv
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: With the advent of the big data era, traditional data collection methods face the problems of inefficiency and excessive manual intervention. This study aims to build an artificial intelligence-based cloud platform automated data collection system to improve the efficiency and accuracy of data collection. In terms of methodology, this paper first designs a data acquisition framework based on cloud computing architecture, using sensors and web crawler technology to collect data in real time; secondly, the random forest algorithm is used to clean and filter the collected data to remove noise and redundant information; finally, the processed data is stored in a cloud database and displayed and analyzed through visualization tools. Through testing, the data accuracy of this method reaches more than 94 %, and it can run stably in different environments. The cloud platform automatic data acquisition system based on artificial intelligence effectively solves the shortcomings of traditional data acquisition and has broad application prospects.

title: Thermal Imaging and Flow Visualization of Capillary-Driven Two-Phase Boiling in Silicon Microchannels Coated with Porous Copper Wick
authors: Yujui Lin, Heungdong Kwon, Kewei Xiao, Man Prakash Gupta, Michael Degner, Mehdi Asheghi, H. Alan Mantooth, Kenneth E. Goodson
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Two-phase embedded microcoolers are emerging as a promising solution to high-performance and highly efficient cooling for microprocessors and power electronics. We characterized a silicon microchannels capillary-driven microcooler coated with hydrophilic copper dendritic microstructure, achieving two-phase boiling at heat flux level $\gt350 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}$ and a small superheat $\left(\sim 10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)$, leading to a heat transfer coefficient of $300,000 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}-{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ (or $\mathrm{R}^{\prime \prime}=0.03 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}- { }^{\circ} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{W}$). To provide additional insight into the physics of capillarydriven boiling, bubble dynamics, and dry-out formation, we conducted IR thermal and high-speed flow visualization imaging. An important finding is related to the delayed dry-out of $\sim 300 \mathrm{~ms}$ in capillary-based microcoolers compared to a much shorter timescale of 2 to 10 ms for the two-phase pumped flow in smooth silicon microchannels. The result demonstrates the potential of the capillary-based two-phase cooler for transient thermal management. For future work, the improvement in liquid delivery will be considered by implementing 2D microchannels, optimizing the microchannel dimensions, in particular width and spacing, and introducing hydrophilic copper dendritic microstructure at the walls of the microchannels.

title: An Enhanced Ensemble Optimized Machine Learning Framework for the Prediction and Assessment of Students' Mental Stress
authors: Guang Du
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In recent years, the frequent occurrence of mental health issues and related incidents among university students has made the effective assessment of their psychological wellbeing a critical research topic. Among these concerns, the prediction and evaluation of students' psychological stress constitute a significant aspect. The psychological pressure of students is a key issue in mental health, necessitating accurate predictive models for early prevention of any fatal outcomes. Traditional machine learning and deep learning techniques are employed to predict the mental stress of the students. However, these algorithm has high probability rate of producing inconsistent performance that leads to the high false rate during its prediction process. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a novel combination Support Vector machines (SVM) and Dolphin optimization-based evaluation framework for predicting and evaluation the students mental stress The framework was evaluated using Kaggle's Student Mental Health datasets with the more than 1000 records. Furthermore, performance metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall are calculated and compared with the other traditional learning algorithms. Results demonstrates the efficacy of the model by achieving the accuracy of 0.998 with the F1-score of 0.99 respectively. The proposed network has established the new path of transforming the conventional framework into cognitive way of predicting the mental stress that helps to assessing the mental health status of college students.

title: Simulating Electrocoagulation for Water Treatment: Effect of Applied Current on Energy Consumption
authors: Amina Tahreen, Mohammed Saedi Jami, Masashi Iwata, Fathilah Ali
publish: 2025 International Power and Sustainable Energy Technologies Conference (PSETC)
abstract: Electrocoagulation (EC) is emerging as a low-footprint, chemical-minimal water treatment technology. Yet, its design and optimization are constrained by trial-and-error methods that lack insight into internal electrochemical dynamics. This study presents a validated 3D COMSOL Multiphysics model of a batch EC reactor, simulating electric potential and current density distribution under varying current inputs. The model integrates experimentally relevant conditions and parametric sweeps to identify optimal energy-efficient operating windows. Electric potential varied from -2.72V to -1.77V across a 0–2A current sweep. Current density visualizations revealed significant edge concentration at lower currents, which improved with increased current input, achieving uniformity at 1.5–1.75 A. Energy consumption was calculated directly from the simulation outputs using electric potential, total current, and process time, enabling realistic energy consumption analysis. The study links current field distribution with energy optimization, offering an insight to scalable, resource-efficient EC design framework aligned with SDGs 6 (Clean Water), 9 (Industry Innovation), and 12 (Responsible Production). This COMSOL Multiphysics-based approach aims to reduce experimental runs, minimize waste, and support predictive engineering for sustainable water treatment systems.

title: Comparative Analysis of PI, PID & Fuzzypid Controllers for Various Load Changes of a Double-Area Power System
authors: Debashish Mishra, Gobinda Chandra Maharana, Prasannajit Malik, Chinmayi Choudhary, Ramesh Chandra Prusty
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: In modern interconnected power systems, maintaining frequency stability and regulating the tie-line power exchange are critical for reliable operation. Conventional PID controllers, though widely implemented for Load Frequency Control (LFC), often struggle to deliver optimal performance under non-linearities and varying system conditions. This paper proposes a Fuzzy-PID controller for effective LFC in a double-area power system. The proposed approach leverages fuzzy logic to adaptively tune PID gains in real time based on system frequency deviation and its rate of change. Each control area is equipped with a governor-turbine-generator model and is interconnected via a tie-line, enabling coordinated control. For optimizing the controllers, the Genetic Algorithm (GA) is implemented here. The proposed strategy offers improved robustness against load disturbances and system uncertainties, making it a viable solution for modern power systems with increasing complexity and variability.

title: Edge-Preserving Multi-Scale Network for Plant Point Cloud Segmentation
authors: Peng Liu, Bin Li
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: Accurate plant organ segmentation is essential for enabling high-throughput extraction of plant phenotypes, as it provides the foundational data for both trait measurement and structural modeling. Although existing studies have made significant progress, plant semantic segmentation (stems and leaves) across multiple species remains underexplored. To this end, this paper introduces an edge-aware downsampling algorithm and a novel network for segmenting plant point clouds at multiple scales, named MSPlantSegNet. Experimental results on a dataset of tobacco, tomato, and sorghum demonstrate that MSPlantSegNet attained superior performance across all four key metrics-precision (97.13 %), recall (95.63 %), F1-score (96.20 %), and IoU (93.14 %). MSPlantSegNet surpasses a set of leading models, including PointNet++, PointNet, ASIS, DGCNN, PlantNet, PSegNet, and PointNeXt. This research has valuable implications for plant phenotyping, the development of smart agriculture, and ideal type selection.

title: Analysis of 12- and 18-Pulse Uncontrolled Graetz Bridge Rectifier with Fork Connection Combined with a Three-Phase Buck Converter to Drive Proton Exchange Membrane Electrolyzers
authors: Juliana B. de Almeida, Vitor Emanuel A. Dourado, Jefferson M. de Sousa, Adolfo J. M. F. Araújo, Fernando L. Tofoli, Edilson M. S. Junior, Paulo P. Praça, Demercil de S. Oliveira
abstract: This study conducts a comparative analysis of 12and 18-pulse uncontrolled rectifier topologies in Graetz bridge systems, incorporating isolated medium-voltage autotransformers and conventional transformer connections, with a focus on polymer electrolyte membrane electrolyzers. Key performance metrics, including volume, losses, Total Harmonic Distortion, and Power Factor, are systematically evaluated to assess the reliability and efficiency of each system configuration. The findings highlight distinct electrical characteristics for each topology, with variations in their impact on the performance indicators. Ultimately, the optimal topology selection is application-specific, requiring a careful balance between electrical performance, spatial constraints, and overall system efficiency.

title: AI-Based Approaches for Early Detection of Major Depressive Disorder: Technical Roadmap and Future Directions
authors: Sanket Shah, Tripti Dodiya, Nisha Prajapati
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Major Depressive Disorder is a highly prevalent and debilitating mental condition, frequently co-occurring with anxiety or sleep disorders and/or suicidal risk. The conventional measures of diagnosis including patient interview and PHQ scores are subjective and ineffective in the early stages of diagnosis. Recent developments in artificial intelligence have introduced the possibility of detecting subtle multimodal biomarkers in EEG, fMRI, speech, facial expressions and Social Media text. The paper provides a survey of the latest AI models-CNN, LSTM, GNN, and multimodal fusion frameworks and outlines a comparative analysis of datasets, methods, and results. Comparative results demonstrate that multimodal methods provide the best accuracy (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$94-99.3 \%$</tex>), psychosocial models slightly below (99.4 %), and EEG-based models slightly under these (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$93-98 \%$</tex>) with visual-only performing lowest <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\sim 81 \%)$</tex>. The study reviews strengths and limitations and outlines a roadmap for explainable, scalable, and clinically viable AI solutions

title: Energy and Thermal Management of Chips, Systems and Data Centers necessitates a Return to Fundamentals
authors: Chandrakant D. Patel
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Increased power consumption and heat dissipation in chips, systems, and data centers necessitates an integrated approach in energy and thermal management. Thermal and energy management solutions must account for energy flow from the energy source to the chips, and heat flow from the chips to the cooling towers. Increasing complexity of chips also require consideration of structural integrity of chips and interconnect, power delivery, power management, high-speed signaling, repairability, and reliability. This paper presents a comprehensive supply-demand based framework for energy and thermal management of chips, systems, and data centers. It references previous research for in-depth information, including key papers from earlier Itherm conferences. The intent is to serve as a guide by providing salient elements that make up the big picture, and provide metrics grounded in fundamentals. Regarding the latter, the paper proposes a thermodynamics-based metric as a key performance indicator of the overall system. Underpinning the holistic framework presented in the paper are the fundamental principles taught by contributors like Dr. Richard Chu and educators like Prof. Francis Huang at San Jose State University. Learning and inspiration from Prof. Huang’s application of the $2^{\text {nd }}$ law of thermodynamics and exergy analysis is a key element of the framework presented in this paper. Indeed, exergy analysis was an integral part of machine age engineering workflows leading to projects like hydro-electric plants for aluminum factories. Modern data centers, akin to those aluminum factories, depend on such power infrastructure established by our predecessors. With AI driving the growth of data centers and their energy demands, returning to exergy analysis is essential.

title: Enhancing Joy with AR Glasses: Intergenerational Engagement for Older Adults and Youth
authors: Chorong Park, Pedro Acevedo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Emotional well-being can be adversely affected by loneliness in older adults and digital overload in younger individuals. Leveraging recent advances in augmented reality (AR), we explore how lightweight AR glasses, paired with a shared screen, can facilitate joyful and meaningful intergenerational interactions. We designed a set of playful AR interaction modes intended to spark engagement and emotional connection between an older adult and a youth partner. Our initial findings indicate that this hybrid system can elicit laughter, storytelling, and a sense of social closeness. By combining the immersive qualities of AR with the familiarity of a shared screen, our approach supports a co-located, technology-mediated setting in which digital content augments rather than detracts from human connection.

title: Simulations for Augmented Reality Evaluation of Tools for Mass Casualty Incident Triage
authors: Cassidy R. Nelson, Joseph L. Gabbard, Jason B. Moats, Ranjana K. Mehta
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Mass casualty incidents (MCIs) are a high-risk, sensitive domain with profound implications for patient and responder safety. Augmented reality has shown promise as an assistive tool for high-stress work domains and MCI triage both in the field and for prefield training. However, the vulnerability of MCIs makes it challenging to evaluate new tools designed to enhance MCI response. In other words, profound evolutions like the integration of augmented reality into field response require thorough proof-of-concept evaluations before being launched into real-world response. This paper describes two progressive simulation strategies for augmented reality that bridge the gap between computer-based simulation and actual field response.

title: Optimization of Medical X-Ray Image Disease Classification Algorithm Integrating Computer Vision Features
authors: Lei Cheng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Current medical X-ray image disease classification algorithms lack accuracy, speed, and consistency. This paper utilizes ResNet to automatically learn and extract feature information from X-ray images and introduces image segmentation and morphological processing techniques to capture subtle lesions in X-ray images. During the feature fusion optimization phase, a feature splicing method is used to directly splice two types of features together. The most influential features are then selected for fusion by evaluating the contribution of each feature to the classification task. The algorithm achieves an average classification time of approximately 19.4 seconds, with a classification accuracy exceeding 97 % across multiple data points. This paper brings new perspectives and improved methods to the field of medical image analysis.

title: Research on Joint Optimization Algorithm for Image Enhancement and Denoising Based on the Combination of Deep Learning and Variational Models
authors: Minkang Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: As an important carrier of modern information transmission, images often encounter problems such as noise interference, structural distortion, and missing details during the acquisition and transmission process due to factors such as imaging environment and equipment performance, which affect visual quality and subsequent analysis. To address such issues, this paper proposes a joint optimization algorithm that integrates deep neural modeling and variational inference framework, aiming to simultaneously improve the clarity and stability of images. Firstly, a pluggable structure based image enhancement strategy was constructed to address the issue of hidden noise in the dark regions, which is difficult to handle. A trained denoising network and an improved Retinex theoretical model were introduced to work together to achieve significant image quality improvement and interference elimination. Secondly, considering the insufficient interpretability of deep learning methods, this paper introduces wavelet compression mechanism and designs a Soft AE structure with logical traceability to quantitatively evaluate the internal behavior of the model from two dimensions: static analysis and dynamic feedback, providing new ideas for the study of model transparency. Finally, in order to balance image edge clarity and texture suppression, this paper introduces a self-adjusting regularization term based on local feature weighting, and combines it with semi quadratic solving techniques to achieve efficient optimization. The experimental evaluation results show that the proposed algorithm exhibits excellent performance in multiple image processing tasks, and has broad practical application value and theoretical promotion significance.

title: Integrated Safety Protection System for New Energy Excavator Cabs Based on IoT Technology
authors: Qiulian Miao, Quan Zheng, Zhenning Hu, Haojie Huang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Manufacturing System (ICAMTMS)
abstract: New energy excavators are prone to risks such as mountain collapse, rollover, and fire under complex working conditions, making it difficult to ensure the safety of drivers. This study deeply integrates Internet of Things (IoT) technology to innovatively design a safety protection system for new energy excavator cabs. It is equipped with a high-stability STM32/STC main control system, multi-type sensor monitoring network, 5G real-time communication module, electromagnetic control airbag system, and stable power supply system. Supporting trigger programs are developed to ensure the efficient collaborative operation of each module. Adopts a dual-mechanism architecture of “active defense + passive response”. The active safety module is equipped with an OPW airbag protective cover, which triggers the airbag to deploy in milliseconds to reduce crush injuries to drivers. The passive safety module integrates flame, smoke, and temperature sensor arrays to monitor and handle fire situations in real time. Through the IoT communication module, key information such as the location of the danger and the type of accident is synchronously transmitted to the remote monitoring center, providing accurate data support for emergency rescue. Experimental verification using a scale model of the Volvo EC160E electric excavator shows that the system performs excellently in simulated scenarios of tipping, heavy object impact, and fire. It provides all-around safety protection for drivers of new energy excavators, offering an innovative paradigm and practical basis for promoting the diversified development of safety protection technologies in the industry.

title: Modeling Social Cognition with Nonverbal Dynamics in Virtual Reality
authors: Hyunchul Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Virtual reality (VR) uniquely enables the expression of nonverbal behaviors that closely resemble real-world social interactions. However, current assessments of social experience in VR rely heavily on self-report measures, limiting scalability and objectivity. To address this, I develop a social cognition model that predicts perceived social connection from behavioral data, with a focus on nonverbal dynamics such as turn-taking, gaze, and nodding. Our findings from dyadic VR conversations show that patterns of turn-taking and nonverbal behavior significantly correlate with perceived social connection. Building on this, we extend our analysis to group conversations to explore more complex interaction structures. This research contributes to computational models of social cognition, offers a scalable method for quantifying social experience, and informs the design of socially responsive agents capable of lifelike, multimodal interaction.

title: Research on the Evolution of UHF and Acoustic Signals During Transformer Tip Discharge Based on Built-in Sensors
authors: Chenlei Han, Wenzhi Chang, Tingyu Gao, Jiangang Bi, Shuai Yuan, Keli Gao
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: This study established an oil-paper insulation defect fault test platform based on a 110kV real-type transformer. Through the built-in acoustic-electrical (ultra-high frequency (UHF) - acoustic) integration sensor, the evolution law of partial discharge (PD) signals during the development of oil-paper insulation tip discharge defects was monitored. The test results indicate that during the development of tip discharge in the oil-paper insulation within the transformer, the variation law of the amplitude of the UHF PD signal exhibits the characteristics of “two sudden growths and fallback before breakdown”; the variation law of the amplitude of the acoustic PD signal shows the characteristics of “overall stable growth, fallback before breakdown and then rose again”. The test results provide data support for the assessment and early warning of internal insulation defect faults of oil-immersed transformers based on the built-in acoustic-electrical PD monitoring.

title: Optimizing Nose and Lips Biometrics for Lightweight Authentication in Constrained Computing Environments
authors: Nithin Kurup U G, Desai Karam Sreekantha
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
abstract: Biometric recognition has become essential or, preferably, the most significant method for identification and authentication in various sectors. This research explores the feasibility of using lips and nose as additional modalities for identification and authentication with high accuracy and precision. The lips possess several distinct attributes, including shape, texture, color, and well-defined boundaries, making them suitable for recognition. Similarly, the nose has various features such as size, shape, curvature, nostril width, and unique markings, which also qualify it for biometric analysis. This work aims to discuss the current status of development in lip and nose biometrics, encompassing feature extraction techniques, matching algorithms, and image capture systems. A lightweight authentication system has been implemented on a Raspberry Pi using these modalities. The recognition phase of the model faces unique challenges due to appearance variations caused by factors like pose, expression, occlusion, lighting, and cultural diversity. Historically, these challenges have limited the broader application of these modalities, but advancements in technology and knowledge are improving their results, precision, and reliability. Thus, it is anticipated that they will continue to progress in certification and potentially expand their application in other secure authentication systems. To date, all research on lip and nose recognition has been conducted on desktop computers; however, I have implemented this recognition on a resource-constrained Raspberry Pi, achieving an accuracy of 91.95 % with an authentication time of 2600 milliseconds. This research on nose and lip biometrics highlights potential future trends, which may lead to increased usage of these biometrics across various disciplines.

title: Evaluation of the Current Situation of Local Culture Dissemination Based on Neural Network
authors: Xiaotang Zhao, Haihan Zhou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The rapid growth of digital communication platforms has intensified the requirements of efficient mechanisms in analyzing and promoting local culture dissemination, where traditional rule-based and statistical methods are prone to difficulties in dealing with dynamic, nonlinear, and high-dimensional data patterns. Current systems depend mainly on rule-based systems and shallow neural networks, which yield suboptimal precision, poor generalizability, and inadequate adaptability to heterogeneous cultural datasets. Traditional proposed frameworks like simple BP Neural Networks or isolated CNNs are concerned solely with static feature extraction and do not address sequential dependencies that are essential for modeling cultural evolution. To address these limitations, a hybrid deep learning model combining Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) for spatial feature abstraction and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) for sequential pattern extraction is proposed, allowing for sound analysis of cultural diffusion trends. Experimental results show that there is an evident performance gain with 97.7 % accuracy and 96.8 % F1-score compared to existing models. The advantage of the CNN-LSTM mechanism is that it can better balance spatial-temporal learning, mitigate loss of information, and improve interpretability, thus presenting a more efficient and scalable approach to local culture dissemination evaluation.

title: Automated Electro-Thermal Modeling Framework of Distributed Vertical Power Delivery Architectures with Substrate-Embedded Microfluidic Cooling
authors: Mingeun Choi, Sriharini Krishnakumar, Yaroslav Popryho, Ramin Rahimzadeh Khorasani, Madhavan Swaminathan, Inna Partin-Vaisband, Satish Kumar
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Next-generation high-performance computing (HPC) systems require power delivery solutions capable of sustaining beyond 1 kW per monolithic chip, with current densities expected to reach or exceed $2 \mathrm{~A} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}$. Distributed vertical power delivery (DVPD) architectures with integrated voltage regulators (IVRs) address this challenge by placing conversion stages closer to the processor, thereby reducing conduction losses. However, the interplay between temperature-dependent power dissipation and substrateembedded microfluidic cooling-particularly in 3D-stacked configurations where inner tiers have limited heat dissipation pathways-has been underexplored. This paper presents a PyAEDT-driven, automated electro-thermal modeling framework for 48 -to- 1 V DVPD architectures to accurately capture realistic power losses and pumping demands. Results demonstrate that ignoring electro-thermal feedback leads to significant underestimation of both power loss and IVR area. An electrical-only analysis predicts a total converter loss of 251.86 W, whereas integrating thermal effects raises this value to 285.91 W -an increase of about 13.5%. Likewise, IVR sizing grows by approximately 11% to mitigate elevated on-resistance and switching losses at higher temperatures. To maintain hot-spot temperatures below $85^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, the required microfluidic flow rate must rise from $1 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{s}$, which is needed without considering electro-thermal interactions, to $2.47 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{s}$, generating a pressure drop of 47.9 kPa. Despite this higher flow rate, the pumping overhead remains only 122.32 mW, which is negligible compared to the extensive conduction and switching losses that would occur in inadequately cooled systems.

title: Low-Resource Myanmar-Dawei Machine Translation using Fine-Tuned Neural Models
authors: Sint Sint Shein, Aye Mya Hlaing
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: In the current machine translation (MT) landscape, the Transformer architecture remains the gold standard, particularly for high-resource language pairs. However, low-resource language pairs—especially those involving regional dialects like Myanmar and Dawei—continue to pose significant challenges due to the scarcity of parallel corpora and the linguistic diversity they exhibit. This limitation highlights the necessity of fine-tuning models and optimizing hyperparameters to enhance translation performance, particularly for the Myanmar-Dawei language pair. This research explores the fine-tuning of pre-trained Opus-MT models on a Myanmar-Dawei parallel corpus for bidirectional translation tasks. We compare a baseline model, Transformer-based NMT, to fine-tuned Opus-MT models. The fine-tuned Opus-MT model achieved impressive BLEU score of 56.49 for Dawei to Myanmar and 45.40 for Myanmar to Dawei translations.This improvement demonstrates the effectiveness of leveraging pre-trained models for low-resource and dialectal translation tasks, contributing to the preservation of linguistic diversity and enhancing digital communication for underrepresented dialects such as Dawei. These findings underscore the importance of employing specialized fine-tuning of pre-trained models for low-resource language pairs and suggest promising directions for further optimization.

title: Transforming Reminiscence Therapy: Designing An Adaptive VR System based on Older Adults’ Emotional Connections and Narrative Patterns
authors: Ruitong Che, Jiaan Li, Hailiang Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Virtual Reality reminiscence therapy shows promise for supporting emotional wellbeing in older adults, yet existing systems often lack personalization and long-term engagement capabilities. We developed an adaptive VR-based reminiscence therapy (VRRT) system that addresses these limitations through three key innovations: (1) scenario progression that evolves from simple object recognition to complex narrative reconstruction, (2) collaborative tools designed to enable intergenerational storytelling, and (3) multi-modal memory triggers enhancing emotional recall. Through focus groups with 18 older adults, we identified distinctive recall patterns, including contextual deduction using historical markers and strong emotional connections to domestic and community spaces. Our findings demonstrate how age-inclusive interaction paradigms can transform static reminiscence into dynamic, personalized experiences. This work advances VR therapy by bridging the gap between technological capability and older adults’ diverse reminiscence needs.

title: Lifelong Learning in Software Engineering: Towards an AI-driven Tutor for Cloud-Based Software Architectures
authors: Marcel Mitas, Sabine Sachweh
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: The emerging of large language models (LLM’s) like ChatGPT helped to utilize artificial intelligence (AI) to understand basic concepts of programming in university courses, but also to automate and assist in repetitive procedures in the software engineering process. However, existing approaches to learn the skills and best practices to create software architectures and the underlying domain models with the help of AI expect a certain level of experience in software engineering. Besides, current approaches to configure LLMs with prompt engineering to answer as an AI tutor rather assist students in learning basic programming skills in university courses than in software architecture design. In this paper, a four-step-approach is proposed to prompt LLMs, namely ChatGPT-4o and Llama 3.1, to act like a tutor and help novices in software engineering build their own software architectures, apply best practices and understand them. To do this, the LLMs receive initial prompts with the assignment of a tutor role, and descriptions of the target group, system’s requirements and context. Then, example questions, domain models, and software architectures will be sent to the LLMs and evaluated if the answers relate to the models and requirements and comply with the initial prompt. Tests with the MobSTr dataset showed overall suitability of these LLMs for tutoring in software design, but also limitations regarding some general answers and the processing speed of local built LLMs.

title: A Real-time Multi-objective Scheduling Method for Wafer Lithography Zone Based on Two-stage Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Keshan Jin, Lihui Wu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Manufacturing System (ICAMTMS)
abstract: To address the challenges of multi-objective coupling, high dynamism, and real-time requirements in photolithography area scheduling, this study proposes a hierarchical deep reinforcement learning framework termed TDQN (Two-Stage Deep Q-Network). The framework integrates a policy-level network and an execution-level network to enable cooperative optimization. Specifically, the policy-level network dynamically captures the state of the production environment through multidimensional encoding, thereby facilitating adaptive weight allocation across multiple objectives, such as maximizing on-time delivery rate and minimizing makespan. Based on the composite reward function derived from the policy-level decisions, the execution-level network selects the most appropriate scheduling rule from a set of classical dispatching heuristics. Comparative experiments are conducted against traditional scheduling rules and other reinforcement learning-based methods. The results demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed TDQN framework in solving multi-objective real-time scheduling problems in the wafer photolithography area.

title: GAN-CMA: Causal mediation analysis based on Generative adversarial network
authors: Haiyue Zhang, Qi Li, Zhe Yang, Mingyu Gao, Lei Shang, Zhijun Tan
abstract: Causal Mediation Analysis plays a vital role in fields such as social sciences, medicine, and education, particularly in uncovering the mechanisms by which treatment variables influence outcomes through mediating pathways. To address the complexities of real-world causal mechanisms such as nonlinear relationships, multiple mediators, and chained mediation structures this paper proposes a suite of models for causal mediation analysis based on the Generative Adversarial Network framework, collectively referred to as GAN-CMA. This framework encompasses three specialized architectures: GAN-SCMA for single mediator scenarios, GAN-MCMA for multiple independent mediators, and GAN-CMCMA for chained multiple mediators. Specifically, the GAN-SCMA model is designed for scenarios involving a single mediator and leverages adversarial training to enhance the estimation of nonlinear causal effects. The GAN-MCMA model handles multiple unordered mediators by enabling parallel mediation modeling. For mediation structures with sequential dependencies, the GAN-CMCMA model is introduced to capture the propagation of effects along causal chains. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed models significantly outperform traditional methods and baseline architectures in terms of estimation accuracy, stability, and generalization capability.

title: Fast Estimation of Eddy Current Power Losses in Soft Ferrites Rings
authors: Vittorio Bertolini, Riccardo Scorretti, Antonio Faba, Ermanno Cardelli
abstract: Ferrite cores are widely recognized as the most effective magnetic materials for medium to high-frequency power electronic applications due to their low losses in dynamic conditions. However, there is an increasing demand for further improvements in their composition and manufacturing processes to reduce losses at the frequencies used by modern electronic switching devices. This is essential for achieving significant reductions in the weight and volume of magnetic cores in contemporary power electronics. To address this need, an efficient tool capable of accurately predicting eddy current losses in ferrites becomes crucial. In this study, we propose two simplified approaches in the frequency domain for modeling these losses in ferrite cores with a toroidal shape. Additionally, we demonstrate how these models can be extended to the time domain and applied to non-sinusoidal signals. The key material parameters—geometric, electrical, and magnetic—required for running the models are measured. We then compare the performance of these models against experimental measurements taken from three different commercial MnZn ferrites (N30, N87, T38) across a broad frequency range (100 kHz to 2 MHz). Furthermore, the T38 ferrite is also evaluated under non-sinusoidal operating conditions. An in-depth analysis of the results is presented, providing insights into the performance of the models for each ferrite material.

title: Few-shot cross-domain fault diagnosis of complex mechanical equipment based on multi-angle Taylor metric
authors: Chenhui Qian, Zhaojun Yang, Jialong He, Yan Liu, Mingdong Yang, Chenchen Wu, Shaoyang Liu
abstract: Although meta-learning models have achieved some success in few-shot cross-domain diagnosis tasks, they still face three major challenges: insufficient feature extraction capability, an uncontrollable domain adaptation process, and low discriminability of class features. To address these problems, a few-shot cross-domain fault diagnosis method for complex mechanical equipment based on multi-angle Taylor prototypes (MATM) is proposed. First, after constructing the dynamic graph autoencoder, the adjacency matrix is updated during the training process to capture the dynamic variations in fault data, which enhances the model’s ability to learn key features. Next, a Gaussian distribution-guided domain adaptation module is constructed, which imposes a Gaussian prior constraint on the latent space during the domain adaptation process to guide the optimization direction of domain-invariant features, thereby promoting the alignment of feature distributions across different domains. Finally, a multi-angle Taylor prototype metric module is constructed to perform nonlinear expansion of supporting features in high-dimensional space, optimizing the quality of class prototype representations from multiple perspectives to more accurately capture the class relationships across different domains. Experimental results on reducer datasets show that, compared to the latest methods, the proposed method improves the average classification accuracy by 1.98% across all diagnostic tasks, demonstrating superior performance in small-sample cross-domain fault diagnosis tasks.

title: Frequency-Domain Equalizer with Embedded Carrier Phase Estimation in Coherent Optical Receivers
authors: Xuemeng Hu, Miao Gong, Yuan Li, Ming Luo, Tianye Huang, Hao Wang, Xiang Li
abstract: We propose a frequency-domain equalizer (FDE) embedded with dual-stage decision-directed carrier phase estimators in coherent optical receivers. The coefficients of the filters and estimators are jointly calculated and updated using the decision-directed least mean square (DD-LMS) algorithm. The phase information derived from the first-stage phase estimator can be used to estimate and compensate for frequency offsets without incurring additional overhead. By eliminating phase fluctuations from the error signal, these phase estimators enhance the system’s resilience to frequency offsets and phase noise. Simulation results for a 60 GBaud dual-polarization 16 quadrature amplitude modulation (DP-16QAM) signal demonstrate the effectiveness of frequency offset estimation and compensation, showing that the performance of the proposed FDE is consistent with that of time-domain equalizers (TDE). Furthermore, we conduct an experimental demonstration utilizing 62.5 GBaud DP-16QAM transmission. The results are similar to those obtained in the simulations, validating the effectiveness of the proposed approach. When compared in terms of computational complexity, FDE has a much lower computational complexity than TDE.

title: A PVT-Tolerant, Curvature-Compensated CMOS Bandgap-Based Current Reference With Single-Point Batch Trim
authors: Ayman Sakr, Mohamed Atef Hassan, Jens Anders
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Solid-State Circuits Society
abstract: Traditional bandgap-based current references display various limitations. This includes large temperature coefficients (TCs) across process corners, necessitating costly trimming cycles, and area inefficiency for low current values (<10 μA). This work addresses these shortcomings by generating a complementary to absolute temperature (CTAT) current that reproduces the temperature dependence of the proportional to absolute temperature (PTAT) current including its curvature over process corners, eliminating multi-temperature TC trimming while retaining a single-point room-temperature calibration to set the absolute current. The design provides this matching PTAT/CTAT feature by relying on the temperature-stable negative TC of the electron mobility to generate the CTAT current instead of the nonlinear and process-sensitive diode-based CTAT generation. Moreover, thanks to the mobility-based CTAT generation, high-resistivity undoped poly resistors with a strong negative TC can be used, enabling area-efficient CTAT current generation in the sub-μA to single-digit μA range. To validate the proposed approach, we fabricated a prototype design in a 130nm SOI CMOS technology, occupying an active area of only 0.016 mm2 and operating over a wide supply range from 1.6V to 3V. Measurements from 10 chips yield a mean current of 1.1 μA (σ/μ ≈ 4.4%) close to the design target of 1.2 μA. Experimental results further demonstrate an average TC of 110 ppm/∘C from 0 ∘C to 100 ∘C without multi-temperature trimming, an average room-temperature supply line sensitivity of 1000 ppm/V, and a load sensitivity better than 250 ppm/V.

title: On Transient Release Dynamics in Robot Throwing: A Sliding Pivot Model
authors: Yang Liu, Aude Billard
abstract: Humans regularly throw projectiles with high speed and accuracy; some animals, including chimpanzees and elephants, also throw objects occasionally. In comparison, robots are currently lagging behind, despite having lower communication latency and more accurate motor control. To understand this paradox and ultimately achieve ubiquitous throwing robots, one of the major obstacles is the lack of high-fidelity and tractable physical models of the transient release dynamics, where the momentum exchange between the hand and the object occurs within tens of milliseconds via the frictional interface. In this work, we try to establish a physical model for the release dynamics. We first demonstrate that the conventional model, which combines rigid-body dynamics and patch friction (limit surface, LS), struggles to capture the release dynamics and exhibits pathological behaviors, such as Zeno-like oscillations, leading to poor accuracy in predicting throwing outcomes. To mitigate this, we formulate a viscous-smoothed variant of the limit surface model solved via implicit integration (ILS), which achieves high predictive fidelity but incurs significant computational cost. On the other hand, motivated by the dominant effect of in-hand pivoting in release dynamics, we propose a Sliding Pivot (SP) model that simplifies the contact dynamics by capturing the sticking-pivoting-sliding behavior emerging under vanishing normal force. This model achieves accuracy comparable to ILS, with only 10% higher error while offering over 20× faster computation. Compared to conventional LS models, our method reduces horizontal velocity prediction error by 40% and angular velocity prediction error by 63%, achieving 2.4 cm mean absolute error (MAE) for landing position and 15.4 degrees MAE for landing orientation. These results provide a robust, physically grounded foundation for future scalable robot throwing systems.

title: A Tactile-Proximity Dual-Mode Photoelectric Sensor: Implementation and Applications_supp2-3629784.mp4
authors: Long Cheng
abstract: Tactile and proximity sensing is essential for robotic tasks involving human-robot interaction (HRI) and manipulation. However, existing dual-mode sensors often face challenges such as environmental interference, large sizes, and task-specific limitations. This study proposes a dual-mode photoelectric sensor that integrates tactile and proximity sensing. The tactile sensing mechanism is based on a variable optical path structure, while the proximity sensing relies on the surface light reflection. The sensor exhibits a high sensitivity (up to 1.12 V/N), compactness (4 mm thickness), and desirable stability with a drift of less than 1% over 8,000 repetitive cycles under pressures ranging from 0 to 63 kPa. A general tactile-proximity servoing framework is also proposed for the dual-mode sensor array which enables tactile servoing, proximity servoing and hybrid tactile-proximity servoing. Under this framework, parameters can be flexibly adjusted to adapt to different servoing tasks including position and orientation control of the robotic arm's end-effector. In more complex robotic tasks, a real-time fruit ripeness classification method is developed based on the proposed sensor. Using the proposed TPNet, the classification method can achieve an accuracy of 94.4% in a four-level tomato ripeness classification task during grasping.

title: Stability Analysis for VSR-Based DC Distribution Network Using Singular Perturbation Theory
authors: Zhenxi Wu, Chi K. Tse, Zhangjie Liu, Chao Charles Liu, Hang Li, Hua Han, Yao Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: This paper addresses the stability analysis of DC distribution networks with voltage source rectifiers (VSRs) and constant power loads (CPLs). Existing stability criteria for DC networks often rely on simplified models neglecting source converter controller dynamics, limiting their applicability in practical controller design. To overcome this, a singular perturbation-based framework is proposed to derive analytical stability conditions for closed-loop DC distribution network systems. By decomposing the high-dimensional Jacobian matrix into two structured low-dimensional matrices, tractable stability criteria are established using properties of Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) matrices. Sufficient stability conditions for local stability of a VSR-based DC distribution network are derived without requiring global VSR information, while a robust stability criterion dependent solely on maximum load data is developed to handle uncertainties. These results provide explicit design guidelines to enhance robustness and reduce computational complexity in stability analysis. Simulations validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Inverse Learning of Black-box Aggregator for Robust Nash Equilibrium
authors: Guanpu Chen, Gehui Xu, Fengxiang He, Dacheng Tao, Thomas Parisini, Karl Henrik Johansson
abstract: We study the robustness of the Nash equilibrium (NE) in aggregative games with coupling constraints. When the constraint parameters are uncertain, the associated NE might be perturbed. It is essential to find a robust NE satisfying all possible constraints affected by the uncertain parameters. Although some methods have been developed for robust NE, these results rely on complete information about the game. We instead consider a scenario when only the uncertain parameters and associated perturbed NE are available, but the players' weights in the aggregator are unknown. With the uncertain parameters and perturbed NE constituting data, we propose data-based optimization to inversely learn players' weights in the black-box aggregator. We then use the learned weights in a transformed augmented problem without uncertainty and derive the first-order conditions for computing the robust NE. Furthermore, we characterize the generalization guarantee of the proposed learning approach in terms of violation probability.

title: Correlation Between Discharge Energy and the Characteristics of Carbon Particles in Transformer Oil
authors: Wu Zhao, Lijun Yang, Chen Chen, Bo Zhou, Shangquan Feng, Chao Guo, Xuetong Zhao, Jun Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: Impurity particles in transformer oil are a critical factor that threatens the insulation performance and safe operation of oil-immersed power transformers. Despite extensive studies on external contaminants and cellulose aging products, the generation of solid particles from insulating oil decomposition under discharge and thermal stress remains poorly understood. Based on micro-flow imaging technology, this paper experimentally investigates the formation characteristics of impurity particles in naphthenic mineral insulating oil under different discharge energies, focusing on the analysis of particle quantity, size distribution, and morphological changes. The results indicate that insulating oil decomposes during discharge, generating a large number of carbon particles, with micron-sized particles below 5 μm predominating. Under experimental conditions, particle quantity and discharge energy exhibit a strong linear correlation independent of electrode size. Although the particle size distribution is independent of discharge energy, its bluntness index increases significantly with increasing energy. This study reveals the pattern of micron-sized particles generated by the decomposition of insulating oil itself, providing a new theoretical basis for diagnosing and assessing the risk of internal discharge faults in transformers.

title: Cutoff Wavenumber Analyses of Multiconnected Domain Waveguides Using the Auxiliary Source Vector Norm-Based MAS
authors: Tingting Yan, Lv Ye, Shengbo Hu, Mengxia Liu, Kejia Hu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: In the latest study, a simple and effective method of auxiliary sources based on the monopole auxiliary source vector norm (MASVN-MAS) was developed to calculate the cutoff wavenumber (eigenvalue) of arbitrarily shaped perfectly electric conducting (PEC) waveguides. However, applied to multiconnected domain waveguides, we demonstrate analytically and numerically that MASVN-MAS may suffer from spurious solutions. This phenomenon, previously overlooked in MASVN-MAS studies, restricts its applicability to such waveguides. Furthermore, based on the idea of MASVN-MAS, we extend auxiliary sources from monopoles to dipoles and establish a MAS based on the dipole auxiliary source vector norm (DASVN-MAS). Our results reveal that spurious solutions of DASVN-MAS still exist in multiconnected domains waveguides. To address this issue, a mono–dipole auxiliary source is introduced into MAS, termed a MAS based on the mono–dipole auxiliary source vector norm (MDASVN-MAS). In contrast to MASVN-MAS and DASVN-MAS, numerical results indicate that MDASVN-MAS has no spurious solutions in multiconnected domain waveguide analyses.

title: Multipath Component-Enhanced Signal Processing for Integrated Sensing and Communication Systems
authors: Haotian Liu, Zhiqing Wei, Xiyang Wang, Huici Wu, Fan Liu, Xingwang Li, Zhiyong Feng
abstract: Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) has gained traction in academia and industry. Recently, multipath components (MPCs), as a type of spatial resource, have the potential to improve the sensing performance in ISAC systems, especially in richly scattering environments. In this paper, we propose to leverage MPC and Khatri-Rao space-time (KRST) code within a single ISAC system to realize high-accuracy sensing for multiple dynamic targets and multi-user communication. Specifically, we propose a novel MPC-enhanced sensing processing scheme with symbol-level fusion, referred to as the “SL-MSP” scheme, to achieve high-accuracy localization of multiple dynamic targets and empower the single ISAC system with a new capability of absolute velocity estimation for multiple targets with a single sensing attempt. Furthermore, the KRST code is applied to flexibly balance communication and sensing performance in richly scattering environments. To evaluate the contribution of MPCs, the closed-form Cramér-Rao lower bounds (CRLBs) for location and absolute velocity estimation are derived. Simulation results illustrate that the proposed SL-MSP scheme is more robust and accurate in localization and absolute velocity estimation compared with the existing state-of-the-art schemes.

title: City-Level Pavement Distress Inspection Using Crowdsourced Data of Logistics Vehicles
authors: Chenglong Liu, Hanlin Yang, Difei Wu, Yishun Li, Yuchuan Du
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Large-scale pavement distress inspection has gained attention recently. Traditional methods, involving dedicated vehicles and professionals, are effective for small-scale evaluations but are labor-intensive for extensive areas. Logistics vehicles, equipped with driving recorders, provide a vast resource of street view images covering urban roads, capturing pavement distress data. This paper proposes a novel framework leveraging logistics vehicle data for rapid distress detection and tracking. A deep convolutional neural network, enhanced with a dual-layer routing attention mechanism, improves detection precision for minor distresses. The optimized Boundary Box Regression (BBR) loss function increases accuracy for common distresses like cracks. A three-stage distress matching algorithm, based on an attentional graph neural network and adjacent-local-area matching, removes duplications and tracks distress deterioration. The Bernoulli function assesses minimal sampling frequency for road segments. Validated in Shanghai, this method achieves 79.6% mean Average Precision (mAP) and a 75.66% matching rate, enabling daily updates for timely maintenance decisions.

title: Design and Analysis of Ultra-Fast Charging Cables with Adaptive Thermal Management
authors: Ya-Chi Ho, Tsai-Liang Wu, Ruei-Yu Lin, Ting-Ruei Huang
publish: 2025 International Power and Sustainable Energy Technologies Conference (PSETC)
abstract: This study proposes a novel cooling system for high-power EV charging cables, integrating Shape Memory Alloys (SMAs) with an adaptive heat dissipation module. The SMA’s temperature-responsive behavior enables autonomous adjustment of cooling channels, enhancing heat transfer through micro-vortices and two-phase flow. Finite Element Method (FEM) simulations were conducted to evaluate temperature distribution under varying spiral pitches, flow rates, and heat loads. To optimize performance, machine learning techniques, including Lasso and Ridge regression, were applied to a dataset of simulations and six months of experimental data. The predictive model accurately forecasts internal temperatures and supports parameter tuning. Results show the system maintains surface temperatures below 45 °C and improves heat transfer efficiency by ~50%. This work demonstrates a scalable thermal management approach that enhances the safety and reliability of next-generation fast-charging infrastructure.

title:
Modifying the Effect of TiO
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Nanoparticles to Enhance Breakdown Voltage of Transformer Oil
authors: Vic William Vinsent Arokiasamy, Nurfarhanim Abu Bakar, Hafizul Azizi Ismail, Hafisoh Binti Ahmad, Hazlee Azil Illias, Hoon Yap
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: This paper explores the potential of using Waste Cooking Oil (WCO) as an environmentally sustainable alternative to mineral oil. It also investigates the effects of incorporating TiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">₂</inf> nanoparticles into Fatty Acid Methyl Ester (FAME) derived from WCO through transesterification, with the aim of enhancing its Breakdown Voltage (BDV). The ester formation is analyzed using Gas Chromatography and Mass Spectrometry (GC MS), while key characteristics of FAME such as acid value, water content, viscosity, and BDV are evaluated in accordance with ASTM and IEC standards. The results indicate that FAME exhibits improved acid value and viscosity compared to unprocessed WCO. Although the addition of TiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">₂</inf> nanoparticles enhances BDV stability over time, a concentration of 0.5 wt.% shows reduced peak BDV, and 1.0 wt.% results in further performance degradation due to nanoparticle agglomeration. The findings suggest that nanoparticle-infused FAME has the potential to serve as an environmental friendly alternative to mineral oil; however, the concentration of nanoparticles should remain below 0.5 wt.% to avoid adverse effects on its electrical performance.

title: Torque Ripple Reduction in Non-Sinusoidal PMSMs Using FCS-MPC-Based Harmonic Current Injection
authors: Emmanuel Adamski De Moura, Lucas Rossato Rocha, Paulo Henrique Alves Da Silva e Silva, Marco Rivera, Rodrigo Padilha Vieira
abstract: This paper presents a Finite Control Set Model Predictive Control (FCS-MPC) strategy for harmonic current injection aiming torque ripple reduction in non-sinusoidal Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors (PMSMs). A mathematical model of the PMSM is presented, emphasizing the harmonic characteristics of the back electromotive force (BEMF), which are responsible for torque oscillations when classic current control strategies are applied. The proposed control strategy leverages FCS-MPC's ability to directly track non-sinusoidal current references and manage inverter switching states efficiently. Simulation results demonstrate that the controller successfully synthesizes the desired current waveforms and achieves significant attenuation of harmonic torque components. The results confirm the effectiveness of the approach in mitigating torque ripple. Future work will focus on experimental implementation and further performance evaluation under varying operating conditions to assess the robustness of the proposed harmonic injection method.

title: Lumped Parameter Thermal Network for a Switched Reluctance Motor in Agricultural Machinery Application
authors: Gabriel Marques Oliveira, Rolando Rodrigo Caicedo Castro, Vinicius Augusto de Abreu Batista, Ingrid Lopes Motta, Marcelo Vinicius de Paula, Tárcio André dos SantosBarros
abstract: At present, there is increasing interest in the usage of electric motors in order to mitigate climate change. An advantageous topology in harsh environments is the switched reluctance motor (SRM). In this context, a lumped parameter thermal network (LPTN) for an SRM is developed by a combination of currently available in the literature conductive models (used to describe each of the motor components) and convective heat transfer correlations (used to quantify heat exchange in the end space air, in the air gap, and in the cooling system). When compared against an industry-standard software for electric motor design, the resulting temperatures in the main points of interest show remarkable precision (with the temperature error in almost all interest points being within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}} \mathbf{C}$</tex>). Additionally, the proposed model allows for transient analyses, a feature that most models available in the literature lack due to numerical instability around negative thermal resistances.

title: In-Depth Comparative Analysis of Transformer Losses in High-Frequency Isolated DC-DC Converters Using the Steinmetz, Generalized Steinmetz, and Improved Generalized Steinmetz Modeling
authors: Davi C. Amorim, Juliana B. de Almeida, João Felipe X. P. Lima, Vitor Emanuel A. D, Raimundo N. Oliveira, Adolfo José M. F. Araújo, Fernando L. Tofoli, José Willamy M., João R. Arnaud da Cruz, Demercil Oliveira
abstract: The losses in a transformer can be divided into conductor losses and core losses. The latter are commonly estimated using the Steinmetz equation, under the assumption of sinusoidal excitation. However, with the advancement of power electronics, transformers operating at high frequencies are now subjected to non-sinusoidal excitations, which invalidate the initial assumption of the equation. Therefore, a comparative analysis is proposed between three core loss estimation methods: the Steinmetz equation (SE), the generalized Steinmetz equation (GSE), and the improved generalized Steinmetz equation (iGSE). These methods were placed side by side and validated by opencircuit temperature rise tests on transformers.

title: Design of Personalized Digital Media Content Recommendation System Based on Deep Learning
authors: Zhaohui Yao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Digital media content recommendation scenarios face challenges such as insufficient recommendation accuracy, high recommendation latency, low coverage of long-tail content, and inefficient cold start. This paper proposes a hybrid deep learning framework based on graph neural networks (GNNs) and causal reasoning. The system employs a four-layer closedloop architecture: the data layer constructs a cross-modal attention mechanism to achieve 128-dimensional dense alignment of text, image, and audio features; the model layer integrates heterogeneous graph neural networks, counterfactual decoupling networks, and meta-learning initialization; the inference layer deploys a 3D sharding computing engine; and the service layer combines IPW weighting and reinforcement learning to improve coverage of long-tail content. The system achieves an AUC of 0.903 on the Netflix-MovieLens hybrid dataset, providing an efficient, fair, and scalable personalized content distribution solution for digital media platforms.

title: Compact thermal modeling methodology for HBM
authors: Younghoon Hyun, Seongwoo Yang, Daewoong Lee, Heejin Lee, Kang-Wook Lee
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: As thermal model complexity increases, model simplification has become essential. This is particularly true for 2.5D SiP (System in Package) designs, which require a simplification methodology due to the inclusion of multiple HBM (High Bandwidth Memory) components. Various methodologies, such as DELPHI, 2-R (two-resistor), and in-house models, have been developed for different purposes. However, these existing methods are not suitable for our specific needs, prompting the development of a new methodology. This new approach must meet the following criteria: i) handle multiple heat sources, ii) include software-independent components, iii) be adaptable to power maps, and iv) maintain a temperature error margin of less than 1%. An HBM detail thermal model consists of 8,12, or 16 core dies, depending on the total number of die stacks. A single core die (DRAM: Dynamic Random Access Memory) includes various cuboids, such as dies, bumps, active layers, and EMC (Epoxy Molded Compound). In contrast, our HBM CTM (Compact Thermal Model) simplifies this structure to just four cuboids, representing a base die, two core dies, and EMC implying that the detail information of HBM is encrypted. To better understand the temperature distribution and heat transfer rate within the detail HBM model, heat equations were defined for each layer, and the isotropic equivalent thermal conductivity was obtained through matrix calculations. The results showed good agreement with CFD (Computational Fluid Dynamics) simulation results under various power dissipation scenarios and controlled conditions, where uniform power was applied and the temperature was monitored at the center of the die. To enhance the versatility of the HBM CTM, including the incorporation of power maps and arbitrary temperature locations, additional anisotropic thermal conductivity components were required. These components were calculated using RSM (Response Surface Methodology), with 210 DOEs (Design of Experiments) conducted to extract the temperature estimation function, which includes parameters such as in-plane and out-of-plane thermal conductivities for the base and core dies. Our HBM CTM reduces computational time by a factor of 5 to 8 while maintaining temperature accuracy within 0.19% for a standalone HBM and within 0.72% for an HBM in SiP.

title: Investigation of An Air-Cooled Integrated Synthetic Jet Heat Sink for Electronics Thermal Management
authors: Faisal Ahmed, Mehmet Arik
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Passive cooling technologies, such as heat sinks, have been widely employed as a reliable solution for efficient heat dissipation, offering the advantages of zero energy consumption and minimal maintenance. However, as the demand for high-performance electronics continues to rise, passive cooling alone is insufficient to meet the thermal management requirements of advanced systems. Recently, synthetic jet (SJ) technology has emerged as a promising active cooling method. SJs, also referred to as zero-net-mass-flux (ZNMF) jets, are produced by an actuator that drives surrounding fluid in and out of a cavity through an orifice, resulting in enhanced airflow within the system. This study explores the thermal performance of two distinct configurations of SJ-integrated heat sinks. The first configuration incorporates an array of multiple orifice SJ devices (SJDs) embedded directly within the heat sink, while the second involves SJDs impinging from above the heat sink. In the embedded configuration, the number of SJDs (2 and 4) and their operating frequencies are varied at a fixed excitation voltage. In the SJDs of impinged configuration, arrays of satellite orifices are positioned around a central orifice, and the number of arrays is adjusted while maintaining a constant central orifice diameter. Additionally, the impingement distance, or the gap between the SJD and the heat sink fins, is varied to analyze cooling performance. The results demonstrate that the embedded SJD heat sink provides superior heat transfer enhancement and reduced footprint area compared to the impinged SJD heat sink. The heat sink is also tested under natural convection conditions for a baseline design. It is found that the Nusselt number has been augmented three times with a low power consumption (1W).

title: Cost-Effective and Space-Saving Power Multiplexer for Active Battery Balancing Based on CCI-MOS Solid-State Relays
authors: Wenzel Maier, Amilcar F. Querubini Gonçalves, Ricardo Quadros Machado
abstract: This paper presents the design of an optimized power multiplexer (switch matrix) for active battery balancing systems. The proposed approach allows a single electronic unit, consisting of a DC/DC converter and measurement circuitry, to address multiple series-connected cells. As a consequence, the overall effort and hardware resources required for individual cell voltage measurement as well as charge and discharge control are significantly reduced. Bidirectional switching is realized using “constant-current-injected MOSFETs” (CCI-MOS), enabling a compact and cost-effective implementation of the switch matrix. The circuit topology is straightforward to implement and can be flexibly scaled with respect to both the number of accumulator cells and the balancing current. To demonstrate the practicality of the approach, a compact multiplexer prototype has been developed. This prototype directly controls up to 18 battery cells. With a current-handling capability of +-10 A, the module achieves fast and efficient cell balancing.

title: Cooperative Edge Inference and Virtual Simulation for Real-Time 3D Human Pose Estimation in Safety-Critical Applications
authors: Hyun-Ho Choi, Kangsoo Kim, Ki-Ho Lee, Kisong Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Accurate and real-time 3D human pose estimation is essential for safety-critical applications such as intelligent surveillance, yet remains challenging in resource-constrained and dynamic environments due to its high computational demands. To address this, we propose a cooperative edge inference method for real-time 3D pose estimation in mobile edge computing networks. End devices equipped with lightweight models apply dual confidence thresholds to filter uncertain inputs, offloading only the selected images to an edge server for refined inference. We formulate a joint optimization problem to determine the optimal confidence thresholds and transmission times per device with the aim of minimizing the mean per-joint position error under end-to-end delay constraints. To evaluate the proposed method under controlled and repeatable multi-view conditions, we developed a virtual 3D simulation environment in Unity that mimics motion scenarios and provides accurate ground-truth pose data. Experimental results demonstrate a clear trade-off between accuracy and latency, and confirm that the proposed method significantly improves estimation accuracy while consistently meeting delay requirements.

title: Sampled-Data $H_{2}$ Output Feedback Control Applied to ATMD Stabilization of FOWT Systems
authors: Agatângelo J. S. Gois, Felipe T. do Nascimento, Marcus V. S. Costa, René D. O. Pereira, Victor de P. B. Aguiar, Ricardo S. T. Pontes, Claudio Gabriel Venceslau Vale
abstract: This paper proposes a Sampled-Data <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathcal{H}_{2}$</tex> (SD <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathcal{H}_{2}$</tex>) output feedback control for floating offshore wind turbine (FOWT) systems using a Differential Linear Matrix Inequalities framework to mitigate environmental disturbances and enhance energy efficiency via an Active Tuned Mass Damper (ATMD). The main objective of this application is to reduce structural vibrations in the wind turbine and improve power generation efficiency. The proposed controller stabilizes tower oscillations by actuating an ATMD device installed in the nacelle. The methodology is supported by mathematical modeling and validated through MATLAB simulations. The results reinforce the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy regarding time response.

title: Multi-physics modeling of dissipation analysis for Lithium-ion batteries
authors: Tae-Hyun Kim, Eun-Ho Lee
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: The importance of developing batteries with high reliability and safety, capable of withstanding various environmental factors and long-term use, is growing. Silicon materials have gained attention due to their high theoretical capacity, low potential difference with lithium, and abundant resources. However, significant challenges such as volume expansion and efficiency degradation due to energy loss remain. To address these issues, comprehensive understanding of electrical, chemical, thermal, and mechanical properties are required incorporating chemical potential, stress, and species transport. This study presents a multiphysics simulation model focusing on the mechanical energy dissipation of silicon anodes, particularly emphasizing expansion and plastic deformation. Implemented in the MATLAB environment, the model calculates the dissipation of electrical, chemical, thermal, and mechanical energy and demonstrates the state of charge (SOC) during charging and discharging cycles. The SOC varies with energy dissipation and anisotropy across different C-rates, and the results provide a comparative analysis of strategies to improve the mechanical stability of silicon anodes. The model validates galvanostatic responses under various C-rate conditions, and cycle-based energy dissipation, highlighting the necessity of mechanical dissipation in the development of next-generation silicon anodes. Future works will focus on the mechanical dissipation in alloying-based anodes such as SnBi.
