This research highlights the long-term stability and cyclic efficiency of alloying-based anodes for high capacity and durable battery systems.

title: Your Eyes Hold Your Mind: Gaze-Based Inference of Human Decision-Making in Conditionally Automated Driving
authors: Minseo Choi, Hoe Sung Ryu, Haechan Lee, Uijong Ju
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Is it possible to predict decision-making during automated driving solely through gaze data? To address this question, this study recruited 54 participants and implemented a two-step decision-making process in a high-risk, conditionally automated driving scenario. The first-order decision involved determining whether to intervene in autonomous control, and the second-order decision required choosing between self-sacrifice or harming others. An analysis of gaze data from 16 to 2 seconds prior to the event onset revealed significant differences in gaze patterns across the different decision groups. For the first-order decision, the intervention group (Manual) fixated more frequently on the road, the cliff, and surrounding elements, whereas the non-intervention group (Auto) maintained their gaze primarily on the forward windshield, implying differing information-seeking strategies between groups. For the second-order decision, the group that chose to harm others (Manual-Collide) concentrated their gaze on the front and the cliff, whereas the group that opted for self-sacrifice (Manual-Fall) distributed their gaze across various Areas of Interest (AOIs) until the moment of decision. This pattern implies that the collide group reached their decision at an earlier stage, while the fall group sought alternative solutions until the last moment. These findings suggest that gaze data could serve as a cognitive indicator, reflecting the flow of human judgment and the underlying intent behind decisions.

title: An Improved Injection Scheme for Impedance Estimation in Integrated-Converter Battery Packs
authors: Bruno de Araujo Coutinho, Lorrane Prado Silva do Carmo, Marcelo Martins Stopa, Victor Flores Mendes, Heverton Augusto Pereira, Allan Fagner Cupertino
abstract: This paper presents a methodology for the online determination of battery impedance using Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) in combination with a distributed power converter architecture. The proposed approach exploits existing boost converters to inject phase-shifted sinusoidal perturbation currents into each battery cell, enabling real-time impedance measurement without introducing ripple into the dclink voltage. Simulations conducted in PLECS validated the control strategy, confirming that the proposed phase-shifting technique effectively suppresses dc-link voltage ripple while allowing impedance estimation. Hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) experiments were carried out using the Typhoon HIL 402 and the Texas Instruments F28379D controlCARD, confirming the feasibility of the method in real time. The proposed methodology represents a step toward integrating real-time impedance tracking into smart battery management systems, with potential applications in state-of-charge and state-of-health estimation.

title: User-Feedback-based On Device AI Alignment System for AR HUDs in Automotive Applications
authors: Sungjei Kim, Sunghee Ahn
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: This paper proposes a user-centered modular Artificial Intelligence (AI) architecture designed to enhance alignment accuracy in Augmented Reality Head-Up Displays (AR HUDs) for autonomous driving environments. Misalignment and latency between virtual content and real-world objects in AR HUDs can lead to cognitive delays and visual discomfort, ultimately lowering user satisfaction and causing physical fatigue. To address this, the proposed system divides on-device AI processing into three real-time modules: (1) perceptual state analysis, (2) spatiotemporal alignment correction, and (3) user feedback-driven adaptive content control. Each module reflects real-time user feedback, dynamically adjusting alignment according to contextual awareness, multisensory inputs, and perceptual thresholds. This human-centered design reduces visual latency, mitigates disorientation and fatigue, and enhances information delivery during driving, thereby ensuring safety. As a methodological basis, a user scenario-based approach is adopted, shifting the paradigm performance-centered AR design to predictive, perception-driven AI-human interaction models.

title: Brute Force Detection and Active Response for Secure Web Login using Wazuh
authors: K Zin Htet, Hnin Thiri Zaw, Aung Htein Maw
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: Web login systems remain at risk from brute force breaches, which result in a large number of unsuccessful login attempts that need to be precisely detected and blocked. This study demonstrates how Wazuh SIEM can detect and prevent these types of attacks in real time when it is integrated with custom rules and active response. Wazuh detected recurring login failures and automatically initiated firewall-drop operations by simulating brute force attacks using a vulnerable web application. Detection rate, active response time, recall and false negatives are used to evaluate the proposed approach at three, five, and ten different frequency levels. According to the findings, administrators may modify brute force countermeasures based on their conditions by tuning detection thresholds, which significantly impacts the response time versus accuracy trade-off.

title: Methodology for Thermal Performance Evaluation using LPV-Based Thermal Resistance Matrix Modeling of Mobile SoC
authors: Myunghoon Lee, Yunhyeok Im, Subodh Deodhar, Gyuick Jung, Vamsi Krishna, Ankit Adhiya
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Chiplets have emerged as an important solution to meet the complex and diverse needs of the electronics market while continuously improving performance, despite the limitations of process scaling. Consequently, system-on-chip (SoCs) are shifting from traditional planar structures to three-dimensional stacked architectures, resulting in a significant increase in heat dissipation per unit area. This has made thermal management a critical performance-limiting factor. To address thermal issues, thermal-aware floorplan design processes are being considered from the early stages of SoC design. Thermal characterization models based on thermal resistance matrices have proven to be valuable tools to predict temperature contour on die, considering both self-heating effects and thermal coupling effects through the principle of linear superposition. However, modern application processors (AP) operate in diverse thermal environments, where operating frequency and boundary conditions are controlled based on temperatures measured by thermal sensors under various operational scenarios. Therefore, there is a need to extend thermal characterization modeling using thermal resistance matrices to accommodate these varied convective heat transfer conditions. We propose a thermal performance evaluation process based on Linear Parameter Varying (LPV) thermal resistance matrices, The proposed process incorporates convective heat transfer coefficients (HTC, h) as thermal boundary conditions applied in Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) models. Thermal resistance matrix models are extracted for various representative HTC values for the temperature evaluation of the chip, HTC is calculated based on the monitored temperature of specific regions, and a thermal resistance matrix is extracted using linear interpolation. This process demonstrates improved accuracy over previous thermal resistance matrix-based thermal evaluation methods by better reflecting boundary conditions

title: Autonomous and Coordinated Control of Pole-Mounted BESS for Overvoltage Mitigation in Low-Voltage Grids
authors: João Marcus Soares Callegari, Danilo Iglesias Brandao
abstract: The increasing integration of distributed energy resources (DERs) into low-voltage (LV) distribution grids has raised technical challenges, particularly related to voltage regulation and overvoltage during high photovoltaic (PV) generation periods. This paper investigates the deployment of distributed pole-mounted battery energy storage systems (BESS) to mitigate overvoltage conditions in LV residential feeders. Two control strategies are compared: autonomous operation based on local volt-watt curves and coordinated operation via a power management system (PMS) located at the point of common coupling (PCC). Simulation results using the CIGRÉ European LV benchmark feeder demonstrate that the coordinated strategy achieves regulatory compliance with 20 % lower rated power per BESS unit compared to the autonomous approach. Furthermore, the coordinated strategy ensures uniform active power dispatch among the devices, promoting balanced thermal stress. Importantly, both control strategies operate without requiring any knowledge of the LV grid topology.

title: A Hybrid Blockchain and Convolutional Neural Network for Secure Cloud-Assisted Medical Image Analysis
authors: Raed Hameed, Mohan Kumar. T G, Narendra Chennupati, Preethi Varthini. S, Vinny Kuriakose
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In recent years, securing medical images in the cloud has become essential owing to the rapid accumulation of Computed Tomography (CT), Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), and ultrasound data from hospitals, diagnostic centers, and IoMT-enabled devices. However, the Customizable Unique Node Access (CUNA)-based deep encryption model has limited scalability, verifiable provenance, and lacked advanced analytics for accurate medical interpretation. To overcome these limitations, this research proposes a hybrid Blockchain and Convolutional Neural Network (B-CNN) model for secure cloud-assisted medical image processing. Initially, data is collected from medical imaging devices integrated with hospital information systems and sensors. Preprocessing at the edge nodes then performs normalization of image dimensions, anonymization of patient identifiers, denoising, and metadata generation. Encrypted medical data are stored off-chain, whereas a permissioned blockchain records immutable hashes, access policies, and consent. A CNN-transformer hybrid network extracts spatial features through convolutional layers and global context from transformer encoders and then combines them for accurate classification to enhance scalability, security, diagnostic precision, and trust in cloud healthcare systems. The experimental results demonstrated that the proposed B-CNN model outperformed the existing CUNA model in terms of accuracy (93.23 %).

title: TalkGenie: Intent and Sentiment-Aware Multilingual Chatbot
authors: Dhulipala Saisubrahmanya Saranya, Dara Anirudh, Koppula Pooja Reddy, N S S S Girish Kumar, M A Jabbar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In an increasingly globalized world characterized by vast linguistic diversity, effective cross-lingual communication remains a significant challenge, particularly when underlying emotions are lost in translation. This paper introduces TalkGenie, a novel chatbot designed to bridge linguistic and emotional gaps by enabling natural speech and text communication across various native languages. TalkGenie goes beyond simple translation, integrating intent detection and sentiment analysis with realtime, context-sensitive response generation. Using the LLaMA3 language model and a custom translation system, TalkGenie delivers multilingual, human-like responses, fostering universal communication. By merging sentiment analysis and intent with real-time response generation and support for multiple languages, TalkGenie brings us closer to universal communication with sentiment accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 9. 4 3 \%}$</tex> and intent accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 3. 9 0 \%}$</tex>. TalkGenie is a revolutionary language conversational companion that revolutionizes multilingual communication by breaking down language, emotional, and disability barriers.

title: Segmentation-Guided Ensemble Learning for Chest X-Ray-Based COVID-19 Diagnosis
authors: Yuvraj Sharma, Ajith Kumar, Srirangam Vyshnavi, Manzoor Mohammad, M. A. Jabbar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: This paper introduces a deep learning system designed to make COVID-19 diagnosis faster and more accurate using chest X-ray (CXR) images. The system has two main steps: segmentation and classification. First, a U-Net model is used to create masks that highlight just the lungs, helping to remove unnecessary areas like ribs and background. These masks are applied to the original images so the models can focus only on the important parts. The masked images are then passed into three deep learning models, ResNet152V2, DenseNet121, and VGG-19, which work together to predict if a person has COVID-19. Since there were fewer COVID-positive images, targeted data augmentation was applied to balance the dataset during training. Finally, a majority voting method was used to combine the predictions from the three models. The system achieved an accuracy of 96 %, showing that focusing on the lungs and balancing the dataset can significantly improve detection performance.

title: Intelligent Evaluation of English Teaching Based on Multi-Modal Framework
authors: Jianfang Shao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Traditional English teaching evaluation processes depends on the student's feedback, manual observation and routine examinations. These methods often considered as the inaccurate and inconsistent methods to evaluate the student to learn and become proficient in the English language. This existing method often fails to support the real-time instructional enhancement of the students to learn the English Language. In this context, this research paper proposes the Capsule Convolutional Networks and Attention Evoked Bi-Gated recurrent units to provide tan effective teaching feedback systems and actionable assessment to enhance the teaching experience among the teachers. Experimental evaluation across 10 universities involving 1400 instructors and 29,000 students in which the performance metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall and F1-score are measured. Results demonstrated significant improvements in evaluation accuracy and utility. The suggested framework achieved 97.4% correlation with expert human evaluators while reducing evaluation processing time by 86%. Hence the proposed research has found a new application for educational systems, significantly improving the English teaching effectiveness and user experiences.

title: Detecting Hate and Offensive Speech in Dravidian Code-Mix Text Using Transformers
authors: Sreeman Macha, Sai Dinesh, Abu Zaid, N S S S Girish Kumar, M.A. Jabbar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Classifying hate speech in low-resource languages like Kannada, Tamil, and Malayalam is challenging due to noisy, unbalanced, and multilingual datasets. This paper introduces a robust pipeline using the IndicBERTv2 transformer to address this. This approach integrates a custom classification head with multiple pooling strategies and employs strong data augmentation, including back translation and paraphrasing, to enhance generalization. This paper tackles class imbalance with focal loss and weighted sampling, while training is optimized through progressive, language-specific fine-tuning and ensembling. The proposed pipeline establishes a crucial performance benchmark. The model achieved classification accuracies of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 3 \%}$</tex> for Malayalam, 69 % for Tamil, and 63 % for Kannada. However, the F1 scores, particularly for Tamil and Kannada (ranging from 0.47 to 0.53), were more modest. This disparity highlights the significant challenge of achieving balanced precision and recall in these complex, imbalanced datasets, setting a clear direction for future work.

title: Evaluating the Environmental and Performance Impact of Bio-Based Epoxy Composites for Semiconductor Packaging
authors: Visakhan Vijayan Nambiar, Sameer Abass, Karthik Gundala, Bharath Gopathi, Nandika Anne D’Souza, Hongbing Lu, Varughese Mathew, Abdullah Fahim, Greta Terzariol
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Epoxies and epoxy composites are widely used across semiconductor package structures, for example as dieattach adhesive and epoxy molding compounds. As the use of these materials are expected to grow further with increased use of electronic components for automation, AI and the Electric Vehicle industry, it is necessary to also take a look at the impact of the materials on the environment as a parameter to guide the material selection, so that we may not only select the best performance to cost, but also the sustainability of the selected material. Here we have presented an initial study towards building a dataset to provide a carbon footprint for bio-based v/s non-bio-based epoxy composites with conductive and non-conductive fillers. The key performance parameters measured are the thermal conductivity, glass transition temperature and dielectric breakdown strength. The effect of the filler type (h-BN, Silica, Alumina) and the filler size on these properties are presented. A life-cycle impact analysis (LCA) is presented to discuss the environmental impact and sustainability of the epoxies and fillers corresponding to the measured parameters. From the initial study and life cycle analysis, it is observed that epoxy resin plays a key role in the environmental impact of the composites even for highly filled formulations, and a switch to bio-based materials would help significantly reduce this impact. The highest thermal conductivity improvement of 294% and dielectric breakdown strength improvement of 119% were achieved using $1.5 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ hBN at $30-40$ weight % filler loading.

title: A Perturb and Observe-Based Algorithm for Automatic Tuning of Controller Gains in Static Converters
authors: Gustavo A. Teixeira, Rafael C. Neto, Calebe H. O. Lima, Fabrício Bradaschia, Leonardo R. Limongi, Eduardo A. O. Barbosa
abstract: With the increasing demand for renewable energy sources and the widespread use of nonlinear loads, such as rectifier-based supplies, the deployment of grid-connected inverters has grown significantly over the past decade. In these applications, the performance of these inverters strongly depends on the current control loop implementation, with shunt active power filters (APFs) being a widely used application for studying and validating control strategies. Although the use of resonant controllers is widely adopted for these applications, tuning their gains is often not a trivial task. In this context, this paper proposes an adaptive controller that uses a perturb and observe (P&O) algorithm for the online tuning of the integral gain of multiples resonant controllers applied to the control of a threephase shunt APF connected to the grid. Experimental results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed strategy.

title: Design and Research on Real-Time Monitoring of Debris Flows Based on Edge Computing and YOLO11 Algorithm
authors: Anzhen Shang, Xin Guan, Lichun Bai
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: In the field of geological disaster monitoring, debris flows, due to their sudden and highly destructive nature, place extremely high demands on real-time monitoring technologies. This paper designs and researches a real-time debris flow monitoring system based on edge computing and the YOLO11 algorithm. The system adopts the Tianmin RK3588 Androidbased edge computing box as its core hardware device, with cameras deployed around mountain slopes and connected to the edge computing box to enable real-time video data collection of the monitoring area. At the edge computing box end, the lightweight YOLO11n model processes the real-time video stream, accurately identifying targets such as debris flows, falling rocks, trees, and people. Through a predefined judgment mechanism, the system can quickly detect the occurrence of debris flows and issue corresponding alarm levels based on the disaster situation, realizing lightweight algorithm deployment and real-time response. Meanwhile, the system uploads relevant video data of debris flow events to the cloud platform, providing emergency departments with more detailed disaster information for in-depth analysis and subsequent decision-making. This design fully leverages the advantages of edge computing in low latency and local processing, as well as the efficient target detection capabilities of the YOLO11 algorithm, effectively improving the real-time performance and accuracy of debris flow monitoring and providing strong technical support for the emergency prevention and control of geological disasters.

title: Deepfake Voice Detection: Countering Deepfake Audio with Deep Learning Architectures
authors: Kaung Khant Ko, Su Wai Wai Tun, Myat Thiri Kyaw, Thet Thet Zin
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: The active development of the Text-to-Speech (TTS) technology as well as the Voice Conversion (VC) has posed an outstanding danger to the digital security. To overcome this obstacle, this paper will compare and contrast systematically three different deep learning structures, a hybrid CNN-RNN framework that aims to conduct both spectral and temporal artifact processing, a CNN-LSTM ensemble framework exploring the distinctive capabilities of the spatial and temporal processing, and a state-of-the-art system with Wav2Vec2 as a pre-trained feature extractor and as a Light Convolutional Neural Network (LCNN) to make predictions. Although all these architectures operate on the basis of known elements, they are new in the way that they specifically aim at deepfake detection and also they are assessed and evaluated in an unprecedented way in parallel. With experiments on a wide variety of benchmark datasets, such as ASVspoof 2019, WaveFake and FoR, this paper compares the trade-offs between feature-engineered and self-supervised methods. As the results show, CNN + LSTM-based platform can deliver better results, its analysis accuracy is 99.81, because it is able to get deep, context-sensitive representations of unprocessed audio. The present study highlights the symbiosis of organizing various deep learning techniques and establishes a complete reference in future studies in resilient equipment of deepfake voice detecting.

title: Real-Time Attendance Monitoring System Using RFID
authors: Debi Prashad Pradhan, Nalini Singh, Dhananjaya Tripathy, Amiya Bhusana Sahoo
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: The implementation of an RFID-based attendance system aims to enhance efficiency in tracking and maintaining full attendance in classrooms, laboratories, offices, or any organizational setting using RFID technology. Each participant is issued an RFID card, which, when scanned, logs their attendance in real-time. The system operates within a closed-loop framework, ensuring data security and privacy. Upon recording attendance, the system automatically dispatches notifications to both the higher authorities and the individual concerned. This immediate notification system serves as a dual-purpose tool: keeping authorities informed of attendance patterns and providing individuals with confirmation of their recorded presence. The technology reduces manual errors, eliminates the need for paper-based attendance records, and streamlines the process for both participants and administrators that can generate comprehensive attendance reports, aiding in decision-making and policy formulation for improved attendance management. Through this innovative approach, organizations can ensure higher compliance, timely interventions, and foster a culture of accountability and transparency.

title: Deep Multiscale Fusion and Feature Enhancement for Underwater Image Dehazing in Turbid Environments
authors: K. Sathish
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: This study presents a comparative evaluation of five underwater image enhancement techniques-Adaptive Histogram Equalization (AHE), Dark Pixel Prior (DPP), Exposure-based Retinex Algorithm (ERA), Multi-Scale Image Fusion (MSIF), and a novel deep learning-based Proposed Approach—across diverse marine settings such as coral reefs, divers, surface vehicles, and aquatic fauna. Using standardized image quality metrics, we assess performance in terms of contrast enhancement, color fidelity, edge clarity, and overall visual realism. While traditional methods like AHE and DPP often distort textures or compress dynamic range, the Proposed Approach achieves up to 95 % visual clarity, outperforming MSIF (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 86 \%$</tex>) and ERA (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 82 \%$</tex>) in preserving structural and color integrity across depths. It also significantly enhances fine details and mitigates depth-induced distortions, making it ideal for robust underwater vision. Additionally, its capability to reconstruct real and simulated pressure components indicates strong potential for applications in acoustic sensing and underwater material design, positioning it at the intersection of AI-driven perception and integrated intelligent systems.

title: Enhanced Thermal Management of Outer-Rotor Electric Motors Through Additively Manufactured Heat Exchangers With End-Winding Cooling
authors: Md. Jubayer Hossain, Amitav Tikadar, Bidzina Kekelia, Rajneesh Chaudhary, Sreekant Narumanchi, Yogendra Joshi, Satish Kumar
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Effective cooling strategy is critical to achieve improved performance and efficiency in electric-drive vehicle motors. Among approaches, direct winding heat exchangers (DWHXs), positioned inside the motor component slots, have demonstrated superior potential for cooling compared to conventional methods such as forced convection air cooling and liquid jacket cooling. In this work, an in-slot heat exchanger (HEx) based on the DWHX concept is developed for an outer-rotor motor with a 100 kW peak and 55 kW continuous power output, and 50 $\mathrm{kW} / \mathrm{L}$ power density. Initial work developed a baseline additively manufactured aluminum oxide heat exchanger to cool concentrated stator windings in an 18 -slot, 16 -pole outer-rotor motor; however, it lacked performance in cooling stator endwindings. A new design was envisioned to address this issue. The present study introduces a novel in-slot HEx design, which also incorporates a cooling solution for end-windings at both sides of the motor. The thermal performance of this new design is assessed and compared with the baseline concept. The results from the new design indicate an over 50% reduction in thermal resistance and more than 30% reduction in hot-spot temperature. The new design reduces end-winding temperature while maintaining improved thermal uniformity across the winding. The increase in pressure drop in the new design adds only 0.013 W to the pumping power. Furthermore, the results indicate that a potting material used as an interface material - with a thermal conductivity of 3$4 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m} \cdot \mathrm{K}$ - to attach these heat exchangers to motor components is found optimal to ensure effective thermal performance. The achieved performance is realized without altering critical electromagnetic parameters, facilitating seamless integration with the current motor design. These results underscore the potential of ceramic-based in-slot HExs in improving the thermal performance and efficiency of modern electric-drive vehicle motors, representing a substantial advancement in the development of high-power-density electric motors.

title: Evaluation Of High-Temperature Performance of Semi-Additive Rectifier Circuits up to 175°C
authors: Bishal Bashyal, Pradeep Lall, Ved Soni, Aditya Amatya, Scott Miller
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Rectifiers, including half-wave and full-wave types, are fundamental components in power conversion circuits, converting alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC), and being used in various applications. Generally, diodes and rectifiers work well and are studied up to $\mathbf{1 2 5}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}} \mathbf{C}$. Temperature changes can significantly affect their effectiveness and performance, especially at temperatures up to $\mathbf{1 7 5}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}} \mathbf{C}$. High-temperature operation results in the rectifier’s efficiency loss due to high heat dissipation and other changes. The performance of rectifiers, including noise immunity and reliability, diminishes as temperatures rise, particularly in harsh environments like automotive and aerospace applications. The testing undertaken in the present study will provide valuable data for optimizing rectifier performance and ensuring the durability of electronic devices that operate in hightemperature scenarios. Data has been presented based on a detailed examination of both half-wave and full-wave rectifiers subjected to controlled high-temperature conditions. Performance metrics are offered at three critical stages: before, during, and after exposure to elevated temperatures. These metrics are compared to the room temperature datasets or the standard dataset. This approach will allow us to analyze the impact on diode characteristics, such as forward voltage drop and leakage current, and overall rectifier efficiency. By evaluating these factors, one can understand how high temperatures influence the performance and reliability of rectifiers. Results presented in the paper focus on how high temperatures impact the efficiency and output characteristics (e.g., DC output voltage and ripple) of half-wave and full-wave rectifiers by comparing the data for varied temperatures and with room temperature/standard data. In addition, operational stability and reliability are presented under prolonged hightemperature conditions.

title: A Review of XR-Based Rehabilitation: Bridging the Gap Between Technology and Therapy
authors: Saima Ahmed Rahin, Wanwan Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Immersive technologies, including Virtual Reality (VR), Augmented Reality (AR), and Mixed Reality (MR), have shown considerable promise in the field of rehabilitation, offering innovative solutions for enhancing both motor and cognitive recovery. These technologies provide unique opportunities for personalized therapy, allowing patients to participate in interactive and adaptive exercises that promote healing in a controlled environment. This work aims to explore the integration of XR technologies in rehabilitation, particularly for patients recovering from brain injuries, stroke, and neurological disorders. It has 2 parts: 1) SWOT analysis of articles 2) A systematic literature review was conducted to examine the current applications, methodologies, technologies, and devices used in immersive rehabilitation programs. Relevant studies were identified through comprehensive searches in scientific databases, such as Google Scholar, Wiley, PubMed, IEEE Xplore, Springer, and ScienceDirect. The findings indicate that VR-based rehabilitation is widely adopted for motor skill recovery, while AR and MR are emerging as powerful tools to improve cognitive therapy and provide real-time feedback. The review also highlights the challenges and limitations of XR technologies in rehabilitation, such as the need for specialized equipment and the lack of long-term efficacy studies. Despite these challenges, the results suggest that immersive technologies can significantly enhance patient engagement, reduce recovery times, and offer a more accessible approach to rehabilitation. The review identifies future research directions for XR technologies to reshape the rehabilitation landscape. (Fig. 1)

title: Comprehensive Evaluation of Economic Efficiency and Environmental Impact of Airport Water Surface Photovoltaic System Based on Particle Swarm Algorithm
authors: Gang Li, Hui Zhang, Hailong Li, Zhonglin Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: This study aims to construct a multi-objective comprehensive evaluation model for airport water surface photovoltaic systems, optimizing both the levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) and carbon reduction benefits. First, an economic model incorporating PV module efficiency degradation, water surface reflection gain, and operation and maintenance costs, and an environmental model accounting for carbon emissions over the entire life cycle, were established. Second, a multi-objective particle swarm optimization algorithm was employed, with the objective functions of minimizing LCOE and maximizing carbon reduction benefits. Particle positions were dynamically adjusted using a velocity update formula, and the Pareto frontier was used to screen nondominated solutions. For an airport water surface with an annual irradiation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1600 \text{kWh} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex>, the algorithm optimized the LCOE to 0.21 yuan/kWh, reducing annual carbon emissions by 250,000 tons of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex>. The optimal solution set demonstrates a balance between economic and environmental benefits when the module tilt angle is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 5}^{\circ}$</tex> and the installation density is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 8 M W} / \mathbf{h a}$</tex>.

title: Accurate Implementation of Gate Resistance Thermometry for GaN HEMTs with a Source Connected Field Plate
authors: Daniel C. Shoemaker, Seokjun Kim, Emils Jurcik, Matthew T. DeJarld, Maher B. Tahhan, Eduardo M. Chumbes, Jeffrey R. Laroche, Samuel Graham, Nicholas C. Miller, Sukwon Choi
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Gate resistance thermometry (GRT) is a well-established electrical method that is used to infer the gate metal temperature of GaN high electron mobility transistors (HEMTs). In this work, the effect of the bottom side thermal boundary condition on the calibration of the temperature coefficient of resistance (TCR) and the measurement of the device temperature rise was investigated by applying GRT to a bare device die and an identical device die solder-bonded to a CuMo shim. It was found that the probing location of the thermocouple utilized during the calibration process can result in a 12% difference in the deduction of the TCR. Furthermore, the temperature rise of a GaN HEMT on a bare die with no thermal interface material between the bottom of the device die and the thermal stage could be $2.35 \times$ greater than a same device mounted to a CuMo shim due to wafer bow that results in a large thermal contact resistance. Therefore, proper experimental setup was found to be crucial in order to extract the correct TCR and temperature rise within GaN HEMTs with complex topside geometries where GRT is needed.

title: Design of a Liquid-Cooled Half-Bridge Power Module for EV Charging Stations
authors: João Mariano Martins, Lucas Tamai Alves De Lima, Victor Cordeiro De Arruda, Gustavo Henrique Magela Silva, José Alexandre Diniz, Joel Filipe Guerreiro
abstract: With growing concerns about global warming and fossil fuel consumption, electric vehicles appear as a possible solution to minimize both problems. However, this kind of solution has many issues. One of them is the power electronic modules used in the charging systems and their overheating/temperature problems. Considering that enabling a charging power system to function as it should and providing it with a suitable thermal control is mandatory. Therefore, this work presents the study of a half-bridge power module for use in 11 kW CLLC DAB converter utilizing SiC MOSFETs and diodes, along with its electrical and thermal performances, and the effectiveness of a liquid-cooled design for the proposed application. Based on the system equivalent thermal circuit, three stacking of insulated metal substrate PCBs were proposed, and a liquid cooled heat sink was designed for CFD simulations performed using ANSYS Discovery. These simulations allowed an analysis of the methods and helped identify the most suitable stack-up to meet the project's thermal requirements.

title: High-Accuracy Emulation of Propeller Mechanical Dynamics with Simulation Validation Using FOC, PCC, and PTC Controllers
authors: Jefferson A. Enriquez, Marco Rivera, Mateus Giesbrecht
abstract: Dynamic torque emulation test benches are widely used to validate electrical drive systems, even in scenarios where real-world tests are impractical or impossible. In the aerial mobility industry, torque emulation test benches are essential tools that must accurately replicate the dynamic behavior of mechanical loads to ensure reliable results. This paper presents a comparative analysis of high-accuracy control strategies applied to dynamic torque emulators, including field-oriented control (FOC), predictive current control (PCC), and predictive torque control (PTC). The resulting emulations are evaluated against the theoretical dynamic behavior of a propeller model within a numerical simulation environment. The results confirm that the emulators accurately reproduce the propeller dynamics, validating both the control strategies and the configuration of the test bench as a high-precision alternative for developing and testing propulsion systems.

title: Context-Aware Augmented Reality for Human-Robot Collaboration
authors: Shakiba Davari, Akhil Ajikumar, Mohsen Moghaddam
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: This work explores the design of augmented reality (AR), particularly intelligent and context-aware AR interfaces, to facilitate seamless, bidirectional intent communication in human-robot collaboration (HRC). Due to the technical difficulty of repurposing and programming new robot actions in real-time, in conventional HRC systems, robots are typically pre-programmed for fixed tasks and procedural actions, offering limited adaptability. The Human Machine Interface’s (HMI) capability to provide natural interaction with the robot and intuitively present the robot’s feedback to the user can increase the adaptability of robots and enable effective robot repurposing. We design and demonstrate an AR interface that supports gaze-based input and real-time contextual adaptation to robot feedback for industrial tasks, illustrating an HMI that can personalize robot behavior, simplify user interaction, and support non-experts in operating and repurposing collaborative robots.

title: Enhancing EMI Shield Design for EV Inverter Using Advanced Simulation Techniques
authors: Nitish Jetithor, Graham Matthew
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding is crucial for maintaining the reliability and performance of inverters in electric vehicles (EVs) [1]. This paper explores, Key design considerations include use of metal sheet to contain electromagnetic fields, thereby reducing EMI interference. Advanced Simulation Techniques including finite element analysis (FEA), Computational fluid dynamics (CFD) and Fracture Mechanics helped to optimize overall EMI design performance. Real-world testing to validate these simulation solutions helped for contributing to the overall reliability and safety of an EV inverter. This research paper investigates the impact of mechanical loading on the Inverter, a crucial EV component. Rigorous mechanical loading, including random vibration testing, revealed cracks in the EMI shield, prompting further exploration. Ansys software’s innovative Separating Morphing and Adaptive Remeshing Technology (SMART) [7], helped to simulate crack initiation and propagation. SMART technology enables automatic remeshing during fracture behavior simulations, allowing accurate prediction of mixed-mode stress intensity factors (SIFs) [2]. This approach aligns remarkably well with test failure data. Design enhancements, specifically the addition of two horizontal ribbings, proved optimal for passing stringent random vibration testing. This paper highlights overall electrical, thermal, and mechanical design and simulation considerations for EMI shield design and emphasizes the pivotal role of simulation studies in enhancing the reliability and performance of EV inverters.

title: GPU-Accelerated Voxel Representation and High-Fidelity Fabrication of Porous Structures
authors: Kaixiang Zhang, Qingfeng Jia, Bingshan Liu, Shan Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Manufacturing System (ICAMTMS)
abstract: Porous structures, particularly Triply Periodic Minimal Surfaces (TPMS), offer exceptional strength-to-weight ratios, high surface-to-volume ratios, and multifunctional capabilities, driving their use in tissue engineering, lightweighting, and heat exchange. Their inherent geometric complexity necessitates additive manufacturing (AM) for fabrication. However, conventional mesh-based methods struggle with high-density complex porous structures, exhibiting poor fitting accuracy, excessive memory use, and low computational efficiency. This paper introduces a novel voxel-based approach for efficient generation and direct fabrication of porous structures. Leveraging GPU-accelerated parallel voxelization enables rapid geometric construction. Crucially, direct fabrication from voxel data via vat photopolymerization printing eliminates the traditional mesh generation, file conversion, and slicing stages—thus removing associated geometric errors. Experiments demonstrate significant improvements in both modeling efficiency and final fabrication accuracy for complex porous structures, enabling high-fidelity design and support-free manufacturing.

title: Addressing Annotation Scarcity in Cardiac Vessel Segmentation Using Edge-Conditioned Cgan
authors: Ramyashri Kulkarni, Shrinivas D. Desai, Vishwanath P Baligar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Cardiac vessel segmentation is an integral aspect of cardiovascular disease diagnosis and management, yet remains difficult due to the scarcity of annotated medical imaging datasets. This study provides an alternative segmentation framework by employing a Conditional Generative Adversarial Network (cGAN) based on a U-Net architecture, conditioned on edge maps that have been generated via Canny edge detection. The generator has been modified to include residual blocks to improve features learning and the discriminator is informed by structural edge information to improve the accuracy of the vessel boundary. The model was trained using adversarial loss and L1 loss which allows it to adequately capture fine vascular structures from single images/masks despite these often being only sparse data. The experimental findings indicate that the proposed method achieves a Dice Coefficient of 84.60 % and IoU of 73.31 % and Pixel Accuracy of 98.22 %, outperforming baseline U-Net and traditional cGAN models. These findings confirm that not only does the proposed model improve segmentation accuracy, but also maintains structural fidelity.

title: Adaptive Playback of Pointing Gestures for Different Target Positions
authors: Jiho Kang, Sung-Hee Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We present a straightforward yet robust method for adaptive playback of pre-recorded pointing gestures in environments where target positions differ from the original recording. Given a recorded pointing gesture sequence, we first extract pointing gesture progressions using the Pointing Progression Network, which identifies the degree of gesture completion over time. During playback, the Pointing Gesture Network uses these progressions to generate adapted motions that preserve the original gesture’s intent while adapting to new target positions. This work enables applications in asynchronous XR communication and educational content where pointing gestures must maintain their communicative intent across different spatial configurations and temporal contexts.

title: Optimal and Robust Control Analysis of Ball and Plate System
authors: Johnson Y, Parvathy Thampi M. S., Anju Das
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: The conventionally known ball and plate system usually exhibits nonlinear and unstable behaviour. It brings crucial challenges to control engineers while dealing with real-time applications. This paper presents stabilizing optimal and robust control strategies using linear-quadratic-gaussian techniques and h-infinity robust solutions for specifying and maintaining ball’s position in a perturbed system of plate and ball.

title: Resilient Cloud Native Architecture for Predictive Anomaly Detection in Industrial IoT with a Case Study on Securing Operational Technology Pipelines
authors: Sruthi Erra Hareram
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) and Operational Technology (OT) are becoming more and more connected. To keep up, we need strong, expandable networks that can identify problems right away and make predictions. Together, edge-to-cloud telemetry, human-in-the-loop AI, and continuous ML lifecycle management are used in this study to show a cloud-native design that can protect Industrial Control Systems (ICS). Azure Event Hubs are used to feed data with low latency, MLflow is used to track and retrain models, and Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) input is used for adaptive anomaly detection. The suggested method works as shown by a real-life case study in a petroleum pipeline monitoring system. The system was able to identify anomalies 94.7% of the time, had 38.5% less detection delay than most edge-only models, and was up 22% more of the time. Using streaming feedback loops cut the time it took to reset the model to less than 30 minutes, which made it more adaptable in real time. These results indicate that cloud-native predictive models could be used in mission-critical OT systems. This would make them safe, scalable, and smart for use in Industry 4.0.

title: Deepfake Detection using Multi-Stream Convolutional Neural Networks with Attention-based Fusion
authors: Mohan Sankaran, Mostafha Alwbaidy, Lathakumari. K R, S. D. Govardhan, Ponmurugan Panneer Selvam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In recent years, DeepFake technology has rapidly evolved by enabling the development of highly realistic forged facial videos that pose serious threats to digital trust and security. Traditional deep learning approaches, although effective in image classification, usually struggle to generalize against subtle manipulation artifacts, compression noise, and temporal inconsistencies. To address these challenges, a MultiStream Convolutional Neural Network (MS-CNN) framework is proposed for robust deepfake detection. Initially, utilizes the FaceForensics++ dataset which is a widely recognized benchmark containing authentic and manipulated facial videos. Preprocessing incorporates face detection, alignment, and the generation of complementary modalities, which include frequency-domain representations, residual noise maps, and temporal signals, such as rPPG and optical flow. These multimodal inputs were passed through parallel CNN streams for feature extraction to capture spatial, spectral, and temporal inconsistencies. The extracted features are combined using an attention-based adaptive fusion mechanism that dynamically learns the relative importance of each modality. Finally, a fully connected softmax classifier produces end-to-end predictions that differentiate between real and fake videos. The experimental results show that the MS-CNN obtains higher accuracy (99.77 %), precision (98.95 %), recall (98.45 %), and F1score (98.76 %) when compared with the existing CNN model, which improves detection robustness and generalization in different manipulation techniques.

title: Secure Vehicular Ad-Hoc Networks Using Directed Acyclic Graph–Based Sharded Blockchain with Edge-Assisted Consensus
authors: Subhra Chakraborty, Saef Thallal, G. Srinivasalu, Uma. S, K. Sangeetha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Recently, Vehicular Ad-Hoc Networks (VANETs) have emerged as crucial enablers of intelligent transportation systems to allow secure communication among vehicles and roadside infrastructure. However, conventional VANETs face challenges such as scalability and vulnerability to secure attacks because of their dynamic and distributed nature; thus, blockchain-based schemes improve trust and data integrity, while edge computing reduces latency. However, existing models suffer from heavy consensus overheads and lack strong decentralized security. Hence, this study proposes a directed acyclic graph-based shared blockchain with edge-assisted consensus (DAG-SBEC) to ensure secure and real-time communication in large-scale VANET deployments. Initially, Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC) was employed to ensure lightweight key management and secure credentials. Then, blockchain sharding with a beacon chain distributes the data and reduces the consensus overhead. Furthermore, the DAG ledger combined with HotStuff consensus allows for rapid and scalable transaction confirmation. Subsequently, edge computing at roadside units (RSUs) provides low-latency verification of vehicle messages. Finally, smart contracts with threshold disclosure handle revocation and accountability. The results show that the proposed DAG-SBEC outperformed the existing Federated Q-learning with secured Blockchain-aided Elliptic Cryptography (FQL-BEC) in terms of average latency (790.572 ms) and consensus delay (48 ms) respectively.

title: Research on the Application of Visual Monitoring Intelligent Vehicle in the Field of Helping the Elderly
authors: Yufan Liu, Shengyu Chen, Mengyu Yang, Yuxiang Ye, Yukang Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: With the continuous expansion of the aging population in China, the elderly, as a vulnerable group in society, are very prone to other accidents such as falls when living alone. Therefore, the issue of old-age care has become a hot topic of social concern. How to ensure the safety of the elderly has aroused the attention of all walks of life and has become an urgent problem to be solved by society. In response to this problem, we use modern technology to create a visual monitoring smart car, using visual detection, intelligent tracking, voice interaction and other technologies to achieve the monitoring of the elderly to ensure their daily life safety.

title: Performance Analysis for Optimized ALU Design Using Carry Select Adder and Vedic Multiplier
authors: Sandeep Dhariwal, S Dileep Kumar, Rajesh S, Rahul P Kalal
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: This research article presents the performance analysis of novel ALU design with incorporated optimized arithmetic circuits. Carry Select Adder (CSLA) and Vedic Multiplier (VM) circuits have been selected for their excellent performances in arithmetic operations. Vedic Multiplier is totally based on ancient Indian mathematics and CSLA is included for its fast addition operations. Vedic Multiplier design offers high speed computation with less complexity and low power consumption. Schematics have been extracted through Vivado design suit. Performance parameters have been observed with CADENCE tool for proposed ALU having efficient CSLA and VM designs. Synthesis has been carried out using Genus and physical design GDSII has been generated through Innvous system in CADENCE tool for all the considered designs in this research article. All these results exhibit the role of proposed ALU for lower delay and low power computation. Further, it can also be considered for power efficient processor architectures.

title: DINov3-UNet: A Pretrained Vision Transformer Enhanced U-Net for Surface Defect Segmentation
authors: Tongjun Xue, Zhenqian He, Guanwei Wei
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: Surface defect segmentation has become a critical component of automated quality inspection in modern Industry 4.0. Conventional convolutional networks capture local features but fail to model long-range dependencies, while Transformerbased models require large-scale annotated datasets and incur high computational costs. In this work, a hybrid architecture, DINOv3-UNet, is proposed by combining a pretrained DINOv3 encoder with a lightweight UNet decoder. The encoder provides semantically rich visual representations through self-supervised training, whereas the decoder reconstructs fine-grained boundaries via multi-scale fusion. Extensive experiments clearly demonstrate that DINOv3-UNet establishes a new state of the art, consistently surpassing CNN and Transformer baselines on surface defect segmentation.

title: Research and Design of Human-Robot Collaborative Riveting Workstation for Aircraft Intake Ducts
authors: Yaling Tian, Ji Li, Shiyang Gong, Li Jiang, Kexu Yang, Junjie Dan, Yaohui Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: Riveting is one of the core processes in aircraft assembly. human-robot collaborative riveting, by integrating human flexibility with the high-precision characteristics of robots, has become an important development direction for intelligent assembly. This study constructed a digital twin system for the human-robot collaborative riveting workstation of aircraft based on the Robot Studio platform, innovatively completing:1) Modular workstation layout design; 2) Adaptation transformation of mechanical equipment for riveting processes; 3) Multimodal control logic architecture based on SMART components; 4) Simulation verification for dynamic collaborative operation; 5) The reliability of riveting quality has been validated through ANSYS simulation and human-machine collaborative experimentation. This digital twin system provides a reusable technical solution for the aviation assembly field, breaking through the balance problem between precision and flexibility in human-robot collaboration and filling the domestic gap in the efficiency of flexible assembly processes.

title: Operation of IGBT Based Active Rectifier Applied to PEM Electrolyzer During Phase Loss
authors: João G. L. Foster, Robson B. Gonzatti, Rondineli R. Pereira, Marcelo G. Siqueira, Victor B. Riboldi, Erik L. Bonaldi, Luiz E. B. da Silva, Yulun Ren, Zhang Ren
abstract: Due to the high investment involved in a hydrogen generation plant installation, it is necessary to ensure its continuous operation. To increase the resilience, robustness and reliability of the plant, this work proposes the application of a rectifier with IGBTs for use in PEM electrolyzers with the capacity to operate even during the loss of one of the phases of the rectifier supply. In this situation, the equipment operates with reduced power, however it is possible to maintain hydrogen production, thus minimizing losses related to the total shut-down of the operation during an event in the network or during scheduled maintenance on circuits of one of the phases of the plant. Also, by avoiding the unexpected shut-down in the voltage supply to the electrolyzer, the proposed method reduces the risk of the electrolyzer stack being damaged in the case of a phase loss. This work presents the development of the proposed method, as well as simulation results demonstrating the equipment operation in both three-phase and two-phase situations.

title: Optimizing Translation Quality Using Cognitive English Machine Translation System Based on Transformer Architectures
authors: Chaoqun Bu, Mi Zhong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: English language is considered to be globally acclaimed language which act as an effective tool for promoting the best education to all sects of the people in the globe. As the cultural heritages are more in the other languages, it is essential to explore and investigate its richness that can add more insights in inidvidual's life. Neural Machine Translation (NMT) is considered as a hybrid combination of Artificial Intelligence(AI), especially natural language processing. The main purpose of NMT is to convert text from one language to another, enhancing both comprehension and shared learning. However, translating the morphological language to English remains significant bottleneck for achieving the high translation accuracy and fluency. In this regard, this research paper proposes the novel transformer-based approach incorporating the pipelined M2M-100 model that aims to enhance the translation quality from the different languages by incorporating information from other modalitiesThe proposed framework is trained with the user defined corpuses of words from the Multi30K-datasets The efficiency of the proposed model is analysed by measuring the metrics including Bilingual Evaluation Understudy (BLEU), character-level F-score (chrF) and Word Error Rate (WER). To prove the excellence of the proposed framework, extensive comparison between the proposed and existing architectures is compared and its performance metrics are analysed. Experimental findings demonstrate that the proposed architecture has attained average of BLEU score of 0.90 for converting the English to resource deficient Japnese languages The proposed network has shown the new paradigm in education system for the students to explore the significance of the other languages that improves the mental status of next younger generation.

title: Content-Based Cyberbullying Detection on Facebook Using Support Vector Machine and Feature Selection
authors: Siti Rahayu Selamat, Randi Rizal, Irfan Darmawan, J. Shanggeetha, Nurhashikin Mohd Salleh, Alam Rahmatulloh
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: Social media platforms like WhatsApp, Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter have made it easier for people to communicate effectively and frequently. Even though these social media platforms have many advantages, they have also led to cyberbullying, which regularly happens when utilizing these networks. Statistics reported that 75% of online cyberbullying occurrences occurred on Facebook, compared to 24% on Twitter and Instagram combined. However, the existing cyberbullying detection accuracy rate is still low due to the feature selection and classification techniques used. Against this backdrop, this research is aimed at analyzing cyberbullying behavior, identifying machine learning algorithms for detecting cyberbullying on Facebook, and testing the machine learning algorithms for detecting cyberbullying on Facebook with higher accuracy. The result of the study indicates that the cyberbullying detection on Facebook using the RBF kernel SVM and consideration of the five selected elements of detection features upper-case character count, personal pronoun count, profanity count, exclamation mark count, and word count has achieved an accuracy of 93%. In the future, other detection techniques and algorithms and other elements of detection features can be used to improve the model’s performance.

title: Fabrication and experimental evaluation of bendable copper flat-plate oscillating heat pipes
authors: Ishan Tandon, Qian Qian, Zekun Wu, Ahmad Rosmahidi, Justin A. Weibel, Liang Pan
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Recent technological advancements in the packaging and integration of electronics in compact systems have introduced a growing demand for efficient and thin heat spreading devices. For various applications, it would be further beneficial to have passive heat spreaders that are also bendable during assembly or end use. Traditional wick-based heat pipes are susceptible to performance degradation under bending due to their sensitive internal wick structures. Oscillating heat pipes (OHPs) are a wickless alternative, leveraging oscillating plug flows within simple channels or tubes, thereby offering a promising solution for bending-tolerant passive two-phase heat spreading. This work introduces the fabrication and testing of a submillimeter thick copper OHP device that maintains functionality under bending. The device is fabricated using an etching process that yields $\sim 250-300 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ deep and $1000 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ wide channels on a 500 $\mu \mathrm{m}$ thick copper substrate, masked with photoresist, using ferric chloride (FeCl<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>) etchant. Sealing is achieved through thermocompression bonding with a $127 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ thick copper top plate and an intermediate electroplated tin layer. The vacuum-holding capability of the OHP is validated under both flat and bent conditions, demonstrating the structural integrity. Thermal performance tests in horizontal and vertical (gravity assisted with bottom heating) orientations demonstrate effective thermal resistance reduction compared to baseline uncharged copper channels. These results demonstrate significant progress toward bendable copper OHPs that could offer adaptable thermal solutions in next-generation compact electronic systems.

title: Load Balancing with a Hybrid Genetic Algorithm in Cloud Computing
authors: Yogasambhuta Dash, Rabindra Kumar Dalei, Kasturi Dhal
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: Cloud Computing provides a platform for the clients to share resources collectively using on demand services. It is essential for a cloud computing platform to efficiently allocate tasks among several virtual machines (VMs) to optimize its performance. Load balancing is an emerging research trend in the field of cloud computing. This work critically investigates various existing load balancing models and establishes that there is scope to improve the execution time of the model without compromising quality of service (QoS). To overcome this, we propose a hybrid load balancing framework that integrates the Genetic Algorithm (GA) and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). The experimental result establishes the proposed model outperforms the existing model. The proposed model achieves better resource allocation, reduces make span, improves execution cost and overall workflow.

title: Mirror-Assisted Three Dimensional Reconstruction in the Space-Constrained Environment of a Japanese Tearoom
authors: Natsuki Hamanishi, Jun Rekimoto
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Multi-camera 3D capture is often challenging in environments with strict spatial and aesthetic constraints. We present a pipeline that leverages planar mirrors to generate dense 3D reconstructions from a single RGB video stream. Our method partitions the video into direct and reflected views using a semi-automatic tool, guided by an optional simulation step. These generated views provide the multi-view input required by modern self-calibrating reconstruction algorithms. This approach not only resolves severe occlusions but also circumvents the need for fragile pre-calibration, making the system robust against physical disturbances. A preliminary evaluation demonstrates the ability to reconstruct the appearance of occluded regions. This cost-effective and minimally invasive approach opens new possibilities for easy-to-deploy HCI applications.

title: Steady-State Temperature Prediction Based on Compact Thermal Models Using Machine Learning
authors: Mohammadamin Hajikhodaverdian, Sherief Reda, Ayse K. Coskun
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: With the scaling up of transistor densities, the thermal management of integrated circuits (IC) in 3D designs is becoming challenging. Conventional simulation methods, such as finite element methods, are accurate but computationally expensive. Compact thermal models (CTMs) provide an effective alternative and produce accurate thermal simulations using numerical solvers. Recent work has also designed machine learning (ML) models for predicting thermal maps. However, most of these ML models are limited by the need for a large dataset to train and a long training time for large chip designs. To overcome these challenges, we present a novel ML framework that integrates with CTMs to accelerate thermal simulations without the need for large datasets. We introduce a methodology that effectively combines the accuracy of CTMs with the efficiency of ML using a physically informed linear regression model based on the thermal conduction equation. We further introduce a window-based model reduction technique for scalability across a range of grid sizes and system architectures by reducing computational overhead without sacrificing accuracy. Unlike most of the existing ML methods for temperature prediction, our model adapts to changes in floorplans and architectures with minimum retraining. Experimental results show that our method achieves up to $70 \times$ speedup over the state-of-the-art thermal simulators and enables real-time, high-resolution thermal simulations on different IC designs from 2D to 3D.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup><sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>This research was partially funded by the NSF CCF 2131127 grant

title: SiC Devices in Power Converters: Gate Drive Circuit and Losses Estimation
authors: João José Ferreira Evangelista Filho, Gabriela Torllone de Carvalho Ferreira, Kristian Pessoa dos Santose, Robson Mayer, José Antenor Pomilio
abstract: This study investigates the use of wide-bandgap (WBG) semiconductors, with a focus on Silicon Carbide (SiC), in power systems for all-electric aircraft (AEA), addressing gate driver performance concerning thermal efficiency and electromagnetic compatibility (EMI). While Gallium Nitride (GaN) and SiC devices outperform traditional silicon transistors, they present challenges related to parasitic-induced resonances during fast switching. Simulations and experiments highlight the impact of these parasitics, the importance of accurate modeling, and how gate resistance (Rg) affects power dissipation and system stability. Simulations of a half-bridge converter revealed that increasing Rg from 3Ω to 30Ω significantly reduced voltage oscillations and spikes, but increased the switching energy dissipation for the low-side (LS) transistor by five times. Strong oscillations, particularly at 24 MHz, were intensified by diode reverse recovery. Experimental comparisons between Si and SiC MOSFETs demonstrated that SiC devices exhibit significantly lower losses and superior thermal performance. Furthermore, current measurement methods, such as using a Hall-effect probe with a series wire, introduced additional parasitic inductances that compromised power estimation accuracy and caused oscillations, even with increased Rg. An increase in gate resistance to 30Ω doubled the power dissipation, affecting thermal stability under non-Zero Voltage Switching (non-ZVS) conditions. Minimizing parasitic inductance and increasing gate resistance were effective in mitigating oscillations

title: Unknown Input Observer Applied to a Single-Phase Grid-Connected VSI Using LCL Filter with Only Grid Current Measurement
authors: Gustavo Miranda Auler, Gabriel Azevedo Fogli
abstract: This paper presents a single-phase grid-connected voltage source inverter with an LCL filter, employing a reduced number of sensors. Only the grid current is measured, while the remaining state variables are estimated using an observer. The control law is based on state feedback, and an Unknown Input Observer is adopted to ensure robustness against disturbances, allowing the observed states to account for their effects. Even the main voltage can be estimated solely from the grid current sensor. Due to the presence of poles with purely imaginary components, some states of the plant are only detectable and not observable. Therefore, a discussion on how to address this condition using the state observer is proposed. Discussions on the necessary conditions for the observer implementation, along with its design criteria integrated with the control loop, are provided. Results based on hardware-in-the-loop platform is carried out to verify the proposed approach.

title: HE-SecureNet: An Efficient and Usable Framework for Model Training via Homomorphic Encryption
authors: Thomas Schneider, Huan-Chih Wang, Hossein Yalame
publish: Proceedings of the 24th Workshop on Privacy in the Electronic Society
abstract: Energy-efficient edge devices are essential for the widespread deployment of machine learning (ML) services. However, their limited computational capabilities make local model training infeasible. While cloud-based training offers a scalable alternative, it raises serious privacy concerns when sensitive data is outsourced. Homomorphic Encryption (HE) enables computation directly on encrypted data and has emerged as a promising solution to this privacy challenge. Yet, current HE-based training frameworks face several shortcomings: they often lack support for complex models and non-linear functions, struggle to train over multiple epochs, and require cryptographic expertise from end users.

title: Distilling Object Detectors with Scale-Conscious Knowledge in Remote Sensing Images
authors: Ruiqing Wang, Yang Xu, Zebin Wu, Zhihui Wei
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Knowledge distillation provides an effective paradigm for developing lightweight remote sensing object detectors. However, existing methods predominantly concentrate on design of foreground feature masks while neglecting the suppression of small-scale targets by dominant large-scale counterparts in cluttered backgrounds during the distillation, which severely degrades detection robustness. To address this, we propose scale-conscious knowledge distillation. Multi-scale feature distillation in this framework decouples the coupled feature in conventional methods into hierarchical multi-scale representation spaces, enabling the student model to capture cross-granularity features from micro-details to macro-structures through differentiated receptive fields. Scale-adaptive output distillation innovatively introduces a dynamic weighting mechanism based on the normalized object area, effectively alleviating the gradient vanishing issue for small objects. Experimental results show that our method consistently improves the performance of student models with different architectures on both the DOTA and DIOR datasets. Source codes are available at https://github.com/RQ-W/SCD.git.

title: Hyperspectral Imaging and Machine Learning for Non-Destructive Phenolic Compounds Measurement in Peat Toward Smart Whisky Manufacturing
authors: Yijun Yan, Jinchang Ren, Barry Harrison, Oliver Lewis, Emanuele Trucco, Guofang Wang, Yi Ma, Yutang Ma
abstract: The whisky industry heavily relies on peat as a key ingredient to impart distinctive smoky flavors to the final product. However, traditional methods for analyzing peat composition and quality are time-consuming and destructive, requiring extensive sample preparation. To address these challenges, we propose a novel nondestructive system for rapid and accurate peat analysis combining push-broom hyperspectral imaging (HSI), singular spectrum analysis (SSA), and machine learning. We introduce a faster SSA variant (SSA++) to overcome the high computational complexity of traditional SSA, enabling real-time processing of HSI data when captured in the push-broom manner. Comprehensive experiments have demonstrated the effectiveness of the proposed system, achieving a total phenol estimation of up to 99.31% R2. SSA++ maintains similar accuracy to SSA while significantly reducing computational time, enabling real-time performance. Our system offers a powerful tool for automated peat analysis, facilitating smart manufacturing and enhanced quality monitoring in the whisky industry.

title: A Reverse Auction-Driven Fog Resource Allocation Strategy for DDoSMitigation in Smart Grids
authors: Jun Chen, Xin Sun, Wen Tian, Miao Du, Xiaoming He, Guangjie Liu
abstract: Advanced metering infrastructure in smart grids faces critical security challenges from distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks, while traditional traceback methods suffer from resource constraints that limit their mitigation effectiveness. To address this, we propose a reverse auction-driven fog resource allocation strategy that innovatively employs a reverse auction mechanism to coordinate distributed fog resources for collaborative DDoS attack mitigation. Specifically, the framework is formulated as a 0–1 integer programming model, for which we develop a second-price sealed-bid auction (SPSA) algorithm that reduces computational complexity from factorial to polynomial time while maintaining allocation optimality. Experimental results demonstrate that the SPSA algorithm outperforms existing baseline methods, significantly improving both the efficiency and security of DDoS defenses in smart grid environments.

title: Unraveling Urban Mobility: A Domain Knowledge-Free Trajectory Classification Using Gramian Angular Fields
authors: Gabriel O. Ferreira, Fabrizio Dabbene, Francesco Malandrino, Chiara Ravazzi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: The diffusion of GPS-equipped devices has resulted in the generation of vast amounts of spatio-temporal data. This data represents a fundamental resource to conduct analysis on transportation networks. It is therefore of great interest to identify models capable of distinguishing and classifying trajectories to facilitate decision-making processes, congestion prediction and emissions monitoring. However, many existing algorithms necessitate a complex feature engineering process and domain knowledge. In this context, this work proposes a neural network-based approach, which eliminates the need for complicated hand-crafted features, using Gramian angular fields and leveraging possibly pre-trained convolutional neural networks. Therefore, we combine these tools to tackle the challenge of multiclass trajectory classification. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method on an imbalanced dataset simulated with SUMO by classifying different means of transportation–private car, taxi, bus, pedestrian, motorcycle, bicycle–achieving good results in terms of accuracy and F1 score.

title: Real-time Dynamic Gesture Recognition Based on Ultrasound : for Human-Robot Interaction
authors: Chengming Tian, Qingying He, Fangyu Shen, Hao Sun
abstract: In human-computer interaction based on gesture recognition, visual schemes are susceptible to interference from light and the background, and wearable sensors restrict hand movement. The aforementioned issues have a restrictive effect on the interaction experience. The present paper proposes an ultrasound-based, real-time, dynamic gesture recognition scheme to address these problems. The extraction of dynamic gesture features is achieved through the utilisation of the channel estimation matrix diagram (CEM-D), while algorithms designed for onset and motion detection ensure the accurate acquisition of features. The classification of gestures is accomplished through the utilization of a RepVGG network, which facilitates the construction of an end-to-end recognition system. On a dataset comprising ten kinds of daily dynamic gestures, the method achieves an accuracy of over 95% in environments with noise levels of 30 dB and 70 dB, and takes an average of 0.0483s for a single recognition, which is 0.00969s faster than the traditional gesture recognition method. The findings indicate that the proposed method exhibits exceptional accuracy, anti-interference capabilities and real-time performance, thus providing a highly efficient solution for human-computer interaction involving dynamic gestures.

title: FedeCouple: Fine-Grained Balancing of Global-Generalization and Local-Adaptability in Federated Learning
authors: Ming Yang, Dongrun Li, Xin Wang, Feng Li, Lisheng Fan, Chunxiao Wang, Xiaoming Wu, Peng Cheng
abstract: In privacy-preserving mobile network transmission scenarios with heterogeneous client data, personalized federated learning methods that decouple feature extractors and classifiers have demonstrated notable advantages in enhancing learning capability.
