However, many existing approaches primarily focus on feature space consistency and classification personalization during local training, often neglecting the local adaptability of the extractor and the global generalization of the classifier. This oversight results in insufficient coordination and weak coupling between the components, ultimately degrading the overall model performance. To address this challenge, we propose FedeCouple, a federated learning method that balances global generalization and local adaptability at a fine-grained level. Our approach jointly learns global and local feature representations while employing dynamic knowledge distillation to enhance the generalization of personalized classifiers. We further introduce anchors to refine the feature space; their strict locality and non-transmission inherently preserve privacy and reduce communication overhead. Furthermore, we provide a theoretical analysis proving that FedeCouple converges for nonconvex objectives, with iterates approaching a stationary point as the number of communication rounds increases. Extensive experiments conducted on five image-classification datasets demonstrate that FedeCouple consistently outperforms nine baseline methods in effectiveness, stability, scalability, and security. Notably, in experiments evaluating effectiveness, FedeCouple surpasses the best baseline by a significant margin of 4.3%.

title: Adaptive Fractional Differencing: Theory and Methodology
authors: Sarit Maitra
abstract: This study presents a theoretical framework for forecasting financial time series that exhibits both non-stationarity and long-range dependence (LRD). Existing fractional differencing (FD) techniques attempt to preserve long-memory properties but suffer from estimation bias, arbitrary truncation of the infinite FD series, and limited compatibility with modern machine learning (ML) workflows. We propose an Adaptive Fractional Differencing (AFD) method introducing three key innovations: (1) a hybrid two-stage estimation procedure combining wavelet-based Hurst exponent analysis with ridge-regularized optimization to yield stable and unbiased estimates of the FD parameter; (2) a data-driven, cross-validation-based truncation strategy replacing heuristic truncation rules by minimizing predictive risk, thereby preserving LRD while bounding approximation error; and (3) a design that supports joint tuning of differencing parameters and forecasting models within ML pipelines, enabling end-to-end optimization in high-dimensional settings. Although empirical testing is left for future work, the theoretical contributions of AFD offer a scalable and principled approach for financial time series modeling. By bridging classical time-series theory with modern ML practices, AFD provides a foundation for developing more accurate and robust forecasting systems in data-rich, complex financial environments.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Based Adaptive Gain Tuning of Terminal Super-Twisting SMC for Lane-Change Control in Autonomous Vehicles
authors: Mohammadreza Maleki, Forough Sadat Razavi, Amir Taghavipour
abstract: This paper presents a reinforcement learning–based adaptive gain tuning strategy for a Terminal Super-Twisting Sliding Mode Controller (TST-SMC) applied to autonomous vehicle lane-change maneuvers. The controller gains are adapted per-maneuver using a Twin-Delayed Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (TD3) algorithm, conditioned on vehicle velocity. The vehicle model, including tire–road interactions, is developed in MATLAB/Simulink-python. Simulation results show that the proposed method reduces lateral position RMSE by up to 28%, yaw RMSE by 20%, and maximum lateral deviation by 33% compared with fixed-gain TST-SMC, while lowering steering effort by about 6-10% across the tested velocity range. These improvements demonstrate that reinforcement learning–based adaptation enhances the robustness and efficiency of sliding mode control under diverse operating conditions.

title: Massive MIMO-OFDM Channel Acquisition with Multi-group Adjustable Phase Shift Pilots
authors: Yu Zhao, Li You, Jinke Tang, Mengyu Qian, Bin Jiang, Xiang-Gen Xia, Xiqi Gao
abstract: Massive multiple-input multiple-output - orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (MIMO-OFDM) systems face the challenge of high channel acquisition overhead while providing significant spectral efficiency (SE). Adjustable phase shift pilots (APSPs) are an effective technique to acquire channels with low overhead by exploiting channel sparsity. In this paper, we extend it to multiple groups and propose multi-group adjustable phase shift pilots (MAPSPs) to improve SE further. We first introduce a massive MIMO-OFDM system model and transform the conventional channel model in the space-frequency domain to the angle-delay domain, obtaining a sparse channel matrix. Then, we propose a method of generating MAPSPs through multiple basic sequences and investigate channel estimation processes. By analyzing the components of pilot interference, we elucidate the underlying mechanism by which interference affects MMSE estimation. Building upon this foundation, we demonstrate the benefit of phase scheduling in MAPSP channel estimation and establish the optimal design condition tailored for scheduling. Furthermore, we propose an implementation scheme based on Zadoff-Chu sequences that includes received signal pre-processing and pilot scheduling methods to mitigate pilot interference. Simulation results indicate that the MAPSP method achieves a lower mean square error (MSE) of estimation than APSP and significantly enhances SE in mobility scenarios.

title: A Hierarchically Adaptive PWM Strategy for Mitigation of Neutral-Point Voltage Oscillation and Circulating Current in Parallel 3L-Inverter-Fed FESS Drives
authors: Xudong Zhang, Qinghu Zhang, Xiaoqin Zheng, Siwei Cheng, Chong Zhang, Chun Gan
abstract: Parallel interleaved three-level (3L) inverters (PITIs) fed flywheel energy storage systems (FESSs) enable efficient energy conversion for high-power applications. However, PITIs suffer from neutral-point voltage oscillation (NPVO), zero-sequence circulating currents (ZSCCs), and common-mode voltage (CMV), which degrade harmonic quality and interfere with the FESS magnetic bearing control. To solve these issues and enhance output quality, this article proposes a hierarchically adaptive modulation strategy. In the first stage, a selection criterion is established within the integrated five-level (5L) plane to determine small vector combinations with low CMV and ZSCC slope. In the second stage, while maintaining an interleaved vector sequence, the dwell times of the selected vector combinations are optimized based on the neutral-point current behavior in the present switching cycle, achieving simultaneous mitigation of NPVO, ZSCC, and CMV. In the third stage, the residual imbalances of NPVO and ZSCC from the previous cycle are considered. By refining vector dwell times in the present cycle, an overcompensation strategy is introduced, enhancing the adaptability of the proposed strategy to dynamic and unbalanced operations. Finally, comparative experiments on a 300-kW PITI-fed FESS drive validate the effectiveness of the proposed strategy in simultaneously suppressing NPVO, ZSCC, and CMV.

title: DehazeMamba: SAR-guided Optical Remote Sensing Image Dehazing with Adaptive State Space Model
authors: Zhicheng Zhao, Jinquan Yan, Chenglong Li, Xiao Wang, Penghui Jiang, Jin Tang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Optical remote sensing image dehazing presents significant challenges due to its extensive spatial scale and highly non-uniform haze distribution, which traditional single-image dehazing methods struggle to address effectively. While Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) imagery offers inherently haze-free reference information for large-scale scenes, existing SAR-guided dehazing approaches face two critical limitations: the integration of SAR information often diminishes the quality of haze-free regions, and the instability of feature quality further exacerbates cross-modal domain shift. To overcome these challenges, we introduce DehazeMamba, a novel SAR-guided dehazing network built on a progressive haze decoupling fusion strategy. Our approach incorporates two key innovations: a Haze Perception and Decoupling Module (HPDM) that dynamically identifies haze-affected regions through SAR-optical difference analysis, and a Progressive Fusion Module (PFM) that mitigates domain shift through a two-stage fusion process based on feature quality assessment. To facilitate research in this domain, we present MRSHaze, a large-scale benchmark dataset comprising 8,000 pairs of temporally synchronized, precisely geo-registered SAR-optical images with high resolution and diverse haze conditions. Extensive experiments demonstrate that DehazeMamba significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 0.73 dB improvement in PSNR and substantial enhancements in downstream tasks such as semantic segmentation.

title: Enhancing Mobility in Smart Cities: People Counting and Characteristics Detection in Public Buses
authors: Beibut Amirgaliyev, Miras Mussabek, Ainur Zhumadillayeva, Zharasbek Baishemirov
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: Detecting passengers and tracking them in public transport is a crucial task in the reality of Smart City(SC) environment. This task combines with additional calculations like passenger counting and utilizes technologies in Computer Vision(CV) field. We explore and evaluate FairMOT hybrid model for passenger counting. It is a state-of-the-art multi-object tracking system that integrates detection and Re-Identification(re-ID) within a single network. This model was trained on 180 videos with a total of 70,710 frames of open source videos containing passenger flow in public buses. Evaluation on different videos showed maximum Recall(97.9%) and MOTA(82.5%) scores. Also moderate IDF1(73.6%) scores. It shows great tracking accuracy and introduces a computationally efficient framework, offering transit operators a scalable and effective solution to optimize passenger flow analysis in SC environment.

title: Physics-Driven Learning for Two-Phase Heat Transfer
authors: Haeun Lee, Hyoungsoon Lee
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Two-phase heat transfer, including condensation and boiling, is critical in applications such as energy systems, electronics cooling, and thermal management. However, accurately modeling these processes remains challenging due to their complex, nonlinear interactions. This study employs physicsinformed machine learning (PIML) to enhance predictive accuracy and generalizability. For condensation, a novel degradation Nusselt model integrated with a PIML framework significantly improved extrapolation accuracy, reducing the mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) from 21.63% (purely datadriven models) to $\mathbf{1 1. 2 2 \%}$. For boiling, critical heat flux (CHF) predictions were refined by incorporating mechanistic insights and tree-based models, reducing MAPE from $20.41 \%$ to $12.7 \%$ in extrapolation scenarios. This work bridges data-driven modeling with physics-based constraints, ensuring predictions align with fundamental heat transfer principles. The findings establish a robust framework for next-generation thermal management systems, with opportunities for future research to expand datasets and integrate additional physical constraints for broader applicability.

title: Generalized Category Discovery in Hyperspectral Images Via Prototype Subspace Modeling
authors: Xianlu Li, Nicolas Nadisic, Shaoguang Huang, Aleksandra Pižurica
publish: 2025 13th European Workshop on Visual Information Processing (EUVIP)
abstract: Generalized category discovery (GCD) seeks to jointly identify both known and novel categories in unlabeled data. While prior works have mainly focused on RGB images, their assumptions and modeling strategies do not generalize well to hyperspectral images (HSI), which are inherently highdimensional and exhibit complex spectral structures. In this paper, we propose the first GCD framework tailored for HSI, introducing a prototype subspace modeling model to better capture class structure. Instead of learning a single prototype vector for each category as in existing methods such as SimGCD, we model each category using a set of basis vectors, forming a subspace representation that enables greater expressiveness and discrimination in a high-dimensional feature space. To guide the learning of such bases, we enforce two key constraints: (1) a basis orthogonality constraint that promotes inter-class separability, and (2) a reconstruction constraint that ensures each prototype basis can effectively reconstruct its corresponding class samples. Experimental results on real-world HSI demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms state-of-the-art GCD methods, establishing a strong foundation for generalized category discovery in hyperspectral settings.

title: Intelligent Adaptive Digital Twin-Based Early Warning System for Construction
authors: Yufei Jiang, Xin Xu, Yue Tong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Nowadays, efficient monitoring of building machine jacking operations is crucial for ensuring the construction safety and operational reliability. However, the existing static Digital Twin (DT) models struggled to adapt to dynamic construction environments which led to limit their effectiveness in detecting potential risks in real-time. Hence, this research proposes an Intelligent Adaptive DT-based Early Warning System (IADT-EWS) which integrates real-time IoT sensor data with predictive modeling to provide continuous monitoring, early warning and decision support. Initially, the data acquisition and integration are performed by using Internet of Thing (IoT) sensors to collect multi-source operational and environmental parameters. Then, the data is preprocessed with median filter for noise removal, linear interpolation for missing value imputation and min-max normalization to scale features respectively. Moreover, the Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is employed for feature extraction to reduce the dimensionality and then, an ADT model is employed by using Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks to dynamically predict operational states. Finally, the statistical anomaly detection generates early warnings and an interactive dashboard provides decision support with real-time alerts and risk visualization for ensuring safe jacking operations. The proposed IADT-EWS achieved better results in terms of accuracy (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 5. 3 2 \%}$</tex>) than existing Mutual Information and Multilayer Perceptron (MI-MLP) model.

title: Neurological Insights into Interactive VR Learning: An EEG-Based Comparative Study
authors: Abhijit Patil, Himangshu Sarma, Annushree Bablani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: This work is about exploring the role of VR in STEM education backed by EEG. We present a Virtual Reality (VR) application designed to enhance STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) education, specifically in teaching Alternating Current (AC) theory. The VR tool allows students to actively engage with 3D simulations of fundamental AC concepts, with integrated quizzes to assess comprehension. A case study is conducted to compare the effectiveness of VR-based learning against traditional textbook methods. The study also utilized EEG (Electroencephalogram) headsets to monitor cognitive load and student engagement, offering insights into the mental effort and focus involved. Statistical analysis revealed significant educational advantages for the VR group. This also gave us an insight into the use of VR with EEG headset. These findings demonstrate the potential of VR technology to improve understanding and engagement in STEM education and inform future teaching strategies.

title: Passivity-Based Stability Analysis Using a Type-III Controller for LCL-Filtered Grid-Connected Inverter
authors: José de Arimatéia O. Filho, Paulo Fernando Silva, Augusto M. S. Alonso, Luis de Oro Arenas, Tiago Davi Curi Busarello, Helmo Kelis Morales Paredes
abstract: This paper introduces a novel passivity-based approach that enhances the external stability of LCL-filtered grid-connected inverters by leveraging the phase-leading characteristics of a Type-III controller. Although effective at attenuating harmonics, such filters introduce stability challenges due to their inherent resonance peak. A passivitybased stability analysis technique is employed, allowing the assessment of system stability through the output impedance characteristics of the inverters. A hybrid strategy is proposed to ensure robustness against grid impedance variations, combining a Type-III controller and an active damping branch based on virtual impedance. With its phase lead characteristic, the TypeIII controller improves the output impedance shaping and extend the passivity region, thereby ensuring the stability of inverter operation. Simulation results obtained in PSIM ® under different conditions confirm the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Smart Deboning: Conceptual Framework for Automating Boneless Milkfish Production
authors: Mark Oliver A. Tabayoyong
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: Milkfish (Chanos chanos) is widely consumed in the Philippines, especially in its deboned form. However, its numerous small bones limit marketability and make the deboning process labor-intensive and reliant on skilled workers. Despite increasing demand, no advanced technology has been developed to automate this process. This study presents a conceptual design for a CNC-based automated deboning system. The approach involves mapping the anatomical spine structure—grouped into dorsal, rib, ventral, and lateral sections—to generate a precise toolpath for deboning. A reference system based on fixed anatomical points is introduced to accommodate fish sizes ranging from 400 to 600 grams. This conceptual framework addresses key challenges in traditional deboning, such as labor shortages and inconsistent output, and lays the groundwork for technological innovation in milkfish processing. The proposed system can potentially improve productivity, ensure better product quality, and support the expanding market for boneless milkfish.

title: Thermal & Electrical Performance Characterization of Power Modules in Single-Phase Liquid Immersion Cooling Environments
authors: Rohit Kumar Suthar, Amit Kumar, Akshay Lakshminayana, Vishal Talari, Dereje Agonafer, Karthekeyan Sridhar, Rajen Murugan, Lalith Karsani, Osvaldo Lopez, Nicolas Forcade-Perkins
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: The data center industry is rapidly evolving with the development of advanced cooling technologies to accommodate increasing compute power densities. Air-cooling systems are nearing their limitations and are no longer sufficient to manage the high thermal design power (TDP) demands of modern applications such as artificial intelligence, neural networks, parallel processing, and high-performance computing. Single-phase liquid immersion cooling (SPLIC) has emerged as a promising solution, where entire servers are immersed in tanks filled with cooling fluid, allowing direct contact between all server components and the fluid for efficient heat dissipation. This approach necessitates a thorough assessment of material compatibility and the performance of system components in the immersion environment. This study investigates the impact of immersion fluids on the electrical, thermal and reliability performance of the power components in data center IT systems, specifically focusing on power modules. These power modules are essential components in servers to convert intermediate bus voltage (IBV) to regulated core point of load (POL) voltages requiring minimal conversion loss and fast transient response. It is therefore critical to ensure that power modules perform according to their design specifications under immersion cooling conditions. The study evaluates the performance of power modules with two varied package designs, in three different single-phase immersion fluids, each with distinct properties such as density, thermal conductivity, and specific heat capacity. The testing involved running the devices at a constant output load, starting at 10 A and increasing by 10 A increments up to 40 A, with each test lasting one hour. During each run, critical performance parameters such as junction temperature, input current, and output voltage were monitored. The devices were first benchmarked in air-cooled environment at room temperature and $\mathbf{4 5}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}} \mathbf{C}$. In-situ testing was subsequently conducted with the devices immersed in all three fluids at $45^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Parametric data collected from the benchmarks and insitu tests were compared to characterize the performance and efficiency of the power modules in the immersion environment. Further, devices were also subjected to thermal aging at $80^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ for 336 hours in each immersion fluid, following the Open Compute Project (OCP) guidelines. Post thermal aging, tests were conducted in air cooled environment at room temperature. The results were compared with the initial benchmark results to assess the long-term impact of immersion fluids on the performance and efficiency of the power modules. The notable findings of this study highlights that the devices demonstrated improved thermal performance at higher power while maintaining consistent efficiency during in-situ testing, compared to the benchmarking results at $\mathbf{4 5}^{\circ} \mathbf{C}$. Furthermore, the long-term fluid impact assessment revealed that after prolonged exposure to more extreme conditions, the devices continued to exhibit comparable thermal performance without any reduction in efficiency across all output load levels.

title: Design and Application of a Smart Sports Training Assistant System Based on Reservoir Learning Algorithms
authors: Jinmao Tong, Huang Fugui, Qiuping He
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The growing integration of AI technology in sports has transformed the way athletes train and monitor performance, yet traditional training systems often lack personalization and real-time adaptability. Common challenges include inaccurate performance tracking, limited feedback mechanisms, and inefficiency in processing large-scale physiological and motion data. To address these issues, this study proposes a Smart Sports Training Assistant System based on machine learning algorithms. In this context, this research proposes a novel Cognitive Monitoring System using the Sports training activities of the different individuals. The proposed framework consist of five components such as a) Intelligent Data Collection b) Data preparation for an effective training and testing the module c) Reservoir Computing Networks d) Model validation and Evaluation. Extensive experimentation is conducted using IoT (Internet of Things) based Sports activity benchmarks and performance metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score are calculated. The empirical results were analysed and compared with the other existing state-of-the-art detection systems. The experimental outcomes demonstrated the proposed approach has achieved the 1.00 accuracy, precision of 0.99, recall of 0.99 and F1-score of 0.99 respectively The suggested research shows the promising direction for the involving this novel ensemble pervasive monitoring of the sports activities among the individuals.

title: Investigation of Heat Sinks with Hybrid Pin-Fin/Absorber-Fin Arrays Considering Multiphysics Thermal-Acoustic Performance
authors: Ziqi Yu, Taehwa Lee, Ercan M. Dede
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: It is well known that pin-fin arrays can significantly improve the convective heat transfer of air-cooled heat sinks due to a large surface area enhancement from the fins. Such pin-fin heat sink designs serve as a promising solution for addressing a wide range of electronic device thermal management needs in both computing and energy conversion applications. However, air movers (e.g., axial fans or centrifugal pumps) that are used to drive and control air flow typically generate noise that tends to have spectral characteristics with specific resonances in the general range of 100 Hz to 10 kHz. Often it is desirable to attenuate such noise using additional sound absorbers, ducting, or grills. Here, we numerically investigate heat sinks with hybrid pin-fin/absorber-fin array designs subject to air jet impingement that simultaneously address heat transfer and noise attenuation. For the hybrid-fin array, Helmholtz resonators are employed for acoustic absorber fins that are then interleaved with more traditional heat sink pin fins whose phononic characteristics are not often discussed for noise mitigation. Through numerical studies, it is shown that the designed acoustic absorber fins effectively reduce the noise level at target frequencies over an acoustic spectrum that mimics a representative rotating axial fan. We further demonstrate that these frequencies can be changed by varying geometrical parameters of the hybrid pin-fin/absorber-fin array. Regarding heat transfer, thermal-fluid conjugate models are utilized to quantify the performance of a standard pin-fin heat sink versus the hybrid pin-fin/absorber-fin heat sink design. Our findings open new possibilities for further optimizing multifunctional hybrid-fin array-based heat sinks considering both thermal and acoustic performance.

title: Development and Application of Intelligent Insulating oil Operation Device
authors: Xie Fangyi, Lu Zhongqiang, Kong Weili, Ma Xiaofeng, Sun Zhongyi, Li Huijuan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: This study addresses the intelligent management and control requirements during the installation process of oil-immersed main equipment (main transformers, reactors) in ultra-high voltage (UHV) projects through proposing a digital intelligent online monitoring device. This device integrates multiple types of sensors to monitor key quality data in real-time during the installation procedures of oil-immersed main equipment, analyze the installation quality level, and provide a quality basis for process transition. Through pilot applications, the overall performance and functionality of the device meet the on-site quality control requirements.

title: Research on the Improvement Method of Microgrid Optimization Operation Strategy Based on Electric Vehicle Load
authors: Xu Wang, Linzhi Han, Xin Qian
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Micro-grid plays an important role in improving the management efficiency of distributed renewable power and various loads in distribution power grid of new-type power system. Taking into account the efficiency problem of operational strategy caused by system prediction errors of micro-grid, this paper studies the policy improvement method of micro-grid operation strategy with electric vehicle loads. First, the structure of micro-grid with electric vehicle loads is discussed. Then a policy improvement method based on day-ahead optimized operation strategy of the micro-grid is proposed. Finally, simulation experiments are conducted to verify and demonstrate that the proposed policy improvement method can effectively improve the operational efficiency and economy of the micro-grid.

title: Two-Leg AC-DC-AC Converter Cascaded with Half-Bridges for Single-Phase Multilevel PV System Applications
authors: Brenda Mayra Da S. Pereira, Cursino B. Jacobina, Arthur P. Da Costa, Douglas De S. Sesion, Jean T. Cardoso, Reuben Palmer R. De Sousa
abstract: This work proposes a cascaded single-phase multilevel converter based on half-bridges fed by balanced and unbalanced DC sources, such as photovoltaic panels. The configuration consists of a half-bridge AC-DC-AC converter combined with series-connected half-bridge voltage source inverters on the load side, each powered by a photovoltaic (PV) cell connected to its DC-Link. While the half-bridge inverters are responsible for voltage generation, the AC-DC-AC converter provides both shunt and series compensation, mitigating the effects of variable shading conditions and ensuring stable operation. The system model, control strategy, and pulse-width modulation technique are presented. Simulation and experimental results are provided to validate the effectiveness of the proposed configuration.

title: GreenSuite: A Decision-Support Tool for Carbon Footprint Monitoring and Reduction
authors: Arkar Moe, Thu Thu Win, Kyi Sin Le, Aye Chan Mon
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: Reducing carbon emissions by any means is known to be one of many top priorities, considering the fact that the alarming rate of climate change is increasing. Since many companies’ purposes is to provide best service to the customers, more carbon footprint emitted has caused the reputation of such companies’ ecosystem goals. GreenSuite aims how carbon footprint could be reduced by analyzing, making particular goals of one’s company to reduce carbon emission and keeping track of it by building on Spring Boot with MongoDB for data persistence. The result employs Artificial Intelligence assistant with functionalities of suggesting how company’s sustainability should be managed.

title: Year of the Cicadas: Using Sound and Story to Understand Parental Grief
authors: Kimberly Hieftje, Asher M. Marks, Andrew Schartmann
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Year of the Cicadas is a narrative-driven VR experience exploring parental grief following the death of a child. Developed through an autoethnographic framework, it spans a 17-year timeline marked by the cyclical emergence of Brood X cicadas. The experience integrates personal narrative, spatialized sound, digitized artifacts, and original music to create an emotionally immersive environment. Sound functions as the primary storytelling element, guiding reflection and emotional tone. The project will be integrated into a medical training curriculum to support grief education for pediatric fellows and medical students.

title: Efficient Power Estimation and Analysis of Digital Circuits Using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Gurudatt B M, Gokul Krishnan V, H V Ravish Aradhya
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
abstract: Accurate power estimation is essential for optimizing digital circuit design in modern VLSI systems. This study employs machine learning techniques, specifically ridge regression and linear regression models, to predict power consumption based on circuit characteristics. The dataset includes various digital circuits with key parameters such as the number of cells, I/O ports, nets, area, and multiple power metrics, including leakage, internal, net, dynamic switching, and total power. Feature analysis is conducted to identify the most significant contributors to power consumption. The proposed ridge regression-based approach outperforms linear regression by effectively handling multicollinearity and providing more stable predictions. Compared to traditional estimation methods, ridge regression demonstrates high prediction accuracy and computational efficiency, making it a suitable choice for realtime power analysis. The results indicate that machine learning, particularly regularized regression techniques, can significantly enhance power-aware design automation, enabling faster and more efficient optimization of digital circuits. The analysis of power prediction accuracy highlights Ridge Regression, Linear Regression, and CatBoost as the top-performing models, achieving exceptional accuracies of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 9. 9 9 8 8 6 4 \%, 9 9. 9 9 8 7 0 6 \%, ~ a n d ~} \mathbf{9 9. 9 9 3 7 8 9 \%}$</tex>, respectively. These models demonstrate outstanding precision in estimating total power, with Ridge Regression showing the lowest absolute error of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 4 3 7 ~ n W}$</tex>, followed closely by Linear Regression and CatBoost. Such high levels of accuracy confirm their reliability and suitability for power estimation tasks, making them ideal choices for applications demanding precise and dependable predictions.

title: ARIA: Demonstrating Transfer from AR-Based Spatial Audio Training to Speech-in-Noise Performance
authors: Pooseung Koh, Jeongwoo Park, Sungyoung Kim, Inyong Choi, Hyojeong Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We demonstrate ARIA, an iOS augmented reality application that addresses engagement and accessibility limitations of traditional auditory training systems. The app integrates 6-degree-of-freedom spatial audio with gamified auditory localization and speech-in-noise training in users’ real environments. Our feasibility study with 11 normal-hearing adults (age: 53±3 years) showed significant improvements in Korean Matrix Sentence Test (KMST) performance across challenging listening conditions (-6dB: 7.3±4.5%, p=0.001; -9dB: 10.5±8.0%, p=0.004). Training duration demonstrated dose-response effects, with correlations between engagement time, in-game localization improvements, and transfer to standardized assessments at -6/-9dB where real-world benefits are most critical

title: An Improved Real Time Child Tracking Device using ESP32S3
authors: Sajal Sarkar, Sayantan Koley, Ankita Sinha, Supriya Dhabal, Palaniandavar Venkateswaran, Saikat Chandra Bakshi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: The safety and security of children are paramount concerns for parents and guardians, particularly in environments prone to high activity, large crowds, or limited supervision. This paper introduces a comprehensive Real-Time Child Tracking Device aimed at providing a reliable solution to monitor children’s movements and ensure their safety. The system is designed with three primary components: the Child Device, the Parent Device, and the Home Device. The Child Device is a lightweight, wearable unit featuring an ESP32S3 microcontroller-based platform, integrated GPS for real-time location tracking, and LoRa for long-range communication. The Parent Device, equipped with ESP32S3, GPS, a compass for directional guidance, a LoRa transceiver, and a display, serves as a portable tracking hub for parents. The Home Device, based on a ESP32S3, compass, LoRa transceiver and it is connected to a computer for centralized monitoring and data storage for parent and child. By leveraging LoRa technology for low-power, long-distance communication and combining it with GPS for precise location data, this system provides a robust, cost-effective, and user-friendly solution for enhancing child safety. The proposed system addresses limitations of existing solutions, such as limited range, dependency on cellular networks, while offering real-time tracking, reliable communication, and versatile usage across diverse environments.

title: Floating Four-Arm Interleaved Boost DC-DC Converter for Photovoltaic Systems
authors: Kassio Derek Nogueira Cavalcante, Menaouar Berrehil El Kattel, Lincoln Moura De Oliveira, Robson Mayer, Edilson Mineiro Sa Junior, Paulo Peixoto Praça, Fernando Luiz Marcelo Antunes
abstract: This work presents a high step-up DC-DC converter, referred to as Floating Four-Arm Interleaved Boost DC-DC Converter for Photovoltaic Systems. The proposed topology is characterized by its capability to operate with low current and voltage ripples at both the input and output, where the ripple frequency is four times higher than the switching frequency. Additionally, the currents in the inductors and capacitors are twice higher than the switching frequency, contributing to ripple reduction and enabling the use of smaller passive components. The converter also exhibits lower component stress, reduced magnetic element volume, and significantly lower losses due to its compact four-arm structure utilizing only two inductors. Among its main advantages are natural current balancing between arms, achieved through interleaved modulation, and the capability to operate at high power densities. The article discusses the operating principle, parameter design, and mathematical analysis of the topology. A <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9-\text{kW}$</tex> prototype was experimentally validated under an input voltage of 350 V, output voltage of 600 V, switching frequency of 20 kHz, and achieved 98.7% efficiency, confirming high voltage gain, low ripple, and overall suitability for photovoltaic applications.

title: Performing Jongmyo Jeryeak in VR: A Rhythm Game with Pyeongyeong
authors: Akeem Pedro, Jean Ho Chu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Although Jongmyo Jeryeak holds significant historical and educational value, students have limited access to its full ceremonial context and traditional instruments, which weakens their cultural connection and understanding of its significance. To address this accessibility gap, this work-in-progress presents a virtual reality rhythm game centered on Heemoon, the opening piece of the Botaepyeong suite in Jongmyo Jeryeak, to support Korean music learning and immersive cultural engagement. A prototype is developed in Unity 3D using the XR Interaction Toolkit. It features custom interaction design, audio synchronization, and a time-coded visual cue and feedback system, allowing users to interactively perform on a virtual Pyeongyeong within a recreated Jongmyo Shrine environment. By making traditional practices more accessible, this work aims to foster deeper cultural understanding among younger generations and contribute to the preservation of intangible heritage.

title: Analyses of Declared Efficiency in Commercial PV Inverters
authors: Geyciane Pinheiro de Lima, Geovana da Cunha Soares, Thallys Luan Bezerra Lima, João Pedro Carvalho Silveira, Pedro José dos Santos Neto, Tárcio André dos Santos Barros
abstract: Efficiency values in photovoltaic (PV) inverter datasheets steer design, simulation, and performance assessment. Among summary metrics, EURO efficiency is widely adopted. This study reports laboratory measurements of EURO efficiency for eight commercial grid-connected PV inverters, executed in accordance with IEC 62891:2020, and compares them with manufacturers' declarations. Conformity is assessed using two acceptance models: the variable tolerance of IEC 61683:1999 and the fixed 1 percentage-point (p.p.) tolerance of Brazilian Ordinance No. 140/2022. For all devices, the measured EURO efficiency is lower than the declared value; the mean declared-measured gap is 1.68 p.p. (range: 0.66-2.80 p.p.). No device complies with IEC 61683, and only one tested device complies under Ordinance 140. These results indicate that datasheet efficiencies are systematically optimistic. For design and performance projections, a conservative specification is recommended: for each device, use the smaller of the laboratory-measured EURO value and the guaranteed minimum.

title: Proposed Experimental Methodology for Characterization and Dynamic Electrical Modeling of Electrolyzers
authors: Francisco W. O. Da Frota, Humberto P. V. Ool De Sousa, João G. D. Chaves Dos Santos, J. S. Bomfim Neto, Leonardo Tabosa Albuquerque, Francisco Murilo Tavares Luna, Edilson M. Sá Júnior
abstract: The integration of electrolyzers with intermittent renewable energy sources (RES) requires the characterization of their electrical behavior under dynamic operating conditions. This work presents a validated experimental methodology for the characterization and modeling of an alkaline electrolysis cell, preceded by a review of existing techniques in the literature. The methodology employs ramp, step, and current interruption tests to analyze the system's static and transient responses. These tests allow for the separation of the ohmic and activation overpotentials. The obtained data are used to parameterize an equivalent electrical circuit model, implemented exclusively with passive elements. The model's accuracy was validated by comparing the simulated results with the experimental data. The quantitative analysis indicated a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of less than 4% and a Mean Squared Error (MSE) of less than 1.5 %, confirming the model's ability to represent the cell's behavior in both transient and steady-state regimes. The main contribution of this work is the provision of an experimental basis for the sizing of power converters and the development of control strategies for green hydrogen production systems.

title: Intelligent Innovation Performance Prediction for Enterprises Based on Hybrid Learning Models
authors: Anfeng Xu, Xiaoxiong Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Enterprises needs a more innovation in investment choices, risk apportionment, and capital sustenance to sustain in competitive global market. As the complexity and volatility of financial settings intensify, adequate risk assessment has become fundamental to safeguard capital resources and drive long-term prosperity. Conventional frameworks varying from statistical methods to basic heuristic approaches are inadequate to properly capture the nonlinear, dynamic, and multi-dimensional character of enterprise risk. In return, machine learning approaches and bio-inspired algorithms have been embraced for improved predictability as well as adaptability. These existing techniques are, however, subject to slow convergence, local optima trap, and poor generalization for a wide range of financial situations. Further, dependence on single-algorithm techniques achieves low performance when addressed to high-dimensional and time-changing data sets typical of enterprise market data. To overcome the aforementioned limitations, this research advances a Hybrid Bio-Inspired Model that leverages synergies of the best features of cutting-edge nature-inspired with deep learning models. Performance metrices measures showed excellent results with accuracy of 96%, precision of 95.6%, recall of 96.4%, and an F1-score of 95.6%. The suggested system improves exploration-exploitation balance, speeds up convergence, and enhances the accuracy of risk categorization. By surmounting the limitations of current methods, this hybrid approach provides a scalable, adaptive, and clever framework for the prediction of enterprise innovation performance.

title: Numerical and Experimental Investigation of High-Powered Chips for Efficient Cooling Using Optimized Electrochemical Additive Manufacturing Based Cold Plates
authors: Gautam Gupta, Douglas Castro, Joseph Madril, Tim Ouradnik, Ian Winfield, Michael Matthews, Dereje Agonafer
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: As computational demands grow due to advancements in artificial intelligence and high-performance computing, the thermal management of high-powered chips becomes increasingly critical. Traditional air-cooling methods are no longer sufficient to meet the needs of modern CPUs and GPUs, which generate significant thermal loads at power densities that push the boundaries of current cooling technologies. This study presents an integrated approach combining Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) and experimental analysis to develop optimized cold plate designs using Electrochemical Additive Manufacturing (ECAM). The study focuses on cooling high-powered chips with non-uniform power distribution under Thermal Design Power (TDP) loads of 700 W, using a coolant inlet temperature of $45^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. CFD simulations were employed to explore and optimize various cold plate geometries, targeting minimal thermal resistance and enhanced heat dissipation across the chip. The ECAM-based cold plates, with their capability to produce highly intricate and customized internal flow structures with high resolutions on the micro scale, were found to offer superior thermal performance compared to conventional straight microchannel cold plates. The best-performing cold plate designs from the CFD simulations were fabricated using ECAM technology and subsequently tested experimentally. The result of this study indicates that the ECAM-manufactured cold plates exhibited 21% lower thermal resistance and achieved a 201% improvement in thermal uniformity compared to the baseline by significantly reducing the temperature gradient and improved temperature uniformity across the chip, outperforming traditional straight microchannel cold plate designs. This study demonstrates the potential of ECAM for fabricating cold plates with complex geometries, providing a significant step forward in thermal management solutions for next-generation high-powered chips and electronics cooling.

title: Optimal Heat Spreading Solutions for Three-Dimensional Heterogeneously Integrated Modules using a Multigrid Topology Optimization Method
authors: C-P. Chen, X. Zhang, C-S. Lee, G. Subbarayan
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Increasing power densities in complex heterogeneously integrated packages require effective thermal design for three-dimensional (3D) chip stacks. In this study, we develop and demonstrate a general design framework for two-dimensional (2D) and 3D heat spreading/removal solutions using multigrid topological optimization methods coupled with sensitivity analysis to achieve efficient optimal design. We begin with an efficient steady-state heat conduction finite element solution using a sparse solver. We then combine the solver with a sequential quadratic programming (SQP) optimizer for workload-specific heat spreader topology design as well as optimized placement of through silicon vias (TSVs) to enable heat removal through the 3D chip stack. Topology optimization is performed using the solid isotropic material with penalization method (SIMP), which iteratively modifies the effective thermal conductivity to optimize material distribution. We also implement a semi-analytical sensitivity analysis to ensure efficient derivative calculation necessary for optimization. The developed multigrid optimization method first optimizes material distribution on a coarse mesh to reduce computation time followed by a refined solution to achieve the same level of accuracy as a direction solution using fine mesh but with less computational cost. This developed multigrid topological optimization framework significantly speeds up the optimization process without loss of accuracy in generating three-dimensional heat removal solutions. Three examples are solved to illustrate the developed method: (1) optimized heat spreader material distribution given heat sources (2) optimized location of thermal vias on a grid for a given power map and (3) optimal die arrangement and via placement in a 3D stack.

title: Quality Evaluation of Labor Education for College Students Based on CATBoost Neural Networks
authors: Jinyu Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Labor education is an essential component of student development in higher education, yet assessing its quality remains a challenge due to the complexity and subjectivity involved. Traditional evaluation approaches often lack precision and consistency, leading to biased, incomplete assessments. To overcome these limitations, this study proposes the application of neural network algorithms for the systematic evaluation of labor education quality. To overcome these constraints, this research proposes the CAT Boosted neural networks for an intelligent evaluation of the labour courses to the students. The proposed networks combines the powerful features of Neural Networks and CaTBoosted for learning the labour education inputs to support for an emergent teaching and evaluation systems. The comprehensive experimentation is carried out using Kaggle Student Performance Evaluation datasets on Labour Education and performance of the model is evaluated. To prove the efficacy of the suggested model, existing architectures are experimented and their performance were compared with the suggested framework. Experimental results demonstrate the superiority of the suggested model by achieving the accuracy of 98.7%, precision of 98.65%, recall of 98.6% and F1-score of 98.5% and outperforms the other learning model. The present research provides the new paths for evaluating the labour education teaching among the students, providing real-world implications for teachers and institutions

title: Research and Application of New Energy Station Rendering Based on Virtual Micro Polygon Geometry Technology
authors: Jianguang Zhang, Di Liu, Shutao Dong, Xiangshang Wang, Yichen Lei, Bo Hu, Peixiang Ren
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Manufacturing System (ICAMTMS)
abstract: To overcome the problems of missing details, low efficiency, and data redundancy in traditional LOD rendering in new energy scenes, this paper renders new energy scenes based on virtual micro polygon geometry technology. This technology achieves automatic clustering of triangular patches by constructing virtual geometric meshes, using cluster boundary locking and quadratic surface error measurement to simplify the model step by step, and dynamically loading the optimal detail level based on directed acyclic graphs. Verified in a 9.42 million panel new energy station model: This technology increases the frame rate at close range by 120% (93.17 FPS) and reduces rendering time by 55%; Long distance frame rate increased by 31% (108.17 FPS). Experimental results have shown that this method significantly improves rendering efficiency while maintaining high detail representation, providing an efficient solution for visualizing new energy scenes.

title: A Phase-Shift Based Wide-Range Soft-Switching Control Strategy for Bidirectional Wireless Power Transfer Systems
authors: Wenze Hong, Dukju Ahn, Xingkui Mao, Yiming Zhang
publish: 2025 International Power and Sustainable Energy Technologies Conference (PSETC)
abstract: This paper presents a method to achieve bidirectional Zero-Voltage Switching (ZVS) in an S-S topology Bidirectional Wireless Power Transfer (BWPT) system. The transmitted power is controlled by adjusting the phase difference between the two arms of the secondary bridge. By formulating a set of differential equations for the system, the current values during switching transitions are determined, which are then used to derive the external phase shift angle required for ZVS. This method enables the realization of ZVS over a wide power range during energy transfer. Simulation results show that with an external phase-shift angle of 83°, the system achieves a peak efficiency of 98.8% at full load and maintains above 92% efficiency down to 10% load.

title: A Comparative Analysis Of Single Phase Liquid Cooled Data Center Coolants Using ASTM D1384 & D8040 Standards
authors: Ali Heydari, Lochan Sai Reddy Chinthaparthy, Pardeep Shahi, Himanshu Modi, Anto Barigala, Ivneet Kaur Banga, Sean Sivapalan, Harold Miyamura, Dereje Agonafer, Mohammad Tradat, Saket Karajgikar, Jeremy Rodriguez
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: The surge in demand, driven by advancements in artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML), and the Internet of Things (IoT), has resulted in an unprecedented growth in transistor density for high-end CPUs and GPUs. The increasing computational demands in modern data centers have led to the widespread adoption of direct-to-chip cold plate-based liquid cooling systems to efficiently manage heat dissipation with high-performance computing equipment. Various single phase coolants such as glycol based, water-based, and nano fluids were introduced in the market to meet the requirements. These coolants, produced by different manufacturers, incorporate diverse inhibitors and chemical additives designed to enhance long-term performance, prevent bio-growth, and offer robust corrosion resistance. Corrosion in liquid cooling systems is a significant concern for the reliability and longevity of equipment within data centers, evaluating the effectiveness of these coolants becomes critical. This study aims to assess the corrosion performance of various coolant formulations used in data center liquid cooling loops, utilizing standardized methods such as ASTM D1384 and ASTM D8040 to evaluate their impact on common wetted materials like copper, brass, stainless steel 304 and stainless steel 316. The ASTM D1384 standard outlines a method to evaluate the corrosiveness of engine coolants under controlled conditions. In this test, coupons made of materials commonly used in cooling systems-such as copper, brass, steel, cast iron, cast aluminum, and solderare immersed in a coolant-water solution and subjected to aeration at an elevated temperature ($88^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$) for a specified duration. Corrosion behavior is assessed by measuring the weight loss of these coupons before and after testing, with the results compared to the acceptable ASTM limits. In contrast, the ASTM D8040 standard is tailored specifically for evaluating coolants in data center environments, considering unique operational conditions such as lower flow rates and extended life cycle demands. In this study, several commercial coolant formulations, including propylene glycol-based coolants and water-based coolants designed specifically for data center cooling systems, were tested. Coupon sets composed of four materials were meticulously prepared, cleaned, and weighed before immersion in coolant solutions as per ASTM specifications. The solutions were maintained at an elevated temperature and aerated to simulate accelerated operating conditions The results of the study revealed significant differences in the corrosion resistance provided by the various coolant formulations. It was evident that the performance of corrosion inhibitors played a crucial role in the protection of materials within liquid cooling systems. This study highlights the critical importance of corrosion inhibitors in safeguarding essential materials and stresses the need for diligent testing and monitoring of coolant formulations to ensure optimal operational efficiency and the durability of cooling equipment. The findings underscore the necessity for data center operators to carefully select coolants that prevent corrosion, thereby reducing maintenance costs and extending equipment lifespan.

title: Parameterized Thermal Compact Modeling for Effective Thermal Management of Advanced Common Multigate Transistors in Sub-7 nm Technology Nodes
authors: Harsh Kumar, Vivek Kumar
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: In the era of extreme scaling of nanoscale devices, the increasing packing density of Advanced Common Multigate Transistors (ACMTs) in modern Integrated Circuits (ICs) has led to significantly higher power densities. Additionally, the self-heating effect in ACMTs, primarily due to their gate-all-around (GAA) structure, exacerbates thermal challenges. The low thermal conductivity of gate oxide materials traps heat in the channel, resulting in a worsened thermal profile, particularly for technology nodes below 14 nm. This thermal stress directly affects device reliability, contributing to issues such as Temperature Dependent Dielectric Breakdown (TDDB), Negative/Positive Bias Temperature Instability (NBTI/PBTI), and Hot Carrier Degradation (HCD). These reliability concerns raise serious questions about the sustainability of modern ICs under such thermal conditions. This work proposes a parameterized Thermal Compact Model (TCM) for ACMTs (including Nanosheet, Forksheet, and Complementary FETs) to improve thermal management in ICs. The approach divides the device into temperature nodes, based on hotspots identified through Finite-Element Method (FEM) simulations. An equivalent thermal RC circuit is then modeled, using design and structural parameters, allowing the model to be adaptable to various types of multigate transistors. The proposed TCM’s thermal DC and frequency responses are validated through Synopsys(c) TCAD tools, ensuring accuracy and effectiveness in managing the thermal behavior of advanced ICs.

title: Optimal Path Selection in Wireless Sensor Networks for Device to Device communication in IoT and 5G Applications
authors: Rashmita Routray, Subesh Kumar Behera, Tapas Kumar Patra
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: The seamless communication across heterogeneous networks (HetNets) made possible by the Device to Device Communication(D2D) has completely changed the world. Rapid growth of the internet users led to the development of a wide range of services, apps, electronic gadgets with built-in sensors, and ideas such as augmented reality, high-definition video streaming, self-driving cars, smart environments, etc. currently have a wall-to-wall presence. Higher data rates, more bandwidth, more capacity, low latency, and high throughput are all necessary for these applications. For fifth-generation (5G) communications, wireless sensor networks (WSN), the IoT’s persistent layer, are crucial. In order to determine the best path selection in WSN, this study compares the Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), Dijkstra’s algorithm, A* algorithm, and Q-learning method. These algorithms offer an effective way to gather data and share knowledge.

title: Real-Time Feedback System for Body Tilt in Archery Shooting
authors: Natsuki Kinoshita, Shizuka Shirai, Masato Kobayashi, Naoya Chiba, Yuki Uranishi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: In archery, stable form is crucial for high scores, but archers often struggle to perceive body tilt in real-time. This study proposes a system providing immediate visual feedback on body inclination near the target during the aiming phase. A within-subjects experiment with nine intermediate archers showed the system improved body tilt, and this effect persisted even after feedback removal. Subjective usability evaluations were highly positive.

title: DriveQuest — Enhancing In-Car Navigation through the Use of Gamification and Augmented Reality
authors: Houssein M. Zaghdane, Johanna Pirker, David A. Plecher, Christian Eichhorn
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We present the game "DriveQuest", targeting in-car gamification for drivers and passengers. It consists of two connected applications: A gamified navigation application on the car’s infotainment display for the driver and a phone application for passengers. The aim is to collect badges by driving to Points of Interest (POIs), supported by features that utilize real-time vehicle signals. The phone application provides an Augmented Reality (AR) mini-game, guiding the passengers towards POIs in a seamless experience that also fosters collaboration. A user study was conducted with pairs of participants (driver and one passenger). Data was collected via questionnaires, real-time logging, and observations. The purpose of the study was to evaluate the potential of the prototype as an educational and entertainment tool while also examining their stance on the features. The System Usability Scale (SUS) and Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) questionnaires revealed a positive user experience, with drivers reporting lower scores overall. The AR feature was appreciated, with challenges remaining. The current moderate potential for day-to-day use needs to be addressed. We conclude by providing recommendations and a discussion on future research in the area of in-car gamification involving AR while driving.

title: MSGS: Multispectral 3D Gaussian Splatting
authors: Iris Zheng, Guojun Tang, Alexander Doronin, Paul Teal, Fang-Lue Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We present a multispectral extension to 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) for wavelength-aware view synthesis. Each Gaussian is augmented with spectral radiance, represented via per-band spherical harmonics, and optimized under a dual-loss supervision scheme combining RGB and multispectral signals. To improve rendering fidelity, we perform spectral-to-RGB conversion at the pixel level, allowing richer spectral cues to be retained during optimization. Our method is evaluated on both public and self-captured real-world datasets, demonstrating consistent improvements over the RGB-only 3DGS baseline in terms of image quality and spectral consistency. Notably, it excels in challenging scenes involving translucent materials and anisotropic reflections. The proposed approach maintains the compactness and real-time efficiency of 3DGS while laying the foundation for future integration with physically based shading models.

title: Split-Phase Power Regulation of the Three-phase Voltage Source Converter via Negative-Sequence Current Injection
authors: Shaoyan Jiang, Qian Li, Huiming Li, Lifeng Du, Zhimin Liu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Three phase imbalance is the typical power quality problem in the distribution networks, which is generally caused by imbalanced active and reactive loads on each phase. Conventionally, additional hardware such as Static Var Generator (SVG) and Active Power Filter (APF) are installed to handle this issue at the cost of increased investment. However, the widely installed three-phase voltage source converter has similar circuit structure and considerable potential in phase balancing. This paper proposes a novel split-phase power control strategy for the three-phase Voltage Source Converter (VSC) via negative-sequence current injection, which achieves independent regulation of the average power of each individual phase so that the VSC can participate in inter-phase imbalance compensation. The single-phase power expression is first derived in the phasor domain considering the positive- and negative-sequence components. Then, to handle the freedom-degree-lacking dilemma, two schemes are proposed to achieve split-phase active or reactive power regulation while keeping the other power constant, respectively. After that, the implementation method into the classic VSC control frame is introduced. Finally, the validness of the control strategy and the effectiveness of the phase power balancing have been well proved by simulation results.

title: Personalized Curriculum Recommendation System for Vocational Education Using Generative Ai Models
authors: Yulong Hu, Qiwen Mo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Effective curriculum recommendation plays a vital role in improving student learning outcomes in vocational education. Providing adaptive and personalized test materials ensures that learners receive resources suited to their proficiency levels. This research presents a Personalized Curriculum Recommendation System utilizing Fine-Tuned BERT to capture contextual semantics in test materials and learner profiles. Despite progress in AI-driven educational recommendations, existing methods often struggle to accurately align resources with individual proficiency levels, leading to inefficient learning experiences. To address these challenges, this study proposes a learning framework that leverages Finetuned BERT-based sentence embeddings and cosine similarity ranking for test material selection. Key linguistic features, including semantic coherence and contextual embeddings, enhance recommendation accuracy. The proposed system achieves a recommendation accuracy of 97 % with Precision of 97.5), Recall of 96.75, and F1-Score (96.2%), validating its effectiveness and reliability. Experimental results demonstrate the system's superiority in optimizing test preparation, outperforming rule-based approaches. These findings highlight the impact of AI-powered recommendation systems in education, enhancing personalized learning pathways, student engagement, and proficiency development. This research represents a significant advancement in intelligent personalized curriculum recommendation for vocational education.

title: A Work-in-Progress Study on Effect of Post-Operation Visual Feedback on Perceived Pleasantness during Membrane Penetration with Force Feedback
authors: Yusuke Ujitoko, Yuki Ban
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Although haptic technologies that allow users to touch virtual objects have been actively studied, they have not yet seen widespread adoption in real-world applications. To facilitate broader adoption, it is essential to design stimuli that elicit pleasant sensations during active interactions with virtual objects. However, how such pleasantness can be effectively induced remains poorly understood. This work-in-progress study investigates whether perceived pleasantness is postdictively modulated by the visual appearance of objects. We conducted a case study in a task where users manipulated a pointer to press and penetrate a virtual membrane. In the experiment, we manipulated visual parameters (i.e., the natural frequency and damping ratio) of the membrane during its recovery phase after penetration. We also varied the resistance force experienced during the pressing phase. Preliminary results suggest that natural frequency as a visual parameter contributed to the perception of pleasantness across force conditions. Based on these findings, which provide valuable insights into designing haptic interactions that elicit pleasantness, we plan to proceed with the main experiment. These insights may help advance the broader adoption of haptic technologies in real-world applications.

title: Design of a Local Energy Market Considering Fuzzy Based Priority Scheduling
authors: Chinmoy Chakraborty, Chaity Sarkar, Swaraj Banerjee, Jibanananda Mahato
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: The aim of this work is to provide each consumer in a local energy market with a sufficient supply of electricity at the lowest possible cost to guarantee transparent power transactions. In the proposed scheme, the energy unit is asked from the consumer’s end. The designed mechanism may then determine which option is more cost-effective for them and deliver the electricity in a manner based on their demand and need priorities. As the validity of scheme is supposed to be verified by real time implementation within the laboratory, some very small-scale available equipment’s are used to represent the system (like batteries as sources, pump, fans, bulbs are load or consumers etc.).

title: Machine Learning for 5G Massive MIMO Systems and Beyond: Integrating Artificial General Intelligence
authors: Mariam Hussain, Alia Mohsin, Amna Abdalla, Maha Bader, Khawla A. Alnajjar
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) technology is essential to enhancing the coverage, capacity, and efficiency of wireless communication systems. Its integration into modern networks helps address key challenges such as spectrum usage, data allocation, and energy efficiency. The application of Machine Learning (ML) improves MIMO by enabling real-time adaptation and optimizing tasks like beamforming, user scheduling, and channel estimation. This paper also discusses the emerging role of Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) in future wireless networks, highlighting its potential for autonomous control and dynamic optimization. A case study on Massive MIMO in 5G networks demonstrates the advantages of integrating MIMO with ML and AGI. The study evaluates performance gains and identifies challenges, providing insight into the development of scalable, efficient, and intelligent wireless architectures.

title: Matrix-Based Apriori Methods for Frequent Pattern Mining: An in-Depth Survey
authors: Kalpana P, Sumathi P, Teena Jose, Deepa S, Raju Ramakrishna Gondkar, Loveline Zeema J
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Recent Advances in Information Technology for Sustainable Development (ICRAIS)
abstract: Data Mining identifies intriguing, useful, and previously unknown patterns and correlations between data stored in databases or warehouses. Frequent Pattern Mining (FPM) is one of the vital methods in the prospering arena of data mining (DM), and it describes the relationship between the items in the datasets. In the last two decades, many studies were carried out in FPM using the Apriori algorithm. The Apriori algorithm requires many database scans and produces numerous candidate itemsets, increasing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$I / O$</tex> cost and decreasing computational efficiency. To address these issues, researchers contributed many improved versions of Apriori and proved that those algorithms scan the database only once and identify the frequent itemsets quickly, especially when the itemsets are higher, and provide higher efficiency and feasibility. This research article summarizes matrix-based Apriori algorithms in the literature used for identifying frequent itemsets.

title: Towards a Modular XR Platform for Personalized Upper Limb Rehab
authors: Sambhav Manohar, Mohit Madhu, Chaitanya Anand, Abhijit Patil, Gabriel Zachmann, Himangshu Sarma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: A modular, clinically informed XR-based rehabilitation platform is presented to support customizable therapy programs for upper limb conditions. Designed in collaboration with rehabilitation physicians, the system enables medical professionals to create, adapt, and deploy personalized therapy routines while monitoring patient progress remotely. The platform incorporates gesture-based exercises and personalized progression through two core techniques: (1) A tolerance adaptation algorithm is proposed to dynamically adjust evaluation difficulty based on user-specific parameters, including age, injury severity, and demographic profile. (2) A weighted gesture scoring model that prioritizes motion components most relevant to the therapeutic objectives of each exercise. Modular game-play allows reconfiguration according to clinical prescriptions for various conditions, including Carpal Tunnel Syndrome, post-stroke upper limb recovery, and rotator cuff rehabilitation. All exercise-to-gesture mappings are derived from validated clinical documentation to ensure medical accuracy. This system establishes a foundation for a general-purpose, adaptable XR rehabilitation framework tailored to individual patient needs and therapeutic outcomes.

title: Data-physics Fusion Regression Modelling of Speed Optimisation Module for Doubly-fed Variable Speed Pumped Storage Units
authors: Rao Liu, Yiwen Sun, Zifeng Li, Chi Tian, Junqing Yang, Haixia Wang, Yu Ba
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Currently, variable-speed pumped storage units are mainly divided into two categories: doubly-fed units and full-power units. In practical applications, doubly-fed units have become the mainstream choice for variable-speed pumped storage power plants due to their excellent cost performance and higher energy conversion efficiency [1]. Compared with fixed-speed pumped storage units, doubly-fed pumped storage units have more complex structures and working principles. In this paper, on the basis of combing the basic principles of frequency response of doubly-fed units, we focus on analyzing its unique frequency response module - speed optimization module, and discuss how to simplify the model appropriately to facilitate the analysis.

title: Method for Constructing Digital Media Virtual Reality Scenes by Integrating Neural Networks
authors: Yuheng Tao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Traditional virtual reality scene construction methods are cumbersome and inefficient, relying on manual modeling and preset rules, which limits immersive experiences. This paper proposes a digital media VR scene construction method that integrates neural networks, utilizing convolutional neural networks and generative adversarial networks to analyze and generate multimodal data such as images, videos, and voices. A neural network-based 3D modeling automation process, scene texture synthesis algorithm, and user behavior interaction optimization are designed, improving construction efficiency and immersion. Experimental results show that this method significantly outperforms traditional ones in speed, image fidelity, and user experience, with modeling times ranging from 60 to 270 seconds and a structural similarity index improvement of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 1 3 - 0. 1 8}$</tex>. This research paves the way for intelligent VR system development and future digital content fusion applications.

title: Method for Suppressing Extraneous Torque in Aircraft Rudder Electric Loading System
authors: Xiaolin Liu, Shuyan Zhao
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: To address extraneous torque disturbances in the Aircraft Rudder Electric Loading System (ARELS), a composite controller combining motor current feedforward compensation with an improved linear active disturbance rejection control (ILADRC) is proposed. A feedforward compensator is designed based on the motor current signal to proactively attenuate extraneous torque disturbances. In the feedback channel, an ILADRC is developed by introducing a derivative state variable of the total disturbance into the extended state observer, thereby enhancing the system's torque tracking accuracy. The effectiveness of the composite controller is validated through simulation studies. Results show that, compared with traditional LADRC and PID controllers, the proposed method achieves superior performance in suppressing extraneous torque in the loading system.

title: Mirror, Mirror on the Wall: A New Teleportation Method for Us All
authors: Yukang Ou, Benjamin W.J. Kwok, Jeannie S. Lee, Kan Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Conventional arc-based teleportation in virtual reality (VR) may not always be easy to use, especially in low-ceiling and narrow environments, areas and corridors with corners, staircases and obstacles, where the arc is often blocked or interrupted, disrupting the movement and limiting the user’s ability to clearly view or reach the intended destination directly. To address these limitations, ReflectPort is introduced as a novel teleportation technique that leverages natural reflection-inspired physics to streamline teleportation within complex virtual environments. This technique allows teleportation paths to bounce off surfaces while previewing the destination, enabling users to navigate around corners, handle elevation changes, and bypass spatial obstacles more effectively.

title: Toward Wearable Biosensing and Rapid Diagnostics via Extraction of Dermal Interstitial Fluid
authors: Christopher T. Sharkey, Isabella G. Agusta, Angélica F. Aroche, Hannah E. Nissan, Kaila L. Peterson, Tamoghna Saha, Jack Twiddy, Alper Bozkurt, Michael D. Dickey, Orlin D. Velev, Michael Daniele
abstract: Wearable biosensing platforms for rapid, minimally invasive biomarker monitoring hold great promise for data-driven healthcare and lifestyle management. This work presents a microneedle-based sampling system for the minimally invasive extraction and analysis of interstitial fluid biomarkers. The sampling system integrates hydrogel-forming microneedle patches with an osmotic pump and paper-based fluidics to efficiently collect dermal interstitial fluid. To demonstrate rapid diagnostics, electrochemical biosensors are incorporated for the detection of cortisol and lactate. Using in vitro skin models, the system demonstrated accurate analyte quantification, with enhanced cortisol detection achieved through pretreatment of paper fluidics with buffering compounds. The platform’s suitability for wearable applications is supported by its rapid time-to-result, physiologically relevant dynamic ranges, and modular design for multianalyte detection.

title: Gaze+Mouth: Gaze-Directed Tongue Input with Intraoral Device for Selection in XR
authors: Thorbjørn Mikkelsen, Yijing Jiang, Baris F. Coskun, Michael Wessely, Ken Pfeuffer
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Extended reality (XR) headsets featuring gaze-tracking enable hands-free selection via explicit dwell or integration with other modalities. This paper demonstrates the novel hands-free interaction technique Gaze+Mouth, which combines eye-gaze for pointing with an intraoral tongue gesture for selection. We implement the technique using a wearable mouthpiece and conduct a user study (N=16) comparing Gaze+Mouth to the established Gaze+Pinch technique. Results show that while Gaze+Pinch is significantly faster, Gaze+Mouth achieved a comparable level of accuracy. This suggests that intraoral input is a viable channel for reliable hands-free selection in XR, offering a new modality for situations where users’ hands are occupied or when an alternative is desired.
