title: Isolating haptic feedback from visual feedback using mixed reality technology: a case study on serial dependence experiment
authors: Jessica Bertolasi, Nadia Vanessa Garcia Hernandez, Emanuele Caroglio, Stefania Petri, Monica Gori
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Mixed Reality (MR) is increasingly used in fields like medical, automotive, and aerospace industries, integrating virtual objects into real-world settings. MR is also valuable in perceptual research, enabling the fast and low-cost creation of controllable environments for psychophysical experiments in a playful manner. This study leveraged MR to isolate vision as a key factor in object size recognition. Using a serial dependence paradigm, we examined how an inducer stimulus influences the perception of a reference and test stimuli. To differentiate visual from haptic contributions, we employed the HoloLens 2 device to project virtual spheres onto participants' hands, providing only visual feedback without haptic input. The results revealed that serial dependence in size discrimination was more pronounced in the visual-only condition compared to the haptic-only condition, indicating that tactile input provides a more stable reference for size estimation. Additionally, the findings support the reliability of the HoloLens 2 as a tool for conducting psychophysical experiments.

title: Improving UAV Localization Accuracy with Multimodal Sensor Data and Machine Learning Models
authors: Yiting Zhu
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: UAV sensor-based precise localization faces major challenges in complex environments such as forests and tunnels. Single-modal sensors (GNSS, INS) suffer from poor robustness and accuracy under these conditions. This study addresses this issue by integrating GNSS, INS and Barometer, focusing on improvements achieved through Extended Kalman algorithms and optimization machine learning models. Experimental results show that compared with the traditional Kalman algorithm, the method of adding a machine learning module after the Kalman algorithm has improved indicators such as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> and 3D visual trajectory.

title: DAUT-DC: Integrating Depth-to-Color refinement into a Depth-Aware U-shape Transformer for Enhanced Underwater Vision
authors: Ardhi Tarun, Kumar Surjeet Chaudhury, Aheeron Changmai, Arghadeep Thakur, Annanya Arora, Archit Jain, Kashish Kumari
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: A depth-aware U-shape transformer framework is presented in this paper, integrating depth-to-color refinement to enhance degraded underwater images. The architecture jointly predicts scene depth and leverages depth cues to guide color correction within a multi-scale transformer structure. It addresses common underwater distortions such as color casts, blur, and low contrast, enabling geometry-aware restoration. The model is trained using synthetically generated underwater images along with real-world datasets to ensure robustness across diverse conditions. Multi-color-space loss functions are employed to encourage accurate recovery of natural color and contrast. Experimental evaluations demonstrate superior performance over existing methods, with significant improvements in multiple quality assessment metrics. The results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed approach and emphasize its potential for practical applications in underwater vision tasks, including marine exploration and object detection.

title: Measurement of Blade-Tower Clearance of Wind Turbine Based on Deformation Estimation
authors: Hang Chen, Fugang Li, Yao Qin, Weizhi Wu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: Applying effective clearance measurement strategies to wind turbines to ensure the safe distance between rotating blades and towers can not only prevent potential safety risks, but also improve the stability and remaining life of wind turbines. However, the existing technology is insufficient in terms of economic benefits or stability. Based on this, this paper proposes a method for measuring the blade-tower clearance based on the deformation estimation of blade and tower. The proposed method first constructs the motion equations of the blade and the tower based on the beam element theory, and then combines the solved modal matrix with the horn lizard optimization algorithm(HLOA) to optimize the installation scheme of the displacement sensor. Then, based on the sensor installation scheme, the blade-tower state space equation is constructed and the deformation is estimated using kalman filter(KF). Finally, the estimated deformation is mapped into the blade-tower clearance using radial basis function(RBF). A 5MW wind turbine is used in experiments to verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Expanding Conversational AI Beyond Context Windows: A Memory-Augmented Approach
authors: Khant Ko, Thinn Thinn Wai, Aung Nway Oo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: Large language models have improved conversational AI by producing fluent, context-aware replies. Still, their short context windows and lack of persistent memory can break conversations: users often must repeat important details. This gap harms personalization and makes it hard for systems to keep a consistent, long-term dialogue. This paper tackles that problem by developing memory extraction and retrieval methods to capture and preserve important user information from conversations. The proposed system extracts compact facts—user preferences, notable events, and situational details—and stores them in a structured repository. Those facts are converted into semantic vectors through modern vectorization (embedding) techniques, which enable fast, similarity-based lookup. During a conversation, the system retrieves relevant memory vectors and injects the matching information into the model’s context. That dynamic retrieval enriches the model’s input with past, relevant details, improving response coherence and personalization without changing the language model itself. Evaluation shows that this memory-augmented pipeline effectively adds high -similarity and usable context to the models.

title: Clustering and Predictive Modeling of Epileptic Spikes and Seizures using EEG Data
authors: Gomathy M, L. Steffina Morin, Lekshmi S. Raveendran, Jose Anand A, A. Jegatheesan, B. Muthukumar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: This study aimed to identify and classify different nodules based on different morphological features and evaluate their value as a prognostic model. Through unsupervised learning, the clustering algorithm successfully distinguished four different cells with a contour score of 0.54, indicating that these cell clusters had clear boundaries and were independent of each other. The study analyzed two experimental scenarios with different target variables, and the random forest classifier achieved the best performance in both cases, with F1 score indicators of 0.60 and 0.62, respectively. The analysis showed that the type of spikes affected the prediction results, especially in the first scenario, while the power band was more important in the second scenario. Model 1 had the highest predictive value in all dimensions. Despite the encouraging results, this classification model is not yet suitable for clinical application due to mediocre performance indicators. Future studies should explore more advanced models, such as deep learning architectures and dynamic time window techniques, to improve classification accuracy.

title: Belonging and Mobility: Constructing Sentiment-embedded Event Evolutionary Graph for Diaspora Oral Archives
authors: Jing Zhou, Charles Jeurgens
publish: Journal on Computing and Cultural Heritage
abstract: Constructing a sentiment-embedded event evolutionary graph (SEEGraph) is proposed to capture the dynamic relationships and narratives embedded in the oral histories of diasporas. It provides data support for applying diaspora oral archives knowledge and realizes the effective transformation of “data-knowledge-application”. Firstly, diaspora oral archives are introduced as the research scope. Secondly, domain ontology is utilized to build a knowledge representation system for diaspora oral archives. Based on the ontology, events, and event relations are defined to construct SEEGraph. Next, the South Asian Oral History Project (SAOHP) is selected as the data source. Events entities and relationships involved in the diaspora oral archives are extracted with Natural language processing (NLP) tools, which form the data layer of the event evolutionary map. SEEGraph is then constructed. This step stores and maps instances extracted from archival data, transforming data into knowledge. Finally, the knowledge graph is applied to analyze and explore the event evolutionary patterns, spatio-temporal and spatio-sentiment rules of historical events, and emotional changes of diasporas. This innovative methodology not only provides valuable insights into the experiences, identities, and connections of diaspora members but also offers a comprehensive framework for understanding the complex interplay between mobility and belonging in diaspora oral archives.

title: Monadic Intersection Types, Relationally and Ordered
authors: Zeinab Galal, Francesco Gavazzo, Riccardo Treglia, Gabriele Vanoni
publish: ACM Transactions on Programming Languages and Systems
abstract: We extend intersection types to a computational λ-calculus with algebraic operations à la Plotkin and Power. We achieve this by considering monadic intersections—whereby computational effects appear not only in the operational semantics, but also in the type system. Since in the effectful setting termination is not anymore the only property of interest, we want to analyze the interactive behavior of typed programs with the environment. Indeed, our type system is able to characterize the natural notion of observation, both in the finite and in the infinitary setting. In a second phase, we extend our system with subtyping to incorporate a richer class of effects via monads on preorders instead of sets allowing us to model in particular non-determinism. The main technical tool is a novel combination of syntactic techniques with abstract relational reasoning, which allows us to lift all the required notions, e.g. of typability and logical relation, to the monadic setting.

title: ReTiDe: Real-Time Denoising for Energy-Efficient Motion Picture Processing with FPGAs
authors: Changhong Li, Clément Bled, Rosa Fernandez, Shreejith Shanker
publish: Proceedings of the 22nd ACM SIGGRAPH European Conference on Visual Media Production
abstract: Denoising is a core operation in modern video pipelines. In codecs, in-loop filters suppress sensor noise and quantisation artefacts to improve rate-distortion performance; in cinema post-production, denoisers are used for restoration, grain management, and plate clean-up. However, state-of-the-art deep denoisers are computationally intensive and, at scale, are typically deployed on GPUs, incurring high power and cost for real-time, high-resolution streams. This paper presents Real-Time Denoise (ReTiDe), a hardware-accelerated denoising system that serves inference on data-centre Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs). A compact convolutional model is quantised (post-training quantisation plus quantisation-aware fine-tuning) to INT8 and compiled for AMD Deep Learning Processor Unit (DPU)-based FPGAs. A client-server integration offloads computation from the host CPU/GPU to a networked FPGA service, while remaining callable from existing workflows, e.g., NUKE, without disrupting artist tooling. On representative benchmarks, ReTiDe delivers 37.71 × Giga Operations Per Second (GOPS) throughput and 5.29 × higher energy efficiency than prior FPGA denoising accelerators, with negligible degradation in Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR)/Structural Similarity Index (SSIM). These results indicate that specialised accelerators can provide practical, scalable denoising for both encoding pipelines and post-production, reducing energy per frame without sacrificing quality or workflow compatibility. Code is available at https://github.com/RCSL-TCD/ReTiDe.

title: A Deep Reinforcement Learning-Based UAV Trajectory Planning Method for Generalizable Radar Phantom Track Generation
authors: Kai Liu, Tianxian Zhang, Jiantao Li, Lingjiang Kong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Phantom track jamming is an important branch of radar deception jamming. Research on unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) trajectory planning for phantom track generation (PTG) is challenged by the high-dimensional solution space, non-differentiable objective function, and complex constraints. Existing PTG methods do not incorporate electromagnetic constraints, employ online one-step optimization, and can only generate limited types of phantom tracks. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a deep reinforcement learning (DRL)-based PTG method. In this paper, we formulate PTG as a Markov decision process, incorporate the electromagnetic constraints, and develop the first offline multi-step optimization method for PTG. Additionally, a state data preprocessing technique is introduced to achieve translation and scaling invariance of scenario features, significantly reducing the learning cost while enhancing policy generalization capability. Three representative scenarios are used to visually demonstrate the superiority of the DRL-based PTG method. Furthermore, numerous experiments are conducted to statistically validate the competitiveness of the proposed method in terms of computational speed and phantom track completeness.

title: Enhancing Decentralized Traffic Signal Control via Multi-Agent Graph Reinforcement Learning with Neighbor State Prediction
authors: Ramesh Babu. N, Chennaiah Madduri, Ali Alkwzahy, K. Hemalatha, Priyadharshini. G
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Over the past few years, urban traffic congestion has become one of the most critical situations in current cities, causing significant travel delays, energy waste, and environmental impacts. However, traditional methods often faced various challenges including unstable communication between intersections, and lack of robustness in dynamic traffic situations. To overcome these challenges, this research proposes a decentralized traffic signal control framework based on MultiAgent Graph Reinforcement Learning (MAGRL) which improved with a Neighbor State Predictor (NSP) and a confidence-based fallback. Moreover, each traffic light works as a smart agent that not only observes local settings but also predicts neighboring states when communication is late, ensuring dependable decision-making. Additionally, a graph convolutional Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) module was utilized to jointly capture spatial correlations across intersections and temporal variations in traffic flow, while the boosted Aggregated Advantage Actor-Critic with Neighbor State Predictor (Agg-A2C-NSP) minimized control policies. Finally, the experimental evaluation of real-world data from Monaco specifies that the proposed method highly minimizes the average trip delay to 500 ms, outperforming existing baselines and highlighting its potential for scalable and communicationresilient urban traffic management.

title: AI-Powered Innovation in the Energy Sector: An Empirical Analysis of How Startups Are Transforming the Energy Value Chain
authors: Martino Bonalumi, Davide Chiaroni
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: The increasing digitalization of the energy sector has opened new avenues for innovation, with artificial intelligence playing a pivotal role in optimizing energy systems. Startups, known for their agility and capacity for innovation, are at the forefront of leveraging AI to enhance efficiency, sustainability, and resilience across the energy value chain. However, limited research has explored the specific ways in which startups deploy AI to address energy challenges. This study aims to bridge this gap by analyzing AI-driven applications in the energy sector, categorizing them based on their function and placement within the energy value chain. Using a dataset of 231 startups identified through Crunchbase, the research examines the prevalence of different AI applications, such as predictive maintenance, asset optimization, energy assessment, and grid stability enhancement. The findings reveal that AI adoption is most prominent in the transportation and distribution segment and in renewable energy generation. The study highlights the factors influencing the diffusion of AI applications, including technological readiness, market demand, and competition with established industry players. By providing empirical insights into how startups are shaping the AI-driven transformation of the energy sector, this research contributes to both academic discourse and industry practice, emphasizing the need for supportive regulatory frameworks and investment strategies to accelerate AI adoption for a more sustainable energy future.

title: Interleaved Bidirectional SEPIC-ZETA Converter with PWM-Based Multi-Arm Technique for Low-Current-Ripple Renewable Energy and Electric Vehicle Systems
authors: Reuber Saraiva De Santiago, Menaouar Berrehil El Kattel, Robson Mayer, Raimundo Nonato Moura De Oliveira, Wilkley Bezerra Correia, Fernando Luiz Marcelo Antunes
abstract: This paper presents a three-phase bidirectional interleaved SEPIC-ZETA DC-DC converter that employs an interleaved PWM technique for parallel-connected switches. The proposed converter offers key advantages, including reduced current and voltage ripple at the input and output ports, achieved through a ripple frequency that is six times higher than the switching frequency. Additionally, the size of magnetic components and capacitors is significantly reduced due to a ripple frequency that is twice the switching frequency, resulting in minimized power losses, reduced stress on power components, and enhanced efficiency. The PWM-based multiarm technique simplifies the converter's structure by eliminating the need for inductors proportional to the number of arms, yielding a compact, lightweight, and cost-effective design. The proposed converter is suitable for electric mobility applications, such as in battery electric vehicles (BEVs) and fuel cell electric vehicles (FCEVs), enabling efficient energy management among the various subsystems of the powertrain. A 5 kW prototype, with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{V}_{1}=220 \mathrm{V}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{V}_{2}=450 \mathrm{V}$</tex>, was built and tested, achieving efficiencies of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 8. 1 \%}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 7. 4 5 \%}$</tex> in the forward and reverse power flow, respectively.

title: Cost-Efficient Federated Learning in Massive IoT: A Physics-Inspired Graph Learning Approach
authors: Lindong Zhao, Dan Wu, Kan He, Hongfei Niu, Liang Zhou
abstract: Federated learning emerges as a key enabler toward pervasive intelligence across IoT ecosystems with provable privacy guarantees. While recent efforts on client selection have been made for optimizing its communication efficiency in iterative model aggregation over resource-constrained networks, their scalability fundamentally breaks down in dense deployments. This limitation stems from the NP-hard complexity of congestion-aware scheduling, where co-channel interference creates exponentially growing solution spaces. In this context, we present a novel client selection framework with asymptotic scalability in massive IoT, which leverages the intrinsic graph topology with insights from statistical physics. First, this work formulate a universal client selection problem, capturing both positive network externalities derived from collaborative knowledge exchange and congestion effects induced by co-channel interference. This formulation is then transformed into a node classification task via Ising spin Hamiltonian mapping, establishing an explicit connection between federated learning, statistical physics, and graph optimization. Building on this foundation, we develop a lightweight graph neural solver that adaptively selects clients via recognizing node state with iterative neighbor aggregation of learnable embeddings. Comprehensive experiments validate that our approach maintains state-of-the-art scheduling performance, while scaling to network sizes orders of magnitude beyond what conventional methods can handle.

title: Performance and Complexity Analysis of Terahertz-Band MIMO Detection
authors: Hakim Jemaa, Simon Tarboush, Hadi Sarieddeen, Mohamed-Slim Alouini, Tareq Y. Al-Naffouri
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Achieving terabit-per-second (Tbps) data rates in terahertz (THz)-band communications requires bridging the complexity gap in baseband transceiver design. This work addresses the signal processing challenges associated with data detection in THz-band mimo systems. We begin by analyzing the trade-offs between performance and complexity across various detection schemes and THz channel models, demonstrating significant complexity reduction by leveraging spatial parallelism across subspaces of correlated, typically ill-conditioned THz mimo channels. We also derive accurate theoretical bounds on the detection error probability by incorporating THz-specific channel distributions and accounting for mismatches introduced by subspace decomposition. In addition, we propose a variation of subspace detectors that combines channel-matrix sorting, QR decomposition, and puncturing. Furthermore, under wideband THz UM-MIMO systems, we introduce a channel-matrix reuse strategy that minimizes exhaustive computations while maintaining reliable detection performance within a coherence bandwidth. Simulations over accurate THz channels show that the proposed efficient spatial parallelization schemes yield multi-dB performance gains, while the proposed reuse strategy offers significant computational savings with minimal performance degradation.

title: Joint Microwave and Physical–Chemical Characterization of Olive Trees
authors: Alessandro Fedeli, Andrea Randazzo, Diego Villa, Giulia D’Agostino, Alessandro Alberto Casazza
abstract: The characterization of trees is important to design and apply nondestructive electronic and electromagnetic diagnostic systems for assessing their health status and capacity of producing fruits. This article focuses on the study of the internal trunk of olive trees, from both the electromagnetic and physical–chemical points of view. To this end, a set of samples has been prepared from a freshly cut olive tree. In particular, eight cylindrical samples have been analyzed with a short-circuited coaxial line to measure the radial, longitudinal, and transverse components of the complex dielectric permittivity tensor at microwave frequencies, extracting the corresponding Debye models. The measured dielectric properties have also been compared with those of other tree species, available in the scientific literature. Moreover, the physical–chemical profile of the trunk has been defined, with particular reference to the moisture content, a fundamental factor that influences the dielectric properties. Moreover, the ash content of the same samples has been analyzed, and both the thermal gravimetric analysis and the Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy have been performed to further characterize the considered tree.

title: Enhancing Calibration-Free Stereoscopic Eye-Tracking with the Navarro Aspherical Cornea Model
authors: A.R. Pijpaert, L.J. Van Rijn, R.M.A. Van Nispen, B.W. Van Dijk, A.D. Barsingerhorn, H.H.L.M. Goossens
abstract: Stereoscopic eye-tracking systems provide accurate gaze estimation with minimal calibration. However, their accuracy declines for eccentric gaze targets due to the common assumption of a spherical cornea. Here, we present the first integration of the Navarro aspherical cornea model into stereoscopic eye-tracking algorithms. We evaluated our approach through simulations and experimental data from a 350 Hz stereoscopic eye-tracking system. Simulations demonstrated a significant reduction in gaze estimation error for eccentric targets, with accuracy improvements up to ±1.3°. In real world validation, the aspherical model reduced noise and improved precision to a level comparable with that of a high-end eye-tracking system (EyeLink 1000 Plus). Accuracy gains were not found, probably due to the limited measurement range. Our results indicate that aspherical cornea modeling can enhance the precision and potential clinical use of stereoscopic eye-tracking, particularly for applications involving eccentric gaze positions. Future research should explore extended measurement ranges to fully realize the benefits of this approach.

title: A Survey and Taxonomy of Unambiguous Binary Offset Carrier Signal Processing Techniques for Satellite Navigation Receivers
authors: Ryan S. Cassel
publish: IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine
abstract: While the binary offset carrier (BOC) spreading modulation offers several advantages over legacy modulations, like binary phase-shift keying with rectangular symbols (BPSK-R), for satellite navigation, it introduces a unique challenge: Its auto-correlation function has multiple peaks, which can cause ambiguities or biases in the estimate of propagation delay. This has motivated a significant amount of research into unambiguous BOC receiver processing techniques, whose underlying operating principles vary widely. This article provides a comprehensive survey of unambiguous processing techniques and classifies them according to a taxonomy that gives insight into their fundamental operating principles and design choices. The purpose of this article is to serve as a unified and accessible guide to learning about and understanding unambiguous BOC receiver processing techniques and how they work, to facilitate the informed selection of candidate techniques for one's application of interest, and to provide a framework for future innovation.

title: A Study on Sow Estrus Prediction Using CCTV Footage and Time-Series Data Sampling
authors: Minseo Jo, Sookeun Song, Hyunbean Yi
abstract: This study proposes a method for estrus prediction in sows using object detection and convolutional recurrent neural network (CRNN) models. Previous estrus prediction models have exhibited inconsistent performance due to variations in posture-transition event frequency and ambiguity in detecting transitions. We observed that when a sow changes its posture once, multiple detections of posture changes often occur, leading to an abnormally high frequency of events. To address this issue, the time-series data were resampled at uniform intervals. The resampled time-series data were processed using a double moving average, which served as the input for the prediction model. In 142 of 175 sows, the activity level during the 24 h preceding the estrus detection point by farm managers showed an increasing trend compared with the previous time period. This observed activity trend is consistent with the behavioral characteristics of sows during estrus reported in previous studies. Estrus prediction using the newly constructed time-series data and CRNN model achieved an accuracy of approximately 86%. The proposed method is expected to facilitate more efficient estrus prediction in pig farms, thereby reducing the associated costs and labor.

title: An Open-Phase Fault-Tolerant DTC Scheme for Five-Phase Induction Motor Drives to Mitigate the $XY$ Currents Due to System Asymmetries
authors: Bheemaiah Chikondra, Prashant Kumar, Ali Arzani, Abdul R Beig
abstract: The uncontrolled <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$xy$</tex-math></inline-formula> subspace greatly enhances the high harmonic components present in the stator currents. Researchers have put significant efforts to address this challenge by exploring the utilization of virtual voltage vectors (VVs) in both healthy and post-fault operating conditions. However, it has been observed that the predetermined duty ratios assigned to these VVs are inadequate to effectively counterbalance intrinsic asymmetries. In order to address the above challenges, the variable switching duty ratio-based DTC was introduced in the literature for healthy operation. This paper presents a VVs based ST-DTC technique with variable duty-ratio for healthy as well as faulty conditions. This technique presents a distinct approach compared to conventional methods, wherein the duty ratios of the selected VVs are continuously tuned based on the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$xy$</tex-math></inline-formula> voltage commands generated by closed-loop <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$xy$</tex-math></inline-formula> current controllers at each sampling interval during an open-phase fault condition. This new developed approach brings several benefits, including the effective elimination of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$xy$</tex-math></inline-formula> currents, without adverse effects on the average switching frequency or utilization of the dc link. The proposed control technique is verified by experimental evidence.

title: Nonlinear Control of Statcom Using Input-State Feedback Linearization and Model Predictive Control
authors: Estevão Modolo de Souza, Lucas Frizera Encarnação
abstract: This paper presents a nonlinear control strategy for a Static Synchronous Compensator (STATCOM) based on Input-State Feedback Linearization (ISFL) combined with Continuous Control Set Model Predictive Control (CCS-MPC). The proposed approach directly regulates the DC link voltage while ensuring a grid unitary power factor by utilizing pq-theory. Unlike conventional MPC strategies that rely on PI controllers to generate current references for DC link regulation, this method addresses the nonlinear nature of the system dynamics. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed control, demonstrating accurate DC voltage tracking, reactive power compensation, and high power quality with low Total Harmonic Distortion (THD). The STATCOM successfully maintains a grid unitary power factor under different load conditions.

title: Beyond Visual Interfaces: Extended Reality for Collaborative Industrial Settings
authors: Neven ElSayed, Eduardo Veas
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: With the growing interest in Industry 4.0 and the transition toward Industry 5.0, the application of extended reality (XR) in industrial settings show significant potential. This potential arises from the strong alignment between industrial objectives and existing infrastructure. Drawing from our research with industrial partners, this paper examines the benefits of employing XR in such environments. We present an illustrated use case, which is expanded into a comprehensive list of opportunities and challenges. These insights aim to inform and guide the research community in developing XR adaptive systems that effectively leverage adaptive interfaces and remote collaboration.

title: Real-Time Vital Sign Monitoring and Health Anomaly Detection on Edge Devices Using Lightweight Machine Learning Models
authors: S. Saraswathi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Real time tracking of vital signs is very important to early warn unfavorable incidents in health. Nonetheless, a majority of AI-based health monitoring use cases require cloud based processing, and in addition cloud based processing may lead to the latency, dependence on internet connection, and privacy issues. This paper presents mqtt-health, a new edgecomputing framework for event-driven detection of health anomalies in real-time by means of lightweight machine learning models that reside directly on wearable and IoT devices. The proposed framework enables real-time monitoring of several vital signs (heart rate, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SpO}_{2}$</tex>, temperature, blood pressure, etc.) and detection of anomalies without depending on a cloud infrastructure. Using pruned decision trees, and as supported by our optimization algorithms which implements quantized neural networks, the system keeps low computational overhead and low-energy-cost profile compatible with power constrained edge devices. Experimental results utilizing publicly available vital sign datasets show the proposed models can achieve more than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 1 \%}$</tex> detection accuracy, taking an inference latency of less than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5 0 m s i n m i c r o - c o n t r o l l e r c l a s s d e v i c e s. T h i s}$</tex> system provides a scalable and privacy-preserving solution for continuous patient monitoring, and is well-suited to be used in remote healthcare, elderly support, and outpatient monitoring. In the future, the detection of anomaly will be extended to personalized baselines and the models of above approaches adaptively change in accordance of the patient's health profile.

title:
Toward Clean Energy: Carrier Density Optimization in FAMASnGeI
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    -Based Perovskite Solar Cells
authors: Aniket Verma, Jaya Madan, Kamaljeet Singh, Suman Gothwal, Nikhil Shrivastav, Raghavendra Sridhar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: The aim of this study is to enhance the photovoltaic performance of PCBM/FAMASnGeI3/CuI based perovskite solar cells by further measuring the influence of various acceptors density (N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">A</inf>) and donors density (N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">D</inf>) in the active process. From the difference between N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">A</inf> and N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">D</inf>, it can clearly see the influence of important electrical parameters including short-circuit current density (J<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">SC</inf>), open-circuit voltage (V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">OC</inf>), Fill factor (FF) and power conversion efficiency (PCE). This study shows that small N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">A</inf> changes can improve J<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">SC</inf> and power efficiency. However, too high a value may cause a decrease, reducing V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">OC</inf> and overall performance. Although V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">OC</inf> increases, the pulse intensity from higher N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">D</inf> values affects FF. Its efforts help achieve capacity and clean energy by making energy and efficiency a reality. This study also supports Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure by defining fundamental design principles and developing solar cells, enabling the creation of new products and technologies that can improve solar energy security and performance. Future work should focus on improving the thickness of the system, seeking knowledge and using the design process to continuously reduce defects and improve fixed devices: these findings are useful for targeting sustainable energy, as they provide new insights into perovskites. They provide the development of solar cells with a strong platform for clean energy.

title: Extension Curricularization in Electrical Engineering: Challenges and Formative Potential in Shaping Socially Committed Engineers
authors: Tiara R. Smarssaro De Freitas, Thais Pedruzzi do Nascimento, Raquel Frizera Vassallo
abstract: This article examines the extension curricularization experience in the Electrical Engineering program at UFES, following the 2022 curriculum reform. Extension activities were integrated through three mandatory components where students develop projects under faculty guidance. The study analyzes reports from 2024 and feedback from participating students. Results highlight diverse, formative initiatives-from educational content to socially impactful applications. Challenges include limited thematic diversity, weak integration with existing projects, and rigid workload management. The article proposes pedagogical strategies to improve implementation and emphasizes extension's key role in training ethically and socially committed engineers.

title: System level Reliability modeling of direct-to-chip liquid cooled data centers
authors: Sidharth Rajeev, Venkata Achyuth Kunchapu, Ryan Enright, Tiwei Wei, Srikanth Rangarajan, Bahgat Sammakia
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: The dependable functioning of thermal regulation systems is crucial to facilitating high-performance computation for the future. As more energy-dense racks materialize to accommodate higher computational demands, the air cooling systems struggle with inefficiency, thermal hot-spots, and increased energy consumption. Conversely, liquid cooling is emerging as a viable solution to address the constraints of air cooling technology. This scholarly article focuses on investigating diverse methodologies to evaluate the reliability and availability of cooling systems for a liquid-cooled data center. The system under examination in this manuscript is a rack-level system, encompassing components within the secondary loop. The sole innovative element examined in this investigation is a two-phase liquid cold-plate, whereas all other elements are conventional. The cold plate is innovative in its architecture due to its capability to segregate the liquid and vapor as it undergoes boiling. Notably, the wick configuration diminishes the total pumping energy requisite. The additional novel aspect is the methodology that encompasses a comprehensive evaluation of the reliability of liquid-cooled data centers. A thorough investigation into the reliability modeling of liquid cooling systems is highly necessary. This necessity arises from the demand for the adaptation of liquid cooling systems to accommodate the escalating requirements for power-dense racks. A technologically advanced solution does not attain significance until it is deemed reliable and adaptable. In our investigation, we present a meticulous examination of the reliability of a particular liquid cooling system and underscore the establishment of a methodology to assess and ascertain the reliability, which is presently deficient in the extant literature.In this investigation, we conduct a comprehensive analysis of various stochastic models that are utilized to forecast reliability. Subsequently, we examine the correlation between system availability and the reliability of a novel component that has been assimilated into the system. In the instance of a liquid-cooled cold plate, we delineate the specific failure modes that the system may manifest. We employ the traditionally utilized Failure Modes and Effects Analysis (FMEA) to facilitate this evaluation. In particular, three failure modes-Erosion, Corrosion, and Clogging-are carefully assessed within this discussion. We outline multiple highly effective models that are currently accessible for the quantification of these failure modes. The findings from the analysis reveal the variables that significantly contribute to each of the failure modes investigated in this study.

title: Comparative Study of APF and RRT Obstacle Avoidance Algorithms for PUMA560 Robotic Arm
authors: Kaiyang Ni
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Manufacturing System (ICAMTMS)
abstract: Obstacle avoidance is very important for the safe and efficient working of robotic arms in a complex environment. It has already been used widely in industrial automation, autonomous vehicles, and service robotics. This essay will compare the performances of two classical obstacle avoidance algorithms which are Artificial Potential Field (APF) and Rapidly-exploring Random Tree (RRT) by using the PUMA560 robotic arm model. By building a system with the same static obstacles. The performances of these two algorithms are evaluated through quantitative metrics including the final position accuracy, path smoothness, and time costs. The result of the experiment shows that APF performs well with higher efficiency and smoother path of avoidance, however, this method would be disturbed by the parameters adjusting. While RRT shows robustness in complex environment but the of path of the motion is not as smooth as that of the APF, and it is more time consuming. Parameter sensitivity analysis shows the influence of parameters on the final performance. Based on these findings, engineers may need to consider more while selecting them in different situations.

title: Person Tracking and Fall Detection in 360° Video with Dynamic Perspective Views
authors: Victor Neto, Hamza Bayd, Baptiste Magnier
publish: 2025 13th European Workshop on Visual Information Processing (EUVIP)
abstract: The increasing adoption of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 6 0}^{\circ}$</tex> cameras has revolutionized the monitoring of large and complex spaces, providing comprehensive visual coverage that traditional cameras cannot match. However, this technology poses significant challenges for person detection and tracking, notably due to distortions caused by equirectangular projection. We present a lightweight method for tracking and fall detection from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 6 0}^{\circ}$</tex> video streams captured by a Ricoh Theta X camera. Our approach combines dynamic generation of perspective views centered on targets, person detection using YOLOv8n, pose estimation via MediaPipe, and fall detection logic based on the skeleton aspect ratio. The entire pipeline operates in near real-time on standard CPU hardware, without requiring a GPU. Experimental results demonstrate the system's robustness in real-world conditions, paving the way for practical applications in constrained environments.

title: Prescribed Performance Sliding Mode Control for Vehicle Platoon Using Disturbance Observer
authors: Jing Jiang, Huimin Meng
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: This paper presents a study on the cooperative control of vehicle platoons under predefined performance constraints. First, to handle unknown disturbances, a predefined-time disturbance observer is developed, enabling accurate estimation within a manually set predefined time. Leveraging a new predefined performance function and observer, this paper designed a continuous non-singular sliding mode controller to guarantee tracking errors stay within prescribed bounds during both transient and steady-state operation. Finally, Simulation outcomes verify the superior performance of the novel controller.

title: Application of Multimodal Data Fusion Algorithm in Early Screening of Fundus Diseases
authors: Jia Yao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: This study proposes a multimodal data fusion algorithm based on deep learning to improve screening accuracy. First, a modified ResNet-50 network is used to extract vascular morphological features from fundus color photography and hierarchical structural features from OCT images. A dual-channel three-dimensional convolutional neural network is then designed to model the spatiotemporal characteristics of fundus blood flow in OCT images. A feature fusion module based on an attention mechanism is then constructed to achieve weighted cross-modal feature fusion. Finally, a dynamic weight classifier is used to output probabilistic predictions for five fundus diseases, including diabetic retinopathy (DR) and age-related macular degeneration (AMD). Experimental validation was conducted on a cross-center dataset of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2, 8 5 0}$</tex> patients. Results showed that the algorithm achieved an accuracy of 98.7 % for DR detection, improved sensitivity to 96.6 %, and an F1 score of 98.0 %. The recognition rate for early AMD was <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 2. 3 \%}$</tex>.

title: Probabilistic Solar Power Forecasting Using Monte Carlo Simulation for Multi-Objective Distribution Network Reconfiguration
authors: Caroline Tedesco Santos, Renato Santos Freire Ferraz, Augusto César Rueda Medina, Jussara Farias Fardin
abstract: This paper presents an integrated planning and operation methodology for distribution networks with high PV-DG penetration. The approach simultaneously addresses optimal siting, sizing, and network reconfiguration, while incorporating the stochastic nature of solar irradiance through Monte Carlo simulation. Seasonal and hourly solar power scenarios are generated using historical meteorological data, producing probabilistic profiles for rainy and dry periods. A multi-objective optimization using the MOCS algorithm minimizes active power losses and voltage deviations in the IEEE 69-bus test system. The results demonstrate that the combined strategy achieves up to 30 % loss reduction and ensures operational voltage compliance under realistic variability scenarios. This methodology offers a robust framework for planners and operators in the context of energy transition and smart grid evolution.

title: Impact of Slot Liner Compression on the Total Thermal Resistance of the Stator-Winding Assembly in Electric Motors
authors: Lindsay K. Sutherland, Shanmukhi Sripada, Amy M. Marconnet
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: The increasing demand for high-performance electric motors, driven by the rapid adoption of electric vehicles, necessitates effective thermal management techniques. Efficient dissipation of heat generated in the copper windings is critical for the safety, efficiency, and reliability of electric motors. Heat must be transferred from the current-carrying copper windings to the metallic stator body through an electrically insulating material called the slot liner. But little research has focused on the interactions between the slot liner and the windings in the statorslot liner-winding assembly in terms of dissipating heat from the windings. This study examines the impact of compression of the slot liner on the thermal resistance across the statorwinding assembly considering two common slot liner materials: Nomex<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">®</sup>410 and Kapton<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">®</sup> MT+. To do so, we developed a mock stator-winding assembly by stacking a rigid, grooved copper piece that mimics the windings, the slot liner, and a rigid silicon piece that imitates the stator, along with a reference material used to quantify heat flow through the assembly. Steady-state temperature gradients are established across the stack, and the resulting two-dimensional temperature maps are captured using infrared (IR) microscopy and analyzed to calculate the total thermal resistance across the assembly. Tests are repeated at several levels of compression and with increasing compression, the area-normalized thermal resistance of the winding-stator interface with a Nomex<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">®</sup>410 slot liner decreases by $\mathbf{1 4. 9 \%}$ (from 94 to $80 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \mathrm{~K} / \mathrm{W}$) and with Kapton<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">®</sup> MT+ decreases by 68.0% (from 50 to $16 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \mathrm{~K} / \mathrm{W}$). Ultimately, this research provides insight into the effects of slot liner material and compression level on the thermal management of electric motors and provides guidance on optimum system configuration. Reducing the total thermal resistance of the stator-winding assembly can reduce temperatures within the windings, which, in turn, improves the longevity and efficiency of the motor.

title: Comparative Analysis of Shunt LC Compensator and APOC Technique for Two-Phase Converters
authors: Magno Otton Schneider, Danilo Iglesias Brandao, Gustavo Vieira Barbosa, Israel Divan Lopes da Costa, Gabriel Azevedo Fogli, Thiago Ribeiro de Oliveira
abstract: This paper proposes a comparative analysis of two active power decoupling techniques. The first is the shunt LC compensator, which employs energy storage elements, and the second is the active power oscillation cancellation method, a passiveless control approach. The performance, efficiency, and power density of both techniques are evaluated in a two-phase converter. For the power density assessment, the total converter weight and volume are estimated using a MATLAB-based routine, whereas power losses are analyzed through the thermal module of PSIM software. The performance evaluation is conducted based on experimental results obtained from a controller hardware prototype. The analysis shows that the LC shunt compensator suppresses DC-link voltage oscillations by more than a factor of 7.5, while the control-based technique suppresses them by more than a factor of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2. 8 4}$</tex>. The shunt LC compensator is plug-and-play offering an additional module that can be integrated into the DC-link of any converter. It has higher efficiency than the passiveless control approach in about <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 9 5 \%}$</tex>. In contrast, the control-based technique requires modification of the reference signals to mitigate oscillation, which negatively affects the converter's power factor, but has higher power density than the LC compensator.

title: Deep Learning for Mental Health: Attention-Driven Multilayer CNN for Audio Depression Detection
authors: Salna Joy, B.V. Santhosh Krishna, Siddharth Rajesh, Neethu. P S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Depressive Disorder is a common mental health problem that affects millions of people around the world. This study proposes a Self-attention based Multi-layer Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model to perform enhanced depression detection from audio modality. The model employs a diverse array of filters, kernel sizes, and pooling strategies across multiple CNN layers to capture local features, while the attention mechanism prioritizes emotionally salient parts of the speech signal, such as regions of low energy and lengthened pauses by assigning higher weights. Measured against the RAVDESS and TESS emotional speech datasets, the method attains an F1 score of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 8 1}$</tex>, an accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 3} \%$</tex> and ROC-AUC of 0.96 when using attention, beating the baseline CNN model, F1 score of 0.77 and 83 % accuracy without attention. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of attention-enhanced architectures in detecting depressive cues from speech and support the feasibility of developing real-world, speech-based mental health screening tools.

title: Automatic Annotation Method for Labor Protection Equipment Dataset Based on Improved YOLOv11n
authors: Mingyao Wang, Yilin Bei, Hao Wu
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: The annotation of the personal protective equipment (PPE) dataset is a crucial step in ensuring accurate identification of whether workers are wearing safety equipment correctly. Given the issues of complex backgrounds, small targets, and occlusions present in the actual collected dataset of construction site workers' PPE wear, this paper proposes an improved automatic image data annotation method for the YOLOv11n model. Firstly, in the backbone network, the original Conv module is replaced with an average pooling downsampling Adown convolution module, ensuring lightweight operations while retaining key information to enhance detection performance. Secondly, detail enhancement convolution is integrated into the C3k2 module to construct C3k2_DEConv, improving the model's ability to better restore and preserve image detail information and texture details during feature extraction. Experimental verification shows that the proposed automatic annotation method achieves a mAP50 of 94.3% and an automatic annotation frame rate (FPS) of 75.2 fps per second, representing significant improvements compared to the original network, and proving the effectiveness and practicality of the proposed method.

title: Renewable Generator Innovations: A Review of Axial Designs and Superconducting Advances
authors: Intan Izafina Idrus, Nohaidda Sariff, Pang Wai Leong, Manee Sangaran Al Diagarajan, Puteri Nor Aznie Fahsyar Syed Mahadzir, Lee Yan Kang
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive review of recent advancements in generator technologies for renewable energy applications, highlighting innovations aimed at improving efficiency, power density and reliability. Key contributions include the development of flux-switching permanent magnet generators (FSPMG), where rotor-mounted configurations and optimized stator-rotor geometries enhance electric loading and reduce torque ripple. In axial flux machines, axial flux permanent magnet generators (AFPMG) are shown to outperform conventional radial flux counterparts in low-speed, low-power scenarios due to superior electromagnetic characteristics and structural efficiency. Induction generators are also revisited with improvements, such as brushless doubly-fed configurations and dual-stator topologies offering robust, cost-effective alternatives for variable-speed operations. Furthermore, high-temperature superconducting (HTS) generators are explored for large-scale wind energy systems, addressing the challenge of AC losses while offering near-zero resistance and high current density. The integration of HTS materials in axial flux configurations is proposed as a future direction for achieving compact, high-performance generators. The study underscores the potential of distributed small-scale power generation using advanced low-cost axial flux and superconducting designs, promoting microgrid implementation. Collectively, these developments represent significant progress towards next-generation generator solutions tailored to the evolving demands of sustainable energy systems.

title: A Mobility-Aware IoT-Fog-Blockchain Framework with Queuing and Game-Theoretic Trust
authors: Ayashkant Mishra, Amrendra Singh Yadav, Veena Goswami, Ankit Vidyarthi, Manaswini Nayak, Rabindra Kumar Barik
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: At this point, Internet of Things devices can be found everywhere. These devices are mobile and produce data on a continuous basis. In order for these data to arrive at the intermediate nodes, also known as fog nodes, in an appropriate manner, they require a suitable approach. In this context, the engagement of queuing and haversine functions is brought into play. By utilizing blockchain technology, we are able to store the data in a manner that safeguards it. Despite the fact that there are a number of different ways to upload data and blocks to the blockchain, the majority of the time, these methods are used for financial transactions. For the purpose of controlling the transfer of data from the Mobile Internet of Things device to the Fog nodes, we have utilized queuing and haversine in our current study. The data is subsequently sent from the Fog nodes to the Blockchain nodes after it has been collected. The Game theoretic principle, which is founded on the rudamantary prisoners dilema, is the one that makes the decision on which blockchain node will be chosen. Through the use of randomly generated data from Internet of Things devices and the modification of its location, we have developed a unique architecture and simulated its operation. The various phases of the simulation, which include the Internet of Things (IoT) fog, the blockchain node in the fog, the blockchain mempool in the block, and the administration of transactions and blocks, have all been recorded from our end. Following that, we have analyzed and visualized the results of our work.

title: Thermal Conductivity Evolution of Non-Pfas Automotive Packaging Material Under High Temperature And Humidity Exposure
authors: Yunli Zhang, Pradeep Lall, Daniel Harris
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: The widespread use of PFAS in electronic packaging poses environmental and health risks due to their persistence. Detectable PFAS in water and food, along with health effects, highlight the need for alternatives. While PFAS are crucial in electronics, their impact extends beyond product life cycles. Regulations may phase them out, challenging the industry to find non-PFAS solutions. The interconnected supply chain amplifies this impact. Developing alternatives is vital for reducing e-waste and protecting future generations, making research into nonPFAS materials essential for sustainable electronics.This paper outlines a methodology for assessing the impact of hydrothermal aging on non-PFAS semiconductor electronic packaging materials. The primary focus of this study involves the examination of thermal conductivity for TIMs in its initial state (pristine samples). Additionally, the research delves into the consequences of prolonged exposure to elevated temperatures and humidity on various thermal interfacial materials (TIMs), exploring the aging process. The Arrhenius Equation is also applied to evaluate the aging effect and the temperature effect on activation energy. Activation energy and the evolution of time exponents are reported. While the detrimental effects of PFAS are well-documented, the existing research landscape lacks comprehensive exploration and viable alternatives in electronic packaging. The dearth of non-PFAS solutions in electronic design and fabrication poses a critical gap, especially considering the impending regulatory measures aimed at eliminating PFAS from consumer products. This deficiency is exacerbated by the interconnected nature of the electronics supply chain, where any regulatory action would reverberate across all levels, from individual components to complete electronic systems. This research investigates the mechanical and thermal properties evolution of a number of non-PFAs TIMs when subjected to longterm, high-temperature and humidity exposure. The study explores the thermal conductivity evolution of TIMs in high temperature and humidity environments ($85 \mathrm{C} 85 \% \mathrm{RH}$) and (60 C $60 \% \mathrm{RH})$ for 164 hours. The results will compare with the existing data of non-PFAs, UFs and TIMs.

title: Alyssum: An Augmented Reality-based Interactive Art Reflecting through the Phytoremediation Metaphor
authors: Soi Choi, Jean Ho Chu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: This study explores the recovery of human senses and the visualization of the mind through Alyssum, an experiential work that integrates video and augmented reality (AR), using the process of phytoremediation as its central metaphor. Beginning from the condition of contemporary individuals who lose their unique senses within the uniformity and repetition of social structures, Alyssum visualizes a process in which participants reflect inwardly and engage with their environment through bodily movement. Users interact via a camera with a virtual metal object that symbolizes the mind. Participants begin by inscribing traces onto the metal surface, expressing internal states and initiating a process of introspection. As they continue, bringing their hands together leads to the visual emergence of a new sprout, marking a shift toward sensory restoration. By applying the ecological principle of phytoremediation to interactive art, Alyssum creates a space for contemplating the relationship between humans and nature and seeks to construct a reflective narrative through active user participation.

title: Phasor-Based Dehomogenisation for Microchannel Cooling Topology Optimisation
authors: Hao Li, Peter DØrffler Ladegaard Jensen, Rebekka Vaarum Woldseth, Joe Alexandersen
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Efficient thermal management is critical for highpower electronics, with microchannel cooling providing enhanced heat dissipation in compact designs. Conventional topology optimisation (TO) methods often fail to capture fine-scale features without relying on extremely fine meshes, leading to high computational costs. This study proposes a homogenisationbased TO framework integrated with an on-the-fly phasorbased dehomogenisation technique. The phasor-based method efficiently maps homogenised designs to fine-scale microchannel networks, maintaining continuous variations in channel properties and improving robustness while reducing computational expense compared to the conventional projection-based method. An idealised two-dimensional chip with heterogeneous heat generation is used to demonstrate the integrated design workflow. The homogenisation-based TO is performed on a coarse $50 \times 50 \mathrm{mesh}$, with the phasor-based dehomogenisation reconstructing fine-scale microchannel networks on a $3213 \times 3213$ mesh. The results show that the framework achieves a three orders-of-magnitude reduction in computational cost compared to hypothetical brute-force full-scale optimisation and a $\mathbf{3 5. 3} \%$ improvement in thermal performance over traditional pin-fin designs (the initial guess). Limitations of the current study, such as refining the homogenisation model and incorporating irregular meshes, point to promising directions for future investigations.

title: Weather Classification via BiLSTM and Feature Ablation Analysis on Synthetic Time-Series Data
authors: Chin Kim Gan, Wei Hown Tee, Chia Chao Kang, Mohammadmahdi Ariannejad, Jian Ding Tan, Manee Diagarajan, Intan Izafina Idrus, Mohamad Razif Mohamad Ismail
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: Accurate weather state classification is crucial for applications in solar energy, agriculture, and environmental monitoring. This study compares the performance of Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) networks with classical machine learning models (Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, and Decision Tree) on synthetic weather data, including global horizontal irradiance (GHI), temperature, humidity, and cloud cover. Feature ablation analysis reveals that adding more meteorological variables improves model performance, with BiLSTM achieving the highest accuracy (92.6%) and F1-score (0.91). BiLSTM’s ability to capture temporal dependencies allows it to effectively distinguish borderline weather states, such as partly cloudy versus sunny conditions. While classical models perform well, BiLSTM remains the superior choice for weather classification tasks. Future work will explore real-world datasets and advanced architectures like attention mechanisms to further improve performance.

title: Satellite Image to Map Conversion Using Conditional Adversarial Networks (cGANs)
authors: Srikanth Indrole, L. Navadeeth, P. Koushik Narayan Reddy, Shaista Farhat, M. A. Jabbar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: A Deep learning model that turns satellite images into road maps with the help of a Conditional Generative Adversarial Network (cGAN). A U-Net generator is applied in the architecture to draw details from the road and map, and a multi-scale PatchGAN discriminator reviews the results at several resolutions to enhance both the fineness and accuracy. Adversarial loss works on realism, L1 loss helps with pixel by pixel, and SSIM loss protects the structural elements. The model is designed using the Massachusetts Roads Dataset and it has attained 95% pixel accuracy, along with impressive accuracy and structure similarity. The proposed model provides road masks that are clearer and more reliable, regardless of environmental complexity or lighting conditions. Using this strategy, it is possible to skip manual mapping and support applications in urban planning, navigation, and responding to disasters. In the future, the optimal solution might involve trimming the model's size to make it work more quickly.

title: Modeling and Control of a Six-Phase PMSM Using Two Three-Phase Inverters with Decoupling Influence Analysis
authors: Letícia Duque Giovannini, Arthur de Carvalho Batista Dias, Lenin Martins Ferreira Morais, Gabriel Azevedo Fogli
abstract: This work presents a study on the control of a sixphase Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor (PMSM) using two three-phase Voltage Source Inverters (VSIs), with applications in the field of vehicle electrification. The machine can be modeled as two coupled three phase sets, each connected to an inverter, which is controlled to deliver the necessary power for the rotational speed required by the system. Thus, mathematical modeling is performed, allowing its representation through state-space. After modeling, controllers are designed in a cascade arrangement, consisting of two internal and parallel current loops and an external speed loop. Based on the developed model in this work, a decoupling action is proposed to mitigate the influences between coordinates. An advantage of the proposed decoupling action is no need to use derivative of state variables. To verify the effectiveness of the designed controllers with the decoupling action, digital simulations are conducted.

title: Employing Federated Learning in Satellite Communication Networks for Global Connectivity
authors: Vijaya Kumbhar, Panchami S.V, Varsha. D. Jadhav, S. K. Poongodi, Sumitra Menaria, Jyoti. D. Shendage
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Satellite communication networks are pivotal in achieving global connectivity, especially in remote and underserved regions. However, the centralized nature of traditional data processing poses significant challenges in terms of latency, privacy, and scalability. This study explores the application of Federated Learning (FL) to satellite communication networks to address these limitations by enabling decentralized data processing and collaborative learning across satellite nodes. The proposed framework achieves a 25 % reduction in communication overhead and a 15 % improvement in model accuracy compared to centralized learning approaches, while preserving data privacy. Simulation experiments conducted on synthetic and real-world satellite network datasets demonstrate the framework's ability to adapt to dynamic environments, ensuring robust and efficient connectivity. This research establishes a foundation for leveraging FL in satellite networks to achieve seamless global communication while maintaining user privacy and network efficiency.

title: Study of a Bidirectional DC-DC Stage with Partial Power Processing in a Solid-State Transformer Applied to Extreme Fast Charging of Electric Vehicles
authors: Duarte Manuel Do S. Raposo, Andre Salume Lima Ferreira Leão, Bartolomeu Ferreira Dos Santos Junior, Tiara Rodrigues Smarssaro De Freitas, Walbermark M. Dos Santos
abstract: This paper presents a high-efficiency solution for Extreme Fast Charging (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$X F C$</tex>) of electric vehicles, based on a Partial Power Processing (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$P P P$</tex>) architecture. The proposed system integrates two converters: a bidirectional <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$C L L L C$</tex> resonant converter and a three-branch interleaved converter, both controlled through a Model Predictive Control (MPC) strategy enhanced with the Back-EMF technique to improve voltage reference estimation.

title: How Long Does It Take to Alleviate Discomfort? A Preliminary Study on Reducing Cybersickness in Novice Users
authors: Zhengxin Zhang, Shufang Qian, Yi Wang, Xiao Liu, Chetan Arora, Thuong Hoang, Jingjing Zhang, Henry Been-Lirn Duh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Cybersickness significantly impacts the user experience in VR applications. Locomotion tunneling is a widely adopted technique for mitigating cybersickness in susceptible users. However, there is a lack of research investigating the effects of prolonged use of locomotion tunneling on cybersickness symptoms among novice users. To fill this gap, we used VRChat as our experimental platform. We recruited 24 novice VR users, defined as participants with no prior experience using immersive virtual environments. We collected five days of data within a one-week period. The results indicated that participants exhibited significant mitigation to cybersickness by Day 4. However, a change in the VR scene on Day 5 led to a notable increase in cybersickness symptoms. Qualitative feedback revealed participant-perceived causes of cybersickness and suggested that the effectiveness of locomotion tunneling was limited in some scenarios. Finally, we discussed the limitations of the study and proposed directions for future research.

title: Performance Optimization of Corn Pest and Disease Detection Based on YOLOv11
authors: Yongyue Zhang, Swee King Phang, Jianfeng Che, Wai Leong Pang, Hui Hwang Goh
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering (ICRAIE)
abstract: This study presents a performance optimization method for corn pest and disease detection based on the YOLOv11 model. To address challenges posed by complex agricultural environments, an image clarity enhancement module based on the Dark Channel Prior and K-means clustering was introduced during data preprocessing, effectively improving image quality and feature visibility. Furthermore, the Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) was integrated into the YOLOv11 backbone to enhance feature extraction by focusing on critical spatial and channel information. In addition, a modified Wise IoU loss function was employed to improve bounding box regression by considering object shape and location more comprehensively. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves higher mean Average Precision (mAP) and lower inference time compared to baseline methods, particularly under limited sample sizes. The optimized YOLOv11 model shows strong robustness and efficiency, offering a promising solution for intelligent and precise pest and disease monitoring in agriculture.

title: Multi-Scale and Bidirectional Feature Fusion DETR for Detection of Cocoa Pests and Diseases in Complex Environments
authors: Shiyu Chen, Shaocong Dong, Song Wang, Mingyu Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: Cocoa disease and pest detection plays a crucial role in maintaining stable cocoa production. To address the challenges of complex environmental interference such as uneven lighting, branch occlusion, and fruit overlap during the detection process, an MSR-DETR algorithm for cocoa disease and pest detection based on an improved RT-DETR model is proposed. First, the MSBlock is introduced to replace the standard convolutional blocks in the original backbone network. Through a cross-scale information interaction mechanism among different branches, the model can focus on the details and contours of targets, enabling the capture and fusion of multi-scale features, thereby improving the detection performance for multi-scale objects. Second, the Semantic and Detail Infusion (SDI) module is introduced to replace the simple concatenation operation in the traditional feature pyramid network, enhancing the detection capability for tiny diseases. Finally, a feature fusion module named REPBFAM is designed to improve feature fusion in the neck through multi-scale context extraction and bidirectional feature enhancement. Experimental results show that, compared to the original RT-DETR, the proposed algorithm achieves a 3.2% increase in mAP50, a 1.7% increase in mAP50:95, and a 2.4% increase in Recall.

title: Neural Network-Based Distance Protection Method with Multiple Information
authors: Li Zhang, Shengnan Li, Shoudong Xu, Xin Zhou, Shuyong Li, Qinlei Chen, Xuehua Lin, Mengjun Liao, Nan Meng
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: This paper proposes a distance protection scheme based on three-phase integrated information. By analyzing the corresponding relationship between fault electrical quantity characteristics and protection actions using mutual information entropy, the fault-related features of three-phase currents and voltages during faults are fully explored and utilized. A feedforward neural network-based lockout criterion is then established to accurately identify system faults, overloads, oscillations, PT line disconnections, and information errors. The proposed distance protection scheme based on three-phase current and voltage integrated information is thus developed. Simulation results validate that the proposed scheme effectively addresses issues such as oscillations, overloads, PT line disconnections, and false tripping caused by information errors in intelligent substations.

title: Research on Complex Face Recognition Technologies Based on Deep Learning Algorithms
authors: Shijie Jia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Face recognition has become one of the most widely adopted technologies, playing a crucial role in security, surveillance, authentication, and access control systems. Traditional approaches, often relying on handcrafted features and shallow classifiers, struggle to handle large-scale variations such as lighting, pose, partial occlusion, and facial expressions. With the rise of deep learning, convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have shown remarkable progress in extracting local spatial features, but they still face limitations in capturing longrange dependencies across the entire face structure. On the other hand, Vision Transformers (ViTs) excel in modeling global context and relationships, yet they require large amounts of data and lack strong inductive biases for local patterns. To overcome these challenges, this research proposes a hybrid CNN-ViT framework that integrates the local feature extraction power of CNN with the global attention mechanism of ViT. The model is trained and evaluated using benchmark datasets such as LFW (Labeled Faces in the Wild) and CelebA, which provide diverse samples with real-world variations. The hybrid framework first uses CNN layers to extract robust low-level facial features, which are then converted into tokens and processed by the transformer encoder for global representation learning. Experimental results show that the CNN-ViT hybrid significantly outperforms standalone CNN and ViT models in terms of accuracy of 98.31 %. This demonstrates the effectiveness of combining local and global feature learning, offering a more reliable and scalable solution for face recognition applications.

title: Educational Resources Development for the Future Workforce: From Collaboration Models to Final Release
authors: Galyna Tabunshchyk, Peter Arras, Carsten Wolff, Carolina Cruz, Iuliia Mende
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: The paper describes the process for developing and testing new learning materials in the context of international educational projects. For the WORK4CE project a process and methodology were developed based on a Plan-Do-Check-Act approach with experts in Open Communities of Practice (OpenCoP). The development starts with the formation of the OpenCoP, gathering academic staff and external experts on a topic.
