The OpenCoP will design the specification (containing the description of learning outcomes, content, learning materials, and learning activities, also to test and evaluate the educational resources and didactic formats). The specification is reviewed in a peer review by an internal evaluation board. As a case study the learning module "M08: Life cycle thinking and sustainable management." is analysed which has broad relevance for digital transformation and smart cities.

title: High-Performance Low-Loss Ceramic Filler with Enhanced Surface for Next-Generation Thermal Management in Electronics
authors: Bei Xiang, Jiarui Yan, Kade McGarrity, Anand Murugaiah
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Modern electronic components in electric vehicles (EVs), artificial intelligence (AI), and high-frequency transmission demand higher power, faster data transfer, lighter weight, and compact designs. These advancements increase heat generation and data loss, necessitating thermal management materials with high thermal conductivity, superior electrical insulation, and low loss. Thermally conductive dielectric polymer composites, enhanced with ceramic fillers like hexagonal boron nitride ($\mathbf{h}-\mathbf{B N}$), are key to achieving these requirements. $h-B N$ improves thermal conductivity while maintaining electrical insulation and low transmission loss, though its anisotropic properties can challenge performance. Agglomerated and surface-modified h-BN powders address these issues, enabling uniform thermal performance, reduced viscosity, thinner bond line thickness, and improved adhesion. Surface modification of h-BN enhances compatibility with epoxy resins, reducing viscosity by up to two orders of magnitude and increasing adhesion strength by over $\mathbf{1 0} \boldsymbol{\%}$ compared to epoxy compounded filled with unmodified BN powders. These advancements provide high-performance solutions for next-generation electronics in EVs, AI, and highfrequency applications.

title: Internet of Ai Things (Ioat): a Novel Paradigm for the Edge-Iot Ecosystem
authors: Partha Pratim Ray
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The Internet of AI Things (IoAT) is proposed as a novel transformative paradigm in which every connected device functions as an autonomous AI agent, collaborating over a peer-to-peer mesh to perform on-device perception, inference, and federated learning at the network edge. Departing from traditional cloud-centric AIoT models, IoAT embeds intelligence directly within resource-constrained endpoints-ranging from microcontrollers with neural processing units (NPUs) to graphics processing units (GPU)-accelerated edge servers-and interconnects them via a distributed AI mesh featuring a content-addressed model registry, federated learning coordination, and confidenceweighted inference federation. An adaptive Orchestration Layer leverages service discovery, software-defined networking (SDN)inspired quality of service (QoS) routing, and a domain-specific language (DSL)-driven policy engine to enforce service level objectives (SLOs) and elastic scaling, while a zero-trust security and governance fabric-built on mutual TLS (mTLS), hardware roots of trust (RoT), trusted execution environments (TEEs), rolebased access control (RBAC), and immutable Merkle-tree audit logs-ensures end-to-end confidentiality, integrity, and auditability. We present the first-ever formal IoAT architecture, describe a prototype implementation spanning diverse hardware platforms, and discuss prospective evaluation strategies to assess latency, bandwidth efficiency, privacy preservation, and resilience.

title: Six-Leg Single-Phase to Split-Phase Converter Based on Parallel-Connected Three-Leg Cells
authors: Fábio Xavier Guedes Filho, Cursino Brandão Jacobina, Alan Santana Felinto, Jean Torelli Cardoso
abstract: This paper proposes a single-phase to split-phase AC-DC-AC converter based on the parallel connection of two three-leg cells, suitable for single-phase three-wire systems. The proposed topology allows effective dc-link control, ensuring proper operation even under unbalanced load conditions. A space vector pulse-width modulation (SVPWM) is implemented, enabling efficient switching and improving waveform quality. Control strategy and DC-link voltage analysis are presented. Finally, simulation results and experimental results are presented. The proposed converter is compared with two conventional converters in terms of harmonic distortion and number of components.

title: Federated Data Spaces as an Enabler for Smart City Services - Logistics Use-Case Example
authors: Timon Sachweh, Helen Kuhlmann, Henning Gösling, Thomas Liebig
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: Innovative technologies enable the collection of Smart City data resulting in a lot of heterogeneous data pools. Linking these leads to the development of more complex services, which enables added value services for citizens. Since the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) guarantees extensive data rights for EU citizens, the linking of the above mentioned data pools becomes quite complicated. In order to accomplish this, a variety of different implementations for Federated Data Spaces are currently being developed. Gaia-X is one of the most relevant Data Space architectures and the Eclipse Data Space (EDC) implementation is another. However, they focus on different aspects. Gaia-X solves the problems of data sovereignty and compliant participants and the EDC allows the control of data transfer and interoperable data exchange.With this paper, we want to build an easy-to-use Data Space demonstrator (FedDSGcon), which combines EDC with Gaia-X federation services to take advantage of both technologies. A logistics use-case is used for evaluation purposes, as well as an instruction set to set up FedDSGcon.

title: Traveling from Fiction to Future : Ethical Design Principles for AI-Integrated XR Workplaces
authors: Esha Mahendran
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: As extended reality (XR) technologies become increasingly integrated into workplace environments, ethical and human centered design considerations grow more critical for society. Fictional narratives such as Psycho-Pass, Detroit: Become Human, and Black Mirror provide illustrations of artificial intelligence (AI) integrated systems that adapt to context, sense emotions, and mediate human behavior. Drawing on these speculative sources, this paper seeks to propose a framework of ethical design strategies for XR workplaces in three domains: adaptive interfaces, multimodal feedback, and embodied cognitive support. By bridging fiction and design, the paper advocates for emotionally responsive systems that enhance user agency and well-being while avoiding the pitfalls of surveillance, overload, and autonomy mismanagement. The goal is to reframe dystopian warnings into constructive guidelines that promote inclusive, trustworthy, and sustainable XR work environments.

title: Fostering Critical Thinking through Ethical Dilemmas in Virtual Reality: An Interactive Prototype with 3D Generative Agents
authors: Diego Julian Santos Méndez, Margarita María Pineda Romero, Darío José Delgado Quintero
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: This poster presents the design, development, and functional validation of an immersive virtual reality (VR) environment built in Unity 3D, which integrates conversational agents powered by generative artificial intelligence (GenAI). The objective is to foster critical thinking and ethical reflection among engineering students through interactive simulations of real and speculative ethical dilemmas in product design. Using a narrative backbone that defines the agents’ domain of discourse, the experience promotes situated ethical analysis within engineering and technological design contexts.

title: Minichannel Flow Boiling Enhancement using Femtosecond Laser Surface Processed Stainless Steel Surfaces in Water: Effect of Laser Fluence
authors: Logan Pettit, Josh Gerdes, Andrew Reicks, Craig Zuhlke, George Gogos
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: As electronic and thermal management systems become more compact and power-dense, the need for efficient twophase cooling strategies, such as flow boiling in mini/microchannels, is increasing. Surface modification has been widely explored to enhance its heat transfer capabilities, with femtosecond laser surface processing (FLSP) emerging as a promising technique due to its durability, scalability, and ability to create hierarchical structures in a single step. This study presents the results of a single-channel flow boiling system using functionalized 304 stainless steel surfaces with deionized (DI) water as the working fluid. The surfaces were modified through FLSP, which generates self-organized micro- and nanoscale features, enhancing nucleation site density and increasing surface area for two-phase heat transfer. Three FLSP surfaces were fabricated by varying laser fluence at a fixed pulse count to investigate the influence of surface morphology on flow boiling performance. Each surface was tested up to critical heat flux (CHF) at a mass flux of $455 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{~s}$, and the results were compared to a polished surface as a reference. Enhancement in the maximum heat transfer coefficient ranged from $70.1 \%$ to $178.8 \%$, and the highest fluence sample showed slight enhancements to CHF. Furthermore, the FLSP surfaces significantly reduced the magnitude of inlet pressure oscillations caused by flow instability. These enhancements are attributed primarily to the abundance of potential nucleation cavities that exist in a wide range of sizes. This study demonstrates the potential of FLSP-functionalized stainless steel surfaces as a promising technique for enhancing two-phase heat transfer performance.

title: Multi-Objective Optimization of a Boost Converter in a Photovoltaic System Considering Meteorological Data and Non-Linear Inductance
authors: André Luiz Silva Crivellari, Andre Salume Lima Ferreira Leão, Walbermark Marques dos Santos
abstract: This study presents the optimization of a Boost converter operating as an MPPT in a photovoltaic system, considering climatic data from Vila Velha. The analysis accounts for the influence of the nonlinear inductor, along with other system nonlinearities, on power losses. The optimization is performed via numerical integration of the state-space model using the RKF45 method, with nonlinear elements updated at each integration step. System performance and losses are evaluated under the most frequent climatic conditions observed in the city.

title: AR Visualization of Cross-Attention–Enhanced Biomedical Image Volumes for AI-assisted Disease Diagnosis
authors: Benjamin Freeman, Kuang Sun, Roshan Kenia, Anfei Li, Steven K Feiner, Kaveri A Thakoor
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We demonstrate an augmented reality (AR) visualization of attention maps extracted from our team’s previously developed artificial intelligence (AI) glaucoma diagnosis model. Users can intuitively explore these as overlays on 3D volumetric imaging data from real patients. This allows clinicians to verify that the diagnostic model attends to anatomic regions relevant to the patient’s suspected disease, going beyond existing 2D approaches. To our knowledge, this is the first demonstration of an AR representation of model attention for enhancing interpretability of clinical AI.

title: Physiological Stress Signal Validation Across Desktop and Immersive VR Using the Stroop Task
authors: Nicholas Fisher, Blake Hargrave, Arun K. Kulshreshth
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Virtual reality has emerged as a promising tool for managing stress and promoting emotional well-being. However, building adaptive virtual environments that respond to a user’s stress level in real time requires validated physiological measures that function reliably in immersive contexts. In this poster, we present the design of an upcoming within-subjects study aimed at evaluating the consistency of common stress-related physiological signals across traditional desktop and immersive virtual reality conditions. Participants will complete the Stroop Color-Word Task in both settings while wearing multiple biosensors that capture skin conductance, heart rate, brain activity, and body movement. Both physiological and self-reported measures will be analyzed to assess the robustness of these signals under different levels of immersion. Our goal is to determine whether stress detection techniques from screen-based research can be reliably extended to immersive virtual environments.

title: GenLARP: Enabling Immersive Live Action Role-Play through LLM-Generated Worlds and Characters
authors: Yichen Yu, Yifan Jiang, Mandy Lui, Qiao Jin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We introduce GENLARP, a virtual reality (VR) system that transforms personalized stories into immersive live action role-playing (LARP) experiences. GenLARP enables users to act as both creators and players, allowing them to design characters based on their descriptions and live in the story world. Generative AI and agents powered by Large Language Models (LLMs) enrich these experiences.

title: Situated Embodied XR Agents via Spatial Reasoning and Prompting
authors: Jihun Shin, Hyeonjin Kim, Eunseong Lee, Donghwan Shin, Kwang Bin Lee, Taehei Kim, Hyeshim Kim, Joonsik An, Sung-Hee Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: As AI agents become increasingly integrated into daily life, new interaction paradigms are needed to support their presence as embodied, situated forms. We present a prototype that embeds LLM-powered agents within stylized virtual spaces anchored to a user’s real-world room in XR. The system provides spatial context to the LLM through structured scene descriptions, enabling agents to refer to and act upon their environment. A unified interaction loop integrates voice input, spatial reasoning, and motion planning with shared state across dialogue and gesture modules. This work demonstrates how spatially grounded agents can inhabit XR spaces for expressive, situated interaction.

title: Development of Liquid Metal and Silicon Pin Fin Composite Thermal Interface Materials
authors: Matthew Coughlin, Andrew Clements, Fangzhou Wang, Luke Gyubin Min, Kaiying Jiang, Heungdong Kwon, Mehdi Asheghi, Kenneth Goodson
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: The next generation of high heat flux electronics demand thermal interface materials (TIMs) that balance excellent thermal conductivity with mechanical compliance. This paper focuses on the fabrication and characterization of silicon pin fin and liquid metal (PFLM) composites with target thermal resistance of $1 \mathrm{~mm}^{2} \mathrm{KW}^{-1}$. We micropatterned silicon pin fin wicks ($55 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ thickness, $41-96 \%$ porosity, $1 \times 1 \mathrm{~cm}$ footprint) infiltrated with liquid metal (LM). We utilized high spatial resolution IR cross-sectional microscopy to map the temperature profile, achieving measurement sensitivity of less than $1 \mathrm{~mm}^{2} \mathrm{KW}^{-1}$. To quantify variability between TIMs due to assembly and coppergallium interfacial reactions, we stacked three PFLM composite samples for each measurement. We measured thermal resistances from $2.2 \pm 0.8 \mathrm{~mm}^{2} \mathrm{KW}^{-1}(41 \% \mathrm{LM}-59 \% \mathrm{Si})$ to $5.2 \pm 0.9 \mathrm{~mm}^{2} \mathrm{KW}^{-1} (96 \% \mathrm{LM}-4 \% \mathrm{Si})$. The results are in good agreement with a onedimensional (1D) conduction model and mark a reduction of up to a third from a $51 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ thick LM TIM without pin fins ($\mathbf{3. 2 5} \pm \mathbf{1. 2 4} \mathrm{mm}^{2} \mathrm{KW}^{-1}$). We further show the pin fins precisely control the thickness of the LM. Future work should focus on optimizing the pin fin geometry and making the TIMs resistant to gallium corrosion.

title: Design of a 4 kW Dual-LLC Resonant Converter Featuring a Modified Secondary Side for EV Charging
authors: Luís Gustavo Piva Machado, Gierri Waltrich
abstract: In this paper, a DC/DC converter with a wide output voltage range of 150-1000 V is proposed for electric vehicle (EV) charging, providing high efficiency across the entire range. The converter consists of two LLC resonant converters connected to a center-tapped DC bus, each linked to a three-winding transformer. On the secondary side, a modified rectifier bridge enables both LLCs to deliver power jointly to the load. This bridge uses a reduced number of diodes and only two additional relays for reconfiguration, fewer than many existing topologies, by leveraging a specific transformer connection. The output filter is a passive damped LCL filter that ensures low output current ripple. A theoretical model of the 4 kW-rated topology is developed and simulated for validation, with estimated efficiency exceeding 95% across the entire output range at rated power and reaching a maximum of 98.4%.

title: Evaluation of an Asymmetric Dual-Hop RF-FSO Relay System under the Effect of Atmospheric Turbulence and Misalignment
authors: Utpal Das, Bijayananda Patnaik, Bibhudendra Acharya
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: This study analyses the efficacy of a fixed gain asymmetric dual-hop relay framework utilising the combination of radio frequency (RF) and free-space optical (FSO) methodology. This work calculates precise expressions in closed form for important statistical parameters, which are given by Meijer’s G functions. Key performance metrics such as outage probability, average channel capacity and average bit-error rate (BER) for binary modulation schemes have been analytically derived under diverse atmospheric scenarios. Intensity modulation with direct detection (IM/DD) is employed in the system for optical signal transmission. To provide a more practical approach, probability density function (PDF) and cummilative distribution function (CDF) expression are derived under turbulence and misalignment to verify the theoretical results. The findings also offer valuable information for improving RF/FSO mixed systems when pointing errors are present, which is essential for reliable and effective 6G and beyond communication.

title: CryptoFilter: Privacy-Preserving Traffic Analysis of Weak Transport Layer Encryption at Internet Gateways
authors: Benjamin Mixon-Baca, Diwen Xue, Roya Ensafi, Jedidiah R. Crandall
publish: Proceedings of the 24th Workshop on Privacy in the Electronic Society
abstract: Transport-layer encryption is fundamental to protecting the basic rights of Internet users from tracking, surveillance, and machine-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks by adversaries along the network path. Despite decades of progress in applied cryptography and an increasing adoption of HTTPS, a substantial amount of network traffic continues to lack proper transport-layer encryption, threatening the privacy of end users and the integrity of the networks they inhabit. Researchers and network operators examining the issue, however, face a dilemma – in order to understand and mitigate these risks, they often have to examine the very information they aim to protect, such as sensitive user data exposed in plaintext. This tension raises ethical concerns, impedes research efforts, and limits our understanding of the threats posed by unencrypted traffic.

title: Unsafe by Design? A First Look at Security and Privacy Risks in OpenAI’s Custom GPT Ecosystem
authors: Sunday Oyinlola Ogundoyin, Muhammad Ikram, Hassan Jameel Asghar, Benjamin Zi Hao Zhao, Dali Kaafar
publish: Proceedings of the 24th Workshop on Privacy in the Electronic Society
abstract: Millions of users leverage generative pretrained transformer (GPT)-based language models developed by leading model providers for a wide range of tasks. To support enhanced user interaction and customization, many platforms–such as OpenAI–now enable developers to create and publish tailored model instances, known as custom GPTs, via dedicated repositories or application stores. These custom GPTs empower users to browse and interact with specialized applications designed to meet specific needs. However, as custom GPTs see growing adoption, concerns regarding their security vulnerabilities have intensified. Existing research on these vulnerabilities remains largely theoretical, often lacking empirical, large-scale, and statistically rigorous assessments of associated risks. In this study, we analyze 14,904 custom GPTs to assess their susceptibility to seven exploitable threats, such as roleplay-based attacks, system prompt leakage, phishing content generation, and malicious code synthesis, across various categories and popularity tiers within the OpenAI marketplace. We introduce a multi-metric ranking system to examine the relationship between a custom GPT’s popularity and its associated security risks. Our findings reveal that over 95% of custom GPTs lack adequate security protections. The most prevalent vulnerabilities include roleplay-based vulnerabilities (96.51%), system prompt leakage (92.20%), and phishing (91.22%). Furthermore, we demonstrate that OpenAI’s foundational models exhibit inherent security weaknesses, which are often inherited or amplified in custom GPTs. These results highlight the urgent need for enhanced security measures and stricter content moderation to ensure the safe deployment of GPT-based applications.

title: Advanced Sensor Analytics and Extreme Value Modeling: Dichotomizing Day–Night Variability in Rear-End Collisions on Expressways
authors: Akshay Gupta, Pushpa Choudhary, Manoranjan Parida
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Nighttime driving presents unique challenges and risks compared to daytime driving. This study analyzed rear-end conflicts on expressways and identified thresholds for various conflict indicators under both day and night conditions. Utilizing cost-effective 3D LiDAR technology, renowned for its robustness in low-light environments, this study elucidates the multifaceted influence of various factors on traffic safety dynamics across day and night conditions. Extreme value theory was applied to evaluate safety, incorporating factors like traffic environment and driver characteristics that are often overlooked in naturalistic studies. The analysis also included the effect of percentage oblique width on safety-critical events. Interestingly, drivers experienced about three times higher crash risks during the day compared to night, likely due to increased vigilance and caution at night. These findings offer valuable recommendations for setting headway requirements based on lighting conditions and can help improve advanced driver assistance systems to detect and respond more effectively to unsafe following distances.

title: Enhancing Spacecraft Pose Estimation with Unsupervised Multiview Stereo Schemes And Bayesian Networks
authors: Haoran Yuan, Junfeng Wu, Bojian Shao, Guohua Kang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: In the field of spacecraft pose estimation, complex illumination variations and limited computational resources pose critical challenges. Supervised learning methods achieve higher accuracy but require massive labeled data for training, which is extremely costly to acquire for space scenarios. Meanwhile, traditional non-learning methods, though label-free, suffer from significant performance degradation under complex illumination variations. This paper proposes an end-to-end unsupervised framework for bidirectional optimization of pose estimation and 3D reconstruction. First, an unsupervised multi-view stereo network is designed using a two-stage comparative learning strategy, which is capable of accurately reconstructing the target object from multi-view images to obtain depth information. Then, a feature fusion method based on the attention mechanism is proposed to fuse the depth information into the pose estimation network so as to enhance the robustness of pose estimation. In addition, spacecraft pose constraints are obtained from the pose estimation, which in turn constrain the 3D reconstruction. Finally, the probabilistic inference capability of the Bayesian network is utilized to adapt to different lighting environments. The proposed method eliminates the need for large labeled datasets, suits resource-limited spacecraft, and enables efficient pose estimation using lightweight monocular cameras. Experiments on SPEED, URSO, and a semi-physical platform show state-of-the-art accuracy (42.4% lower median rotation error than SOTA) and real-time capability (19ms/frame).

title: ST-Gesture: Spatio-Temporal Feature Extraction Network for Gesture Recognition Based on Attention Mechanism
authors: Hongchen Tang, Wanyun Chen, Yihui Yan, Yajing Tang, Yueyue Yang, Yuchen Feng, Ximing JIang, Jun Lu, Yong Xu, Qun Fang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Gesture recognition, a crucial technology in human-computer interaction, finds applications across various domains, including smart homes, automotive driver assistance systems, and more. However, existing millimeter-wave radar-based gesture recognition algorithms often face challenges in achieving high accuracy and robustness in complex environments. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a Space-Time Gesture Recognition algorithm (ST-Gesture) that leverages attention mechanisms. The approach first exploits the multi-dimensional information within mmWave radar data cubes. ST-Gesture processes the Range-Azimuth-Doppler (RAD) data to generate three types of spectrograms: Range-Azimuth Map (RAM), Azimuth-Doppler Map (ADM), and Range-Doppler Map (RDM). Spatial and temporal features are then extracted from these spectrograms using an enhanced model that combines Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) with Temporal Convolutional Networks (TCNs). A cross-attention mechanism is employed to fuse complementary information from the different spectrograms, thereby improving recognition accuracy. Experimental results, based on both a self-constructed dataset encompassing diverse environments and positions, as well as public dataset, demonstrate that ST-Gesture outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving up to 99.2% accuracy. Additionally, the system's robustness to environmental and positional variations is thoroughly validated.

authors: Ariel Haziot, Ezio Todesco
abstract: As part of the High Field Magnet programme (HFM) at CERN, the Nb3Sn block coil configuration is a candidate for the main dipole in future large hadron collider as FCC-hh. To reduce the cost, the use of material grading in the block coil is explored by using Nb-Ti conductor instead of Nb<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>Sn in the external low field regions. Different designs are being investigated for dipoles with a target nominal field of 14 T and 12 T. The gain in conductor as well as in AC-losses are reported, together with consideration on operational temperature (1.9 K vs. 4.5 K). Finally, the preliminary design of a Nb<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>Sn/Nb-Ti Short Model Coil (SMC) is presented as a first proof of such a concept of hybrid technology in block coils.

title: Design of A Wireless Passive Micro-Magnetic Stimulator Using Independent Power Control Method of Multiple Channels_supp1-3631044.docx
authors: Wei Xu
abstract: This article proposed a wireless passive micro-magnetic stimulation (WP-μMS) device capable of delivering spatially targeted and quantitatively controllable micromagnetic stimulation across multiple sites. The system incorporates a multiple-frequency resonating compensation (MFRC), engineered to reduce the impedance of the imaginary part of the transmitter circuit when exposed to multi-frequency signals. A hybrid-frequency modulation algorithm is implemented by dynamically adjusting the frequency and duty cycle of pulse-width modulation (PWM) signals driving the dual arms of an H-bridge inverter, generating a synthesized current waveform with superimposed frequency components. Compensation capacitors are strategically integrated into the micro-coil array to enable frequency-selective addressing and assign distinct resonant frequencies to individual coils while minimizing inter-channel crosstalk. The WP-μMS prototype operates at 8 and 10 MHz, with experimental validation confirming its ability to achieve precise spatial targeting and independent power regulation. These advancements establish the WP-μMS as a critical tool for high-precision neuromodulation applications requiring localized and adjustable magnetic stimulation.

title: Pilot-Assisted Angle-of-Arrival Estimation for Wearable Devices in Rician Fading Channels: A Low-SNR Focused Method
authors: Ahmad Aldelemy, Ali Al-Dulaimi, Geili T. A. El Sanousi, Prince O. Siaw, Nazar T. Ali, Viktor Doychinov, Yousef Dama, Raed A. Abd-Alhameed
abstract: Accurate angle-of-arrival (AoA) estimation is critical for precise localisation in wearable devices, particularly in challenging wireless environments such as Rician fading with low signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs). This paper proposes a pilot-assisted AoA estimation technique that integrates pseudo-random permutations and Walsh sequences within an OFDM-based transmission framework. The method preserves phase coherence and enhances spatial resolution by optimising pilot allocation and leveraging advanced signal processing. Comprehensive Matlab simulations show sub-degree AoA errors, with robustness validated in ultra-dense multipath scenarios where the Rician K-factor is less than 3 dB. Furthermore, a lightweight, one-dimensional (1D) convolutional neural network (CNN) reduces residual carrier-frequency offsets by over 30%, highlighting a promising synergy between classical signal processing and data-driven learning. Comparative analysis against state-of-the-art techniques and a discussion of computational complexity are provided, underscoring the suitability of the proposed method for next-generation wearable and IoT direction-finding applications.
