title: Research on S-Shaped Curve Trajectory Tracking of Unmanned Vehicles Based on Active MPC
authors: Peize Li
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: This paper focuses on the complex trajectory tracking requirements of unmanned vehicles and specifically studies the S-shaped curve trajectory tracking problem. To achieve precise control, a high-precision vehicle dynamics model is constructed, and based on this model, a trajectory tracking controller based on Model Predictive Control (MPC) is designed. Through system simulation experiments on the Matla/Simulink platform, the trajectory tracking effect, state error convergence characteristics, control quantity variation patterns, and computational performance are comprehensively tested and analyzed, verifying the algorithm's related performance. Within each control cycle, this controller predicts the vehicle's future state and solves the optimal control problem within a finite time domain to generate an optimal control sequence, ensuring that the vehicle can precisely, smoothly, and safely track the given reference trajectory. The results show that the control strategy used in the experiment not only achieves centimeter-level high-precision tracking during the tracking process but also takes into account control smoothness, constraint satisfaction, and real-time computational performance, while also having energy consumption advantages and strong robustness, providing an effective solution for complex trajectory tracking of unmanned vehicles.

title: Simulation study of a SiC planar MOSFET Structure with Integrated Super Schottky Barrier Rectifier
authors: Jinglong Yan, Xintian Zhou, Yun Tang, Dongqing Hu, Yu Wu, Yunpeng Jia
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: In this paper, a SiC planar MOSFET with integrated super schottky barrier rectifier (SiC SSBR-MOSFET) is investigated through TCAD simulations. This structural innovation completely eliminates bipolar degradation concerns. The proposed device demonstrates superior dynamic performance characteristics. Compared to the conventional SiC MOSFET (SiC C-MOSFET), the key parameters show substantial improvement: input capacitance (C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ISS</inf>), reverse transfer capacitance (C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">RSS</inf>), gate charge (Q<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">G</inf>) and gate-to-drain charge (Q<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">GD</inf>) are reduced by factors of ~2, ~6, ~2 and ~12, respectively. Despite a marginal on-resistance (R<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ON</inf>) increase, the enhancements of remarkable figures of merit (R<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ON</inf> × Q<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">G</inf> and R<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ON</inf> × Q<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">GD</inf> are reduced by factors of 1.8 and 11, respectively) are achieved for the SiC SSBR-MOSFET. The superior performance and ease of implementation position the SiC SSBR-MOSFET as a promising candidate for further power electronics applications.

title: A Self-Powered Sensing Mechanism for Potassium Monitoring in Sweat Using Spore Germination
authors: Yang Gao, Seokheun Choi
abstract: This study presents a novel potassium sensor that harnesses the metabolic activity of germinating spores for real-time, self-powered detection. By leveraging the relationship between potassium concentration and microbial electrochemical output, the sensor effectively distinguishes physiological potassium levels and provides a reliable, discrete visual response through LED illumination. The integration of sonication significantly accelerates spore germination, addressing a critical limitation in rapid diagnostics. This innovative approach enhances sensor performance and eliminates the need for external power sources and complex calibration, making it highly suitable for wearable and point-of-care applications.

title: Design of Energy storage systems and Fuzzy Tilt Controller for improving stability in AC Microgrid
authors: Madhab Chandra Das, Sarat Chandra Swain, Sunil Kumar Bhatta, Biranchi Kumar Mahala
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: The design and modelling of energy storage systems (ESS) such as battery power storage system and ultra-capacitor are addressed in this research article for improving frequency profile an AC microgrid. Further, this research article demonstrates and models a resilient Fuzzy tilt control scheme to act secondary control path for microgrid’s load frequency regulator (LFR) model. This proposed controller does necessary control action once the disturbance occurs in the microgrid scenario. This aims to pertain nominal grid frequency under any type of electrical hazards. The effectiveness of the Fuzzy tilt controller also has been compared over universal Fuzzy PID and PID controllers in constraint to the frequency stabilization synthesis. Further, the potential of the incorporated ESS are also well investigated for stabilization improvement in microgrid. The projected Fizzy tilt controller parameters are obtained critically with suggesting a Sine Cosine Algorithm (SCA). To highlight nature of the SCA technique, its optimal attitudes are compared to the well existing PSO and GA algorithms. At last, the stability in microgrid performance is synthesized under the influence of the energy storing devices.

title: Analysis of Thermal Characteristics According to Semiconductor Package Structure and Application
authors: Youngsang Cho, Wonsik Shin, Moonseob Jeong, Junso Pak, Seungwook Yoon, Ilryong Kim
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: A semiconductor packaging process is necessary to connect the semiconductor components to the applications that use them and the silicon chip. The chip is produced in various types of packages to meet the application requirements, and differences in the structure and materials of these packages can affect the thermal characteristics of the chip. The heat generated by the chip first dissipates through the package and then transfers system. To enhance the efficiency of the heat dissipation system, it is crucial to understand the thermal characteristics of the package, where the primary heat diffusion occurs. This paper analyzes and compares the thermal characteristics of different packages used in mobile Application Processor (AP), including stacked Package-On-Package (PoP), Flip-Chip Ball Grid Array (fcBGA), and fcBGA with a Heatslug (fcBGAH) used in automotive and datacenter applications. Typically, the thermal resistance value of a package is used as an indicator of its intrinsic thermal characteristics. However, the thermal resistance parameter varies not only based on the package structure but also depending on the external thermal environment of the system in which it is mounted, as well as the floorplan design of the heat source. Therefore, the thermal resistance value does not solely represent the package structure but serves as a comprehensive thermal characteristic indicator that includes specific environments and scenarios. This paper explores a method for defining the structural and material thermal characteristics of the package. It defines the inherent thermal characteristics of each package in terms of its vertical heat transfer rate and horizontal heat diffusion rate. Additionally, the paper also analyzes the sensitivity of the thermal characteristics of each package type to changes in the external heat dissipation environment.

title: A Spatial Pose Detection Method for Scrapers Based on Planar Vision and Laser Range Fusion
authors: Senqi Xie, Qiaomu Xu, Jinglei Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Advanced Manufacturing Technology and Manufacturing System (ICAMTMS)
abstract: In the automated quenching process of scraper-type workpieces, the accuracy of initial pose detection directly determines the quality of subsequent operations. To address the issues of high equipment costs, complex calibration procedures, and maintenance difficulties in existing stereo vision positioning systems, this paper proposes a three-dimensional pose detection method that integrates monocular planar vision with laser displacement sensing. A heterogeneous sensor fusion framework is established by combining the two-dimensional contour features of the scraper, captured by a planar camera, with high-precision Z-axis displacement data acquired from a laser displacement sensor[1][3][7]. A geometric key-point matching algorithm is developed to extract the two-dimensional coordinates of critical edge points of the scraper, which are then combined with depth information to compute the three-dimensional pose parameters through spatial coordinate mapping. Experimental results show that within a detection area of 1500 mm × 1500 mm, the method achieves horizontal and vertical positioning errors of less than ± 2 mm, and angular deviations within ±3°[6][12][15], while reducing system cost by 80% compared with conventional stereo vision systems. Moreover, the proposed approach eliminates the need for complex vision modeling and sample training. This method provides a cost-effective and efficient solution for rapid positioning of large metal components in industrial settings.

title: A Hybrid Approach to Financial Analysis: Integrating Machine Learning with Blockchain for Transparency and Efficiency
authors: Manthan Gujar, Parth Daware, Arnav Sakharkar, Princy Diwan, Soubhagya Ranjan Mallick, Rakesh Kumar Lenka
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: Stock market prediction is a critical aspect of financial decision-making, traditionally relying on statistical models that often fail to capture complex market dynamics. With advancements in artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML), and blockchain technology, predictive models have significantly improved accuracy and reliability. This paper proposes an AI-powered stock prediction system that integrates ML techniques, sentiment analysis, and blockchain security to enhance forecasting and data integrity. Historical stock data is analyzed using machine learning algorithms, and financial news and social media sentiment analysis are performed to improve prediction accuracy. Additionally, blockchain technology ensures data transparency and prevents manipulation by securely storing financial records and AI-generated predictions. The proposed system also features a user-friendly dashboard for real-time stock visualization and interactive analytics. Challenges such as data privacy, computational efficiency, and market volatility are discussed, along with future directions focusing on reinforcement learning, improved sentiment analysis, and multi-asset investment strategies. Integrating AI and blockchain in stock forecasting provides a secure and transparent approach to financial market analysis, aiding investors in making informed decisions.

title: Comprehensive Review of Battery Degradation in Vehicle-to-Grid Application
authors: Leandro de Abreu Zilinski, Francisco Joaquim de Souza Neto, Vinicius Madureira, Joao Francisco Justo, Vanessa Ferreira Dalborgo
abstract: As the world seeks cleaner and smarter energy solutions, electric vehicles (EVs) are emerging as key players in reshaping energy systems. Bidirectional charging technologies enable EVs not only to recharge but also to return energy to the grid, enhancing flexibility and sustainability. However, frequent energy exchanges accelerate battery degradation, reducing lifetime and affecting economic feasibility. This review examines bidirectional charger topologies, battery aging mechanisms, and predictive models, highlighting both calendar and cycle aging. Reported studies indicate that lithium-ion batteries typically reach end-of-life (70-80% of initial capacity) after 1,000-3,000 cycles under V2G duty, with lifetime strongly dependent on depth of discharge, state of charge, temperature, and charge/discharge rate. High DoD (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>80 \%$</tex>) and C-rates above 2 C can shorten lifetime by over 40 %, while optimized charging strategies may extend service life by up to 25 %. By consolidating quantitative data and modeling approaches, this work provides valuable guidance for researchers, manufacturers, and grid operators in designing resilient and economically viable EVbased energy infrastructures. Future work will focus on implementing battery systems with multiple chemistries, simulating their degradation under V2G duty using MATLAB/Simulink, and performing comparative analyses across technologies.

title: Automation and Monitoring of Electric Vehicle Charging Stations Using Node-RED
authors: Nathan De Oliveira Martins, Phillipp De Souza Gama Lavor, Andre Luiz Marques Leopoldino, José Antenor Pomilio, Joel Filipe Guerreiro
abstract: Node-RED is a widely-used visual programming environment for industrial automation, monitoring, and control. This study investigates how the open source tool Node-RED can be applied to control and monitor electrical charging stations by integrating various communication protocols, with emphasis on the Controller Area Network (CAN) bus. The implementation utilized a Vector controller that executes the Node-RED service locally, enabling bidirectional communication with power electronics. The results demonstrate that the platform simplifies system integration, reduces technical complexity, and improves operational efficiency.

title: Adaptive Dynamic Scheduling Strategy of Multiple Large Language Models for Scientific Literature Classification Tasks
authors: Xiangyu Li, Yujie Deng, Qiyu Liu, Yingfan Gao, Gexiang Zhang, Ming Zhu
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: The rapid expansion of scientific literature poses significant challenges for information organization and retrieval, particularly in adapting to diverse academic domains. Conventional single-model approaches often lack the flexibility and generalization required for effective cross-domain classification. This study proposes BSL-LLMs (BERT-based Scheduling for Large Language Models in Scientific Literature), a dynamic multi-model scheduling framework for scientific literature classification. The method integrates a fine-tuned BERT model for coarse-grained label prediction with a dynamically updated expert selection strategy to route each query to the most suitable LLM from a pool of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5}$</tex> pre-trained models. An adaptive probability matrix and entropy-based regularization are employed to balance specialization and exploration, while a confidence-weighted fusion mechanism combines outputs from BERT and the selected LLM to enhance decision reliability. Experiments on the CSL (Chinese Scientific Literature) dataset show that BSL-LLMs achieves an average classification accuracy of 76.8 %, outperforming individual LLMs and traditional deep learning baselines. The framework primarily relies on small-parameter models, reducing computational cost without compromising accuracy. These results validate the effectiveness of the proposed adaptive scheduling strategy in improving both classification accuracy and generalization for scientific literature tasks. The framework shows potential for extension to other domain-specific applications, including question answering and summarization.

title: Multimodal Machine Intelligent Techniques for Cognitive Behavior Monitoring and Feedback System
authors: Dhanraj, Arun Biradar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Recent advancements in multimodal artificial intelligence has enabled non-invasive, real-time monitoring of human cognitive stress by integrating physiological, behavioral, speech, and gesture data. This survey systematically reviews advances in machine learning models-particularly neural and attention-based architectures-for cognitive load, fatigue, and affect detection using wearable sensors, speech and facial cues, and behavioral interfaces. It examines the datasets, resourceefficient system designs, and feedback frameworks, highlighting best practices and real-world challenges such as data integration, interpretability, and scalability. Comparative insights reveal that multimodal fusion significantly enhances estimation accuracy and dynamic feedback but also introduces new technical hurdles. The review concludes by outlining the limitations of current research-including generalization, deployment feasibility, and data privacy-and suggests future directions for robust, adaptable, and user-centered cognitive monitoring systems.

title: Rapeseed Growth Stage Identification Based on an Improved SegFormer Model
authors: Xinmeng Liu, Chenglong Li, Yang Tian, Xiaoyong Sun
publish: 2025 5th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Manufacturing (AIIM)
abstract: In rapeseed breeding and variety experiments, plot division and planting is the key link of scientific experimental design, and its core goal is to reduce environmental errors and improve the reliability of experimental results. However, due to the differences of rapeseed varieties and environmental conditions in different plots, the growth process of rapeseed is often inconsistent, and the rapeseed in different plots is in different growth stages. In order to solve this problem, this study proposed a rape growth period recognition model GA-Segformer based on improved Segformer, which can efficiently and accurately identify the growth period of rape in each plot, thus improving the recognition efficiency of growth period. In the model design, GASegformer has been improved in many aspects: firstly, GGCA global grouping coordinate attention mechanism is introduced to enhance the model's attention to key features, thereby improving the detection accuracy and segmentation performance; Secondly, the improved ASPP multi-scale feature extraction module is added to obtain rich context information through hole convolution of different scales, which further improves the performance of the model. In addition, in terms of loss function, the advantages of CrossEntropyLoss and Focal Loss are combined to effectively optimize the training effect of the network. The comparative experimental results show that GA-SegFormer outperforms the traditional SegFormer model in mIoU and mDice, with an increase of 0.83 and 0.44, respectively. The experimental results show that the method can solve the recognition problem caused by the difference of rape growth period in different plots in the same plot, and can meet the application requirements of automatic recognition of rape growth period.

title: Stacked Ensemble Learning for Neuroblastoma Prediction Using Gene Expression Profiles
authors: Sekar K, Sanjay S, Devendar Rao B, Sanjayan S, Sharath Kandhan B A, Dheepa T
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Neuroblastoma is one of the most prevalent pediatric solid tumors, characterized by high heterogeneity in progression and clinical outcomes. Accurate prediction of survival and risk stratification remains a critical challenge in pediatric oncology. This study proposes a stacked ensemble learning framework that integrates Random Forest, Extreme Gradient Boosting, and Multi-Layer Perceptron models to improve prognosis prediction using gene expression data from publicly available repositories. The proposed model leverages the complementary strengths of base learners to achieve robust generalization while addressing the challenges posed by high-dimensional, sparse, and noisy genomic features. Both single-output and multi-output prediction strategies were investigated, with results showing that while multi-output modeling experienced slight performance degradation due to overlapping but distinct feature spaces, it offered a unified framework for predicting multiple outcomes simultaneously. Experimental evaluations demonstrated the superiority of the ensemble compared to individual models, highlighting its potential utility in clinical decision support. Future work will focus on multi-omics integration, model interpretability, and validation across larger and more diverse cohorts.

title: Quantum-Enhanced Reflection Equivariant Neural Networks for Predicting Rutting in Pet Bituminous Layers Under Load and Temperature Variations
authors: P. Senthil Pandian, J. Jean Justus, Rudresh Shah, Suwarna Gothane, D. Revathi, K. E. Eswari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The accurate prediction of rutting behavior (RB) in bituminous pavements under fluctuating dynamic and static loads at various temperatures is crucial for the durability and performance of road infrastructure. State-of-the-art methods such as empirical models and traditional machine learning techniques often fail to capture the complex interactions between material properties, loading conditions, and temperature variations, leading to less reliable predictions. This paper proposes a novel approach combining a Reflection Equivariant Quantum Neural Network (REQNN) with the Human Memory Optimization Algorithm (HMOA) to optimize the hyperparameters of the model. On integrating quantum machine learning (QML) techniques, the REQNN can account for symmetries and interactions in the data, enhancing its ability to predict rutting behavior more accurately. The HMOA optimizes the model's hyperparameters by balancing exploration and exploitation, inspired by human memory processes. This method aims to improve the prediction accuracy and reliability of PET-bituminous pavements under various loading and temperature conditions. The REQNN-HMOA method outperforms others with a rutting depth of 4.8 mm and 95% accuracy, showing superior predictive capabilities, lower errors, and enhanced material strength and stiffness under varying loading conditions.

title: Comparative Analysis of SARIMAX and LSTM Models for Fisheries and Multivariate Time Series Forecasting
authors: Zar Zar Oo, Win Lelt Lelt Phyu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: Forecasting techniques are essential for sustainable fisheries management as they enhance planning, resource allocation, and long-term decision-making. This paper evaluates the performance of two widely used models, SARIMAX and LSTM, for multivariate time series forecasting. SARIMAX is well-suited for capturing seasonality, linear trends, and incorporating exogenous variables, while LSTM excels at modeling complex non-linear dependencies and long-term temporal patterns. The study applies both models to ten datasets, including real-world fisheries data from Myanmar (Auk A Lal Bote and Yin Sae Lease Areas) and benchmark datasets such as Daily Delhi Climate, Microsoft Stock, and Power Consumption, in order to test generalizability across domains. Model performance was assessed using RMSE, MAE, MAPE, and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. Experimental results reveal that SARIMAX consistently outperforms LSTM on small, seasonal fisheries datasets due to its strength in capturing structured patterns and exogenous influences, whereas LSTM demonstrates superior accuracy on benchmark datasets with continuous, complex, and highly non-linear characteristics. These findings highlight the importance of aligning model selection with dataset properties, making SARIMAX more practical for short-term fisheries forecasting and LSTM more effective for dynamic and volatile time series.

title: Study, Design and Implementation of a Single-Phase Double-Conversion Online Transformerless Uninterruptible Power Supply Prototype
authors: Murilo Meneghetti Caramori, Matheus Schramm Dall'Asta, Ion Leandro dos Santos, Mateus Nava Mezaroba, Antonio Luiz Schalata Pacheco, Marcos Didjurgeit, Samir Ahmad Mussa, Telles Brunelli Lazzarin
abstract: This paper presents the study and implementation of a single-phase double conversion transformerless uninterruptible power supply system. The proposed online UPS topology is recommended for use in mission-critical operations. Initially, the converters were designed based on theoretical static and dynamic analysis, aiming for a simple and low-cost solution by minimizing the number of semiconductor devices. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$127 / 220 ~\mathrm{V}$</tex> input stage consists of a Vienna double-booster rectifier for power factor correction. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$48 / 96 ~\mathrm{V}$</tex> battery bank is managed by a full-bridge ZVS-PS-DC-DC step-up converter, and the output stage uses a half-bridge inverter to deliver a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$127 / 220 ~\mathrm{V}$</tex> sinusoidal voltage with low harmonic distortion. Experimental results are presented to validate the proposed approach. The implemented control strategy operated successfully, maintaining a stable DC link, achieving a power factor of 0.98, and delivering a sinusoidal output voltage under a power load step.

title: Coordinated Sizing of Multiple Energy Storages in Stand-alone Microgrid: A Time-Frequency Framework
authors: Shutong Chen, Luan Chen, Zhongjie Guo, Weihao Hu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Power Energy Systems and Applications (ICoPESA)
abstract: All-renewable energy systems including stand-alone microgrid are sensitive to the randomness of sustainable energy resources. This paper sizes multiple energy storages in standalone microgrids to handle the multi-timescale fluctuations of renewable energy. Firstly, the frequency analysis is applied to the renewable energy output sequence to extract key characteristic frequencies, which are then converted to representative timescales. Then, a coordinated optimization problem is established to size multiple energy storages, considering the power and energy balance at different timescales, as well as the state-of-charge’s consistency. Finally, the simulation results show that the proposed method effectively captures the multi-timescale fluctuation characteristics of renewable energy and realizes coordinated optimization of multiple energy storages in different timescales, enhancing the economy of the system.

title: Winding Connection and Gauge Analysis for a 16/12 Switched Reluctance Motor
authors: Rolando R. Caicedo Castro, Vinicius A. de Abreu Batista, Raul G. Intriago-Velasquez, Bruna Aderbal de Oliveira, Marcelo Vinícius de Paula, Tárcio André dos S. Barros
abstract: Switched reluctance motors (SRMs) are attractive for vehicle electrification due to their mechanical simplicity, robustness, competitive power density and cost. This paper studies how conductor gauge, coil connection and slot fill factor interact to shape the electromagnetic performance of a 30 kW four-phase 16/12 SRM. Starting from an initial design, nine winding variants are evaluated while varying fill factors. Ansys Motor-CAD and finite-element simulations are used to produce speed and power envelopes, detailed current and torque waveforms at the design operating point and determine the temperatures in the motor. Results show that increasing turns and appropriately selecting wire gauge can raise the machine's average electromagnetic and shaft torque by up to 5% and also influence the maximum power, while keeping efficiency above <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 3 \%}$</tex> and maintain the temperature in the motor under the thermal limits of the insulation coatings. Augmenting average torque can also cause an increase in torque ripple by up to 58% in the studied case. The findings demonstrate that simple, manufacturer choices in winding arrangement and conductor sizing provide a practical means to tune torque, power and torque ripple for SRM applications.

title: Combined On-Chip Ion-Concentration Polarization-Based Biomolecule Preconcentration and Solution Exchange Operations Toward Enhanced Biosensing
authors: Sinwook Park, Daniel Kaufman, Hadar Ben-Yoav, Gilad Yossifon
abstract: This work presents a novel approach for on-chip sample preprocessing by combining two key on-chip operations for enhanced biosensing: ionic concentration-polarization (ICP)-based biomolecule preconcentration and buffer exchange. Preconcentration increases local target biomolecule concentration, enhancing biosensing sensitivity, while buffer exchange replaces the sample—potentially containing inhibitory molecules (e.g., those affecting electrochemical sensing)—with a chosen buffer to optimize sensing conditions. The chip is designed to release the washed, preconcentrated biomolecule plug into a downstream on-chip sensing chamber with minimal dilution, maximizing signal enhancement. After allowing sufficient diffusion time for the released molecules within the chamber, a ~55-fold enrichment of the target molecules and ~67-fold depletion of the neutral interferents from their initial levels were achieved. Future work will explore the applicability of this approach for various on-chip sensors, including electrochemical sensing and immunoassays.

title: Reconstructing Reality over Time: From Drone Capture to Timelapse Gaussian Splatting
authors: Jaehong Kim, Srinivasan Seshan, Anthony Rowe
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: We present a system for reconstructing and visualizing time-varying 3D scenes from multi-day drone imagery using Gaussian Splatting (GS). While existing Gaussian Splatting methods excel at static or short-term dynamic scenes, long-term outdoor capture presents new challenges due to temporal inconsistencies and computational overhead when processing thousands of images across days. We introduce an automated alignment pipeline combining GPS-guided spatial matching, geo-registration, and multi-stage ICP refinement to enable temporally consistent reconstruction without manual intervention or physical markers. Applied to our 30-day construction site dataset, our method demonstrates photorealistic timelapse reconstruction and interactive novel view rendering through a web-based client. This case study shows how 3DGS can be extended to real-world long-term scene monitoring applications.

title: Design-Simulation-Improvement of Thermal Management System Combining Two Passives Cooling for Electromechanical Actuators in the Aerospace Industry
authors: M Leopold, Nzonou, Attarzadeh, Faridreza, Xu, Jiajun
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: This study addresses the critical challenge of overheating in Electromechanical Actuators (EMAs) used in the aerospace industry, where they play a vital role in flight control, landing gear systems, and door actuation. While EMAs are favored over traditional actuators for their compact and lightweight design, their high power density results in significant heat generation during operation, posing a risk to reliability and performance. To mitigate this issue, a thermal management system (TMS) employing a dual passive cooling approach was investigated. The system integrates Phase Change Material (PCM) to absorb heat from the motor, along with heat pipes to transfer excess heat to a cooler external surface for dissipation. Using COMSOL Multiphysics’ heat transfer module, various designs were simulated with three distinct PCM thicknesses, both with and without heat pipes, under two different condenser cooling temperatures. The results highlight that an inverse Christmas tree fin design with 15 mm PCM layers on the inner and outer shells of an aluminum casing, combined with heat pipes on the outer shell, effectively maintains motor case temperatures below $\sim 330 \mathrm{~K}$ - well within safe operational limits. This configuration allows the PCM to remain in a solid-liquid mixture state for up to five operational cycles, each generating 340.8 W of heat, thereby significantly enhancing the EMA’s thermal performance and operational longevity.

title: Analytical and Experimental Methods for Junction Temperature Estimation in Power Semiconductor Modules
authors: David L. Valentim, Ádrian L. S. De Oliveira, Gabriel A. F. De Oliveira, Allan F. Cupertino, João V. M. Farias, Heverton A. Pereira, João H. De Oliveira, Erick M. S. Brito
abstract: Junction temperature is a critical parameter for the reliability of power modules, especially with the advancement of more powerful and efficient converters. This article compares different methods for its determination: direct methods, such as infrared thermography and optical fiber sensors; indirect methods, based on thermosensitive electrical parameters (TSEPs) and the NTC (Negative Temperature Coefficient) thermistor; and analytical approaches through electrothermal simulations. The experimental results demonstrated a low discrepancy among the junction temperature estimation techniques. For direct measurement methods, the error obtained was approximately 1.72%. In the case of indirect measurements using the NTC thermistor, a maximum error of 2.53 % was observed in comparison with thermography. In the electrothermal simulation, considering a range of possible values for the thermal resistance of the heat sink, it was verified that the actual value lies within this interval when comparing the results obtained with the sensor method to estimate the average junction temperature of the IGBT. Regarding the TSEP method, it was found that the collector-emitter voltage (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{C E}$</tex>) measurement circuit exhibits high accuracy, with errors close to 2%. However, for estimating the junction temperature of the IGBT, the results indicated that the tested module requires a new characterization due to its aging.

title: A Portable Palmtop Dielectric Blood Coagulometer with a Single-Chip Multichannel Microfluidic Sensor
authors: Christopher A. Delianides, Hanif Alizadeh, Calvin Abonga, Michael A. Suster, Pedram Mohseni
abstract: This paper presents a portable, palmtop, battery-operable, dielectric blood coagulometry platform incorporating a single-chip, four-channel, microfluidic sensor. The system incorporates building blocks for generating the sensor excitation signal at 1 MHz, performing multichannel multiplexed impedance measurements, controlled heating of the sensor to a target temperature of 37 °C, and plotting the output data in real time on a 4.3-inch touchscreen display, all within a 17 cm × 9 cm × 5 cm 3D-printed enclosure and weighing ~470 g. The system dissipates ~2 W during active testing and is powered by either a 5-V USB-C input or a 6-Ah, 3.7-V lithium polymer (LiPo) battery, permitting continuous operation for up to 11 hours. When measuring fixed test impedances across all four channels, the system exhibits an excellent agreement with an Agilent 4294A impedance analyzer, with rms errors of ≤0.10% over a capacitance range of 47–330 pF and ≤0.37% over a conductance range of 2.13–10 mS. The system functionality is further evaluated in experiments involving healthy human whole blood samples that are in vitro-treated with heparin and tested in two uncoated and two tissue factor (TF)-coated microchannels of the sensor along with untreated samples. With heparin being an anticoagulant, the system expectedly shows a significant prolongation of coagulation time for heparinized blood samples compared to untreated ones with uncoated microchannels. However, with TF-coated microchannels, there is no significant difference in the coagulation time between untreated and heparinized blood samples due to a strong procoagulant effect of TF. This miniaturized, whole blood-based platform has significant potential for rapid assessment of hemostasis using microliter-range sample volumes at the point-of-need.

title: Application of AI Tools in Project Stakeholder Management
authors: Ieva Vinkšnaitė, Meda Andrijauskienė
publish: 2025 IEEE European Technology and Engineering Management Summit (E-TEMS)
abstract: In these progressive times, the market is constantly filling up with innovative technologies that inspire experts to explore its wider use. Project management is not an exception and artificial intelligence is applied to perform complex tasks, thereby adding value to individuals and organizations who are actively involved in the projects. The main aim of this study is to identify the benefits of implementing artificial intelligence tools in improving the stakeholder management performance domain. To achieve this aim, a scientific literature review and a semi-structured interviews with professional project managers were carried out. The results reveal 9 AI tools that enhance project stakeholder management processes. These tools help in identifying stakeholders, creating visuals and information layouts, meetings summaries, to-do lists and transcriptions. Also, they are useful for information search and text generation, stakeholders’ feedback processing, document drafting, creating communication plans and writing emails. To summarize, AI technologies are proved to save project managers’ time by automating the routine tasks and assure stakeholder satisfaction. The study presents the current level of digital transformation and gives practical, real case recommendations on AI integration for a more effective project stakeholder management.

title: Enhanced Algorithm for Myanmar Syllable Normalization in Poetic Text Classification
authors: Khaing Su Latt, Myo Khaing
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Advanced Information Technologies (ICAIT)
abstract: Poetry classification has been studied in many languages, yet research on Myanmar poetry remains scarce due to limited resources and linguistic complexity. The diversity in syllable representations within the Myanmar script presents difficulties across multiple Natural Language Processing tasks due to inconsistent spellings of phonetically similar syllables. Traditional machine learning methods and transformer-based embedding, often fail to capture the unique rhythm, rhyme schemes, and structural depth of poetry, particularly in Languages with fewer digital resources. To address this challenge, this research proposes a deep learning-based system for the automatic classification of Myanmar poetry into five distinct genres. A Myanmar Syllable Normalization (MSN) algorithm is developed to preprocess and standardize poetic text, followed by feature transformation using hash code conversion and rhyme-based binarization. A Bi-directional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM) model is then applied to capture sequential and stylistic patterns without extensive feature engineering. The proposed approach demonstrates promising results in recognizing rhythmic and structural nuances, contributing to computational analysis of Myanmar literature and cultural preservation.

title: Digital Application of Virtual Reality Technology Based on Cloud Computing in Film and Television Art
authors: Tao Zhang, Yiyang Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: Digital works not only provide more space for the display of film and television art, but also enhance its appeal and promote its dissemination. Cloud computing-based virtual reality (VR) technology has also had a profound impact on the creation and dissemination of film and television art. This paper attempts to explore the creation of digital works of film and television art from the perspective of VR technology in cloud computing. To this end, this paper conducts an in-depth analysis of VR technology in cloud computing. The research finds that the proposed method can improve the economic efficiency of the film and television art industry. Compared with conventional methods, the profit margins of Works 4 and 5 increased by 9.7% and 10.1%, respectively. Furthermore, the proposed method for film and television art digital content can reduce creation costs and improve the accuracy of dissemination, thereby furthering the development of film and television art and ultimately achieving a comprehensive digital upgrade of film and television art.

title: Guidelines for combining user preference and interaction experience to visualize the spatial imagination in virtual reality memory training
authors: Cancan Jin, Yanze Gao, Zirui Yu, Ningning Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Memory is an essential part of life. A comprehensive grasp of mnemonic techniques enables the application of effective memory strategies and will enhance educational and professional outcomes. The Method of Loci is widely recognized as an effective scientific mnemonic technique, though it has certain limitations due to its high demand for spatial imagination. In this paper, we conducted an exploratory comparative study (N = 36) to investigate the relationship between three mnemonic methods (i.e., Loci Booklet, Personal Adapted Loci, LociVR) and memory performance and experience. We recorded subjective ratings of user experience, measured times, test scores, and memory retention in this study. The quantitative and qualitative analyzes provide design directions for memory training based on mnemonic methods. We further identified the design goals from the preliminary investigation, and proposed key design features, as well as interactive mechanisms, through a participatory workshop (N = 28). Based on these findings, we derived a set of design implications. In future, the design of LociVR would be optimized and contribute to a more personalized and interactive experience for memory training.

title: Enhanced Thermal Management in High-Performance Computing: A Novel Cascaded Solid-Solid Phase Change Material Honeycomb Heat Sink Design
authors: Mayank Maroliya, Sandip K. Saha
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: This study presents an innovative approach to improving the thermal performance of solid-solid phase change material (SSPCM)-based honeycomb heat storage systems through the development of cascaded latent heat thermal energy storage (CLHTES) units. By strategically layering different SSPCMs within the honeycomb structure, the design optimizes heat transfer, reduces melting time, and enhances overall thermal efficiency. The enthalpy-porosity method is used for numerical analysis, focusing on the phase transition behavior within an insulated cavity containing two commercial organic SSPCMs, X30 and X40. These materials have phase transition temperatures of $28.65^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $40.85^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $39.00^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $51.91^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, respectively, making them ideal for thermal management in high-performance computing (HPC) systems. The cascaded configuration demonstrates a significant $\mathbf{3 1. 5 \%}$ increase in safe operational time over single SSPCM designs, along with an average enhancement ratio of 4.83. A parametric analysis identifies an optimal $3: 1$ ratio of X40 to X30 for maximizing operational time and phase transition uniformity. This cascaded SSPCM honeycomb design effectively balances heat transfer rates, offering enhanced thermal management solutions for high-density electronics, particularly in HPC applications. The findings underscore the potential of SSPCM-based systems to address critical thermal challenges in modern electronics.

title: Smart Farming System for Plant Disease Detection using Optimized Spectral Domain Reconstruction Graph Neural Network
authors: L. Febin Rani, Devi. T, N. Deepa
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The practice of cultivating the soil, growing crops and keeping livestock is referred to as farming. An essential component of a nation's economic growth is agriculture. Farming accounts for around 58 % of a nation's main source of income. Up until now, farmers have used traditional farming methods. These methods took a lot of time and were less productive since they were imprecise. By accurately identifying actions that taken at appropriate time, precise farming contributes to increased output. Precision farming includes forecasting the weather, evaluating the soil, suggesting crops to be grown, and figuring out how much fertilizer and pesticides are necessary. In this manuscript, Smart Farming System for Plant Disease Detection using Optimized Spectral Domain Reconstruction Graph Neural Network (SFS-PDD-SDRGNN) is proposed. Initially real time input data is gathered from IoT sensors. Then, input data is fed into preprocessing stage. In preprocessing, Regularized Bias aware Ensemble Kalman Filtering (RBAEKF) is utilized to remove noise and normalize data. After preprocessing, preprocessed data is fed to Spectral Domain Reconstruction Graph Neural Network (SDRGNN) for plant disease detection as fungal infection and nutrient deficiency. To enhance accuracy, the Arctic Tern Optimization Algorithm (ATOA) is utilized to optimize SDRGNN weight parameters and ensuring precise plant disease detection. The proposed SFS-PDD-SDRGNN method is executed in Python and evaluated utilizing performance metrics like accuracy, detection rate, recall, precision, computation time. The proposed method attains <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$23.41 \%, 25.29 \%$</tex> and 24.35 % higher accuracy; <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$25.41 \%, 24.29 \%$</tex> and 27.35 % higher precision; <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 3. 4 1 \%, ~} \mathbf{2 2. 2 9 \%}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 5. 3 5 \%}$</tex> higher recall when analyzed with existing techniques.

title: Development of High-Temperature Capable SemiAdditive Logic Gate Circuits on Copper-Clad Ceramic Substrates for Automotive Applications
authors: Aditya Amatya, Pradeep Lall, Ved Soni, Scott Miller
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: The need for innovative manufacturing techniques and materials for electronic circuits is growing quickly in automotive applications due to the increasing demand for high performance. The existing electronic packaging fails to meet the high-temperature requirements of modern automotive applications, which operate above $150^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. This extreme operating temperature degrades the performance of electronic circuits. It causes reliability issues over time which creates a need for circuit designs using new manufacturing techniques that can maintain its performance at even extreme temperatures condition. The major focus of this research is to develop and test high-performance logic gate circuits on copper-clad ceramic substrates using laser pattern manufacturing techniques. These circuits can withstand high-temperature conditions relevant to current automotive applications. This work will validate the reliability and operability of these circuits at high temperatures and focus on their integration with SiC devices in thermally enhanced additive packaging. The traditional methods do not fully utilize the advanced manufacturing techniques for electronic packaging. This work avoids these limitations by using copper-clad ceramic substrates that improve thermal conductivity and integration for high-temperature applications. Utilizing copper-clad ceramic substrates, three types of logic gates-NAND, NOR, and NOT-were fabricated, with three samples of each tested at room temperature $\left(23^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right), 125^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, and $\mathbf{1 7 5}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}} \mathbf{C}$. SiC MOSFETs were selected for their superior thermal stability, and SAC 305 was used as the interconnect material for component attachments. The circuits were designed and optimized using LTSpice simulations, fabricated through laser patterning techniques, and assessed for signal integrity and performance reliability. Results indicate that the circuits maintain operational stability across the temperature range, demonstrating the potential of copper-clad ceramic substrates and advanced manufacturing methods to meet the thermal and reliability demands of automotive applications.

title: Thermal management of stacked die power module
authors: Himel Barua, Shajjad Chowdhury, Pedro Ribeiro, Burak Ozpineci
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Stacked die in power electronics refers to a packaging approach where multiple semiconductor dies are vertically integrated or “stacked” in a single package. This technique aims to reduce the loop inductance and volume of power electronic systems but increases heat extraction challenges. Such die stacking technique introduces heat loading from one die to another and additional layers in between the devices increases effective thermal resistance. With highly resistive path between junction to case the traditional cooling systems will not be adequate to keep the device temperature within manufacturers recommended limits unless the device rating is significantly reduced. To overcome the thermal challenges, a novel stack design has been proposed along with cooling system that can match the thermal performance of the traditional packaging techniques with added benefit of low power loop inductance and high density. The proposed module performance is validated with a detailed finite element simulation platform.

title: Dynamic Multi-Task Spatio-Temporal Gated Graph Attention Network for Comprehensive Traffic Forecasting
authors: K. M. Monica, Manjunath. H N, Zahraa Alkhafajy, Rajavadhani Kuppan, Sanitha. P C
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: In recent years, systems of intelligent transportation have increasingly relied on advanced machine learning and deep learning models for accurate traffic forecasting, which is critical for urban mobility, and smart city development. Traditional work on Spatio-Temporal Gated Graph Attention Networks (STGGAN) has shown promising results. However, model faces challenges due to its dependence on a static graph structure, which cannot adapt to dynamic traffic variations, and its single-task focus on speed prediction. Therefore, a Dynamic Multi-Task Spatio-Temporal Gated Graph Attention Network (DM-STGGAN) is proposed. Initially, traffic datasets like California Performance Measurement System District 4 (PeMSD4) and PeMSD8 are preprocessed by cleaning missing values and deriving indicators of key traffic including flow, density, and average speed. Further, a Dynamic Graph Learner adaptively updates adjacency matrices using both road topology and real-time traffic correlations followed by node and edge feature representation. Then, temporal dependencies are captured using Gated Recurrent Units (GRUs), while edge-aware multihead attention with a gated mechanism models complex spatial dependencies. Furthermore, a multi-task output layer jointly predicts speed, flow, and density for comprehensive forecasting. Experimental results demonstrate that proposed DM-STGGAN achieves lower root mean square error (2.7 speed), mean absolute error (1.6 speed) and higher accuracy (98.4 %) respectively.

title: Application of Improved NSGA-II Algorithm in Low-Carbon Tourism Path Planning
authors: Ting Bu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: This paper proposes an improved non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm II (INSGA-II). Its core methods include: 1) Adaptive crossover and mutation strategy: This algorithm applies a path similarity feedback mechanism to dynamically adjust the crossover probability (Pc) and mutation probability (Pm). Increasing Pm for individuals with high similarity enhances diversity, while increasing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$P c$</tex> for individuals with low similarity accelerates convergence. 2) Dynamic crowding operator: This algorithm improves the crowding distance calculation, prioritizes sparse solution regions, and guides a uniform population distribution. 3) Elite strategy-integrated local search: After the non-dominated sorting algorithm, a simulated annealing algorithm (SA) is embedded to perturb the neighborhood of elite solutions and enhance local exploration capabilities. Compared to the classic NSGA-II and MOEA/D algorithms, the Pareto-optimal solution set obtained by INSGA-II reduces carbon emissions by an average of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5. 4 \%}$</tex> (compared to NSGA-II) and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2. 2 \%}$</tex> (compared to MOEA/D), and reduces the total path cost by $ 50 and $ 32, respectively.

title: cARdefender: a Mixed Reality Game for Vehicle Passengers
authors: Simone Spera, Otino Pio Santosuosso, Aurelio Sepe, Giuliana Vitiello, Andrea Antonio Cantone, Stephen Brewster
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: Mixed Reality is transforming the gaming landscape by merging the real and virtual worlds into immersive, interactive experiences. In this poster, we present cARdefender, a mixed reality game designed specifically for vehicle passengers. The design and development of mixed reality games in this context pose unique challenges, such as creating intuitive interfaces for limited environments, optimizing performance on mobile devices, and minimizing motion sickness. This poster outlines the design and implementation process of cARdefender, focusing on key aspects such as MR technology integration, game mechanics, and interaction design tailored for use inside vehicles. Our work offers insights into the development of MR applications for non-traditional gaming contexts and highlights the potential of MR to enhance the passenger travel experience through fun and engaging interaction.

title: Design, Parameterization and Experimental Validation of a Modular BMS Applied to Second-Life ZEBRA Batteries from EVs for Stationary Energy Storage Systems
authors: Anderson de Camargo Bortoluzzi, Diogo Marujo, Nathalie Danree Busti, Tales Gottlieb Jahn, Henrique Peron, Fernando Marcos De Oliveira
abstract: Sodium-nickel (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(\text{NaNiCl}_{2}\right)$</tex>, ZEBRA) batteries are promising for stationary energy storage in tropical regions due to their thermal stability and safe high-temperature operation. This work presents the design and experimental validation of a modular Battery Management System (BMS) for second-life ZEBRA batteries retired from electric vehicles. The proposed BMS includes string-level modularity, advanced thermal control, state-of-charge (SoC) estimation by Coulomb counting, hybrid state-of-health (SoH) assessment, and comprehensive fault protection. The system was integrated into a PV-grid hybrid bench operating in backup and self-consumption modes. Experimental results demonstrated 819 Wh delivered in backup mode (500 W load for 1 h 38 min) and 1424 Wh in self-consumption mode (average 442 W for 3 h 13 min). Despite reduced usable capacity compared to nominal ratings, these results confirm the technical feasibility of repurposing ZEBRA cells for lowto medium-power stationary applications, such as residential backup and microgrids. Preliminary analysis highlights the sustainability benefits of extending service life, reducing raw material demand and deferring recycling, while customized BMS solutions enable safe, efficient, and adaptive operation of secondlife sodium-nickel batteries. The system was developed by Itaipu Parquetec (GE.DT).

title: A streamlined multiplexed digital mRNA quantification platform with universal primers and limited fluorescence channels
authors: Joon Soo Park, Jiumei Hu, Liben Chen, Tza-Huei Wang
abstract: Multiplexed RNA quantification is a crucial tool in various biological fields, but current PCR-based methods often face challenges in primer design, amplification bias, and limited fluorescence labels for multiplexing. Here, we introduce Fluorescence-coding extension PCR (FlexPCR), a novel digital PCR-based assay that overcomes these limitations by employing a simple universal primer and probe strategy. FlexPCR leverages oligo extensions to generate distinct fluorescence-coded PCR template for multiple RNA targets, enabling multiplexed amplification detection using universal primers and probes with a limited number of fluorescence colors. Subsequent digital detection allows accurate decoding and quantification of individual targets, eliminating the issue of mixed signals common in bulk assays. We demonstrate FlexPCR by developing a two-color-based assay for quantification of seven host-response mRNA biomarkers in various human total RNA samples. The assay accuracy is confirmed through comparison with the gold-standard single-plex RT-qPCR method. FlexPCR offers a streamlined approach to multiplexed RNA quantification, simplifying assay design and broadening its potential applications in gene expression analysis and beyond.

title: Optimal contact angle for dropwise condensation
authors: Tomasz K. Kułakowski, Yimin Zhou, Grzegorz Celichowski, Maciej Psarski, Solomon Adera
publish: 2025 24th IEEE Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm)
abstract: Dropwise condensation is renowned for its superior heat transfer efficiency compared to the more common filmwise regime. Despite extensive research over the years, a comprehensive understanding of this phenomenon remains elusive, limiting its industrial application. In this study, we experimentally investigate analytical predictions suggesting the existence of an optimal contact angle and challenge the common assumption that increasing hydrophobicity will invariably enhance heat transfer performance. By creating self-assembled monolayers of thiols on gold-coated surfaces, we systematically examined contact angles ranging from 84° to 115°. Experiments conducted in a temperature and pressure controlled climatic chamber provided strong evidence for an optimal contact angle between 96° and 105°. These findings not only support analytical models but also represent a paradigm shift in the design and optimization of condenser surface coatings. The insights gained from this research hold significant implications for industries such as power generation, chemical processing, liquid separation, desalination, and thermal management, while also expanding our understanding of this intriguing process.

title: Enhancing Cyber Threat Detection with Generative Adversarial Networks and Anomaly Detection Techniques
authors: Ajit Baral, Bijay Kumar Paikaray, Sumati Baral
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Circuits, Power and Intelligent Systems (CCPIS)
abstract: The escalating complexity of cyber threats demands advanced solutions capable of detecting both known and novel attack patterns. This study presents a novel framework that synergistically integrates Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) with machine learning-based anomaly detection to enhance threat identification. The proposed TS-GAN (Threat Simulation GAN) generates realistic synthetic attack data, addressing dataset scarcity and diversity limitations inherent in traditional cybersecurity systems. Coupled with an Isolation Forest anomaly detection module, the framework identifies deviations from established network behavior baselines, enabling robust detection of sophisticated and zero-day threats. Experimental results demonstrate a 25% anomaly detection rate in combined real-synthetic data, with 97% of alerts classified as high severity. The system processes 48,000 samples in under 80 seconds while maintaining ε-differential privacy (ε=1.0) through a dedicated Privacy-Preserving Data Synthesizer. This work advances adaptive cyber defence mechanisms by combining generative AI with real-time anomaly analysis, offering a 19% improvement in detection accuracy over existing methods while ensuring secure data sharing capabilities.

title: Behavior Metric for Evaluating the Impact of Visual Distortions on User Viewport in a VR Navigation Experience
authors: Yujie Huang, Pierre Lebreton, Alexandre Bruckert, Patrick Le Callet
publish: 2025 13th European Workshop on Visual Information Processing (EUVIP)
abstract: Visual distortions significantly impact user experience in virtual reality (VR). Understanding these effects is essential for delivering a higher-quality VR experience. However, existing studies focus on distortions from image capturing, processing, or display, relying largely on self-reported scores. The impact of visual distortions on viewport caused by simulated visual impairments in VR remains underexplored, despite its importance in creating realistic VR experiences, raising public awareness, and studying the effects of visual impairment. This study proposes a Hidden Markov Model (HMM)-based behavior entropy metric to measure the effects of visual distortions on a user's viewport in a 6-Degrees-of-Freedom (DoF) VR navigation experience. An Orientation and Mobility (O&M) VR scenario designed to assess the navigation performance of visually impaired individuals was used for the experiment. Results reveal a relationship between behavior entropy and distortion severity: slight to moderate distortions reduce entropy, while severe distortions cause a significant decline. Additionally, behavior entropy correlates with O&M test performance metrics, indicating its potential as an objective behavioral measure of VR navigation performance. These findings highlight the value of behavior analysis in evaluating VR user experience, offering a new analytical perspective on visual distortion effects and expanding applications of behavior analysis in multidisciplinary research.

title: Cryogenic Operation of a 1200V/300A IGBT Module: Static and Dynamic Experimental Characterization
authors: Mateus Caruso, Marília M. A. N. e Silva, Alexandre A. Bitencourt, Guilherme G. Sotelo, Bruno W. França
abstract: The performance of power semiconductor devices at cryogenic temperatures has gained increasing attention due to potential benefits in efficiency, thermal control, and power density. This paper investigates the static and dynamic behavior of a commercial 2-pack IGBT module (X2G300SD12P3-1200 V <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$/ 300$</tex> A) at room temperature and at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-196{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> (liquid nitrogen). Three configurations were analyzed: the standard encapsulated module at room temperature, the open chip without gel at room temperature, and the open chip without gel at cryogenic temperature. Experimental results reveal that at cryogenic temperature the initial voltage drop increases from 0.6 V to 1.1 V, and the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$I_{C}-V_{C E}$</tex> curve no longer reaches a linear region, exhibiting a variable on-resistance. In terms of switching behavior, the turnon transient is strongly affected, with higher <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$d v / d t$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$d i / d t$</tex>, an increased <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{C E}$</tex> overvoltage (813 V compared to 633 V at room temperature), and a collector current tail nearly twice as large. These findings highlight the significant impact of extreme temperature reduction on IGBT operation and provide valuable insight for benchmarking against other devices for cryogenic power electronic systems.

title: Tourism Economic Development Trend Prediction Algorithm Based on XGBOOST
authors: Hong Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Communication Networks and Computational Techniques (ICICNCT)
abstract: The development of cross-border tourism cooperation zones, particularly in Mengla County-a key node under China's “Belt and Road” initiative-requires accurate tourism economy forecasting to support regional planning and policy-making. This study employs the XGBoost algorithm to construct a predictive model integrating multi-dimensional data, including tourist flow, consumption levels, and infrastructure. Feature engineering and time-series sliding windows are applied to enhance model performance. The XGBoost model achieved an MSE of 15.23, RMSE of 3.91, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 8 9}$</tex>, outperforming linear and decision tree regression models. It effectively captured seasonal variations and nonlinear relationships, demonstrating high predictive accuracy and robustness. The XGBoost-based model offers a scientifically-grounded tool for forecasting tourism economic trends in cross-border regions. Future work should incorporate broader data sources and improve adaptability to dynamic policy and environmental changes.

title: Embracing "Lost Tracking" Events: Exploring Design Considerations for Embodied Virtual Pets in Extended Reality
authors: Jih-Hsuan Peng, Kuan-Ning Chang, Jung Shen, Chieh-Hsin Liu, Meng-Wei Lu, Ping-Hsuan Han
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Mixed and Augmented Reality Adjunct (ISMAR-Adjunct)
abstract: This study explores how tracking loss, an issue frequently encountered in Extended Reality (XR), can be reframed as a form of interactional uncertainty that mirrors real world experiences with animals, thereby enhancing user experiences with embodied virtual pets (EVPs). A user study (N = 17) was conducted, documenting participants’ free form interactions with an EVP system and analyzing both quantitative questionnaire data and qualitative interview responses. Results indicate that participants primarily detected tracking errors through unexpected anomalies in the EVP’s behavior; however, the number of instances they reported was significantly lower than those recorded by observers and the system. Users’ reactions to tracking loss whether through active attempts to reengage or passive waiting together with their feedback on the overall interaction process, revealed a consistent expectation that EVPs should demonstrate more autonomous and life-like behaviors. These findings offer valuable insights and design implications for transforming system errors into expressions of lifelikeness in the development of EVP interactions within XR environments.
